The Lord High Chancellor, at his (Chancellor) best, appeared so poor a substitute for the love and pride of parents.

``The Jarndyce in question,'' (Lord)
said the Lord Chancellor, still turning over leaves,
``is Jarndyce of Bleak House.'' (the Lord Chancellor)

``Jarndyce of Bleak House, my lord,'' (Mr. Kenge)
said Mr. Kenge.

``A dreary name,'' (Lord Chancellor)
said the Lord Chancellor.

``But not a dreary place at present, my lord,'' (Mr. Kenge)
said Mr. Kenge.

``And Bleak House,'' (lordship)
said his (Kenge) lordship,
``is in--'' (lordship)

``Hertfordshire, my lord.'' (lordship)

``Mr. Jarndyce of Bleak House is not married?'' (lordship)
said his (Kenge) lordship.

``He (Jarndyce) is not, my lord,'' (Mr. Kenge)
said Mr. Kenge.

A pause.

``Young Mr. Richard Carstone is present?'' (Lord)
said the Lord Chancellor, glancing towards him (Chancellor).

Richard bowed and stepped forward.

``Hum!'' (Lord)
said the Lord Chancellor, turning over more leaves.

``Mr. Jarndyce of Bleak House, my lord,'' (Mr. Kenge)
Mr. Kenge observed in a low voice,
``if I may venture to remind your lordship, provides a suitable companion for--'' (Mr. Kenge)

``For Mr. Richard Carstone?'' (Mr. Kenge)
I thought -LRB-but I am not quite sure-RRB- I heard his (Kenge) lordship say in an equally low voice and with a smile.

``For Miss Ada Clare. This is the young lady. Miss Summerson.'' (lordship)

His (lordship) lordship gave me an indulgent look and acknowledged my curtsy very graciously.

``Miss Summerson is not related to any party in the cause, I think?'' (unknown)

``No, my lord.'' (Mr. Kenge)

Mr. Kenge leant over before it was quite said and whispered. His (Kenge) lordship, with his (lordship) eyes upon his (lordship) papers, listened, nodded twice or thrice, turned over more leaves, and did not look towards me again until we were going away.

Mr. Kenge now retired, and Richard with him (Richard), to where I was, near the door, leaving my pet -LRB-it is so natural to me that again I can't help it!-RRB- sitting near the Lord Chancellor, with whom his (Lord) lordship spoke a little part, asking her (my), as she (my) told me afterwards, whether she (my) had well reflected on the proposed arrangement, and if she (my) thought she (my) would be happy under the roof of Mr. Jarndyce of Bleak House, and why she (my) thought so? Presently he (Jarndyce) rose courteously and released her (my), and then he (Jarndyce) spoke for a minute or two with Richard Carstone, not seated, but standing, and altogether with more ease and less ceremony, as if he (Carstone) still knew, though he (Carstone) WAS Lord Chancellor, how to go straight to the candour of a boy.

``Very well!'' (lordship)
said his (Lord) lordship aloud.
``I shall make the order. Mr. Jarndyce of Bleak House has chosen, so far as I may judge,'' (he)
and this was when he (lordship) looked at me,
``a very good companion for the young lady, and the arrangement altogether seems the best of which the circumstances admit.'' (me)

He (lordship) dismissed us pleasantly, and we all went out, very much obliged to him (lordship) for being so affable and polite, by which he (lordship) had certainly lost no dignity but seemed to us to have gained some.

When we got under the colonnade, Mr. Kenge remembered that he (Kenge) must go back for a moment to ask a question and left us in the fog, with the Lord Chancellor's carriage and servants waiting for him (Lord) to come out.

``Well!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard Carstone.
``THAT'S over! And where do we go next, Miss Summerson?'' (unknown)

``Don't you know?'' (I)
I said.

``Not in the least,'' (he)
said he (Carstone).

``And don't YOU know, my love?'' (I)
I asked Ada.

``No!'' (she)
said she (Ada).
``Don't you?'' (unknown)

``Not at all!'' (I)
said I.

We looked at one another, half laughing at our being like the children in the wood, when a curious little old woman in a squeezed bonnet and carrying a reticule came curtsying and smiling up to us with an air of great ceremony.

``Oh!'' (she)
said she (woman).
``The wards in Jarndyce! Ve-ry happy, I am sure, to have the honour! It is a good omen for youth, and hope, and beauty when they find themselves in this place, and don't know what's to come of it.'' (unknown)

``Mad!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
whispered Richard, not thinking she (woman) could hear him (Richard).

``Right! Mad, young gentleman,'' (she)
she (woman) returned so quickly that he (Richard) was quite abashed.
``I was a ward myself. I was not mad at that time,'' (unknown)
curtsying low and smiling between every little sentence.
``I had youth and hope. I believe, beauty. It matters very little now. Neither of the three served or saved me. I have the honour to attend court regularly. With my documents. I expect a judgment. Shortly. On the Day of Judgment. I have discovered that the sixth seal mentioned in the Revelations is the Great Seal. It has been open a long time! Pray accept my blessing.'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)

As Ada was a little frightened, I said, to humour the poor old lady, that we were much obliged to her (lady).

``Ye-es!'' (she)
she (lady) said mincingly.
``I imagine so. And here is Conversation Kenge. With HIS (my) documents! How does your honourable worship do?'' (unknown)

``Quite well, quite well! Now don't be troublesome, that's a good soul!'' (Mr. Kenge)
said Mr. Kenge, leading the way back.

``By no means,'' (the lady)
said the poor old lady, keeping up with Ada and me.
``Anything but troublesome. I shall confer estates on both--which is not being troublesome, I trust? I expect a judgment. Shortly. On the Day of Judgment. This is a good omen for you. Accept my blessing!'' (She)

She (Ada) stopped at the bottom of the steep, broad flight of stairs; but we looked back as we went up, and she (Ada) was still there, saying, still with a curtsy and a smile between every little sentence,

``Youth. And hope. And beauty. And Chancery. And Conversation Kenge! Ha! Pray accept my blessing!'' (she)

CHAPTER IV

Telescopic Philanthropy

We were to pass the night, Mr. Kenge told us when we arrived in his (Kenge) room, at Mrs. Jellyby's; and then he (Kenge) turned to me and said he (Kenge) took it for granted I knew who Mrs. Jellyby was.

``I really don't, sir,'' (I)
I returned.
``Perhaps Mr. Carstone--or Miss Clare--'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)

But no, they knew nothing whatever about Mrs. Jellyby.

``In-deed! Mrs. Jellyby,'' (Mr. Kenge)
said Mr. Kenge, standing with his (Kenge) back to the fire and casting his (Kenge) eyes over the dusty hearth-rug as if it were Mrs. Jellyby's biography,
``is a lady of very remarkable strength of character who devotes herself entirely to the public. She (Jellyby) has devoted herself to an extensive variety of public subjects at various times and is at present -LRB-until something else attracts her (Jellyby)-RRB- devoted to the subject of Africa, with a view to the general cultivation of the coffee berry--AND the natives--and the happy settlement, on the banks of the African rivers, of our superabundant home population. Mr. Jarndyce, who is desirous to aid any work that is considered likely to be a good work and who is much sought after by philanthropists, has, I believe, a very high opinion of Mrs. Jellyby.'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)

Mr. Kenge, adjusting his (Kenge) cravat, then looked at us.

``And Mr. Jellyby, sir?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
suggested Richard.

``Ah! Mr. Jellyby,'' (Mr. Kenge)
said Mr. Kenge,
``is--a--I don't know that I can describe him (Jellyby) to you better than by saying that he (Jellyby) is the husband of Mrs. Jellyby.'' (Mr. Kenge)

``A nonentity, sir?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard with a droll look.

``I don't say that,'' (Mr. Kenge)
returned Mr. Kenge gravely.
``I can't say that, indeed, for I know nothing whatever OF Mr. Jellyby. I never, to my knowledge, had the pleasure of seeing Mr. Jellyby. He (Jellyby) may be a very superior man, but he (Jellyby) is, so to speak, merged--merged--in the more shining qualities of his (Jellyby) wife.'' (Mr. Kenge)
Mr. Kenge proceeded to tell us that as the road to Bleak House would have been very long, dark, and tedious on such an evening, and as we had been travelling already, Mr. Jarndyce had himself proposed this arrangement. A carriage would be at Mrs. Jellyby's to convey us out of town early in the forenoon of to-morrow.

He (Jarndyce) then rang a little bell, and the young gentleman came in. Addressing him (gentleman) by the name of Guppy, Mr. Kenge inquired whether Miss Summerson's boxes and the rest of the baggage had been

``sent round.'' (Esther/Miss Summerson/Esther Summerson)
Mr. Guppy said yes, they had been sent round, and a coach was waiting to take us round too as soon as we pleased.

``Then it only remains,'' (Mr. Kenge)
said Mr. Kenge, shaking hands with us,
``for me to express my lively satisfaction in -LRB-good day, Miss Clare!-RRB- the arrangement this day concluded and my -LRB-GOOD-bye to you, Miss Summerson!-RRB- lively hope that it will conduce to the happiness, the -LRB-glad to have had the honour of making your acquaintance, Mr. Carstone!-RRB- welfare, the advantage in all points of view, of all concerned! Guppy, see the party safely there.'' (Mr. Kenge)

``Where IS ``there,

'' Mr. Guppy?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard as we went downstairs.

``No distance,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
said Mr. Guppy;
``round in Thavies Inn, you know.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``I can't say I know where it is, for I come from Winchester and am strange in London.'' (unknown)

``Only round the corner,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
said Mr. Guppy.
``We just twist up Chancery Lane, and cut along Holborn, and there we are in four minutes' time, as near as a toucher. This is about a London particular NOW, ain't it, miss?'' (He)
He (Guppy) seemed quite delighted with it on my account.

``The fog is very dense indeed!'' (I.)
said I.

``Not that it affects you, though, I'm sure,'' (I.)
said Mr. Guppy, putting up the steps.
``On the contrary, it seems to do you good, miss, judging from your appearance.'' (I)

I knew he (Guppy) meant well in paying me this compliment, so I laughed at myself for blushing at it when he (Guppy) had shut the door and got upon the box; and we all three laughed and chatted about our inexperience and the strangeness of London until we turned up under an archway to our destination--a narrow street of high houses like an oblong cistern to hold the fog. There was a confused little crowd of people, principally children, gathered about the house at which we stopped, which had a tarnished brass plate on the door with the inscription JELLYBY.

``Don't be frightened!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
said Mr. Guppy, looking in at the coach-window.
``One of the young Jellybys been and got his (We) head through the area railings!'' (unknown)

``Oh, poor child,'' (I)
said I;
``let me out, if you please!'' (I)

``Pray be careful of yourself, miss. The young Jellybys are always up to something,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
said Mr. Guppy.

I made my way to the poor child, who was one of the dirtiest little unfortunates I ever saw, and found him (Guppy) very hot and frightened and crying loudly, fixed by the neck between two iron railings, while a milkman and a beadle, with the kindest intentions possible, were endeavouring to drag him (milkman) back by the legs, under a general impression that his (milkman) skull was compressible by those means. As I found -LRB-after pacifying him (milkman)-RRB- that he (milkman) was a little boy with a naturally large head, I thought that perhaps where his (milkman) head could go, his (milkman) body could follow, and mentioned that the best mode of extrication might be to push him (milkman) forward. This was so favourably received by the milkman and beadle that he (beadle) would immediately have been pushed into the area if I had not held his (beadle) pinafore while Richard and Mr. Guppy ran down through the kitchen to catch him (Guppy) when he (Guppy) should be released. At last he (Guppy) was happily got down without any accident, and then he (Guppy) began to beat Mr. Guppy with a hoop-stick in quite a frantic manner.

Nobody had appeared belonging to the house except a person in pattens, who had been poking at the child from below with a broom; I don't know with what object, and I don't think she (I) did. I therefore supposed that Mrs. Jellyby was not at home, and was quite surprised when the person appeared in the passage without the pattens, and going up to the back room on the first floor before Ada and me, announced us as,

``Them two young ladies, Missis Jellyby!'' (me)
We passed several more children on the way up, whom it was difficult to avoid treading on in the dark; and as we came into Mrs. Jellyby's presence, one of the poor little things fell downstairs--down a whole flight -LRB-as it sounded to me-RRB-, with a great noise.

Mrs. Jellyby, whose face reflected none of the uneasiness which we could not help showing in our own faces as the dear child's head recorded its passage with a bump on every stair--Richard afterwards said he (Richard) counted seven, besides one for the landing--received us with perfect equanimity. She (Jellyby) was a pretty, very diminutive, plump woman of from forty to fifty, with handsome eyes, though they had a curious habit of seeming to look a long way off. As if--I am quoting Richard again--they could see nothing nearer than Africa!

``I am very glad indeed,'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)
said Mrs. Jellyby in an agreeable voice,
``to have the pleasure of receiving you. I have a great respect for Mr. Jarndyce, and no one in whom he (Jarndyce) is interested can be an object of indifference to me.'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)

We expressed our acknowledgments and sat down behind the door, where there was a lame invalid of a sofa. Mrs. Jellyby had very good hair but was too much occupied with her (Jellyby) African duties to brush it. The shawl in which she (Jellyby) had been loosely muffled dropped onto her (Jellyby) chair when she (Jellyby) advanced to us; and as she (Jellyby) turned to resume her (Jellyby) seat, we could not help noticing that her (Jellyby) dress didn't nearly meet up the back and that the open space was railed across with a lattice-work of stay-lace--like a summer-house.

The room, which was strewn with papers and nearly filled by a great writing-table covered with similar litter, was, I must say, not only very untidy but very dirty. We were obliged to take notice of that with our sense of sight, even while, with our sense of hearing, we followed the poor child who had tumbled downstairs: I think into the back kitchen, where somebody seemed to stifle him (I).

But what principally struck us was a jaded and unhealthy-looking though by no means plain girl at the writing-table, who sat biting the feather of her (girl) pen and staring at us. I suppose nobody ever was in such a state of ink. And from her (girl) tumbled hair to her (girl) pretty feet, which were disfigured with frayed and broken satin slippers trodden down at heel, she (girl) really seemed to have no article of dress upon her (girl), from a pin upwards, that was in its proper condition or its right place.

``You find me, my dears,'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)
said Mrs. Jellyby, snuffing the two great office candles in tin candlesticks, which made the room taste strongly of hot tallow -LRB-the fire had gone out, and there was nothing in the grate but ashes, a bundle of wood, and a poker-RRB-,
``you find me, my dears, as usual, very busy; but that you will excuse. The African project at present employs my whole time. It involves me in correspondence with public bodies and with private individuals anxious for the welfare of their species all over the country. I am happy to say it is advancing. We hope by this time next year to have from a hundred and fifty to two hundred healthy families cultivating coffee and educating the natives of Borrioboola-Gha, on the left bank of the Niger.'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)

As Ada said nothing, but looked at me, I said it must be very gratifying.

``It IS gratifying,'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)
said Mrs. Jellyby.
``It involves the devotion of all my energies, such as they are; but that is nothing, so that it succeeds; and I am more confident of success every day. Do you know, Miss Summerson, I almost wonder that YOU never turned your thoughts to Africa.'' (me)

This application of the subject was really so unexpected to me that I was quite at a loss how to receive it. I hinted that the climate--

``The finest climate in the world!'' (I)
said Mrs. Jellyby.

``Indeed, ma'am?'' (unknown)

``Certainly. With precaution,'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)
said Mrs. Jellyby.
``You may go into Holborn, without precaution, and be run over. You may go into Holborn, with precaution, and never be run over. Just so with Africa.'' (I)

I said,

``No doubt.'' (I)
I meant as to Holborn.

``If you would like,'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)
said Mrs. Jellyby, putting a number of papers towards us,
``to look over some remarks on that head, and on the general subject, which have been extensively circulated, while I finish a letter I am now dictating to my eldest daughter, who is my amanuensis--'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)

The girl at the table left off biting her (Jellyby) pen and made a return to our recognition, which was half bashful and half sulky.

''--I shall then have finished for the present,'' (The girl)
proceeded Mrs. Jellyby with a sweet smile,
``though my work is never done. Where are you, Caddy?'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)

''`Presents her (Jellyby) compliments to Mr. Swallow, and begs--''' (unknown)
said Caddy.

''`And begs,''' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)
said Mrs. Jellyby, dictating,
''`to inform him (Swallow), in reference to his (Swallow) letter of inquiry on the African project--' No, Peepy! Not on my account!'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)

Peepy -LRB-so self-named-RRB- was the unfortunate child who had fallen downstairs, who now interrupted the correspondence by presenting himself, with a strip of plaster on his (Swallow) forehead, to exhibit his (Swallow) wounded knees, in which Ada and I did not know which to pity most--the bruises or the dirt. Mrs. Jellyby merely added, with the serene composure with which she (Jellyby) said everything,

``Go along, you naughty Peepy!'' (she)
and fixed her (Jellyby) fine eyes on Africa again.

However, as she (Jellyby) at once proceeded with her (Jellyby) dictation, and as I interrupted nothing by doing it, I ventured quietly to stop poor Peepy as he (Swallow) was going out and to take him (Swallow) up to nurse. He (Swallow) looked very much astonished at it and at Ada's kissing him (Swallow), but soon fell fast asleep in my arms, sobbing at longer and longer intervals, until he (Swallow) was quiet. I was so occupied with Peepy that I lost the letter in detail, though I derived such a general impression from it of the momentous importance of Africa, and the utter insignificance of all other places and things, that I felt quite ashamed to have thought so little about it.

``Six o'clock!'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)
said Mrs. Jellyby.
``And our dinner hour is nominally -LRB-for we dine at all hours-RRB- five! Caddy, show Miss Clare and Miss Summerson their rooms. You will like to make some change, perhaps? You will excuse me, I know, being so much occupied. Oh, that very bad child! Pray put him (we) down, Miss Summerson!'' (I)

I begged permission to retain him (Swallow), truly saying that he (Swallow) was not at all troublesome, and carried him (Swallow) upstairs and laid him (Swallow) on my bed. Ada and I had two upper rooms with a door of communication between. They were excessively bare and disorderly, and the curtain to my window was fastened up with a fork.

``You would like some hot water, wouldn't you?'' (Miss Jellyby)
said Miss Jellyby, looking round for a jug with a handle to it, but looking in vain.

``If it is not being troublesome,'' (unknown)
said we.

``Oh, it's not the trouble,'' (Miss Jellyby)
returned Miss Jellyby;
``the question is, if there IS any.'' (Miss Jellyby)

The evening was so very cold and the rooms had such a marshy smell that I must confess it was a little miserable, and Ada was half crying. We soon laughed, however, and were busily unpacking when Miss Jellyby came back to say that she (Jellyby) was sorry there was no hot water, but they couldn't find the kettle, and the boiler was out of order.

We begged her (Jellyby) not to mention it and made all the haste we could to get down to the fire again. But all the little children had come up to the landing outside to look at the phenomenon of Peepy lying on my bed, and our attention was distracted by the constant apparition of noses and fingers in situations of danger between the hinges of the doors. It was impossible to shut the door of either room, for my lock, with no knob to it, looked as if it wanted to be wound up; and though the handle of Ada's went round and round with the greatest smoothness, it was attended with no effect whatever on the door. Therefore I proposed to the children that they should come in and be very good at my table, and I would tell them the story of Little Red Riding Hood while I dressed; which they did, and were as quiet as mice, including Peepy, who awoke opportunely before the appearance of the wolf.

When we went downstairs we found a mug with

``A Present from Tunbridge Wells'' (a woman)
on it lighted up in the staircase window with a floating wick, and a young woman, with a swelled face bound up in a flannel bandage blowing the fire of the drawing-room -LRB-now connected by an open door with Mrs. Jellyby's room-RRB- and choking dreadfully. It smoked to that degree, in short, that we all sat coughing and crying with the windows open for half an hour, during which Mrs. Jellyby, with the same sweetness of temper, directed letters about Africa. Her (Jellyby) being so employed was, I must say, a great relief to me, for Richard told us that he (Richard) had washed his (Richard) hands in a pie-dish and that they had found the kettle on his (Richard) dressing-table, and he (Richard) made Ada laugh so that they made me laugh in the most ridiculous manner.

Soon after seven o'clock we went down to dinner, carefully, by Mrs. Jellyby's advice, for the stair-carpets, besides being very deficient in stair-wires, were so torn as to be absolute traps. We had a fine cod-fish, a piece of roast beef, a dish of cutlets, and a pudding; an excellent dinner, if it had had any cooking to speak of, but it was almost raw. The young woman with the flannel bandage waited, and dropped everything on the table wherever it happened to go, and never moved it again until she (woman) put it on the stairs. The person I had seen in pattens, who I suppose to have been the cook, frequently came and skirmished with her (woman) at the door, and there appeared to be ill will between them.

All through dinner--which was long, in consequence of such accidents as the dish of potatoes being mislaid in the coal skuttle and the handle of the corkscrew coming off and striking the young woman in the chin--Mrs. Jellyby preserved the evenness of her (Jellyby) disposition. She (Jellyby) told us a great deal that was interesting about Borrioboola-Gha and the natives, and received so many letters that Richard, who sat by her (Jellyby), saw four envelopes in the gravy at once. Some of the letters were proceedings of ladies' committees or resolutions of ladies' meetings, which she (Jellyby) read to us; others were applications from people excited in various ways about the cultivation of coffee, and natives; others required answers, and these she (Jellyby) sent her (Jellyby) eldest daughter from the table three or four times to write. She (Jellyby) was full of business and undoubtedly was, as she (Jellyby) had told us, devoted to the cause.

I was a little curious to know who a mild bald gentleman in spectacles was, who dropped into a vacant chair -LRB-there was no top or bottom in particular-RRB- after the fish was taken away and seemed passively to submit himself to Borrioboola-Gha but not to be actively interested in that settlement. As he (gentleman) never spoke a word, he (gentleman) might have been a native but for his (gentleman) complexion. It was not until we left the table and he (gentleman) remained alone with Richard that the possibility of his (Richard) being Mr. Jellyby ever entered my head. But he (Jellyby) WAS Mr. Jellyby; and a loquacious young man called Mr. Quale, with large shining knobs for temples and his (Quale) hair all brushed to the back of his (Quale) head, who came in the evening, and told Ada he (Quale) was a philanthropist, also informed her (Ada) that he (Quale) called the matrimonial alliance of Mrs. Jellyby with Mr. Jellyby the union of mind and matter.

This young man, besides having a great deal to say for himself about Africa and a project of his (Jellyby) for teaching the coffee colonists to teach the natives to turn piano-forte legs and establish an export trade, delighted in drawing Mrs. Jellyby out by saying,

``I believe now, Mrs. Jellyby, you have received as many as from one hundred and fifty to two hundred letters respecting Africa in a single day, have you not?'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)
or,
``If my memory does not deceive me, Mrs. Jellyby, you once mentioned that you had sent off five thousand circulars from one post-office at one time?'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)
--always repeating Mrs. Jellyby's answer to us like an interpreter. During the whole evening, Mr. Jellyby sat in a corner with his (Jellyby) head against the wall as if he (Jellyby) were subject to low spirits. It seemed that he (Jellyby) had several times opened his (Jellyby) mouth when alone with Richard after dinner, as if he (Richard) had something on his (Richard) mind, but had always shut it again, to Richard's extreme confusion, without saying anything.

Mrs. Jellyby, sitting in quite a nest of waste paper, drank coffee all the evening and dictated at intervals to her (Jellyby) eldest daughter. She (Jellyby) also held a discussion with Mr. Quale, of which the subject seemed to be--if I understood it--the brotherhood of humanity, and gave utterance to some beautiful sentiments. I was not so attentive an auditor as I might have wished to be, however, for Peepy and the other children came flocking about Ada and me in a corner of the drawing-room to ask for another story; so we sat down among them and told them in whispers

``Puss in Boots'' (me)
and I don't know what else until Mrs. Jellyby, accidentally remembering them, sent them to bed. As Peepy cried for me to take him (auditor) to bed, I carried him (auditor) upstairs, where the young woman with the flannel bandage charged into the midst of the little family like a dragon and overturned them into cribs.

After that I occupied myself in making our room a little tidy and in coaxing a very cross fire that had been lighted to burn, which at last it did, quite brightly. On my return downstairs, I felt that Mrs. Jellyby looked down upon me rather for being so frivolous, and I was sorry for it, though at the same time I knew that I had no higher pretensions.

It was nearly midnight before we found an opportunity of going to bed, and even then we left Mrs. Jellyby among her (Jellyby) papers drinking coffee and Miss Jellyby biting the feather of her (Jellyby) pen.

``What a strange house!'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)
said Ada when we got upstairs.
``How curious of my cousin Jarndyce to send us here!'' (unknown)

``My love,'' (I)
said I,
``it quite confuses me. I want to understand it, and I can't understand it at all.'' (I)

``What?'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)
asked Ada with her (Ada) pretty smile.

``All this, my dear,'' (I.)
said I.
``It MUST be very good of Mrs. Jellyby to take such pains about a scheme for the benefit of natives--and yet--Peepy and the housekeeping!'' (I.)

Ada laughed and put her (Ada) arm about my neck as I stood looking at the fire, and told me I was a quiet, dear, good creature and had won her (Ada) heart.

``You are so thoughtful, Esther,'' (she)
she (Ada) said,
``and yet so cheerful! And you do so much, so unpretendingly! You would make a home out of even this house.'' (she)

My simple darling! She (Ada) was quite unconscious that she (Ada) only praised herself and that it was in the goodness of her (Ada) own heart that she (Ada) made so much of me!

``May I ask you a question?'' (I)
said I when we had sat before the fire a little while.

``Five hundred,'' (Ada)
said Ada.

``Your cousin, Mr. Jarndyce. I owe so much to him (Jarndyce). Would you mind describing him (Jarndyce) to me?'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)

Shaking her (Ada) golden hair, Ada turned her (Ada) eyes upon me with such laughing wonder that I was full of wonder too, partly at her (Ada) beauty, partly at her (Ada) surprise.

``Esther!'' (she)
she (Ada) cried.

``My dear!'' (unknown)

``You want a description of my cousin Jarndyce?'' (unknown)

``My dear, I never saw him (Jarndyce).'' (unknown)

``And I never saw him (Jarndyce)!'' (Ada)
returned Ada.

Well, to be sure!

No, she (Ada) had never seen him (it). Young as she (Ada) was when her (Ada) mama died, she (Ada) remembered how the tears would come into her (Ada) eyes when she (Ada) spoke of him (Young) and of the noble generosity of his (Young) character, which she (Ada) had said was to be trusted above all earthly things; and Ada trusted it. Her (Ada) cousin Jarndyce had written to her (Ada) a few months ago--

``a plain, honest letter,'' (Jarndyce/Fitz Jarndyce)
Ada said--proposing the arrangement we were now to enter on and telling her (Ada) that
``in time it might heal some of the wounds made by the miserable Chancery suit.'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)
She (Ada) had replied, gratefully accepting his (Jarndyce) proposal. Richard had received a similar letter and had made a similar response. He (Richard) HAD seen Mr. Jarndyce once, but only once, five years ago, at Winchester school. He (Jarndyce) had told Ada, when they were leaning on the screen before the fire where I found them, that he (Jarndyce) recollected him (Jarndyce) as
``a bluff, rosy fellow.'' (him)
This was the utmost description Ada could give me.

It set me thinking so that when Ada was asleep, I still remained before the fire, wondering and wondering about Bleak House, and wondering and wondering that yesterday morning should seem so long ago. I don't know where my thoughts had wandered when they were recalled by a tap at the door.

I opened it softly and found Miss Jellyby shivering there with a broken candle in a broken candlestick in one hand and an egg-cup in the other.

``Good night!'' (she)
she (Jellyby) said very sulkily.

``Good night!'' (I.)
said I.

``May I come in?'' (I.)
she (Jellyby) shortly and unexpectedly asked me in the same sulky way.

``Certainly,'' (I.)
said I.
``Don't wake Miss Clare.'' (I.)

She (Jellyby) would not sit down, but stood by the fire dipping her (Jellyby) inky middle finger in the egg-cup, which contained vinegar, and smearing it over the ink stains on her (Jellyby) face, frowning the whole time and looking very gloomy.

``I wish Africa was dead!'' (she)
she (Jellyby) said on a sudden.

I was going to remonstrate.

``I do!'' (she)
she (Jellyby) said
``Don't talk to me, Miss Summerson. I hate it and detest it. It's a beast!'' (she)

I told her (Jellyby) she (Jellyby) was tired, and I was sorry. I put my hand upon her (Jellyby) head, and touched her (Jellyby) forehead, and said it was hot now but would be cool to-morrow. She (Jellyby) still stood pouting and frowning at me, but presently put down her (Jellyby) egg-cup and turned softly towards the bed where Ada lay.

``She (Summerson) is very pretty!'' (she)
she (Ada) said with the same knitted brow and in the same uncivil manner.

I assented with a smile.

``An orphan. Ain't she (Summerson)?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``But knows a quantity, I suppose? Can dance, and play music, and sing? She (Summerson) can talk French, I suppose, and do geography, and globes, and needlework, and everything?'' (unknown)

``No doubt,'' (I.)
said I.

``I can't,'' (I.)
she (Ada) returned.
``I can't do anything hardly, except write. I'm always writing for Ma. I wonder you two were not ashamed of yourselves to come in this afternoon and see me able to do nothing else. It was like your ill nature. Yet you think yourselves very fine, I dare say!'' (I)

I could see that the poor girl was near crying, and I resumed my chair without speaking and looked at her (girl) -LRB-I hope-RRB- as mildly as I felt towards her (girl).

``It's disgraceful,'' (she)
she (girl) said. ``You know it is. The whole house is disgraceful. The children are disgraceful. I
``M disgraceful. Pa's miserable, and no wonder! Priscilla drinks--she (Priscilla)'s always drinking. It's a great shame and a great story of you if you say you didn't smell her (Priscilla) to-day. It was as bad as a public-house, waiting at dinner; you know it was!'' (unknown)

``My dear, I don't know it,'' (I.)
said I.

``You do,'' (I.)
she (girl) said very shortly.
``You shan't say you don't. You do!'' (unknown)

``Oh, my dear!'' (I.)
said I.
``If you won't let me speak--'' (I.)

``You're speaking now. You know you are. Don't tell stories, Miss Summerson.'' (I.)

``My dear,'' (I)
said I,
``as long as you won't hear me out--'' (I)

``I don't want to hear you out.'' (I)

``Oh, yes, I think you do,'' (I)
said I,
``because that would be so very unreasonable. I did not know what you tell me because the servant did not come near me at dinner; but I don't doubt what you tell me, and I am sorry to hear it.'' (I)

``You needn't make a merit of that,'' (she)
said she (girl).

``No, my dear,'' (I.)
said I.
``That would be very foolish.'' (I.)

She (girl) was still standing by the bed, and now stooped down -LRB-but still with the same discontented face-RRB- and kissed Ada. That done, she (Ada) came softly back and stood by the side of my chair. Her (Ada) bosom was heaving in a distressful manner that I greatly pitied, but I thought it better not to speak.

``I wish I was dead!'' (she)
she (Ada) broke out.
``I wish we were all dead. It would be a great deal better for us.'' (she)

In a moment afterwards, she (Ada) knelt on the ground at my side, hid her (Ada) face in my dress, passionately begged my pardon, and wept. I comforted her (Ada) and would have raised her (Ada), but she (Ada) cried no, no; she (Ada) wanted to stay there!

``You used to teach girls,'' (she)
she (Ada) said,
``If you could only have taught me, I could have learnt from you! I am so very miserable, and I like you so much!'' (she)

I could not persuade her (Ada) to sit by me or to do anything but move a ragged stool to where she (Ada) was kneeling, and take that, and still hold my dress in the same manner. By degrees the poor tired girl fell asleep, and then I contrived to raise her (girl) head so that it should rest on my lap, and to cover us both with shawls. The fire went out, and all night long she (girl) slumbered thus before the ashy grate. At first I was painfully awake and vainly tried to lose myself, with my eyes closed, among the scenes of the day. At length, by slow degrees, they became indistinct and mingled. I began to lose the identity of the sleeper resting on me. Now it was Ada, now one of my old Reading friends from whom I could not believe I had so recently parted. Now it was the little mad woman worn out with curtsying and smiling, now some one in authority at Bleak House. Lastly, it was no one, and I was no one.

The purblind day was feebly struggling with the fog when I opened my eyes to encounter those of a dirty-faced little spectre fixed upon me. Peepy had scaled his (I) crib, and crept down in his (I) bed-gown and cap, and was so cold that his (I) teeth were chattering as if he (I) had cut them all.

CHAPTER V

A Morning Adventure

Although the morning was raw, and although the fog still seemed heavy--I say seemed, for the windows were so encrusted with dirt that they would have made midsummer sunshine dim--I was sufficiently forewarned of the discomfort within doors at that early hour and sufficiently curious about London to think it a good idea on the part of Miss Jellyby when she (Jellyby) proposed that we should go out for a walk.

``Ma won't be down for ever so long,'' (she)
she (Jellyby) said,
``and then it's a chance if breakfast's ready for an hour afterwards, they dawdle so. As to Pa, he (us) gets what he (us) can and goes to the office. He (us) never has what you would call a regular breakfast. Priscilla leaves him (us) out the loaf and some milk, when there is any, overnight. Sometimes there isn't any milk, and sometimes the cat drinks it. But I'm afraid you must be tired, Miss Summerson, and perhaps you would rather go to bed.'' (she)

``I am not at all tired, my dear,'' (I)
said I,
``and would much prefer to go out.'' (I)

``If you're sure you would,'' (Miss Jellyby)
returned Miss Jellyby,
``I'll get my things on.'' (Miss Jellyby)

Ada said she (Ada) would go too, and was soon astir. I made a proposal to Peepy, in default of being able to do anything better for him (I), that he (I) should let me wash him (I) and afterwards lay him (I) down on my bed again. To this he (I) submitted with the best grace possible, staring at me during the whole operation as if he (I) never had been, and never could again be, so astonished in his (I) life--looking very miserable also, certainly, but making no complaint, and going snugly to sleep as soon as it was over. At first I was in two minds about taking such a liberty, but I soon reflected that nobody in the house was likely to notice it.

What with the bustle of dispatching Peepy and the bustle of getting myself ready and helping Ada, I was soon quite in a glow. We found Miss Jellyby trying to warm herself at the fire in the writing-room, which Priscilla was then lighting with a smutty parlour candlestick, throwing the candle in to make it burn better. Everything was just as we had left it last night and was evidently intended to remain so. Below-stairs the dinner-cloth had not been taken away, but had been left ready for breakfast. Crumbs, dust, and waste-paper were all over the house. Some pewter pots and a milk-can hung on the area railings; the door stood open; and we met the cook round the corner coming out of a public-house, wiping her (Priscilla) mouth. She (Priscilla) mentioned, as she (Priscilla) passed us, that she (Priscilla) had been to see what o'clock it was.

But before we met the cook, we met Richard, who was dancing up and down Thavies Inn to warm his (Richard) feet. He (Richard) was agreeably surprised to see us stirring so soon and said he (Richard) would gladly share our walk. So he (Richard) took care of Ada, and Miss Jellyby and I went first. I may mention that Miss Jellyby had relapsed into her (Jellyby) sulky manner and that I really should not have thought she (Jellyby) liked me much unless she (Jellyby) had told me so.

``Where would you wish to go?'' (she)
she (Jellyby) asked.

``Anywhere, my dear,'' (I)
I replied.

``Anywhere's nowhere,'' (Miss Jellyby)
said Miss Jellyby, stopping perversely.

``Let us go somewhere at any rate,'' (I)
said I.

She (Jellyby) then walked me on very fast.

``I don't care!'' (she)
she (Jellyby) said.
``Now, you are my witness, Miss Summerson, I say I don't care--but if he (witness) was to come to our house with his (witness) great, shining, lumpy forehead night after night till he (witness) was as old as Methuselah, I wouldn't have anything to say to him (witness). Such ASSES as he (witness) and Ma make of themselves!'' (unknown)

``My dear!'' (I)
I remonstrated, in allusion to the epithet and the vigorous emphasis Miss Jellyby set upon it.
``Your duty as a child--'' (unknown)

``Oh! Don't talk of duty as a child, Miss Summerson; where's Ma's duty as a parent? All made over to the public and Africa, I suppose! Then let the public and Africa show duty as a child; it's much more their affair than mine. You are shocked, I dare say! Very well, so am I shocked too; so we are both shocked, and there's an end of it!'' (She)

She (Jellyby) walked me on faster yet.

``But for all that, I say again, he (I) may come, and come, and come, and I won't have anything to say to him (I). I can't bear him (I). If there's any stuff in the world that I hate and detest, it's the stuff he (I) and Ma talk. I wonder the very paving-stones opposite our house can have the patience to stay there and be a witness of such inconsistencies and contradictions as all that sounding nonsense, and Ma's management!'' (I)

I could not but understand her (Jellyby) to refer to Mr. Quale, the young gentleman who had appeared after dinner yesterday. I was saved the disagreeable necessity of pursuing the subject by Richard and Ada coming up at a round pace, laughing and asking us if we meant to run a race. Thus interrupted, Miss Jellyby became silent and walked moodily on at my side while I admired the long successions and varieties of streets, the quantity of people already going to and fro, the number of vehicles passing and repassing, the busy preparations in the setting forth of shop windows and the sweeping out of shops, and the extraordinary creatures in rags secretly groping among the swept-out rubbish for pins and other refuse.

``So, cousin,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said the cheerful voice of Richard to Ada behind me.
``We are never to get out of Chancery! We have come by another way to our place of meeting yesterday, and--by the Great Seal, here's the old lady again!'' (she)

Truly, there she (Ada) was, immediately in front of us, curtsying, and smiling, and saying with her (Ada) yesterday's air of patronage,

``The wards in Jarndyce! Ve-ry happy, I am sure!'' (she)

``You are out early, ma'am,'' (I)
said I as she (Ada) curtsied to me.

``Ye-es! I usually walk here early. Before the court sits. It's retired. I collect my thoughts here for the business of the day,'' (the lady)
said the old lady mincingly.
``The business of the day requires a great deal of thought. Chancery justice is so ve-ry difficult to follow.'' (unknown)

``Who's this, Miss Summerson?'' (Miss Jellyby)
whispered Miss Jellyby, drawing my arm tighter through her (Jellyby) own.

The little old lady's hearing was remarkably quick. She (Jellyby) answered for herself directly.

``A suitor, my child. At your service. I have the honour to attend court regularly. With my documents. Have I the pleasure of addressing another of the youthful parties in Jarndyce?'' (the lady)
said the old lady, recovering herself, with her (lady) head on one side, from a very low curtsy.

Richard, anxious to atone for his (Richard) thoughtlessness of yesterday, good-naturedly explained that Miss Jellyby was not connected with the suit.

``Ha!'' (the lady)
said the old lady.
``She (Summerson) does not expect a judgment? She (Summerson) will still grow old. But not so old. Oh, dear, no! This is the garden of Lincoln's Inn. I call it my garden. It is quite a bower in the summer-time. Where the birds sing melodiously. I pass the greater part of the long vacation here. In contemplation. You find the long vacation exceedingly long, don't you?'' (she)

We said yes, as she (lady) seemed to expect us to say so.

``When the leaves are falling from the trees and there are no more flowers in bloom to make up into nosegays for the Lord Chancellor's court,'' (the lady)
said the old lady,
``the vacation is fulfilled and the sixth seal, mentioned in the Revelations, again prevails. Pray come and see my lodging. It will be a good omen for me. Youth, and hope, and beauty are very seldom there. It is a long, long time since I had a visit from either.'' (the lady)

She (lady) had taken my hand, and leading me and Miss Jellyby away, beckoned Richard and Ada to come too. I did not know how to excuse myself and looked to Richard for aid. As he (Richard) was half amused and half curious and all in doubt how to get rid of the old lady without offence, she (lady) continued to lead us away, and he (Richard) and Ada continued to follow, our strange conductress informing us all the time, with much smiling condescension, that she (Ada) lived close by.

It was quite true, as it soon appeared. She (Ada) lived so close by that we had not time to have done humouring her (Ada) for a few moments before she (Ada) was at home. Slipping us out at a little side gate, the old lady stopped most unexpectedly in a narrow back street, part of some courts and lanes immediately outside the wall of the inn, and said,

``This is my lodging. Pray walk up!'' (the lady)

She (lady) had stopped at a shop over which was written KROOK, RAG AND BOTTLE WAREHOUSE. Also, in long thin letters, KROOK, DEALER IN MARINE STORES. In one part of the window was a picture of a red paper mill at which a cart was unloading a quantity of sacks of old rags. In another was the inscription BONES BOUGHT. In another, KITCHEN-STUFF BOUGHT. In another, OLD IRON BOUGHT. In another, WASTE-PAPER BOUGHT. In another, LADIES' AND GENTLEMEN``S WARDROBES BOUGHT. Everything seemed to be bought and nothing to be sold there. In all parts of the window were quantities of dirty bottles--blacking bottles, medicine bottles, ginger-beer and soda-water bottles, pickle bottles, wine bottles, ink bottles; I am reminded by mentioning the latter that the shop had in several little particulars the air of being in a legal neighbourhood and of being, as it were, a dirty hanger-on and disowned relation of the law. There were a great many ink bottles. There was a little tottering bench of shabby old volumes outside the door, labelled

``Law Books, all at 9d.'' (unknown)
Some of the inscriptions I have enumerated were written in law-hand, like the papers I had seen in Kenge and Carboy's office and the letters I had so long received from the firm. Among them was one, in the same writing, having nothing to do with the business of the shop, but announcing that a respectable man aged forty-five wanted engrossing or copying to execute with neatness and dispatch: Address to Nemo, care of Mr. Krook, within. There were several second-hand bags, blue and red, hanging up. A little way within the shop-door lay heaps of old crackled parchment scrolls and discoloured and dog's-eared law-papers. I could have fancied that all the rusty keys, of which there must have been hundreds huddled together as old iron, had once belonged to doors of rooms or strong chests in lawyers' offices. The litter of rags tumbled partly into and partly out of a one-legged wooden scale, hanging without any counterpoise from a beam, might have been counsellors' bands and gowns torn up. One had only to fancy, as Richard whispered to Ada and me while we all stood looking in, that yonder bones in a corner, piled together and picked very clean, were the bones of clients, to make the picture complete.

As it was still foggy and dark, and as the shop was blinded besides by the wall of Lincoln's Inn, intercepting the light within a couple of yards, we should not have seen so much but for a lighted lantern that an old man in spectacles and a hairy cap was carrying about in the shop. Turning towards the door, he (man) now caught sight of us. He (man) was short, cadaverous, and withered, with his (man) head sunk sideways between his (man) shoulders and the breath issuing in visible smoke from his (man) mouth as if he (man) were on fire within. His (man) throat, chin, and eyebrows were so frosted with white hairs and so gnarled with veins and puckered skin that he (man) looked from his (man) breast upward like some old root in a fall of snow.

``Hi, hi!'' (the man)
said the old man, coming to the door.
``Have you anything to sell?'' (she)

We naturally drew back and glanced at our conductress, who had been trying to open the house-door with a key she (man) had taken from her (man) pocket, and to whom Richard now said that as we had had the pleasure of seeing where she (man) lived, we would leave her (man), being pressed for time. But she (man) was not to be so easily left. She (man) became so fantastically and pressingly earnest in her (man) entreaties that we would walk up and see her (man) apartment for an instant, and was so bent, in her (man) harmless way, on leading me in, as part of the good omen she (man) desired, that I -LRB-whatever the others might do-RRB- saw nothing for it but to comply. I suppose we were all more or less curious; at any rate, when the old man added his (man) persuasions to hers and said,

``Aye, aye! Please her (it)! It won't take a minute! Come in, come in! Come in through the shop if t`other door's out of order!'' (persuasions)
we all went in, stimulated by Richard's laughing encouragement and relying on his (Richard) protection.

``My landlord, Krook,'' (the lady)
said the little old lady, condescending to him (Richard) from her (lady) lofty station as she (lady) presented him (Richard) to us.
``He (Krook) is called among the neighbours the Lord Chancellor. His (Krook) shop is called the Court of Chancery. He (Krook) is a very eccentric person. He (Krook) is very odd. Oh, I assure you he (Krook) is very odd!'' (She)

She (lady) shook her (lady) head a great many times and tapped her (lady) forehead with her (lady) finger to express to us that we must have the goodness to excuse him (Richard),

``For he (Krook) is a little--you know--M!'' (him)
said the old lady with great stateliness. The old man overheard, and laughed.

``It's true enough,'' (he)
he (man) said, going before us with the lantern,
``that they call me the Lord Chancellor and call my shop Chancery. And why do you think they call me the Lord Chancellor and my shop Chancery?'' (he)

``I don't know, I am sure!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard rather carelessly.

``You see,'' (the man)
said the old man, stopping and turning round,
``they--Hi! Here's lovely hair! I have got three sacks of ladies' hair below, but none so beautiful and fine as this. What colour, and what texture!'' (the man)

``That'll do, my good friend!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard, strongly disapproving of his (Richard) having drawn one of Ada's tresses through his (Richard) yellow hand.
``You can admire as the rest of us do without taking that liberty.'' (The man)

The old man darted at him (Richard) a sudden look which even called my attention from Ada, who, startled and blushing, was so remarkably beautiful that she (Ada) seemed to fix the wandering attention of the little old lady herself. But as Ada interposed and laughingly said she (Ada) could only feel proud of such genuine admiration, Mr. Krook shrunk into his (Krook) former self as suddenly as he (Krook) had leaped out of it.

``You see, I have so many things here,'' (he)
he (Krook) resumed, holding up the lantern,
``of so many kinds, and all as the neighbours think -LRB-but THEY know nothing-RRB-, wasting away and going to rack and ruin, that that's why they have given me and my place a christening. And I have so many old parchmentses and papers in my stock. And I have a liking for rust and must and cobwebs. And all's fish that comes to my net. And I can't abear to part with anything I once lay hold of -LRB-or so my neighbours think, but what do THEY know?-RRB- or to alter anything, or to have any sweeping, nor scouring, nor cleaning, nor repairing going on about me. That's the way I've got the ill name of Chancery. I don't mind. I go to see my noble and learned brother pretty well every day, when he (brother) sits in the Inn. He (brother) don't notice me, but I notice him (brother). There's no great odds betwixt us. We both grub on in a muddle. Hi, Lady Jane!'' (he)

A large grey cat leaped from some neighbouring shelf on his (Krook) shoulder and startled us all.

``Hi! Show 'em how you scratch. Hi! Tear, my lady!'' (master)
said her (Ada) master.

The cat leaped down and ripped at a bundle of rags with her (Ada) tigerish claws, with a sound that it set my teeth on edge to hear.

``She (lady)'d do as much for any one I was to set her (lady) on,'' (the man)
said the old man.
``I deal in cat-skins among other general matters, and hers was offered to me. It's a very fine skin, as you may see, but I didn't have it stripped off! THAT warn't like Chancery practice though, says you!'' (He)

He (man) had by this time led us across the shop, and now opened a door in the back part of it, leading to the house-entry. As he (man) stood with his (man) hand upon the lock, the little old lady graciously observed to him (man) before passing out,

``That will do, Krook. You mean well, but are tiresome. My young friends are pressed for time. I have none to spare myself, having to attend court very soon. My young friends are the wards in Jarndyce.'' (him)

``Jarndyce!'' (the man)
said the old man with a start.

``Jarndyce and Jarndyce. The great suit, Krook,'' (lodger)
returned his (man) lodger.

``Hi!'' (the man)
exclaimed the old man in a tone of thoughtful amazement and with a wider stare than before.
``Think of it!'' (He)

He (man) seemed so rapt all in a moment and looked so curiously at us that Richard said,

``Why, you appear to trouble yourself a good deal about the causes before your noble and learned brother, the other Chancellor!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``Yes,'' (the man)
said the old man abstractedly.
``Sure! YOUR name now will be--'' (unknown)

``Richard Carstone.'' (unknown)

``Carstone,'' (he)
he (man) repeated, slowly checking off that name upon his (man) forefinger; and each of the others he (man) went on to mention upon a separate finger.
``Yes. There was the name of Barbary, and the name of Clare, and the name of Dedlock, too, I think.'' (unknown)

``He (Carstone) knows as much of the cause as the real salaried Chancellor!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard, quite astonished, to Ada and me.

``Aye!'' (the man)
said the old man, coming slowly out of his (man) abstraction.
``Yes! Tom Jarndyce--you'll excuse me, being related; but he (Jarndyce) was never known about court by any other name, and was as well known there as--she (Dedlock) is now,'' (lodger)
nodding slightly at his (man) lodger. ``Tom Jarndyce was often in here. He (Jarndyce) got into a restless habit of strolling about when the cause was on, or expected, talking to the little shopkeepers and telling 'em to keep out of Chancery, whatever they did. ``For,
'' says he (man), `it's being ground to bits in a slow mill; it's being roasted at a slow fire; it's being stung to death by single bees; it's being drowned by drops; it's going mad by grains.'' (He)
He (man) was as near making away with himself, just where the young lady stands, as near could be.''

We listened with horror.

``He (Jarndyce) come in at the door,'' (the man)
said the old man, slowly pointing an imaginary track along the shop, ``on the day he (Jarndyce) did it--the whole neighbourhood had said for months before that he (Jarndyce) would do it, of a certainty sooner or later--he (Jarndyce) come in at the door that day, and walked along there, and sat himself on a bench that stood there, and asked me -LRB-you'll judge I was a mortal sight younger then-RRB- to fetch him (Jarndyce) a pint of wine. ``For,'' says he (man), ``Krook, I am much depressed; my cause is on again, and I think I'm nearer judgment than I ever was.'' I hadn't a mind to leave him (man) alone; and I persuaded him (man) to go to the tavern over the way there, t`other side my lane -LRB-I mean Chancery Lane-RRB-; and I followed and looked in at the window, and saw him (man), comfortable as I thought, in the arm-chair by the fire, and company with him (man). I hadn't hardly got back here when I heard a shot go echoing and rattling right away into the inn. I ran out--neighbours ran out--twenty of us cried at once,
``Tom Jarndyce!''' (The man)

The old man stopped, looked hard at us, looked down into the lantern, blew the light out, and shut the lantern up.

``We were right, I needn't tell the present hearers. Hi! To be sure, how the neighbourhood poured into court that afternoon while the cause was on! How my noble and learned brother, and all the rest of 'em, grubbed and muddled away as usual and tried to look as if they hadn't heard a word of the last fact in the case or as if they had--Oh, dear me!--nothing at all to do with it if they had heard of it by any chance!'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)

Ada's colour had entirely left her (Ada), and Richard was scarcely less pale. Nor could I wonder, judging even from my emotions, and I was no party in the suit, that to hearts so untried and fresh it was a shock to come into the inheritance of a protracted misery, attended in the minds of many people with such dreadful recollections. I had another uneasiness, in the application of the painful story to the poor half-witted creature who had brought us there; but, to my surprise, she (Ada) seemed perfectly unconscious of that and only led the way upstairs again, informing us with the toleration of a superior creature for the infirmities of a common mortal that her (Ada) landlord was

``a little M, you know!'' (a creature)

She (Ada) lived at the top of the house, in a pretty large room, from which she (Ada) had a glimpse of Lincoln's Inn Hall. This seemed to have been her (Ada) principal inducement, originally, for taking up her (Ada) residence there. She (Ada) could look at it, she (Ada) said, in the night, especially in the moonshine. Her (Ada) room was clean, but very, very bare. I noticed the scantiest necessaries in the way of furniture; a few old prints from books, of Chancellors and barristers, wafered against the wall; and some half-dozen reticles and work-bags,

``containing documents,'' (barristers)
as she (Ada) informed us. There were neither coals nor ashes in the grate, and I saw no articles of clothing anywhere, nor any kind of food. Upon a shelf in an open cupboard were a plate or two, a cup or two, and so forth, but all dry and empty. There was a more affecting meaning in her (Ada) pinched appearance, I thought as I looked round, than I had understood before.

``Extremely honoured, I am sure,'' (hostess)
said our poor hostess with the greatest suavity,
``by this visit from the wards in Jarndyce. And very much indebted for the omen. It is a retired situation. Considering. I am limited as to situation. In consequence of the necessity of attending on the Chancellor. I have lived here many years. I pass my days in court, my evenings and my nights here. I find the nights long, for I sleep but little and think much. That is, of course, unavoidable, being in Chancery. I am sorry I cannot offer chocolate. I expect a judgment shortly and shall then place my establishment on a superior footing. At present, I don't mind confessing to the wards in Jarndyce -LRB-in strict confidence-RRB- that I sometimes find it difficult to keep up a genteel appearance. I have felt the cold here. I have felt something sharper than cold. It matters very little. Pray excuse the introduction of such mean topics.'' (hostess)

She (hostess) partly drew aside the curtain of the long, low garret window and called our attention to a number of bird-cages hanging there, some containing several birds. There were larks, linnets, and goldfinches--I should think at least twenty.

``I began to keep the little creatures,'' (she)
she (hostess) said,
``with an object that the wards will readily comprehend. With the intention of restoring them to liberty. When my judgment should be given. Ye-es! They die in prison, though. Their lives, poor silly things, are so short in comparison with Chancery proceedings that, one by one, the whole collection has died over and over again. I doubt, do you know, whether one of these, though they are all young, will live to be free! Ve-ry mortifying, is it not?'' (she)

Although she (hostess) sometimes asked a question, she (hostess) never seemed to expect a reply, but rambled on as if she (hostess) were in the habit of doing so when no one but herself was present.

``Indeed,'' (she)
she (hostess) pursued,
``I positively doubt sometimes, I do assure you, whether while matters are still unsettled, and the sixth or Great Seal still prevails, I may not one day be found lying stark and senseless here, as I have found so many birds!'' (she)

Richard, answering what he (Richard) saw in Ada's compassionate eyes, took the opportunity of laying some money, softly and unobserved, on the chimney-piece. We all drew nearer to the cages, feigning to examine the birds.

``I can't allow them to sing much,'' (the lady)
said the little old lady,
``for -LRB-you'll think this curious-RRB- I find my mind confused by the idea that they are singing while I am following the arguments in court. And my mind requires to be so very clear, you know! Another time, I'll tell you their names. Not at present. On a day of such good omen, they shall sing as much as they like. In honour of youth,'' (the lady)
a smile and curtsy,
``hope,'' (unknown)
a smile and curtsy,
``and beauty,'' (unknown)
a smile and curtsy.
``There! We'll let in the full light.'' (unknown)

The birds began to stir and chirp.

``I cannot admit the air freely,'' (the lady)
said the little old lady--the room was close, and would have been the better for it--
``because the cat you saw downstairs, called Lady Jane, is greedy for their lives. She (Jane) crouches on the parapet outside for hours and hours. I have discovered,'' (the lady)
whispering mysteriously,
``that her (Jane) natural cruelty is sharpened by a jealous fear of their regaining their liberty. In consequence of the judgment I expect being shortly given. She (Jane) is sly and full of malice. I half believe, sometimes, that she (Jane) is no cat, but the wolf of the old saying. It is so very difficult to keep her (Jane) from the door.'' (unknown)

Some neighbouring bells, reminding the poor soul that it was half-past nine, did more for us in the way of bringing our visit to an end than we could easily have done for ourselves. She (lady) hurriedly took up her (lady) little bag of documents, which she (lady) had laid upon the table on coming in, and asked if we were also going into court. On our answering no, and that we would on no account detain her (lady), she (lady) opened the door to attend us downstairs.

``With such an omen, it is even more necessary than usual that I should be there before the Chancellor comes in,'' (she)
said she (lady),
``for he (Chancellor) might mention my case the first thing. I have a presentiment that he (Chancellor) WILL mention it the first thing this morning.'' (she)

She (lady) stopped to tell us in a whisper as we were going down that the whole house was filled with strange lumber which her (lady) landlord had bought piecemeal and had no wish to sell, in consequence of being a little M. This was on the first floor. But she (lady) had made a previous stoppage on the second floor and had silently pointed at a dark door there.

``The only other lodger,'' (she)
she (lady) now whispered in explanation,
``a law-writer. The children in the lanes here say he (Chancellor) has sold himself to the devil. I don't know what he (devil) can have done with the money. Hush!'' (she)

She (lady) appeared to mistrust that the lodger might hear her (lady) even there, and repeating

``Hush!'' (the lodger)
went before us on tiptoe as though even the sound of her (lady) footsteps might reveal to him (lady) what she (lady) had said.

Passing through the shop on our way out, as we had passed through it on our way in, we found the old man storing a quantity of packets of waste-paper in a kind of well in the floor. He (man) seemed to be working hard, with the perspiration standing on his (man) forehead, and had a piece of chalk by him (man), with which, as he (man) put each separate package or bundle down, he (man) made a crooked mark on the panelling of the wall.

Richard and Ada, and Miss Jellyby, and the little old lady had gone by him (Richard), and I was going when he (Richard) touched me on the arm to stay me, and chalked the letter J upon the wall--in a very curious manner, beginning with the end of the letter and shaping it backward. It was a capital letter, not a printed one, but just such a letter as any clerk in Messrs. Kenge and Carboy's office would have made.

``Can you read it?'' (he)
he (Richard) asked me with a keen glance.

``Surely,'' (I.)
said I.
``It's very plain.'' (I.)

``What is it?'' (unknown)

``J.'' (me)

With another glance at me, and a glance at the door, he (Richard) rubbed it out and turned an

``a'' (he)
in its place -LRB-not a capital letter this time-RRB-, and said,
``What's that?'' (he)

I told him (Richard). He (Richard) then rubbed that out and turned the letter

``r,'' (He)
and asked me the same question. He (Richard) went on quickly until he (Richard) had formed in the same curious manner, beginning at the ends and bottoms of the letters, the word Jarndyce, without once leaving two letters on the wall together.

``What does that spell?'' (he)
he (Jarndyce) asked me.

When I told him (Jarndyce), he (Jarndyce) laughed. In the same odd way, yet with the same rapidity, he (Jarndyce) then produced singly, and rubbed out singly, the letters forming the words Bleak House. These, in some astonishment, I also read; and he (Jarndyce) laughed again.

``Hi!'' (the man)
said the old man, laying aside the chalk.
``I have a turn for copying from memory, you see, miss, though I can neither read nor write.'' (He)

He (man) looked so disagreeable and his (man) cat looked so wickedly at me, as if I were a blood-relation of the birds upstairs, that I was quite relieved by Richard's appearing at the door and saying,

``Miss Summerson, I hope you are not bargaining for the sale of your hair. Don't be tempted. Three sacks below are quite enough for Mr. Krook!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

I lost no time in wishing Mr. Krook good morning and joining my friends outside, where we parted with the little old lady, who gave us her (lady) blessing with great ceremony and renewed her (lady) assurance of yesterday in reference to her (lady) intention of settling estates on Ada and me. Before we finally turned out of those lanes, we looked back and saw Mr. Krook standing at his (Krook) shop-door, in his (Krook) spectacles, looking after us, with his (Krook) cat upon his (Krook) shoulder, and her (lady) tail sticking up on one side of his (Krook) hairy cap like a tall feather.

``Quite an adventure for a morning in London!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard with a sigh.
``Ah, cousin, cousin, it's a weary word this Chancery!'' (unknown)

``It is to me, and has been ever since I can remember,'' (Ada)
returned Ada.
``I am grieved that I should be the enemy--as I suppose I am--of a great number of relations and others, and that they should be my enemies--as I suppose they are--and that we should all be ruining one another without knowing how or why and be in constant doubt and discord all our lives. It seems very strange, as there must be right somewhere, that an honest judge in real earnest has not been able to find out through all these years where it is.'' (unknown)

``Ah, cousin!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard.
``Strange, indeed! All this wasteful, wanton chess-playing IS very strange. To see that composed court yesterday jogging on so serenely and to think of the wretchedness of the pieces on the board gave me the headache and the heartache both together. My head ached with wondering how it happened, if men were neither fools nor rascals; and my heart ached to think they could possibly be either. But at all events, Ada--I may call you Ada?'' (unknown)

``Of course you may, cousin Richard.'' (unknown)

``At all events, Chancery will work none of its bad influences on US. We have happily been brought together, thanks to our good kinsman, and it can't divide us now!'' (unknown)

``Never, I hope, cousin Richard!'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)
said Ada gently.

Miss Jellyby gave my arm a squeeze and me a very significant look. I smiled in return, and we made the rest of the way back very pleasantly.

In half an hour after our arrival, Mrs. Jellyby appeared; and in the course of an hour the various things necessary for breakfast straggled one by one into the dining-room. I do not doubt that Mrs. Jellyby had gone to bed and got up in the usual manner, but she (Jellyby) presented no appearance of having changed her (Jellyby) dress. She (Jellyby) was greatly occupied during breakfast, for the morning's post brought a heavy correspondence relative to Borrioboola-Gha, which would occasion her (Jellyby) -LRB-she (Jellyby) said-RRB- to pass a busy day. The children tumbled about, and notched memoranda of their accidents in their legs, which were perfect little calendars of distress; and Peepy was lost for an hour and a half, and brought home from Newgate market by a policeman. The equable manner in which Mrs. Jellyby sustained both his (policeman) absence and his (policeman) restoration to the family circle surprised us all.

She (Jellyby) was by that time perseveringly dictating to Caddy, and Caddy was fast relapsing into the inky condition in which we had found her (Jellyby). At one o'clock an open carriage arrived for us, and a cart for our luggage. Mrs. Jellyby charged us with many remembrances to her (Jellyby) good friend Mr. Jarndyce; Caddy left her (Jellyby) desk to see us depart, kissed me in the passage, and stood biting her (Jellyby) pen and sobbing on the steps; Peepy, I am happy to say, was asleep and spared the pain of separation -LRB-I was not without misgivings that he (Jarndyce) had gone to Newgate market in search of me-RRB-; and all the other children got up behind the barouche and fell off, and we saw them, with great concern, scattered over the surface of Thavies Inn as we rolled out of its precincts.

CHAPTER VI

Quite at Home

The day had brightened very much, and still brightened as we went westward. We went our way through the sunshine and the fresh air, wondering more and more at the extent of the streets, the brilliancy of the shops, the great traffic, and the crowds of people whom the pleasanter weather seemed to have brought out like many-coloured flowers. By and by we began to leave the wonderful city and to proceed through suburbs which, of themselves, would have made a pretty large town in my eyes; and at last we got into a real country road again, with windmills, rick-yards, milestones, farmers' waggons, scents of old hay, swinging signs, and horse troughs: trees, fields, and hedge-rows. It was delightful to see the green landscape before us and the immense metropolis behind; and when a waggon with a train of beautiful horses, furnished with red trappings and clear-sounding bells, came by us with its music, I believe we could all three have sung to the bells, so cheerful were the influences around.

``The whole road has been reminding me of my namesake Whittington,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard,
``and that waggon is the finishing touch. Halloa! What's the matter?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

We had stopped, and the waggon had stopped too. Its music changed as the horses came to a stand, and subsided to a gentle tinkling, except when a horse tossed his (Richard) head or shook himself and sprinkled off a little shower of bell-ringing.

``Our postilion is looking after the waggoner,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard,
``and the waggoner is coming back after us. Good day, friend!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
The waggoner was at our coach-door.
``Why, here's an extraordinary thing!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
added Richard, looking closely at the man.
``He (friend) has got your name, Ada, in his (friend) hat!'' (He)

He (Richard) had all our names in his (Richard) hat. Tucked within the band were three small notes--one addressed to Ada, one to Richard, one to me. These the waggoner delivered to each of us respectively, reading the name aloud first. In answer to Richard's inquiry from whom they came, he (Richard) briefly answered,

``Master, sir, if you please'' (he)
; and putting on his (Richard) hat again -LRB-which was like a soft bowl-RRB-, cracked his (Richard) whip, re-awakened his (Richard) music, and went melodiously away.

``Is that Mr. Jarndyce's waggon?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard, calling to our post-boy.

``Yes, sir,'' (he)
he (Richard) replied.
``Going to London.'' (unknown)

We opened the notes. Each was a counterpart of the other and contained these words in a solid, plain hand.

I look forward, my dear, to our meeting easily and without constraint on either side. I therefore have to propose that we meet as old friends and take the past for granted. It will be a relief to you possibly, and to me certainly, and so my love to you.

John Jarndyce

I had perhaps less reason to be surprised than either of my companions, having never yet enjoyed an opportunity of thanking one who had been my benefactor and sole earthly dependence through so many years. I had not considered how I could thank him (benefactor), my gratitude lying too deep in my heart for that; but I now began to consider how I could meet him (benefactor) without thanking him (benefactor), and felt it would be very difficult indeed.

The notes revived in Richard and Ada a general impression that they both had, without quite knowing how they came by it, that their cousin Jarndyce could never bear acknowledgments for any kindness he (Jarndyce) performed and that sooner than receive any he (Jarndyce) would resort to the most singular expedients and evasions or would even run away. Ada dimly remembered to have heard her (Ada) mother tell, when she (Ada) was a very little child, that he (Jarndyce) had once done her (Ada) an act of uncommon generosity and that on her (Ada) going to his (Jarndyce) house to thank him (Jarndyce), he (Jarndyce) happened to see her (Ada) through a window coming to the door, and immediately escaped by the back gate, and was not heard of for three months. This discourse led to a great deal more on the same theme, and indeed it lasted us all day, and we talked of scarcely anything else. If we did by any chance diverge into another subject, we soon returned to this, and wondered what the house would be like, and when we should get there, and whether we should see Mr. Jarndyce as soon as we arrived or after a delay, and what he (Jarndyce) would say to us, and what we should say to him (Jarndyce). All of which we wondered about, over and over again.

The roads were very heavy for the horses, but the pathway was generally good, so we alighted and walked up all the hills, and liked it so well that we prolonged our walk on the level ground when we got to the top. At Barnet there were other horses waiting for us, but as they had only just been fed, we had to wait for them too, and got a long fresh walk over a common and an old battle-field before the carriage came up. These delays so protracted the journey that the short day was spent and the long night had closed in before we came to St. Albans, near to which town Bleak House was, we knew.

By that time we were so anxious and nervous that even Richard confessed, as we rattled over the stones of the old street, to feeling an irrational desire to drive back again. As to Ada and me, whom he (Richard) had wrapped up with great care, the night being sharp and frosty, we trembled from head to foot. When we turned out of the town, round a corner, and Richard told us that the post-boy, who had for a long time sympathized with our heightened expectation, was looking back and nodding, we both stood up in the carriage -LRB-Richard holding Ada lest she (Ada) should be jolted down-RRB- and gazed round upon the open country and the starlight night for our destination. There was a light sparkling on the top of a hill before us, and the driver, pointing to it with his (driver) whip and crying,

``That's Bleak House!'' (the driver House)
put his (driver) horses into a canter and took us forward at such a rate, uphill though it was, that the wheels sent the road drift flying about our heads like spray from a water-mill. Presently we lost the light, presently saw it, presently lost it, presently saw it, and turned into an avenue of trees and cantered up towards where it was beaming brightly. It was in a window of what seemed to be an old-fashioned house with three peaks in the roof in front and a circular sweep leading to the porch. A bell was rung as we drew up, and amidst the sound of its deep voice in the still air, and the distant barking of some dogs, and a gush of light from the opened door, and the smoking and steaming of the heated horses, and the quickened beating of our own hearts, we alighted in no inconsiderable confusion.

``Ada, my love, Esther, my dear, you are welcome. I rejoice to see you! Rick, if I had a hand to spare at present, I would give it you!'' (The gentleman)

The gentleman who said these words in a clear, bright, hospitable voice had one of his (gentleman) arms round Ada's waist and the other round mine, and kissed us both in a fatherly way, and bore us across the hall into a ruddy little room, all in a glow with a blazing fire. Here he (gentleman) kissed us again, and opening his (gentleman) arms, made us sit down side by side on a sofa ready drawn out near the hearth. I felt that if we had been at all demonstrative, he (gentleman) would have run away in a moment.

``Now, Rick!'' (he)
said he (gentleman).
``I have a hand at liberty. A word in earnest is as good as a speech. I am heartily glad to see you. You are at home. Warm yourself!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

Richard shook him (Richard) by both hands with an intuitive mixture of respect and frankness, and only saying -LRB-though with an earnestness that rather alarmed me, I was so afraid of Mr. Jarndyce's suddenly disappearing-RRB-,

``You are very kind, sir! We are very much obliged to you!'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
laid aside his (Jarndyce) hat and coat and came up to the fire.

``And how did you like the ride? And how did you like Mrs. Jellyby, my dear?'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce to Ada.

While Ada was speaking to him (Jarndyce) in reply, I glanced -LRB-I need not say with how much interest-RRB- at his (Jarndyce) face. It was a handsome, lively, quick face, full of change and motion; and his (Jarndyce) hair was a silvered iron-grey. I took him (Jarndyce) to be nearer sixty than fifty, but he (Jarndyce) was upright, hearty, and robust. From the moment of his (Jarndyce) first speaking to us his (Jarndyce) voice had connected itself with an association in my mind that I could not define; but now, all at once, a something sudden in his (Jarndyce) manner and a pleasant expression in his (Jarndyce) eyes recalled the gentleman in the stagecoach six years ago on the memorable day of my journey to Reading. I was certain it was he (Jarndyce). I never was so frightened in my life as when I made the discovery, for he (Jarndyce) caught my glance, and appearing to read my thoughts, gave such a look at the door that I thought we had lost him (Jarndyce).

However, I am happy to say he (Jarndyce) remained where he (Jarndyce) was, and asked me what I thought of Mrs. Jellyby.

``She (Jellyby) exerts herself very much for Africa, sir,'' (I)
I said.

``Nobly!'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
returned Mr. Jarndyce.
``But you answer like Ada.'' (I)
Whom I had not heard.
