``You all think something else, I see.'' (unknown)

``We rather thought,'' (I)
said I, glancing at Richard and Ada, who entreated me with their eyes to speak,
``that perhaps she (Ada) was a little unmindful of her (Ada) home.'' (me)

``Floored!'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
cried Mr. Jarndyce.

I was rather alarmed again.

``Well! I want to know your real thoughts, my dear. I may have sent you there on purpose.'' (unknown)

``We thought that, perhaps,'' (I)
said I, hesitating,
``it is right to begin with the obligations of home, sir; and that, perhaps, while those are overlooked and neglected, no other duties can possibly be substituted for them.'' (I)

``The little Jellybys,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard, coming to my relief,
``are really--I can't help expressing myself strongly, sir--in a devil of a state.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``She (I) means well,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce hastily.
``The wind's in the east.'' (unknown)

``It was in the north, sir, as we came down,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
observed Richard.

``My dear Rick,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce, poking the fire,
``I'll take an oath it's either in the east or going to be. I am always conscious of an uncomfortable sensation now and then when the wind is blowing in the east.'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)

``Rheumatism, sir?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard.

``I dare say it is, Rick. I believe it is. And so the little Jell--I had my doubts about 'em--are in a--oh, Lord, yes, it's easterly!'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce.

He (Jarndyce) had taken two or three undecided turns up and down while uttering these broken sentences, retaining the poker in one hand and rubbing his (Jarndyce) hair with the other, with a good-natured vexation at once so whimsical and so lovable that I am sure we were more delighted with him (Jarndyce) than we could possibly have expressed in any words. He (Jarndyce) gave an arm to Ada and an arm to me, and bidding Richard bring a candle, was leading the way out when he (Richard) suddenly turned us all back again.

``Those little Jellybys. Couldn't you--didn't you--now, if it had rained sugar-plums, or three-cornered raspberry tarts, or anything of that sort!'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce.

``Oh, cousin--'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)
Ada hastily began.

``Good, my pretty pet. I like cousin. Cousin John, perhaps, is better.'' (unknown)

``Then, cousin John--'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)
Ada laughingly began again.

``Ha, ha! Very good indeed!'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce with great enjoyment.
``Sounds uncommonly natural. Yes, my dear?'' (unknown)

``It did better than that. It rained Esther.'' (unknown)

``Aye?'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce.
``What did Esther do?'' (unknown)

``Why, cousin John,'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)
said Ada, clasping her (Ada) hands upon his (Jarndyce) arm and shaking her (Ada) head at me across him (Jarndyce)--for I wanted her (Ada) to be quiet--
``Esther was their friend directly. Esther nursed them, coaxed them to sleep, washed and dressed them, told them stories, kept them quiet, bought them keepsakes'' (her)
--My dear girl! I had only gone out with Peepy after he (Jarndyce) was found and given him (Jarndyce) a little, tiny horse!--
``and, cousin John, she (Esther) softened poor Caroline, the eldest one, so much and was so thoughtful for me and so amiable! No, no, I won't be contradicted, Esther dear! You know, you know, it's true!'' (cousin)

The warm-hearted darling leaned across her (girl) cousin John and kissed me, and then looking up in his (John) face, boldly said,

``At all events, cousin John, I WILL thank you for the companion you have given me.'' (me)
I felt as if she (girl) challenged him (John) to run away. But he (John) didn't.

``Where did you say the wind was, Rick?'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
asked Mr. Jarndyce.

``In the north as we came down, sir.'' (unknown)

``You are right. There's no east in it. A mistake of mine. Come, girls, come and see your home!'' (unknown)

It was one of those delightfully irregular houses where you go up and down steps out of one room into another, and where you come upon more rooms when you think you have seen all there are, and where there is a bountiful provision of little halls and passages, and where you find still older cottage-rooms in unexpected places with lattice windows and green growth pressing through them. Mine, which we entered first, was of this kind, with an up-and-down roof that had more corners in it than I ever counted afterwards and a chimney -LRB-there was a wood fire on the hearth-RRB- paved all around with pure white tiles, in every one of which a bright miniature of the fire was blazing. Out of this room, you went down two steps into a charming little sitting-room looking down upon a flower-garden, which room was henceforth to belong to Ada and me. Out of this you went up three steps into Ada's bedroom, which had a fine broad window commanding a beautiful view -LRB-we saw a great expanse of darkness lying underneath the stars-RRB-, to which there was a hollow window-seat, in which, with a spring-lock, three dear Adas might have been lost at once. Out of this room you passed into a little gallery, with which the other best rooms -LRB-only two-RRB- communicated, and so, by a little staircase of shallow steps with a number of corner stairs in it, considering its length, down into the hall. But if instead of going out at Ada's door you came back into my room, and went out at the door by which you had entered it, and turned up a few crooked steps that branched off in an unexpected manner from the stairs, you lost yourself in passages, with mangles in them, and three-cornered tables, and a native Hindu chair, which was also a sofa, a box, and a bedstead, and looked in every form something between a bamboo skeleton and a great bird-cage, and had been brought from India nobody knew by whom or when. From these you came on Richard's room, which was part library, part sitting-room, part bedroom, and seemed indeed a comfortable compound of many rooms. Out of that you went straight, with a little interval of passage, to the plain room where Mr. Jarndyce slept, all the year round, with his (Jarndyce) window open, his (Jarndyce) bedstead without any furniture standing in the middle of the floor for more air, and his (Jarndyce) cold bath gaping for him (Jarndyce) in a smaller room adjoining. Out of that you came into another passage, where there were back-stairs and where you could hear the horses being rubbed down outside the stable and being told to

``Hold up'' (unknown)
and
``Get over,'' (unknown)
as they slipped about very much on the uneven stones. Or you might, if you came out at another door -LRB-every room had at least two doors-RRB-, go straight down to the hall again by half-a-dozen steps and a low archway, wondering how you got back there or had ever got out of it.

The furniture, old-fashioned rather than old, like the house, was as pleasantly irregular. Ada's sleeping-room was all flowers--in chintz and paper, in velvet, in needlework, in the brocade of two stiff courtly chairs which stood, each attended by a little page of a stool for greater state, on either side of the fire-place. Our sitting-room was green and had framed and glazed upon the walls numbers of surprising and surprised birds, staring out of pictures at a real trout in a case, as brown and shining as if it had been served with gravy; at the death of Captain Cook; and at the whole process of preparing tea in China, as depicted by Chinese artists. In my room there were oval engravings of the months--ladies haymaking in short waists and large hats tied under the chin, for June; smooth-legged noblemen pointing with cocked-hats to village steeples, for October. Half-length portraits in crayons abounded all through the house, but were so dispersed that I found the brother of a youthful officer of mine in the china-closet and the grey old age of my pretty young bride, with a flower in her (bride) bodice, in the breakfast-room. As substitutes, I had four angels, of Queen Anne's reign, taking a complacent gentleman to heaven, in festoons, with some difficulty; and a composition in needlework representing fruit, a kettle, and an alphabet. All the movables, from the wardrobes to the chairs and tables, hangings, glasses, even to the pincushions and scent-bottles on the dressing-tables, displayed the same quaint variety. They agreed in nothing but their perfect neatness, their display of the whitest linen, and their storing-up, wheresoever the existence of a drawer, small or large, rendered it possible, of quantities of rose-leaves and sweet lavender. Such, with its illuminated windows, softened here and there by shadows of curtains, shining out upon the starlight night; with its light, and warmth, and comfort; with its hospitable jingle, at a distance, of preparations for dinner; with the face of its generous master brightening everything we saw; and just wind enough without to sound a low accompaniment to everything we heard, were our first impressions of Bleak House.

``I am glad you like it,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce when he (Jarndyce) had brought us round again to Ada's sitting-room.
``It makes no pretensions, but it is a comfortable little place, I hope, and will be more so with such bright young looks in it. You have barely half an hour before dinner. There's no one here but the finest creature upon earth--a child.'' (unknown)

``More children, Esther!'' (Ada)
said Ada.

``I don't mean literally a child,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
pursued Mr. Jarndyce;
``not a child in years. He (child) is grown up--he (child) is at least as old as I am--but in simplicity, and freshness, and enthusiasm, and a fine guileless inaptitude for all worldly affairs, he (child) is a perfect child.'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)

We felt that he (Jarndyce) must be very interesting.

``He (child) knows Mrs. Jellyby,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce.
``He (child) is a musical man, an amateur, but might have been a professional. He (child) is an artist too, an amateur, but might have been a professional. He (child) is a man of attainments and of captivating manners. He (child) has been unfortunate in his (child) affairs, and unfortunate in his (child) pursuits, and unfortunate in his (child) family; but he (child) don't care--he (child)'s a child!'' (unknown)

``Did you imply that he (child) has children of his (child) own, sir?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
inquired Richard.

``Yes, Rick! Half-a-dozen. More! Nearer a dozen, I should think. But he (Rick) has never looked after them. How could he (Rick)? He (Rick) wanted somebody to look after HIM. He (Rick) is a child, you know!'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce.

``And have the children looked after themselves at all, sir?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
inquired Richard.

``Why, just as you may suppose,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce, his (Jarndyce) countenance suddenly falling.
``It is said that the children of the very poor are not brought up, but dragged up. Harold Skimpole's children have tumbled up somehow or other. The wind's getting round again, I am afraid. I feel it rather!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

Richard observed that the situation was exposed on a sharp night.

``It IS exposed,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce.
``No doubt that's the cause. Bleak House has an exposed sound. But you are coming my way. Come along!'' (I)

Our luggage having arrived and being all at hand, I was dressed in a few minutes and engaged in putting my worldly goods away when a maid -LRB-not the one in attendance upon Ada, but another, whom I had not seen-RRB- brought a basket into my room with two bunches of keys in it, all labelled.

``For you, miss, if you please,'' (she)
said she (Ada).

``For me?'' (I.)
said I.

``The housekeeping keys, miss.'' (I.)

I showed my surprise, for she (Ada) added with some little surprise on her (Ada) own part,

``I was told to bring them as soon as you was alone, miss. Miss Summerson, if I don't deceive myself?'' (she)

``Yes,'' (I.)
said I.
``That is my name.'' (I.)

``The large bunch is the housekeeping, and the little bunch is the cellars, miss. Any time you was pleased to appoint to-morrow morning, I was to show you the presses and things they belong to.'' (I)

I said I would be ready at half-past six, and after she (Ada) was gone, stood looking at the basket, quite lost in the magnitude of my trust. Ada found me thus and had such a delightful confidence in me when I showed her (Ada) the keys and told her (Ada) about them that it would have been insensibility and ingratitude not to feel encouraged. I knew, to be sure, that it was the dear girl's kindness, but I liked to be so pleasantly cheated.

When we went downstairs, we were presented to Mr. Skimpole, who was standing before the fire telling Richard how fond he (Richard) used to be, in his (Richard) school-time, of football. He (Richard) was a little bright creature with a rather large head, but a delicate face and a sweet voice, and there was a perfect charm in him (Richard). All he (Richard) said was so free from effort and spontaneous and was said with such a captivating gaiety that it was fascinating to hear him (Richard) talk. Being of a more slender figure than Mr. Jarndyce and having a richer complexion, with browner hair, he (Jarndyce) looked younger. Indeed, he (Jarndyce) had more the appearance in all respects of a damaged young man than a well-preserved elderly one. There was an easy negligence in his (Jarndyce) manner and even in his (Jarndyce) dress -LRB-his (Jarndyce) hair carelessly disposed, and his (Jarndyce) neckkerchief loose and flowing, as I have seen artists paint their own portraits-RRB- which I could not separate from the idea of a romantic youth who had undergone some unique process of depreciation. It struck me as being not at all like the manner or appearance of a man who had advanced in life by the usual road of years, cares, and experiences.

I gathered from the conversation that Mr. Skimpole had been educated for the medical profession and had once lived, in his (Skimpole) professional capacity, in the household of a German prince. He (Skimpole) told us, however, that as he (Skimpole) had always been a mere child in point of weights and measures and had never known anything about them -LRB-except that they disgusted him (Skimpole)-RRB-, he (Skimpole) had never been able to prescribe with the requisite accuracy of detail. In fact, he (Skimpole) said, he (Skimpole) had no head for detail. And he (Skimpole) told us, with great humour, that when he (Skimpole) was wanted to bleed the prince or physic any of his (Skimpole) people, he (Skimpole) was generally found lying on his (Skimpole) back in bed, reading the newspapers or making fancy-sketches in pencil, and couldn't come. The prince, at last, objecting to this,

``in which,'' (The prince)
said Mr. Skimpole, in the frankest manner,
``he (I) was perfectly right,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
the engagement terminated, and Mr. Skimpole having -LRB-as he (Skimpole) added with delightful gaiety-RRB-
``nothing to live upon but love, fell in love, and married, and surrounded himself with rosy cheeks.'' (he)
His (Skimpole) good friend Jarndyce and some other of his (Skimpole) good friends then helped him (Skimpole), in quicker or slower succession, to several openings in life, but to no purpose, for he (Skimpole) must confess to two of the oldest infirmities in the world: one was that he (Skimpole) had no idea of time, the other that he (Skimpole) had no idea of money. In consequence of which he (Skimpole) never kept an appointment, never could transact any business, and never knew the value of anything! Well! So he (Skimpole) had got on in life, and here he (Skimpole) was! He (Skimpole) was very fond of reading the papers, very fond of making fancy-sketches with a pencil, very fond of nature, very fond of art. All he (Skimpole) asked of society was to let him (Skimpole) live. THAT wasn't much. His (Skimpole) wants were few. Give him (Skimpole) the papers, conversation, music, mutton, coffee, landscape, fruit in the season, a few sheets of Bristol-board, and a little claret, and he (Skimpole) asked no more. He (Skimpole) was a mere child in the world, but he (Skimpole) didn't cry for the moon. He (Skimpole) said to the world,
``Go your several ways in peace! Wear red coats, blue coats, lawn sleeves; put pens behind your ears, wear aprons; go after glory, holiness, commerce, trade, any object you prefer; only--let Harold Skimpole live!'' (He)

All this and a great deal more he (Skimpole) told us, not only with the utmost brilliancy and enjoyment, but with a certain vivacious candour--speaking of himself as if he (Skimpole) were not at all his (Skimpole) own affair, as if Skimpole were a third person, as if he (Skimpole) knew that Skimpole had his (Skimpole) singularities but still had his (Skimpole) claims too, which were the general business of the community and must not be slighted. He (Skimpole) was quite enchanting. If I felt at all confused at that early time in endeavouring to reconcile anything he (Skimpole) said with anything I had thought about the duties and accountabilities of life -LRB-which I am far from sure of-RRB-, I was confused by not exactly understanding why he (Skimpole) was free of them. That he (Skimpole) WAS free of them, I scarcely doubted; he (Skimpole) was so very clear about it himself.

``I covet nothing,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole in the same light way.
``Possession is nothing to me. Here is my friend Jarndyce's excellent house. I feel obliged to him (Jarndyce) for possessing it. I can sketch it and alter it. I can set it to music. When I am here, I have sufficient possession of it and have neither trouble, cost, nor responsibility. My steward's name, in short, is Jarndyce, and he (Jarndyce) can't cheat me. We have been mentioning Mrs. Jellyby. There is a bright-eyed woman, of a strong will and immense power of business detail, who throws herself into objects with surprising ardour! I don't regret that I have not a strong will and an immense power of business detail to throw myself into objects with surprising ardour. I can admire her (woman) without envy. I can sympathize with the objects. I can dream of them. I can lie down on the grass--in fine weather--and float along an African river, embracing all the natives I meet, as sensible of the deep silence and sketching the dense overhanging tropical growth as accurately as if I were there. I don't know that it's of any direct use my doing so, but it's all I can do, and I do it thoroughly. Then, for heaven's sake, having Harold Skimpole, a confiding child, petitioning you, the world, an agglomeration of practical people of business habits, to let him (Skimpole) live and admire the human family, do it somehow or other, like good souls, and suffer him (Skimpole) to ride his (Skimpole) rocking-horse!'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)

It was plain enough that Mr. Jarndyce had not been neglectful of the adjuration. Mr. Skimpole's general position there would have rendered it so without the addition of what he (Skimpole) presently said.

``It's only you, the generous creatures, whom I envy,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole, addressing us, his (Skimpole) new friends, in an impersonal manner.
``I envy you your power of doing what you do. It is what I should revel in myself. I don't feel any vulgar gratitude to you. I almost feel as if YOU ought to be grateful to ME for giving you the opportunity of enjoying the luxury of generosity. I know you like it. For anything I can tell, I may have come into the world expressly for the purpose of increasing your stock of happiness. I may have been born to be a benefactor to you by sometimes giving you an opportunity of assisting me in my little perplexities. Why should I regret my incapacity for details and worldly affairs when it leads to such pleasant consequences? I don't regret it therefore.'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)

Of all his (Skimpole) playful speeches -LRB-playful, yet always fully meaning what they expressed-RRB- none seemed to be more to the taste of Mr. Jarndyce than this. I had often new temptations, afterwards, to wonder whether it was really singular, or only singular to me, that he (Jarndyce), who was probably the most grateful of mankind upon the least occasion, should so desire to escape the gratitude of others.

We were all enchanted. I felt it a merited tribute to the engaging qualities of Ada and Richard that Mr. Skimpole, seeing them for the first time, should be so unreserved and should lay himself out to be so exquisitely agreeable. They -LRB-and especially Richard-RRB- were naturally pleased, for similar reasons, and considered it no common privilege to be so freely confided in by such an attractive man. The more we listened, the more gaily Mr. Skimpole talked. And what with his (Skimpole) fine hilarious manner and his (Skimpole) engaging candour and his (Skimpole) genial way of lightly tossing his (Skimpole) own weaknesses about, as if he (Skimpole) had said,

``I am a child, you know! You are designing people compared with me'' (he)
-LRB-he (Skimpole) really made me consider myself in that light-RRB-
``but I am gay and innocent; forget your worldly arts and play with me!'' (me)
the effect was absolutely dazzling.

He (Skimpole) was so full of feeling too and had such a delicate sentiment for what was beautiful or tender that he (Skimpole) could have won a heart by that alone. In the evening, when I was preparing to make tea and Ada was touching the piano in the adjoining room and softly humming a tune to her (Ada) cousin Richard, which they had happened to mention, he (Richard) came and sat down on the sofa near me and so spoke of Ada that I almost loved him (Richard).

``She (I) is like the morning,'' (he)
he (Richard) said.
``With that golden hair, those blue eyes, and that fresh bloom on her (I) cheek, she (I) is like the summer morning. The birds here will mistake her (I) for it. We will not call such a lovely young creature as that, who is a joy to all mankind, an orphan. She (I) is the child of the universe.'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)

Mr. Jarndyce, I found, was standing near us with his (Jarndyce) hands behind him (Jarndyce) and an attentive smile upon his (Jarndyce) face.

``The universe,'' (he)
he (Jarndyce) observed,
``makes rather an indifferent parent, I am afraid.'' (he)

``Oh! I don't know!'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
cried Mr. Skimpole buoyantly.

``I think I do know,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce.

``Well!'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
cried Mr. Skimpole.
``You know the world -LRB-which in your sense is the universe-RRB-, and I know nothing of it, so you shall have your way. But if I had mine,'' (the cousins)
glancing at the cousins,
``there should be no brambles of sordid realities in such a path as that. It should be strewn with roses; it should lie through bowers, where there was no spring, autumn, nor winter, but perpetual summer. Age or change should never wither it. The base word money should never be breathed near it!'' (the cousins)

Mr. Jarndyce patted him (Jarndyce) on the head with a smile, as if he (Jarndyce) had been really a child, and passing a step or two on, and stopping a moment, glanced at the young cousins. His (Jarndyce) look was thoughtful, but had a benignant expression in it which I often -LRB-how often!-RRB- saw again, which has long been engraven on my heart. The room in which they were, communicating with that in which he (Jarndyce) stood, was only lighted by the fire. Ada sat at the piano; Richard stood beside her (Ada), bending down. Upon the wall, their shadows blended together, surrounded by strange forms, not without a ghostly motion caught from the unsteady fire, though reflecting from motionless objects. Ada touched the notes so softly and sang so low that the wind, sighing away to the distant hills, was as audible as the music. The mystery of the future and the little clue afforded to it by the voice of the present seemed expressed in the whole picture.

But it is not to recall this fancy, well as I remember it, that I recall the scene. First, I was not quite unconscious of the contrast in respect of meaning and intention between the silent look directed that way and the flow of words that had preceded it. Secondly, though Mr. Jarndyce's glance as he (Jarndyce) withdrew it rested for but a moment on me, I felt as if in that moment he (Jarndyce) confided to me--and knew that he (Jarndyce) confided to me and that I received the confidence--his (Jarndyce) hope that Ada and Richard might one day enter on a dearer relationship.

Mr. Skimpole could play on the piano and the violoncello, and he (Skimpole) was a composer--had composed half an opera once, but got tired of it--and played what he (Skimpole) composed with taste. After tea we had quite a little concert, in which Richard--who was enthralled by Ada's singing and told me that she (Ada) seemed to know all the songs that ever were written--and Mr. Jarndyce, and I were the audience. After a little while I missed first Mr. Skimpole and afterwards Richard, and while I was thinking how could Richard stay away so long and lose so much, the maid who had given me the keys looked in at the door, saying,

``If you please, miss, could you spare a minute?'' (me)

When I was shut out with her (maid) in the hall, she (maid) said, holding up her (maid) hands,

``Oh, if you please, miss, Mr. Carstone says would you come upstairs to Mr. Skimpole's room. He (Skimpole) has been took, miss!'' (she)

``Took?'' (I.)
said I.

``Took, miss. Sudden,'' (I.)
said the maid.

I was apprehensive that his (Richard) illness might be of a dangerous kind, but of course I begged her (maid) to be quiet and not disturb any one and collected myself, as I followed her (maid) quickly upstairs, sufficiently to consider what were the best remedies to be applied if it should prove to be a fit. She (maid) threw open a door and I went into a chamber, where, to my unspeakable surprise, instead of finding Mr. Skimpole stretched upon the bed or prostrate on the floor, I found him (Skimpole) standing before the fire smiling at Richard, while Richard, with a face of great embarrassment, looked at a person on the sofa, in a white great-coat, with smooth hair upon his (Richard) head and not much of it, which he (Richard) was wiping smoother and making less of with a pocket-handkerchief.

``Miss Summerson,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard hurriedly,
``I am glad you are come. You will be able to advise us. Our friend Mr. Skimpole--don't be alarmed!--is arrested for debt.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``And really, my dear Miss Summerson,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole with his (Skimpole) agreeable candour,
``I never was in a situation in which that excellent sense and quiet habit of method and usefulness, which anybody must observe in you who has the happiness of being a quarter of an hour in your society, was more needed.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

The person on the sofa, who appeared to have a cold in his (Skimpole) head, gave such a very loud snort that he (Skimpole) startled me.

``Are you arrested for much, sir?'' (I)
I inquired of Mr. Skimpole.

``My dear Miss Summerson,'' (he)
said he (Skimpole), shaking his (Skimpole) head pleasantly,
``I don't know. Some pounds, odd shillings, and halfpence, I think, were mentioned.'' (he)

``It's twenty-four pound, sixteen, and sevenpence ha`penny,'' (the stranger)
observed the stranger.
``That's wot it is.'' (unknown)

``And it sounds--somehow it sounds,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole,
``like a small sum?'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

The strange man said nothing but made another snort. It was such a powerful one that it seemed quite to lift him (Skimpole) out of his (Skimpole) seat.

``Mr. Skimpole,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard to me,
``has a delicacy in applying to my cousin Jarndyce because he (Skimpole) has lately--I think, sir, I understood you that you had lately--'' (me)

``Oh, yes!'' (me)
returned Mr. Skimpole, smiling.
``Though I forgot how much it was and when it was. Jarndyce would readily do it again, but I have the epicure-like feeling that I would prefer a novelty in help, that I would rather,'' (he)
and he (Skimpole) looked at Richard and me,
``develop generosity in a new soil and in a new form of flower.'' (me)

``What do you think will be best, Miss Summerson?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard, aside.

I ventured to inquire, generally, before replying, what would happen if the money were not produced.

``Jail,'' (the man)
said the strange man, coolly putting his (man) handkerchief into his (man) hat, which was on the floor at his (man) feet.
``Or Coavinses.'' (unknown)

``May I ask, sir, what is--'' (unknown)

``Coavinses?'' (the man)
said the strange man.
``A `ouse.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

Richard and I looked at one another again. It was a most singular thing that the arrest was our embarrassment and not Mr. Skimpole's. He (Skimpole) observed us with a genial interest, but there seemed, if I may venture on such a contradiction, nothing selfish in it. He (Skimpole) had entirely washed his (Skimpole) hands of the difficulty, and it had become ours.

``I thought,'' (he)
he (Skimpole) suggested, as if good-naturedly to help us out,
``that being parties in a Chancery suit concerning -LRB-as people say-RRB- a large amount of property, Mr. Richard or his (Richard) beautiful cousin, or both, could sign something, or make over something, or give some sort of undertaking, or pledge, or bond? I don't know what the business name of it may be, but I suppose there is some instrument within their power that would settle this?'' (he)

``Not a bit on it,'' (the man)
said the strange man.

``Really?'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
returned Mr. Skimpole.
``That seems odd, now, to one who is no judge of these things!'' (unknown)

``Odd or even,'' (the stranger)
said the stranger gruffly,
``I tell you, not a bit on it!'' (the stranger)

``Keep your temper, my good fellow, keep your temper!'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
Mr. Skimpole gently reasoned with him (Skimpole) as he (Skimpole) made a little drawing of his (Skimpole) head on the fly-leaf of a book.
``Don't be ruffled by your occupation. We can separate you from your office; we can separate the individual from the pursuit. We are not so prejudiced as to suppose that in private life you are otherwise than a very estimable man, with a great deal of poetry in your nature, of which you may not be conscious.'' (The stranger)

The stranger only answered with another violent snort, whether in acceptance of the poetry-tribute or in disdainful rejection of it, he (Skimpole) did not express to me.

``Now, my dear Miss Summerson, and my dear Mr. Richard,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole gaily, innocently, and confidingly as he (Skimpole) looked at his (Skimpole) drawing with his (Skimpole) head on one side,
``here you see me utterly incapable of helping myself, and entirely in your hands! I only ask to be free. The butterflies are free. Mankind will surely not deny to Harold Skimpole what it concedes to the butterflies!'' (he)

``My dear Miss Summerson,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard in a whisper,
``I have ten pounds that I received from Mr. Kenge. I must try what that will do.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

I possessed fifteen pounds, odd shillings, which I had saved from my quarterly allowance during several years. I had always thought that some accident might happen which would throw me suddenly, without any relation or any property, on the world and had always tried to keep some little money by me that I might not be quite penniless. I told Richard of my having this little store and having no present need of it, and I asked him (Richard) delicately to inform Mr. Skimpole, while I should be gone to fetch it, that we would have the pleasure of paying his (Skimpole) debt.

When I came back, Mr. Skimpole kissed my hand and seemed quite touched. Not on his (Skimpole) own account -LRB-I was again aware of that perplexing and extraordinary contradiction-RRB-, but on ours, as if personal considerations were impossible with him (Skimpole) and the contemplation of our happiness alone affected him (Skimpole). Richard, begging me, for the greater grace of the transaction, as he (Richard) said, to settle with Coavinses -LRB-as Mr. Skimpole now jocularly called him (Skimpole)-RRB-, I counted out the money and received the necessary acknowledgment. This, too, delighted Mr. Skimpole.

His (Skimpole) compliments were so delicately administered that I blushed less than I might have done and settled with the stranger in the white coat without making any mistakes. He (stranger) put the money in his (stranger) pocket and shortly said, ``Well, then, I'll wish you a good evening, miss.

``My friend,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole, standing with his (Skimpole) back to the fire after giving up the sketch when it was half finished,
``I should like to ask you something, without offence.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

I think the reply was,

``Cut away, then!'' (I)

``Did you know this morning, now, that you were coming out on this errand?'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole.

``Know'd it yes`day aft`noon at tea-time,'' (Coavinses)
said Coavinses.

``It didn't affect your appetite? Didn't make you at all uneasy?'' (unknown)

``Not a bit,'' (Coavinses)
said Coavinses.
``I know'd if you wos missed to-day, you wouldn't be missed to-morrow. A day makes no such odds.'' (unknown)

``But when you came down here,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
proceeded Mr. Skimpole,
``it was a fine day. The sun was shining, the wind was blowing, the lights and shadows were passing across the fields, the birds were singing.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

``Nobody said they warn't, in MY hearing,'' (unknown)
returned Coavinses.

``No,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
observed Mr. Skimpole.
``But what did you think upon the road?'' (unknown)

``Wot do you mean?'' (unknown)
growled Coavinses with an appearance of strong resentment.
``Think! I've got enough to do, and little enough to get for it without thinking. Thinking!'' (unknown)
-LRB-with profound contempt-RRB-.

``Then you didn't think, at all events,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
proceeded Mr. Skimpole, ``to this effect: ``Harold Skimpole loves to see the sun shine, loves to hear the wind blow, loves to watch the changing lights and shadows, loves to hear the birds, those choristers in Nature's great cathedral. And does it seem to me that I am about to deprive Harold Skimpole of his (Skimpole) share in such possessions, which are his (Skimpole) only birthright!
'' You thought nothing to that effect?'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

``I--certainly--did--NOT,'' (Coavinses)
said Coavinses, whose doggedness in utterly renouncing the idea was of that intense kind that he (Skimpole) could only give adequate expression to it by putting a long interval between each word, and accompanying the last with a jerk that might have dislocated his (jerk) neck.

``Very odd and very curious, the mental process is, in you men of business!'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole thoughtfully.
``Thank you, my friend. Good night.'' (I)

As our absence had been long enough already to seem strange downstairs, I returned at once and found Ada sitting at work by the fireside talking to her (Ada) cousin John. Mr. Skimpole presently appeared, and Richard shortly after him (Skimpole). I was sufficiently engaged during the remainder of the evening in taking my first lesson in backgammon from Mr. Jarndyce, who was very fond of the game and from whom I wished of course to learn it as quickly as I could in order that I might be of the very small use of being able to play when he (Jarndyce) had no better adversary. But I thought, occasionally, when Mr. Skimpole played some fragments of his (Skimpole) own compositions or when, both at the piano and the violoncello, and at our table, he (Skimpole) preserved with an absence of all effort his (Skimpole) delightful spirits and his (Skimpole) easy flow of conversation, that Richard and I seemed to retain the transferred impression of having been arrested since dinner and that it was very curious altogether.

It was late before we separated, for when Ada was going at eleven o'clock, Mr. Skimpole went to the piano and rattled hilariously that the best of all ways to lengthen our days was to steal a few hours from night, my dear! It was past twelve before he (Skimpole) took his (Skimpole) candle and his (Skimpole) radiant face out of the room, and I think he (Skimpole) might have kept us there, if he (Skimpole) had seen fit, until daybreak. Ada and Richard were lingering for a few moments by the fire, wondering whether Mrs. Jellyby had yet finished her (Jellyby) dictation for the day, when Mr. Jarndyce, who had been out of the room, returned.

``Oh, dear me, what's this, what's this!'' (he)
he (Jarndyce) said, rubbing his (Jarndyce) head and walking about with his (Jarndyce) good-humoured vexation.
``What's this they tell me? Rick, my boy, Esther, my dear, what have you been doing? Why did you do it? How could you do it? How much apiece was it? The wind's round again. I feel it all over me!'' (unknown)

We neither of us quite knew what to answer.

``Come, Rick, come! I must settle this before I sleep. How much are you out of pocket? You two made the money up, you know! Why did you? How could you? Oh, Lord, yes, it's due east--must be!'' (unknown)

``Really, sir,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard,
``I don't think it would be honourable in me to tell you. Mr. Skimpole relied upon us--'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``Lord bless you, my dear boy! He (Lord) relies upon everybody!'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce, giving his (Jarndyce) head a great rub and stopping short.

``Indeed, sir?'' (unknown)

``Everybody! And he (Lord)'ll be in the same scrape again next week!'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce, walking again at a great pace, with a candle in his (Jarndyce) hand that had gone out. ``He (Lord)'s always in the same scrape. He (Lord) was born in the same scrape. I verily believe that the announcement in the newspapers when his (Lord) mother was confined was
``On Tuesday last, at her (mother) residence in Botheration Buildings, Mrs. Skimpole of a son in difficulties.''' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

Richard laughed heartily but added,

``Still, sir, I don't want to shake his (son) confidence or to break his (son) confidence, and if I submit to your better knowledge again, that I ought to keep his (son) secret, I hope you will consider before you press me any more. Of course, if you do press me, sir, I shall know I am wrong and will tell you.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``Well!'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
cried Mr. Jarndyce, stopping again, and making several absent endeavours to put his (Jarndyce) candlestick in his (Jarndyce) pocket.
``I--here! Take it away, my dear. I don't know what I am about with it; it's all the wind--invariably has that effect--I won't press you, Rick; you may be right. But really--to get hold of you and Esther--and to squeeze you like a couple of tender young Saint Michael's oranges! It'll blow a gale in the course of the night!'' (He)

He (Jarndyce) was now alternately putting his (Jarndyce) hands into his (Jarndyce) pockets as if he (Jarndyce) were going to keep them there a long time, and taking them out again and vehemently rubbing them all over his (Jarndyce) head.

I ventured to take this opportunity of hinting that Mr. Skimpole, being in all such matters quite a child--

``Eh, my dear?'' (Skimpole a child)
said Mr. Jarndyce, catching at the word.

``Being quite a child, sir,'' (I)
said I,
``and so different from other people--'' (I)

``You are right!'' (I)
said Mr. Jarndyce, brightening.
``Your woman's wit hits the mark. He (Michael) is a child--an absolute child. I told you he (Michael) was a child, you know, when I first mentioned him (Michael).'' (unknown)

Certainly! Certainly! we said.

``And he (Michael) IS a child. Now, isn't he (Michael)?'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
asked Mr. Jarndyce, brightening more and more.

He (Jarndyce) was indeed, we said.

``When you come to think of it, it's the height of childishness in you--I mean me--'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce,
``to regard him (Michael) for a moment as a man. You can't make HIM responsible. The idea of Harold Skimpole with designs or plans, or knowledge of consequences! Ha, ha, ha!'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)

It was so delicious to see the clouds about his (Jarndyce) bright face clearing, and to see him (Jarndyce) so heartily pleased, and to know, as it was impossible not to know, that the source of his (Jarndyce) pleasure was the goodness which was tortured by condemning, or mistrusting, or secretly accusing any one, that I saw the tears in Ada's eyes, while she (Ada) echoed his (Jarndyce) laugh, and felt them in my own.

``Why, what a cod's head and shoulders I am,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce,
``to require reminding of it! The whole business shows the child from beginning to end. Nobody but a child would have thought of singling YOU two out for parties in the affair! Nobody but a child would have thought of YOUR having the money! If it had been a thousand pounds, it would have been just the same!'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce with his (Jarndyce) whole face in a glow.

We all confirmed it from our night's experience.

``To be sure, to be sure!'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce.
``However, Rick, Esther, and you too, Ada, for I don't know that even your little purse is safe from his (Rick) inexperience--I must have a promise all round that nothing of this sort shall ever be done any more. No advances! Not even sixpences.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

We all promised faithfully, Richard with a merry glance at me touching his (Jarndyce) pocket as if to remind me that there was no danger of OUR transgressing.

``As to Skimpole,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce,
``a habitable doll's house with good board and a few tin people to get into debt with and borrow money of would set the boy up in life. He (boy) is in a child's sleep by this time, I suppose; it's time I should take my craftier head to my more worldly pillow. Good night, my dears. God bless you!'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)

He (Jarndyce) peeped in again, with a smiling face, before we had lighted our candles, and said,

``Oh! I have been looking at the weather-cock. I find it was a false alarm about the wind. It's in the south!'' (He)
And went away singing to himself.

Ada and I agreed, as we talked together for a little while upstairs, that this caprice about the wind was a fiction and that he (Jarndyce) used the pretence to account for any disappointment he (Jarndyce) could not conceal, rather than he (Jarndyce) would blame the real cause of it or disparage or depreciate any one. We thought this very characteristic of his (Jarndyce) eccentric gentleness and of the difference between him (Jarndyce) and those petulant people who make the weather and the winds -LRB-particularly that unlucky wind which he (Jarndyce) had chosen for such a different purpose-RRB- the stalking-horses of their splenetic and gloomy humours.

Indeed, so much affection for him (Jarndyce) had been added in this one evening to my gratitude that I hoped I already began to understand him (Jarndyce) through that mingled feeling. Any seeming inconsistencies in Mr. Skimpole or in Mrs. Jellyby I could not expect to be able to reconcile, having so little experience or practical knowledge. Neither did I try, for my thoughts were busy when I was alone, with Ada and Richard and with the confidence I had seemed to receive concerning them. My fancy, made a little wild by the wind perhaps, would not consent to be all unselfish, either, though I would have persuaded it to be so if I could. It wandered back to my godmother's house and came along the intervening track, raising up shadowy speculations which had sometimes trembled there in the dark as to what knowledge Mr. Jarndyce had of my earliest history--even as to the possibility of his (Jarndyce) being my father, though that idle dream was quite gone now.

It was all gone now, I remembered, getting up from the fire. It was not for me to muse over bygones, but to act with a cheerful spirit and a grateful heart. So I said to myself,

``Esther, Esther, Esther! Duty, my dear!'' (I)
and gave my little basket of housekeeping keys such a shake that they sounded like little bells and rang me hopefully to bed.

CHAPTER VII

The Ghost's Walk

While Esther sleeps, and while Esther wakes, it is still wet weather down at the place in Lincolnshire. The rain is ever falling--drip, drip, drip--by day and night upon the broad flagged terrace-pavement, the Ghost's Walk. The weather is so very bad down in Lincolnshire that the liveliest imagination can scarcely apprehend its ever being fine again. Not that there is any superabundant life of imagination on the spot, for Sir Leicester is not here -LRB-and, truly, even if he (Esther) were, would not do much for it in that particular-RRB-, but is in Paris with my Lady; and solitude, with dusky wings, sits brooding upon Chesney Wold.

There may be some motions of fancy among the lower animals at Chesney Wold. The horses in the stables--the long stables in a barren, red-brick court-yard, where there is a great bell in a turret, and a clock with a large face, which the pigeons who live near it and who love to perch upon its shoulders seem to be always consulting--THEY may contemplate some mental pictures of fine weather on occasions, and may be better artists at them than the grooms. The old roan, so famous for cross-country work, turning his (grooms) large eyeball to the grated window near his (grooms) rack, may remember the fresh leaves that glisten there at other times and the scents that stream in, and may have a fine run with the hounds, while the human helper, clearing out the next stall, never stirs beyond his (helper) pitchfork and birch-broom. The grey, whose place is opposite the door and who with an impatient rattle of his (helper) halter pricks his (helper) ears and turns his (helper) head so wistfully when it is opened, and to whom the opener says,

``Woa grey, then, steady! Noabody wants you to-day!'' (the man)
may know it quite as well as the man. The whole seemingly monotonous and uncompanionable half-dozen, stabled together, may pass the long wet hours when the door is shut in livelier communication than is held in the servants' hall or at the Dedlock Arms, or may even beguile the time by improving -LRB-perhaps corrupting-RRB- the pony in the loose-box in the corner.

So the mastiff, dozing in his (man) kennel in the court-yard with his (man) large head on his (man) paws, may think of the hot sunshine when the shadows of the stable-buildings tire his (man) patience out by changing and leave him (man) at one time of the day no broader refuge than the shadow of his (man) own house, where he (man) sits on end, panting and growling short, and very much wanting something to worry besides himself and his (man) chain. So now, half-waking and all-winking, he (man) may recall the house full of company, the coach-houses full of vehicles, the stables full of horses, and the out-buildings full of attendants upon horses, until he (man) is undecided about the present and comes forth to see how it is. Then, with that impatient shake of himself, he (man) may growl in the spirit,

``Rain, rain, rain! Nothing but rain--and no family here!'' (he)
as he (man) goes in again and lies down with a gloomy yawn.

So with the dogs in the kennel-buildings across the park, who have their restless fits and whose doleful voices when the wind has been very obstinate have even made it known in the house itself--upstairs, downstairs, and in my Lady's chamber. They may hunt the whole country-side, while the raindrops are pattering round their inactivity. So the rabbits with their self-betraying tails, frisking in and out of holes at roots of trees, may be lively with ideas of the breezy days when their ears are blown about or of those seasons of interest when there are sweet young plants to gnaw. The turkey in the poultry-yard, always troubled with a class-grievance -LRB-probably Christmas-RRB-, may be reminiscent of that summer morning wrongfully taken from him (Lady) when he (Lady) got into the lane among the felled trees, where there was a barn and barley. The discontented goose, who stoops to pass under the old gateway, twenty feet high, may gabble out, if we only knew it, a waddling preference for weather when the gateway casts its shadow on the ground.

Be this as it may, there is not much fancy otherwise stirring at Chesney Wold. If there be a little at any odd moment, it goes, like a little noise in that old echoing place, a long way and usually leads off to ghosts and mystery.

It has rained so hard and rained so long down in Lincolnshire that Mrs. Rouncewell, the old housekeeper at Chesney Wold, has several times taken off her (Rouncewell) spectacles and cleaned them to make certain that the drops were not upon the glasses. Mrs. Rouncewell might have been sufficiently assured by hearing the rain, but that she (Rouncewell) is rather deaf, which nothing will induce her (Rouncewell) to believe. She (Rouncewell) is a fine old lady, handsome, stately, wonderfully neat, and has such a back and such a stomacher that if her (Rouncewell) stays should turn out when she (Rouncewell) dies to have been a broad old-fashioned family fire-grate, nobody who knows her (Rouncewell) would have cause to be surprised. Weather affects Mrs. Rouncewell little. The house is there in all weathers, and the house, as she (Rouncewell) expresses it,

``is what she (Esther) looks at.'' (she)
She (Rouncewell) sits in her (Rouncewell) room -LRB-in a side passage on the ground floor, with an arched window commanding a smooth quadrangle, adorned at regular intervals with smooth round trees and smooth round blocks of stone, as if the trees were going to play at bowls with the stones-RRB-, and the whole house reposes on her (Rouncewell) mind. She (Rouncewell) can open it on occasion and be busy and fluttered, but it is shut up now and lies on the breadth of Mrs. Rouncewell's iron-bound bosom in a majestic sleep.

It is the next difficult thing to an impossibility to imagine Chesney Wold without Mrs. Rouncewell, but she (Rouncewell) has only been here fifty years. Ask her (Rouncewell) how long, this rainy day, and she (Rouncewell) shall answer

``fifty year, three months, and a fortnight, by the blessing of heaven, if I live till Tuesday.'' (she)
Mr. Rouncewell died some time before the decease of the pretty fashion of pig-tails, and modestly hid his (Rouncewell) own -LRB-if he (Rouncewell) took it with him (Rouncewell)-RRB- in a corner of the churchyard in the park near the mouldy porch. He (Rouncewell) was born in the market-town, and so was his (Rouncewell) young widow. Her (widow) progress in the family began in the time of the last Sir Leicester and originated in the still-room.

The present representative of the Dedlocks is an excellent master. He (master) supposes all his (master) dependents to be utterly bereft of individual characters, intentions, or opinions, and is persuaded that he (master) was born to supersede the necessity of their having any. If he (master) were to make a discovery to the contrary, he (master) would be simply stunned--would never recover himself, most likely, except to gasp and die. But he (master) is an excellent master still, holding it a part of his (master) state to be so. He (master) has a great liking for Mrs. Rouncewell; he (master) says she (Rouncewell) is a most respectable, creditable woman. He (master) always shakes hands with her (Rouncewell) when he (master) comes down to Chesney Wold and when he (Wold) goes away; and if he (Wold) were very ill, or if he (Wold) were knocked down by accident, or run over, or placed in any situation expressive of a Dedlock at a disadvantage, he (Wold) would say if he (Wold) could speak,

``Leave me, and send Mrs. Rouncewell here!'' (he)
feeling his (Wold) dignity, at such a pass, safer with her (Rouncewell) than with anybody else.

Mrs. Rouncewell has known trouble. She (Rouncewell) has had two sons, of whom the younger ran wild, and went for a soldier, and never came back. Even to this hour, Mrs. Rouncewell's calm hands lose their composure when she (Rouncewell) speaks of him (soldier), and unfolding themselves from her (Rouncewell) stomacher, hover about her (Rouncewell) in an agitated manner as she (Rouncewell) says what a likely lad, what a fine lad, what a gay, good-humoured, clever lad he (lad) was! Her (Rouncewell) second son would have been provided for at Chesney Wold and would have been made steward in due season, but he (Chesney) took, when he (Chesney) was a schoolboy, to constructing steam-engines out of saucepans and setting birds to draw their own water with the least possible amount of labour, so assisting them with artful contrivance of hydraulic pressure that a thirsty canary had only, in a literal sense, to put his (Chesney) shoulder to the wheel and the job was done. This propensity gave Mrs. Rouncewell great uneasiness. She (Rouncewell) felt it with a mother's anguish to be a move in the Wat Tyler direction, well knowing that Sir Leicester had that general impression of an aptitude for any art to which smoke and a tall chimney might be considered essential. But the doomed young rebel -LRB-otherwise a mild youth, and very persevering-RRB-, showing no sign of grace as he (rebel) got older but, on the contrary, constructing a model of a power-loom, she (Rouncewell) was fain, with many tears, to mention his (rebel) backslidings to the baronet.

``Mrs. Rouncewell,'' (unknown)
said Sir Leicester,
``I can never consent to argue, as you know, with any one on any subject. You had better get rid of your boy; you had better get him (boy) into some Works. The iron country farther north is, I suppose, the congenial direction for a boy with these tendencies.'' (he)
Farther north he (rebel) went, and farther north he (rebel) grew up; and if Sir Leicester Dedlock ever saw him (rebel) when he (rebel) came to Chesney Wold to visit his (Wold) mother, or ever thought of him (Wold) afterwards, it is certain that he (Wold) only regarded him (Wold) as one of a body of some odd thousand conspirators, swarthy and grim, who were in the habit of turning out by torchlight two or three nights in the week for unlawful purposes.

Nevertheless, Mrs. Rouncewell's son has, in the course of nature and art, grown up, and established himself, and married, and called unto him (son) Mrs. Rouncewell's grandson, who, being out of his (son) apprenticeship, and home from a journey in far countries, whither he (son) was sent to enlarge his (son) knowledge and complete his (son) preparations for the venture of this life, stands leaning against the chimney-piece this very day in Mrs. Rouncewell's room at Chesney Wold.

``And, again and again, I am glad to see you, Watt! And, once again, I am glad to see you, Watt!'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)
says Mrs. Rouncewell.
``You are a fine young fellow. You are like your poor uncle George. Ah!'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)
Mrs. Rouncewell's hands unquiet, as usual, on this reference.

``They say I am like my father, grandmother.'' (unknown)

``Like him (father), also, my dear--but most like your poor uncle George! And your dear father.'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)
Mrs. Rouncewell folds her (Rouncewell) hands again.
``He (father) is well?'' (unknown)

``Thriving, grandmother, in every way.'' (unknown)

``I am thankful!'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)
Mrs. Rouncewell is fond of her (Rouncewell) son but has a plaintive feeling towards him (son), much as if he (son) were a very honourable soldier who had gone over to the enemy.

``He (father) is quite happy?'' (she)
says she (Rouncewell).

``Quite.'' (unknown)

``I am thankful! So he (father) has brought you up to follow in his (father) ways and has sent you into foreign countries and the like? Well, he (father) knows best. There may be a world beyond Chesney Wold that I don't understand. Though I am not young, either. And I have seen a quantity of good company too!'' (unknown)

``Grandmother,'' (the man)
says the young man, changing the subject,
``what a very pretty girl that was I found with you just now. You called her (Grandmother) Rosa?'' (the man)

``Yes, child. She (Grandmother) is daughter of a widow in the village. Maids are so hard to teach, now-a-days, that I have put her (Grandmother) about me young. She (Grandmother)'s an apt scholar and will do well. She (Grandmother) shows the house already, very pretty. She (Grandmother) lives with me at my table here.'' (unknown)

``I hope I have not driven her (Grandmother) away?'' (unknown)

``She (Grandmother) supposes we have family affairs to speak about, I dare say. She (Grandmother) is very modest. It is a fine quality in a young woman. And scarcer,'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)
says Mrs. Rouncewell, expanding her (Rouncewell) stomacher to its utmost limits,
``than it formerly was!'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)

The young man inclines his (man) head in acknowledgment of the precepts of experience. Mrs. Rouncewell listens.

``Wheels!'' (she)
says she (Rouncewell). They have long been audible to the younger ears of her (Rouncewell) companion.
``What wheels on such a day as this, for gracious sake?'' (unknown)

After a short interval, a tap at the door.

``Come in!'' (unknown)
A dark-eyed, dark-haired, shy, village beauty comes in--so fresh in her (Rouncewell) rosy and yet delicate bloom that the drops of rain which have beaten on her (Rouncewell) hair look like the dew upon a flower fresh gathered.

``What company is this, Rosa?'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)
says Mrs. Rouncewell.

``It's two young men in a gig, ma'am, who want to see the house--yes, and if you please, I told them so!'' (the housekeeper)
in quick reply to a gesture of dissent from the housekeeper.
``I went to the hall-door and told them it was the wrong day and the wrong hour, but the young man who was driving took off his (man) hat in the wet and begged me to bring this card to you.'' (unknown)

``Read it, my dear Watt,'' (the housekeeper)
says the housekeeper.

Rosa is so shy as she (housekeeper) gives it to him (Rosa) that they drop it between them and almost knock their foreheads together as they pick it up. Rosa is shyer than before.

``Mr. Guppy'' (unknown)
is all the information the card yields.

``Guppy!'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)
repeats Mrs. Rouncewell,
``MR. Guppy! Nonsense, I never heard of him (Guppy)!'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)

``If you please, he (Guppy) told ME that!'' (Rosa)
says Rosa.
``But he (Guppy) said that he (Guppy) and the other young gentleman came from London only last night by the mail, on business at the magistrates' meeting, ten miles off, this morning, and that as their business was soon over, and they had heard a great deal said of Chesney Wold, and really didn't know what to do with themselves, they had come through the wet to see it. They are lawyers. He (Wold) says he (Wold) is not in Mr. Tulkinghorn's office, but he (Wold) is sure he (Wold) may make use of Mr. Tulkinghorn's name if necessary.'' (she)
Finding, now she (Rouncewell) leaves off, that she (Rouncewell) has been making quite a long speech, Rosa is shyer than ever.

Now, Mr. Tulkinghorn is, in a manner, part and parcel of the place, and besides, is supposed to have made Mrs. Rouncewell's will. The old lady relaxes, consents to the admission of the visitors as a favour, and dismisses Rosa. The grandson, however, being smitten by a sudden wish to see the house himself, proposes to join the party. The grandmother, who is pleased that he (Rosa) should have that interest, accompanies him (Rosa)--though to do him (Rosa) justice, he (Rosa) is exceedingly unwilling to trouble her (grandmother).

``Much obliged to you, ma'am!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy, divesting himself of his (Guppy) wet dreadnought in the hall.
``Us London lawyers don't often get an out, and when we do, we like to make the most of it, you know.'' (The housekeeper)

The old housekeeper, with a gracious severity of deportment, waves her (housekeeper) hand towards the great staircase. Mr. Guppy and his (Guppy) friend follow Rosa; Mrs. Rouncewell and her (Rouncewell) grandson follow them; a young gardener goes before to open the shutters.

As is usually the case with people who go over houses, Mr. Guppy and his (Guppy) friend are dead beat before they have well begun. They straggle about in wrong places, look at wrong things, don't care for the right things, gape when more rooms are opened, exhibit profound depression of spirits, and are clearly knocked up. In each successive chamber that they enter, Mrs. Rouncewell, who is as upright as the house itself, rests apart in a window-seat or other such nook and listens with stately approval to Rosa's exposition. Her (Rouncewell) grandson is so attentive to it that Rosa is shyer than ever--and prettier. Thus they pass on from room to room, raising the pictured Dedlocks for a few brief minutes as the young gardener admits the light, and reconsigning them to their graves as he (gardener) shuts it out again. It appears to the afflicted Mr. Guppy and his (Guppy) inconsolable friend that there is no end to the Dedlocks, whose family greatness seems to consist in their never having done anything to distinguish themselves for seven hundred years.

Even the long drawing-room of Chesney Wold cannot revive Mr. Guppy's spirits. He (Guppy) is so low that he (Guppy) droops on the threshold and has hardly strength of mind to enter. But a portrait over the chimney-piece, painted by the fashionable artist of the day, acts upon him (artist) like a charm. He (artist) recovers in a moment. He (artist) stares at it with uncommon interest; he (artist) seems to be fixed and fascinated by it.

``Dear me!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy.
``Who's that?'' (unknown)

``The picture over the fire-place,'' (Rosa)
says Rosa,
``is the portrait of the present Lady Dedlock. It is considered a perfect likeness, and the best work of the master.'' (Rosa)

``Blest,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy, staring in a kind of dismay at his (Guppy) friend,
``if I can ever have seen her (Lady). Yet I know her (Lady)! Has the picture been engraved, miss?'' (friend)

``The picture has never been engraved. Sir Leicester has always refused permission.'' (unknown)

``Well!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy in a low voice.
``I'll be shot if it ain't very curious how well I know that picture! So that's Lady Dedlock, is it!'' (unknown)

``The picture on the right is the present Sir Leicester Dedlock. The picture on the left is his (master) father, the late Sir Leicester.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Mr. Guppy has no eyes for either of these magnates.

``It's unaccountable to me,'' (he)
he (Guppy) says, still staring at the portrait,
``how well I know that picture! I'm dashed,'' (he)
adds Mr. Guppy, looking round,
``if I don't think I must have had a dream of that picture, you know!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

As no one present takes any especial interest in Mr. Guppy's dreams, the probability is not pursued. But he (Guppy) still remains so absorbed by the portrait that he (Guppy) stands immovable before it until the young gardener has closed the shutters, when he (gardener) comes out of the room in a dazed state that is an odd though a sufficient substitute for interest and follows into the succeeding rooms with a confused stare, as if he (gardener) were looking everywhere for Lady Dedlock again.

He (gardener) sees no more of her (Lady). He (gardener) sees her (Lady) rooms, which are the last shown, as being very elegant, and he (gardener) looks out of the windows from which she (Lady) looked out, not long ago, upon the weather that bored her (Lady) to death. All things have an end, even houses that people take infinite pains to see and are tired of before they begin to see them. He (gardener) has come to the end of the sight, and the fresh village beauty to the end of her (Lady) description; which is always this:

``The terrace below is much admired. It is called, from an old story in the family, the Ghost's Walk.'' (He)

``No?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy, greedily curious.
``What's the story, miss? Is it anything about a picture?'' (unknown)

``Pray tell us the story,'' (Watt)
says Watt in a half whisper.

``I don't know it, sir.'' (Rosa)
Rosa is shyer than ever.

``It is not related to visitors; it is almost forgotten,'' (the housekeeper)
says the housekeeper, advancing.
``It has never been more than a family anecdote.'' (unknown)

``You'll excuse my asking again if it has anything to do with a picture, ma'am,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
observes Mr. Guppy,
``because I do assure you that the more I think of that picture the better I know it, without knowing how I know it!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

The story has nothing to do with a picture; the housekeeper can guarantee that. Mr. Guppy is obliged to her (housekeeper) for the information and is, moreover, generally obliged. He (Guppy) retires with his (Guppy) friend, guided down another staircase by the young gardener, and presently is heard to drive away. It is now dusk. Mrs. Rouncewell can trust to the discretion of her (Rouncewell) two young hearers and may tell THEM how the terrace came to have that ghostly name.

She (Rouncewell) seats herself in a large chair by the fast-darkening window and tells them:

``In the wicked days, my dears, of King Charles the First--I mean, of course, in the wicked days of the rebels who leagued themselves against that excellent king--Sir Morbury Dedlock was the owner of Chesney Wold. Whether there was any account of a ghost in the family before those days, I can't say. I should think it very likely indeed.'' (She)

Mrs. Rouncewell holds this opinion because she (Rouncewell) considers that a family of such antiquity and importance has a right to a ghost. She (Rouncewell) regards a ghost as one of the privileges of the upper classes, a genteel distinction to which the common people have no claim.

``Sir Morbury Dedlock,'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)
says Mrs. Rouncewell,
``was, I have no occasion to say, on the side of the blessed martyr. But it IS supposed that his (martyr) Lady, who had none of the family blood in her (Lady) veins, favoured the bad cause. It is said that she (Lady) had relations among King Charles's enemies, that she (Lady) was in correspondence with them, and that she (Lady) gave them information. When any of the country gentlemen who followed his (King) Majesty's cause met here, it is said that my Lady was always nearer to the door of their council-room than they supposed. Do you hear a sound like a footstep passing along the terrace, Watt?'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)

Rosa draws nearer to the housekeeper.

``I hear the rain-drip on the stones,'' (the man)
replies the young man,
``and I hear a curious echo--I suppose an echo--which is very like a halting step.'' (the man)

The housekeeper gravely nods and continues:

``Partly on account of this division between them, and partly on other accounts, Sir Morbury and his (Watt) Lady led a troubled life. She (Lady) was a lady of a haughty temper. They were not well suited to each other in age or character, and they had no children to moderate between them. After her (Lady) favourite brother, a young gentleman, was killed in the civil wars -LRB-by Sir Morbury's near kinsman-RRB-, her (Lady) feeling was so violent that she (Lady) hated the race into which she (Lady) had married. When the Dedlocks were about to ride out from Chesney Wold in the king's cause, she (Lady) is supposed to have more than once stolen down into the stables in the dead of night and lamed their horses; and the story is that once at such an hour, her (Lady) husband saw her (Lady) gliding down the stairs and followed her (Lady) into the stall where his (husband) own favourite horse stood. There he (husband) seized her (Lady) by the wrist, and in a struggle or in a fall or through the horse being frightened and lashing out, she (Lady) was lamed in the hip and from that hour began to pine away.'' (The housekeeper)

The housekeeper has dropped her (housekeeper) voice to a little more than a whisper.

``She (Lady) had been a lady of a handsome figure and a noble carriage. She (Lady) never complained of the change; she (Lady) never spoke to any one of being crippled or of being in pain, but day by day she (Lady) tried to walk upon the terrace, and with the help of the stone balustrade, went up and down, up and down, up and down, in sun and shadow, with greater difficulty every day. At last, one afternoon her (Lady) husband -LRB-to whom she (Lady) had never, on any persuasion, opened her (Lady) lips since that night-RRB-, standing at the great south window, saw her (Lady) drop upon the pavement. He (husband) hastened down to raise her (Lady), but she (Lady) repulsed him (husband) as he (husband) bent over her (Lady), and looking at him (husband) fixedly and coldly, said,

``I will die here where I have walked. And I will walk here, though I am in my grave. I will walk here until the pride of this house is humbled. And when calamity or when disgrace is coming to it, let the Dedlocks listen for my step!''' (Watt)

Watt looks at Rosa. Rosa in the deepening gloom looks down upon the ground, half frightened and half shy.

``There and then she (Lady) died. And from those days,'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)
says Mrs. Rouncewell,
``the name has come down--the Ghost's Walk. If the tread is an echo, it is an echo that is only heard after dark, and is often unheard for a long while together. But it comes back from time to time; and so sure as there is sickness or death in the family, it will be heard then.'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)

``And disgrace, grandmother--'' (Watt)
says Watt.

``Disgrace never comes to Chesney Wold,'' (the housekeeper)
returns the housekeeper.

Her (Rouncewell) grandson apologizes with

``True. True.'' (grandson)

``That is the story. Whatever the sound is, it is a worrying sound,'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)
says Mrs. Rouncewell, getting up from her (Rouncewell) chair;
``and what is to be noticed in it is that it MUST BE HEARD. My Lady, who is afraid of nothing, admits that when it is there, it must be heard. You cannot shut it out. Watt, there is a tall French clock behind you -LRB-placed there, 'a purpose-RRB- that has a loud beat when it is in motion and can play music. You understand how those things are managed?'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)

``Pretty well, grandmother, I think.'' (unknown)

``Set it a-going.'' (Watt)

Watt sets it a-going--music and all.

``Now, come hither,'' (the housekeeper)
says the housekeeper.
``Hither, child, towards my Lady's pillow. I am not sure that it is dark enough yet, but listen! Can you hear the sound upon the terrace, through the music, and the beat, and everything?'' (unknown)

``I certainly can!'' (unknown)

``So my Lady says.'' (I)

CHAPTER VIII

Covering a Multitude of Sins

It was interesting when I dressed before daylight to peep out of window, where my candles were reflected in the black panes like two beacons, and finding all beyond still enshrouded in the indistinctness of last night, to watch how it turned out when the day came on. As the prospect gradually revealed itself and disclosed the scene over which the wind had wandered in the dark, like my memory over my life, I had a pleasure in discovering the unknown objects that had been around me in my sleep. At first they were faintly discernible in the mist, and above them the later stars still glimmered. That pale interval over, the picture began to enlarge and fill up so fast that at every new peep I could have found enough to look at for an hour. Imperceptibly my candles became the only incongruous part of the morning, the dark places in my room all melted away, and the day shone bright upon a cheerful landscape, prominent in which the old Abbey Church, with its massive tower, threw a softer train of shadow on the view than seemed compatible with its rugged character. But so from rough outsides -LRB-I hope I have learnt-RRB-, serene and gentle influences often proceed.

Every part of the house was in such order, and every one was so attentive to me, that I had no trouble with my two bunches of keys, though what with trying to remember the contents of each little store-room drawer and cupboard; and what with making notes on a slate about jams, and pickles, and preserves, and bottles, and glass, and china, and a great many other things; and what with being generally a methodical, old-maidish sort of foolish little person, I was so busy that I could not believe it was breakfast-time when I heard the bell ring. Away I ran, however, and made tea, as I had already been installed into the responsibility of the tea-pot; and then, as they were all rather late and nobody was down yet, I thought I would take a peep at the garden and get some knowledge of that too. I found it quite a delightful place--in front, the pretty avenue and drive by which we had approached -LRB-and where, by the by, we had cut up the gravel so terribly with our wheels that I asked the gardener to roll it-RRB-; at the back, the flower-garden, with my darling at her (it) window up there, throwing it open to smile out at me, as if she (it) would have kissed me from that distance. Beyond the flower-garden was a kitchen-garden, and then a paddock, and then a snug little rick-yard, and then a dear little farm-yard. As to the house itself, with its three peaks in the roof; its various-shaped windows, some so large, some so small, and all so pretty; its trellis-work, against the south-front for roses and honey-suckle, and its homely, comfortable, welcoming look--it was, as Ada said when she (Ada) came out to meet me with her (Ada) arm through that of its master, worthy of her (Ada) cousin John, a bold thing to say, though he (John) only pinched her (Ada) dear cheek for it.

Mr. Skimpole was as agreeable at breakfast as he (Skimpole) had been overnight. There was honey on the table, and it led him (Skimpole) into a discourse about bees. He (Skimpole) had no objection to honey, he (Skimpole) said -LRB-and I should think he (Skimpole) had not, for he (Skimpole) seemed to like it-RRB-, but he (Skimpole) protested against the overweening assumptions of bees. He (Skimpole) didn't at all see why the busy bee should be proposed as a model to him (Skimpole); he (Skimpole) supposed the bee liked to make honey, or he (Skimpole) wouldn't do it--nobody asked him (Skimpole). It was not necessary for the bee to make such a merit of his (Skimpole) tastes. If every confectioner went buzzing about the world banging against everything that came in his (Skimpole) way and egotistically calling upon everybody to take notice that he (Skimpole) was going to his (Skimpole) work and must not be interrupted, the world would be quite an unsupportable place. Then, after all, it was a ridiculous position to be smoked out of your fortune with brimstone as soon as you had made it. You would have a very mean opinion of a Manchester man if he (man) spun cotton for no other purpose. He (man) must say he (man) thought a drone the embodiment of a pleasanter and wiser idea. The drone said unaffectedly,

``You will excuse me; I really cannot attend to the shop! I find myself in a world in which there is so much to see and so short a time to see it in that I must take the liberty of looking about me and begging to be provided for by somebody who doesn't want to look about him (I).'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
This appeared to Mr. Skimpole to be the drone philosophy, and he (Skimpole) thought it a very good philosophy, always supposing the drone to be willing to be on good terms with the bee, which, so far as he (Skimpole) knew, the easy fellow always was, if the consequential creature would only let him (Skimpole), and not be so conceited about his (Skimpole) honey!

He (Skimpole) pursued this fancy with the lightest foot over a variety of ground and made us all merry, though again he (Skimpole) seemed to have as serious a meaning in what he (Skimpole) said as he (Skimpole) was capable of having. I left them still listening to him (Skimpole) when I withdrew to attend to my new duties. They had occupied me for some time, and I was passing through the passages on my return with my basket of keys on my arm when Mr. Jarndyce called me into a small room next his (Jarndyce) bed-chamber, which I found to be in part a little library of books and papers and in part quite a little museum of his (Jarndyce) boots and shoes and hat-boxes.

``Sit down, my dear,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce.
``This, you must know, is the growlery. When I am out of humour, I come and growl here.'' (unknown)

``You must be here very seldom, sir,'' (I.)
said I.

``Oh, you don't know me!'' (I.)
he (Jarndyce) returned.
``When I am deceived or disappointed in--the wind, and it's easterly, I take refuge here. The growlery is the best-used room in the house. You are not aware of half my humours yet. My dear, how you are trembling!'' (I)

I could not help it; I tried very hard, but being alone with that benevolent presence, and meeting his (Jarndyce) kind eyes, and feeling so happy and so honoured there, and my heart so full--I kissed his (Jarndyce) hand. I don't know what I said, or even that I spoke. He (Jarndyce) was disconcerted and walked to the window; I almost believed with an intention of jumping out, until he (Jarndyce) turned and I was reassured by seeing in his (Jarndyce) eyes what he (Jarndyce) had gone there to hide. He (Jarndyce) gently patted me on the head, and I sat down.

``There! There!'' (he)
he (Jarndyce) said.
``That's over. Pooh! Don't be foolish.'' (unknown)

``It shall not happen again, sir,'' (I)
I returned,
``but at first it is difficult--'' (I)

``Nonsense!'' (I)
he (Jarndyce) said.
``It's easy, easy. Why not? I hear of a good little orphan girl without a protector, and I take it into my head to be that protector. She (girl) grows up, and more than justifies my good opinion, and I remain her (girl) guardian and her (girl) friend. What is there in all this? So, so! Now, we have cleared off old scores, and I have before me thy pleasant, trusting, trusty face again.'' (I)

I said to myself,

``Esther, my dear, you surprise me! This really is not what I expected of you!'' (I)
And it had such a good effect that I folded my hands upon my basket and quite recovered myself.
