But, when I went upstairs to my own room, I surprised myself by beginning to laugh about it and then surprised myself still more by beginning to cry about it. In short, I was in a flutter for a little while and felt as if an old chord had been more coarsely touched than it ever had been since the days of the dear old doll, long buried in the garden.

CHAPTER X

The Law-Writer

On the eastern borders of Chancery Lane, that is to say, more particularly in Cook's Court, Cursitor Street, Mr. Snagsby, law-stationer, pursues his (Snagsby) lawful calling. In the shade of Cook's Court, at most times a shady place, Mr. Snagsby has dealt in all sorts of blank forms of legal process; in skins and rolls of parchment; in paper--foolscap, brief, draft, brown, white, whitey-brown, and blotting; in stamps; in office-quills, pens, ink, India-rubber, pounce, pins, pencils, sealing-wax, and wafers; in red tape and green ferret; in pocket-books, almanacs, diaries, and law lists; in string boxes, rulers, inkstands--glass and leaden--pen-knives, scissors, bodkins, and other small office-cutlery; in short, in articles too numerous to mention, ever since he (rulers) was out of his (rulers) time and went into partnership with Peffer. On that occasion, Cook's Court was in a manner revolutionized by the new inscription in fresh paint, PEFFER AND SNAGSBY, displacing the time-honoured and not easily to be deciphered legend PEFFER only. For smoke, which is the London ivy, had so wreathed itself round Peffer's name and clung to his (Cook) dwelling-place that the affectionate parasite quite overpowered the parent tree.

Peffer is never seen in Cook's Court now. He (Cook) is not expected there, for he (Cook) has been recumbent this quarter of a century in the churchyard of St. Andrews, Holborn, with the waggons and hackney-coaches roaring past him (Andrews) all the day and half the night like one great dragon. If he (Andrews) ever steal forth when the dragon is at rest to air himself again in Cook's Court until admonished to return by the crowing of the sanguine cock in the cellar at the little dairy in Cursitor Street, whose ideas of daylight it would be curious to ascertain, since he (Cook) knows from his (Cook) personal observation next to nothing about it--if Peffer ever do revisit the pale glimpses of Cook's Court, which no law-stationer in the trade can positively deny, he (Cook) comes invisibly, and no one is the worse or wiser.

In his (Cook) lifetime, and likewise in the period of Snagsby's

``time'' (Peffer/PEFFER)
of seven long years, there dwelt with Peffer in the same law-stationering premises a niece--a short, shrewd niece, something too violently compressed about the waist, and with a sharp nose like a sharp autumn evening, inclining to be frosty towards the end. The Cook's Courtiers had a rumour flying among them that the mother of this niece did, in her (mother) daughter's childhood, moved by too jealous a solicitude that her (mother) figure should approach perfection, lace her (mother) up every morning with her (mother) maternal foot against the bed-post for a stronger hold and purchase; and further, that she (mother) exhibited internally pints of vinegar and lemon-juice, which acids, they held, had mounted to the nose and temper of the patient. With whichsoever of the many tongues of Rumour this frothy report originated, it either never reached or never influenced the ears of young Snagsby, who, having wooed and won its fair subject on his (Snagsby) arrival at man's estate, entered into two partnerships at once. So now, in Cook's Court, Cursitor Street, Mr. Snagsby and the niece are one; and the niece still cherishes her (niece) figure, which, however tastes may differ, is unquestionably so far precious that there is mighty little of it.

Mr. and Mrs. Snagsby are not only one bone and one flesh, but, to the neighbours' thinking, one voice too. That voice, appearing to proceed from Mrs. Snagsby alone, is heard in Cook's Court very often. Mr. Snagsby, otherwise than as he (Snagsby) finds expression through these dulcet tones, is rarely heard. He (Snagsby) is a mild, bald, timid man with a shining head and a scrubby clump of black hair sticking out at the back. He (Snagsby) tends to meekness and obesity. As he (Snagsby) stands at his (Snagsby) door in Cook's Court in his (Cook) grey shop-coat and black calico sleeves, looking up at the clouds, or stands behind a desk in his (Cook) dark shop with a heavy flat ruler, snipping and slicing at sheepskin in company with his (Cook) two `prentices, he (Cook) is emphatically a retiring and unassuming man. From beneath his (Cook) feet, at such times, as from a shrill ghost unquiet in its grave, there frequently arise complainings and lamentations in the voice already mentioned; and haply, on some occasions when these reach a sharper pitch than usual, Mr. Snagsby mentions to the `prentices,

``I think my little woman is a-giving it to Guster!'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

This proper name, so used by Mr. Snagsby, has before now sharpened the wit of the Cook's Courtiers to remark that it ought to be the name of Mrs. Snagsby, seeing that she (Snagsby) might with great force and expression be termed a Guster, in compliment to her (Snagsby) stormy character. It is, however, the possession, and the only possession except fifty shillings per annum and a very small box indifferently filled with clothing, of a lean young woman from a workhouse -LRB-by some supposed to have been christened Augusta-RRB- who, although she (woman) was farmed or contracted for during her (woman) growing time by an amiable benefactor of his (benefactor) species resident at Tooting, and cannot fail to have been developed under the most favourable circumstances,

``has fits,'' (species resident)
which the parish can't account for.

Guster, really aged three or four and twenty, but looking a round ten years older, goes cheap with this unaccountable drawback of fits, and is so apprehensive of being returned on the hands of her (woman) patron saint that except when she (woman) is found with her (woman) head in the pail, or the sink, or the copper, or the dinner, or anything else that happens to be near her (woman) at the time of her (woman) seizure, she (woman) is always at work. She (woman) is a satisfaction to the parents and guardians of the `prentices, who feel that there is little danger of her (woman) inspiring tender emotions in the breast of youth; she (woman) is a satisfaction to Mrs. Snagsby, who can always find fault with her (Snagsby); she (Snagsby) is a satisfaction to Mr. Snagsby, who thinks it a charity to keep her (Snagsby). The law-stationer's establishment is, in Guster's eyes, a temple of plenty and splendour. She (Snagsby) believes the little drawing-room upstairs, always kept, as one may say, with its hair in papers and its pinafore on, to be the most elegant apartment in Christendom. The view it commands of Cook's Court at one end -LRB-not to mention a squint into Cursitor Street-RRB- and of Coavinses' the sheriff's officer's backyard at the other she (Snagsby) regards as a prospect of unequalled beauty. The portraits it displays in oil--and plenty of it too--of Mr. Snagsby looking at Mrs. Snagsby and of Mrs. Snagsby looking at Mr. Snagsby are in her (Snagsby) eyes as achievements of Raphael or Titian. Guster has some recompenses for her (Snagsby) many privations.

Mr. Snagsby refers everything not in the practical mysteries of the business to Mrs. Snagsby. She (Snagsby) manages the money, reproaches the tax-gatherers, appoints the times and places of devotion on Sundays, licenses Mr. Snagsby's entertainments, and acknowledges no responsibility as to what she (Snagsby) thinks fit to provide for dinner, insomuch that she (Snagsby) is the high standard of comparison among the neighbouring wives a long way down Chancery Lane on both sides, and even out in Holborn, who in any domestic passages of arms habitually call upon their husbands to look at the difference between their -LRB-the wives'-RRB- position and Mrs. Snagsby's, and their -LRB-the husbands'-RRB- behaviour and Mr. Snagsby's. Rumour, always flying bat-like about Cook's Court and skimming in and out at everybody's windows, does say that Mrs. Snagsby is jealous and inquisitive and that Mr. Snagsby is sometimes worried out of house and home, and that if he (Snagsby) had the spirit of a mouse he (Snagsby) wouldn't stand it. It is even observed that the wives who quote him (Snagsby) to their self-willed husbands as a shining example in reality look down upon him (Snagsby) and that nobody does so with greater superciliousness than one particular lady whose lord is more than suspected of laying his (lord) umbrella on her (lady) as an instrument of correction. But these vague whisperings may arise from Mr. Snagsby's being in his (Snagsby) way rather a meditative and poetical man, loving to walk in Staple Inn in the summer-time and to observe how countrified the sparrows and the leaves are, also to lounge about the Rolls Yard of a Sunday afternoon and to remark -LRB-if in good spirits-RRB- that there were old times once and that you'd find a stone coffin or two now under that chapel, he (Snagsby)'ll be bound, if you was to dig for it. He (Snagsby) solaces his (Snagsby) imagination, too, by thinking of the many Chancellors and Vices, and Masters of the Rolls who are deceased; and he (Snagsby) gets such a flavour of the country out of telling the two `prentices how he (Snagsby) HAS heard say that a brook

``as clear as crystial'' (he)
once ran right down the middle of Holborn, when Turnstile really was a turnstile, leading slap away into the meadows--gets such a flavour of the country out of this that he (Snagsby) never wants to go there.

The day is closing in and the gas is lighted, but is not yet fully effective, for it is not quite dark. Mr. Snagsby standing at his (Snagsby) shop-door looking up at the clouds sees a crow who is out late skim westward over the slice of sky belonging to Cook's Court. The crow flies straight across Chancery Lane and Lincoln's Inn Garden into Lincoln's Inn Fields.

Here, in a large house, formerly a house of state, lives Mr. Tulkinghorn. It is let off in sets of chambers now, and in those shrunken fragments of its greatness, lawyers lie like maggots in nuts. But its roomy staircases, passages, and antechambers still remain; and even its painted ceilings, where Allegory, in Roman helmet and celestial linen, sprawls among balustrades and pillars, flowers, clouds, and big-legged boys, and makes the head ache--as would seem to be Allegory's object always, more or less. Here, among his (Roman) many boxes labelled with transcendent names, lives Mr. Tulkinghorn, when not speechlessly at home in country-houses where the great ones of the earth are bored to death. Here he (Tulkinghorn) is to-day, quiet at his (Tulkinghorn) table. An oyster of the old school whom nobody can open.

Like as he (Tulkinghorn) is to look at, so is his (Tulkinghorn) apartment in the dusk of the present afternoon. Rusty, out of date, withdrawing from attention, able to afford it. Heavy, broad-backed, old-fashioned, mahogany-and-horsehair chairs, not easily lifted; obsolete tables with spindle-legs and dusty baize covers; presentation prints of the holders of great titles in the last generation or the last but one, environ him (Rusty). A thick and dingy Turkey-carpet muffles the floor where he (Rusty) sits, attended by two candles in old-fashioned silver candlesticks that give a very insufficient light to his (Rusty) large room. The titles on the backs of his (Rusty) books have retired into the binding; everything that can have a lock has got one; no key is visible. Very few loose papers are about. He (Rusty) has some manuscript near him (Rusty), but is not referring to it. With the round top of an inkstand and two broken bits of sealing-wax he (Rusty) is silently and slowly working out whatever train of indecision is in his (Rusty) mind. Now the inkstand top is in the middle, now the red bit of sealing-wax, now the black bit. That's not it. Mr. Tulkinghorn must gather them all up and begin again.

Here, beneath the painted ceiling, with foreshortened Allegory staring down at his (Tulkinghorn) intrusion as if it meant to swoop upon him (Tulkinghorn), and he (Tulkinghorn) cutting it dead, Mr. Tulkinghorn has at once his (Tulkinghorn) house and office. He (Tulkinghorn) keeps no staff, only one middle-aged man, usually a little out at elbows, who sits in a high pew in the hall and is rarely overburdened with business. Mr. Tulkinghorn is not in a common way. He (Tulkinghorn) wants no clerks. He (Tulkinghorn) is a great reservoir of confidences, not to be so tapped. His (Tulkinghorn) clients want HIM; he (Tulkinghorn) is all in all. Drafts that he (Tulkinghorn) requires to be drawn are drawn by special-pleaders in the temple on mysterious instructions; fair copies that he (Tulkinghorn) requires to be made are made at the stationers', expense being no consideration. The middle-aged man in the pew knows scarcely more of the affairs of the peerage than any crossing-sweeper in Holborn.

The red bit, the black bit, the inkstand top, the other inkstand top, the little sand-box. So! You to the middle, you to the right, you to the left. This train of indecision must surely be worked out now or never. Now! Mr. Tulkinghorn gets up, adjusts his (Tulkinghorn) spectacles, puts on his (Tulkinghorn) hat, puts the manuscript in his (Tulkinghorn) pocket, goes out, tells the middle-aged man out at elbows,

``I shall be back presently.'' (the man)
Very rarely tells him (Tulkinghorn) anything more explicit.

Mr. Tulkinghorn goes, as the crow came--not quite so straight, but nearly--to Cook's Court, Cursitor Street. To Snagsby's, Law-Stationer's, Deeds engrossed and copied, Law-Writing executed in all its branches, &c., &c., &c.

It is somewhere about five or six o'clock in the afternoon, and a balmy fragrance of warm tea hovers in Cook's Court. It hovers about Snagsby's door. The hours are early there: dinner at half-past one and supper at half-past nine. Mr. Snagsby was about to descend into the subterranean regions to take tea when he (Snagsby) looked out of his (Snagsby) door just now and saw the crow who was out late.

``Master at home?'' (Guster)

Guster is minding the shop, for the `prentices take tea in the kitchen with Mr. and Mrs. Snagsby; consequently, the robe-maker's two daughters, combing their curls at the two glasses in the two second-floor windows of the opposite house, are not driving the two `prentices to distraction as they fondly suppose, but are merely awakening the unprofitable admiration of Guster, whose hair won't grow, and never would, and it is confidently thought, never will.

``Master at home?'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn.

Master is at home, and Guster will fetch him (Tulkinghorn). Guster disappears, glad to get out of the shop, which she (Mr.) regards with mingled dread and veneration as a storehouse of awful implements of the great torture of the law--a place not to be entered after the gas is turned off.

Mr. Snagsby appears, greasy, warm, herbaceous, and chewing. Bolts a bit of bread and butter. Says,

``Bless my soul, sir! Mr. Tulkinghorn!'' (unknown)

``I want half a word with you, Snagsby.'' (unknown)

``Certainly, sir! Dear me, sir, why didn't you send your young man round for me? Pray walk into the back shop, sir.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
Snagsby has brightened in a moment.

The confined room, strong of parchment-grease, is warehouse, counting-house, and copying-office. Mr. Tulkinghorn sits, facing round, on a stool at the desk.

``Jarndyce and Jarndyce, Snagsby.'' (unknown)

``Yes, sir.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
Mr. Snagsby turns up the gas and coughs behind his (Snagsby) hand, modestly anticipating profit. Mr. Snagsby, as a timid man, is accustomed to cough with a variety of expressions, and so to save words.

``You copied some affidavits in that cause for me lately.'' (unknown)

``Yes, sir, we did.'' (unknown)

``There was one of them,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn, carelessly feeling--tight, unopenable oyster of the old school!--in the wrong coat-pocket,
``the handwriting of which is peculiar, and I rather like. As I happened to be passing, and thought I had it about me, I looked in to ask you--but I haven't got it. No matter, any other time will do. Ah! here it is! I looked in to ask you who copied this.'' (unknown)

``Who copied this, sir?'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby, taking it, laying it flat on the desk, and separating all the sheets at once with a twirl and a twist of the left hand peculiar to lawstationers.
``We gave this out, sir. We were giving out rather a large quantity of work just at that time. I can tell you in a moment who copied it, sir, by referring to my book.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

Mr. Snagsby takes his (Snagsby) book down from the safe, makes another bolt of the bit of bread and butter which seemed to have stopped short, eyes the affidavit aside, and brings his (Snagsby) right forefinger travelling down a page of the book,

``Jewby--Packer--Jarndyce.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``Jarndyce! Here we are, sir,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby.
``To be sure! I might have remembered it. This was given out, sir, to a writer who lodges just over on the opposite side of the lane.'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

Mr. Tulkinghorn has seen the entry, found it before the law-stationer, read it while the forefinger was coming down the hill.

``WHAT do you call him (writer)? Nemo?'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn.
``Nemo, sir. Here it is. Forty-two folio. Given out on the Wednesday night at eight o'clock, brought in on the Thursday morning at half after nine.'' (unknown)

``Nemo!'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
repeats Mr. Tulkinghorn.
``Nemo is Latin for no one.'' (unknown)

``It must be English for some one, sir, I think,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
Mr. Snagsby submits with his (Snagsby) deferential cough.
``It is a person's name. Here it is, you see, sir! Forty-two folio. Given out Wednesday night, eight o'clock; brought in Thursday morning, half after nine.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

The tail of Mr. Snagsby's eye becomes conscious of the head of Mrs. Snagsby looking in at the shop-door to know what he (Snagsby) means by deserting his (Snagsby) tea. Mr. Snagsby addresses an explanatory cough to Mrs. Snagsby, as who should say,

``My dear, a customer!'' (Mrs. Snagsby)

``Half after nine, sir,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
repeats Mr. Snagsby.
``Our law-writers, who live by job-work, are a queer lot; and this may not be his (Nemo) name, but it's the name he (Nemo) goes by. I remember now, sir, that he (Nemo) gives it in a written advertisement he (Nemo) sticks up down at the Rule Office, and the King's Bench Office, and the Judges' Chambers, and so forth. You know the kind of document, sir--wanting employ?'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

Mr. Tulkinghorn glances through the little window at the back of Coavinses', the sheriff's officer's, where lights shine in Coavinses' windows. Coavinses' coffee-room is at the back, and the shadows of several gentlemen under a cloud loom cloudily upon the blinds. Mr. Snagsby takes the opportunity of slightly turning his (Snagsby) head to glance over his (Snagsby) shoulder at his (Snagsby) little woman and to make apologetic motions with his (Snagsby) mouth to this effect:

``Tul-king-horn--rich--in-flu-en-tial!'' (woman)

``Have you given this man work before?'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
asks Mr. Tulkinghorn.

``Oh, dear, yes, sir! Work of yours.'' (unknown)

``Thinking of more important matters, I forget where you said he (man) lived?'' (unknown)

``Across the lane, sir. In fact, he (man) lodges at a--'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
Mr. Snagsby makes another bolt, as if the bit of bread and buffer were insurmountable
''--at a rag and bottle shop.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``Can you show me the place as I go back?'' (unknown)

``With the greatest pleasure, sir!'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

Mr. Snagsby pulls off his (Snagsby) sleeves and his (Snagsby) grey coat, pulls on his (Snagsby) black coat, takes his (Snagsby) hat from its peg.

``Oh! Here is my little woman!'' (he)
he (Snagsby) says aloud.
``My dear, will you be so kind as to tell one of the lads to look after the shop while I step across the lane with Mr. Tulkinghorn? Mrs. Snagsby, sir--I shan't be two minutes, my love!'' (Mrs. Snagsby)

Mrs. Snagsby bends to the lawyer, retires behind the counter, peeps at them through the window-blind, goes softly into the back office, refers to the entries in the book still lying open. Is evidently curious.

``You will find that the place is rough, sir,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby, walking deferentially in the road and leaving the narrow pavement to the lawyer;
``and the party is very rough. But they're a wild lot in general, sir. The advantage of this particular man is that he (man) never wants sleep. He (man)'ll go at it right on end if you want him (man) to, as long as ever you like.'' (the lawyer)

It is quite dark now, and the gas-lamps have acquired their full effect. Jostling against clerks going to post the day's letters, and against counsel and attorneys going home to dinner, and against plaintiffs and defendants and suitors of all sorts, and against the general crowd, in whose way the forensic wisdom of ages has interposed a million of obstacles to the transaction of the commonest business of life; diving through law and equity, and through that kindred mystery, the street mud, which is made of nobody knows what and collects about us nobody knows whence or how--we only knowing in general that when there is too much of it we find it necessary to shovel it away--the lawyer and the law-stationer come to a rag and bottle shop and general emporium of much disregarded merchandise, lying and being in the shadow of the wall of Lincoln's Inn, and kept, as is announced in paint, to all whom it may concern, by one Krook.

``This is where he (man) lives, sir,'' (unknown)
says the law-stationer.

``This is where he (man) lives, is it?'' (the lawyer)
says the lawyer unconcernedly.
``Thank you.'' (unknown)

``Are you not going in, sir?'' (unknown)

``No, thank you, no; I am going on to the Fields at present. Good evening. Thank you!'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
Mr. Snagsby lifts his (Snagsby) hat and returns to his (Snagsby) little woman and his (Snagsby) tea.

But Mr. Tulkinghorn does not go on to the Fields at present. He (Tulkinghorn) goes a short way, turns back, comes again to the shop of Mr. Krook, and enters it straight. It is dim enough, with a blot-headed candle or so in the windows, and an old man and a cat sitting in the back part by a fire. The old man rises and comes forward, with another blot-headed candle in his (man) hand.

``Pray is your lodger within?'' (unknown)

``Male or female, sir?'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
says Mr. Krook.

``Male. The person who does copying.'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)

Mr. Krook has eyed his (Krook) man narrowly. Knows him (Krook) by sight. Has an indistinct impression of his (Krook) aristocratic repute.

``Did you wish to see him (Male), sir?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``It's what I seldom do myself,'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
says Mr. Krook with a grin.
``Shall I call him (Male) down? But it's a weak chance if he (Male)'d come, sir!'' (unknown)

``I'll go up to him (Male), then,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn.

``Second floor, sir. Take the candle. Up there!'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
Mr. Krook, with his (Krook) cat beside him (Krook), stands at the bottom of the staircase, looking after Mr. Tulkinghorn.
``Hi-hi!'' (he)
he (Tulkinghorn) says when Mr. Tulkinghorn has nearly disappeared. The lawyer looks down over the hand-rail. The cat expands her (lawyer) wicked mouth and snarls at him (Tulkinghorn).

``Order, Lady Jane! Behave yourself to visitors, my lady! You know what they say of my lodger?'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
whispers Krook, going up a step or two.

``What do they say of him (Male)?'' (unknown)

``They say he (Male) has sold himself to the enemy, but you and I know better--he (Male) don't buy. I'll tell you what, though; my lodger is so black-humoured and gloomy that I believe he (Male)'d as soon make that bargain as any other. Don't put him (Male) out, sir. That's my advice!'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

Mr. Tulkinghorn with a nod goes on his (Tulkinghorn) way. He (Tulkinghorn) comes to the dark door on the second floor. He (Tulkinghorn) knocks, receives no answer, opens it, and accidentally extinguishes his (Tulkinghorn) candle in doing so.

The air of the room is almost bad enough to have extinguished it if he (Tulkinghorn) had not. It is a small room, nearly black with soot, and grease, and dirt. In the rusty skeleton of a grate, pinched at the middle as if poverty had gripped it, a red coke fire burns low. In the corner by the chimney stand a deal table and a broken desk, a wilderness marked with a rain of ink. In another corner a ragged old portmanteau on one of the two chairs serves for cabinet or wardrobe; no larger one is needed, for it collapses like the cheeks of a starved man. The floor is bare, except that one old mat, trodden to shreds of rope-yarn, lies perishing upon the hearth. No curtain veils the darkness of the night, but the discoloured shutters are drawn together, and through the two gaunt holes pierced in them, famine might be staring in--the banshee of the man upon the bed.

For, on a low bed opposite the fire, a confusion of dirty patchwork, lean-ribbed ticking, and coarse sacking, the lawyer, hesitating just within the doorway, sees a man. He (man) lies there, dressed in shirt and trousers, with bare feet. He (man) has a yellow look in the spectral darkness of a candle that has guttered down until the whole length of its wick -LRB-still burning-RRB- has doubled over and left a tower of winding-sheet above it. His (man) hair is ragged, mingling with his (man) whiskers and his (man) beard--the latter, ragged too, and grown, like the scum and mist around him (man), in neglect. Foul and filthy as the room is, foul and filthy as the air is, it is not easy to perceive what fumes those are which most oppress the senses in it; but through the general sickliness and faintness, and the odour of stale tobacco, there comes into the lawyer's mouth the bitter, vapid taste of opium.

``Hallo, my friend!'' (he)
he (lawyer) cries, and strikes his (lawyer) iron candlestick against the door.

He (lawyer) thinks he (lawyer) has awakened his (lawyer) friend. He (lawyer) lies a little turned away, but his (lawyer) eyes are surely open.

``Hallo, my friend!'' (he)
he (lawyer) cries again.
``Hallo! Hallo!'' (he)

As he (lawyer) rattles on the door, the candle which has drooped so long goes out and leaves him (lawyer) in the dark, with the gaunt eyes in the shutters staring down upon the bed.

CHAPTER XI

Our Dear Brother

A touch on the lawyer's wrinkled hand as he (Brother) stands in the dark room, irresolute, makes him (Brother) start and say,

``What's that?'' (him)

``It's me,'' (the man)
returns the old man of the house, whose breath is in his (Brother) ear.
``Can't you wake him (friend)?'' (unknown)

``No.'' (unknown)

``What have you done with your candle?'' (unknown)

``It's gone out. Here it is.'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)

Krook takes it, goes to the fire, stoops over the red embers, and tries to get a light. The dying ashes have no light to spare, and his (Krook) endeavours are vain. Muttering, after an ineffectual call to his (Krook) lodger, that he (Krook) will go downstairs and bring a lighted candle from the shop, the old man departs. Mr. Tulkinghorn, for some new reason that he (Tulkinghorn) has, does not await his (Tulkinghorn) return in the room, but on the stairs outside.

The welcome light soon shines upon the wall, as Krook comes slowly up with his (Krook) green-eyed cat following at his (Krook) heels.

``Does the man generally sleep like this?'' (the lawyer)
inquired the lawyer in a low voice.
``Hi! I don't know,'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
says Krook, shaking his (Krook) head and lifting his (Krook) eyebrows.
``I know next to nothing of his (man) habits except that he (man) keeps himself very close.'' (unknown)

Thus whispering, they both go in together. As the light goes in, the great eyes in the shutters, darkening, seem to close. Not so the eyes upon the bed.

``God save us!'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
exclaims Mr. Tulkinghorn.
``He (God) is dead!'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
Krook drops the heavy hand he (Krook) has taken up so suddenly that the arm swings over the bedside.

They look at one another for a moment.

``Send for some doctor! Call for Miss Flite up the stairs, sir. Here's poison by the bed! Call out for Flite, will you?'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
says Krook, with his (Krook) lean hands spread out above the body like a vampire's wings.

Mr. Tulkinghorn hurries to the landing and calls,

``Miss Flite! Flite! Make haste, here, whoever you are! Flite!'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
Krook follows him (Krook) with his (Krook) eyes, and while he (Krook) is calling, finds opportunity to steal to the old portmanteau and steal back again.

``Run, Flite, run! The nearest doctor! Run!'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
So Mr. Krook addresses a crazy little woman who is his (Krook) female lodger, who appears and vanishes in a breath, who soon returns accompanied by a testy medical man brought from his (man) dinner, with a broad, snuffy upper lip and a broad Scotch tongue.

``Ey! Bless the hearts o' ye,'' (the man)
says the medical man, looking up at them after a moment's examination.
``He (doctor)'s just as dead as Phairy!'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

Mr. Tulkinghorn -LRB-standing by the old portmanteau-RRB- inquires if he (Tulkinghorn) has been dead any time.

``Any time, sir?'' (the gentleman)
says the medical gentleman.
``It's probable he (doctor) wull have been dead aboot three hours.'' (unknown)

``About that time, I should say,'' (a man)
observes a dark young man on the other side of the bed.

``Air you in the maydickle prayfession yourself, sir?'' (unknown)
inquires the first.

The dark young man says yes.

``Then I'll just tak' my depairture,'' (unknown)
replies the other,
``for I'm nae gude here!'' (he)
With which remark he (man) finishes his (man) brief attendance and returns to finish his (man) dinner.

The dark young surgeon passes the candle across and across the face and carefully examines the law-writer, who has established his (man) pretensions to his (man) name by becoming indeed No one.

``I knew this person by sight very well,'' (he)
says he (man).
``He (doctor) has purchased opium of me for the last year and a half. Was anybody present related to him (doctor)?'' (the bystanders)
glancing round upon the three bystanders.

``I was his (doctor) landlord,'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
grimly answers Krook, taking the candle from the surgeon's outstretched hand.
``He (doctor) told me once I was the nearest relation he (doctor) had.'' (unknown)

``He (doctor) has died,'' (the surgeon)
says the surgeon,
``of an over-dose of opium, there is no doubt. The room is strongly flavoured with it. There is enough here now,'' (the surgeon)
taking an old tea-pot from Mr. Krook,
``to kill a dozen people.'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)

``Do you think he (doctor) did it on purpose?'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
asks Krook.

``Took the over-dose?'' (unknown)

``Yes!'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
Krook almost smacks his (Krook) lips with the unction of a horrible interest.

``I can't say. I should think it unlikely, as he (doctor) has been in the habit of taking so much. But nobody can tell. He (doctor) was very poor, I suppose?'' (unknown)

``I suppose he (doctor) was. His (doctor) room--don't look rich,'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
says Krook, who might have changed eyes with his (Krook) cat, as he (Krook) casts his (Krook) sharp glance around.
``But I have never been in it since he (doctor) had it, and he (doctor) was too close to name his (doctor) circumstances to me.'' (unknown)

``Did he (doctor) owe you any rent?'' (unknown)

``Six weeks.'' (unknown)

``He (doctor) will never pay it!'' (the man)
says the young man, resuming his (man) examination.
``It is beyond a doubt that he (doctor) is indeed as dead as Pharaoh; and to judge from his (Pharaoh) appearance and condition, I should think it a happy release. Yet he (Pharaoh) must have been a good figure when a youth, and I dare say, good-looking.'' (He)
He (man) says this, not unfeelingly, while sitting on the bedstead's edge with his (man) face towards that other face and his (man) hand upon the region of the heart.
``I recollect once thinking there was something in his (Pharaoh) manner, uncouth as it was, that denoted a fall in life. Was that so?'' (he)
he (man) continues, looking round.

Krook replies,

``You might as well ask me to describe the ladies whose heads of hair I have got in sacks downstairs. Than that he (Pharaoh) was my lodger for a year and a half and lived--or didn't live--by law-writing, I know no more of him (Pharaoh).'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)

During this dialogue Mr. Tulkinghorn has stood aloof by the old portmanteau, with his (Tulkinghorn) hands behind him (Tulkinghorn), equally removed, to all appearance, from all three kinds of interest exhibited near the bed--from the young surgeon's professional interest in death, noticeable as being quite apart from his (surgeon) remarks on the deceased as an individual; from the old man's unction; and the little crazy woman's awe. His (surgeon) imperturbable face has been as inexpressive as his (surgeon) rusty clothes. One could not even say he (surgeon) has been thinking all this while. He (surgeon) has shown neither patience nor impatience, nor attention nor abstraction. He (surgeon) has shown nothing but his (surgeon) shell. As easily might the tone of a delicate musical instrument be inferred from its case, as the tone of Mr. Tulkinghorn from his (Tulkinghorn) case.

He (Tulkinghorn) now interposes, addressing the young surgeon in his (Tulkinghorn) unmoved, professional way.

``I looked in here,'' (he)
he (Tulkinghorn) observes,
``just before you, with the intention of giving this deceased man, whom I never saw alive, some employment at his (man) trade of copying. I had heard of him (man) from my stationer--Snagsby of Cook's Court. Since no one here knows anything about him (Cook), it might be as well to send for Snagsby. Ah!'' (he)
to the little crazy woman, who has often seen him (Tulkinghorn) in court, and whom he (Tulkinghorn) has often seen, and who proposes, in frightened dumb-show, to go for the law-stationer.
``Suppose you do!'' (she)

While she (woman) is gone, the surgeon abandons his (surgeon) hopeless investigation and covers its subject with the patchwork counterpane. Mr. Krook and he (Krook) interchange a word or two. Mr. Tulkinghorn says nothing, but stands, ever, near the old portmanteau.

Mr. Snagsby arrives hastily in his (Snagsby) grey coat and his (Snagsby) black sleeves.

``Dear me, dear me,'' (he)
he (Snagsby) says;
``and it has come to this, has it! Bless my soul!'' (he)

``Can you give the person of the house any information about this unfortunate creature, Snagsby?'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
inquires Mr. Tulkinghorn.
``He (Cook) was in arrears with his (Cook) rent, it seems. And he (Cook) must be buried, you know.'' (unknown)

``Well, sir,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby, coughing his (Snagsby) apologetic cough behind his (Snagsby) hand,
``I really don't know what advice I could offer, except sending for the beadle.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``I don't speak of advice,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
returns Mr. Tulkinghorn.
``I could advise--'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``No one better, sir, I am sure,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby, with his (Snagsby) deferential cough.

``I speak of affording some clue to his (beadle) connexions, or to where he (beadle) came from, or to anything concerning him (beadle).'' (unknown)

``I assure you, sir,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby after prefacing his (Snagsby) reply with his (Snagsby) cough of general propitiation,
``that I no more know where he (beadle) came from than I know--'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``Where he (beadle) has gone to, perhaps,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
suggests the surgeon to help him (Snagsby) out.

A pause. Mr. Tulkinghorn looking at the law-stationer. Mr. Krook, with his (Krook) mouth open, looking for somebody to speak next.

``As to his (beadle) connexions, sir,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby, ``if a person was to say to me, ``Snagsby, here's twenty thousand pound down, ready for you in the Bank of England if you'll only name one of
``em,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
I couldn't do it, sir! About a year and a half ago--to the best of my belief, at the time when he (Snagsby) first came to lodge at the present rag and bottle shop--''

``That was the time!'' (he)
says Krook with a nod.

``About a year and a half ago,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby, strengthened,
``he (beadle) came into our place one morning after breakfast, and finding my little woman -LRB-which I name Mrs. Snagsby when I use that appellation-RRB- in our shop, produced a specimen of his (beadle) handwriting and gave her (Snagsby) to understand that he (beadle) was in want of copying work to do and was, not to put too fine a point upon it,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
a favourite apology for plain speaking with Mr. Snagsby, which he (Snagsby) always offers with a sort of argumentative frankness,
``hard up! My little woman is not in general partial to strangers, particular--not to put too fine a point upon it--when they want anything. But she (woman) was rather took by something about this person, whether by his (beadle) being unshaved, or by his (beadle) hair being in want of attention, or by what other ladies' reasons, I leave you to judge; and she (woman) accepted of the specimen, and likewise of the address. My little woman hasn't a good ear for names,'' (he)
proceeds Mr. Snagsby after consulting his (Snagsby) cough of consideration behind his (Snagsby) hand, ``and she (woman) considered Nemo equally the same as Nimrod. In consequence of which, she (woman) got into a habit of saying to me at meals, ``Mr. Snagsby, you haven't found Nimrod any work yet!'' or ``Mr. Snagsby, why didn't you give that eight and thirty Chancery folio in Jarndyce to Nimrod?
'' or such like. And that is the way he (Snagsby) gradually fell into job-work at our place; and that is the most I know of him (Snagsby) except that he (Snagsby) was a quick hand, and a hand not sparing of night-work, and that if you gave him (Snagsby) out, say, five and forty folio on the Wednesday night, you would have it brought in on the Thursday morning. All of which--'' (Nimrod)
Mr. Snagsby concludes by politely motioning with his (Snagsby) hat towards the bed, as much as to add,
``I have no doubt my honourable friend would confirm if he (friend) were in a condition to do it.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``Hadn't you better see,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn to Krook,
``whether he (friend) had any papers that may enlighten you? There will be an inquest, and you will be asked the question. You can read?'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)

``No, I can't,'' (the man)
returns the old man with a sudden grin.

``Snagsby,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn,
``look over the room for him (friend). He (friend) will get into some trouble or difficulty otherwise. Being here, I'll wait if you make haste, and then I can testify on his (friend) behalf, if it should ever be necessary, that all was fair and right. If you will hold the candle for Mr. Snagsby, my friend, he (Snagsby)'ll soon see whether there is anything to help you.'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

``In the first place, here's an old portmanteau, sir,'' (unknown)
says Snagsby.

Ah, to be sure, so there is! Mr. Tulkinghorn does not appear to have seen it before, though he (Tulkinghorn) is standing so close to it, and though there is very little else, heaven knows.

The marine-store merchant holds the light, and the law-stationer conducts the search. The surgeon leans against the corner of the chimney-piece; Miss Flite peeps and trembles just within the door. The apt old scholar of the old school, with his (scholar) dull black breeches tied with ribbons at the knees, his (scholar) large black waistcoat, his (scholar) long-sleeved black coat, and his (scholar) wisp of limp white neckerchief tied in the bow the peerage knows so well, stands in exactly the same place and attitude.

There are some worthless articles of clothing in the old portmanteau; there is a bundle of pawnbrokers' duplicates, those turnpike tickets on the road of poverty; there is a crumpled paper, smelling of opium, on which are scrawled rough memoranda--as, took, such a day, so many grains; took, such another day, so many more--begun some time ago, as if with the intention of being regularly continued, but soon left off. There are a few dirty scraps of newspapers, all referring to coroners' inquests; there is nothing else. They search the cupboard and the drawer of the ink-splashed table. There is not a morsel of an old letter or of any other writing in either. The young surgeon examines the dress on the law-writer. A knife and some odd halfpence are all he (surgeon) finds. Mr. Snagsby's suggestion is the practical suggestion after all, and the beadle must be called in.

So the little crazy lodger goes for the beadle, and the rest come out of the room.

``Don't leave the cat there!'' (the surgeon)
says the surgeon;
``that won't do!'' (the surgeon)
Mr. Krook therefore drives her (They) out before him (Krook), and she (They) goes furtively downstairs, winding her (They) lithe tail and licking her (They) lips.

``Good night!'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn, and goes home to Allegory and meditation.

By this time the news has got into the court. Groups of its inhabitants assemble to discuss the thing, and the outposts of the army of observation -LRB-principally boys-RRB- are pushed forward to Mr. Krook's window, which they closely invest. A policeman has already walked up to the room, and walked down again to the door, where he (policeman) stands like a tower, only condescending to see the boys at his (policeman) base occasionally; but whenever he (policeman) does see them, they quail and fall back. Mrs. Perkins, who has not been for some weeks on speaking terms with Mrs. Piper in consequence for an unpleasantness originating in young Perkins' having

``fetched'' (Mrs. Perkins/Perkins)
young Piper
``a crack,'' (Mrs. Piper/Piper)
renews her (Piper) friendly intercourse on this auspicious occasion. The potboy at the corner, who is a privileged amateur, as possessing official knowledge of life and having to deal with drunken men occasionally, exchanges confidential communications with the policeman and has the appearance of an impregnable youth, unassailable by truncheons and unconfinable in station-houses. People talk across the court out of window, and bare-headed scouts come hurrying in from Chancery Lane to know what's the matter. The general feeling seems to be that it's a blessing Mr. Krook warn't made away with first, mingled with a little natural disappointment that he (Krook) was not. In the midst of this sensation, the beadle arrives.

The beadle, though generally understood in the neighbourhood to be a ridiculous institution, is not without a certain popularity for the moment, if it were only as a man who is going to see the body. The policeman considers him (policeman) an imbecile civilian, a remnant of the barbarous watchmen times, but gives him (policeman) admission as something that must be borne with until government shall abolish him (policeman). The sensation is heightened as the tidings spread from mouth to mouth that the beadle is on the ground and has gone in.

By and by the beadle comes out, once more intensifying the sensation, which has rather languished in the interval. He (beadle) is understood to be in want of witnesses for the inquest to-morrow who can tell the coroner and jury anything whatever respecting the deceased. Is immediately referred to innumerable people who can tell nothing whatever. Is made more imbecile by being constantly informed that Mrs. Green's son

``was a law-writer his-self and knowed him (Snagsby) better than anybody,'' (Green son)
which son of Mrs. Green's appears, on inquiry, to be at the present time aboard a vessel bound for China, three months out, but considered accessible by telegraph on application to the Lords of the Admiralty. Beadle goes into various shops and parlours, examining the inhabitants, always shutting the door first, and by exclusion, delay, and general idiotcy exasperating the public. Policeman seen to smile to potboy. Public loses interest and undergoes reaction. Taunts the beadle in shrill youthful voices with having boiled a boy, choruses fragments of a popular song to that effect and importing that the boy was made into soup for the workhouse. Policeman at last finds it necessary to support the law and seize a vocalist, who is released upon the flight of the rest on condition of his (Policeman) getting out of this then, come, and cutting it--a condition he (Policeman) immediately observes. So the sensation dies off for the time; and the unmoved policeman -LRB-to whom a little opium, more or less, is nothing-RRB-, with his (policeman) shining hat, stiff stock, inflexible great-coat, stout belt and bracelet, and all things fitting, pursues his (policeman) lounging way with a heavy tread, beating the palms of his (policeman) white gloves one against the other and stopping now and then at a street-corner to look casually about for anything between a lost child and a murder.

Under cover of the night, the feeble-minded beadle comes flitting about Chancery Lane with his (beadle) summonses, in which every juror's name is wrongly spelt, and nothing rightly spelt but the beadle's own name, which nobody can read or wants to know. The summonses served and his (beadle) witnesses forewarned, the beadle goes to Mr. Krook's to keep a small appointment he (beadle) has made with certain paupers, who, presently arriving, are conducted upstairs, where they leave the great eyes in the shutter something new to stare at, in that last shape which earthly lodgings take for No one--and for Every one.

And all that night the coffin stands ready by the old portmanteau; and the lonely figure on the bed, whose path in life has lain through five and forty years, lies there with no more track behind him (beadle) that any one can trace than a deserted infant.

Next day the court is all alive--is like a fair, as Mrs. Perkins, more than reconciled to Mrs. Piper, says in amicable conversation with that excellent woman. The coroner is to sit in the first-floor room at the Sol's Arms, where the Harmonic Meetings take place twice a week and where the chair is filled by a gentleman of professional celebrity, faced by Little Swills, the comic vocalist, who hopes -LRB-according to the bill in the window-RRB- that his (celebrity) friends will rally round him (celebrity) and support first-rate talent. The Sol's Arms does a brisk stroke of business all the morning. Even children so require sustaining under the general excitement that a pieman who has established himself for the occasion at the corner of the court says his (Sol) brandy-balls go off like smoke. What time the beadle, hovering between the door of Mr. Krook's establishment and the door of the Sol's Arms, shows the curiosity in his (Sol) keeping to a few discreet spirits and accepts the compliment of a glass of ale or so in return.

At the appointed hour arrives the coroner, for whom the jurymen are waiting and who is received with a salute of skittles from the good dry skittle-ground attached to the Sol's Arms. The coroner frequents more public-houses than any man alive. The smell of sawdust, beer, tobacco-smoke, and spirits is inseparable in his (coroner) vocation from death in its most awful shapes. He (coroner) is conducted by the beadle and the landlord to the Harmonic Meeting Room, where he (coroner) puts his (coroner) hat on the piano and takes a Windsor-chair at the head of a long table formed of several short tables put together and ornamented with glutinous rings in endless involutions, made by pots and glasses. As many of the jury as can crowd together at the table sit there. The rest get among the spittoons and pipes or lean against the piano. Over the coroner's head is a small iron garland, the pendant handle of a bell, which rather gives the majesty of the court the appearance of going to be hanged presently.

Call over and swear the jury! While the ceremony is in progress, sensation is created by the entrance of a chubby little man in a large shirt-collar, with a moist eye and an inflamed nose, who modestly takes a position near the door as one of the general public, but seems familiar with the room too. A whisper circulates that this is Little Swills. It is considered not unlikely that he (man) will get up an imitation of the coroner and make it the principal feature of the Harmonic Meeting in the evening.

``Well, gentlemen--'' (the coroner)
the coroner begins.

``Silence there, will you!'' (the beadle)
says the beadle. Not to the coroner, though it might appear so.

``Well, gentlemen,'' (the coroner)
resumes the coroner.
``You are impanelled here to inquire into the death of a certain man. Evidence will be given before you as to the circumstances attending that death, and you will give your verdict according to the--skittles; they must be stopped, you know, beadle!--evidence, and not according to anything else. The first thing to be done is to view the body.'' (unknown)

``Make way there!'' (the beadle)
cries the beadle.

So they go out in a loose procession, something after the manner of a straggling funeral, and make their inspection in Mr. Krook's back second floor, from which a few of the jurymen retire pale and precipitately. The beadle is very careful that two gentlemen not very neat about the cuffs and buttons -LRB-for whose accommodation he (beadle) has provided a special little table near the coroner in the Harmonic Meeting Room-RRB- should see all that is to be seen. For they are the public chroniclers of such inquiries by the line; and he (coroner) is not superior to the universal human infirmity, but hopes to read in print what

``Mooney, the active and intelligent beadle of the district,'' (he)
said and did and even aspires to see the name of Mooney as familiarly and patronizingly mentioned as the name of the hangman is, according to the latest examples.

Little Swills is waiting for the coroner and jury on their return. Mr. Tulkinghorn, also. Mr. Tulkinghorn is received with distinction and seated near the coroner between that high judicial officer, a bagatelle-board, and the coal-box. The inquiry proceeds. The jury learn how the subject of their inquiry died, and learn no more about him (coroner).

``A very eminent solicitor is in attendance, gentlemen,'' (the coroner)
says the coroner,
``who, I am informed, was accidentally present when discovery of the death was made, but he (solicitor) could only repeat the evidence you have already heard from the surgeon, the landlord, the lodger, and the law-stationer, and it is not necessary to trouble him (solicitor). Is anybody in attendance who knows anything more?'' (the coroner)

Mrs. Piper pushed forward by Mrs. Perkins. Mrs. Piper sworn.

Anastasia Piper, gentlemen. Married woman. Now, Mrs. Piper, what have you got to say about this?

Why, Mrs. Piper has a good deal to say, chiefly in parentheses and without punctuation, but not much to tell. Mrs. Piper lives in the court -LRB-which her (Piper) husband is a cabinet-maker-RRB-, and it has long been well beknown among the neighbours -LRB-counting from the day next but one before the half-baptizing of Alexander James Piper aged eighteen months and four days old on accounts of not being expected to live such was the sufferings gentlemen of that child in his (Piper) gums-RRB- as the plaintive--so Mrs. Piper insists on calling the deceased--was reported to have sold himself. Thinks it was the plaintive's air in which that report originatinin. See the plaintive often and considered as his (Piper) air was feariocious and not to be allowed to go about some children being timid -LRB-and if doubted hoping Mrs. Perkins may be brought forard for she (Perkins) is here and will do credit to her (Perkins) husband and herself and family-RRB-. Has seen the plaintive wexed and worrited by the children -LRB-for children they will ever be and you cannot expect them specially if of playful dispositions to be Methoozellers which you was not yourself-RRB-. On accounts of this and his (husband) dark looks has often dreamed as she (Perkins) see him (husband) take a pick-axe from his (husband) pocket and split Johnny's head -LRB-which the child knows not fear and has repeatually called after him (husband) close at his (husband) eels-RRB-. Never however see the plaintive take a pick-axe or any other wepping far from it. Has seen him (husband) hurry away when run and called after as if not partial to children and never see him (husband) speak to neither child nor grown person at any time -LRB-excepting the boy that sweeps the crossing down the lane over the way round the corner which if he (husband) was here would tell you that he (husband) has been seen a-speaking to him (husband) frequent-RRB-.

Says the coroner, is that boy here? Says the beadle, no, sir, he (beadle) is not here. Says the coroner, go and fetch him (beadle) then. In the absence of the active and intelligent, the coroner converses with Mr. Tulkinghorn.

Oh! Here's the boy, gentlemen!

Here he (boy) is, very muddy, very hoarse, very ragged. Now, boy! But stop a minute. Caution. This boy must be put through a few preliminary paces.

Name, Jo. Nothing else that he (boy) knows on. Don't know that everybody has two names. Never heerd of sich a think. Don't know that Jo is short for a longer name. Thinks it long enough for HIM. HE (boy) don't find no fault with it. Spell it? No. HE (boy) can't spell it. No father, no mother, no friends. Never been to school. What's home? Knows a broom's a broom, and knows it's wicked to tell a lie. Don't recollect who told him (boy) about the broom or about the lie, but knows both. Can't exactly say what'll be done to him (boy) arter he (boy)'s dead if he (boy) tells a lie to the gentlemen here, but believes it'll be something wery bad to punish him (boy), and serve him (boy) right--and so he (boy)'ll tell the truth.

``This won't do, gentlemen!'' (the coroner)
says the coroner with a melancholy shake of the head.

``Don't you think you can receive his (solicitor) evidence, sir?'' (an juryman)
asks an attentive juryman.

``Out of the question,'' (the coroner)
says the coroner. ``You have heard the boy.
``Can't exactly say' won't do, you know. We can't take THAT in a court of justice, gentlemen. It's terrible depravity. Put the boy aside.'' (Boy)

Boy put aside, to the great edification of the audience, especially of Little Swills, the comic vocalist.

Now. Is there any other witness? No other witness.

Very well, gentlemen! Here's a man unknown, proved to have been in the habit of taking opium in large quantities for a year and a half, found dead of too much opium. If you think you have any evidence to lead you to the conclusion that he (man) committed suicide, you will come to that conclusion. If you think it is a case of accidental death, you will find a verdict accordingly.

Verdict accordingly. Accidental death. No doubt. Gentlemen, you are discharged. Good afternoon.

While the coroner buttons his (coroner) great-coat, Mr. Tulkinghorn and he (coroner) give private audience to the rejected witness in a corner.

That graceless creature only knows that the dead man -LRB-whom he (man) recognized just now by his (man) yellow face and black hair-RRB- was sometimes hooted and pursued about the streets. That one cold winter night when he (man), the boy, was shivering in a doorway near his (boy) crossing, the man turned to look at him (boy), and came back, and having questioned him (boy) and found that he (boy) had not a friend in the world, said,

``Neither have I. Not one!'' (a friend)
and gave him (boy) the price of a supper and a night's lodging. That the man had often spoken to him (man) since and asked him (man) whether he (man) slept sound at night, and how he (man) bore cold and hunger, and whether he (man) ever wished to die, and similar strange questions. That when the man had no money, he (man) would say in passing,
``I am as poor as you to-day, Jo,'' (he)
but that when he (man) had any, he (man) had always -LRB-as the boy most heartily believes-RRB- been glad to give him (boy) some.

``He (boy) was wery good to me,'' (the boy)
says the boy, wiping his (boy) eyes with his (boy) wretched sleeve.
``Wen I see him (Wen) a-layin' so stritched out just now, I wished he (Wen) could have heerd me tell him (Wen) so. He (Wen) wos wery good to me, he (Wen) wos!'' (he)

As he (boy) shuffles downstairs, Mr. Snagsby, lying in wait for him (Snagsby), puts a half-crown in his (Snagsby) hand.

``If you ever see me coming past your crossing with my little woman--I mean a lady--'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby with his (Snagsby) finger on his (Snagsby) nose,
``don't allude to it!'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

For some little time the jurymen hang about the Sol's Arms colloquially. In the sequel, half-a-dozen are caught up in a cloud of pipe-smoke that pervades the parlour of the Sol's Arms; two stroll to Hampstead; and four engage to go half-price to the play at night, and top up with oysters. Little Swills is treated on several hands. Being asked what he (Sol) thinks of the proceedings, characterizes them -LRB-his (Sol) strength lying in a slangular direction-RRB- as

``a rummy start.'' (he)
The landlord of the Sol's Arms, finding Little Swills so popular, commends him (Sol) highly to the jurymen and public, observing that for a song in character he (character) don't know his (character) equal and that that man's character-wardrobe would fill a cart.

Thus, gradually the Sol's Arms melts into the shadowy night and then flares out of it strong in gas. The Harmonic Meeting hour arriving, the gentleman of professional celebrity takes the chair, is faced -LRB-red-faced-RRB- by Little Swills; their friends rally round them and support first-rate talent. In the zenith of the evening, Little Swills says,

``Gentlemen, if you'll permit me, I'll attempt a short description of a scene of real life that came off here to-day.'' (unknown)
Is much applauded and encouraged; goes out of the room as Swills; comes in as the coroner -LRB-not the least in the world like him (coroner)-RRB-; describes the inquest, with recreative intervals of piano-forte accompaniment, to the refrain: With his (coroner) -LRB-the coroner's-RRB- tippy tol li doll, tippy tol lo doll, tippy tol li doll, Dee!

The jingling piano at last is silent, and the Harmonic friends rally round their pillows. Then there is rest around the lonely figure, now laid in its last earthly habitation; and it is watched by the gaunt eyes in the shutters through some quiet hours of night. If this forlorn man could have been prophetically seen lying here by the mother at whose breast he (man) nestled, a little child, with eyes upraised to her (mother) loving face, and soft hand scarcely knowing how to close upon the neck to which it crept, what an impossibility the vision would have seemed! Oh, if in brighter days the now-extinguished fire within him (man) ever burned for one woman who held him (man) in her (woman) heart, where is she (woman), while these ashes are above the ground!

It is anything but a night of rest at Mr. Snagsby's, in Cook's Court, where Guster murders sleep by going, as Mr. Snagsby himself allows--not to put too fine a point upon it--out of one fit into twenty. The occasion of this seizure is that Guster has a tender heart and a susceptible something that possibly might have been imagination, but for Tooting and her (woman) patron saint. Be it what it may, now, it was so direfully impressed at tea-time by Mr. Snagsby's account of the inquiry at which he (Snagsby) had assisted that at supper-time she (woman) projected herself into the kitchen, preceded by a flying Dutch cheese, and fell into a fit of unusual duration, which she (woman) only came out of to go into another, and another, and so on through a chain of fits, with short intervals between, of which she (woman) has pathetically availed herself by consuming them in entreaties to Mrs. Snagsby not to give her (Snagsby) warning

``when she (lady) quite comes to,'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
and also in appeals to the whole establishment to lay her (Snagsby) down on the stones and go to bed. Hence, Mr. Snagsby, at last hearing the cock at the little dairy in Cursitor Street go into that disinterested ecstasy of his (Snagsby) on the subject of daylight, says, drawing a long breath, though the most patient of men,
``I thought you was dead, I am sure!'' (men)

What question this enthusiastic fowl supposes he (Snagsby) settles when he (Snagsby) strains himself to such an extent, or why he (Snagsby) should thus crow -LRB-so men crow on various triumphant public occasions, however-RRB- about what cannot be of any moment to him (Snagsby), is his (Snagsby) affair. It is enough that daylight comes, morning comes, noon comes.

Then the active and intelligent, who has got into the morning papers as such, comes with his (Snagsby) pauper company to Mr. Krook's and bears off the body of our dear brother here departed to a hemmed-in churchyard, pestiferous and obscene, whence malignant diseases are communicated to the bodies of our dear brothers and sisters who have not departed, while our dear brothers and sisters who hang about official back-stairs--would to heaven they HAD departed!--are very complacent and agreeable. Into a beastly scrap of ground which a Turk would reject as a savage abomination and a Caffre would shudder at, they bring our dear brother here departed to receive Christian burial.

With houses looking on, on every side, save where a reeking little tunnel of a court gives access to the iron gate--with every villainy of life in action close on death, and every poisonous element of death in action close on life--here they lower our dear brother down a foot or two, here sow him (brother) in corruption, to be raised in corruption: an avenging ghost at many a sick-bedside, a shameful testimony to future ages how civilization and barbarism walked this boastful island together.

Come night, come darkness, for you cannot come too soon or stay too long by such a place as this! Come, straggling lights into the windows of the ugly houses; and you who do iniquity therein, do it at least with this dread scene shut out! Come, flame of gas, burning so sullenly above the iron gate, on which the poisoned air deposits its witch-ointment slimy to the touch! It is well that you should call to every passerby,

``Look here!'' (every passerby)

With the night comes a slouching figure through the tunnel-court to the outside of the iron gate. It holds the gate with its hands and looks in between the bars, stands looking in for a little while.

It then, with an old broom it carries, softly sweeps the step and makes the archway clean. It does so very busily and trimly, looks in again a little while, and so departs.

Jo, is it thou? Well, well! Though a rejected witness, who

``can't exactly say'' (a witness)
what will be done to him (witness) in greater hands than men's, thou art not quite in outer darkness. There is something like a distant ray of light in thy muttered reason for this:
``He (Wen) wos wery good to me, he (Wen) wos!'' (Chesney Wold)

CHAPTER XII

On the Watch

It has left off raining down in Lincolnshire at last, and Chesney Wold has taken heart. Mrs. Rouncewell is full of hospitable cares, for Sir Leicester and my Lady are coming home from Paris. The fashionable intelligence has found it out and communicates the glad tidings to benighted England. It has also found out that they will entertain a brilliant and distinguished circle of the ELITE of the BEAU MONDE -LRB-the fashionable intelligence is weak in English, but a giant refreshed in French-RRB- at the ancient and hospitable family seat in Lincolnshire.

For the greater honour of the brilliant and distinguished circle, and of Chesney Wold into the bargain, the broken arch of the bridge in the park is mended; and the water, now retired within its proper limits and again spanned gracefully, makes a figure in the prospect from the house. The clear, cold sunshine glances into the brittle woods and approvingly beholds the sharp wind scattering the leaves and drying the moss. It glides over the park after the moving shadows of the clouds, and chases them, and never catches them, all day. It looks in at the windows and touches the ancestral portraits with bars and patches of brightness never contemplated by the painters. Athwart the picture of my Lady, over the great chimney-piece, it throws a broad bend-sinister of light that strikes down crookedly into the hearth and seems to rend it.

Through the same cold sunshine and the same sharp wind, my Lady and Sir Leicester, in their travelling chariot -LRB-my Lady's woman and Sir Leicester's man affectionate in the rumble-RRB-, start for home. With a considerable amount of jingling and whip-cracking, and many plunging demonstrations on the part of two bare-backed horses and two centaurs with glazed hats, jack-boots, and flowing manes and tails, they rattle out of the yard of the Hotel Bristol in the Place Vendome and canter between the sun-and-shadow-chequered colonnade of the Rue de Rivoli and the garden of the ill-fated palace of a headless king and queen, off by the Place of Concord, and the Elysian Fields, and the Gate of the Star, out of Paris.

Sooth to say, they cannot go away too fast, for even here my Lady Dedlock has been bored to death. Concert, assembly, opera, theatre, drive, nothing is new to my Lady under the worn-out heavens. Only last Sunday, when poor wretches were gay--within the walls playing with children among the clipped trees and the statues in the Palace Garden; walking, a score abreast, in the Elysian Fields, made more Elysian by performing dogs and wooden horses; between whiles filtering -LRB-a few-RRB- through the gloomy Cathedral of Our Lady to say a word or two at the base of a pillar within flare of a rusty little gridiron-full of gusty little tapers; without the walls encompassing Paris with dancing, love-making, wine-drinking, tobacco-smoking, tomb-visiting, billiard card and domino playing, quack-doctoring, and much murderous refuse, animate and inanimate--only last Sunday, my Lady, in the desolation of Boredom and the clutch of Giant Despair, almost hated her (Lady) own maid for being in spirits.

She (Lady) cannot, therefore, go too fast from Paris. Weariness of soul lies before her (Lady), as it lies behind--her (Lady) Ariel has put a girdle of it round the whole earth, and it cannot be unclasped--but the imperfect remedy is always to fly from the last place where it has been experienced. Fling Paris back into the distance, then, exchanging it for endless avenues and cross-avenues of wintry trees! And, when next beheld, let it be some leagues away, with the Gate of the Star a white speck glittering in the sun, and the city a mere mound in a plain--two dark square towers rising out of it, and light and shadow descending on it aslant, like the angels in Jacob's dream!

Sir Leicester is generally in a complacent state, and rarely bored. When he (Jacob) has nothing else to do, he (Jacob) can always contemplate his (Jacob) own greatness. It is a considerable advantage to a man to have so inexhaustible a subject. After reading his (Jacob) letters, he (Jacob) leans back in his (Jacob) corner of the carriage and generally reviews his (Jacob) importance to society.

``You have an unusual amount of correspondence this morning?'' (Lady)
says my Lady after a long time. She (Lady) is fatigued with reading. Has almost read a page in twenty miles.

``Nothing in it, though. Nothing whatever.'' (unknown)

``I saw one of Mr. Tulkinghorn's long effusions, I think?'' (unknown)

``You see everything,'' (unknown)
says Sir Leicester with admiration.

``Ha!'' (sighs Lady)
sighs my Lady.
``He (Tulkinghorn) is the most tiresome of men!'' (unknown)

``He (Tulkinghorn) sends--I really beg your pardon--he (Tulkinghorn) sends,'' (unknown)
says Sir Leicester, selecting the letter and unfolding it,
``a message to you. Our stopping to change horses as I came to his (Tulkinghorn) postscript drove it out of my memory. I beg you'll excuse me. He (Tulkinghorn) says--'' (Lady)
Sir Leicester is so long in taking out his (Jacob) eye-glass and adjusting it that my Lady looks a little irritated. ``He (Tulkinghorn) says ``In the matter of the right of way--' I beg your pardon, that's not the place. He (Tulkinghorn) says--yes! Here I have it! He (Tulkinghorn) says,
``I beg my respectful compliments to my Lady, who, I hope, has benefited by the change. Will you do me the favour to mention -LRB-as it may interest her (Lady)-RRB- that I have something to tell her (Lady) on her (Lady) return in reference to the person who copied the affidavit in the Chancery suit, which so powerfully stimulated her (Lady) curiosity. I have seen him (Tulkinghorn).''' (He)

My Lady, leaning forward, looks out of her (Lady) window.

``That's the message,'' (unknown)
observes Sir Leicester.

``I should like to walk a little,'' (Lady)
says my Lady, still looking out of her (Lady) window.

``Walk?'' (unknown)
repeats Sir Leicester in a tone of surprise.

``I should like to walk a little,'' (Lady)
says my Lady with unmistakable distinctness.
``Please to stop the carriage.'' (man)

The carriage is stopped, the affectionate man alights from the rumble, opens the door, and lets down the steps, obedient to an impatient motion of my Lady's hand. My Lady alights so quickly and walks away so quickly that Sir Leicester, for all his (man) scrupulous politeness, is unable to assist her (Lady), and is left behind. A space of a minute or two has elapsed before he (man) comes up with her (Lady). She (Lady) smiles, looks very handsome, takes his (man) arm, lounges with him (man) for a quarter of a mile, is very much bored, and resumes her (Lady) seat in the carriage.

The rattle and clatter continue through the greater part of three days, with more or less of bell-jingling and whip-cracking, and more or less plunging of centaurs and bare-backed horses. Their courtly politeness to each other at the hotels where they tarry is the theme of general admiration. Though my Lord IS a little aged for my Lady, says Madame, the hostess of the Golden Ape, and though he (Golden) might be her (Lady) amiable father, one can see at a glance that they love each other. One observes my Lord with his (Lord) white hair, standing, hat in hand, to help my Lady to and from the carriage. One observes my Lady, how recognisant of my Lord's politeness, with an inclination of her (Lady) gracious head and the concession of her (Lady) so-genteel fingers! It is ravishing!

The sea has no appreciation of great men, but knocks them about like the small fry. It is habitually hard upon Sir Leicester, whose countenance it greenly mottles in the manner of sage-cheese and in whose aristocratic system it effects a dismal revolution. It is the Radical of Nature to him (Radical). Nevertheless, his (Radical) dignity gets over it after stopping to refit, and he (Radical) goes on with my Lady for Chesney Wold, lying only one night in London on the way to Lincolnshire.

Through the same cold sunlight, colder as the day declines, and through the same sharp wind, sharper as the separate shadows of bare trees gloom together in the woods, and as the Ghost's Walk, touched at the western corner by a pile of fire in the sky, resigns itself to coming night, they drive into the park. The rooks, swinging in their lofty houses in the elm-tree avenue, seem to discuss the question of the occupancy of the carriage as it passes underneath, some agreeing that Sir Leicester and my Lady are come down, some arguing with malcontents who won't admit it, now all consenting to consider the question disposed of, now all breaking out again in violent debate, incited by one obstinate and drowsy bird who will persist in putting in a last contradictory croak. Leaving them to swing and caw, the travelling chariot rolls on to the house, where fires gleam warmly through some of the windows, though not through so many as to give an inhabited expression to the darkening mass of front. But the brilliant and distinguished circle will soon do that.

Mrs. Rouncewell is in attendance and receives Sir Leicester's customary shake of the hand with a profound curtsy.

``How do you do, Mrs. Rouncewell? I am glad to see you.'' (unknown)

``I hope I have the honour of welcoming you in good health, Sir Leicester?'' (unknown)

``In excellent health, Mrs. Rouncewell.'' (unknown)

``My Lady is looking charmingly well,'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)
says Mrs. Rouncewell with another curtsy.

My Lady signifies, without profuse expenditure of words, that she (Lady) is as wearily well as she (Lady) can hope to be.

But Rosa is in the distance, behind the housekeeper; and my Lady, who has not subdued the quickness of her (Lady) observation, whatever else she (Lady) may have conquered, asks,

``Who is that girl?'' (she)

``A young scholar of mine, my Lady. Rosa.'' (unknown)

``Come here, Rosa!'' (Lady Dedlock/Dedlock)
Lady Dedlock beckons her (Dedlock), with even an appearance of interest.
``Why, do you know how pretty you are, child?'' (she)
she (Dedlock) says, touching her (Dedlock) shoulder with her (Dedlock) two forefingers.

Rosa, very much abashed, says,

``No, if you please, my Lady!'' (Rosa)
and glances up, and glances down, and don't know where to look, but looks all the prettier.

``How old are you?'' (unknown)

``Nineteen, my Lady.'' (unknown)

``Nineteen,'' (Lady)
repeats my Lady thoughtfully.
``Take care they don't spoil you by flattery.'' (unknown)

``Yes, my Lady.'' (Lady)

My Lady taps her (Lady) dimpled cheek with the same delicate gloved fingers and goes on to the foot of the oak staircase, where Sir Leicester pauses for her (Lady) as her (Lady) knightly escort. A staring old Dedlock in a panel, as large as life and as dull, looks as if he (Rosa) didn't know what to make of it, which was probably his (Rosa) general state of mind in the days of Queen Elizabeth.

That evening, in the housekeeper's room, Rosa can do nothing but murmur Lady Dedlock's praises. She (Lady) is so affable, so graceful, so beautiful, so elegant; has such a sweet voice and such a thrilling touch that Rosa can feel it yet! Mrs. Rouncewell confirms all this, not without personal pride, reserving only the one point of affability. Mrs. Rouncewell is not quite sure as to that. Heaven forbid that she (Rouncewell) should say a syllable in dispraise of any member of that excellent family, above all, of my Lady, whom the whole world admires; but if my Lady would only be

``a little more free,'' (Lady)
not quite so cold and distant, Mrs. Rouncewell thinks she (Rouncewell) would be more affable.

''`Tis almost a pity,'' (she)
Mrs. Rouncewell adds--only
``almost'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)
because it borders on impiety to suppose that anything could be better than it is, in such an express dispensation as the Dedlock affairs--
``that my Lady has no family. If she (Lady) had had a daughter now, a grown young lady, to interest her (lady), I think she (lady) would have had the only kind of excellence she (lady) wants.'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)

``Might not that have made her (lady) still more proud, grandmother?'' (Watt)
says Watt, who has been home and come back again, he (Watt) is such a good grandson.

``More and most, my dear,'' (the housekeeper)
returns the housekeeper with dignity,
``are words it's not my place to use--nor so much as to hear--applied to any drawback on my Lady.'' (the housekeeper)

``I beg your pardon, grandmother. But she (Lady) is proud, is she (Lady) not?'' (unknown)

``If she (Lady) is, she (Lady) has reason to be. The Dedlock family have always reason to be.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Watt)
says Watt,
``it's to be hoped they line out of their prayer-books a certain passage for the common people about pride and vainglory. Forgive me, grandmother! Only a joke!'' (Watt)

``Sir Leicester and Lady Dedlock, my dear, are not fit subjects for joking.'' (unknown)

``Sir Leicester is no joke by any means,'' (Watt)
says Watt,
``and I humbly ask his (me) pardon. I suppose, grandmother, that even with the family and their guests down here, there is no objection to my prolonging my stay at the Dedlock Arms for a day or two, as any other traveller might?'' (Watt)

``Surely, none in the world, child.'' (unknown)

``I am glad of that,'' (Watt)
says Watt,
``because I have an inexpressible desire to extend my knowledge of this beautiful neighbourhood.'' (Watt)

He (Watt) happens to glance at Rosa, who looks down and is very shy indeed. But according to the old superstition, it should be Rosa's ears that burn, and not her (housekeeper) fresh bright cheeks, for my Lady's maid is holding forth about her (housekeeper) at this moment with surpassing energy.

My Lady's maid is a Frenchwoman of two and thirty, from somewhere in the southern country about Avignon and Marseilles, a large-eyed brown woman with black hair who would be handsome but for a certain feline mouth and general uncomfortable tightness of face, rendering the jaws too eager and the skull too prominent. There is something indefinably keen and wan about her (woman) anatomy, and she (woman) has a watchful way of looking out of the corners of her (woman) eyes without turning her (woman) head which could be pleasantly dispensed with, especially when she (woman) is in an ill humour and near knives. Through all the good taste of her (woman) dress and little adornments, these objections so express themselves that she (woman) seems to go about like a very neat she-wolf imperfectly tamed. Besides being accomplished in all the knowledge appertaining to her (woman) post, she (woman) is almost an Englishwoman in her (woman) acquaintance with the language; consequently, she (woman) is in no want of words to shower upon Rosa for having attracted my Lady's attention, and she (Lady) pours them out with such grim ridicule as she (Lady) sits at dinner that her (Lady) companion, the affectionate man, is rather relieved when she (Lady) arrives at the spoon stage of that performance.

Ha, ha, ha! She (Lady), Hortense, been in my Lady's service since five years and always kept at the distance, and this doll, this puppet, caressed--absolutely caressed--by my Lady on the moment of her (Lady) arriving at the house! Ha, ha, ha!

``And do you know how pretty you are, child?'' (unknown)
``No, my Lady.'' (unknown)
You are right there!
``And how old are you, child! And take care they do not spoil you by flattery, child!'' (unknown)
Oh, how droll! It is the BEST thing altogether.
