With that apology I withdrew to a seat between Peepy -LRB-who, being well used to it, had already climbed into a corner place-RRB- and an old lady of a censorious countenance whose two nieces were in the class and who was very indignant with Peepy's boots. Prince Turveydrop then tinkled the strings of his (Turveydrop) kit with his (Turveydrop) fingers, and the young ladies stood up to dance. Just then there appeared from a side-door old Mr. Turveydrop, in the full lustre of his (Turveydrop) deportment.

He (Turveydrop) was a fat old gentleman with a false complexion, false teeth, false whiskers, and a wig. He (Turveydrop) had a fur collar, and he (Turveydrop) had a padded breast to his (Turveydrop) coat, which only wanted a star or a broad blue ribbon to be complete. He (Turveydrop) was pinched in, and swelled out, and got up, and strapped down, as much as he (Turveydrop) could possibly bear. He (Turveydrop) had such a neckcloth on -LRB-puffing his (Turveydrop) very eyes out of their natural shape-RRB-, and his (Turveydrop) chin and even his (Turveydrop) ears so sunk into it, that it seemed as though he (Turveydrop) must inevitably double up if it were cast loose. He (Turveydrop) had under his (Turveydrop) arm a hat of great size and weight, shelving downward from the crown to the brim, and in his (Turveydrop) hand a pair of white gloves with which he (Turveydrop) flapped it as he (Turveydrop) stood poised on one leg in a high-shouldered, round-elbowed state of elegance not to be surpassed. He (Turveydrop) had a cane, he (Turveydrop) had an eye-glass, he (Turveydrop) had a snuff-box, he (Turveydrop) had rings, he (Turveydrop) had wristbands, he (Turveydrop) had everything but any touch of nature; he (Turveydrop) was not like youth, he (Turveydrop) was not like age, he (Turveydrop) was not like anything in the world but a model of deportment.

``Father! A visitor. Miss Jellyby's friend, Miss Summerson.'' (unknown)

``Distinguished,'' (Mr. Turveydrop/Turveydrop/MR. TURVEYDROP)
said Mr. Turveydrop,
``by Miss Summerson's presence.'' (Mr. Turveydrop/Turveydrop/MR. TURVEYDROP)
As he (Turveydrop) bowed to me in that tight state, I almost believe I saw creases come into the whites of his (Turveydrop) eyes.

``My father,'' (the son)
said the son, aside, to me with quite an affecting belief in him (Turveydrop),
``is a celebrated character. My father is greatly admired.'' (him)

``Go on, Prince! Go on!'' (Mr. Turveydrop/Turveydrop/MR. TURVEYDROP)
said Mr. Turveydrop, standing with his (Turveydrop) back to the fire and waving his (Turveydrop) gloves condescendingly.
``Go on, my son!'' (unknown)

At this command, or by this gracious permission, the lesson went on. Prince Turveydrop sometimes played the kit, dancing; sometimes played the piano, standing; sometimes hummed the tune with what little breath he (Turveydrop) could spare, while he (Turveydrop) set a pupil right; always conscientiously moved with the least proficient through every step and every part of the figure; and never rested for an instant. His (Turveydrop) distinguished father did nothing whatever but stand before the fire, a model of deportment.

``And he (son) never does anything else,'' (the lady)
said the old lady of the censorious countenance.
``Yet would you believe that it's HIS (son) name on the door-plate?'' (unknown)

``His (son) son's name is the same, you know,'' (I.)
said I.

``He (son) wouldn't let his (son) son have any name if he (son) could take it from him (son),'' (I.)
returned the old lady.
``Look at the son's dress!'' (unknown)
It certainly was plain--threadbare--almost shabby.
``Yet the father must be garnished and tricked out,'' (the lady)
said the old lady,
``because of his (father) deportment. I'd deport him (father)! Transport him (father) would be better!'' (the lady)

I felt curious to know more concerning this person. I asked,

``Does he (father) give lessons in deportment now?'' (I)

``Now!'' (the lady)
returned the old lady shortly.
``Never did.'' (I)

After a moment's consideration, I suggested that perhaps fencing had been his (Turveydrop) accomplishment.

``I don't believe he (father) can fence at all, ma'am,'' (the lady)
said the old lady.

I looked surprised and inquisitive. The old lady, becoming more and more incensed against the master of deportment as she (lady) dwelt upon the subject, gave me some particulars of his (master) career, with strong assurances that they were mildly stated.

He (master) had married a meek little dancing-mistress, with a tolerable connexion -LRB-having never in his (master) life before done anything but deport himself-RRB-, and had worked her (lady) to death, or had, at the best, suffered her (lady) to work herself to death, to maintain him (master) in those expenses which were indispensable to his (master) position. At once to exhibit his (master) deportment to the best models and to keep the best models constantly before himself, he (master) had found it necessary to frequent all public places of fashionable and lounging resort, to be seen at Brighton and elsewhere at fashionable times, and to lead an idle life in the very best clothes. To enable him (master) to do this, the affectionate little dancing-mistress had toiled and laboured and would have toiled and laboured to that hour if her (master) strength had lasted so long. For the mainspring of the story was that in spite of the man's absorbing selfishness, his (man) wife -LRB-overpowered by his (man) deportment-RRB- had, to the last, believed in him (man) and had, on her (wife) death-bed, in the most moving terms, confided him (man) to their son as one who had an inextinguishable claim upon him (son) and whom he (son) could never regard with too much pride and deference. The son, inheriting his (son) mother's belief, and having the deportment always before him (son), had lived and grown in the same faith, and now, at thirty years of age, worked for his (son) father twelve hours a day and looked up to him (son) with veneration on the old imaginary pinnacle.

``The airs the fellow gives himself!'' (informant)
said my informant, shaking her (mother) head at old Mr. Turveydrop with speechless indignation as he (Turveydrop) drew on his (Turveydrop) tight gloves, of course unconscious of the homage she (mother) was rendering.
``He (father) fully believes he (father) is one of the aristocracy! And he (father) is so condescending to the son he (father) so egregiously deludes that you might suppose him (father) the most virtuous of parents. Oh!'' (the lady)
said the old lady, apostrophizing him (Turveydrop) with infinite vehemence.
``I could bite you!'' (I)

I could not help being amused, though I heard the old lady out with feelings of real concern. It was difficult to doubt her (lady) with the father and son before me. What I might have thought of them without the old lady's account, or what I might have thought of the old lady's account without them, I cannot say. There was a fitness of things in the whole that carried conviction with it.

My eyes were yet wandering, from young Mr. Turveydrop working so hard, to old Mr. Turveydrop deporting himself so beautifully, when the latter came ambling up to me and entered into conversation.

He (Turveydrop) asked me, first of all, whether I conferred a charm and a distinction on London by residing in it? I did not think it necessary to reply that I was perfectly aware I should not do that, in any case, but merely told him (Turveydrop) where I did reside.

``A lady so graceful and accomplished,'' (he)
he (Turveydrop) said, kissing his (Turveydrop) right glove and afterwards extending it towards the pupils,
``will look leniently on the deficiencies here. We do our best to polish--polish--polish!'' (the pupils)

He (Turveydrop) sat down beside me, taking some pains to sit on the form, I thought, in imitation of the print of his (Turveydrop) illustrious model on the sofa. And really he (Turveydrop) did look very like it.

``To polish--polish--polish!'' (he)
he (Turveydrop) repeated, taking a pinch of snuff and gently fluttering his (Turveydrop) fingers.
``But we are not, if I may say so to one formed to be graceful both by Nature and Art--'' (him)
with the high-shouldered bow, which it seemed impossible for him (Turveydrop) to make without lifting up his (Turveydrop) eyebrows and shutting his (Turveydrop) eyes
''--we are not what we used to be in point of deportment.'' (him)

``Are we not, sir?'' (I.)
said I.

``We have degenerated,'' (I.)
he (Turveydrop) returned, shaking his (Turveydrop) head, which he (Turveydrop) could do to a very limited extent in his (Turveydrop) cravat. ``A levelling age is not favourable to deportment. It develops vulgarity. Perhaps I speak with some little partiality. It may not be for me to say that I have been called, for some years now, Gentleman Turveydrop, or that his (Gentleman) Royal Highness the Prince Regent did me the honour to inquire, on my removing my hat as he (Highness) drove out of the Pavilion at Brighton -LRB-that fine building-RRB-, ``Who is he (Highness)? Who the devil is he (devil)? Why don't I know him (devil)? Why hasn't he (devil) thirty thousand a year?
'' But these are little matters of anecdote--the general property, ma'am--still repeated occasionally among the upper classes.'' (he)

``Indeed?'' (I)
said I.

He (Turveydrop) replied with the high-shouldered bow.

``Where what is left among us of deportment,'' (he)
he (Turveydrop) added,
``still lingers. England--alas, my country!--has degenerated very much, and is degenerating every day. She (Highness) has not many gentlemen left. We are few. I see nothing to succeed us but a race of weavers.'' (he)

``One might hope that the race of gentlemen would be perpetuated here,'' (I.)
said I.

``You are very good.'' (I.)
He (Turveydrop) smiled with a high-shouldered bow again.
``You flatter me. But, no--no! I have never been able to imbue my poor boy with that part of his (boy) art. Heaven forbid that I should disparage my dear child, but he (boy) has--no deportment.'' (unknown)

``He (boy) appears to be an excellent master,'' (I)
I observed.

``Understand me, my dear madam, he (boy) IS an excellent master. All that can be acquired, he (boy) has acquired. All that can be imparted, he (boy) can impart. But there ARE things--'' (He)
He (Turveydrop) took another pinch of snuff and made the bow again, as if to add,
``This kind of thing, for instance.'' (He)

I glanced towards the centre of the room, where Miss Jellyby's lover, now engaged with single pupils, was undergoing greater drudgery than ever.

``My amiable child,'' (Mr. Turveydrop/Turveydrop/MR. TURVEYDROP)
murmured Mr. Turveydrop, adjusting his (Turveydrop) cravat.

``Your son is indefatigable,'' (I.)
said I.

``It is my reward,'' (I.)
said Mr. Turveydrop,
``to hear you say so. In some respects, he (son) treads in the footsteps of his (son) sainted mother. She (mother) was a devoted creature. But wooman, lovely wooman,'' (Mr. Turveydrop/Turveydrop/MR. TURVEYDROP)
said Mr. Turveydrop with very disagreeable gallantry,
``what a sex you are!'' (Mr. Turveydrop/Turveydrop/MR. TURVEYDROP)

I rose and joined Miss Jellyby, who was by this time putting on her (Jellyby) bonnet. The time allotted to a lesson having fully elapsed, there was a general putting on of bonnets. When Miss Jellyby and the unfortunate Prince found an opportunity to become betrothed I don't know, but they certainly found none on this occasion to exchange a dozen words.

``My dear,'' (Mr. Turveydrop/Turveydrop/MR. TURVEYDROP)
said Mr. Turveydrop benignly to his (Turveydrop) son,
``do you know the hour?'' (son)

``No, father.'' (The son)
The son had no watch. The father had a handsome gold one, which he (father) pulled out with an air that was an example to mankind.

``My son,'' (he)
said he (father),
``it's two o'clock. Recollect your school at Kensington at three.'' (he)

``That's time enough for me, father,'' (Prince)
said Prince.
``I can take a morsel of dinner standing and be off.'' (unknown)

``My dear boy,'' (father)
returned his (Prince) father,
``you must be very quick. You will find the cold mutton on the table.'' (father)

``Thank you, father. Are YOU off now, father?'' (unknown)

``Yes, my dear. I suppose,'' (Mr. Turveydrop/Turveydrop/MR. TURVEYDROP)
said Mr. Turveydrop, shutting his (Turveydrop) eyes and lifting up his (Turveydrop) shoulders with modest consciousness,
``that I must show myself, as usual, about town.'' (Mr. Turveydrop/Turveydrop/MR. TURVEYDROP)

``You had better dine out comfortably somewhere,'' (son)
said his (Turveydrop) son.

``My dear child, I intend to. I shall take my little meal, I think, at the French house, in the Opera Colonnade.'' (unknown)

``That's right. Good-bye, father!'' (Prince)
said Prince, shaking hands.

``Good-bye, my son. Bless you!'' (Mr. Turveydrop/Turveydrop/MR. TURVEYDROP)

Mr. Turveydrop said this in quite a pious manner, and it seemed to do his (Turveydrop) son good, who, in parting from him (son), was so pleased with him (son), so dutiful to him (son), and so proud of him (son) that I almost felt as if it were an unkindness to the younger man not to be able to believe implicitly in the elder. The few moments that were occupied by Prince in taking leave of us -LRB-and particularly of one of us, as I saw, being in the secret-RRB-, enhanced my favourable impression of his (Prince) almost childish character. I felt a liking for him (Prince) and a compassion for him (Prince) as he (Prince) put his (Prince) little kit in his (Prince) pocket--and with it his (Prince) desire to stay a little while with Caddy--and went away good-humouredly to his (Prince) cold mutton and his (Prince) school at Kensington, that made me scarcely less irate with his (Prince) father than the censorious old lady.

The father opened the room door for us and bowed us out in a manner, I must acknowledge, worthy of his (father) shining original. In the same style he (father) presently passed us on the other side of the street, on his (father) way to the aristocratic part of the town, where he (father) was going to show himself among the few other gentlemen left. For some moments, I was so lost in reconsidering what I had heard and seen in Newman Street that I was quite unable to talk to Caddy or even to fix my attention on what she (Newman) said to me, especially when I began to inquire in my mind whether there were, or ever had been, any other gentlemen, not in the dancing profession, who lived and founded a reputation entirely on their deportment. This became so bewildering and suggested the possibility of so many Mr. Turveydrops that I said,

``Esther, you must make up your mind to abandon this subject altogether and attend to Caddy.'' (I)
I accordingly did so, and we chatted all the rest of the way to Lincoln's Inn.

Caddy told me that her (Newman) lover's education had been so neglected that it was not always easy to read his (lover) notes. She (Newman) said if he (lover) were not so anxious about his (lover) spelling and took less pains to make it clear, he (lover) would do better; but he (lover) put so many unnecessary letters into short words that they sometimes quite lost their English appearance.

``He (son) does it with the best intention,'' (unknown)
observed Caddy,
``but it hasn't the effect he (son) means, poor fellow!'' (he)
Caddy then went on to reason, how could he (lover) be expected to be a scholar when he (lover) had passed his (lover) whole life in the dancing-school and had done nothing but teach and fag, fag and teach, morning, noon, and night! And what did it matter? She (Newman) could write letters enough for both, as she (Newman) knew to her (Newman) cost, and it was far better for him (lover) to be amiable than learned.
``Besides, it's not as if I was an accomplished girl who had any right to give herself airs,'' (unknown)
said Caddy. ``I know little enough, I am sure, thanks to Ma!

``There's another thing I want to tell you, now we are alone,'' (unknown)
continued Caddy,
``which I should not have liked to mention unless you had seen Prince, Miss Summerson. You know what a house ours is. It's of no use my trying to learn anything that it would be useful for Prince's wife to know in OUR house. We live in such a state of muddle that it's impossible, and I have only been more disheartened whenever I have tried. So I get a little practice with--who do you think? Poor Miss Flite! Early in the morning I help her (wife) to tidy her (wife) room and clean her (wife) birds, and I make her (wife) cup of coffee for her (wife) -LRB-of course she (wife) taught me-RRB-, and I have learnt to make it so well that Prince says it's the very best coffee he (Prince) ever tasted, and would quite delight old Mr. Turveydrop, who is very particular indeed about his (Turveydrop) coffee. I can make little puddings too; and I know how to buy neck of mutton, and tea, and sugar, and butter, and a good many housekeeping things. I am not clever at my needle, yet,'' (Peepy)
said Caddy, glancing at the repairs on Peepy's frock,
``but perhaps I shall improve, and since I have been engaged to Prince and have been doing all this, I have felt better-tempered, I hope, and more forgiving to Ma. It rather put me out at first this morning to see you and Miss Clare looking so neat and pretty and to feel ashamed of Peepy and myself too, but on the whole I hope I am better-tempered than I was and more forgiving to Ma.'' (Peepy)

The poor girl, trying so hard, said it from her (girl) heart, and touched mine.

``Caddy, my love,'' (I)
I replied,
``I begin to have a great affection for you, and I hope we shall become friends.'' (I)

``Oh, do you?'' (unknown)
cried Caddy.
``How happy that would make me!'' (unknown)

``My dear Caddy,'' (I)
said I,
``let us be friends from this time, and let us often have a chat about these matters and try to find the right way through them.'' (I)
Caddy was overjoyed. I said everything I could in my old-fashioned way to comfort and encourage her (girl), and I would not have objected to old Mr. Turveydrop that day for any smaller consideration than a settlement on his (Turveydrop) daughter-in-law.

By this time we were come to Mr. Krook's, whose private door stood open. There was a bill, pasted on the door-post, announcing a room to let on the second floor. It reminded Caddy to tell me as we proceeded upstairs that there had been a sudden death there and an inquest and that our little friend had been ill of the fright. The door and window of the vacant room being open, we looked in. It was the room with the dark door to which Miss Flite had secretly directed my attention when I was last in the house. A sad and desolate place it was, a gloomy, sorrowful place that gave me a strange sensation of mournfulness and even dread.

``You look pale,'' (I)
said Caddy when we came out,
``and cold!'' (I)
I felt as if the room had chilled me.

We had walked slowly while we were talking, and my guardian and Ada were here before us. We found them in Miss Flite's garret. They were looking at the birds, while a medical gentleman who was so good as to attend Miss Flite with much solicitude and compassion spoke with her (Ada) cheerfully by the fire.

``I have finished my professional visit,'' (he)
he (gentleman) said, coming forward.
``Miss Flite is much better and may appear in court -LRB-as her (My) mind is set upon it-RRB- to-morrow. She (My) has been greatly missed there, I understand.'' (unknown)

Miss Flite received the compliment with complacency and dropped a general curtsy to us.

``Honoured, indeed,'' (she)
said she (Ada),
``by another visit from the wards in Jarndyce! Ve-ry happy to receive Jarndyce of Bleak House beneath my humble roof!'' (she)
with a special curtsy.
``Fitz-Jarndyce, my dear'' (she)
--she (Ada) had bestowed that name on Caddy, it appeared, and always called her (Ada) by it--
``a double welcome!'' (she)

``Has she (My) been very ill?'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
asked Mr. Jarndyce of the gentleman whom we had found in attendance on her (Ada). She (Ada) answered for herself directly, though he (Jarndyce) had put the question in a whisper.

``Oh, decidedly unwell! Oh, very unwell indeed,'' (she)
she (Ada) said confidentially.
``Not pain, you know--trouble. Not bodily so much as nervous, nervous! The truth is,'' (unknown)
in a subdued voice and trembling,
``we have had death here. There was poison in the house. I am very susceptible to such horrid things. It frightened me. Only Mr. Woodcourt knows how much. My physician, Mr. Woodcourt!'' (unknown)
with great stateliness.
``The wards in Jarndyce--Jarndyce of Bleak House--Fitz-Jarndyce!'' (unknown)

``Miss Flite,'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
said Mr. Woodcourt in a grave kind of voice, as if he (Woodcourt) were appealing to her (Ada) while speaking to us, and laying his (Woodcourt) hand gently on her (Ada) arm,
``Miss Flite describes her (physician) illness with her (physician) usual accuracy. She (physician) was alarmed by an occurrence in the house which might have alarmed a stronger person, and was made ill by the distress and agitation. She (physician) brought me here in the first hurry of the discovery, though too late for me to be of any use to the unfortunate man. I have compensated myself for that disappointment by coming here since and being of some small use to her (physician).'' (he)

``The kindest physician in the college,'' (me)
whispered Miss Flite to me.
``I expect a judgment. On the day of judgment. And shall then confer estates.'' (unknown)

``She (physician) will be as well in a day or two,'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
said Mr. Woodcourt, looking at her (Ada) with an observant smile,
``as she (physician) ever will be. In other words, quite well of course. Have you heard of her (physician) good fortune?'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)

``Most extraordinary!'' (unknown)
said Miss Flite, smiling brightly.
``You never heard of such a thing, my dear! Every Saturday, Conversation Kenge or Guppy -LRB-clerk to Conversation K.-RRB- places in my hand a paper of shillings. Shillings. I assure you! Always the same number in the paper. Always one for every day in the week. Now you know, really! So well-timed, is it not? Ye-es! From whence do these papers come, you say? That is the great question. Naturally. Shall I tell you what I think? I think,'' (unknown)
said Miss Flite, drawing herself back with a very shrewd look and shaking her (Ada) right forefinger in a most significant manner,
``that the Lord Chancellor, aware of the length of time during which the Great Seal has been open -LRB-for it has been open a long time!-RRB-, forwards them. Until the judgment I expect is given. Now that's very creditable, you know. To confess in that way that he (Great) IS a little slow for human life. So delicate! Attending court the other day--I attend it regularly, with my documents--I taxed him (Great) with it, and he (Great) almost confessed. That is, I smiled at him (Great) from my bench, and HE (Great) smiled at me from his (Great) bench. But it's great good fortune, is it not? And Fitz-Jarndyce lays the money out for me to great advantage. Oh, I assure you to the greatest advantage!'' (I)

I congratulated her (Ada) -LRB-as she (Ada) addressed herself to me-RRB- upon this fortunate addition to her (Ada) income and wished her (Ada) a long continuance of it. I did not speculate upon the source from which it came or wonder whose humanity was so considerate. My guardian stood before me, contemplating the birds, and I had no need to look beyond him (Ada).

``And what do you call these little fellows, ma'am?'' (he)
said he (Ada) in his (Ada) pleasant voice.
``Have they any names?'' (unknown)

``I can answer for Miss Flite that they have,'' (I)
said I,
``for she (I) promised to tell us what they were. Ada remembers?'' (I)

Ada remembered very well.

``Did I?'' (unknown)
said Miss Flite.
``Who's that at my door? What are you listening at my door for, Krook?'' (The man)

The old man of the house, pushing it open before him (man), appeared there with his (man) fur cap in his (man) hand and his (man) cat at his (man) heels.

``I warn't listening, Miss Flite,'' (he)
he (man) said,
``I was going to give a rap with my knuckles, only you're so quick!'' (he)

``Make your cat go down. Drive her (Ada) away!'' (the lady)
the old lady angrily exclaimed.

``Bah, bah! There ain't no danger, gentlefolks,'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
said Mr. Krook, looking slowly and sharply from one to another until he (Krook) had looked at all of us;
``she (Ada)'d never offer at the birds when I was here unless I told her (Ada) to it.'' (he)

``You will excuse my landlord,'' (the lady)
said the old lady with a dignified air.
``M, quite M! What do you want, Krook, when I have company?'' (unknown)

``Hi!'' (the man)
said the old man.
``You know I am the Chancellor.'' (unknown)

``Well?'' (unknown)
returned Miss Flite.
``What of that?'' (unknown)

``For the Chancellor,'' (the man)
said the old man with a chuckle,
``not to be acquainted with a Jarndyce is queer, ain't it, Miss Flite? Mightn't I take the liberty? Your servant, sir. I know Jarndyce and Jarndyce a`most as well as you do, sir. I knowed old Squire Tom, sir. I never to my knowledge see you afore though, not even in court. Yet, I go there a mortal sight of times in the course of the year, taking one day with another.'' (the man)

``I never go there,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce -LRB-which he (Jarndyce) never did on any consideration-RRB-.
``I would sooner go--somewhere else.'' (unknown)

``Would you though?'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
returned Krook, grinning.
``You're bearing hard upon my noble and learned brother in your meaning, sir, though perhaps it is but nat`ral in a Jarndyce. The burnt child, sir! What, you're looking at my lodger's birds, Mr. Jarndyce?'' (The man)
The old man had come by little and little into the room until he (Krook) now touched my guardian with his (Krook) elbow and looked close up into his (Krook) face with his (Krook) spectacled eyes.
``It's one of her (I) strange ways that she (I)'ll never tell the names of these birds if she (I) can help it, though she (I) named 'em all.'' (unknown)
This was in a whisper.
``Shall I run 'em over, Flite?'' (he)
he (Krook) asked aloud, winking at us and pointing at her (lady) as she (lady) turned away, affecting to sweep the grate.

``If you like,'' (she)
she (lady) answered hurriedly.

The old man, looking up at the cages after another look at us, went through the list.

``Hope, Joy, Youth, Peace, Rest, Life, Dust, Ashes, Waste, Want, Ruin, Despair, Madness, Death, Cunning, Folly, Words, Wigs, Rags, Sheepskin, Plunder, Precedent, Jargon, Gammon, and Spinach. That's the whole collection,'' (the man)
said the old man,
``all cooped up together, by my noble and learned brother.'' (the man)

``This is a bitter wind!'' (guardian)
muttered my guardian.

``When my noble and learned brother gives his (brother) judgment, they're to be let go free,'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
said Krook, winking at us again.
``And then,'' (he)
he (Krook) added, whispering and grinning,
``if that ever was to happen--which it won't--the birds that have never been caged would kill 'em.'' (he)

``If ever the wind was in the east,'' (guardian)
said my guardian, pretending to look out of the window for a weathercock,
``I think it's there to-day!'' (guardian)

We found it very difficult to get away from the house. It was not Miss Flite who detained us; she (lady) was as reasonable a little creature in consulting the convenience of others as there possibly could be. It was Mr. Krook. He (Krook) seemed unable to detach himself from Mr. Jarndyce. If he (Jarndyce) had been linked to him (Jarndyce), he (Jarndyce) could hardly have attended him (Jarndyce) more closely. He (Jarndyce) proposed to show us his (Jarndyce) Court of Chancery and all the strange medley it contained; during the whole of our inspection -LRB-prolonged by himself-RRB- he (Jarndyce) kept close to Mr. Jarndyce and sometimes detained him (Jarndyce) under one pretence or other until we had passed on, as if he (Jarndyce) were tormented by an inclination to enter upon some secret subject which he (Jarndyce) could not make up his (Jarndyce) mind to approach. I cannot imagine a countenance and manner more singularly expressive of caution and indecision, and a perpetual impulse to do something he (Jarndyce) could not resolve to venture on, than Mr. Krook's was that day. His (Krook) watchfulness of my guardian was incessant. He (Krook) rarely removed his (Krook) eyes from his (Krook) face. If he (Krook) went on beside him (Krook), he (Krook) observed him (Krook) with the slyness of an old white fox. If he (Krook) went before, he (Krook) looked back. When we stood still, he (Krook) got opposite to him (Krook), and drawing his (Krook) hand across and across his (Krook) open mouth with a curious expression of a sense of power, and turning up his (Krook) eyes, and lowering his (Krook) grey eyebrows until they appeared to be shut, seemed to scan every lineament of his (Krook) face.

At last, having been -LRB-always attended by the cat-RRB- all over the house and having seen the whole stock of miscellaneous lumber, which was certainly curious, we came into the back part of the shop. Here on the head of an empty barrel stood on end were an ink-bottle, some old stumps of pens, and some dirty playbills; and against the wall were pasted several large printed alphabets in several plain hands.

``What are you doing here?'' (guardian)
asked my guardian.

``Trying to learn myself to read and write,'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
said Krook.

``And how do you get on?'' (unknown)

``Slow. Bad,'' (the man)
returned the old man impatiently.
``It's hard at my time of life.'' (unknown)

``It would be easier to be taught by some one,'' (guardian)
said my guardian.

``Aye, but they might teach me wrong!'' (the man)
returned the old man with a wonderfully suspicious flash of his (Krook) eye.
``I don't know what I may have lost by not being learned afore. I wouldn't like to lose anything by being learned wrong now.'' (unknown)

``Wrong?'' (guardian)
said my guardian with his (Krook) good-humoured smile.
``Who do you suppose would teach you wrong?'' (unknown)

``I don't know, Mr. Jarndyce of Bleak House!'' (the man)
replied the old man, turning up his (Krook) spectacles on his (Krook) forehead and rubbing his (Krook) hands.
``I don't suppose as anybody would, but I'd rather trust my own self than another!'' (guardian)

These answers and his (Krook) manner were strange enough to cause my guardian to inquire of Mr. Woodcourt, as we all walked across Lincoln's Inn together, whether Mr. Krook were really, as his (Krook) lodger represented him (Krook), deranged. The young surgeon replied, no, he (surgeon) had seen no reason to think so. He (surgeon) was exceedingly distrustful, as ignorance usually was, and he (surgeon) was always more or less under the influence of raw gin, of which he (surgeon) drank great quantities and of which he (surgeon) and his (surgeon) back-shop, as we might have observed, smelt strongly; but he (surgeon) did not think him (surgeon) mad as yet.

On our way home, I so conciliated Peepy's affections by buying him (surgeon) a windmill and two flour-sacks that he (surgeon) would suffer nobody else to take off his (surgeon) hat and gloves and would sit nowhere at dinner but at my side. Caddy sat upon the other side of me, next to Ada, to whom we imparted the whole history of the engagement as soon as we got back. We made much of Caddy, and Peepy too; and Caddy brightened exceedingly; and my guardian was as merry as we were; and we were all very happy indeed until Caddy went home at night in a hackney-coach, with Peepy fast asleep, but holding tight to the windmill.

I have forgotten to mention--at least I have not mentioned--that Mr. Woodcourt was the same dark young surgeon whom we had met at Mr. Badger's. Or that Mr. Jarndyce invited him (Jarndyce) to dinner that day. Or that he (Jarndyce) came. Or that when they were all gone and I said to Ada,

``Now, my darling, let us have a little talk about Richard!'' (Ada)
Ada laughed and said--

But I don't think it matters what my darling said. She (Ada) was always merry.

CHAPTER XV

Bell Yard

While we were in London Mr. Jarndyce was constantly beset by the crowd of excitable ladies and gentlemen whose proceedings had so much astonished us. Mr. Quale, who presented himself soon after our arrival, was in all such excitements. He (Quale) seemed to project those two shining knobs of temples of his (Quale) into everything that went on and to brush his (Quale) hair farther and farther back, until the very roots were almost ready to fly out of his (Quale) head in inappeasable philanthropy. All objects were alike to him (Quale), but he (Quale) was always particularly ready for anything in the way of a testimonial to any one. His (Quale) great power seemed to be his (Quale) power of indiscriminate admiration. He (Quale) would sit for any length of time, with the utmost enjoyment, bathing his (Quale) temples in the light of any order of luminary. Having first seen him (Quale) perfectly swallowed up in admiration of Mrs. Jellyby, I had supposed her (Jellyby) to be the absorbing object of his (Quale) devotion. I soon discovered my mistake and found him (Quale) to be train-bearer and organ-blower to a whole procession of people.

Mrs. Pardiggle came one day for a subscription to something, and with her (Pardiggle), Mr. Quale. Whatever Mrs. Pardiggle said, Mr. Quale repeated to us; and just as he (Quale) had drawn Mrs. Jellyby out, he (Quale) drew Mrs. Pardiggle out. Mrs. Pardiggle wrote a letter of introduction to my guardian in behalf of her (Pardiggle) eloquent friend Mr. Gusher. With Mr. Gusher appeared Mr. Quale again. Mr. Gusher, being a flabby gentleman with a moist surface and eyes so much too small for his (Gusher) moon of a face that they seemed to have been originally made for somebody else, was not at first sight prepossessing; yet he (Gusher) was scarcely seated before Mr. Quale asked Ada and me, not inaudibly, whether he (Quale) was not a great creature--which he (Quale) certainly was, flabbily speaking, though Mr. Quale meant in intellectual beauty--and whether we were not struck by his (Quale) massive configuration of brow. In short, we heard of a great many missions of various sorts among this set of people, but nothing respecting them was half so clear to us as that it was Mr. Quale's mission to be in ecstasies with everybody else's mission and that it was the most popular mission of all.

Mr. Jarndyce had fallen into this company in the tenderness of his (Jarndyce) heart and his (Jarndyce) earnest desire to do all the good in his (Jarndyce) power; but that he (Jarndyce) felt it to be too often an unsatisfactory company, where benevolence took spasmodic forms, where charity was assumed as a regular uniform by loud professors and speculators in cheap notoriety, vehement in profession, restless and vain in action, servile in the last degree of meanness to the great, adulatory of one another, and intolerable to those who were anxious quietly to help the weak from failing rather than with a great deal of bluster and self-laudation to raise them up a little way when they were down, he (Jarndyce) plainly told us. When a testimonial was originated to Mr. Quale by Mr. Gusher -LRB-who had already got one, originated by Mr. Quale-RRB-, and when Mr. Gusher spoke for an hour and a half on the subject to a meeting, including two charity schools of small boys and girls, who were specially reminded of the widow's mite, and requested to come forward with halfpence and be acceptable sacrifices, I think the wind was in the east for three whole weeks.

I mention this because I am coming to Mr. Skimpole again. It seemed to me that his (Skimpole) off-hand professions of childishness and carelessness were a great relief to my guardian, by contrast with such things, and were the more readily believed in since to find one perfectly undesigning and candid man among many opposites could not fail to give him (man) pleasure. I should be sorry to imply that Mr. Skimpole divined this and was politic; I really never understood him (Skimpole) well enough to know. What he (Skimpole) was to my guardian, he (Skimpole) certainly was to the rest of the world.

He (Skimpole) had not been very well; and thus, though he (Skimpole) lived in London, we had seen nothing of him (Skimpole) until now. He (Skimpole) appeared one morning in his (Skimpole) usual agreeable way and as full of pleasant spirits as ever.

Well, he (Skimpole) said, here he (Skimpole) was! He (Skimpole) had been bilious, but rich men were often bilious, and therefore he (Skimpole) had been persuading himself that he (Skimpole) was a man of property. So he (Skimpole) was, in a certain point of view--in his (Skimpole) expansive intentions. He (Skimpole) had been enriching his (Skimpole) medical attendant in the most lavish manner. He (Skimpole) had always doubled, and sometimes quadrupled, his (Skimpole) fees. He (Skimpole) had said to the doctor,

``Now, my dear doctor, it is quite a delusion on your part to suppose that you attend me for nothing. I am overwhelming you with money--in my expansive intentions--if you only knew it!'' (the doctor)
And really -LRB-he (Skimpole) said-RRB- he (Skimpole) meant it to that degree that he (Skimpole) thought it much the same as doing it. If he (Skimpole) had had those bits of metal or thin paper to which mankind attached so much importance to put in the doctor's hand, he (doctor) would have put them in the doctor's hand. Not having them, he (doctor) substituted the will for the deed. Very well! If he (doctor) really meant it--if his (doctor) will were genuine and real, which it was--it appeared to him (doctor) that it was the same as coin, and cancelled the obligation.

``It may be, partly, because I know nothing of the value of money,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole, ``but I often feel this. It seems so reasonable! My butcher says to me he (butcher) wants that little bill. It's a part of the pleasant unconscious poetry of the man's nature that he (man) always calls it a `little' bill--to make the payment appear easy to both of us. I reply to the butcher,
``My good friend, if you knew it, you are paid. You haven't had the trouble of coming to ask for the little bill. You are paid. I mean it.''' (unknown)

``But, suppose,'' (guardian)
said my guardian, laughing,
``he (friend) had meant the meat in the bill, instead of providing it?'' (guardian)

``My dear Jarndyce,'' (he)
he (Skimpole) returned, ``you surprise me. You take the butcher's position. A butcher I once dealt with occupied that very ground. Says he (butcher), ``Sir, why did you eat spring lamb at eighteen pence a pound?'' ``Why did I eat spring lamb at eighteen pence a pound, my honest friend?'' said I, naturally amazed by the question. ``I like spring lamb!'' This was so far convincing. ``Well, sir,'' says he (Skimpole), ``I wish I had meant the lamb as you mean the money!'' ``My good fellow,
'' said I, `pray let us reason like intellectual beings. How could that be? It was impossible. You HAD got the lamb, and I have NOT got the money. You couldn't really mean the lamb without sending it in, whereas I can, and do, really mean the money without paying it!'' (fellow)
He (Skimpole) had not a word. There was an end of the subject.''

``Did he (fellow) take no legal proceedings?'' (guardian)
inquired my guardian.

``Yes, he (fellow) took legal proceedings,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole.
``But in that he (fellow) was influenced by passion, not by reason. Passion reminds me of Boythorn. He (fellow) writes me that you and the ladies have promised him (fellow) a short visit at his (fellow) bachelor-house in Lincolnshire.'' (unknown)

``He (fellow) is a great favourite with my girls,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce,
``and I have promised for them.'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)

``Nature forgot to shade him (fellow) off, I think,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
observed Mr. Skimpole to Ada and me.
``A little too boisterous--like the sea. A little too vehement--like a bull who has made up his (fellow) mind to consider every colour scarlet. But I grant a sledge-hammering sort of merit in him (fellow)!'' (I)

I should have been surprised if those two could have thought very highly of one another, Mr. Boythorn attaching so much importance to many things and Mr. Skimpole caring so little for anything. Besides which, I had noticed Mr. Boythorn more than once on the point of breaking out into some strong opinion when Mr. Skimpole was referred to. Of course I merely joined Ada in saying that we had been greatly pleased with him (Skimpole).

``He (fellow) has invited me,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole;
``and if a child may trust himself in such hands--which the present child is encouraged to do, with the united tenderness of two angels to guard him (fellow)--I shall go. He (fellow) proposes to frank me down and back again. I suppose it will cost money? Shillings perhaps? Or pounds? Or something of that sort? By the by, Coavinses. You remember our friend Coavinses, Miss Summerson?'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

He (Skimpole) asked me as the subject arose in his (Skimpole) mind, in his (Skimpole) graceful, light-hearted manner and without the least embarrassment.

``Oh, yes!'' (I.)
said I.

``Coavinses has been arrested by the Great Bailiff,'' (I.)
said Mr. Skimpole.
``He (Bailiff) will never do violence to the sunshine any more.'' (me)

It quite shocked me to hear it, for I had already recalled with anything but a serious association the image of the man sitting on the sofa that night wiping his (man) head.

``His (Bailiff) successor informed me of it yesterday,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole. ``His (Bailiff) successor is in my house now--in possession, I think he (Bailiff) calls it. He (Bailiff) came yesterday, on my blue-eyed daughter's birthday. I put it to him (Bailiff), ``This is unreasonable and inconvenient. If you had a blue-eyed daughter you wouldn't like ME to come, uninvited, on HER birthday?
'' But he (Skimpole) stayed.'' (a daughter)

Mr. Skimpole laughed at the pleasant absurdity and lightly touched the piano by which he (Skimpole) was seated.

``And he (Bailiff) told me,'' (he)
he (Skimpole) said, playing little chords where I shall put full stops,
``The Coavinses had left. Three children. No mother. And that Coavinses' profession. Being unpopular. The rising Coavinses. Were at a considerable disadvantage.'' (I)

Mr. Jarndyce got up, rubbing his (Jarndyce) head, and began to walk about. Mr. Skimpole played the melody of one of Ada's favourite songs. Ada and I both looked at Mr. Jarndyce, thinking that we knew what was passing in his (Jarndyce) mind.

After walking and stopping, and several times leaving off rubbing his (Jarndyce) head, and beginning again, my guardian put his (Jarndyce) hand upon the keys and stopped Mr. Skimpole's playing.

``I don't like this, Skimpole,'' (he)
he (Skimpole) said thoughtfully.

Mr. Skimpole, who had quite forgotten the subject, looked up surprised.

``The man was necessary,'' (guardian)
pursued my guardian, walking backward and forward in the very short space between the piano and the end of the room and rubbing his (Skimpole) hair up from the back of his (Skimpole) head as if a high east wind had blown it into that form.
``If we make such men necessary by our faults and follies, or by our want of worldly knowledge, or by our misfortunes, we must not revenge ourselves upon them. There was no harm in his (Skimpole) trade. He (Skimpole) maintained his (Skimpole) children. One would like to know more about this.'' (unknown)

``Oh! Coavinses?'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
cried Mr. Skimpole, at length perceiving what he (Skimpole) meant.
``Nothing easier. A walk to Coavinses' headquarters, and you can know what you will.'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)

Mr. Jarndyce nodded to us, who were only waiting for the signal.

``Come! We will walk that way, my dears. Why not that way as soon as another!'' (unknown)
We were quickly ready and went out. Mr. Skimpole went with us and quite enjoyed the expedition. It was so new and so refreshing, he (Skimpole) said, for him (Skimpole) to want Coavinses instead of Coavinses wanting him (Skimpole)!

He (Skimpole) took us, first, to Cursitor Street, Chancery Lane, where there was a house with barred windows, which he (Lane) called Coavinses' Castle. On our going into the entry and ringing a bell, a very hideous boy came out of a sort of office and looked at us over a spiked wicket.

``Who did you want?'' (the boy)
said the boy, fitting two of the spikes into his (boy) chin.

``There was a follower, or an officer, or something, here,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce,
``who is dead.'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)

``Yes?'' (the boy)
said the boy.
``Well?'' (unknown)

``I want to know his (follower) name, if you please?'' (unknown)

``Name of Neckett,'' (the boy)
said the boy.

``And his (follower) address?'' (unknown)

``Bell Yard,'' (the boy)
said the boy.
``Chandler's shop, left hand side, name of Blinder.'' (unknown)

``Was he (Chandler)--I don't know how to shape the question--'' (guardian)
murmured my guardian,
``industrious?'' (guardian)

``Was Neckett?'' (the boy)
said the boy.
``Yes, wery much so. He (Chandler) was never tired of watching. He (Chandler)'d set upon a post at a street corner eight or ten hours at a stretch if he (Chandler) undertook to do it.'' (unknown)

``He (Chandler) might have done worse,'' (I)
I heard my guardian soliloquize.
``He (Chandler) might have undertaken to do it and not done it. Thank you. That's all I want.'' (the boy)

We left the boy, with his (boy) head on one side and his (boy) arms on the gate, fondling and sucking the spikes, and went back to Lincoln's Inn, where Mr. Skimpole, who had not cared to remain nearer Coavinses, awaited us. Then we all went to Bell Yard, a narrow alley at a very short distance. We soon found the chandler's shop. In it was a good-natured-looking old woman with a dropsy, or an asthma, or perhaps both.

``Neckett's children?'' (she)
said she (woman) in reply to my inquiry.
``Yes, Surely, miss. Three pair, if you please. Door right opposite the stairs.'' (she)
And she (woman) handed me the key across the counter.

I glanced at the key and glanced at her (woman), but she (woman) took it for granted that I knew what to do with it. As it could only be intended for the children's door, I came out without asking any more questions and led the way up the dark stairs. We went as quietly as we could, but four of us made some noise on the aged boards, and when we came to the second story we found we had disturbed a man who was standing there looking out of his (man) room.

``Is it Gridley that's wanted?'' (he)
he (man) said, fixing his (man) eyes on me with an angry stare.

``No, sir,'' (I)
said I;
``I am going higher up.'' (I)

He (man) looked at Ada, and at Mr. Jarndyce, and at Mr. Skimpole, fixing the same angry stare on each in succession as they passed and followed me. Mr. Jarndyce gave him (Jarndyce) good day.

``Good day!'' (he)
he (Jarndyce) said abruptly and fiercely. He (Jarndyce) was a tall, sallow man with a careworn head on which but little hair remained, a deeply lined face, and prominent eyes. He (Jarndyce) had a combative look and a chafing, irritable manner which, associated with his (Jarndyce) figure--still large and powerful, though evidently in its decline--rather alarmed me. He (Jarndyce) had a pen in his (Jarndyce) hand, and in the glimpse I caught of his (Jarndyce) room in passing, I saw that it was covered with a litter of papers.

Leaving him (Jarndyce) standing there, we went up to the top room. I tapped at the door, and a little shrill voice inside said,

``We are locked in. Mrs. Blinder's got the key!'' (I)

I applied the key on hearing this and opened the door. In a poor room with a sloping ceiling and containing very little furniture was a mite of a boy, some five or six years old, nursing and hushing a heavy child of eighteen months. There was no fire, though the weather was cold; both children were wrapped in some poor shawls and tippets as a substitute. Their clothing was not so warm, however, but that their noses looked red and pinched and their small figures shrunken as the boy walked up and down nursing and hushing the child with its head on his (boy) shoulder.

``Who has locked you up here alone?'' (unknown)
we naturally asked.

``Charley,'' (the boy)
said the boy, standing still to gaze at us.

``Is Charley your brother?'' (unknown)

``No. She (Blinder)'s my sister, Charlotte. Father called her (Blinder) Charley.'' (unknown)

``Are there any more of you besides Charley?'' (unknown)

``Me,'' (the boy)
said the boy,
``and Emma,'' (the boy)
patting the limp bonnet of the child he (boy) was nursing.
``And Charley.'' (unknown)

``Where is Charley now?'' (unknown)

``Out a-washing,'' (the boy)
said the boy, beginning to walk up and down again and taking the nankeen bonnet much too near the bedstead by trying to gaze at us at the same time.

We were looking at one another and at these two children when there came into the room a very little girl, childish in figure but shrewd and older-looking in the face--pretty-faced too--wearing a womanly sort of bonnet much too large for her (girl) and drying her (girl) bare arms on a womanly sort of apron. Her (girl) fingers were white and wrinkled with washing, and the soap-suds were yet smoking which she (girl) wiped off her (girl) arms. But for this, she (girl) might have been a child playing at washing and imitating a poor working-woman with a quick observation of the truth.

She (girl) had come running from some place in the neighbourhood and had made all the haste she (girl) could. Consequently, though she (girl) was very light, she (girl) was out of breath and could not speak at first, as she (girl) stood panting, and wiping her (girl) arms, and looking quietly at us.

``Oh, here's Charley!'' (the boy)
said the boy.

The child he (boy) was nursing stretched forth its arms and cried out to be taken by Charley. The little girl took it, in a womanly sort of manner belonging to the apron and the bonnet, and stood looking at us over the burden that clung to her (girl) most affectionately.

``Is it possible,'' (guardian)
whispered my guardian as we put a chair for the little creature and got her (girl) to sit down with her (girl) load, the boy keeping close to her (girl), holding to her (girl) apron,
``that this child works for the rest? Look at this! For God's sake, look at this!'' (her)

It was a thing to look at. The three children close together, and two of them relying solely on the third, and the third so young and yet with an air of age and steadiness that sat so strangely on the childish figure.

``Charley, Charley!'' (guardian)
said my guardian.
``How old are you?'' (unknown)

``Over thirteen, sir,'' (the child)
replied the child.

``Oh! What a great age,'' (guardian)
said my guardian.
``What a great age, Charley!'' (I)

I cannot describe the tenderness with which he (boy) spoke to her (girl), half playfully yet all the more compassionately and mournfully.

``And do you live alone here with these babies, Charley?'' (guardian)
said my guardian.

``Yes, sir,'' (the child)
returned the child, looking up into his (boy) face with perfect confidence,
``since father died.'' (the child)

``And how do you live, Charley? Oh! Charley,'' (guardian)
said my guardian, turning his (boy) face away for a moment,
``how do you live?'' (guardian)

``Since father died, sir, I've gone out to work. I'm out washing to-day.'' (unknown)

``God help you, Charley!'' (guardian)
said my guardian.
``You're not tall enough to reach the tub!'' (unknown)

``In pattens I am, sir,'' (she)
she (girl) said quickly.
``I've got a high pair as belonged to mother.'' (unknown)

``And when did mother die? Poor mother!'' (unknown)

``Mother died just after Emma was born,'' (the child)
said the child, glancing at the face upon her (girl) bosom.
``Then father said I was to be as good a mother to her (mother) as I could. And so I tried. And so I worked at home and did cleaning and nursing and washing for a long time before I began to go out. And that's how I know how; don't you see, sir?'' (unknown)

``And do you often go out?'' (unknown)

``As often as I can,'' (Charley)
said Charley, opening her (girl) eyes and smiling,
``because of earning sixpences and shillings!'' (Charley)

``And do you always lock the babies up when you go out?'' (unknown)

``To keep 'em safe, sir, don't you see?'' (Charley)
said Charley.
``Mrs. Blinder comes up now and then, and Mr. Gridley comes up sometimes, and perhaps I can run in sometimes, and they can play you know, and Tom an't afraid of being locked up, are you, Tom?'' (unknown)

``No-o!'' (Tom/Tom Jarndyce)
said Tom stoutly.

``When it comes on dark, the lamps are lighted down in the court, and they show up here quite bright--almost quite bright. Don't they, Tom?'' (unknown)

``Yes, Charley,'' (Tom/Tom Jarndyce)
said Tom,
``almost quite bright.'' (Tom/Tom Jarndyce)

``Then he (Charley)'s as good as gold,'' (the creature)
said the little creature--Oh, in such a motherly, womanly way!
``And when Emma's tired, he (Charley) puts her (Emma) to bed. And when he (Charley)'s tired he (Charley) goes to bed himself. And when I come home and light the candle and has a bit of supper, he (Charley) sits up again and has it with me. Don't you, Tom?'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes, Charley!'' (Tom/Tom Jarndyce)
said Tom.
``That I do!'' (Charley)
And either in this glimpse of the great pleasure of his (Tom) life or in gratitude and love for Charley, who was all in all to him (Charley), he (Charley) laid his (Charley) face among the scanty folds of her (girl) frock and passed from laughing into crying.

It was the first time since our entry that a tear had been shed among these children. The little orphan girl had spoken of their father and their mother as if all that sorrow were subdued by the necessity of taking courage, and by her (mother) childish importance in being able to work, and by her (mother) bustling busy way. But now, when Tom cried, although she (mother) sat quite tranquil, looking quietly at us, and did not by any movement disturb a hair of the head of either of her (mother) little charges, I saw two silent tears fall down her (mother) face.

I stood at the window with Ada, pretending to look at the housetops, and the blackened stack of chimneys, and the poor plants, and the birds in little cages belonging to the neighbours, when I found that Mrs. Blinder, from the shop below, had come in -LRB-perhaps it had taken her (Blinder) all this time to get upstairs-RRB- and was talking to my guardian.

``It's not much to forgive 'em the rent, sir,'' (she)
she (Blinder) said;
``who could take it from them!'' (she)

``Well, well!'' (guardian)
said my guardian to us two.
``It is enough that the time will come when this good woman will find that it WAS much, and that forasmuch as she (woman) did it unto the least of these--This child,'' (he)
he (Blinder) added after a few moments,
``could she (woman) possibly continue this?'' (he)

``Really, sir, I think she (woman) might,'' (Mrs. Blinder/Blinder)
said Mrs. Blinder, getting her (Blinder) heavy breath by painful degrees. ``She (woman)'s as handy as it's possible to be. Bless you, sir, the way she (woman) tended them two children after the mother died was the talk of the yard! And it was a wonder to see her (mother) with him (it) after he (it) was took ill, it really was! ``Mrs. Blinder,'' he (Blinder) said to me the very last he (Blinder) spoke--he (Blinder) was lying there--
``Mrs. Blinder, whatever my calling may have been, I see a angel sitting in this room last night along with my child, and I trust her (Blinder) to Our Father!''' (Mrs. Blinder/Blinder)

``He (Father) had no other calling?'' (guardian)
said my guardian.

``No, sir,'' (Mrs. Blinder/Blinder)
returned Mrs. Blinder,
``he (Father) was nothing but a follerers. When he (Father) first came to lodge here, I didn't know what he (Father) was, and I confess that when I found out I gave him (Father) notice. It wasn't liked in the yard. It wasn't approved by the other lodgers. It is NOT a genteel calling,'' (Mrs. Blinder/Blinder)
said Mrs. Blinder,
``and most people do object to it. Mr. Gridley objected to it very strong, and he (Gridley) is a good lodger, though his (Gridley) temper has been hard tried.'' (Mrs. Blinder/Blinder)

``So you gave him (Gridley) notice?'' (guardian)
said my guardian.

``So I gave him (Gridley) notice,'' (Mrs. Blinder/Blinder)
said Mrs. Blinder.
``But really when the time came, and I knew no other ill of him (Gridley), I was in doubts. He (Gridley) was punctual and diligent; he (Gridley) did what he (Gridley) had to do, sir,'' (Mrs. Blinder/Blinder)
said Mrs. Blinder, unconsciously fixing Mr. Skimpole with her (Blinder) eye,
``and it's something in this world even to do that.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

``So you kept him (Gridley) after all?'' (unknown)

``Why, I said that if he (Gridley) could arrange with Mr. Gridley, I could arrange it with the other lodgers and should not so much mind its being liked or disliked in the yard. Mr. Gridley gave his (Gridley) consent gruff--but gave it. He (Gridley) was always gruff with him (Gridley), but he (Gridley) has been kind to the children since. A person is never known till a person is proved.'' (unknown)

``Have many people been kind to the children?'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
asked Mr. Jarndyce.

``Upon the whole, not so bad, sir,'' (Mrs. Blinder/Blinder)
said Mrs. Blinder;
``but certainly not so many as would have been if their father's calling had been different. Mr. Coavins gave a guinea, and the follerers made up a little purse. Some neighbours in the yard that had always joked and tapped their shoulders when he (Mr.) went by came forward with a little subscription, and--in general--not so bad. Similarly with Charlotte. Some people won't employ her (Charlotte) because she (Charlotte) was a follerer's child; some people that do employ her (Charlotte) cast it at her (Charlotte); some make a merit of having her (Charlotte) to work for them, with that and all her (Charlotte) draw-backs upon her (Charlotte), and perhaps pay her (Charlotte) less and put upon her (Charlotte) more. But she (Charlotte)'s patienter than others would be, and is clever too, and always willing, up to the full mark of her (Charlotte) strength and over. So I should say, in general, not so bad, sir, but might be better.'' (Mrs. Blinder/Blinder)

Mrs. Blinder sat down to give herself a more favourable opportunity of recovering her (Blinder) breath, exhausted anew by so much talking before it was fully restored. Mr. Jarndyce was turning to speak to us when his (Jarndyce) attention was attracted by the abrupt entrance into the room of the Mr. Gridley who had been mentioned and whom we had seen on our way up.

``I don't know what you may be doing here, ladies and gentlemen,'' (he)
he (Gridley) said, as if he (Gridley) resented our presence,
``but you'll excuse my coming in. I don't come in to stare about me. Well, Charley! Well, Tom! Well, little one! How is it with us all to-day?'' (he)

He (Gridley) bent over the group in a caressing way and clearly was regarded as a friend by the children, though his (friend) face retained its stern character and his (friend) manner to us was as rude as it could be. My guardian noticed it and respected it.

``No one, surely, would come here to stare about him (Tom),'' (he)
he (friend) said mildly.

``May be so, sir, may be so,'' (Tom/Tom Jarndyce)
returned the other, taking Tom upon his (Tom) knee and waving him (Tom) off impatiently.
``I don't want to argue with ladies and gentlemen. I have had enough of arguing to last one man his (man) life.'' (unknown)

``You have sufficient reason, I dare say,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce,
``for being chafed and irritated--'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)

``There again!'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
exclaimed the man, becoming violently angry.
``I am of a quarrelsome temper. I am irascible. I am not polite!'' (unknown)

``Not very, I think.'' (unknown)

``Sir,'' (Gridley/Mr. Gridley)
said Gridley, putting down the child and going up to him (Gridley) as if he (Gridley) meant to strike him (Gridley),
``do you know anything of Courts of Equity?'' (him)

``Perhaps I do, to my sorrow.'' (unknown)

``To your sorrow?'' (the man)
said the man, pausing in his (man) wrath,
``if so, I beg your pardon. I am not polite, I know. I beg your pardon! Sir,'' (the man)
with renewed violence,
``I have been dragged for five and twenty years over burning iron, and I have lost the habit of treading upon velvet. Go into the Court of Chancery yonder and ask what is one of the standing jokes that brighten up their business sometimes, and they will tell you that the best joke they have is the man from Shropshire. I,'' (he)
he (man) said, beating one hand on the other passionately,
``am the man from Shropshire.'' (he)

``I believe I and my family have also had the honour of furnishing some entertainment in the same grave place,'' (guardian)
said my guardian composedly.
``You may have heard my name--Jarndyce.'' (unknown)

``Mr. Jarndyce,'' (Gridley/Mr. Gridley)
said Gridley with a rough sort of salutation,
``you bear your wrongs more quietly than I can bear mine. More than that, I tell you--and I tell this gentleman, and these young ladies, if they are friends of yours--that if I took my wrongs in any other way, I should be driven mad! It is only by resenting them, and by revenging them in my mind, and by angrily demanding the justice I never get, that I am able to keep my wits together. It is only that!'' (Gridley/Mr. Gridley)
he (Gridley) said, speaking in a homely, rustic way and with great vehemence.
``You may tell me that I over-excite myself. I answer that it's in my nature to do it, under wrong, and I must do it. There's nothing between doing it, and sinking into the smiling state of the poor little mad woman that haunts the court. If I was once to sit down under it, I should become imbecile.'' (he)

The passion and heat in which he (Gridley) was, and the manner in which his (Gridley) face worked, and the violent gestures with which he (Gridley) accompanied what he (Gridley) said, were most painful to see.

``Mr. Jarndyce,'' (he)
he (Gridley) said,
``consider my case. As true as there is a heaven above us, this is my case. I am one of two brothers. My father -LRB-a farmer-RRB- made a will and left his (father) farm and stock and so forth to my mother for her (mother) life. After my mother's death, all was to come to me except a legacy of three hundred pounds that I was then to pay my brother. My mother died. My brother some time afterwards claimed his (brother) legacy. I and some of my relations said that he (brother) had had a part of it already in board and lodging and some other things. Now mind! That was the question, and nothing else. No one disputed the will; no one disputed anything but whether part of that three hundred pounds had been already paid or not. To settle that question, my brother filing a bill, I was obliged to go into this accursed Chancery; I was forced there because the law forced me and would let me go nowhere else. Seventeen people were made defendants to that simple suit! It first came on after two years. It was then stopped for another two years while the master -LRB-may his (master) head rot off!-RRB- inquired whether I was my father's son, about which there was no dispute at all with any mortal creature. He (master) then found out that there were not defendants enough--remember, there were only seventeen as yet!--but that we must have another who had been left out and must begin all over again. The costs at that time--before the thing was begun!--were three times the legacy. My brother would have given up the legacy, and joyful, to escape more costs. My whole estate, left to me in that will of my father's, has gone in costs. The suit, still undecided, has fallen into rack, and ruin, and despair, with everything else--and here I stand, this day! Now, Mr. Jarndyce, in your suit there are thousands and thousands involved, where in mine there are hundreds. Is mine less hard to bear or is it harder to bear, when my whole living was in it and has been thus shamefully sucked away?'' (he)

Mr. Jarndyce said that he (Jarndyce) condoled with him (Jarndyce) with all his (Jarndyce) heart and that he (Jarndyce) set up no monopoly himself in being unjustly treated by this monstrous system.

``There again!'' (Gridley/Mr. Gridley)
said Mr. Gridley with no diminution of his (Gridley) rage. ``The system! I am told on all hands, it's the system. I mustn't look to individuals. It's the system. I mustn't go into court and say, ``My Lord, I beg to know this from you--is this right or wrong? Have you the face to tell me I have received justice and therefore am dismissed?'' My Lord knows nothing of it. He (Lord) sits there to administer the system. I mustn't go to Mr. Tulkinghorn, the solicitor in Lincoln's Inn Fields, and say to him (Lincoln) when he (Lincoln) makes me furious by being so cool and satisfied--as they all do, for I know they gain by it while I lose, don't I?--I mustn't say to him (Lincoln), ``I will have something out of some one for my ruin, by fair means or foul!
'' HE (Lincoln) is not responsible. It's the system. But, if I do no violence to any of them, here--I may! I don't know what may happen if I am carried beyond myself at last! I will accuse the individual workers of that system against me, face to face, before the great eternal bar!'' (I)

His (Lincoln) passion was fearful. I could not have believed in such rage without seeing it.

``I have done!'' (he)
he (Lincoln) said, sitting down and wiping his (Lincoln) face.
``Mr. Jarndyce, I have done! I am violent, I know. I ought to know it. I have been in prison for contempt of court. I have been in prison for threatening the solicitor. I have been in this trouble, and that trouble, and shall be again. I am the man from Shropshire, and I sometimes go beyond amusing them, though they have found it amusing, too, to see me committed into custody and brought up in custody and all that. It would be better for me, they tell me, if I restrained myself. I tell them that if I did restrain myself I should become imbecile. I was a good-enough-tempered man once, I believe. People in my part of the country say they remember me so, but now I must have this vent under my sense of injury or nothing could hold my wits together. It would be far better for you, Mr. Gridley,'' (Lord)
the Lord Chancellor told me last week, `not to waste your time here, and to stay, usefully employed, down in Shropshire.'' ``My Lord, my Lord, I know it would,
'' said I to him (Chancellor), `and it would have been far better for me never to have heard the name of your high office, but unhappily for me, I can't undo the past, and the past drives me here!'' (I)
Besides,'' he (Chancellor) added, breaking fiercely out, ``I'll shame them. To the last, I'll show myself in that court to its shame. If I knew when I was going to die, and could be carried there, and had a voice to speak with, I would die there, saying,
``You have brought me here and sent me from here many and many a time. Now send me out feet foremost!''' (I)

His (Chancellor) countenance had, perhaps for years, become so set in its contentious expression that it did not soften, even now when he (Chancellor) was quiet.

``I came to take these babies down to my room for an hour,'' (he)
he (Chancellor) said, going to them again,
``and let them play about. I didn't mean to say all this, but it don't much signify. You're not afraid of me, Tom, are you?'' (he)

``No!'' (Tom/Tom Jarndyce)
said Tom.
``You ain't angry with ME.'' (unknown)

``You are right, my child. You're going back, Charley? Aye? Come then, little one!'' (He)
He (Tom) took the youngest child on his (Tom) arm, where she (Chancellor) was willing enough to be carried.
``I shouldn't wonder if we found a ginger-bread soldier downstairs. Let's go and look for him (soldier)!'' (He)

He (Tom) made his (Tom) former rough salutation, which was not deficient in a certain respect, to Mr. Jarndyce, and bowing slightly to us, went downstairs to his (Jarndyce) room.

Upon that, Mr. Skimpole began to talk, for the first time since our arrival, in his (Skimpole) usual gay strain. He (Skimpole) said, Well, it was really very pleasant to see how things lazily adapted themselves to purposes. Here was this Mr. Gridley, a man of a robust will and surprising energy--intellectually speaking, a sort of inharmonious blacksmith--and he (blacksmith) could easily imagine that there Gridley was, years ago, wandering about in life for something to expend his (Gridley) superfluous combativeness upon--a sort of Young Love among the thorns--when the Court of Chancery came in his (Young) way and accommodated him (Young) with the exact thing he (Young) wanted. There they were, matched, ever afterwards! Otherwise he (Young) might have been a great general, blowing up all sorts of towns, or he (Young) might have been a great politician, dealing in all sorts of parliamentary rhetoric; but as it was, he (Young) and the Court of Chancery had fallen upon each other in the pleasantest way, and nobody was much the worse, and Gridley was, so to speak, from that hour provided for. Then look at Coavinses! How delightfully poor Coavinses -LRB-father of these charming children-RRB- illustrated the same principle! He (father), Mr. Skimpole, himself, had sometimes repined at the existence of Coavinses. He (Skimpole) had found Coavinses in his (Skimpole) way. He (Skimpole) could had dispensed with Coavinses. There had been times when, if he (Skimpole) had been a sultan, and his (Skimpole) grand vizier had said one morning,

``What does the Commander of the Faithful require at the hands of his (Commander) slave?'' (vizier)
he (Skimpole) might have even gone so far as to reply,
``The head of Coavinses!'' (he)
But what turned out to be the case? That, all that time, he (Skimpole) had been giving employment to a most deserving man, that he (Skimpole) had been a benefactor to Coavinses, that he (Skimpole) had actually been enabling Coavinses to bring up these charming children in this agreeable way, developing these social virtues! Insomuch that his (Skimpole) heart had just now swelled and the tears had come into his (Skimpole) eyes when he (Skimpole) had looked round the room and thought,
``I was the great patron of Coavinses, and his (patron) little comforts were MY work!'' (he)

There was something so captivating in his (Skimpole) light way of touching these fantastic strings, and he (Skimpole) was such a mirthful child by the side of the graver childhood we had seen, that he (Skimpole) made my guardian smile even as he (Skimpole) turned towards us from a little private talk with Mrs. Blinder. We kissed Charley, and took her (Blinder) downstairs with us, and stopped outside the house to see her (Blinder) run away to her (Blinder) work. I don't know where she (Blinder) was going, but we saw her (Blinder) run, such a little, little creature in her (Blinder) womanly bonnet and apron, through a covered way at the bottom of the court and melt into the city's strife and sound like a dewdrop in an ocean.

CHAPTER XVI

Tom-all-Alone's

My Lady Dedlock is restless, very restless. The astonished fashionable intelligence hardly knows where to have her (Lady). To-day she (Lady) is at Chesney Wold; yesterday she (Lady) was at her (Lady) house in town; to-morrow she (Lady) may be abroad, for anything the fashionable intelligence can with confidence predict. Even Sir Leicester's gallantry has some trouble to keep pace with her (Lady). It would have more but that his (Chesney) other faithful ally, for better and for worse--the gout--darts into the old oak bed-chamber at Chesney Wold and grips him (Chesney) by both legs.

Sir Leicester receives the gout as a troublesome demon, but still a demon of the patrician order. All the Dedlocks, in the direct male line, through a course of time during and beyond which the memory of man goeth not to the contrary, have had the gout. It can be proved, sir. Other men's fathers may have died of the rheumatism or may have taken base contagion from the tainted blood of the sick vulgar, but the Dedlock family have communicated something exclusive even to the levelling process of dying by dying of their own family gout. It has come down through the illustrious line like the plate, or the pictures, or the place in Lincolnshire. It is among their dignities. Sir Leicester is perhaps not wholly without an impression, though he (family) has never resolved it into words, that the angel of death in the discharge of his (angel) necessary duties may observe to the shades of the aristocracy,

``My lords and gentlemen, I have the honour to present to you another Dedlock certified to have arrived per the family gout.'' (the angel)

Hence Sir Leicester yields up his (angel) family legs to the family disorder as if he (angel) held his (angel) name and fortune on that feudal tenure. He (angel) feels that for a Dedlock to be laid upon his (angel) back and spasmodically twitched and stabbed in his (angel) extremities is a liberty taken somewhere, but he (angel) thinks,

``We have all yielded to this; it belongs to us; it has for some hundreds of years been understood that we are not to make the vaults in the park interesting on more ignoble terms; and I submit myself to the compromise.'' (he)

And a goodly show he (angel) makes, lying in a flush of crimson and gold in the midst of the great drawing-room before his (angel) favourite picture of my Lady, with broad strips of sunlight shining in, down the long perspective, through the long line of windows, and alternating with soft reliefs of shadow. Outside, the stately oaks, rooted for ages in the green ground which has never known ploughshare, but was still a chase when kings rode to battle with sword and shield and rode a-hunting with bow and arrow, bear witness to his (witness) greatness. Inside, his (witness) forefathers, looking on him (witness) from the walls, say,

``Each of us was a passing reality here and left this coloured shadow of himself and melted into remembrance as dreamy as the distant voices of the rooks now lulling you to rest,'' (him)
and hear their testimony to his (witness) greatness too. And he (witness) is very great this day. And woe to Boythorn or other daring wight who shall presumptuously contest an inch with him (wight)!

My Lady is at present represented, near Sir Leicester, by her (Lady) portrait. She (Lady) has flitted away to town, with no intention of remaining there, and will soon flit hither again, to the confusion of the fashionable intelligence. The house in town is not prepared for her (Lady) reception. It is muffled and dreary. Only one Mercury in powder gapes disconsolate at the hall-window; and he (wight) mentioned last night to another Mercury of his (wight) acquaintance, also accustomed to good society, that if that sort of thing was to last--which it couldn't, for a man of his (man) spirits couldn't bear it, and a man of his (man) figure couldn't be expected to bear it--there would be no resource for him (man), upon his (man) honour, but to cut his (man) throat!

What connexion can there be between the place in Lincolnshire, the house in town, the Mercury in powder, and the whereabout of Jo the outlaw with the broom, who had that distant ray of light upon him (outlaw) when he (outlaw) swept the churchyard-step? What connexion can there have been between many people in the innumerable histories of this world who from opposite sides of great gulfs have, nevertheless, been very curiously brought together!

Jo sweeps his (outlaw) crossing all day long, unconscious of the link, if any link there be. He (outlaw) sums up his (outlaw) mental condition when asked a question by replying that he (outlaw)

``don't know nothink.'' (he)
He (outlaw) knows that it's hard to keep the mud off the crossing in dirty weather, and harder still to live by doing it. Nobody taught him (outlaw) even that much; he (outlaw) found it out.

Jo lives--that is to say, Jo has not yet died--in a ruinous place known to the like of him (outlaw) by the name of Tom-all-Alone's. It is a black, dilapidated street, avoided by all decent people, where the crazy houses were seized upon, when their decay was far advanced, by some bold vagrants who after establishing their own possession took to letting them out in lodgings. Now, these tumbling tenements contain, by night, a swarm of misery. As on the ruined human wretch vermin parasites appear, so these ruined shelters have bred a crowd of foul existence that crawls in and out of gaps in walls and boards; and coils itself to sleep, in maggot numbers, where the rain drips in; and comes and goes, fetching and carrying fever and sowing more evil in its every footprint than Lord Coodle, and Sir Thomas Doodle, and the Duke of Foodle, and all the fine gentlemen in office, down to Zoodle, shall set right in five hundred years--though born expressly to do it.

Twice lately there has been a crash and a cloud of dust, like the springing of a mine, in Tom-all-Alone's; and each time a house has fallen. These accidents have made a paragraph in the newspapers and have filled a bed or two in the nearest hospital. The gaps remain, and there are not unpopular lodgings among the rubbish. As several more houses are nearly ready to go, the next crash in Tom-all-Alone's may be expected to be a good one.

This desirable property is in Chancery, of course. It would be an insult to the discernment of any man with half an eye to tell him (man) so. Whether

``Tom'' (Tom the representative)
is the popular representative of the original plaintiff or defendant in Jarndyce and Jarndyce, or whether Tom lived here when the suit had laid the street waste, all alone, until other settlers came to join him (Tom), or whether the traditional title is a comprehensive name for a retreat cut off from honest company and put out of the pale of hope, perhaps nobody knows. Certainly Jo don't know.

``For I don't,'' (Jo)
says Jo,
``I don't know nothink.'' (Jo)

It must be a strange state to be like Jo! To shuffle through the streets, unfamiliar with the shapes, and in utter darkness as to the meaning, of those mysterious symbols, so abundant over the shops, and at the corners of streets, and on the doors, and in the windows! To see people read, and to see people write, and to see the postmen deliver letters, and not to have the least idea of all that language--to be, to every scrap of it, stone blind and dumb! It must be very puzzling to see the good company going to the churches on Sundays, with their books in their hands, and to think -LRB-for perhaps Jo DOES think at odd times-RRB- what does it all mean, and if it means anything to anybody, how comes it that it means nothing to me? To be hustled, and jostled, and moved on; and really to feel that it would appear to be perfectly true that I have no business here, or there, or anywhere; and yet to be perplexed by the consideration that I AM here somehow, too, and everybody overlooked me until I became the creature that I am!
