It must be a strange state, not merely to be told that I am scarcely human -LRB-as in the case of my offering myself for a witness-RRB-, but to feel it of my own knowledge all my life! To see the horses, dogs, and cattle go by me and to know that in ignorance I belong to them and not to the superior beings in my shape, whose delicacy I offend! Jo's ideas of a criminal trial, or a judge, or a bishop, or a government, or that inestimable jewel to him (bishop) -LRB-if he (bishop) only knew it-RRB- the Constitution, should be strange! His (bishop) whole material and immaterial life is wonderfully strange; his (bishop) death, the strangest thing of all.

Jo comes out of Tom-all-Alone's, meeting the tardy morning which is always late in getting down there, and munches his (bishop) dirty bit of bread as he (bishop) comes along. His (bishop) way lying through many streets, and the houses not yet being open, he (bishop) sits down to breakfast on the door-step of the Society for the Propagation of the Gospel in Foreign Parts and gives it a brush when he (bishop) has finished as an acknowledgment of the accommodation. He (bishop) admires the size of the edifice and wonders what it's all about. He (bishop) has no idea, poor wretch, of the spiritual destitution of a coral reef in the Pacific or what it costs to look up the precious souls among the coco-nuts and bread-fruit.

He (bishop) goes to his (bishop) crossing and begins to lay it out for the day. The town awakes; the great tee-totum is set up for its daily spin and whirl; all that unaccountable reading and writing, which has been suspended for a few hours, recommences. Jo and the other lower animals get on in the unintelligible mess as they can. It is market-day. The blinded oxen, over-goaded, over-driven, never guided, run into wrong places and are beaten out, and plunge red-eyed and foaming at stone walls, and often sorely hurt the innocent, and often sorely hurt themselves. Very like Jo and his (It) order; very, very like!

A band of music comes and plays. Jo listens to it. So does a dog--a drover's dog, waiting for his (It) master outside a butcher's shop, and evidently thinking about those sheep he (It) has had upon his (It) mind for some hours and is happily rid of. He (It) seems perplexed respecting three or four, can't remember where he (It) left them, looks up and down the street as half expecting to see them astray, suddenly pricks up his (It) ears and remembers all about it. A thoroughly vagabond dog, accustomed to low company and public-houses; a terrific dog to sheep, ready at a whistle to scamper over their backs and tear out mouthfuls of their wool; but an educated, improved, developed dog who has been taught his (It) duties and knows how to discharge them. He (It) and Jo listen to the music, probably with much the same amount of animal satisfaction; likewise as to awakened association, aspiration, or regret, melancholy or joyful reference to things beyond the senses, they are probably upon a par. But, otherwise, how far above the human listener is the brute!

Turn that dog's descendants wild, like Jo, and in a very few years they will so degenerate that they will lose even their bark--but not their bite.

The day changes as it wears itself away and becomes dark and drizzly. Jo fights it out at his (listener) crossing among the mud and wheels, the horses, whips, and umbrellas, and gets but a scanty sum to pay for the unsavoury shelter of Tom-all-Alone's. Twilight comes on; gas begins to start up in the shops; the lamplighter, with his (listener) ladder, runs along the margin of the pavement. A wretched evening is beginning to close in.

In his (listener) chambers Mr. Tulkinghorn sits meditating an application to the nearest magistrate to-morrow morning for a warrant. Gridley, a disappointed suitor, has been here to-day and has been alarming. We are not to be put in bodily fear, and that ill-conditioned fellow shall be held to bail again. From the ceiling, foreshortened Allegory, in the person of one impossible Roman upside down, points with the arm of Samson -LRB-out of joint, and an odd one-RRB- obtrusively toward the window. Why should Mr. Tulkinghorn, for such no reason, look out of window? Is the hand not always pointing there? So he (Tulkinghorn) does not look out of window.

And if he (Tulkinghorn) did, what would it be to see a woman going by? There are women enough in the world, Mr. Tulkinghorn thinks--too many; they are at the bottom of all that goes wrong in it, though, for the matter of that, they create business for lawyers. What would it be to see a woman going by, even though she (woman) were going secretly? They are all secret. Mr. Tulkinghorn knows that very well.

But they are not all like the woman who now leaves him (Tulkinghorn) and his (Tulkinghorn) house behind, between whose plain dress and her (woman) refined manner there is something exceedingly inconsistent. She (woman) should be an upper servant by her (woman) attire, yet in her (woman) air and step, though both are hurried and assumed--as far as she (woman) can assume in the muddy streets, which she (woman) treads with an unaccustomed foot--she (woman) is a lady. Her (woman) face is veiled, and still she (woman) sufficiently betrays herself to make more than one of those who pass her (woman) look round sharply.

She (woman) never turns her (woman) head. Lady or servant, she (woman) has a purpose in her (woman) and can follow it. She (woman) never turns her (woman) head until she (woman) comes to the crossing where Jo plies with his (servant) broom. He (servant) crosses with her (Jo) and begs. Still, she (Jo) does not turn her (Jo) head until she (Jo) has landed on the other side. Then she (Jo) slightly beckons to him (servant) and says,

``Come here!'' (him)

Jo follows her (Jo) a pace or two into a quiet court.

``Are you the boy I've read of in the papers?'' (she)
she (Jo) asked behind her (Jo) veil.

``I don't know,'' (Jo)
says Jo, staring moodily at the veil,
``nothink about no papers. I don't know nothink about nothink at all.'' (Jo)

``Were you examined at an inquest?'' (unknown)

``I don't know nothink about no--where I was took by the beadle, do you mean?'' (Jo)
says Jo.
``Was the boy's name at the inkwhich Jo?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``That's me!'' (Jo)
says Jo.

``Come farther up.'' (unknown)

``You mean about the man?'' (Jo)
says Jo, following.
``Him (man) as wos dead?'' (unknown)

``Hush! Speak in a whisper! Yes. Did he (man) look, when he (man) was living, so very ill and poor?'' (unknown)

``Oh, jist!'' (Jo)
says Jo.

``Did he (man) look like--not like YOU?'' (the woman)
says the woman with abhorrence.

``Oh, not so bad as me,'' (Jo)
says Jo.
``I'm a reg`lar one I am! You didn't know him (man), did you?'' (unknown)

``How dare you ask me if I knew him (man)?'' (unknown)

``No offence, my lady,'' (Jo)
says Jo with much humility, for even he (servant) has got at the suspicion of her (Jo) being a lady.

``I am not a lady. I am a servant.'' (unknown)

``You are a jolly servant!'' (Jo)
says Jo without the least idea of saying anything offensive, merely as a tribute of admiration.

``Listen and be silent. Don't talk to me, and stand farther from me! Can you show me all those places that were spoken of in the account I read? The place he (servant) wrote for, the place he (servant) died at, the place where you were taken to, and the place where he (servant) was buried? Do you know the place where he (servant) was buried?'' (Jo)

Jo answers with a nod, having also nodded as each other place was mentioned.

``Go before me and show me all those dreadful places. Stop opposite to each, and don't speak to me unless I speak to you. Don't look back. Do what I want, and I will pay you well.'' (Jo)

Jo attends closely while the words are being spoken; tells them off on his (servant) broom-handle, finding them rather hard; pauses to consider their meaning; considers it satisfactory; and nods his (servant) ragged head.

``I'm fly,'' (Jo)
says Jo.
``But fen larks, you know. Stow hooking it!'' (unknown)

``What does the horrible creature mean?'' (the servant)
exclaims the servant, recoiling from him (servant).

``Stow cutting away, you know!'' (Jo)
says Jo.

``I don't understand you. Go on before! I will give you more money than you ever had in your life.'' (Jo)

Jo screws up his (servant) mouth into a whistle, gives his (servant) ragged head a rub, takes his (servant) broom under his (servant) arm, and leads the way, passing deftly with his (servant) bare feet over the hard stones and through the mud and mire.

Cook's Court. Jo stops. A pause.

``Who lives here?'' (unknown)

``Him (you) wot give him (you) his (you) writing and give me half a bull,'' (Jo)
says Jo in a whisper without looking over his (Cook) shoulder.

``Go on to the next.'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)

Krook's house. Jo stops again. A longer pause.

``Who lives here?'' (unknown)

``HE (you) lived here,'' (Jo)
Jo answers as before.

After a silence he (Cook) is asked,

``In which room?'' (he)

``In the back room up there. You can see the winder from this corner. Up there! That's where I see him (you) stritched out. This is the public-ouse where I was took to.'' (unknown)

``Go on to the next!'' (Jo)

It is a longer walk to the next, but Jo, relieved of his (Cook) first suspicions, sticks to the forms imposed upon him (Cook) and does not look round. By many devious ways, reeking with offence of many kinds, they come to the little tunnel of a court, and to the gas-lamp -LRB-lighted now-RRB-, and to the iron gate.

``He (you) was put there,'' (Jo)
says Jo, holding to the bars and looking in.

``Where? Oh, what a scene of horror!'' (unknown)

``There!'' (Jo)
says Jo, pointing.
``Over yinder. Among them piles of bones, and close to that there kitchin winder! They put him (you) wery nigh the top. They was obliged to stamp upon it to git it in. I could unkiver it for you with my broom if the gate was open. That's why they locks it, I s`pose,'' (unknown)
giving it a shake.
``It's always locked. Look at the rat!'' (Jo)
cries Jo, excited.
``Hi! Look! There he (you) goes! Ho! Into the ground!'' (The servant)

The servant shrinks into a corner, into a corner of that hideous archway, with its deadly stains contaminating her (Jo) dress; and putting out her (Jo) two hands and passionately telling him (servant) to keep away from her (Jo), for he (servant) is loathsome to her (Jo), so remains for some moments. Jo stands staring and is still staring when she (Jo) recovers herself.

``Is this place of abomination consecrated ground?'' (unknown)

``I don't know nothink of consequential ground,'' (Jo)
says Jo, still staring.

``Is it blessed?'' (unknown)

``Which?'' (Jo)
says Jo, in the last degree amazed.

``Is it blessed?'' (unknown)

``I'm blest if I know,'' (Jo)
says Jo, staring more than ever;
``but I shouldn't think it warn't. Blest?'' (Jo)
repeats Jo, something troubled in his (servant) mind.
``It an't done it much good if it is. Blest? I should think it was t`othered myself. But I don't know nothink!'' (he)

The servant takes as little heed of what he (servant) says as she (Jo) seems to take of what she (Jo) has said herself. She (Jo) draws off her (Jo) glove to get some money from her (Jo) purse. Jo silently notices how white and small her (Jo) hand is and what a jolly servant she (Jo) must be to wear such sparkling rings.

She (Jo) drops a piece of money in his (servant) hand without touching it, and shuddering as their hands approach.

``Now,'' (she)
she (Jo) adds,
``show me the spot again!'' (she)

Jo thrusts the handle of his (servant) broom between the bars of the gate, and with his (servant) utmost power of elaboration, points it out. At length, looking aside to see if he (servant) has made himself intelligible, he (servant) finds that he (servant) is alone.

His (servant) first proceeding is to hold the piece of money to the gas-light and to be overpowered at finding that it is yellow--gold. His (servant) next is to give it a one-sided bite at the edge as a test of its quality. His (servant) next, to put it in his (servant) mouth for safety and to sweep the step and passage with great care. His (servant) job done, he (servant) sets off for Tom-all-Alone's, stopping in the light of innumerable gas-lamps to produce the piece of gold and give it another one-sided bite as a reassurance of its being genuine.

The Mercury in powder is in no want of society to-night, for my Lady goes to a grand dinner and three or four balls. Sir Leicester is fidgety down at Chesney Wold, with no better company than the gout; he (Chesney) complains to Mrs. Rouncewell that the rain makes such a monotonous pattering on the terrace that he (Chesney) can't read the paper even by the fireside in his (Chesney) own snug dressing-room.

``Sir Leicester would have done better to try the other side of the house, my dear,'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)
says Mrs. Rouncewell to Rosa.
``His (myself) dressing-room is on my Lady's side. And in all these years I never heard the step upon the Ghost's Walk more distinct than it is to-night!'' (Esther/Miss Summerson/Esther Summerson)

CHAPTER XVII

Esther's Narrative

Richard very often came to see us while we remained in London -LRB-though he (Richard) soon failed in his (Richard) letter-writing-RRB-, and with his (Richard) quick abilities, his (Richard) good spirits, his (Richard) good temper, his (Richard) gaiety and freshness, was always delightful. But though I liked him (Richard) more and more the better I knew him (Richard), I still felt more and more how much it was to be regretted that he (Richard) had been educated in no habits of application and concentration. The system which had addressed him (Richard) in exactly the same manner as it had addressed hundreds of other boys, all varying in character and capacity, had enabled him (character) to dash through his (character) tasks, always with fair credit and often with distinction, but in a fitful, dazzling way that had confirmed his (character) reliance on those very qualities in himself which it had been most desirable to direct and train. They were good qualities, without which no high place can be meritoriously won, but like fire and water, though excellent servants, they were very bad masters. If they had been under Richard's direction, they would have been his (Richard) friends; but Richard being under their direction, they became his (Richard) enemies.

I write down these opinions not because I believe that this or any other thing was so because I thought so, but only because I did think so and I want to be quite candid about all I thought and did. These were my thoughts about Richard. I thought I often observed besides how right my guardian was in what he (Richard) had said, and that the uncertainties and delays of the Chancery suit had imparted to his (Richard) nature something of the careless spirit of a gamester who felt that he (Richard) was part of a great gaming system.

Mr. and Mrs. Bayham Badger coming one afternoon when my guardian was not at home, in the course of conversation I naturally inquired after Richard.

``Why, Mr. Carstone,'' (Mrs. Badger/Mrs. Bayham Badger)
said Mrs. Badger,
``is very well and is, I assure you, a great acquisition to our society. Captain Swosser used to say of me that I was always better than land a-head and a breeze a-starn to the midshipmen's mess when the purser's junk had become as tough as the fore-topsel weather earings. It was his (Captain) naval way of mentioning generally that I was an acquisition to any society. I may render the same tribute, I am sure, to Mr. Carstone. But I--you won't think me premature if I mention it?'' (Mrs. Badger/Mrs. Bayham Badger)

I said no, as Mrs. Badger's insinuating tone seemed to require such an answer.

``Nor Miss Clare?'' (Mrs. Badger/Mrs. Bayham Badger)
said Mrs. Bayham Badger sweetly.

Ada said no, too, and looked uneasy.

``Why, you see, my dears,'' (Mrs. Badger/Mrs. Bayham Badger)
said Mrs. Badger,
''--you'll excuse me calling you my dears?'' (Mrs. Badger/Mrs. Bayham Badger)

We entreated Mrs. Badger not to mention it.

``Because you really are, if I may take the liberty of saying so,'' (Mrs. Badger/Mrs. Bayham Badger)
pursued Mrs. Badger,
``so perfectly charming. You see, my dears, that although I am still young--or Mr. Bayham Badger pays me the compliment of saying so--'' (Mrs. Badger/Mrs. Bayham Badger)

``No,'' (Mr. Badger/Mr. Bayham Badger)
Mr. Badger called out like some one contradicting at a public meeting.
``Not at all!'' (unknown)

``Very well,'' (Mrs. Badger/Mrs. Bayham Badger)
smiled Mrs. Badger,
``we will say still young.'' (Mrs. Badger/Mrs. Bayham Badger)

``Undoubtedly,'' (Mr. Badger/Mr. Bayham Badger)
said Mr. Badger.

``My dears, though still young, I have had many opportunities of observing young men. There were many such on board the dear old Crippler, I assure you. After that, when I was with Captain Swosser in the Mediterranean, I embraced every opportunity of knowing and befriending the midshipmen under Captain Swosser's command. YOU never heard them called the young gentlemen, my dears, and probably would not understand allusions to their pipe-claying their weekly accounts, but it is otherwise with me, for blue water has been a second home to me, and I have been quite a sailor. Again, with Professor Dingo.'' (unknown)

``A man of European reputation,'' (Mr. Badger/Mr. Bayham Badger)
murmured Mr. Badger.

``When I lost my dear first and became the wife of my dear second,'' (Mrs. Badger/Mrs. Bayham Badger)
said Mrs. Badger, speaking of her (Badger) former husbands as if they were parts of a charade,
``I still enjoyed opportunities of observing youth. The class attendant on Professor Dingo's lectures was a large one, and it became my pride, as the wife of an eminent scientific man seeking herself in science the utmost consolation it could impart, to throw our house open to the students as a kind of Scientific Exchange. Every Tuesday evening there was lemonade and a mixed biscuit for all who chose to partake of those refreshments. And there was science to an unlimited extent.'' (husbands)

``Remarkable assemblies those, Miss Summerson,'' (Mr. Badger/Mr. Bayham Badger)
said Mr. Badger reverentially.
``There must have been great intellectual friction going on there under the auspices of such a man!'' (unknown)

``And now,'' (Mrs. Badger/Mrs. Bayham Badger)
pursued Mrs. Badger,
``now that I am the wife of my dear third, Mr. Badger, I still pursue those habits of observation which were formed during the lifetime of Captain Swosser and adapted to new and unexpected purposes during the lifetime of Professor Dingo. I therefore have not come to the consideration of Mr. Carstone as a neophyte. And yet I am very much of the opinion, my dears, that he (Carstone) has not chosen his (Carstone) profession advisedly.'' (Mrs. Badger/Mrs. Bayham Badger)

Ada looked so very anxious now that I asked Mrs. Badger on what she (Badger) founded her (Badger) supposition.

``My dear Miss Summerson,'' (she)
she (Badger) replied,
``on Mr. Carstone's character and conduct. He (Carstone) is of such a very easy disposition that probably he (Carstone) would never think it worth-while to mention how he (Carstone) really feels, but he (Carstone) feels languid about the profession. He (Carstone) has not that positive interest in it which makes it his (Carstone) vocation. If he (Carstone) has any decided impression in reference to it, I should say it was that it is a tiresome pursuit. Now, this is not promising. Young men like Mr. Allan Woodcourt who take it from a strong interest in all that it can do will find some reward in it through a great deal of work for a very little money and through years of considerable endurance and disappointment. But I am quite convinced that this would never be the case with Mr. Carstone.'' (she)

``Does Mr. Badger think so too?'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)
asked Ada timidly.

``Why,'' (Mr. Badger/Mr. Bayham Badger)
said Mr. Badger,
``to tell the truth, Miss Clare, this view of the matter had not occurred to me until Mrs. Badger mentioned it. But when Mrs. Badger put it in that light, I naturally gave great consideration to it, knowing that Mrs. Badger's mind, in addition to its natural advantages, has had the rare advantage of being formed by two such very distinguished -LRB-I will even say illustrious-RRB- public men as Captain Swosser of the Royal Navy and Professor Dingo. The conclusion at which I have arrived is--in short, is Mrs. Badger's conclusion.'' (Mr. Badger/Mr. Bayham Badger)

``It was a maxim of Captain Swosser's,'' (Mrs. Badger/Mrs. Bayham Badger)
said Mrs. Badger, ``speaking in his (Captain) figurative naval manner, that when you make pitch hot, you cannot make it too hot; and that if you only have to swab a plank, you should swab it as if Davy Jones were after you. It appears to me that this maxim is applicable to the medical as well as to the nautical profession.

``To all professions,'' (Mr. Badger/Mr. Bayham Badger)
observed Mr. Badger.
``It was admirably said by Captain Swosser. Beautifully said.'' (unknown)

``People objected to Professor Dingo when we were staying in the north of Devon after our marriage,'' (Mrs. Badger/Mrs. Bayham Badger)
said Mrs. Badger,
``that he (Professor) disfigured some of the houses and other buildings by chipping off fragments of those edifices with his (Professor) little geological hammer. But the professor replied that he (professor) knew of no building save the Temple of Science. The principle is the same, I think?'' (Mrs. Badger/Mrs. Bayham Badger)

``Precisely the same,'' (Mr. Badger/Mr. Bayham Badger)
said Mr. Badger.
``Finely expressed! The professor made the same remark, Miss Summerson, in his (professor) last illness, when -LRB-his (professor) mind wandering-RRB- he (professor) insisted on keeping his (professor) little hammer under the pillow and chipping at the countenances of the attendants. The ruling passion!'' (Mr. Mrs.)

Although we could have dispensed with the length at which Mr. and Mrs. Badger pursued the conversation, we both felt that it was disinterested in them to express the opinion they had communicated to us and that there was a great probability of its being sound. We agreed to say nothing to Mr. Jarndyce until we had spoken to Richard; and as he (Richard) was coming next evening, we resolved to have a very serious talk with him (Richard).

So after he (Richard) had been a little while with Ada, I went in and found my darling -LRB-as I knew she (Ada) would be-RRB- prepared to consider him (Richard) thoroughly right in whatever he (Richard) said.

``And how do you get on, Richard?'' (I.)
said I. I always sat down on the other side of him (Richard). He (Richard) made quite a sister of me.

``Oh! Well enough!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard.

``He (Richard) can't say better than that, Esther, can he (Richard)?'' (unknown)
cried my pet triumphantly.

I tried to look at my pet in the wisest manner, but of course I couldn't.

``Well enough?'' (I)
I repeated.

``Yes,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard,
``well enough. It's rather jog-trotty and humdrum. But it'll do as well as anything else!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``Oh! My dear Richard!'' (I)
I remonstrated.

``What's the matter?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard.

``Do as well as anything else!'' (unknown)

``I don't think there's any harm in that, Dame Durden,'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)
said Ada, looking so confidingly at me across him (Richard);
``because if it will do as well as anything else, it will do very well, I hope.'' (him)

``Oh, yes, I hope so,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
returned Richard, carelessly tossing his (Richard) hair from his (Richard) forehead.
``After all, it may be only a kind of probation till our suit is--I forgot though. I am not to mention the suit. Forbidden ground! Oh, yes, it's all right enough. Let us talk about something else.'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)

Ada would have done so willingly, and with a full persuasion that we had brought the question to a most satisfactory state. But I thought it would be useless to stop there, so I began again.

``No, but Richard,'' (I)
said I,
``and my dear Ada! Consider how important it is to you both, and what a point of honour it is towards your cousin, that you, Richard, should be quite in earnest without any reservation. I think we had better talk about this, really, Ada. It will be too late very soon.'' (I)

``Oh, yes! We must talk about it!'' (Ada)
said Ada.
``But I think Richard is right.'' (she)

What was the use of my trying to look wise when she (Ada) was so pretty, and so engaging, and so fond of him (Richard)!

``Mr. and Mrs. Badger were here yesterday, Richard,'' (I)
said I,
``and they seemed disposed to think that you had no great liking for the profession.'' (I)

``Did they though?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard.
``Oh! Well, that rather alters the case, because I had no idea that they thought so, and I should not have liked to disappoint or inconvenience them. The fact is, I don't care much about it. But, oh, it don't matter! It'll do as well as anything else!'' (unknown)

``You hear him (Richard), Ada!'' (I.)
said I.

``The fact is,'' (I.)
Richard proceeded, half thoughtfully and half jocosely,
``it is not quite in my way. I don't take to it. And I get too much of Mrs. Bayham Badger's first and second.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``I am sure THAT``S very natural!'' cried Ada, quite delighted.

``The very thing we both said yesterday, Esther!'' (unknown)

``Then,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
pursued Richard,
``it's monotonous, and to-day is too like yesterday, and to-morrow is too like to-day.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``But I am afraid,'' (I)
said I,
``this is an objection to all kinds of application--to life itself, except under some very uncommon circumstances.'' (I)

``Do you think so?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
returned Richard, still considering.
``Perhaps! Ha! Why, then, you know,'' (he)
he (Richard) added, suddenly becoming gay again,
``we travel outside a circle to what I said just now. It'll do as well as anything else. Oh, it's all right enough! Let us talk about something else.'' (he)

But even Ada, with her (Ada) loving face--and if it had seemed innocent and trusting when I first saw it in that memorable November fog, how much more did it seem now when I knew her (Ada) innocent and trusting heart--even Ada shook her (Ada) head at this and looked serious. So I thought it a good opportunity to hint to Richard that if he (Richard) were sometimes a little careless of himself, I was very sure he (Richard) never meant to be careless of Ada, and that it was a part of his (Richard) affectionate consideration for her (Ada) not to slight the importance of a step that might influence both their lives. This made him (Richard) almost grave.

``My dear Mother Hubbard,'' (he)
he (Richard) said,
``that's the very thing! I have thought of that several times and have been quite angry with myself for meaning to be so much in earnest and--somehow--not exactly being so. I don't know how it is; I seem to want something or other to stand by. Even you have no idea how fond I am of Ada -LRB-my darling cousin, I love you, so much!-RRB-, but I don't settle down to constancy in other things. It's such uphill work, and it takes such a time!'' (he)
said Richard with an air of vexation.

``That may be,'' (I)
I suggested,
``because you don't like what you have chosen.'' (I)

``Poor fellow!'' (Ada)
said Ada.
``I am sure I don't wonder at it!'' (unknown)

No. It was not of the least use my trying to look wise. I tried again, but how could I do it, or how could it have any effect if I could, while Ada rested her (Ada) clasped hands upon his (Richard) shoulder and while he (Richard) looked at her (Ada) tender blue eyes, and while they looked at him (Richard)!

``You see, my precious girl,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard, passing her (Ada) golden curls through and through his (Richard) hand,
``I was a little hasty perhaps; or I misunderstood my own inclinations perhaps. They don't seem to lie in that direction. I couldn't tell till I tried. Now the question is whether it's worth-while to undo all that has been done. It seems like making a great disturbance about nothing particular.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``My dear Richard,'' (I)
said I,
``how CAN you say about nothing particular?'' (I)

``I don't mean absolutely that,'' (he)
he (Richard) returned.
``I mean that it MAY be nothing particular because I may never want it.'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)

Both Ada and I urged, in reply, not only that it was decidedly worth-while to undo what had been done, but that it must be undone. I then asked Richard whether he (Richard) had thought of any more congenial pursuit.

``There, my dear Mrs. Shipton,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard,
``you touch me home. Yes, I have. I have been thinking that the law is the boy for me.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``The law!'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)
repeated Ada as if she (Ada) were afraid of the name.

``If I went into Kenge's office,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard,
``and if I were placed under articles to Kenge, I should have my eye on the--hum!--the forbidden ground--and should be able to study it, and master it, and to satisfy myself that it was not neglected and was being properly conducted. I should be able to look after Ada's interests and my own interests -LRB-the same thing!-RRB-; and I should peg away at Blackstone and all those fellows with the most tremendous ardour.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

I was not by any means so sure of that, and I saw how his (Richard) hankering after the vague things yet to come of those long-deferred hopes cast a shade on Ada's face. But I thought it best to encourage him (Richard) in any project of continuous exertion, and only advised him (Richard) to be quite sure that his (Richard) mind was made up now.

``My dear Minerva,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard,
``I am as steady as you are. I made a mistake; we are all liable to mistakes; I won't do so any more, and I'll become such a lawyer as is not often seen. That is, you know,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard, relapsing into doubt,
``if it really is worth-while, after all, to make such a disturbance about nothing particular!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

This led to our saying again, with a great deal of gravity, all that we had said already and to our coming to much the same conclusion afterwards. But we so strongly advised Richard to be frank and open with Mr. Jarndyce, without a moment's delay, and his (Jarndyce) disposition was naturally so opposed to concealment that he (Jarndyce) sought him (Jarndyce) out at once -LRB-taking us with him (Jarndyce)-RRB- and made a full avowal.

``Rick,'' (guardian)
said my guardian, after hearing him (Jarndyce) attentively,
``we can retreat with honour, and we will. But we must be careful--for our cousin's sake, Rick, for our cousin's sake--that we make no more such mistakes. Therefore, in the matter of the law, we will have a good trial before we decide. We will look before we leap, and take plenty of time about it.'' (him)

Richard's energy was of such an impatient and fitful kind that he (Richard) would have liked nothing better than to have gone to Mr. Kenge's office in that hour and to have entered into articles with him (Kenge) on the spot. Submitting, however, with a good grace to the caution that we had shown to be so necessary, he (Kenge) contented himself with sitting down among us in his (Kenge) lightest spirits and talking as if his (Kenge) one unvarying purpose in life from childhood had been that one which now held possession of him (Kenge). My guardian was very kind and cordial with him (Kenge), but rather grave, enough so to cause Ada, when he (Kenge) had departed and we were going upstairs to bed, to say,

``Cousin John, I hope you don't think the worse of Richard?'' (he)

``No, my love,'' (he)
said he (Kenge).

``Because it was very natural that Richard should be mistaken in such a difficult case. It is not uncommon.'' (unknown)

``No, no, my love,'' (he)
said he (Kenge).
``Don't look unhappy.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I am not unhappy, cousin John!'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)
said Ada, smiling cheerfully, with her (Ada) hand upon his (Kenge) shoulder, where she (Ada) had put it in bidding him (Kenge) good night.
``But I should be a little so if you thought at all the worse of Richard.'' (unknown)

``My dear,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce,
``I should think the worse of him (Richard) only if you were ever in the least unhappy through his (Richard) means. I should be more disposed to quarrel with myself even then, than with poor Rick, for I brought you together. But, tut, all this is nothing! He (Rick) has time before him (Rick), and the race to run. I think the worse of him (Rick)? Not I, my loving cousin! And not you, I swear!'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)

``No, indeed, cousin John,'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)
said Ada,
``I am sure I could not--I am sure I would not--think any ill of Richard if the whole world did. I could, and I would, think better of him (Richard) then than at any other time!'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)

So quietly and honestly she (Ada) said it, with her (Ada) hands upon his (Jarndyce) shoulders--both hands now--and looking up into his (Jarndyce) face, like the picture of truth!

``I think,'' (guardian)
said my guardian, thoughtfully regarding her (Ada),
``I think it must be somewhere written that the virtues of the mothers shall occasionally be visited on the children, as well as the sins of the father. Good night, my rosebud. Good night, little woman. Pleasant slumbers! Happy dreams!'' (her)

This was the first time I ever saw him (Jarndyce) follow Ada with his (Jarndyce) eyes with something of a shadow on their benevolent expression. I well remembered the look with which he (Jarndyce) had contemplated her (Ada) and Richard when she (Ada) was singing in the firelight; it was but a very little while since he (Richard) had watched them passing down the room in which the sun was shining, and away into the shade; but his (Richard) glance was changed, and even the silent look of confidence in me which now followed it once more was not quite so hopeful and untroubled as it had originally been.

Ada praised Richard more to me that night than ever she (Ada) had praised him (Richard) yet. She (Ada) went to sleep with a little bracelet he (Richard) had given her (Ada) clasped upon her (Ada) arm. I fancied she (Ada) was dreaming of him (Richard) when I kissed her (Ada) cheek after she (Ada) had slept an hour and saw how tranquil and happy she (Ada) looked.

For I was so little inclined to sleep myself that night that I sat up working. It would not be worth mentioning for its own sake, but I was wakeful and rather low-spirited. I don't know why. At least I don't think I know why. At least, perhaps I do, but I don't think it matters.

At any rate, I made up my mind to be so dreadfully industrious that I would leave myself not a moment's leisure to be low-spirited. For I naturally said,

``Esther! You to be low-spirited. YOU!'' (I)
And it really was time to say so, for I--yes, I really did see myself in the glass, almost crying.
``As if you had anything to make you unhappy, instead of everything to make you happy, you ungrateful heart!'' (I)
said I.

If I could have made myself go to sleep, I would have done it directly, but not being able to do that, I took out of my basket some ornamental work for our house -LRB-I mean Bleak House-RRB- that I was busy with at that time and sat down to it with great determination. It was necessary to count all the stitches in that work, and I resolved to go on with it until I couldn't keep my eyes open, and then to go to bed.

I soon found myself very busy. But I had left some silk downstairs in a work-table drawer in the temporary growlery, and coming to a stop for want of it, I took my candle and went softly down to get it. To my great surprise, on going in I found my guardian still there, and sitting looking at the ashes. He (I) was lost in thought, his (I) book lay unheeded by his (I) side, his (I) silvered iron-grey hair was scattered confusedly upon his (I) forehead as though his (I) hand had been wandering among it while his (I) thoughts were elsewhere, and his (I) face looked worn. Almost frightened by coming upon him (I) so unexpectedly, I stood still for a moment and should have retired without speaking had he (I) not, in again passing his (I) hand abstractedly through his (I) hair, seen me and started.

``Esther!'' (I)

I told him (I) what I had come for.

``At work so late, my dear?'' (unknown)

``I am working late to-night,'' (I)
said I,
``because I couldn't sleep and wished to tire myself. But, dear guardian, you are late too, and look weary. You have no trouble, I hope, to keep you waking?'' (I)

``None, little woman, that YOU would readily understand,'' (he)
said he (I).

He (I) spoke in a regretful tone so new to me that I inwardly repeated, as if that would help me to his (I) meaning,

``That I could readily understand!'' (me)

``Remain a moment, Esther,'' (he)
said he (I),
``You were in my thoughts.'' (he)

``I hope I was not the trouble, guardian?'' (He)

He (I) slightly waved his (I) hand and fell into his (I) usual manner. The change was so remarkable, and he (I) appeared to make it by dint of so much self-command, that I found myself again inwardly repeating,

``None that I could understand!'' (I)

``Little woman,'' (guardian)
said my guardian,
``I was thinking--that is, I have been thinking since I have been sitting here--that you ought to know of your own history all I know. It is very little. Next to nothing.'' (guardian)

``Dear guardian,'' (I)
I replied,
``when you spoke to me before on that subject--'' (I)

``But since then,'' (I)
he (I) gravely interposed, anticipating what I meant to say,
``I have reflected that your having anything to ask me, and my having anything to tell you, are different considerations, Esther. It is perhaps my duty to impart to you the little I know.'' (I)

``If you think so, guardian, it is right.'' (unknown)

``I think so,'' (he)
he (I) returned very gently, and kindly, and very distinctly.
``My dear, I think so now. If any real disadvantage can attach to your position in the mind of any man or woman worth a thought, it is right that you at least of all the world should not magnify it to yourself by having vague impressions of its nature.'' (I)

I sat down and said after a little effort to be as calm as I ought to be, ``One of my earliest remembrances, guardian, is of these words:

``Your mother, Esther, is your disgrace, and you were hers. The time will come, and soon enough, when you will understand this better, and will feel it too, as no one save a woman can.''' (I)
I had covered my face with my hands in repeating the words, but I took them away now with a better kind of shame, I hope, and told him (I) that to him (I) I owed the blessing that I had from my childhood to that hour never, never, never felt it. He (I) put up his (I) hand as if to stop me. I well knew that he (I) was never to be thanked, and said no more.

``Nine years, my dear,'' (he)
he (I) said after thinking for a little while,
``have passed since I received a letter from a lady living in seclusion, written with a stern passion and power that rendered it unlike all other letters I have ever read. It was written to me -LRB-as it told me in so many words-RRB-, perhaps because it was the writer's idiosyncrasy to put that trust in me, perhaps because it was mine to justify it. It told me of a child, an orphan girl then twelve years old, in some such cruel words as those which live in your remembrance. It told me that the writer had bred her (girl) in secrecy from her (girl) birth, had blotted out all trace of her (girl) existence, and that if the writer were to die before the child became a woman, she (woman) would be left entirely friendless, nameless, and unknown. It asked me to consider if I would, in that case, finish what the writer had begun.'' (he)

I listened in silence and looked attentively at him (I).

``Your early recollection, my dear, will supply the gloomy medium through which all this was seen and expressed by the writer, and the distorted religion which clouded her (woman) mind with impressions of the need there was for the child to expiate an offence of which she (woman) was quite innocent. I felt concerned for the little creature, in her (woman) darkened life, and replied to the letter.'' (I)

I took his (I) hand and kissed it.

``It laid the injunction on me that I should never propose to see the writer, who had long been estranged from all intercourse with the world, but who would see a confidential agent if I would appoint one. I accredited Mr. Kenge. The lady said, of her (lady) own accord and not of his (Kenge) seeking, that her (lady) name was an assumed one. That she (lady) was, if there were any ties of blood in such a case, the child's aunt. That more than this she (aunt) would never -LRB-and he (Kenge) was well persuaded of the steadfastness of her (aunt) resolution-RRB- for any human consideration disclose. My dear, I have told you all.'' (I)

I held his (I) hand for a little while in mine.

``I saw my ward oftener than she (aunt) saw me,'' (he)
he (I) added, cheerily making light of it,
``and I always knew she (aunt) was beloved, useful, and happy. She (aunt) repays me twenty-thousandfold, and twenty more to that, every hour in every day!'' (he)

``And oftener still,'' (I)
said I,
``she (aunt) blesses the guardian who is a father to her (aunt)!'' (I)

At the word father, I saw his (father) former trouble come into his (father) face. He (father) subdued it as before, and it was gone in an instant; but it had been there and it had come so swiftly upon my words that I felt as if they had given him (father) a shock. I again inwardly repeated, wondering,

``That I could readily understand. None that I could readily understand!'' (I)
No, it was true. I did not understand it. Not for many and many a day.

``Take a fatherly good night, my dear,'' (he)
said he (father), kissing me on the forehead,
``and so to rest. These are late hours for working and thinking. You do that for all of us, all day long, little housekeeper!'' (me)

I neither worked nor thought any more that night. I opened my grateful heart to heaven in thankfulness for its providence to me and its care of me, and fell asleep.

We had a visitor next day. Mr. Allan Woodcourt came. He (Woodcourt) came to take leave of us; he (Woodcourt) had settled to do so beforehand. He (Woodcourt) was going to China and to India as a surgeon on board ship. He (Woodcourt) was to be away a long, long time.

I believe--at least I know--that he (Woodcourt) was not rich. All his (Woodcourt) widowed mother could spare had been spent in qualifying him (Woodcourt) for his (Woodcourt) profession. It was not lucrative to a young practitioner, with very little influence in London; and although he (Woodcourt) was, night and day, at the service of numbers of poor people and did wonders of gentleness and skill for them, he (Woodcourt) gained very little by it in money. He (Woodcourt) was seven years older than I. Not that I need mention it, for it hardly seems to belong to anything.

I think--I mean, he (Woodcourt) told us--that he (Woodcourt) had been in practice three or four years and that if he (Woodcourt) could have hoped to contend through three or four more, he (Woodcourt) would not have made the voyage on which he (Woodcourt) was bound. But he (Woodcourt) had no fortune or private means, and so he (Woodcourt) was going away. He (Woodcourt) had been to see us several times altogether. We thought it a pity he (Woodcourt) should go away. Because he (Woodcourt) was distinguished in his (Woodcourt) art among those who knew it best, and some of the greatest men belonging to it had a high opinion of him (Woodcourt).

When he (Woodcourt) came to bid us good-bye, he (Woodcourt) brought his (Woodcourt) mother with him (Woodcourt) for the first time. She (mother) was a pretty old lady, with bright black eyes, but she (mother) seemed proud. She (mother) came from Wales and had had, a long time ago, an eminent person for an ancestor, of the name of Morgan ap-Kerrig--of some place that sounded like Gimlet--who was the most illustrious person that ever was known and all of whose relations were a sort of royal family. He (royal) appeared to have passed his (royal) life in always getting up into mountains and fighting somebody; and a bard whose name sounded like Crumlinwallinwer had sung his (bard) praises in a piece which was called, as nearly as I could catch it, Mewlinnwillinwodd.

Mrs. Woodcourt, after expatiating to us on the fame of her (Woodcourt) great kinsman, said that no doubt wherever her (Woodcourt) son Allan went he (Allan) would remember his (Allan) pedigree and would on no account form an alliance below it. She (Woodcourt) told him (Allan) that there were many handsome English ladies in India who went out on speculation, and that there were some to be picked up with property, but that neither charms nor wealth would suffice for the descendant from such a line without birth, which must ever be the first consideration. She (Woodcourt) talked so much about birth that for a moment I half fancied, and with pain--But what an idle fancy to suppose that she (Woodcourt) could think or care what MINE was!

Mr. Woodcourt seemed a little distressed by her (Woodcourt) prolixity, but he (Woodcourt) was too considerate to let her (Woodcourt) see it and contrived delicately to bring the conversation round to making his (Woodcourt) acknowledgments to my guardian for his (Woodcourt) hospitality and for the very happy hours--he (Woodcourt) called them the very happy hours--he (Woodcourt) had passed with us. The recollection of them, he (Woodcourt) said, would go with him (Woodcourt) wherever he (Woodcourt) went and would be always treasured. And so we gave him (Woodcourt) our hands, one after another--at least, they did--and I did; and so he (Woodcourt) put his (Woodcourt) lips to Ada's hand--and to mine; and so he (Woodcourt) went away upon his (Woodcourt) long, long voyage!

I was very busy indeed all day and wrote directions home to the servants, and wrote notes for my guardian, and dusted his (Woodcourt) books and papers, and jingled my housekeeping keys a good deal, one way and another. I was still busy between the lights, singing and working by the window, when who should come in but Caddy, whom I had no expectation of seeing!

``Why, Caddy, my dear,'' (I)
said I,
``what beautiful flowers!'' (I)

She (Ada) had such an exquisite little nosegay in her (Ada) hand.

``Indeed, I think so, Esther,'' (unknown)
replied Caddy.
``They are the loveliest I ever saw.'' (unknown)

``Prince, my dear?'' (I)
said I in a whisper.

``No,'' (me)
answered Caddy, shaking her (Ada) head and holding them to me to smell.
``Not Prince.'' (unknown)

``Well, to be sure, Caddy!'' (I.)
said I.
``You must have two lovers!'' (I.)

``What? Do they look like that sort of thing?'' (unknown)
said Caddy.

``Do they look like that sort of thing?'' (I)
I repeated, pinching her (Ada) cheek.

Caddy only laughed in return, and telling me that she (Ada) had come for half an hour, at the expiration of which time Prince would be waiting for her (Ada) at the corner, sat chatting with me and Ada in the window, every now and then handing me the flowers again or trying how they looked against my hair. At last, when she (Ada) was going, she (Ada) took me into my room and put them in my dress.

``For me?'' (I)
said I, surprised.

``For you,'' (unknown)
said Caddy with a kiss.
``They were left behind by somebody.'' (unknown)

``Left behind?'' (unknown)

``At poor Miss Flite's,'' (unknown)
said Caddy.
``Somebody who has been very good to her (my) was hurrying away an hour ago to join a ship and left these flowers behind. No, no! Don't take them out. Let the pretty little things lie here,'' (unknown)
said Caddy, adjusting them with a careful hand,
``because I was present myself, and I shouldn't wonder if somebody left them on purpose!'' (unknown)

``Do they look like that sort of thing?'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)
said Ada, coming laughingly behind me and clasping me merrily round the waist.
``Oh, yes, indeed they do, Dame Durden! They look very, very like that sort of thing. Oh, very like it indeed, my dear!'' (Lady)

CHAPTER XVIII

Lady Dedlock

It was not so easy as it had appeared at first to arrange for Richard's making a trial of Mr. Kenge's office. Richard himself was the chief impediment. As soon as he (Richard) had it in his (Richard) power to leave Mr. Badger at any moment, he (Richard) began to doubt whether he (Richard) wanted to leave him (Richard) at all. He (Richard) didn't know, he (Richard) said, really. It wasn't a bad profession; he (Richard) couldn't assert that he (Richard) disliked it; perhaps he (Richard) liked it as well as he (Richard) liked any other--suppose he (Richard) gave it one more chance! Upon that, he (Richard) shut himself up for a few weeks with some books and some bones and seemed to acquire a considerable fund of information with great rapidity. His (Richard) fervour, after lasting about a month, began to cool, and when it was quite cooled, began to grow warm again. His (Richard) vacillations between law and medicine lasted so long that midsummer arrived before he (Richard) finally separated from Mr. Badger and entered on an experimental course of Messrs. Kenge and Carboy. For all his (Badger) waywardness, he (Badger) took great credit to himself as being determined to be in earnest

``this time.'' (he)
And he (Badger) was so good-natured throughout, and in such high spirits, and so fond of Ada, that it was very difficult indeed to be otherwise than pleased with him (Badger).

``As to Mr. Jarndyce,'' (I)
who, I may mention, found the wind much given, during this period, to stick in the east;
``As to Mr. Jarndyce,'' (I)
Richard would say to me,
``he (Jarndyce) is the finest fellow in the world, Esther! I must be particularly careful, if it were only for his (Jarndyce) satisfaction, to take myself well to task and have a regular wind-up of this business now.'' (me)

The idea of his (Richard) taking himself well to task, with that laughing face and heedless manner and with a fancy that everything could catch and nothing could hold, was ludicrously anomalous. However, he (Richard) told us between-whiles that he (Richard) was doing it to such an extent that he (Richard) wondered his (Richard) hair didn't turn grey. His (Richard) regular wind-up of the business was -LRB-as I have said-RRB- that he (Richard) went to Mr. Kenge's about midsummer to try how he (Kenge) liked it.

All this time he (Kenge) was, in money affairs, what I have described him (Kenge) in a former illustration--generous, profuse, wildly careless, but fully persuaded that he (Kenge) was rather calculating and prudent. I happened to say to Ada, in his (Kenge) presence, half jestingly, half seriously, about the time of his (Kenge) going to Mr. Kenge's, that he (Kenge) needed to have Fortunatus' purse, he (Kenge) made so light of money, which he (Kenge) answered in this way,

``My jewel of a dear cousin, you hear this old woman! Why does she (woman) say that? Because I gave eight pounds odd -LRB-or whatever it was-RRB- for a certain neat waistcoat and buttons a few days ago. Now, if I had stayed at Badger's I should have been obliged to spend twelve pounds at a blow for some heart-breaking lecture-fees. So I make four pounds--in a lump--by the transaction!'' (he)

It was a question much discussed between him (Kenge) and my guardian what arrangements should be made for his (Kenge) living in London while he (Kenge) experimented on the law, for we had long since gone back to Bleak House, and it was too far off to admit of his (Kenge) coming there oftener than once a week. My guardian told me that if Richard were to settle down at Mr. Kenge's he (Kenge) would take some apartments or chambers where we too could occasionally stay for a few days at a time;

``but, little woman,'' (he)
he (Kenge) added, rubbing his (Kenge) head very significantly,
``he (Badger) hasn't settled down there yet!'' (he)
The discussions ended in our hiring for him (Kenge), by the month, a neat little furnished lodging in a quiet old house near Queen Square. He (Kenge) immediately began to spend all the money he (Kenge) had in buying the oddest little ornaments and luxuries for this lodging; and so often as Ada and I dissuaded him (Kenge) from making any purchase that he (Kenge) had in contemplation which was particularly unnecessary and expensive, he (Kenge) took credit for what it would have cost and made out that to spend anything less on something else was to save the difference.

While these affairs were in abeyance, our visit to Mr. Boythorn's was postponed. At length, Richard having taken possession of his (Richard) lodging, there was nothing to prevent our departure. He (Richard) could have gone with us at that time of the year very well, but he (Richard) was in the full novelty of his (Richard) new position and was making most energetic attempts to unravel the mysteries of the fatal suit. Consequently we went without him (Richard), and my darling was delighted to praise him (Richard) for being so busy.

We made a pleasant journey down into Lincolnshire by the coach and had an entertaining companion in Mr. Skimpole. His (Skimpole) furniture had been all cleared off, it appeared, by the person who took possession of it on his (Skimpole) blue-eyed daughter's birthday, but he (Skimpole) seemed quite relieved to think that it was gone. Chairs and table, he (Skimpole) said, were wearisome objects; they were monotonous ideas, they had no variety of expression, they looked you out of countenance, and you looked them out of countenance. How pleasant, then, to be bound to no particular chairs and tables, but to sport like a butterfly among all the furniture on hire, and to flit from rosewood to mahogany, and from mahogany to walnut, and from this shape to that, as the humour took one!

``The oddity of the thing is,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole with a quickened sense of the ludicrous,
``that my chairs and tables were not paid for, and yet my landlord walks off with them as composedly as possible. Now, that seems droll! There is something grotesque in it. The chair and table merchant never engaged to pay my landlord my rent. Why should my landlord quarrel with HIM? If I have a pimple on my nose which is disagreeable to my landlord's peculiar ideas of beauty, my landlord has no business to scratch my chair and table merchant's nose, which has no pimple on it. His (merchant) reasoning seems defective!'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

``Well,'' (guardian)
said my guardian good-humouredly,
``it's pretty clear that whoever became security for those chairs and tables will have to pay for them.'' (guardian)

``Exactly!'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
returned Mr. Skimpole. ``That's the crowning point of unreason in the business! I said to my landlord, ``My good man, you are not aware that my excellent friend Jarndyce will have to pay for those things that you are sweeping off in that indelicate manner. Have you no consideration for HIS (Jarndyce) property?
'' He (Skimpole) hadn't the least.'' (unknown)

``And refused all proposals,'' (guardian)
said my guardian.

``Refused all proposals,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
returned Mr. Skimpole. ``I made him (Jarndyce) business proposals. I had him (Jarndyce) into my room. I said, ``You are a man of business, I believe?'' He (Skimpole) replied, ``I am,'' ``Very well,
'' said I, `now let us be business-like. Here is an inkstand, here are pens and paper, here are wafers. What do you want? I have occupied your house for a considerable period, I believe to our mutual satisfaction until this unpleasant misunderstanding arose; let us be at once friendly and business-like. What do you want?'' (I)
In reply to this, he (Skimpole) made use of the figurative expression--which has something Eastern about it--that he (Skimpole) had never seen the colour of my money.
``My amiable friend,'' (I)
said I,
``I never have any money. I never know anything about money.'' (I)
``Well, sir,'' (he)
said he (Skimpole), `what do you offer if I give you time?'' ``My good fellow,'' said I, ``I have no idea of time; but you say you are a man of business, and whatever you can suggest to be done in a business-like way with pen, and ink, and paper--and wafers--I am ready to do. Don't pay yourself at another man's expense -LRB-which is foolish-RRB-, but be business-like!
'' However, he (Skimpole) wouldn't be, and there was an end of it.'' (another man)

If these were some of the inconveniences of Mr. Skimpole's childhood, it assuredly possessed its advantages too. On the journey he (Skimpole) had a very good appetite for such refreshment as came in our way -LRB-including a basket of choice hothouse peaches-RRB-, but never thought of paying for anything. So when the coachman came round for his (Skimpole) fee, he (Skimpole) pleasantly asked him (Skimpole) what he (Skimpole) considered a very good fee indeed, now--a liberal one--and on his (Skimpole) replying half a crown for a single passenger, said it was little enough too, all things considered, and left Mr. Jarndyce to give it him (Jarndyce).

It was delightful weather. The green corn waved so beautifully, the larks sang so joyfully, the hedges were so full of wild flowers, the trees were so thickly out in leaf, the bean-fields, with a light wind blowing over them, filled the air with such a delicious fragrance! Late in the afternoon we came to the market-town where we were to alight from the coach--a dull little town with a church-spire, and a marketplace, and a market-cross, and one intensely sunny street, and a pond with an old horse cooling his (coach) legs in it, and a very few men sleepily lying and standing about in narrow little bits of shade. After the rustling of the leaves and the waving of the corn all along the road, it looked as still, as hot, as motionless a little town as England could produce.

At the inn we found Mr. Boythorn on horseback, waiting with an open carriage to take us to his (Boythorn) house, which was a few miles off. He (Boythorn) was overjoyed to see us and dismounted with great alacrity.

``By heaven!'' (he)
said he (Boythorn) after giving us a courteous greeting.
``This a most infamous coach. It is the most flagrant example of an abominable public vehicle that ever encumbered the face of the earth. It is twenty-five minutes after its time this afternoon. The coachman ought to be put to death!'' (unknown)

``IS he (coach) after his (coach) time?'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole, to whom he (Skimpole) happened to address himself.
``You know my infirmity.'' (unknown)

``Twenty-five minutes! Twenty-six minutes!'' (Mr. Boythorn/Boythorn/Lawrence Boythorn)
replied Mr. Boythorn, referring to his (Boythorn) watch.
``With two ladies in the coach, this scoundrel has deliberately delayed his (scoundrel) arrival six and twenty minutes. Deliberately! It is impossible that it can be accidental! But his (scoundrel) father--and his (scoundrel) uncle--were the most profligate coachmen that ever sat upon a box.'' (he)

While he (Boythorn) said this in tones of the greatest indignation, he (Boythorn) handed us into the little phaeton with the utmost gentleness and was all smiles and pleasure.

``I am sorry, ladies,'' (he)
he (Boythorn) said, standing bare-headed at the carriage-door when all was ready,
``that I am obliged to conduct you nearly two miles out of the way. But our direct road lies through Sir Leicester Dedlock's park, and in that fellow's property I have sworn never to set foot of mine, or horse's foot of mine, pending the present relations between us, while I breathe the breath of life!'' (he)
And here, catching my guardian's eye, he (Boythorn) broke into one of his (Boythorn) tremendous laughs, which seemed to shake even the motionless little market-town.

``Are the Dedlocks down here, Lawrence?'' (guardian)
said my guardian as we drove along and Mr. Boythorn trotted on the green turf by the roadside.

``Sir Arrogant Numskull is here,'' (Mr. Boythorn/Boythorn/Lawrence Boythorn)
replied Mr. Boythorn.
``Ha ha ha! Sir Arrogant is here, and I am glad to say, has been laid by the heels here. My Lady,'' (he)
in naming whom he (Boythorn) always made a courtly gesture as if particularly to exclude her (Boythorn) from any part in the quarrel,
``is expected, I believe, daily. I am not in the least surprised that she (Lady) postpones her (Lady) appearance as long as possible. Whatever can have induced that transcendent woman to marry that effigy and figure-head of a baronet is one of the most impenetrable mysteries that ever baffled human inquiry. Ha ha ha ha!'' (he)

``I suppose,'' (guardian)
said my guardian, laughing,
``WE may set foot in the park while we are here? The prohibition does not extend to us, does it?'' (guardian)

``I can lay no prohibition on my guests,'' (he)
he (Boythorn) said, bending his (Boythorn) head to Ada and me with the smiling politeness which sat so gracefully upon him (Boythorn),
``except in the matter of their departure. I am only sorry that I cannot have the happiness of being their escort about Chesney Wold, which is a very fine place! But by the light of this summer day, Jarndyce, if you call upon the owner while you stay with me, you are likely to have but a cool reception. He (owner) carries himself like an eight-day clock at all times, like one of a race of eight-day clocks in gorgeous cases that never go and never went--Ha ha ha!--but he (owner) will have some extra stiffness, I can promise you, for the friends of his (owner) friend and neighbour Boythorn!'' (him)

``I shall not put him (owner) to the proof,'' (guardian)
said my guardian.
``He (owner) is as indifferent to the honour of knowing me, I dare say, as I am to the honour of knowing him (owner). The air of the grounds and perhaps such a view of the house as any other sightseer might get are quite enough for me.'' (unknown)

``Well!'' (Mr. Boythorn/Boythorn/Lawrence Boythorn)
said Mr. Boythorn.
``I am glad of it on the whole. It's in better keeping. I am looked upon about here as a second Ajax defying the lightning. Ha ha ha ha! When I go into our little church on a Sunday, a considerable part of the inconsiderable congregation expect to see me drop, scorched and withered, on the pavement under the Dedlock displeasure. Ha ha ha ha! I have no doubt he (It) is surprised that I don't. For he (It) is, by heaven, the most self-satisfied, and the shallowest, and the most coxcombical and utterly brainless ass!'' (friend)

Our coming to the ridge of a hill we had been ascending enabled our friend to point out Chesney Wold itself to us and diverted his (Wold) attention from its master.

It was a picturesque old house in a fine park richly wooded. Among the trees and not far from the residence he (Wold) pointed out the spire of the little church of which he (Wold) had spoken. Oh, the solemn woods over which the light and shadow travelled swiftly, as if heavenly wings were sweeping on benignant errands through the summer air; the smooth green slopes, the glittering water, the garden where the flowers were so symmetrically arranged in clusters of the richest colours, how beautiful they looked! The house, with gable and chimney, and tower, and turret, and dark doorway, and broad terrace-walk, twining among the balustrades of which, and lying heaped upon the vases, there was one great flush of roses, seemed scarcely real in its light solidity and in the serene and peaceful hush that rested on all around it. To Ada and to me, that above all appeared the pervading influence. On everything, house, garden, terrace, green slopes, water, old oaks, fern, moss, woods again, and far away across the openings in the prospect to the distance lying wide before us with a purple bloom upon it, there seemed to be such undisturbed repose.

When we came into the little village and passed a small inn with the sign of the Dedlock Arms swinging over the road in front, Mr. Boythorn interchanged greetings with a young gentleman sitting on a bench outside the inn-door who had some fishing-tackle lying beside him (Boythorn).

``That's the housekeeper's grandson, Mr. Rouncewell by name,'' (he)
said, he (Boythorn),
``and he (Rouncewell) is in love with a pretty girl up at the house. Lady Dedlock has taken a fancy to the pretty girl and is going to keep her (Dedlock) about her (Dedlock) own fair person--an honour which my young friend himself does not at all appreciate. However, he (friend) can't marry just yet, even if his (friend) Rosebud were willing; so he (friend) is fain to make the best of it. In the meanwhile, he (friend) comes here pretty often for a day or two at a time to--fish. Ha ha ha ha!'' (he)

``Are he (friend) and the pretty girl engaged, Mr. Boythorn?'' (Ada)
asked Ada.

``Why, my dear Miss Clare,'' (he)
he (Boythorn) returned,
``I think they may perhaps understand each other; but you will see them soon, I dare say, and I must learn from you on such a point--not you from me.'' (he)

Ada blushed, and Mr. Boythorn, trotting forward on his (Boythorn) comely grey horse, dismounted at his (Boythorn) own door and stood ready with extended arm and uncovered head to welcome us when we arrived.

He (Boythorn) lived in a pretty house, formerly the parsonage house, with a lawn in front, a bright flower-garden at the side, and a well-stocked orchard and kitchen-garden in the rear, enclosed with a venerable wall that had of itself a ripened ruddy look. But, indeed, everything about the place wore an aspect of maturity and abundance. The old lime-tree walk was like green cloisters, the very shadows of the cherry-trees and apple-trees were heavy with fruit, the gooseberry-bushes were so laden that their branches arched and rested on the earth, the strawberries and raspberries grew in like profusion, and the peaches basked by the hundred on the wall. Tumbled about among the spread nets and the glass frames sparkling and winking in the sun there were such heaps of drooping pods, and marrows, and cucumbers, that every foot of ground appeared a vegetable treasury, while the smell of sweet herbs and all kinds of wholesome growth -LRB-to say nothing of the neighbouring meadows where the hay was carrying-RRB- made the whole air a great nosegay. Such stillness and composure reigned within the orderly precincts of the old red wall that even the feathers hung in garlands to scare the birds hardly stirred; and the wall had such a ripening influence that where, here and there high up, a disused nail and scrap of list still clung to it, it was easy to fancy that they had mellowed with the changing seasons and that they had rusted and decayed according to the common fate.

The house, though a little disorderly in comparison with the garden, was a real old house with settles in the chimney of the brick-floored kitchen and great beams across the ceilings. On one side of it was the terrible piece of ground in dispute, where Mr. Boythorn maintained a sentry in a smock-frock day and night, whose duty was supposed to be, in cases of aggression, immediately to ring a large bell hung up there for the purpose, to unchain a great bull-dog established in a kennel as his (Boythorn) ally, and generally to deal destruction on the enemy. Not content with these precautions, Mr. Boythorn had himself composed and posted there, on painted boards to which his (Boythorn) name was attached in large letters, the following solemn warnings:

``Beware of the bull-dog. He (Boythorn) is most ferocious. Lawrence Boythorn.'' (Mr. Boythorn/Boythorn/Lawrence Boythorn)
``The blunderbus is loaded with slugs. Lawrence Boythorn.'' (unknown)
``Man-traps and spring-guns are set here at all times of the day and night. Lawrence Boythorn.'' (unknown)
``Take notice. That any person or persons audaciously presuming to trespass on this property will be punished with the utmost severity of private chastisement and prosecuted with the utmost rigour of the law. Lawrence Boythorn.'' (he)
These he (Boythorn) showed us from the drawing-room window, while his (Boythorn) bird was hopping about his (Boythorn) head, and he (Boythorn) laughed,
``Ha ha ha ha! Ha ha ha ha!'' (he)
to that extent as he (Boythorn) pointed them out that I really thought he (Boythorn) would have hurt himself.

``But this is taking a good deal of trouble,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole in his (Skimpole) light way,
``when you are not in earnest after all.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

``Not in earnest!'' (Mr. Boythorn/Boythorn/Lawrence Boythorn)
returned Mr. Boythorn with unspeakable warmth.
``Not in earnest! If I could have hoped to train him (Boythorn), I would have bought a lion instead of that dog and would have turned him (Boythorn) loose upon the first intolerable robber who should dare to make an encroachment on my rights. Let Sir Leicester Dedlock consent to come out and decide this question by single combat, and I will meet him (robber) with any weapon known to mankind in any age or country. I am that much in earnest. Not more!'' (unknown)

We arrived at his (Boythorn) house on a Saturday. On the Sunday morning we all set forth to walk to the little church in the park. Entering the park, almost immediately by the disputed ground, we pursued a pleasant footpath winding among the verdant turf and the beautiful trees until it brought us to the church-porch.

The congregation was extremely small and quite a rustic one with the exception of a large muster of servants from the house, some of whom were already in their seats, while others were yet dropping in. There were some stately footmen, and there was a perfect picture of an old coachman, who looked as if he (footmen) were the official representative of all the pomps and vanities that had ever been put into his (footmen) coach. There was a very pretty show of young women, and above them, the handsome old face and fine responsible portly figure of the housekeeper towered pre-eminent. The pretty girl of whom Mr. Boythorn had told us was close by her (girl). She (girl) was so very pretty that I might have known her (girl) by her (girl) beauty even if I had not seen how blushingly conscious she (girl) was of the eyes of the young fisherman, whom I discovered not far off. One face, and not an agreeable one, though it was handsome, seemed maliciously watchful of this pretty girl, and indeed of every one and everything there. It was a Frenchwoman's.

As the bell was yet ringing and the great people were not yet come, I had leisure to glance over the church, which smelt as earthy as a grave, and to think what a shady, ancient, solemn little church it was. The windows, heavily shaded by trees, admitted a subdued light that made the faces around me pale, and darkened the old brasses in the pavement and the time and damp-worn monuments, and rendered the sunshine in the little porch, where a monotonous ringer was working at the bell, inestimably bright. But a stir in that direction, a gathering of reverential awe in the rustic faces, and a blandly ferocious assumption on the part of Mr. Boythorn of being resolutely unconscious of somebody's existence forewarned me that the great people were come and that the service was going to begin.

''`Enter not into judgment with thy servant, O Lord, for in thy sight--''' (the people)

Shall I ever forget the rapid beating at my heart, occasioned by the look I met as I stood up! Shall I ever forget the manner in which those handsome proud eyes seemed to spring out of their languor and to hold mine! It was only a moment before I cast mine down--released again, if I may say so--on my book; but I knew the beautiful face quite well in that short space of time.

And, very strangely, there was something quickened within me, associated with the lonely days at my godmother's; yes, away even to the days when I had stood on tiptoe to dress myself at my little glass after dressing my doll. And this, although I had never seen this lady's face before in all my life--I was quite sure of it--absolutely certain.

It was easy to know that the ceremonious, gouty, grey-haired gentleman, the only other occupant of the great pew, was Sir Leicester Dedlock, and that the lady was Lady Dedlock. But why her (Dedlock) face should be, in a confused way, like a broken glass to me, in which I saw scraps of old remembrances, and why I should be so fluttered and troubled -LRB-for I was still-RRB- by having casually met her (Dedlock) eyes, I could not think.

I felt it to be an unmeaning weakness in me and tried to overcome it by attending to the words I heard. Then, very strangely, I seemed to hear them, not in the reader's voice, but in the well-remembered voice of my godmother. This made me think, did Lady Dedlock's face accidentally resemble my godmother's? It might be that it did, a little; but the expression was so different, and the stern decision which had worn into my godmother's face, like weather into rocks, was so completely wanting in the face before me that it could not be that resemblance which had struck me. Neither did I know the loftiness and haughtiness of Lady Dedlock's face, at all, in any one. And yet I--I, little Esther Summerson, the child who lived a life apart and on whose birthday there was no rejoicing--seemed to arise before my own eyes, evoked out of the past by some power in this fashionable lady, whom I not only entertained no fancy that I had ever seen, but whom I perfectly well knew I had never seen until that hour.

It made me tremble so to be thrown into this unaccountable agitation that I was conscious of being distressed even by the observation of the French maid, though I knew she (maid) had been looking watchfully here, and there, and everywhere, from the moment of her (maid) coming into the church. By degrees, though very slowly, I at last overcame my strange emotion. After a long time, I looked towards Lady Dedlock again. It was while they were preparing to sing, before the sermon. She (Lady) took no heed of me, and the beating at my heart was gone. Neither did it revive for more than a few moments when she (Lady) once or twice afterwards glanced at Ada or at me through her (Ada) glass.

The service being concluded, Sir Leicester gave his (Ada) arm with much taste and gallantry to Lady Dedlock--though he (Ada) was obliged to walk by the help of a thick stick--and escorted her (Dedlock) out of church to the pony carriage in which they had come. The servants then dispersed, and so did the congregation, whom Sir Leicester had contemplated all along -LRB-Mr. Skimpole said to Mr. Boythorn's infinite delight-RRB- as if he (Skimpole) were a considerable landed proprietor in heaven.

``He (robber) believes he (robber) is!'' (Mr. Boythorn/Boythorn/Lawrence Boythorn)
said Mr. Boythorn.
``He (robber) firmly believes it. So did his (robber) father, and his (robber) grandfather, and his (robber) great-grandfather!'' (unknown)

``Do you know,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
pursued Mr. Skimpole very unexpectedly to Mr. Boythorn,
``it's agreeable to me to see a man of that sort.'' (Mr. Boythorn/Boythorn/Lawrence Boythorn)

``IS it!'' (Mr. Boythorn/Boythorn/Lawrence Boythorn)
said Mr. Boythorn.

``Say that he (man) wants to patronize me,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
pursued Mr. Skimpole.
``Very well! I don't object.'' (unknown)

``I do,'' (Mr. Boythorn/Boythorn/Lawrence Boythorn)
said Mr. Boythorn with great vigour.

``Do you really?'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
returned Mr. Skimpole in his (Boythorn) easy light vein. ``But that's taking trouble, surely. And why should you take trouble? Here am I, content to receive things childishly as they fall out, and I never take trouble! I come down here, for instance, and I find a mighty potentate exacting homage. Very well! I say ``Mighty potentate, here IS my homage! It's easier to give it than to withhold it. Here it is. If you have anything of an agreeable nature to show me, I shall be happy to see it; if you have anything of an agreeable nature to give me, I shall be happy to accept it.'' Mighty potentate replies in effect, ``This is a sensible fellow. I find him (fellow) accord with my digestion and my bilious system. He (fellow) doesn't impose upon me the necessity of rolling myself up like a hedgehog with my points outward. I expand, I open, I turn my silver lining outward like Milton's cloud, and it's more agreeable to both of us.
'' That's my view of such things, speaking as a child!'' (Milton)

``But suppose you went down somewhere else to-morrow,'' (Mr. Boythorn/Boythorn/Lawrence Boythorn)
said Mr. Boythorn,
``where there was the opposite of that fellow--or of this fellow. How then?'' (Mr. Boythorn/Boythorn/Lawrence Boythorn)

``How then?'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole with an appearance of the utmost simplicity and candour. ``Just the same then! I should say,
``My esteemed Boythorn'--to make you the personification of our imaginary friend--`my esteemed Boythorn, you object to the mighty potentate? Very good. So do I. I take it that my business in the social system is to be agreeable; I take it that everybody's business in the social system is to be agreeable. It's a system of harmony, in short. Therefore if you object, I object. Now, excellent Boythorn, let us go to dinner!''' (unknown)

``But excellent Boythorn might say,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
returned our host, swelling and growing very red,
``I'll be--'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

``I understand,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole.
``Very likely he (Boythorn) would.'' (unknown)

''--if I WILL go to dinner!'' (Mr. Boythorn/Boythorn/Lawrence Boythorn)
cried Mr. Boythorn in a violent burst and stopping to strike his (Boythorn) stick upon the ground. ``And he (Boythorn) would probably add,
``Is there such a thing as principle, Mr. Harold Skimpole?''' (unknown)

``To which Harold Skimpole would reply, you know,'' (he)
he (Boythorn) returned in his (Boythorn) gayest manner and with his (Boythorn) most ingenuous smile,
''`Upon my life I have not the least idea! I don't know what it is you call by that name, or where it is, or who possesses it. If you possess it and find it comfortable, I am quite delighted and congratulate you heartily. But I know nothing about it, I assure you; for I am a mere child, and I lay no claim to it, and I don't want it!'' (he)
So, you see, excellent Boythorn and I would go to dinner after all!''

This was one of many little dialogues between them which I always expected to end, and which I dare say would have ended under other circumstances, in some violent explosion on the part of our host. But he (Boythorn) had so high a sense of his (Boythorn) hospitable and responsible position as our entertainer, and my guardian laughed so sincerely at and with Mr. Skimpole, as a child who blew bubbles and broke them all day long, that matters never went beyond this point.
