Mr. Skimpole, who always seemed quite unconscious of having been on delicate ground, then betook himself to beginning some sketch in the park which he (Skimpole) never finished, or to playing fragments of airs on the piano, or to singing scraps of songs, or to lying down on his (Skimpole) back under a tree and looking at the sky--which he (Skimpole) couldn't help thinking, he (Skimpole) said, was what he (Skimpole) was meant for; it suited him (Skimpole) so exactly.

``Enterprise and effort,'' (he)
he (Skimpole) would say to us -LRB-on his (Skimpole) back-RRB-, ``are delightful to me. I believe I am truly cosmopolitan. I have the deepest sympathy with them. I lie in a shady place like this and think of adventurous spirits going to the North Pole or penetrating to the heart of the Torrid Zone with admiration. Mercenary creatures ask, ``What is the use of a man's going to the North Pole? What good does it do?
'' I can't say; but, for anything I CAN say, he (Skimpole) may go for the purpose--though he (Skimpole) don't know it--of employing my thoughts as I lie here. Take an extreme case. Take the case of the slaves on American plantations. I dare say they are worked hard, I dare say they don't altogether like it. I dare say theirs is an unpleasant experience on the whole; but they people the landscape for me, they give it a poetry for me, and perhaps that is one of the pleasanter objects of their existence. I am very sensible of it, if it be, and I shouldn't wonder if it were!'' (I)

I always wondered on these occasions whether he (they) ever thought of Mrs. Skimpole and the children, and in what point of view they presented themselves to his (they) cosmopolitan mind. So far as I could understand, they rarely presented themselves at all.

The week had gone round to the Saturday following that beating of my heart in the church; and every day had been so bright and blue that to ramble in the woods, and to see the light striking down among the transparent leaves and sparkling in the beautiful interlacings of the shadows of the trees, while the birds poured out their songs and the air was drowsy with the hum of insects, had been most delightful. We had one favourite spot, deep in moss and last year's leaves, where there were some felled trees from which the bark was all stripped off. Seated among these, we looked through a green vista supported by thousands of natural columns, the whitened stems of trees, upon a distant prospect made so radiant by its contrast with the shade in which we sat and made so precious by the arched perspective through which we saw it that it was like a glimpse of the better land. Upon the Saturday we sat here, Mr. Jarndyce, Ada, and I, until we heard thunder muttering in the distance and felt the large raindrops rattle through the leaves.

The weather had been all the week extremely sultry, but the storm broke so suddenly--upon us, at least, in that sheltered spot--that before we reached the outskirts of the wood the thunder and lightning were frequent and the rain came plunging through the leaves as if every drop were a great leaden bead. As it was not a time for standing among trees, we ran out of the wood, and up and down the moss-grown steps which crossed the plantation-fence like two broad-staved ladders placed back to back, and made for a keeper's lodge which was close at hand. We had often noticed the dark beauty of this lodge standing in a deep twilight of trees, and how the ivy clustered over it, and how there was a steep hollow near, where we had once seen the keeper's dog dive down into the fern as if it were water.

The lodge was so dark within, now the sky was overcast, that we only clearly saw the man who came to the door when we took shelter there and put two chairs for Ada and me. The lattice-windows were all thrown open, and we sat just within the doorway watching the storm. It was grand to see how the wind awoke, and bent the trees, and drove the rain before it like a cloud of smoke; and to hear the solemn thunder and to see the lightning; and while thinking with awe of the tremendous powers by which our little lives are encompassed, to consider how beneficent they are and how upon the smallest flower and leaf there was already a freshness poured from all this seeming rage which seemed to make creation new again.

``Is it not dangerous to sit in so exposed a place?'' (unknown)

``Oh, no, Esther dear!'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)
said Ada quietly.

Ada said it to me, but I had not spoken.

The beating of my heart came back again. I had never heard the voice, as I had never seen the face, but it affected me in the same strange way. Again, in a moment, there arose before my mind innumerable pictures of myself.

Lady Dedlock had taken shelter in the lodge before our arrival there and had come out of the gloom within. She (Dedlock) stood behind my chair with her (Dedlock) hand upon it. I saw her (Dedlock) with her (Dedlock) hand close to my shoulder when I turned my head.

``I have frightened you?'' (she)
she (Dedlock) said.

No. It was not fright. Why should I be frightened!

``I believe,'' (Lady Dedlock/Dedlock)
said Lady Dedlock to my guardian,
``I have the pleasure of speaking to Mr. Jarndyce.'' (guardian)

``Your remembrance does me more honour than I had supposed it would, Lady Dedlock,'' (he)
he (myself) returned.

``I recognized you in church on Sunday. I am sorry that any local disputes of Sir Leicester's--they are not of his (Jarndyce) seeking, however, I believe--should render it a matter of some absurd difficulty to show you any attention here.'' (unknown)

``I am aware of the circumstances,'' (guardian)
returned my guardian with a smile,
``and am sufficiently obliged.'' (guardian)

She (Dedlock) had given him (myself) her (Dedlock) hand in an indifferent way that seemed habitual to her (Dedlock) and spoke in a correspondingly indifferent manner, though in a very pleasant voice. She (Dedlock) was as graceful as she (Dedlock) was beautiful, perfectly self-possessed, and had the air, I thought, of being able to attract and interest any one if she (Dedlock) had thought it worth her (Dedlock) while. The keeper had brought her (Dedlock) a chair on which she (Dedlock) sat in the middle of the porch between us.

``Is the young gentleman disposed of whom you wrote to Sir Leicester about and whose wishes Sir Leicester was sorry not to have it in his (gentleman) power to advance in any way?'' (she)
she (Dedlock) said over her (Dedlock) shoulder to my guardian.

``I hope so,'' (he)
said he (keeper).

She (Dedlock) seemed to respect him (keeper) and even to wish to conciliate him (keeper). There was something very winning in her (Dedlock) haughty manner, and it became more familiar--I was going to say more easy, but that could hardly be--as she (Dedlock) spoke to him (keeper) over her (Dedlock) shoulder.

``I presume this is your other ward, Miss Clare?'' (He)

He (keeper) presented Ada, in form.

``You will lose the disinterested part of your Don Quixote character,'' (Lady Dedlock/Dedlock)
said Lady Dedlock to Mr. Jarndyce over her (Dedlock) shoulder again,
``if you only redress the wrongs of beauty like this. But present me,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
and she (Dedlock) turned full upon me,
``to this young lady too!'' (me)

``Miss Summerson really is my ward,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce.
``I am responsible to no Lord Chancellor in her (Summerson) case.'' (unknown)

``Has Miss Summerson lost both her (Summerson) parents?'' (Lady)
said my Lady.

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``She (Summerson) is very fortunate in her (Summerson) guardian.'' (Lady)

Lady Dedlock looked at me, and I looked at her (Lady) and said I was indeed. All at once she (Lady) turned from me with a hasty air, almost expressive of displeasure or dislike, and spoke to him (Jarndyce) over her (Lady) shoulder again.

``Ages have passed since we were in the habit of meeting, Mr. Jarndyce.'' (unknown)

``A long time. At least I thought it was a long time, until I saw you last Sunday,'' (he)
he (Jarndyce) returned.

``What! Even you are a courtier, or think it necessary to become one to me!'' (she)
she (Lady) said with some disdain.
``I have achieved that reputation, I suppose.'' (unknown)

``You have achieved so much, Lady Dedlock,'' (guardian)
said my guardian,
``that you pay some little penalty, I dare say. But none to me.'' (guardian)

``So much!'' (she)
she (Lady) repeated, slightly laughing.
``Yes!'' (I)

With her (Lady) air of superiority, and power, and fascination, and I know not what, she (Lady) seemed to regard Ada and me as little more than children. So, as she (Lady) slightly laughed and afterwards sat looking at the rain, she (Lady) was as self-possessed and as free to occupy herself with her (Lady) own thoughts as if she (Lady) had been alone.

``I think you knew my sister when we were abroad together better than you know me?'' (she)
she (Lady) said, looking at him (Jarndyce) again.

``Yes, we happened to meet oftener,'' (he)
he (Jarndyce) returned.

``We went our several ways,'' (Lady Dedlock/Dedlock)
said Lady Dedlock,
``and had little in common even before we agreed to differ. It is to be regretted, I suppose, but it could not be helped.'' (Lady Dedlock/Dedlock)

Lady Dedlock again sat looking at the rain. The storm soon began to pass upon its way. The shower greatly abated, the lightning ceased, the thunder rolled among the distant hills, and the sun began to glisten on the wet leaves and the falling rain. As we sat there, silently, we saw a little pony phaeton coming towards us at a merry pace.

``The messenger is coming back, my Lady,'' (the keeper)
said the keeper,
``with the carriage.'' (the keeper)

As it drove up, we saw that there were two people inside. There alighted from it, with some cloaks and wrappers, first the Frenchwoman whom I had seen in church, and secondly the pretty girl, the Frenchwoman with a defiant confidence, the pretty girl confused and hesitating.

``What now?'' (Lady Dedlock/Dedlock)
said Lady Dedlock.
``Two!'' (unknown)

``I am your maid, my Lady, at the present,'' (the Frenchwoman)
said the Frenchwoman.
``The message was for the attendant.'' (unknown)

``I was afraid you might mean me, my Lady,'' (the girl)
said the pretty girl.

``I did mean you, child,'' (mistress)
replied her (Dedlock) mistress calmly.
``Put that shawl on me.'' (She)

She (Dedlock) slightly stooped her (Dedlock) shoulders to receive it, and the pretty girl lightly dropped it in its place. The Frenchwoman stood unnoticed, looking on with her (Frenchwoman) lips very tightly set.

``I am sorry,'' (Lady Dedlock/Dedlock)
said Lady Dedlock to Mr. Jarndyce,
``that we are not likely to renew our former acquaintance. You will allow me to send the carriage back for your two wards. It shall be here directly.'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)

But as he (Jarndyce) would on no account accept this offer, she (Dedlock) took a graceful leave of Ada--none of me--and put her (Ada) hand upon his (Jarndyce) proffered arm, and got into the carriage, which was a little, low, park carriage with a hood.

``Come in, child,'' (she)
she (Ada) said to the pretty girl;
``I shall want you. Go on!'' (the girl)

The carriage rolled away, and the Frenchwoman, with the wrappers she (Frenchwoman) had brought hanging over her (Frenchwoman) arm, remained standing where she (Frenchwoman) had alighted.

I suppose there is nothing pride can so little bear with as pride itself, and that she (Frenchwoman) was punished for her (Frenchwoman) imperious manner. Her (Frenchwoman) retaliation was the most singular I could have imagined. She (Frenchwoman) remained perfectly still until the carriage had turned into the drive, and then, without the least discomposure of countenance, slipped off her (Frenchwoman) shoes, left them on the ground, and walked deliberately in the same direction through the wettest of the wet grass.

``Is that young woman mad?'' (guardian)
said my guardian.

``Oh, no, sir!'' (the keeper)
said the keeper, who, with his (keeper) wife, was looking after her (wife).
``Hortense is not one of that sort. She (Hortense) has as good a head-piece as the best. But she (Hortense)'s mortal high and passionate--powerful high and passionate; and what with having notice to leave, and having others put above her (Hortense), she (Hortense) don't take kindly to it.'' (unknown)

``But why should she (Hortense) walk shoeless through all that water?'' (guardian)
said my guardian.

``Why, indeed, sir, unless it is to cool her (Hortense) down!'' (the man)
said the man.

``Or unless she (Hortense) fancies it's blood,'' (the woman)
said the woman.
``She (Hortense)'d as soon walk through that as anything else, I think, when her (Hortense) own's up!'' (unknown)

We passed not far from the house a few minutes afterwards. Peaceful as it had looked when we first saw it, it looked even more so now, with a diamond spray glittering all about it, a light wind blowing, the birds no longer hushed but singing strongly, everything refreshed by the late rain, and the little carriage shining at the doorway like a fairy carriage made of silver. Still, very steadfastly and quietly walking towards it, a peaceful figure too in the landscape, went Mademoiselle Hortense, shoeless, through the wet grass.

CHAPTER XIX

Moving On

It is the long vacation in the regions of Chancery Lane. The good ships Law and Equity, those teak-built, copper-bottomed, iron-fastened, brazen-faced, and not by any means fast-sailing clippers are laid up in ordinary. The Flying Dutchman, with a crew of ghostly clients imploring all whom they may encounter to peruse their papers, has drifted, for the time being, heaven knows where. The courts are all shut up; the public offices lie in a hot sleep. Westminster Hall itself is a shady solitude where nightingales might sing, and a tenderer class of suitors than is usually found there, walk.

The Temple, Chancery Lane, Serjeants' Inn, and Lincoln's Inn even unto the Fields are like tidal harbours at low water, where stranded proceedings, offices at anchor, idle clerks lounging on lop-sided stools that will not recover their perpendicular until the current of Term sets in, lie high and dry upon the ooze of the long vacation. Outer doors of chambers are shut up by the score, messages and parcels are to be left at the Porter's Lodge by the bushel. A crop of grass would grow in the chinks of the stone pavement outside Lincoln's Inn Hall, but that the ticket-porters, who have nothing to do beyond sitting in the shade there, with their white aprons over their heads to keep the flies off, grub it up and eat it thoughtfully.

There is only one judge in town. Even he (judge) only comes twice a week to sit in chambers. If the country folks of those assize towns on his (judge) circuit could see him (judge) now! No full-bottomed wig, no red petticoats, no fur, no javelin-men, no white wands. Merely a close-shaved gentleman in white trousers and a white hat, with sea-bronze on the judicial countenance, and a strip of bark peeled by the solar rays from the judicial nose, who calls in at the shell-fish shop as he (gentleman) comes along and drinks iced ginger-beer!

The bar of England is scattered over the face of the earth. How England can get on through four long summer months without its bar--which is its acknowledged refuge in adversity and its only legitimate triumph in prosperity--is beside the question; assuredly that shield and buckler of Britannia are not in present wear. The learned gentleman who is always so tremendously indignant at the unprecedented outrage committed on the feelings of his (gentleman) client by the opposite party that he (gentleman) never seems likely to recover it is doing infinitely better than might be expected in Switzerland. The learned gentleman who does the withering business and who blights all opponents with his (gentleman) gloomy sarcasm is as merry as a grig at a French watering-place. The learned gentleman who weeps by the pint on the smallest provocation has not shed a tear these six weeks. The very learned gentleman who has cooled the natural heat of his (gentleman) gingery complexion in pools and fountains of law until he (gentleman) has become great in knotty arguments for term-time, when he (gentleman) poses the drowsy bench with legal

``chaff,'' (he)
inexplicable to the uninitiated and to most of the initiated too, is roaming, with a characteristic delight in aridity and dust, about Constantinople. Other dispersed fragments of the same great palladium are to be found on the canals of Venice, at the second cataract of the Nile, in the baths of Germany, and sprinkled on the sea-sand all over the English coast. Scarcely one is to be encountered in the deserted region of Chancery Lane. If such a lonely member of the bar do flit across the waste and come upon a prowling suitor who is unable to leave off haunting the scenes of his (member) anxiety, they frighten one another and retreat into opposite shades.

It is the hottest long vacation known for many years. All the young clerks are madly in love, and according to their various degrees, pine for bliss with the beloved object, at Margate, Ramsgate, or Gravesend. All the middle-aged clerks think their families too large. All the unowned dogs who stray into the Inns of Court and pant about staircases and other dry places seeking water give short howls of aggravation. All the blind men's dogs in the streets draw their masters against pumps or trip them over buckets. A shop with a sun-blind, and a watered pavement, and a bowl of gold and silver fish in the window, is a sanctuary. Temple Bar gets so hot that it is, to the adjacent Strand and Fleet Street, what a heater is in an urn, and keeps them simmering all night.

There are offices about the Inns of Court in which a man might be cool, if any coolness were worth purchasing at such a price in dullness; but the little thoroughfares immediately outside those retirements seem to blaze. In Mr. Krook's court, it is so hot that the people turn their houses inside out and sit in chairs upon the pavement--Mr. Krook included, who there pursues his (Krook) studies, with his (Krook) cat -LRB-who never is too hot-RRB- by his (Krook) side. The Sol's Arms has discontinued the Harmonic Meetings for the season, and Little Swills is engaged at the Pastoral Gardens down the river, where he (Krook) comes out in quite an innocent manner and sings comic ditties of a juvenile complexion calculated -LRB-as the bill says-RRB- not to wound the feelings of the most fastidious mind.

Over all the legal neighbourhood there hangs, like some great veil of rust or gigantic cobweb, the idleness and pensiveness of the long vacation. Mr. Snagsby, law-stationer of Cook's Court, Cursitor Street, is sensible of the influence not only in his (Street) mind as a sympathetic and contemplative man, but also in his (Street) business as a law-stationer aforesaid. He (Street) has more leisure for musing in Staple Inn and in the Rolls Yard during the long vacation than at other seasons, and he (Street) says to the two `prentices, what a thing it is in such hot weather to think that you live in an island with the sea a-rolling and a-bowling right round you.

Guster is busy in the little drawing-room on this present afternoon in the long vacation, when Mr. and Mrs. Snagsby have it in contemplation to receive company. The expected guests are rather select than numerous, being Mr. and Mrs. Chadband and no more. From Mr. Chadband's being much given to describe himself, both verbally and in writing, as a vessel, he (Chadband) is occasionally mistaken by strangers for a gentleman connected with navigation, but he (Chadband) is, as he (Chadband) expresses it,

``in the ministry.'' (he)
Mr. Chadband is attached to no particular denomination and is considered by his (Chadband) persecutors to have nothing so very remarkable to say on the greatest of subjects as to render his (Chadband) volunteering, on his (Chadband) own account, at all incumbent on his (Chadband) conscience; but he (Chadband) has his (Chadband) followers, and Mrs. Snagsby is of the number. Mrs. Snagsby has but recently taken a passage upward by the vessel, Chadband; and her (Snagsby) attention was attracted to that Bark A 1, when she (Snagsby) was something flushed by the hot weather.

``My little woman,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby to the sparrows in Staple Inn,
``likes to have her (woman) religion rather sharp, you see!'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

So Guster, much impressed by regarding herself for the time as the handmaid of Chadband, whom she (Snagsby) knows to be endowed with the gift of holding forth for four hours at a stretch, prepares the little drawing-room for tea. All the furniture is shaken and dusted, the portraits of Mr. and Mrs. Snagsby are touched up with a wet cloth, the best tea-service is set forth, and there is excellent provision made of dainty new bread, crusty twists, cool fresh butter, thin slices of ham, tongue, and German sausage, and delicate little rows of anchovies nestling in parsley, not to mention new-laid eggs, to be brought up warm in a napkin, and hot buttered toast. For Chadband is rather a consuming vessel--the persecutors say a gorging vessel--and can wield such weapons of the flesh as a knife and fork remarkably well.

Mr. Snagsby in his (Snagsby) best coat, looking at all the preparations when they are completed and coughing his (Snagsby) cough of deference behind his (Snagsby) hand, says to Mrs. Snagsby,

``At what time did you expect Mr. and Mrs. Chadband, my love?'' (Mrs. Snagsby)

``At six,'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
says Mrs. Snagsby.

Mr. Snagsby observes in a mild and casual way that

``it's gone that.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``Perhaps you'd like to begin without them,'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
is Mrs. Snagsby's reproachful remark.

Mr. Snagsby does look as if he (Snagsby) would like it very much, but he (Snagsby) says, with his (Snagsby) cough of mildness,

``No, my dear, no. I merely named the time.'' (he)

``What's time,'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
says Mrs. Snagsby,
``to eternity?'' (Mrs. Snagsby)

``Very true, my dear,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby.
``Only when a person lays in victuals for tea, a person does it with a view--perhaps--more to time. And when a time is named for having tea, it's better to come up to it.'' (unknown)

``To come up to it!'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
Mrs. Snagsby repeats with severity.
``Up to it! As if Mr. Chadband was a fighter!'' (unknown)

``Not at all, my dear,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby.

Here, Guster, who had been looking out of the bedroom window, comes rustling and scratching down the little staircase like a popular ghost, and falling flushed into the drawing-room, announces that Mr. and Mrs. Chadband have appeared in the court. The bell at the inner door in the passage immediately thereafter tinkling, she (Chadband) is admonished by Mrs. Snagsby, on pain of instant reconsignment to her (Snagsby) patron saint, not to omit the ceremony of announcement. Much discomposed in her (Snagsby) nerves -LRB-which were previously in the best order-RRB- by this threat, she (Snagsby) so fearfully mutilates that point of state as to announce

``Mr. and Mrs. Cheeseming, least which, Imeantersay, whatsername!'' (she)
and retires conscience-stricken from the presence.

Mr. Chadband is a large yellow man with a fat smile and a general appearance of having a good deal of train oil in his (Chadband) system. Mrs. Chadband is a stern, severe-looking, silent woman. Mr. Chadband moves softly and cumbrously, not unlike a bear who has been taught to walk upright. He (Chadband) is very much embarrassed about the arms, as if they were inconvenient to him (Chadband) and he (Chadband) wanted to grovel, is very much in a perspiration about the head, and never speaks without first putting up his (Chadband) great hand, as delivering a token to his (Chadband) hearers that he (Chadband) is going to edify them.

``My friends,'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)
says Mr. Chadband,
``peace be on this house! On the master thereof, on the mistress thereof, on the young maidens, and on the young men! My friends, why do I wish for peace? What is peace? Is it war? No. Is it strife? No. Is it lovely, and gentle, and beautiful, and pleasant, and serene, and joyful? Oh, yes! Therefore, my friends, I wish for peace, upon you and upon yours.'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)

In consequence of Mrs. Snagsby looking deeply edified, Mr. Snagsby thinks it expedient on the whole to say amen, which is well received.

``Now, my friends,'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)
proceeds Mr. Chadband,
``since I am upon this theme--'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)

Guster presents herself. Mrs. Snagsby, in a spectral bass voice and without removing her (Snagsby) eyes from Chadband, says with dreadful distinctness,

``Go away!'' (Mrs. Snagsby)

``Now, my friends,'' (Guster)
says Chadband,
``since I am upon this theme, and in my lowly path improving it--'' (Guster)

Guster is heard unaccountably to murmur

``one thousing seven hundred and eighty-two.'' (Guster)
The spectral voice repeats more solemnly,
``Go away!'' (unknown)

``Now, my friends,'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)
says Mr. Chadband,
``we will inquire in a spirit of love--'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)

Still Guster reiterates

``one thousing seven hundred and eighty-two.'' (Guster)

Mr. Chadband, pausing with the resignation of a man accustomed to be persecuted and languidly folding up his (Chadband) chin into his (Chadband) fat smile, says,

``Let us hear the maiden! Speak, maiden!'' (a man)

``One thousing seven hundred and eighty-two, if you please, sir. Which he (my) wish to know what the shilling ware for,'' (Guster)
says Guster, breathless.

``For?'' (Mrs. Chadband)
returns Mrs. Chadband.
``For his (my) fare!'' (Guster)

Guster replied that

``he (my) insistes on one and eightpence or on summonsizzing the party.'' (Guster)
Mrs. Snagsby and Mrs. Chadband are proceeding to grow shrill in indignation when Mr. Chadband quiets the tumult by lifting up his (Chadband) hand.

``My friends,'' (he)
says he (Chadband),
``I remember a duty unfulfilled yesterday. It is right that I should be chastened in some penalty. I ought not to murmur. Rachael, pay the eightpence!'' (he)

While Mrs. Snagsby, drawing her (Snagsby) breath, looks hard at Mr. Snagsby, as who should say,

``You hear this apostle!'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
and while Mr. Chadband glows with humility and train oil, Mrs. Chadband pays the money. It is Mr. Chadband's habit--it is the head and front of his (Chadband) pretensions indeed--to keep this sort of debtor and creditor account in the smallest items and to post it publicly on the most trivial occasions.

``My friends,'' (unknown)
says Chadband,
``eightpence is not much; it might justly have been one and fourpence; it might justly have been half a crown. O let us be joyful, joyful! O let us be joyful!'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)

With which remark, which appears from its sound to be an extract in verse, Mr. Chadband stalks to the table, and before taking a chair, lifts up his (Chadband) admonitory hand.

``My friends,'' (he)
says he (Chadband),
``what is this which we now behold as being spread before us? Refreshment. Do we need refreshment then, my friends? We do. And why do we need refreshment, my friends? Because we are but mortal, because we are but sinful, because we are but of the earth, because we are not of the air. Can we fly, my friends? We cannot. Why can we not fly, my friends?'' (he)

Mr. Snagsby, presuming on the success of his (Snagsby) last point, ventures to observe in a cheerful and rather knowing tone,

``No wings.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
But is immediately frowned down by Mrs. Snagsby.

``I say, my friends,'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)
pursues Mr. Chadband, utterly rejecting and obliterating Mr. Snagsby's suggestion,
``why can we not fly? Is it because we are calculated to walk? It is. Could we walk, my friends, without strength? We could not. What should we do without strength, my friends? Our legs would refuse to bear us, our knees would double up, our ankles would turn over, and we should come to the ground. Then from whence, my friends, in a human point of view, do we derive the strength that is necessary to our limbs? Is it,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Chadband, glancing over the table,
``from bread in various forms, from butter which is churned from the milk which is yielded unto us by the cow, from the eggs which are laid by the fowl, from ham, from tongue, from sausage, and from such like? It is. Then let us partake of the good things which are set before us!'' (The persecutors)

The persecutors denied that there was any particular gift in Mr. Chadband's piling verbose flights of stairs, one upon another, after this fashion. But this can only be received as a proof of their determination to persecute, since it must be within everybody's experience that the Chadband style of oratory is widely received and much admired.

Mr. Chadband, however, having concluded for the present, sits down at Mr. Snagsby's table and lays about him (Snagsby) prodigiously. The conversion of nutriment of any sort into oil of the quality already mentioned appears to be a process so inseparable from the constitution of this exemplary vessel that in beginning to eat and drink, he (Snagsby) may be described as always becoming a kind of considerable oil mills or other large factory for the production of that article on a wholesale scale. On the present evening of the long vacation, in Cook's Court, Cursitor Street, he (Cook) does such a powerful stroke of business that the warehouse appears to be quite full when the works cease.

At this period of the entertainment, Guster, who has never recovered her (Cook) first failure, but has neglected no possible or impossible means of bringing the establishment and herself into contempt--among which may be briefly enumerated her (Cook) unexpectedly performing clashing military music on Mr. Chadband's head with plates, and afterwards crowning that gentleman with muffins--at which period of the entertainment, Guster whispers Mr. Snagsby that he (Snagsby) is wanted.

``And being wanted in the--not to put too fine a point upon it--in the shop,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby, rising,
``perhaps this good company will excuse me for half a minute.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

Mr. Snagsby descends and finds the two `prentices intently contemplating a police constable, who holds a ragged boy by the arm.

``Why, bless my heart,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby,
``what's the matter!'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``This boy,'' (the constable)
says the constable,
``although he (boy)'s repeatedly told to, won't move on--'' (the constable)

``I'm always a-moving on, sar,'' (the constable)
cries the boy, wiping away his (Snagsby) grimy tears with his (Snagsby) arm.
``I've always been a-moving and a-moving on, ever since I was born. Where can I possibly move to, sir, more nor I do move!'' (unknown)

``He (sar) won't move on,'' (unknown)
says the constable calmly, with a slight professional hitch of his (Snagsby) neck involving its better settlement in his (Snagsby) stiff stock, ``although he (sar) has been repeatedly cautioned, and therefore I am obliged to take him (sar) into custody. He (sar)'s as obstinate a young gonoph as I know. He (sar) WON
``T move on.'' (unknown)

``Oh, my eye! Where can I move to!'' (the boy)
cries the boy, clutching quite desperately at his (Snagsby) hair and beating his (Snagsby) bare feet upon the floor of Mr. Snagsby's passage.

``Don't you come none of that or I shall make blessed short work of you!'' (the constable)
says the constable, giving him (constable) a passionless shake.
``My instructions are that you are to move on. I have told you so five hundred times.'' (unknown)

``But where?'' (the boy)
cries the boy.

``Well! Really, constable, you know,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby wistfully, and coughing behind his (Snagsby) hand his (Snagsby) cough of great perplexity and doubt,
``really, that does seem a question. Where, you know?'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``My instructions don't go to that,'' (the constable)
replies the constable.
``My instructions are that this boy is to move on.'' (Jo)

Do you hear, Jo? It is nothing to you or to any one else that the great lights of the parliamentary sky have failed for some few years in this business to set you the example of moving on. The one grand recipe remains for you--the profound philosophical prescription--the be-all and the end-all of your strange existence upon earth. Move on! You are by no means to move off, Jo, for the great lights can't at all agree about that. Move on!

Mr. Snagsby says nothing to this effect, says nothing at all indeed, but coughs his (Snagsby) forlornest cough, expressive of no thoroughfare in any direction. By this time Mr. and Mrs. Chadband and Mrs. Snagsby, hearing the altercation, have appeared upon the stairs. Guster having never left the end of the passage, the whole household are assembled.

``The simple question is, sir,'' (the constable)
says the constable,
``whether you know this boy. He (boy) says you do.'' (the constable)

Mrs. Snagsby, from her (Snagsby) elevation, instantly cries out,

``No he (boy) don't!'' (Mrs. Snagsby)

``My lit-tle woman!'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby, looking up the staircase.
``My love, permit me! Pray have a moment's patience, my dear. I do know something of this lad, and in what I know of him (lad), I can't say that there's any harm; perhaps on the contrary, constable.'' (unknown)
To whom the law-stationer relates his (Snagsby) Joful and woeful experience, suppressing the half-crown fact.

``Well!'' (the constable)
says the constable,
``so far, it seems, he (constable) had grounds for what he (constable) said. When I took him (constable) into custody up in Holborn, he (constable) said you knew him (constable). Upon that, a young man who was in the crowd said he (man) was acquainted with you, and you were a respectable housekeeper, and if I'd call and make the inquiry, he (man)'d appear. The young man don't seem inclined to keep his (man) word, but--Oh! Here IS the young man!'' (the constable)

Enter Mr. Guppy, who nods to Mr. Snagsby and touches his (Snagsby) hat with the chivalry of clerkship to the ladies on the stairs.

``I was strolling away from the office just now when I found this row going on,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy to the law-stationer,
``and as your name was mentioned, I thought it was right the thing should be looked into.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``It was very good-natured of you, sir,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby,
``and I am obliged to you.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
And Mr. Snagsby again relates his (Snagsby) experience, again suppressing the half-crown fact.

``Now, I know where you live,'' (the constable)
says the constable, then, to Jo.
``You live down in Tom-all-Alone's. That's a nice innocent place to live in, ain't it?'' (unknown)

``I can't go and live in no nicer place, sir,'' (Jo)
replies Jo.
``They wouldn't have nothink to say to me if I wos to go to a nice innocent place fur to live. Who ud go and let a nice innocent lodging to such a reg`lar one as me!'' (unknown)

``You are very poor, ain't you?'' (the constable)
says the constable.

``Yes, I am indeed, sir, wery poor in gin`ral,'' (Jo)
replies Jo.
``I leave you to judge now! I shook these two half-crowns out of him (I),'' (the constable)
says the constable, producing them to the company,
``in only putting my hand upon him (I)!'' (the constable)

``They're wot's left, Mr. Snagsby,'' (Jo)
says Jo,
``out of a sov-ring as wos give me by a lady in a wale as sed she (lady) wos a servant and as come to my crossin one night and asked to be showd this `ere ouse and the ouse wot him (servant) as you giv the writin to died at, and the berrin-ground wot he (servant)'s berrid in. She (lady) ses to me she (lady) ses `are you the boy at the inkwhich?'' (Jo)
she (Jo) ses. I ses `yes' I ses. She (Jo) ses to me she (Jo) ses `can you show me all them places?
'' I ses `yes I can' I ses. And she (Jo) ses to me `do it' and I dun it and she (Jo) giv me a sov`ring and hooked it. And I an't had much of the sov`ring neither,'' (me)
says Jo, with dirty tears,
``fur I had to pay five bob, down in Tom-all-Alone's, afore they'd square it fur to give me change, and then a young man he (man) thieved another five while I was asleep and another boy he (boy) thieved ninepence and the landlord he (boy) stood drains round with a lot more on it.'' (Jo)

``You don't expect anybody to believe this, about the lady and the sovereign, do you?'' (the constable)
says the constable, eyeing him (constable) aside with ineffable disdain.

``I don't know as I do, sir,'' (Jo)
replies Jo.
``I don't expect nothink at all, sir, much, but that's the true hist`ry on it.'' (unknown)

``You see what he (boy) is!'' (the audience)
the constable observes to the audience.
``Well, Mr. Snagsby, if I don't lock him (Snagsby) up this time, will you engage for his (Snagsby) moving on?'' (unknown)

``No!'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
cries Mrs. Snagsby from the stairs.

``My little woman!'' (husband)
pleads her (Jo) husband.
``Constable, I have no doubt he (Constable)'ll move on. You know you really must do it,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby.

``I'm everyways agreeable, sir,'' (Jo)
says the hapless Jo.

``Do it, then,'' (the constable)
observes the constable.
``You know what you have got to do. Do it! And recollect you won't get off so easy next time. Catch hold of your money. Now, the sooner you're five mile off, the better for all parties.'' (auditors)

With this farewell hint and pointing generally to the setting sun as a likely place to move on to, the constable bids his (Snagsby) auditors good afternoon and makes the echoes of Cook's Court perform slow music for him (Snagsby) as he (Snagsby) walks away on the shady side, carrying his (Snagsby) iron-bound hat in his (Snagsby) hand for a little ventilation.

Now, Jo's improbable story concerning the lady and the sovereign has awakened more or less the curiosity of all the company. Mr. Guppy, who has an inquiring mind in matters of evidence and who has been suffering severely from the lassitude of the long vacation, takes that interest in the case that he (Guppy) enters on a regular cross-examination of the witness, which is found so interesting by the ladies that Mrs. Snagsby politely invites him (Guppy) to step upstairs and drink a cup of tea, if he (Guppy) will excuse the disarranged state of the tea-table, consequent on their previous exertions. Mr. Guppy yielding his (Guppy) assent to this proposal, Jo is requested to follow into the drawing-room doorway, where Mr. Guppy takes him (Guppy) in hand as a witness, patting him (Guppy) into this shape, that shape, and the other shape like a butterman dealing with so much butter, and worrying him (Guppy) according to the best models. Nor is the examination unlike many such model displays, both in respect of its eliciting nothing and of its being lengthy, for Mr. Guppy is sensible of his (Guppy) talent, and Mrs. Snagsby feels not only that it gratifies her (Snagsby) inquisitive disposition, but that it lifts her (Snagsby) husband's establishment higher up in the law. During the progress of this keen encounter, the vessel Chadband, being merely engaged in the oil trade, gets aground and waits to be floated off.

``Well!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy.
``Either this boy sticks to it like cobbler's-wax or there is something out of the common here that beats anything that ever came into my way at Kenge and Carboy's.'' (Mrs. Chadband)

Mrs. Chadband whispers Mrs. Snagsby, who exclaims,

``You don't say so!'' (Mrs. Snagsby)

``For years!'' (Mrs. Chadband)
replied Mrs. Chadband.

``Has known Kenge and Carboy's office for years,'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
Mrs. Snagsby triumphantly explains to Mr. Guppy.
``Mrs. Chadband--this gentleman's wife--Reverend Mr. Chadband.'' (unknown)

``Oh, indeed!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy.

``Before I married my present husband,'' (Mrs. Chadband)
says Mrs. Chadband.

``Was you a party in anything, ma'am?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy, transferring his (Guppy) cross-examination.

``No.'' (unknown)

``NOT a party in anything, ma'am?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy.

Mrs. Chadband shakes her (Chadband) head.

``Perhaps you were acquainted with somebody who was a party in something, ma'am?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy, who likes nothing better than to model his (Guppy) conversation on forensic principles.

``Not exactly that, either,'' (Mrs. Chadband)
replies Mrs. Chadband, humouring the joke with a hard-favoured smile.

``Not exactly that, either!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
repeats Mr. Guppy.
``Very good. Pray, ma'am, was it a lady of your acquaintance who had some transactions -LRB-we will not at present say what transactions-RRB- with Kenge and Carboy's office, or was it a gentleman of your acquaintance? Take time, ma'am. We shall come to it presently. Man or woman, ma'am?'' (unknown)

``Neither,'' (Mrs. Chadband)
says Mrs. Chadband as before.

``Oh! A child!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy, throwing on the admiring Mrs. Snagsby the regular acute professional eye which is thrown on British jurymen.
``Now, ma'am, perhaps you'll have the kindness to tell us WHAT child.'' (unknown)

``You have got it at last, sir,'' (Mrs. Chadband)
says Mrs. Chadband with another hard-favoured smile.
``Well, sir, it was before your time, most likely, judging from your appearance. I was left in charge of a child named Esther Summerson, who was put out in life by Messrs. Kenge and Carboy.'' (unknown)

``Miss Summerson, ma'am!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
cries Mr. Guppy, excited.

``I call her (Summerson) Esther Summerson,'' (Mrs. Chadband)
says Mrs. Chadband with austerity. ``There was no Miss-ing of the girl in my time. It was Esther. ``Esther, do this! Esther, do that!
'' and she (Chadband) was made to do it.'' (Esther/Miss Summerson/Esther Summerson)

``My dear ma'am,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
returns Mr. Guppy, moving across the small apartment,
``the humble individual who now addresses you received that young lady in London when she (lady) first came here from the establishment to which you have alluded. Allow me to have the pleasure of taking you by the hand.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Mr. Chadband, at last seeing his (Chadband) opportunity, makes his (Chadband) accustomed signal and rises with a smoking head, which he (Chadband) dabs with his (Chadband) pocket-handkerchief. Mrs. Snagsby whispers

``Hush!'' (Mrs. Snagsby)

``My friends,'' (he)
says Chadband,
``we have partaken in moderation'' (he)
-LRB-which was certainly not the case so far as he (Chadband) was concerned-RRB-
``of the comforts which have been provided for us. May this house live upon the fatness of the land; may corn and wine be plentiful therein; may it grow, may it thrive, may it prosper, may it advance, may it proceed, may it press forward! But, my friends, have we partaken of anything else? We have. My friends, of what else have we partaken? Of spiritual profit? Yes. From whence have we derived that spiritual profit? My young friend, stand forth!'' (he)

Jo, thus apostrophized, gives a slouch backward, and another slouch forward, and another slouch to each side, and confronts the eloquent Chadband with evident doubts of his (Chadband) intentions.

``My young friend,'' (unknown)
says Chadband,
``you are to us a pearl, you are to us a diamond, you are to us a gem, you are to us a jewel. And why, my young friend?'' (unknown)

``I don't know,'' (Jo)
replies Jo.
``I don't know nothink.'' (unknown)

``My young friend,'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)
says Chadband,
``it is because you know nothing that you are to us a gem and jewel. For what are you, my young friend? Are you a beast of the field? No. A bird of the air? No. A fish of the sea or river? No. You are a human boy, my young friend. A human boy. O glorious to be a human boy! And why glorious, my young friend? Because you are capable of receiving the lessons of wisdom, because you are capable of profiting by this discourse which I now deliver for your good, because you are not a stick, or a staff, or a stock, or a stone, or a post, or a pillar.

O running stream of sparkling joy To be a soaring human boy!

And do you cool yourself in that stream now, my young friend? No. Why do you not cool yourself in that stream now? Because you are in a state of darkness, because you are in a state of obscurity, because you are in a state of sinfulness, because you are in a state of bondage. My young friend, what is bondage? Let us, in a spirit of love, inquire.'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)

At this threatening stage of the discourse, Jo, who seems to have been gradually going out of his (Chadband) mind, smears his (Chadband) right arm over his (Chadband) face and gives a terrible yawn. Mrs. Snagsby indignantly expresses her (Snagsby) belief that he (Chadband) is a limb of the arch-fiend.

``My friends,'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)
says Mr. Chadband with his (Chadband) persecuted chin folding itself into its fat smile again as he (Chadband) looks round,
``it is right that I should be humbled, it is right that I should be tried, it is right that I should be mortified, it is right that I should be corrected. I stumbled, on Sabbath last, when I thought with pride of my three hours' improving. The account is now favourably balanced: my creditor has accepted a composition. O let us be joyful, joyful! O let us be joyful!'' (he)

Great sensation on the part of Mrs. Snagsby.

``My friends,'' (him)
says Chadband, looking round him (Chadband) in conclusion,
``I will not proceed with my young friend now. Will you come to-morrow, my young friend, and inquire of this good lady where I am to be found to deliver a discourse unto you, and will you come like the thirsty swallow upon the next day, and upon the day after that, and upon the day after that, and upon many pleasant days, to hear discourses?'' (him)
-LRB-This with a cow-like lightness.-RRB-

Jo, whose immediate object seems to be to get away on any terms, gives a shuffling nod. Mr. Guppy then throws him (Guppy) a penny, and Mrs. Snagsby calls to Guster to see him (Guppy) safely out of the house. But before he (Guppy) goes downstairs, Mr. Snagsby loads him (Snagsby) with some broken meats from the table, which he (Snagsby) carries away, hugging in his (Snagsby) arms.

So, Mr. Chadband--of whom the persecutors say that it is no wonder he (Chadband) should go on for any length of time uttering such abominable nonsense, but that the wonder rather is that he (Chadband) should ever leave off, having once the audacity to begin--retires into private life until he (Chadband) invests a little capital of supper in the oil-trade. Jo moves on, through the long vacation, down to Blackfriars Bridge, where he (Chadband) finds a baking stony corner wherein to settle to his (Chadband) repast.

And there he (Chadband) sits, munching and gnawing, and looking up at the great cross on the summit of St. Paul's Cathedral, glittering above a red-and-violet-tinted cloud of smoke. From the boy's face one might suppose that sacred emblem to be, in his (boy) eyes, the crowning confusion of the great, confused city--so golden, so high up, so far out of his (boy) reach. There he (boy) sits, the sun going down, the river running fast, the crowd flowing by him (boy) in two streams--everything moving on to some purpose and to one end--until he (boy) is stirred up and told to

``move on'' (he)
too.

CHAPTER XX

A New Lodger

The long vacation saunters on towards term-time like an idle river very leisurely strolling down a flat country to the sea. Mr. Guppy saunters along with it congenially. He (Guppy) has blunted the blade of his (Guppy) penknife and broken the point off by sticking that instrument into his (Guppy) desk in every direction. Not that he (Guppy) bears the desk any ill will, but he (Guppy) must do something, and it must be something of an unexciting nature, which will lay neither his (Guppy) physical nor his (Guppy) intellectual energies under too heavy contribution. He (Guppy) finds that nothing agrees with him (Guppy) so well as to make little gyrations on one leg of his (Guppy) stool, and stab his (Guppy) desk, and gape.

Kenge and Carboy are out of town, and the articled clerk has taken out a shooting license and gone down to his (Guppy) father's, and Mr. Guppy's two fellow-stipendiaries are away on leave. Mr. Guppy and Mr. Richard Carstone divide the dignity of the office. But Mr. Carstone is for the time being established in Kenge's room, whereat Mr. Guppy chafes. So exceedingly that he (Guppy) with biting sarcasm informs his (Guppy) mother, in the confidential moments when he (Guppy) sups with her (mother) off a lobster and lettuce in the Old Street Road, that he (Guppy) is afraid the office is hardly good enough for swells, and that if he (Guppy) had known there was a swell coming, he (Guppy) would have got it painted.

Mr. Guppy suspects everybody who enters on the occupation of a stool in Kenge and Carboy's office of entertaining, as a matter of course, sinister designs upon him (Guppy). He (Guppy) is clear that every such person wants to depose him (Guppy). If he (Guppy) be ever asked how, why, when, or wherefore, he (Guppy) shuts up one eye and shakes his (Guppy) head. On the strength of these profound views, he (Guppy) in the most ingenious manner takes infinite pains to counterplot when there is no plot, and plays the deepest games of chess without any adversary.

It is a source of much gratification to Mr. Guppy, therefore, to find the new-comer constantly poring over the papers in Jarndyce and Jarndyce, for he (Jarndyce) well knows that nothing but confusion and failure can come of that. His (Jarndyce) satisfaction communicates itself to a third saunterer through the long vacation in Kenge and Carboy's office, to wit, Young Smallweed.

Whether Young Smallweed -LRB-metaphorically called Small and eke Chick Weed, as it were jocularly to express a fledgling-RRB- was ever a boy is much doubted in Lincoln's Inn. He (Lincoln) is now something under fifteen and an old limb of the law. He (Lincoln) is facetiously understood to entertain a passion for a lady at a cigar-shop in the neighbourhood of Chancery Lane and for her (lady) sake to have broken off a contract with another lady, to whom he (Lincoln) had been engaged some years. He (Lincoln) is a town-made article, of small stature and weazen features, but may be perceived from a considerable distance by means of his (Lincoln) very tall hat. To become a Guppy is the object of his (Lincoln) ambition. He (Lincoln) dresses at that gentleman -LRB-by whom he (Lincoln) is patronized-RRB-, talks at him (Lincoln), walks at him (Lincoln), founds himself entirely on him (Lincoln). He (Lincoln) is honoured with Mr. Guppy's particular confidence and occasionally advises him (Guppy), from the deep wells of his (Guppy) experience, on difficult points in private life.

Mr. Guppy has been lolling out of window all the morning after trying all the stools in succession and finding none of them easy, and after several times putting his (Guppy) head into the iron safe with a notion of cooling it. Mr. Smallweed has been twice dispatched for effervescent drinks, and has twice mixed them in the two official tumblers and stirred them up with the ruler. Mr. Guppy propounds for Mr. Smallweed's consideration the paradox that the more you drink the thirstier you are and reclines his (Guppy) head upon the window-sill in a state of hopeless languor.

While thus looking out into the shade of Old Square, Lincoln's Inn, surveying the intolerable bricks and mortar, Mr. Guppy becomes conscious of a manly whisker emerging from the cloistered walk below and turning itself up in the direction of his (Guppy) face. At the same time, a low whistle is wafted through the Inn and a suppressed voice cries,

``Hip! Gup-py!'' (unknown)

``Why, you don't mean it!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy, aroused.
``Small! Here's Jobling!'' (Small)
Small's head looks out of window too and nods to Jobling.

``Where have you sprung up from?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
inquires Mr. Guppy.

``From the market-gardens down by Deptford. I can't stand it any longer. I must enlist. I say! I wish you'd lend me half a crown. Upon my soul, I'm hungry.'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)

Jobling looks hungry and also has the appearance of having run to seed in the market-gardens down by Deptford.

``I say! Just throw out half a crown if you have got one to spare. I want to get some dinner.'' (unknown)

``Will you come and dine with me?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy, throwing out the coin, which Mr. Jobling catches neatly.

``How long should I have to hold out?'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
says Jobling.

``Not half an hour. I am only waiting here till the enemy goes, returns Mr. Guppy, butting inward with his (Guppy) head.

``What enemy?'' (unknown)

``A new one. Going to be articled. Will you wait?'' (unknown)

``Can you give a fellow anything to read in the meantime?'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
says Mr. Jobling.

Smallweed suggests the law list. But Mr. Jobling declares with much earnestness that he (Jobling)

``can't stand it.'' (he)

``You shall have the paper,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy.
``He (Guppy) shall bring it down. But you had better not be seen about here. Sit on our staircase and read. It's a quiet place.'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)

Jobling nods intelligence and acquiescence. The sagacious Smallweed supplies him (Guppy) with the newspaper and occasionally drops his (Guppy) eye upon him (Guppy) from the landing as a precaution against his (Guppy) becoming disgusted with waiting and making an untimely departure. At last the enemy retreats, and then Smallweed fetches Mr. Jobling up.

``Well, and how are you?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy, shaking hands with him (Guppy).

``So, so. How are you?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Mr. Guppy replying that he (Guppy) is not much to boast of, Mr. Jobling ventures on the question,

``How is SHE?'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
This Mr. Guppy resents as a liberty, retorting,
``Jobling, there ARE chords in the human mind--'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
Jobling begs pardon.

``Any subject but that!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy with a gloomy enjoyment of his (Guppy) injury.
``For there ARE chords, Jobling--'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)

Mr. Jobling begs pardon again.

During this short colloquy, the active Smallweed, who is of the dinner party, has written in legal characters on a slip of paper,

``Return immediately.'' (characters)
This notification to all whom it may concern, he (Jobling) inserts in the letter-box, and then putting on the tall hat at the angle of inclination at which Mr. Guppy wears his (Guppy), informs his (Guppy) patron that they may now make themselves scarce.

Accordingly they betake themselves to a neighbouring dining-house, of the class known among its frequenters by the denomination slap-bang, where the waitress, a bouncing young female of forty, is supposed to have made some impression on the susceptible Smallweed, of whom it may be remarked that he (Guppy) is a weird changeling to whom years are nothing. He (Guppy) stands precociously possessed of centuries of owlish wisdom. If he (Guppy) ever lay in a cradle, it seems as if he (Guppy) must have lain there in a tail-coat. He (Guppy) has an old, old eye, has Smallweed; and he (Guppy) drinks and smokes in a monkeyish way; and his (Guppy) neck is stiff in his (Guppy) collar; and he (Guppy) is never to be taken in; and he (Guppy) knows all about it, whatever it is. In short, in his (Guppy) bringing up he (Guppy) has been so nursed by Law and Equity that he (Guppy) has become a kind of fossil imp, to account for whose terrestrial existence it is reported at the public offices that his (Guppy) father was John Doe and his (Guppy) mother the only female member of the Roe family, also that his (Guppy) first long-clothes were made from a blue bag.

Into the dining-house, unaffected by the seductive show in the window of artificially whitened cauliflowers and poultry, verdant baskets of peas, coolly blooming cucumbers, and joints ready for the spit, Mr. Smallweed leads the way. They know him (Smallweed) there and defer to him (Smallweed). He (Smallweed) has his (Smallweed) favourite box, he (Smallweed) bespeaks all the papers, he (Smallweed) is down upon bald patriarchs, who keep them more than ten minutes afterwards. It is of no use trying him (Smallweed) with anything less than a full-sized

``bread'' (him)
or proposing to him (Smallweed) any joint in cut unless it is in the very best cut. In the matter of gravy he (Smallweed) is adamant.

Conscious of his (Smallweed) elfin power and submitting to his (Smallweed) dread experience, Mr. Guppy consults him (Guppy) in the choice of that day's banquet, turning an appealing look towards him (Guppy) as the waitress repeats the catalogue of viands and saying

``What do YOU take, Chick?'' (the waitress)
Chick, out of the profundity of his (Guppy) artfulness, preferring
``veal and ham and French beans--and don't you forget the stuffing, Polly'' (Chick)
-LRB-with an unearthly cock of his (Guppy) venerable eye-RRB-, Mr. Guppy and Mr. Jobling give the like order. Three pint pots of half-and-half are superadded. Quickly the waitress returns bearing what is apparently a model of the Tower of Babel but what is really a pile of plates and flat tin dish-covers. Mr. Smallweed, approving of what is set before him (Smallweed), conveys intelligent benignity into his (Smallweed) ancient eye and winks upon her (waitress). Then, amid a constant coming in, and going out, and running about, and a clatter of crockery, and a rumbling up and down of the machine which brings the nice cuts from the kitchen, and a shrill crying for more nice cuts down the speaking-pipe, and a shrill reckoning of the cost of nice cuts that have been disposed of, and a general flush and steam of hot joints, cut and uncut, and a considerably heated atmosphere in which the soiled knives and tablecloths seem to break out spontaneously into eruptions of grease and blotches of beer, the legal triumvirate appease their appetites.

Mr. Jobling is buttoned up closer than mere adornment might require. His (Jobling) hat presents at the rims a peculiar appearance of a glistening nature, as if it had been a favourite snail-promenade. The same phenomenon is visible on some parts of his (Jobling) coat, and particularly at the seams. He (Jobling) has the faded appearance of a gentleman in embarrassed circumstances; even his (Jobling) light whiskers droop with something of a shabby air.

His (Jobling) appetite is so vigorous that it suggests spare living for some little time back. He (Jobling) makes such a speedy end of his (Jobling) plate of veal and ham, bringing it to a close while his (Jobling) companions are yet midway in theirs, that Mr. Guppy proposes another.

``Thank you, Guppy,'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
says Mr. Jobling,
``I really don't know but what I WILL take another.'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)

Another being brought, he (Jobling) falls to with great goodwill.

Mr. Guppy takes silent notice of him (Guppy) at intervals until he (Guppy) is half way through this second plate and stops to take an enjoying pull at his (Guppy) pint pot of half-and-half -LRB-also renewed-RRB- and stretches out his (Guppy) legs and rubs his (Guppy) hands. Beholding him (Guppy) in which glow of contentment, Mr. Guppy says,

``You are a man again, Tony!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``Well, not quite yet,'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
says Mr. Jobling.
``Say, just born.'' (unknown)

``Will you take any other vegetables? Grass? Peas? Summer cabbage?'' (unknown)

``Thank you, Guppy,'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
says Mr. Jobling.
``I really don't know but what I WILL take summer cabbage.'' (unknown)

Order given; with the sarcastic addition -LRB-from Mr. Smallweed-RRB- of

``Without slugs, Polly!'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
And cabbage produced.

``I am growing up, Guppy,'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
says Mr. Jobling, plying his (Jobling) knife and fork with a relishing steadiness.

``Glad to hear it.'' (unknown)

``In fact, I have just turned into my teens,'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
says Mr. Jobling.

He (Jobling) says no more until he (Jobling) has performed his (Jobling) task, which he (Jobling) achieves as Messrs. Guppy and Smallweed finish theirs, thus getting over the ground in excellent style and beating those two gentlemen easily by a veal and ham and a cabbage.

``Now, Small,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy,
``what would you recommend about pastry?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``Marrow puddings,'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
says Mr. Smallweed instantly.

``Aye, aye!'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
cries Mr. Jobling with an arch look.
``You're there, are you? Thank you, Mr. Guppy, I don't know but what I WILL take a marrow pudding.'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)

Three marrow puddings being produced, Mr. Jobling adds in a pleasant humour that he (Jobling) is coming of age fast. To these succeed, by command of Mr. Smallweed,

``three Cheshires,'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
and to those
``three small rums.'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
This apex of the entertainment happily reached, Mr. Jobling puts up his (Jobling) legs on the carpeted seat -LRB-having his (Jobling) own side of the box to himself-RRB-, leans against the wall, and says,
``I am grown up now, Guppy. I have arrived at maturity.'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)

``What do you think, now,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy,
``about--you don't mind Smallweed?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``Not the least in the world. I have the pleasure of drinking his (Guppy) good health.'' (unknown)

``Sir, to you!'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
says Mr. Smallweed.

``I was saying, what do you think NOW,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
pursues Mr. Guppy,
``of enlisting?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``Why, what I may think after dinner,'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
returns Mr. Jobling,
``is one thing, my dear Guppy, and what I may think before dinner is another thing. Still, even after dinner, I ask myself the question, What am I to do? How am I to live? Ill fo manger, you know,'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
says Mr. Jobling, pronouncing that word as if he (Jobling) meant a necessary fixture in an English stable.
``Ill fo manger. That's the French saying, and mangering is as necessary to me as it is to a Frenchman. Or more so.'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)

Mr. Smallweed is decidedly of opinion

``much more so.'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)

``If any man had told me,'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
pursues Jobling,
``even so lately as when you and I had the frisk down in Lincolnshire, Guppy, and drove over to see that house at Castle Wold--'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)

Mr. Smallweed corrects him (Smallweed)--Chesney Wold.

``Chesney Wold. -LRB-I thank my honourable friend for that cheer.-RRB- If any man had told me then that I should be as hard up at the present time as I literally find myself, I should have--well, I should have pitched into him (man),'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
says Mr. Jobling, taking a little rum-and-water with an air of desperate resignation;
``I should have let fly at his (man) head.'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)

``Still, Tony, you were on the wrong side of the post then,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
remonstrates Mr. Guppy.
``You were talking about nothing else in the gig.'' (unknown)

``Guppy,'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
says Mr. Jobling,
``I will not deny it. I was on the wrong side of the post. But I trusted to things coming round.'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)

That very popular trust in flat things coming round! Not in their being beaten round, or worked round, but in their

``coming'' (unknown)
round! As though a lunatic should trust in the world's
``coming'' (unknown)
triangular!

``I had confident expectations that things would come round and be all square,'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
says Mr. Jobling with some vagueness of expression and perhaps of meaning too.
``But I was disappointed. They never did. And when it came to creditors making rows at the office and to people that the office dealt with making complaints about dirty trifles of borrowed money, why there was an end of that connexion. And of any new professional connexion too, for if I was to give a reference to-morrow, it would be mentioned and would sew me up. Then what's a fellow to do? I have been keeping out of the way and living cheap down about the market-gardens, but what's the use of living cheap when you have got no money? You might as well live dear.'' (unknown)

``Better,'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
Mr. Smallweed thinks.

``Certainly. It's the fashionable way; and fashion and whiskers have been my weaknesses, and I don't care who knows it,'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
says Mr. Jobling.
``They are great weaknesses--Damme, sir, they are great. Well,'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
proceeds Mr. Jobling after a defiant visit to his (Jobling) rum-and-water,
``what can a fellow do, I ask you, BUT enlist?'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)

Mr. Guppy comes more fully into the conversation to state what, in his (Guppy) opinion, a fellow can do. His (Guppy) manner is the gravely impressive manner of a man who has not committed himself in life otherwise than as he (Guppy) has become the victim of a tender sorrow of the heart.

``Jobling,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy,
``myself and our mutual friend Smallweed--'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Mr. Smallweed modestly observes,

``Gentlemen both!'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
and drinks.

''--Have had a little conversation on this matter more than once since you--'' (unknown)

``Say, got the sack!'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
cries Mr. Jobling bitterly.
``Say it, Guppy. You mean it.'' (unknown)

``No-o-o! Left the Inn,'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
Mr. Smallweed delicately suggests.

``Since you left the Inn, Jobling,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy;
``and I have mentioned to our mutual friend Smallweed a plan I have lately thought of proposing. You know Snagsby the stationer?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``I know there is such a stationer,'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
returns Mr. Jobling.
``He (Smallweed) was not ours, and I am not acquainted with him (Smallweed).'' (unknown)

``He (Smallweed) IS ours, Jobling, and I AM acquainted with him (Jobling),'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
Mr. Guppy retorts.
``Well, sir! I have lately become better acquainted with him (Jobling) through some accidental circumstances that have made me a visitor of his (visitor) in private life. Those circumstances it is not necessary to offer in argument. They may--or they may not--have some reference to a subject which may--or may not--have cast its shadow on my existence.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

As it is Mr. Guppy's perplexing way with boastful misery to tempt his (Guppy) particular friends into this subject, and the moment they touch it, to turn on them with that trenchant severity about the chords in the human mind, both Mr. Jobling and Mr. Smallweed decline the pitfall by remaining silent.

``Such things may be,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
repeats Mr. Guppy,
``or they may not be. They are no part of the case. It is enough to mention that both Mr. and Mrs. Snagsby are very willing to oblige me and that Snagsby has, in busy times, a good deal of copying work to give out. He (Mr.) has all Tulkinghorn's, and an excellent business besides. I believe if our mutual friend Smallweed were put into the box, he (Smallweed) could prove this?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Mr. Smallweed nods and appears greedy to be sworn.

``Now, gentlemen of the jury,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy,
''--I mean, now, Jobling--you may say this is a poor prospect of a living. Granted. But it's better than nothing, and better than enlistment. You want time. There must be time for these late affairs to blow over. You might live through it on much worse terms than by writing for Snagsby.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Mr. Jobling is about to interrupt when the sagacious Smallweed checks him (Jobling) with a dry cough and the words,

``Hem! Shakspeare!'' (him)

``There are two branches to this subject, Jobling,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy.
``That is the first. I come to the second. You know Krook, the Chancellor, across the lane. Come, Jobling,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy in his (Guppy) encouraging cross-examination-tone,
``I think you know Krook, the Chancellor, across the lane?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``I know him (Jobling) by sight,'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
says Mr. Jobling.

``You know him (Jobling) by sight. Very well. And you know little Flite?'' (unknown)

``Everybody knows her (Jobling),'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
says Mr. Jobling.

``Everybody knows her (Jobling). VERY well. Now it has been one of my duties of late to pay Flite a certain weekly allowance, deducting from it the amount of her (Jobling) weekly rent, which I have paid -LRB-in consequence of instructions I have received-RRB- to Krook himself, regularly in her (Jobling) presence. This has brought me into communication with Krook and into a knowledge of his (Krook) house and his (Krook) habits. I know he (Krook) has a room to let. You may live there at a very low charge under any name you like, as quietly as if you were a hundred miles off. He (Krook)'ll ask no questions and would accept you as a tenant at a word from me--before the clock strikes, if you chose. And I tell you another thing, Jobling,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy, who has suddenly lowered his (Jobling) voice and become familiar again,
``he (Jobling)'s an extraordinary old chap--always rummaging among a litter of papers and grubbing away at teaching himself to read and write, without getting on a bit, as it seems to me. He (Jobling) is a most extraordinary old chap, sir. I don't know but what it might be worth a fellow's while to look him (fellow) up a bit.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``You don't mean--'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
Mr. Jobling begins.

``I mean,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
returns Mr. Guppy, shrugging his (Guppy) shoulders with becoming modesty,
``that I can't make him (fellow) out. I appeal to our mutual friend Smallweed whether he (Smallweed) has or has not heard me remark that I can't make him (Smallweed) out.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Mr. Smallweed bears the concise testimony,

``A few!'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)

``I have seen something of the profession and something of life, Tony,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy,
``and it's seldom I can't make a man out, more or less. But such an old card as this, so deep, so sly, and secret -LRB-though I don't believe he (man) is ever sober-RRB-, I never came across. Now, he (man) must be precious old, you know, and he (man) has not a soul about him (man), and he (man) is reported to be immensely rich; and whether he (man) is a smuggler, or a receiver, or an unlicensed pawnbroker, or a money-lender--all of which I have thought likely at different times--it might pay you to knock up a sort of knowledge of him (man). I don't see why you shouldn't go in for it, when everything else suits.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Mr. Jobling, Mr. Guppy, and Mr. Smallweed all lean their elbows on the table and their chins upon their hands, and look at the ceiling. After a time, they all drink, slowly lean back, put their hands in their pockets, and look at one another.

``If I had the energy I once possessed, Tony!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy with a sigh.
``But there are chords in the human mind--'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Expressing the remainder of the desolate sentiment in rum-and-water, Mr. Guppy concludes by resigning the adventure to Tony Jobling and informing him (Guppy) that during the vacation and while things are slack, his (Guppy) purse,

``as far as three or four or even five pound goes,'' (him)
will be at his (Guppy) disposal.
``For never shall it be said,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
Mr. Guppy adds with emphasis,
``that William Guppy turned his (Guppy) back upon his (Guppy) friend!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

The latter part of the proposal is so directly to the purpose that Mr. Jobling says with emotion,

``Guppy, my trump, your fist!'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
Mr. Guppy presents it, saying,
``Jobling, my boy, there it is!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
Mr. Jobling returns,
``Guppy, we have been pals now for some years!'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
Mr. Guppy replies,
``Jobling, we have.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

They then shake hands, and Mr. Jobling adds in a feeling manner,

``Thank you, Guppy, I don't know but what I WILL take another glass for old acquaintance sake.'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)

``Krook's last lodger died there,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
observes Mr. Guppy in an incidental way.

``Did he (Krook) though!'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
says Mr. Jobling.

``There was a verdict. Accidental death. You don't mind that?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
says Mr. Jobling,
``I don't mind it; but he (Krook) might as well have died somewhere else. It's devilish odd that he (Krook) need go and die at MY place!'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
Mr. Jobling quite resents this liberty, several times returning to it with such remarks as,
``There are places enough to die in, I should think!'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
or,
``He (Krook) wouldn't have liked my dying at HIS (Krook) place, I dare say!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

However, the compact being virtually made, Mr. Guppy proposes to dispatch the trusty Smallweed to ascertain if Mr. Krook is at home, as in that case they may complete the negotiation without delay. Mr. Jobling approving, Smallweed puts himself under the tall hat and conveys it out of the dining-rooms in the Guppy manner. He (Jobling) soon returns with the intelligence that Mr. Krook is at home and that he (Krook) has seen him (Krook) through the shop-door, sitting in the back premises, sleeping

``like one o'clock.'' (him)

``Then I'll pay,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy,
``and we'll go and see him (Krook). Small, what will it be?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Mr. Smallweed, compelling the attendance of the waitress with one hitch of his (Guppy) eyelash, instantly replies as follows:

``Four veals and hams is three, and four potatoes is three and four, and one summer cabbage is three and six, and three marrows is four and six, and six breads is five, and three Cheshires is five and three, and four half-pints of half-and-half is six and three, and four small rums is eight and three, and three Pollys is eight and six. Eight and six in half a sovereign, Polly, and eighteenpence out!'' (the waitress)

Not at all excited by these stupendous calculations, Smallweed dismisses his (Smallweed) friends with a cool nod and remains behind to take a little admiring notice of Polly, as opportunity may serve, and to read the daily papers, which are so very large in proportion to himself, shorn of his (Smallweed) hat, that when he (Smallweed) holds up the Times to run his (Smallweed) eye over the columns, he (Smallweed) seems to have retired for the night and to have disappeared under the bedclothes.

Mr. Guppy and Mr. Jobling repair to the rag and bottle shop, where they find Krook still sleeping like one o'clock, that is to say, breathing stertorously with his (Krook) chin upon his (Krook) breast and quite insensible to any external sounds or even to gentle shaking. On the table beside him (Krook), among the usual lumber, stand an empty gin-bottle and a glass. The unwholesome air is so stained with this liquor that even the green eyes of the cat upon her (Smallweed) shelf, as they open and shut and glimmer on the visitors, look drunk.

``Hold up here!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy, giving the relaxed figure of the old man another shake.
``Mr. Krook! Halloa, sir!'' (unknown)

But it would seem as easy to wake a bundle of old clothes with a spirituous heat smouldering in it.

``Did you ever see such a stupor as he (Krook) falls into, between drink and sleep?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy.

``If this is his (Krook) regular sleep,'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
returns Jobling, rather alarmed,
``it'll last a long time one of these days, I am thinking.'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)

``It's always more like a fit than a nap,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy, shaking him (Guppy) again.
``Halloa, your lordship! Why, he (lordship) might be robbed fifty times over! Open your eyes!'' (he)

After much ado, he (Guppy) opens them, but without appearing to see his (Guppy) visitors or any other objects. Though he (Guppy) crosses one leg on another, and folds his (Guppy) hands, and several times closes and opens his (Guppy) parched lips, he (Guppy) seems to all intents and purposes as insensible as before.

``He (lordship) is alive, at any rate,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy.
``How are you, my Lord Chancellor. I have brought a friend of mine, sir, on a little matter of business.'' (The man)

The old man still sits, often smacking his (Guppy) dry lips without the least consciousness. After some minutes he (Guppy) makes an attempt to rise. They help him (Guppy) up, and he (Guppy) staggers against the wall and stares at them.

``How do you do, Mr. Krook?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy in some discomfiture.
``How do you do, sir? You are looking charming, Mr. Krook. I hope you are pretty well?'' (The man)

The old man, in aiming a purposeless blow at Mr. Guppy, or at nothing, feebly swings himself round and comes with his (Guppy) face against the wall. So he (Guppy) remains for a minute or two, heaped up against it, and then staggers down the shop to the front door. The air, the movement in the court, the lapse of time, or the combination of these things recovers him (Guppy). He (Guppy) comes back pretty steadily, adjusting his (Guppy) fur cap on his (Guppy) head and looking keenly at them.

``Your servant, gentlemen; I've been dozing. Hi! I am hard to wake, odd times.'' (unknown)

``Rather so, indeed, sir,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
responds Mr. Guppy.

``What? You've been a-trying to do it, have you?'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
says the suspicious Krook.

``Only a little,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
Mr. Guppy explains.

The old man's eye resting on the empty bottle, he (Guppy) takes it up, examines it, and slowly tilts it upside down.

``I say!'' (he)
he (Guppy) cries like the hobgoblin in the story.
``Somebody's been making free here!'' (unknown)

``I assure you we found it so,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy.
``Would you allow me to get it filled for you?'' (unknown)

``Yes, certainly I would!'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
cries Krook in high glee.
``Certainly I would! Don't mention it! Get it filled next door--Sol's Arms--the Lord Chancellor's fourteenpenny. Bless you, they know ME!'' (He)

He (Guppy) so presses the empty bottle upon Mr. Guppy that that gentleman, with a nod to his (Guppy) friend, accepts the trust and hurries out and hurries in again with the bottle filled. The old man receives it in his (man) arms like a beloved grandchild and pats it tenderly.

``But, I say,'' (he)
he (man) whispers, with his (man) eyes screwed up, after tasting it,
