``this ain't the Lord Chancellor's fourteenpenny. This is eighteenpenny!'' (he)

``I thought you might like that better,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy.

``You're a nobleman, sir,'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
returns Krook with another taste, and his (Guppy) hot breath seems to come towards them like a flame.
``You're a baron of the land.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Taking advantage of this auspicious moment, Mr. Guppy presents his (Guppy) friend under the impromptu name of Mr. Weevle and states the object of their visit. Krook, with his (Krook) bottle under his (Krook) arm -LRB-he (Krook) never gets beyond a certain point of either drunkenness or sobriety-RRB-, takes time to survey his (Krook) proposed lodger and seems to approve of him (Krook).

``You'd like to see the room, young man?'' (he)
he (Krook) says.
``Ah! It's a good room! Been whitewashed. Been cleaned down with soft soap and soda. Hi! It's worth twice the rent, letting alone my company when you want it and such a cat to keep the mice away.'' (the man)

Commending the room after this manner, the old man takes them upstairs, where indeed they do find it cleaner than it used to be and also containing some old articles of furniture which he (man) has dug up from his (man) inexhaustible stores. The terms are easily concluded--for the Lord Chancellor cannot be hard on Mr. Guppy, associated as he (Guppy) is with Kenge and Carboy, Jarndyce and Jarndyce, and other famous claims on his (Jarndyce) professional consideration--and it is agreed that Mr. Weevle shall take possession on the morrow. Mr. Weevle and Mr. Guppy then repair to Cook's Court, Cursitor Street, where the personal introduction of the former to Mr. Snagsby is effected and -LRB-more important-RRB- the vote and interest of Mrs. Snagsby are secured. They then report progress to the eminent Smallweed, waiting at the office in his (Snagsby) tall hat for that purpose, and separate, Mr. Guppy explaining that he (Guppy) would terminate his (Guppy) little entertainment by standing treat at the play but that there are chords in the human mind which would render it a hollow mockery.

On the morrow, in the dusk of evening, Mr. Weevle modestly appears at Krook's, by no means incommoded with luggage, and establishes himself in his (Krook) new lodging, where the two eyes in the shutters stare at him (Krook) in his (Krook) sleep, as if they were full of wonder. On the following day Mr. Weevle, who is a handy good-for-nothing kind of young fellow, borrows a needle and thread of Miss Flite and a hammer of his (Weevle) landlord and goes to work devising apologies for window-curtains, and knocking up apologies for shelves, and hanging up his (Weevle) two teacups, milkpot, and crockery sundries on a pennyworth of little hooks, like a shipwrecked sailor making the best of it.

But what Mr. Weevle prizes most of all his (Weevle) few possessions -LRB-next after his (Weevle) light whiskers, for which he (Weevle) has an attachment that only whiskers can awaken in the breast of man-RRB- is a choice collection of copper-plate impressions from that truly national work The Divinities of Albion, or Galaxy Gallery of British Beauty, representing ladies of title and fashion in every variety of smirk that art, combined with capital, is capable of producing. With these magnificent portraits, unworthily confined in a band-box during his (man) seclusion among the market-gardens, he (man) decorates his (man) apartment; and as the Galaxy Gallery of British Beauty wears every variety of fancy dress, plays every variety of musical instrument, fondles every variety of dog, ogles every variety of prospect, and is backed up by every variety of flower-pot and balustrade, the result is very imposing.

But fashion is Mr. Weevle's, as it was Tony Jobling's, weakness. To borrow yesterday's paper from the Sol's Arms of an evening and read about the brilliant and distinguished meteors that are shooting across the fashionable sky in every direction is unspeakable consolation to him (Sol). To know what member of what brilliant and distinguished circle accomplished the brilliant and distinguished feat of joining it yesterday or contemplates the no less brilliant and distinguished feat of leaving it to-morrow gives him (Sol) a thrill of joy. To be informed what the Galaxy Gallery of British Beauty is about, and means to be about, and what Galaxy marriages are on the tapis, and what Galaxy rumours are in circulation, is to become acquainted with the most glorious destinies of mankind. Mr. Weevle reverts from this intelligence to the Galaxy portraits implicated, and seems to know the originals, and to be known of them.

For the rest he (Weevle) is a quiet lodger, full of handy shifts and devices as before mentioned, able to cook and clean for himself as well as to carpenter, and developing social inclinations after the shades of evening have fallen on the court. At those times, when he (carpenter) is not visited by Mr. Guppy or by a small light in his (carpenter) likeness quenched in a dark hat, he (carpenter) comes out of his (carpenter) dull room--where he (carpenter) has inherited the deal wilderness of desk bespattered with a rain of ink--and talks to Krook or is

``very free,'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
as they call it in the court, commendingly, with any one disposed for conversation. Wherefore, Mrs. Piper, who leads the court, is impelled to offer two remarks to Mrs. Perkins: firstly, that if her (Perkins) Johnny was to have whiskers, she (Perkins) could wish 'em to be identically like that young man's; and secondly,
``Mark my words, Mrs. Perkins, ma'am, and don't you be surprised, Lord bless you, if that young man comes in at last for old Krook's money!'' (that man)

CHAPTER XXI

The Smallweed Family

In a rather ill-favoured and ill-savoured neighbourhood, though one of its rising grounds bears the name of Mount Pleasant, the Elfin Smallweed, christened Bartholomew and known on the domestic hearth as Bart, passes that limited portion of his (Bart) time on which the office and its contingencies have no claim. He (Bart) dwells in a little narrow street, always solitary, shady, and sad, closely bricked in on all sides like a tomb, but where there yet lingers the stump of an old forest tree whose flavour is about as fresh and natural as the Smallweed smack of youth.

There has been only one child in the Smallweed family for several generations. Little old men and women there have been, but no child, until Mr. Smallweed's grandmother, now living, became weak in her (grandmother) intellect and fell -LRB-for the first time-RRB- into a childish state. With such infantine graces as a total want of observation, memory, understanding, and interest, and an eternal disposition to fall asleep over the fire and into it, Mr. Smallweed's grandmother has undoubtedly brightened the family.

Mr. Smallweed's grandfather is likewise of the party. He (Smallweed) is in a helpless condition as to his (Smallweed) lower, and nearly so as to his (Smallweed) upper, limbs, but his (Smallweed) mind is unimpaired. It holds, as well as it ever held, the first four rules of arithmetic and a certain small collection of the hardest facts. In respect of ideality, reverence, wonder, and other such phrenological attributes, it is no worse off than it used to be. Everything that Mr. Smallweed's grandfather ever put away in his (Smallweed) mind was a grub at first, and is a grub at last. In all his (Smallweed) life he (Smallweed) has never bred a single butterfly.

The father of this pleasant grandfather, of the neighbourhood of Mount Pleasant, was a horny-skinned, two-legged, money-getting species of spider who spun webs to catch unwary flies and retired into holes until they were entrapped. The name of this old pagan's god was Compound Interest. He (god) lived for it, married it, died of it. Meeting with a heavy loss in an honest little enterprise in which all the loss was intended to have been on the other side, he (god) broke something--something necessary to his (god) existence, therefore it couldn't have been his (god) heart--and made an end of his (god) career. As his (god) character was not good, and he (god) had been bred at a charity school in a complete course, according to question and answer, of those ancient people the Amorites and Hittites, he (god) was frequently quoted as an example of the failure of education.

His (god) spirit shone through his (god) son, to whom he (god) had always preached of

``going out'' (he)
early in life and whom he (god) made a clerk in a sharp scrivener's office at twelve years old. There the young gentleman improved his (gentleman) mind, which was of a lean and anxious character, and developing the family gifts, gradually elevated himself into the discounting profession. Going out early in life and marrying late, as his (gentleman) father had done before him (gentleman), he (gentleman) too begat a lean and anxious-minded son, who in his (gentleman) turn, going out early in life and marrying late, became the father of Bartholomew and Judith Smallweed, twins. During the whole time consumed in the slow growth of this family tree, the house of Smallweed, always early to go out and late to marry, has strengthened itself in its practical character, has discarded all amusements, discountenanced all story-books, fairy-tales, fictions, and fables, and banished all levities whatsoever. Hence the gratifying fact that it has had no child born to it and that the complete little men and women whom it has produced have been observed to bear a likeness to old monkeys with something depressing on their minds.

At the present time, in the dark little parlour certain feet below the level of the street--a grim, hard, uncouth parlour, only ornamented with the coarsest of baize table-covers, and the hardest of sheet-iron tea-trays, and offering in its decorative character no bad allegorical representation of Grandfather Smallweed's mind--seated in two black horsehair porter's chairs, one on each side of the fire-place, the superannuated Mr. and Mrs. Smallweed while away the rosy hours. On the stove are a couple of trivets for the pots and kettles which it is Grandfather Smallweed's usual occupation to watch, and projecting from the chimney-piece between them is a sort of brass gallows for roasting, which he (Grandfather) also superintends when it is in action. Under the venerable Mr. Smallweed's seat and guarded by his (Smallweed) spindle legs is a drawer in his (Smallweed) chair, reported to contain property to a fabulous amount. Beside him (Smallweed) is a spare cushion with which he (Smallweed) is always provided in order that he (Smallweed) may have something to throw at the venerable partner of his (Smallweed) respected age whenever she (them) makes an allusion to money--a subject on which he (Smallweed) is particularly sensitive.

``And where's Bart?'' (Grandfather)
Grandfather Smallweed inquires of Judy, Bart's twin sister.

``He (Bart) an't come in yet,'' (Judy)
says Judy.

``It's his (Bart) tea-time, isn't it?'' (unknown)

``No.'' (unknown)

``How much do you mean to say it wants then?'' (unknown)

``Ten minutes.'' (unknown)

``Hey?'' (unknown)

``Ten minutes.'' (Judy)
-LRB-Loud on the part of Judy.-RRB-

``Ho!'' (Grandfather)
says Grandfather Smallweed.
``Ten minutes.'' (Grandmother)

Grandmother Smallweed, who has been mumbling and shaking her (Judy) head at the trivets, hearing figures mentioned, connects them with money and screeches like a horrible old parrot without any plumage,

``Ten ten-pound notes!'' (a parrot)

Grandfather Smallweed immediately throws the cushion at her (Judy).

``Drat you, be quiet!'' (the man)
says the good old man.

The effect of this act of jaculation is twofold. It not only doubles up Mrs. Smallweed's head against the side of her (Smallweed) porter's chair and causes her (Smallweed) to present, when extricated by her (Smallweed) granddaughter, a highly unbecoming state of cap, but the necessary exertion recoils on Mr. Smallweed himself, whom it throws back into HIS (Smallweed) porter's chair like a broken puppet. The excellent old gentleman being at these times a mere clothes-bag with a black skull-cap on the top of it, does not present a very animated appearance until he (gentleman) has undergone the two operations at the hands of his (gentleman) granddaughter of being shaken up like a great bottle and poked and punched like a great bolster. Some indication of a neck being developed in him (gentleman) by these means, he (gentleman) and the sharer of his (gentleman) life's evening again fronting one another in their two porter's chairs, like a couple of sentinels long forgotten on their post by the Black Serjeant, Death.

Judy the twin is worthy company for these associates. She (Judy) is so indubitably sister to Mr. Smallweed the younger that the two kneaded into one would hardly make a young person of average proportions, while she (Judy) so happily exemplifies the before-mentioned family likeness to the monkey tribe that attired in a spangled robe and cap she (Judy) might walk about the table-land on the top of a barrel-organ without exciting much remark as an unusual specimen. Under existing circumstances, however, she (Judy) is dressed in a plain, spare gown of brown stuff.

Judy never owned a doll, never heard of Cinderella, never played at any game. She (Judy) once or twice fell into children's company when she (Judy) was about ten years old, but the children couldn't get on with Judy, and Judy couldn't get on with them. She (Judy) seemed like an animal of another species, and there was instinctive repugnance on both sides. It is very doubtful whether Judy knows how to laugh. She (Judy) has so rarely seen the thing done that the probabilities are strong the other way. Of anything like a youthful laugh, she (Judy) certainly can have no conception. If she (Judy) were to try one, she (Judy) would find her (Judy) teeth in her (Judy) way, modelling that action of her (Judy) face, as she (Judy) has unconsciously modelled all its other expressions, on her (Judy) pattern of sordid age. Such is Judy.

And her (Judy) twin brother couldn't wind up a top for his (brother) life. He (brother) knows no more of Jack the Giant Killer or of Sinbad the Sailor than he (Sinbad) knows of the people in the stars. He (Sinbad) could as soon play at leap-frog or at cricket as change into a cricket or a frog himself. But he (Sinbad) is so much the better off than his (Sinbad) sister that on his (Sinbad) narrow world of fact an opening has dawned into such broader regions as lie within the ken of Mr. Guppy. Hence his (Guppy) admiration and his (Guppy) emulation of that shining enchanter.

Judy, with a gong-like clash and clatter, sets one of the sheet-iron tea-trays on the table and arranges cups and saucers. The bread she (Judy) puts on in an iron basket, and the butter -LRB-and not much of it-RRB- in a small pewter plate. Grandfather Smallweed looks hard after the tea as it is served out and asks Judy where the girl is.

``Charley, do you mean?'' (Judy)
says Judy.

``Hey?'' (Grandfather)
from Grandfather Smallweed.

``Charley, do you mean?'' (Grandmother)

This touches a spring in Grandmother Smallweed, who, chuckling as usual at the trivets, cries,

``Over the water! Charley over the water, Charley over the water, over the water to Charley, Charley over the water, over the water to Charley!'' (Grandmother)
and becomes quite energetic about it. Grandfather looks at the cushion but has not sufficiently recovered his (Grandfather) late exertion.

``Ha!'' (he)
he (Grandfather) says when there is silence.
``If that's her (Charley) name. She (Charley) eats a deal. It would be better to allow her (Charley) for her (Charley) keep.'' (Judy)

Judy, with her (Judy) brother's wink, shakes her (Judy) head and purses up her (Judy) mouth into no without saying it.

``No?'' (returns the man)
returns the old man.
``Why not?'' (unknown)

``She (Charley)'d want sixpence a day, and we can do it for less,'' (Judy)
says Judy.

``Sure?'' (Judy)

Judy answers with a nod of deepest meaning and calls, as she (Judy) scrapes the butter on the loaf with every precaution against waste and cuts it into slices,

``You, Charley, where are you?'' (she)
Timidly obedient to the summons, a little girl in a rough apron and a large bonnet, with her (girl) hands covered with soap and water and a scrubbing brush in one of them, appears, and curtsys.

``What work are you about now?'' (Judy)
says Judy, making an ancient snap at her (Judy) like a very sharp old beldame.

``I'm a-cleaning the upstairs back room, miss,'' (Charley)
replies Charley.

``Mind you do it thoroughly, and don't loiter. Shirking won't do for me. Make haste! Go along!'' (Judy)
cries Judy with a stamp upon the ground.
``You girls are more trouble than you're worth, by half.'' (this matron)

On this severe matron, as she (Judy) returns to her (Judy) task of scraping the butter and cutting the bread, falls the shadow of her (Judy) brother, looking in at the window. For whom, knife and loaf in hand, she (Judy) opens the street-door.

``Aye, aye, Bart!'' (Grandfather)
says Grandfather Smallweed.
``Here you are, hey?'' (unknown)

``Here I am,'' (Bart)
says Bart.

``Been along with your friend again, Bart?'' (unknown)

Small nods.

``Dining at his (Bart) expense, Bart?'' (unknown)

Small nods again.

``That's right. Live at his (Bart) expense as much as you can, and take warning by his (Bart) foolish example. That's the use of such a friend. The only use you can put him (Bart) to,'' (the sage)
says the venerable sage.

His (Bart) grandson, without receiving this good counsel as dutifully as he (Bart) might, honours it with all such acceptance as may lie in a slight wink and a nod and takes a chair at the tea-table. The four old faces then hover over teacups like a company of ghastly cherubim, Mrs. Smallweed perpetually twitching her (Smallweed) head and chattering at the trivets and Mr. Smallweed requiring to be repeatedly shaken up like a large black draught.

``Yes, yes,'' (the gentleman)
says the good old gentleman, reverting to his (gentleman) lesson of wisdom.
``That's such advice as your father would have given you, Bart. You never saw your father. More's the pity. He (Bart) was my true son.'' (he)
Whether it is intended to be conveyed that he (gentleman) was particularly pleasant to look at, on that account, does not appear.

``He (Bart) was my true son,'' (the gentleman)
repeats the old gentleman, folding his (gentleman) bread and butter on his (gentleman) knee,
``a good accountant, and died fifteen years ago.'' (the gentleman)

Mrs. Smallweed, following her (Smallweed) usual instinct, breaks out with

``Fifteen hundred pound. Fifteen hundred pound in a black box, fifteen hundred pound locked up, fifteen hundred pound put away and hid!'' (Mrs. Smallweed)
Her (Smallweed) worthy husband, setting aside his (husband) bread and butter, immediately discharges the cushion at her (Smallweed), crushes her (Smallweed) against the side of her (Smallweed) chair, and falls back in his (husband) own, overpowered. His (husband) appearance, after visiting Mrs. Smallweed with one of these admonitions, is particularly impressive and not wholly prepossessing, firstly because the exertion generally twists his (husband) black skull-cap over one eye and gives him (husband) an air of goblin rakishness, secondly because he (husband) mutters violent imprecations against Mrs. Smallweed, and thirdly because the contrast between those powerful expressions and his (husband) powerless figure is suggestive of a baleful old malignant who would be very wicked if he (husband) could. All this, however, is so common in the Smallweed family circle that it produces no impression. The old gentleman is merely shaken and has his (gentleman) internal feathers beaten up, the cushion is restored to its usual place beside him (gentleman), and the old lady, perhaps with her (lady) cap adjusted and perhaps not, is planted in her (lady) chair again, ready to be bowled down like a ninepin.

Some time elapses in the present instance before the old gentleman is sufficiently cool to resume his (gentleman) discourse, and even then he (gentleman) mixes it up with several edifying expletives addressed to the unconscious partner of his (gentleman) bosom, who holds communication with nothing on earth but the trivets. As thus:

``If your father, Bart, had lived longer, he (Bart) might have been worth a deal of money--you brimstone chatterer!--but just as he (Bart) was beginning to build up the house that he (Bart) had been making the foundations for, through many a year--you jade of a magpie, jackdaw, and poll-parrot, what do you mean!--he (Bart) took ill and died of a low fever, always being a sparing and a spare man, full of business care--I should like to throw a cat at you instead of a cushion, and I will too if you make such a confounded fool of yourself!--and your mother, who was a prudent woman as dry as a chip, just dwindled away like touchwood after you and Judy were born--you are an old pig. You are a brimstone pig. You're a head of swine!'' (Judy)

Judy, not interested in what she (Judy) has often heard, begins to collect in a basin various tributary streams of tea, from the bottoms of cups and saucers and from the bottom of the tea-pot for the little charwoman's evening meal. In like manner she (Judy) gets together, in the iron bread-basket, as many outside fragments and worn-down heels of loaves as the rigid economy of the house has left in existence.

``But your father and me were partners, Bart,'' (the gentleman)
says the old gentleman,
``and when I am gone, you and Judy will have all there is. It's rare for you both that you went out early in life--Judy to the flower business, and you to the law. You won't want to spend it. You'll get your living without it, and put more to it. When I am gone, Judy will go back to the flower business and you'll still stick to the law.'' (the gentleman)

One might infer from Judy's appearance that her (Judy) business rather lay with the thorns than the flowers, but she (Judy) has in her (Judy) time been apprenticed to the art and mystery of artificial flower-making. A close observer might perhaps detect both in her (Judy) eye and her (Judy) brother's, when their venerable grandsire anticipates his (brother) being gone, some little impatience to know when he (brother) may be going, and some resentful opinion that it is time he (brother) went.

``Now, if everybody has done,'' (Judy)
says Judy, completing her (Judy) preparations,
``I'll have that girl in to her (girl) tea. She (girl) would never leave off if she (girl) took it by herself in the kitchen.'' (Judy)

Charley is accordingly introduced, and under a heavy fire of eyes, sits down to her (Judy) basin and a Druidical ruin of bread and butter. In the active superintendence of this young person, Judy Smallweed appears to attain a perfectly geological age and to date from the remotest periods. Her (Judy) systematic manner of flying at her (Judy) and pouncing on her (Judy), with or without pretence, whether or no, is wonderful, evincing an accomplishment in the art of girl-driving seldom reached by the oldest practitioners.

``Now, don't stare about you all the afternoon,'' (Judy)
cries Judy, shaking her (Judy) head and stamping her (Judy) foot as she (Judy) happens to catch the glance which has been previously sounding the basin of tea,
``but take your victuals and get back to your work.'' (she)

``Yes, miss,'' (Charley)
says Charley.

``Don't say yes,'' (unknown)
returns Miss Smallweed,
``for I know what you girls are. Do it without saying it, and then I may begin to believe you.'' (Charley)

Charley swallows a great gulp of tea in token of submission and so disperses the Druidical ruins that Miss Smallweed charges her (Judy) not to gormandize, which

``in you girls,'' (her)
she (Judy) observes, is disgusting. Charley might find some more difficulty in meeting her (Judy) views on the general subject of girls but for a knock at the door.

``See who it is, and don't chew when you open it!'' (Judy)
cries Judy.

The object of her (Judy) attentions withdrawing for the purpose, Miss Smallweed takes that opportunity of jumbling the remainder of the bread and butter together and launching two or three dirty tea-cups into the ebb-tide of the basin of tea as a hint that she (Judy) considers the eating and drinking terminated.

``Now! Who is it, and what's wanted?'' (Judy)
says the snappish Judy.

It is one Mr. George, it appears. Without other announcement or ceremony, Mr. George walks in.

``Whew!'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George.
``You are hot here. Always a fire, eh? Well! Perhaps you do right to get used to one.'' (Mr. George/George)
Mr. George makes the latter remark to himself as he (George) nods to Grandfather Smallweed.

``Ho! It's you!'' (the gentleman)
cries the old gentleman.
``How de do? How de do?'' (unknown)

``Middling,'' (Mr. George/George)
replies Mr. George, taking a chair.
``Your granddaughter I have had the honour of seeing before; my service to you, miss.'' (unknown)

``This is my grandson,'' (Grandfather)
says Grandfather Smallweed.
``You ha'n't seen him (grandson) before. He (grandson) is in the law and not much at home.'' (unknown)

``My service to him (grandson), too! He (grandson) is like his (grandson) sister. He (grandson) is very like his (grandson) sister. He (grandson) is devilish like his (grandson) sister,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George, laying a great and not altogether complimentary stress on his (George) last adjective.

``And how does the world use you, Mr. George?'' (Grandfather)
Grandfather Smallweed inquires, slowly rubbing his (Smallweed) legs.

``Pretty much as usual. Like a football.'' (He)

He (Smallweed) is a swarthy brown man of fifty, well made, and good looking, with crisp dark hair, bright eyes, and a broad chest. His (Smallweed) sinewy and powerful hands, as sunburnt as his (Smallweed) face, have evidently been used to a pretty rough life. What is curious about him (Smallweed) is that he (Smallweed) sits forward on his (Smallweed) chair as if he (Smallweed) were, from long habit, allowing space for some dress or accoutrements that he (Smallweed) has altogether laid aside. His (Smallweed) step too is measured and heavy and would go well with a weighty clash and jingle of spurs. He (Smallweed) is close-shaved now, but his (Smallweed) mouth is set as if his (Smallweed) upper lip had been for years familiar with a great moustache; and his (Smallweed) manner of occasionally laying the open palm of his (Smallweed) broad brown hand upon it is to the same effect. Altogether one might guess Mr. George to have been a trooper once upon a time.

A special contrast Mr. George makes to the Smallweed family. Trooper was never yet billeted upon a household more unlike him (George). It is a broadsword to an oyster-knife. His (George) developed figure and their stunted forms, his (George) large manner filling any amount of room and their little narrow pinched ways, his (George) sounding voice and their sharp spare tones, are in the strongest and the strangest opposition. As he (George) sits in the middle of the grim parlour, leaning a little forward, with his (George) hands upon his (George) thighs and his (George) elbows squared, he (George) looks as though, if he (George) remained there long, he (George) would absorb into himself the whole family and the whole four-roomed house, extra little back-kitchen and all.

``Do you rub your legs to rub life into 'em?'' (he)
he (George) asks of Grandfather Smallweed after looking round the room.

``Why, it's partly a habit, Mr. George, and--yes--it partly helps the circulation,'' (he)
he (Grandfather) replies.

``The cir-cu-la-tion!'' (Mr. George/George)
repeats Mr. George, folding his (George) arms upon his (George) chest and seeming to become two sizes larger.
``Not much of that, I should think.'' (unknown)

``Truly I'm old, Mr. George,'' (Grandfather)
says Grandfather Smallweed.
``But I can carry my years. I'm older than HER,'' (wife)
nodding at his (Grandfather) wife,
``and see what she (I) is? You're a brimstone chatterer!'' (wife)
with a sudden revival of his (Grandfather) late hostility.

``Unlucky old soul!'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George, turning his (George) head in that direction.
``Don't scold the old lady. Look at her (lady) here, with her (lady) poor cap half off her (lady) head and her (lady) poor hair all in a muddle. Hold up, ma'am. That's better. There we are! Think of your mother, Mr. Smallweed,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George, coming back to his (George) seat from assisting her (wife),
``if your wife an't enough.'' (her)

``I suppose you were an excellent son, Mr. George?'' (man)
the old man hints with a leer.

The colour of Mr. George's face rather deepens as he (George) replies,

``Why no. I wasn't.'' (he)

``I am astonished at it.'' (unknown)

``So am I. I ought to have been a good son, and I think I meant to have been one. But I wasn't. I was a thundering bad son, that's the long and the short of it, and never was a credit to anybody.'' (unknown)

``Surprising!'' (the man)
cries the old man.

``However,'' (Mr. George/George)
Mr. George resumes,
``the less said about it, the better now. Come! You know the agreement. Always a pipe out of the two months' interest! -LRB-Bosh! It's all correct. You needn't be afraid to order the pipe. Here's the new bill, and here's the two months' interest-money, and a devil-and-all of a scrape it is to get it together in my business.-RRB-'' (Mr. George/George)

Mr. George sits, with his (George) arms folded, consuming the family and the parlour while Grandfather Smallweed is assisted by Judy to two black leathern cases out of a locked bureau, in one of which he (George) secures the document he (George) has just received, and from the other takes another similar document which he (George) hands to Mr. George, who twists it up for a pipelight. As the old man inspects, through his (man) glasses, every up-stroke and down-stroke of both documents before he (man) releases them from their leathern prison, and as he (man) counts the money three times over and requires Judy to say every word she (Judy) utters at least twice, and is as tremulously slow of speech and action as it is possible to be, this business is a long time in progress. When it is quite concluded, and not before, he (man) disengages his (man) ravenous eyes and fingers from it and answers Mr. George's last remark by saying,

``Afraid to order the pipe? We are not so mercenary as that, sir. Judy, see directly to the pipe and the glass of cold brandy-and-water for Mr. George.'' (Mr. George/George)

The sportive twins, who have been looking straight before them all this time except when they have been engrossed by the black leathern cases, retire together, generally disdainful of the visitor, but leaving him (visitor) to the old man as two young cubs might leave a traveller to the parental bear.

``And there you sit, I suppose, all the day long, eh?'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George with folded arms.

``Just so, just so,'' (the man)
the old man nods.

``And don't you occupy yourself at all?'' (unknown)

``I watch the fire--and the boiling and the roasting--'' (Mr. George/George)

``When there is any,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George with great expression.

``Just so. When there is any.'' (unknown)

``Don't you read or get read to?'' (The man)

The old man shakes his (George) head with sharp sly triumph.

``No, no. We have never been readers in our family. It don't pay. Stuff. Idleness. Folly. No, no!'' (unknown)

``There's not much to choose between your two states,'' (the visitor)
says the visitor in a key too low for the old man's dull hearing as he (man) looks from him (man) to the old woman and back again.
``I say!'' (unknown)
in a louder voice.

``I hear you.'' (unknown)

``You'll sell me up at last, I suppose, when I am a day in arrear.'' (unknown)

``My dear friend!'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
cries Grandfather Smallweed, stretching out both hands to embrace him (Smallweed).
``Never! Never, my dear friend! But my friend in the city that I got to lend you the money--HE (friend) might!'' (unknown)

``Oh! You can't answer for him (friend)?'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George, finishing the inquiry in his (George) lower key with the words
``You lying old rascal!'' (Mr. George/George)

``My dear friend, he (friend) is not to be depended on. I wouldn't trust him (friend). He (friend) will have his (friend) bond, my dear friend.'' (unknown)

``Devil doubt him (Devil),'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George. Charley appearing with a tray, on which are the pipe, a small paper of tobacco, and the brandy-and-water, he (George) asks her (woman),
``How do you come here! You haven't got the family face.'' (her)

``I goes out to work, sir,'' (Charley)
returns Charley.

The trooper -LRB-if trooper he (Charley) be or have been-RRB- takes her (woman) bonnet off, with a light touch for so strong a hand, and pats her (woman) on the head.

``You give the house almost a wholesome look. It wants a bit of youth as much as it wants fresh air.'' (he)
Then he (Charley) dismisses her (woman), lights his (Charley) pipe, and drinks to Mr. Smallweed's friend in the city--the one solitary flight of that esteemed old gentleman's imagination.

``So you think he (Devil) might be hard upon me, eh?'' (unknown)

``I think he (Devil) might--I am afraid he (Devil) would. I have known him (Devil) do it,'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
says Grandfather Smallweed incautiously,
``twenty times.'' (Grandfather Smallweed)

Incautiously, because his (Smallweed) stricken better-half, who has been dozing over the fire for some time, is instantly aroused and jabbers

``Twenty thousand pounds, twenty twenty-pound notes in a money-box, twenty guineas, twenty million twenty per cent, twenty--'' (the visitor)
and is then cut short by the flying cushion, which the visitor, to whom this singular experiment appears to be a novelty, snatches from her (woman) face as it crushes her (woman) in the usual manner.

``You're a brimstone idiot. You're a scorpion--a brimstone scorpion! You're a sweltering toad. You're a chattering clattering broomstick witch that ought to be burnt!'' (the man)
gasps the old man, prostrate in his (man) chair.
``My dear friend, will you shake me up a little?'' (Mr. George/George)

Mr. George, who has been looking first at one of them and then at the other, as if he (George) were demented, takes his (George) venerable acquaintance by the throat on receiving this request, and dragging him (George) upright in his (George) chair as easily as if he (George) were a doll, appears in two minds whether or no to shake all future power of cushioning out of him (George) and shake him (George) into his (George) grave. Resisting the temptation, but agitating him (George) violently enough to make his (George) head roll like a harlequin's, he (George) puts him (George) smartly down in his (George) chair again and adjusts his (George) skull-cap with such a rub that the old man winks with both eyes for a minute afterwards.

``O Lord!'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
gasps Mr. Smallweed.
``That'll do. Thank you, my dear friend, that'll do. Oh, dear me, I'm out of breath. O Lord!'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
And Mr. Smallweed says it not without evident apprehensions of his (Smallweed) dear friend, who still stands over him (Smallweed) looming larger than ever.

The alarming presence, however, gradually subsides into its chair and falls to smoking in long puffs, consoling itself with the philosophical reflection,

``The name of your friend in the city begins with a D, comrade, and you're about right respecting the bond.'' (unknown)

``Did you speak, Mr. George?'' (the man)
inquires the old man.

The trooper shakes his (trooper) head, and leaning forward with his (trooper) right elbow on his (trooper) right knee and his (trooper) pipe supported in that hand, while his (trooper) other hand, resting on his (trooper) left leg, squares his (trooper) left elbow in a martial manner, continues to smoke. Meanwhile he (trooper) looks at Mr. Smallweed with grave attention and now and then fans the cloud of smoke away in order that he (Smallweed) may see him (Smallweed) the more clearly.

``I take it,'' (he)
he (Smallweed) says, making just as much and as little change in his (Smallweed) position as will enable him (Smallweed) to reach the glass to his (Smallweed) lips with a round, full action,
``that I am the only man alive -LRB-or dead either-RRB- that gets the value of a pipe out of YOU?'' (him)

``Well,'' (the man)
returns the old man,
``it's true that I don't see company, Mr. George, and that I don't treat. I can't afford to it. But as you, in your pleasant way, made your pipe a condition--'' (the man)

``Why, it's not for the value of it; that's no great thing. It was a fancy to get it out of you. To have something in for my money.'' (unknown)

``Ha! You're prudent, prudent, sir!'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
cries Grandfather Smallweed, rubbing his (Smallweed) legs.

``Very. I always was.'' (Puff)
Puff.
``It's a sure sign of my prudence that I ever found the way here.'' (Puff)
Puff.
``Also, that I am what I am.'' (Puff)
Puff.
``I am well known to be prudent,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George, composedly smoking.
``I rose in life that way.'' (unknown)

``Don't be down-hearted, sir. You may rise yet.'' (Mr. George/George)

Mr. George laughs and drinks.

``Ha'n't you no relations, now,'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
asks Grandfather Smallweed with a twinkle in his (Smallweed) eyes,
``who would pay off this little principal or who would lend you a good name or two that I could persuade my friend in the city to make you a further advance upon? Two good names would be sufficient for my friend in the city. Ha'n't you no such relations, Mr. George?'' (Grandfather Smallweed)

Mr. George, still composedly smoking, replies,

``If I had, I shouldn't trouble them. I have been trouble enough to my belongings in my day. It MAY be a very good sort of penitence in a vagabond, who has wasted the best time of his (George) life, to go back then to decent people that he (George) never was a credit to and live upon them, but it's not my sort. The best kind of amends then for having gone away is to keep away, in my opinion.'' (Mr. George/George)

``But natural affection, Mr. George,'' (Grandfather)
hints Grandfather Smallweed.

``For two good names, hey?'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George, shaking his (George) head and still composedly smoking.
``No. That's not my sort either.'' (Grandfather)

Grandfather Smallweed has been gradually sliding down in his (Smallweed) chair since his (Smallweed) last adjustment and is now a bundle of clothes with a voice in it calling for Judy. That houri, appearing, shakes him (Smallweed) up in the usual manner and is charged by the old gentleman to remain near him (gentleman). For he (gentleman) seems chary of putting his (gentleman) visitor to the trouble of repeating his (gentleman) late attentions.

``Ha!'' (he)
he (gentleman) observes when he (gentleman) is in trim again. ``If you could have traced out the captain, Mr. George, it would have been the making of you. If when you first came here, in consequence of our advertisement in the newspapers--when I say ``our,
'' I'm alluding to the advertisements of my friend in the city, and one or two others who embark their capital in the same way, and are so friendly towards me as sometimes to give me a lift with my little pittance--if at that time you could have helped us, Mr. George, it would have been the making of you.'' (unknown)

``I was willing enough to be ``made,

'' as you call it,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George, smoking not quite so placidly as before, for since the entrance of Judy he (George) has been in some measure disturbed by a fascination, not of the admiring kind, which obliges him (George) to look at her (Judy) as she (Judy) stands by her (Judy) grandfather's chair,
``but on the whole, I am glad I wasn't now.'' (grandfather)

``Why, Mr. George? In the name of--of brimstone, why?'' (Grandfather)
says Grandfather Smallweed with a plain appearance of exasperation. -LRB-Brimstone apparently suggested by his (Grandfather) eye lighting on Mrs. Smallweed in her (Smallweed) slumber.-RRB-

``For two reasons, comrade.'' (unknown)

``And what two reasons, Mr. George? In the name of the--'' (unknown)

``Of our friend in the city?'' (Mr. George/George)
suggests Mr. George, composedly drinking.

``Aye, if you like. What two reasons?'' (unknown)

``In the first place,'' (Mr. George/George)
returns Mr. George, but still looking at Judy as if she (Judy) being so old and so like her (Judy) grandfather it is indifferent which of the two he (George) addresses, ``you gentlemen took me in. You advertised that Mr. Hawdon -LRB-Captain Hawdon, if you hold to the saying
``Once a captain, always a captain'-RRB- was to hear of something to his (captain) advantage.'' (unknown)

``Well?'' (returns the man)
returns the old man shrilly and sharply.

``Well!'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George, smoking on.
``It wouldn't have been much to his (captain) advantage to have been clapped into prison by the whole bill and judgment trade of London.'' (unknown)

``How do you know that? Some of his (captain) rich relations might have paid his (captain) debts or compounded for 'em. Besides, he (captain) had taken US in. He (captain) owed us immense sums all round. I would sooner have strangled him (captain) than had no return. If I sit here thinking of him (captain),'' (snarls the man)
snarls the old man, holding up his (George) impotent ten fingers,
``I want to strangle him (captain) now.'' (snarls the man)
And in a sudden access of fury, he (George) throws the cushion at the unoffending Mrs. Smallweed, but it passes harmlessly on one side of her (Smallweed) chair.

``I don't need to be told,'' (the trooper)
returns the trooper, taking his (trooper) pipe from his (trooper) lips for a moment and carrying his (trooper) eyes back from following the progress of the cushion to the pipe-bowl which is burning low,
``that he (captain) carried on heavily and went to ruin. I have been at his (captain) right hand many a day when he (captain) was charging upon ruin full-gallop. I was with him (captain) when he (captain) was sick and well, rich and poor. I laid this hand upon him (captain) after he (captain) had run through everything and broken down everything beneath him (captain)--when he (captain) held a pistol to his (captain) head.'' (the trooper)

``I wish he (captain) had let it off,'' (the man)
says the benevolent old man,
``and blown his (captain) head into as many pieces as he (captain) owed pounds!'' (the man)

``That would have been a smash indeed,'' (the trooper)
returns the trooper coolly;
``any way, he (captain) had been young, hopeful, and handsome in the days gone by, and I am glad I never found him (captain), when he (captain) was neither, to lead to a result so much to his (captain) advantage. That's reason number one.'' (the trooper)

``I hope number two's as good?'' (snarls the man)
snarls the old man.

``Why, no. It's more of a selfish reason. If I had found him (captain), I must have gone to the other world to look. He (captain) was there.'' (unknown)

``How do you know he (captain) was there?'' (unknown)

``He (captain) wasn't here.'' (unknown)

``How do you know he (captain) wasn't here?'' (unknown)

``Don't lose your temper as well as your money,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George, calmly knocking the ashes out of his (George) pipe.
``He (captain) was drowned long before. I am convinced of it. He (captain) went over a ship's side. Whether intentionally or accidentally, I don't know. Perhaps your friend in the city does. Do you know what that tune is, Mr. Smallweed?'' (he)
he (George) adds after breaking off to whistle one, accompanied on the table with the empty pipe.

``Tune!'' (the man)
replied the old man.
``No. We never have tunes here.'' (unknown)

``That's the Dead March in Saul. They bury soldiers to it, so it's the natural end of the subject. Now, if your pretty granddaughter--excuse me, miss--will condescend to take care of this pipe for two months, we shall save the cost of one next time. Good evening, Mr. Smallweed!'' (unknown)

``My dear friend!'' (the man)
the old man gives him (man) both his (man) hands.

``So you think your friend in the city will be hard upon me if I fall in a payment?'' (the trooper)
says the trooper, looking down upon him (man) like a giant.

``My dear friend, I am afraid he (friend) will,'' (the man)
returns the old man, looking up at him (man) like a pygmy.

Mr. George laughs, and with a glance at Mr. Smallweed and a parting salutation to the scornful Judy, strides out of the parlour, clashing imaginary sabres and other metallic appurtenances as he (Smallweed) goes.

``You're a damned rogue,'' (the gentleman)
says the old gentleman, making a hideous grimace at the door as he (gentleman) shuts it.
``But I'll lime you, you dog, I'll lime you!'' (he)

After this amiable remark, his (gentleman) spirit soars into those enchanting regions of reflection which its education and pursuits have opened to it, and again he (gentleman) and Mrs. Smallweed while away the rosy hours, two unrelieved sentinels forgotten as aforesaid by the Black Serjeant.

While the twain are faithful to their post, Mr. George strides through the streets with a massive kind of swagger and a grave-enough face. It is eight o'clock now, and the day is fast drawing in. He (George) stops hard by Waterloo Bridge and reads a playbill, decides to go to Astley's Theatre. Being there, is much delighted with the horses and the feats of strength; looks at the weapons with a critical eye; disapproves of the combats as giving evidences of unskilful swordsmanship; but is touched home by the sentiments. In the last scene, when the Emperor of Tartary gets up into a cart and condescends to bless the united lovers by hovering over them with the Union Jack, his (Jack) eyelashes are moistened with emotion.

The theatre over, Mr. George comes across the water again and makes his (George) way to that curious region lying about the Haymarket and Leicester Square which is a centre of attraction to indifferent foreign hotels and indifferent foreigners, racket-courts, fighting-men, swordsmen, footguards, old china, gaming-houses, exhibitions, and a large medley of shabbiness and shrinking out of sight. Penetrating to the heart of this region, he (George) arrives by a court and a long whitewashed passage at a great brick building composed of bare walls, floors, roof-rafters, and skylights, on the front of which, if it can be said to have any front, is painted GEORGE``S SHOOTING GALLERY, &c.

Into George's Shooting Gallery, &c., he (George) goes; and in it there are gaslights -LRB-partly turned off now-RRB-, and two whitened targets for rifle-shooting, and archery accommodation, and fencing appliances, and all necessaries for the British art of boxing. None of these sports or exercises being pursued in George's Shooting Gallery to-night, which is so devoid of company that a little grotesque man with a large head has it all to himself and lies asleep upon the floor.

The little man is dressed something like a gunsmith, in a green-baize apron and cap; and his (man) face and hands are dirty with gunpowder and begrimed with the loading of guns. As he (man) lies in the light before a glaring white target, the black upon him (man) shines again. Not far off is the strong, rough, primitive table with a vice upon it at which he (man) has been working. He (man) is a little man with a face all crushed together, who appears, from a certain blue and speckled appearance that one of his (man) cheeks presents, to have been blown up, in the way of business, at some odd time or times.

``Phil!'' (the trooper)
says the trooper in a quiet voice.

``All right!'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
cries Phil, scrambling to his (Phil) feet.

``Anything been doing?'' (unknown)

``Flat as ever so much swipes,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
says Phil.
``Five dozen rifle and a dozen pistol. As to aim!'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
Phil gives a howl at the recollection.

``Shut up shop, Phil!'' (Phil/Phil Squod)

As Phil moves about to execute this order, it appears that he (Phil) is lame, though able to move very quickly. On the speckled side of his (Phil) face he (Phil) has no eyebrow, and on the other side he (Phil) has a bushy black one, which want of uniformity gives him (Phil) a very singular and rather sinister appearance. Everything seems to have happened to his (Phil) hands that could possibly take place consistently with the retention of all the fingers, for they are notched, and seamed, and crumpled all over. He (Phil) appears to be very strong and lifts heavy benches about as if he (Phil) had no idea what weight was. He (Phil) has a curious way of limping round the gallery with his (Phil) shoulder against the wall and tacking off at objects he (Phil) wants to lay hold of instead of going straight to them, which has left a smear all round the four walls, conventionally called

``Phil's mark.'' (he)

This custodian of George's Gallery in George's absence concludes his (George) proceedings, when he (George) has locked the great doors and turned out all the lights but one, which he (George) leaves to glimmer, by dragging out from a wooden cabin in a corner two mattresses and bedding. These being drawn to opposite ends of the gallery, the trooper makes his (trooper) own bed and Phil makes his (Phil).

``Phil!'' (the master)
says the master, walking towards him (Phil) without his (Phil) coat and waistcoat, and looking more soldierly than ever in his (Phil) braces.
``You were found in a doorway, weren't you?'' (unknown)

``Gutter,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
says Phil.
``Watchman tumbled over me.'' (unknown)

``Then vagabondizing came natural to YOU from the beginning.'' (unknown)

``As nat`ral as possible,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
says Phil.

``Good night!'' (unknown)

``Good night, guv`ner.'' (Phil/Phil Squod)

Phil cannot even go straight to bed, but finds it necessary to shoulder round two sides of the gallery and then tack off at his (Phil) mattress. The trooper, after taking a turn or two in the rifle-distance and looking up at the moon now shining through the skylights, strides to his (Phil) own mattress by a shorter route and goes to bed too.

CHAPTER XXII

Mr. Bucket

Allegory looks pretty cool in Lincoln's Inn Fields, though the evening is hot, for both Mr. Tulkinghorn's windows are wide open, and the room is lofty, gusty, and gloomy. These may not be desirable characteristics when November comes with fog and sleet or January with ice and snow, but they have their merits in the sultry long vacation weather. They enable Allegory, though it has cheeks like peaches, and knees like bunches of blossoms, and rosy swellings for calves to its legs and muscles to its arms, to look tolerably cool to-night.

Plenty of dust comes in at Mr. Tulkinghorn's windows, and plenty more has generated among his (Tulkinghorn) furniture and papers. It lies thick everywhere. When a breeze from the country that has lost its way takes fright and makes a blind hurry to rush out again, it flings as much dust in the eyes of Allegory as the law--or Mr. Tulkinghorn, one of its trustiest representatives--may scatter, on occasion, in the eyes of the laity.

In his (Tulkinghorn) lowering magazine of dust, the universal article into which his (Tulkinghorn) papers and himself, and all his (Tulkinghorn) clients, and all things of earth, animate and inanimate, are resolving, Mr. Tulkinghorn sits at one of the open windows enjoying a bottle of old port. Though a hard-grained man, close, dry, and silent, he (man) can enjoy old wine with the best. He (man) has a priceless bin of port in some artful cellar under the Fields, which is one of his (man) many secrets. When he (man) dines alone in chambers, as he (man) has dined to-day, and has his (man) bit of fish and his (man) steak or chicken brought in from the coffee-house, he (man) descends with a candle to the echoing regions below the deserted mansion, and heralded by a remote reverberation of thundering doors, comes gravely back encircled by an earthy atmosphere and carrying a bottle from which he (man) pours a radiant nectar, two score and ten years old, that blushes in the glass to find itself so famous and fills the whole room with the fragrance of southern grapes.

Mr. Tulkinghorn, sitting in the twilight by the open window, enjoys his (Tulkinghorn) wine. As if it whispered to him (Tulkinghorn) of its fifty years of silence and seclusion, it shuts him (Tulkinghorn) up the closer. More impenetrable than ever, he (Tulkinghorn) sits, and drinks, and mellows as it were in secrecy, pondering at that twilight hour on all the mysteries he (Tulkinghorn) knows, associated with darkening woods in the country, and vast blank shut-up houses in town, and perhaps sparing a thought or two for himself, and his (Tulkinghorn) family history, and his (Tulkinghorn) money, and his (Tulkinghorn) will--all a mystery to every one--and that one bachelor friend of his (Tulkinghorn), a man of the same mould and a lawyer too, who lived the same kind of life until he (Tulkinghorn) was seventy-five years old, and then suddenly conceiving -LRB-as it is supposed-RRB- an impression that it was too monotonous, gave his (Tulkinghorn) gold watch to his (Tulkinghorn) hair-dresser one summer evening and walked leisurely home to the Temple and hanged himself.

But Mr. Tulkinghorn is not alone to-night to ponder at his (Tulkinghorn) usual length. Seated at the same table, though with his (Tulkinghorn) chair modestly and uncomfortably drawn a little way from it, sits a bald, mild, shining man who coughs respectfully behind his (man) hand when the lawyer bids him (man) fill his (man) glass.

``Now, Snagsby,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn,
``to go over this odd story again.'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

``If you please, sir.'' (unknown)

``You told me when you were so good as to step round here last night--'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

``For which I must ask you to excuse me if it was a liberty, sir; but I remember that you had taken a sort of an interest in that person, and I thought it possible that you might--just--wish--to--'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

Mr. Tulkinghorn is not the man to help him (Tulkinghorn) to any conclusion or to admit anything as to any possibility concerning himself. So Mr. Snagsby trails off into saying, with an awkward cough,

``I must ask you to excuse the liberty, sir, I am sure.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``Not at all,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn.
``You told me, Snagsby, that you put on your hat and came round without mentioning your intention to your wife. That was prudent I think, because it's not a matter of such importance that it requires to be mentioned.'' (unknown)

``Well, sir,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
returns Mr. Snagsby,
``you see, my little woman is--not to put too fine a point upon it--inquisitive. She (woman)'s inquisitive. Poor little thing, she (woman)'s liable to spasms, and it's good for her (woman) to have her (woman) mind employed. In consequence of which she (woman) employs it--I should say upon every individual thing she (woman) can lay hold of, whether it concerns her (woman) or not--especially not. My little woman has a very active mind, sir.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

Mr. Snagsby drinks and murmurs with an admiring cough behind his (Snagsby) hand,

``Dear me, very fine wine indeed!'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``Therefore you kept your visit to yourself last night?'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn.
``And to-night too?'' (unknown)

``Yes, sir, and to-night, too. My little woman is at present in--not to put too fine a point on it--in a pious state, or in what she (woman) considers such, and attends the Evening Exertions -LRB-which is the name they go by-RRB- of a reverend party of the name of Chadband. He (reverend) has a great deal of eloquence at his (reverend) command, undoubtedly, but I am not quite favourable to his (reverend) style myself. That's neither here nor there. My little woman being engaged in that way made it easier for me to step round in a quiet manner.'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

Mr. Tulkinghorn assents.

``Fill your glass, Snagsby.'' (unknown)

``Thank you, sir, I am sure,'' (the stationer)
returns the stationer with his (Tulkinghorn) cough of deference.
``This is wonderfully fine wine, sir!'' (unknown)

``It is a rare wine now,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn.
``It is fifty years old.'' (unknown)

``Is it indeed, sir? But I am not surprised to hear it, I am sure. It might be--any age almost.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
After rendering this general tribute to the port, Mr. Snagsby in his (Snagsby) modesty coughs an apology behind his (Snagsby) hand for drinking anything so precious.

``Will you run over, once again, what the boy said?'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
asks Mr. Tulkinghorn, putting his (Tulkinghorn) hands into the pockets of his (Tulkinghorn) rusty smallclothes and leaning quietly back in his (Tulkinghorn) chair.

``With pleasure, sir.'' (Jo)

Then, with fidelity, though with some prolixity, the law-stationer repeats Jo's statement made to the assembled guests at his (Tulkinghorn) house. On coming to the end of his (Tulkinghorn) narrative, he (Tulkinghorn) gives a great start and breaks off with,

``Dear me, sir, I wasn't aware there was any other gentleman present!'' (he)

Mr. Snagsby is dismayed to see, standing with an attentive face between himself and the lawyer at a little distance from the table, a person with a hat and stick in his (Snagsby) hand who was not there when he (Snagsby) himself came in and has not since entered by the door or by either of the windows. There is a press in the room, but its hinges have not creaked, nor has a step been audible upon the floor. Yet this third person stands there with his (Snagsby) attentive face, and his (Snagsby) hat and stick in his (Snagsby) hands, and his (Snagsby) hands behind him (Snagsby), a composed and quiet listener. He (Snagsby) is a stoutly built, steady-looking, sharp-eyed man in black, of about the middle-age. Except that he (Snagsby) looks at Mr. Snagsby as if he (Snagsby) were going to take his (Snagsby) portrait, there is nothing remarkable about him (Snagsby) at first sight but his (Snagsby) ghostly manner of appearing.

``Don't mind this gentleman,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn in his (Tulkinghorn) quiet way.
``This is only Mr. Bucket.'' (unknown)

``Oh, indeed, sir?'' (returns the stationer)
returns the stationer, expressing by a cough that he (Tulkinghorn) is quite in the dark as to who Mr. Bucket may be.

``I wanted him (Mr.) to hear this story,'' (the lawyer)
says the lawyer,
``because I have half a mind -LRB-for a reason-RRB- to know more of it, and he (Mr.) is very intelligent in such things. What do you say to this, Bucket?'' (the lawyer)

``It's very plain, sir. Since our people have moved this boy on, and he (boy)'s not to be found on his (boy) old lay, if Mr. Snagsby don't object to go down with me to Tom-all-Alone's and point him (Snagsby) out, we can have him (Snagsby) here in less than a couple of hours' time. I can do it without Mr. Snagsby, of course, but this is the shortest way.'' (unknown)

``Mr. Bucket is a detective officer, Snagsby,'' (the lawyer)
says the lawyer in explanation.

``Is he (Mr.) indeed, sir?'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby with a strong tendency in his (Snagsby) clump of hair to stand on end.

``And if you have no real objection to accompany Mr. Bucket to the place in question,'' (the lawyer)
pursues the lawyer,
``I shall feel obliged to you if you will do so.'' (the lawyer)

In a moment's hesitation on the part of Mr. Snagsby, Bucket dips down to the bottom of his (Snagsby) mind.

``Don't you be afraid of hurting the boy,'' (he)
he (Snagsby) says.
``You won't do that. It's all right as far as the boy's concerned. We shall only bring him (boy) here to ask him (boy) a question or so I want to put to him (boy), and he (boy)'ll be paid for his (boy) trouble and sent away again. It'll be a good job for him (boy). I promise you, as a man, that you shall see the boy sent away all right. Don't you be afraid of hurting him (boy); you an't going to do that.'' (unknown)

``Very well, Mr. Tulkinghorn!'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
cries Mr. Snagsby cheerfully. And reassured,
``Since that's the case--'' (unknown)

``Yes! And lookee here, Mr. Snagsby,'' (him)
resumes Bucket, taking him (Snagsby) aside by the arm, tapping him (Snagsby) familiarly on the breast, and speaking in a confidential tone.
``You're a man of the world, you know, and a man of business, and a man of sense. That's what YOU are.'' (unknown)

``I am sure I am much obliged to you for your good opinion,'' (the stationer)
returns the stationer with his (Snagsby) cough of modesty,
``but--'' (the stationer)

``That's what YOU are, you know,'' (the stationer)
says Bucket.
``Now, it an't necessary to say to a man like you, engaged in your business, which is a business of trust and requires a person to be wide awake and have his (man) senses about him (man) and his (man) head screwed on tight -LRB-I had an uncle in your business once-RRB---it an't necessary to say to a man like you that it's the best and wisest way to keep little matters like this quiet. Don't you see? Quiet!'' (unknown)

``Certainly, certainly,'' (unknown)
returns the other.

``I don't mind telling YOU,'' (unknown)
says Bucket with an engaging appearance of frankness,
``that as far as I can understand it, there seems to be a doubt whether this dead person wasn't entitled to a little property, and whether this female hasn't been up to some games respecting that property, don't you see?'' (unknown)

``Oh!'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby, but not appearing to see quite distinctly.

``Now, what YOU want,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
pursues Bucket, again tapping Mr. Snagsby on the breast in a comfortable and soothing manner,
``is that every person should have their rights according to justice. That's what YOU want.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``To be sure,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
returns Mr. Snagsby with a nod.

``On account of which, and at the same time to oblige a--do you call it, in your business, customer or client? I forget how my uncle used to call it.'' (unknown)

``Why, I generally say customer myself,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
replies Mr. Snagsby.

``You're right!'' (Mr. Bucket)
returns Mr. Bucket, shaking hands with him (Snagsby) quite affectionately.
''--On account of which, and at the same time to oblige a real good customer, you mean to go down with me, in confidence, to Tom-all-Alone's and to keep the whole thing quiet ever afterwards and never mention it to any one. That's about your intentions, if I understand you?'' (him)

``You are right, sir. You are right,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby.

``Then here's your hat,'' (friend)
returns his (Snagsby) new friend, quite as intimate with it as if he (Snagsby) had made it;
``and if you're ready, I am.'' (he)

They leave Mr. Tulkinghorn, without a ruffle on the surface of his (Tulkinghorn) unfathomable depths, drinking his (Tulkinghorn) old wine, and go down into the streets.

``You don't happen to know a very good sort of person of the name of Gridley, do you?'' (unknown)
says Bucket in friendly converse as they descend the stairs.

``No,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby, considering,
``I don't know anybody of that name. Why?'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``Nothing particular,'' (unknown)
says Bucket;
``only having allowed his (Gridley) temper to get a little the better of him (Gridley) and having been threatening some respectable people, he (Gridley) is keeping out of the way of a warrant I have got against him (Gridley)--which it's a pity that a man of sense should do.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

As they walk along, Mr. Snagsby observes, as a novelty, that however quick their pace may be, his (Snagsby) companion still seems in some undefinable manner to lurk and lounge; also, that whenever he (Snagsby) is going to turn to the right or left, he (Snagsby) pretends to have a fixed purpose in his (Snagsby) mind of going straight ahead, and wheels off, sharply, at the very last moment. Now and then, when they pass a police-constable on his (Snagsby) beat, Mr. Snagsby notices that both the constable and his (Snagsby) guide fall into a deep abstraction as they come towards each other, and appear entirely to overlook each other, and to gaze into space. In a few instances, Mr. Bucket, coming behind some under-sized young man with a shining hat on, and his (Mr.) sleek hair twisted into one flat curl on each side of his (Mr.) head, almost without glancing at him (Mr.) touches him (Mr.) with his (Mr.) stick, upon which the young man, looking round, instantly evaporates. For the most part Mr. Bucket notices things in general, with a face as unchanging as the great mourning ring on his (Mr.) little finger or the brooch, composed of not much diamond and a good deal of setting, which he (Mr.) wears in his (Mr.) shirt.

When they come at last to Tom-all-Alone's, Mr. Bucket stops for a moment at the corner and takes a lighted bull's-eye from the constable on duty there, who then accompanies him (constable) with his (constable) own particular bull's-eye at his (constable) waist. Between his (constable) two conductors, Mr. Snagsby passes along the middle of a villainous street, undrained, unventilated, deep in black mud and corrupt water--though the roads are dry elsewhere--and reeking with such smells and sights that he (Snagsby), who has lived in London all his (Snagsby) life, can scarce believe his (Snagsby) senses. Branching from this street and its heaps of ruins are other streets and courts so infamous that Mr. Snagsby sickens in body and mind and feels as if he (Snagsby) were going every moment deeper down into the infernal gulf.

``Draw off a bit here, Mr. Snagsby,'' (unknown)
says Bucket as a kind of shabby palanquin is borne towards them, surrounded by a noisy crowd.
``Here's the fever coming up the street!'' (the wretch)

As the unseen wretch goes by, the crowd, leaving that object of attraction, hovers round the three visitors like a dream of horrible faces and fades away up alleys and into ruins and behind walls, and with occasional cries and shrill whistles of warning, thenceforth flits about them until they leave the place.

``Are those the fever-houses, Darby?'' (Mr.)
Mr. Bucket coolly asks as he (Mr.) turns his (Mr.) bull's-eye on a line of stinking ruins.

Darby replies that

``all them are,'' (Darby)
and further that in all, for months and months, the people
``have been down by dozens'' (the people)
and have been carried out dead and dying
``like sheep with the rot.'' (the people)
Bucket observing to Mr. Snagsby as they go on again that he (Snagsby) looks a little poorly, Mr. Snagsby answers that he (Snagsby) feels as if he (Snagsby) couldn't breathe the dreadful air.

There is inquiry made at various houses for a boy named Jo. As few people are known in Tom-all-Alone's by any Christian sign, there is much reference to Mr. Snagsby whether he (Snagsby) means Carrots, or the Colonel, or Gallows, or Young Chisel, or Terrier Tip, or Lanky, or the Brick. Mr. Snagsby describes over and over again. There are conflicting opinions respecting the original of his (Snagsby) picture. Some think it must be Carrots, some say the Brick. The Colonel is produced, but is not at all near the thing. Whenever Mr. Snagsby and his (Snagsby) conductors are stationary, the crowd flows round, and from its squalid depths obsequious advice heaves up to Mr. Bucket. Whenever they move, and the angry bull's-eyes glare, it fades away and flits about them up the alleys, and in the ruins, and behind the walls, as before.

At last there is a lair found out where Toughy, or the Tough Subject, lays him (Mr.) down at night; and it is thought that the Tough Subject may be Jo. Comparison of notes between Mr. Snagsby and the proprietress of the house--a drunken face tied up in a black bundle, and flaring out of a heap of rags on the floor of a dog-hutch which is her (Jo) private apartment--leads to the establishment of this conclusion. Toughy has gone to the doctor's to get a bottle of stuff for a sick woman but will be here anon.

``And who have we got here to-night?'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket, opening another door and glaring in with his (Mr.) bull's-eye.
``Two drunken men, eh? And two women? The men are sound enough,'' (each sleeper)
turning back each sleeper's arm from his (Mr.) face to look at him (Mr.).
``Are these your good men, my dears?'' (unknown)

``Yes, sir,'' (the women)
returns one of the women.
``They are our husbands.'' (unknown)

``Brickmakers, eh?'' (unknown)

``Yes, sir.'' (unknown)

``What are you doing here? You don't belong to London.'' (unknown)

``No, sir. We belong to Hertfordshire.'' (unknown)

``Whereabouts in Hertfordshire?'' (unknown)

``Saint Albans.'' (unknown)

``Come up on the tramp?'' (unknown)

``We walked up yesterday. There's no work down with us at present, but we have done no good by coming here, and shall do none, I expect.'' (unknown)

``That's not the way to do much good,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket, turning his (Mr.) head in the direction of the unconscious figures on the ground.

``It an't indeed,'' (the woman)
replies the woman with a sigh.
``Jenny and me knows it full well.'' (the visitors)

The room, though two or three feet higher than the door, is so low that the head of the tallest of the visitors would touch the blackened ceiling if he (Mr.) stood upright. It is offensive to every sense; even the gross candle burns pale and sickly in the polluted air. There are a couple of benches and a higher bench by way of table. The men lie asleep where they stumbled down, but the women sit by the candle. Lying in the arms of the woman who has spoken is a very young child.

``Why, what age do you call that little creature?'' (unknown)
says Bucket.
``It looks as if it was born yesterday.'' (He)
He (Mr.) is not at all rough about it; and as he (Mr.) turns his (Mr.) light gently on the infant, Mr. Snagsby is strangely reminded of another infant, encircled with light, that he (Snagsby) has seen in pictures.

``He (tramp) is not three weeks old yet, sir,'' (the woman)
says the woman.

``Is he (tramp) your child?'' (unknown)

``Mine.'' (The woman)

The other woman, who was bending over it when they came in, stoops down again and kisses it as it lies asleep.

``You seem as fond of it as if you were the mother yourself,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.

``I was the mother of one like it, master, and it died.'' (unknown)

``Ah, Jenny, Jenny!'' (the woman)
says the other woman to her (woman).
``Better so. Much better to think of dead than alive, Jenny! Much better!'' (unknown)

``Why, you an't such an unnatural woman, I hope,'' (unknown)
returns Bucket sternly,
``as to wish your own child dead?'' (unknown)

``God knows you are right, master,'' (she)
she (woman) returns.
``I am not. I'd stand between it and death with my own life if I could, as true as any pretty lady.'' (unknown)

``Then don't talk in that wrong manner,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket, mollified again.
``Why do you do it?'' (unknown)

``It's brought into my head, master,'' (the woman eyes)
returns the woman, her (woman) eyes filling with tears,
``when I look down at the child lying so. If it was never to wake no more, you'd think me mad, I should take on so. I know that very well. I was with Jenny when she (Jenny) lost hers--warn't I, Jenny?--and I know how she (Jenny) grieved. But look around you at this place. Look at them,'' (the woman eyes)
glancing at the sleepers on the ground.
``Look at the boy you're waiting for, who's gone out to do me a good turn. Think of the children that your business lays with often and often, and that YOU see grow up!'' (unknown)

``Well, well,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket,
``you train him (boy) respectable, and he (boy)'ll be a comfort to you, and look after you in your old age, you know.'' (Mr.)

``I mean to try hard,'' (she)
she (woman) answers, wiping her (woman) eyes.
``But I have been a-thinking, being over-tired to-night and not well with the ague, of all the many things that'll come in his (boy) way. My master will be against it, and he (master)'ll be beat, and see me beat, and made to fear his (master) home, and perhaps to stray wild. If I work for him (master) ever so much, and ever so hard, there's no one to help me; and if he (master) should be turned bad `spite of all I could do, and the time should come when I should sit by him (master) in his (master) sleep, made hard and changed, an't it likely I should think of him (master) as he (master) lies in my lap now and wish he (master) had died as Jenny's child died!'' (unknown)

``There, there!'' (Jenny/Will Jenny)
says Jenny.
``Liz, you're tired and ill. Let me take him (master).'' (she)

In doing so, she (Jenny) displaces the mother's dress, but quickly readjusts it over the wounded and bruised bosom where the baby has been lying.

``It's my dead child,'' (Jenny/Will Jenny)
says Jenny, walking up and down as she (Jenny) nurses,
``that makes me love this child so dear, and it's my dead child that makes her (Liz) love it so dear too, as even to think of its being taken away from her (Liz) now. While she (Liz) thinks that, I think what fortune would I give to have my darling back. But we mean the same thing, if we knew how to say it, us two mothers does in our poor hearts!'' (nurses)

As Mr. Snagsby blows his (Snagsby) nose and coughs his (Snagsby) cough of sympathy, a step is heard without. Mr. Bucket throws his (Mr.) light into the doorway and says to Mr. Snagsby,

``Now, what do you say to Toughy? Will HE (my) do?'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``That's Jo,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby.

Jo stands amazed in the disk of light, like a ragged figure in a magic-lantern, trembling to think that he (Snagsby) has offended against the law in not having moved on far enough. Mr. Snagsby, however, giving him (Snagsby) the consolatory assurance,

``It's only a job you will be paid for, Jo,'' (him)
he (Snagsby) recovers; and on being taken outside by Mr. Bucket for a little private confabulation, tells his (Mr.) tale satisfactorily, though out of breath.

``I have squared it with the lad,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket, returning,
``and it's all right. Now, Mr. Snagsby, we're ready for you.'' (Mr.)

First, Jo has to complete his (Mr.) errand of good nature by handing over the physic he (Mr.) has been to get, which he (Mr.) delivers with the laconic verbal direction that

``it's to be all took d'rectly.'' (he)
Secondly, Mr. Snagsby has to lay upon the table half a crown, his (Snagsby) usual panacea for an immense variety of afflictions. Thirdly, Mr. Bucket has to take Jo by the arm a little above the elbow and walk him (Mr.) on before him (Mr.), without which observance neither the Tough Subject nor any other Subject could be professionally conducted to Lincoln's Inn Fields. These arrangements completed, they give the women good night and come out once more into black and foul Tom-all-Alone's.

By the noisome ways through which they descended into that pit, they gradually emerge from it, the crowd flitting, and whistling, and skulking about them until they come to the verge, where restoration of the bull's-eyes is made to Darby. Here the crowd, like a concourse of imprisoned demons, turns back, yelling, and is seen no more. Through the clearer and fresher streets, never so clear and fresh to Mr. Snagsby's mind as now, they walk and ride until they come to Mr. Tulkinghorn's gate.

As they ascend the dim stairs -LRB-Mr. Tulkinghorn's chambers being on the first floor-RRB-, Mr. Bucket mentions that he (Bucket) has the key of the outer door in his (Bucket) pocket and that there is no need to ring. For a man so expert in most things of that kind, Bucket takes time to open the door and makes some noise too. It may be that he (Bucket) sounds a note of preparation.

Howbeit, they come at last into the hall, where a lamp is burning, and so into Mr. Tulkinghorn's usual room--the room where he (Tulkinghorn) drank his (Tulkinghorn) old wine to-night. He (Tulkinghorn) is not there, but his (Tulkinghorn) two old-fashioned candlesticks are, and the room is tolerably light.

Mr. Bucket, still having his (Bucket) professional hold of Jo and appearing to Mr. Snagsby to possess an unlimited number of eyes, makes a little way into this room, when Jo starts and stops.

``What's the matter?'' (unknown)
says Bucket in a whisper.

``There she (Jo) is!'' (Jo)
cries Jo.

``Who!'' (unknown)

``The lady!'' (unknown)

A female figure, closely veiled, stands in the middle of the room, where the light falls upon it. It is quite still and silent. The front of the figure is towards them, but it takes no notice of their entrance and remains like a statue.

``Now, tell me,'' (unknown)
says Bucket aloud,
``how you know that to be the lady.'' (unknown)

``I know the wale,'' (Jo)
replies Jo, staring,
``and the bonnet, and the gownd.'' (Jo)

``Be quite sure of what you say, Tough,'' (him)
returns Bucket, narrowly observant of him (Snagsby).
``Look again.'' (unknown)

``I am a-looking as hard as ever I can look,'' (Jo)
says Jo with starting eyes,
``and that there's the wale, the bonnet, and the gownd.'' (Jo)

``What about those rings you told me of?'' (unknown)
asks Bucket.

``A-sparkling all over here,'' (Jo)
says Jo, rubbing the fingers of his (Snagsby) left hand on the knuckles of his (Snagsby) right without taking his (Snagsby) eyes from the figure.

The figure removes the right-hand glove and shows the hand.

``Now, what do you say to that?'' (unknown)
asks Bucket.

Jo shakes his (Snagsby) head.

``Not rings a bit like them. Not a hand like that.'' (unknown)

``What are you talking of?'' (unknown)
says Bucket, evidently pleased though, and well pleased too.

``Hand was a deal whiter, a deal delicater, and a deal smaller,'' (Jo)
returns Jo.

``Why, you'll tell me I'm my own mother next,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.
``Do you recollect the lady's voice?'' (unknown)

``I think I does,'' (Jo)
says Jo.

The figure speaks.

``Was it at all like this? I will speak as long as you like if you are not sure. Was it this voice, or at all like this voice?'' (Jo)

Jo looks aghast at Mr. Bucket.

``Not a bit!'' (unknown)

``Then, what,'' (unknown)
retorts that worthy, pointing to the figure,
``did you say it was the lady for?'' (unknown)

``Cos,'' (Jo)
says Jo with a perplexed stare but without being at all shaken in his (Mr.) certainty,
``cos that there's the wale, the bonnet, and the gownd. It is her (lady) and it an't her (lady). It an't her (lady) hand, nor yet her (lady) rings, nor yet her (lady) woice. But that there's the wale, the bonnet, and the gownd, and they're wore the same way wot she (lady) wore 'em, and it's her (lady) height wot she (lady) wos, and she (lady) giv me a sov`ring and hooked it.'' (Jo)

``Well!'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket slightly,
``we haven't got much good out of YOU. But, however, here's five shillings for you. Take care how you spend it, and don't get yourself into trouble.'' (Mr.)
