``My angry friend from Shropshire! Almost as celebrated as myself!'' (she)
she (George) exclaimed.
``Now really! My dear, I will wait upon him (friend) with the greatest pleasure.'' (unknown)

``He (friend) is living concealed at Mr. George's,'' (I.)
said I.
``Hush! This is Mr. George.'' (I.)

``In--deed!'' (unknown)
returned Miss Flite.
``Very proud to have the honour! A military man, my dear. You know, a perfect general!'' (she)
she (George) whispered to me.

Poor Miss Flite deemed it necessary to be so courtly and polite, as a mark of her (George) respect for the army, and to curtsy so very often that it was no easy matter to get her (George) out of the court. When this was at last done, and addressing Mr. George as

``General,'' (Mr. George/George)
she (George) gave him (George) her (George) arm, to the great entertainment of some idlers who were looking on, he (George) was so discomposed and begged me so respectfully
``not to desert him (General)'' (me)
that I could not make up my mind to do it, especially as Miss Flite was always tractable with me and as she (George) too said,
``Fitz Jarndyce, my dear, you will accompany us, of course.'' (she)
As Richard seemed quite willing, and even anxious, that we should see them safely to their destination, we agreed to do so. And as Mr. George informed us that Gridley's mind had run on Mr. Jarndyce all the afternoon after hearing of their interview in the morning, I wrote a hasty note in pencil to my guardian to say where we were gone and why. Mr. George sealed it at a coffee-house, that it might lead to no discovery, and we sent it off by a ticket-porter.

We then took a hackney-coach and drove away to the neighbourhood of Leicester Square. We walked through some narrow courts, for which Mr. George apologized, and soon came to the shooting gallery, the door of which was closed. As he (George) pulled a bell-handle which hung by a chain to the door-post, a very respectable old gentleman with grey hair, wearing spectacles, and dressed in a black spencer and gaiters and a broad-brimmed hat, and carrying a large gold-beaded cane, addressed him (spencer).

``I ask your pardon, my good friend,'' (he)
said he (spencer),
``but is this George's Shooting Gallery?'' (he)

``It is, sir,'' (Mr. George/George)
returned Mr. George, glancing up at the great letters in which that inscription was painted on the whitewashed wall.

``Oh! To be sure!'' (the gentleman)
said the old gentleman, following his (gentleman) eyes.
``Thank you. Have you rung the bell?'' (unknown)

``My name is George, sir, and I have rung the bell.'' (unknown)

``Oh, indeed?'' (the gentleman)
said the old gentleman.
``Your name is George? Then I am here as soon as you, you see. You came for me, no doubt?'' (unknown)

``No, sir. You have the advantage of me.'' (unknown)

``Oh, indeed?'' (the gentleman)
said the old gentleman.
``Then it was your young man who came for me. I am a physician and was requested--five minutes ago--to come and visit a sick man at George's Shooting Gallery.'' (unknown)

``The muffled drums,'' (Mr. George/George)
said Mr. George, turning to Richard and me and gravely shaking his (George) head.
``It's quite correct, sir. Will you please to walk in.'' (a man)

The door being at that moment opened by a very singular-looking little man in a green-baize cap and apron, whose face and hands and dress were blackened all over, we passed along a dreary passage into a large building with bare brick walls where there were targets, and guns, and swords, and other things of that kind. When we had all arrived here, the physician stopped, and taking off his (physician) hat, appeared to vanish by magic and to leave another and quite a different man in his (man) place.

``Now lookee here, George,'' (the man)
said the man, turning quickly round upon him (man) and tapping him (man) on the breast with a large forefinger.
``You know me, and I know you. You're a man of the world, and I'm a man of the world. My name's Bucket, as you are aware, and I have got a peace-warrant against Gridley. You have kept him (Gridley) out of the way a long time, and you have been artful in it, and it does you credit.'' (Mr. George/George)

Mr. George, looking hard at him (George), bit his (George) lip and shook his (George) head.

``Now, George,'' (him)
said the other, keeping close to him (George), ``you're a sensible man and a well-conducted man; that's what YOU are, beyond a doubt. And mind you, I don't talk to you as a common character, because you have served your country and you know that when duty calls we must obey. Consequently you're very far from wanting to give trouble. If I required assistance, you'd assist me; that's what YOU``D do. Phil Squod, don't you go a-sidling round the gallery like that''--the dirty little man was shuffling about with his (man) shoulder against the wall, and his (man) eyes on the intruder, in a manner that looked threatening--
``because I know you and won't have it.'' (Phil/Phil Squod)

``Phil!'' (Mr. George/George)
said Mr. George.

``Yes, guv`ner.'' (unknown)

``Be quiet.'' (The man)

The little man, with a low growl, stood still.

``Ladies and gentlemen,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket,
``you'll excuse anything that may appear to be disagreeable in this, for my name's Inspector Bucket of the Detective, and I have a duty to perform. George, I know where my man is because I was on the roof last night and saw him (man) through the skylight, and you along with him (man). He (man) is in there, you know,'' (Mr.)
pointing;
``that's where HE (man) is--on a sofy. Now I must see my man, and I must tell my man to consider himself in custody; but you know me, and you know I don't want to take any uncomfortable measures. You give me your word, as from one man to another -LRB-and an old soldier, mind you, likewise-RRB-, that it's honourable between us two, and I'll accommodate you to the utmost of my power.'' (unknown)

``I give it,'' (unknown)
was the reply.
``But it wasn't handsome in you, Mr. Bucket.'' (unknown)

``Gammon, George! Not handsome?'' (Mr. Bucket)
said Mr. Bucket, tapping him (Bucket) on his (Bucket) broad breast again and shaking hands with him (Bucket).
``I don't say it wasn't handsome in you to keep my man so close, do I? Be equally good-tempered to me, old boy! Old William Tell, Old Shaw, the Life Guardsman! Why, he (Guardsman)'s a model of the whole British army in himself, ladies and gentlemen. I'd give a fifty-pun' note to be such a figure of a man!'' (Mr. George/George)

The affair being brought to this head, Mr. George, after a little consideration, proposed to go in first to his (George) comrade -LRB-as he (George) called him (George)-RRB-, taking Miss Flite with him (George). Mr. Bucket agreeing, they went away to the further end of the gallery, leaving us sitting and standing by a table covered with guns. Mr. Bucket took this opportunity of entering into a little light conversation, asking me if I were afraid of fire-arms, as most young ladies were; asking Richard if he (Richard) were a good shot; asking Phil Squod which he (Squod) considered the best of those rifles and what it might be worth first-hand, telling him (Squod) in return that it was a pity he (Squod) ever gave way to his (Squod) temper, for he (Squod) was naturally so amiable that he (Squod) might have been a young woman, and making himself generally agreeable.

After a time he (Squod) followed us to the further end of the gallery, and Richard and I were going quietly away when Mr. George came after us. He (George) said that if we had no objection to see his (George) comrade, he (George) would take a visit from us very kindly. The words had hardly passed his (George) lips when the bell was rung and my guardian appeared,

``on the chance,'' (guardian)
he (George) slightly observed,
``of being able to do any little thing for a poor fellow involved in the same misfortune as himself.'' (he)
We all four went back together and went into the place where Gridley was.

It was a bare room, partitioned off from the gallery with unpainted wood. As the screening was not more than eight or ten feet high and only enclosed the sides, not the top, the rafters of the high gallery roof were overhead, and the skylight through which Mr. Bucket had looked down. The sun was low--near setting--and its light came redly in above, without descending to the ground. Upon a plain canvas-covered sofa lay the man from Shropshire, dressed much as we had seen him (man) last, but so changed that at first I recognized no likeness in his (man) colourless face to what I recollected.

He (man) had been still writing in his (man) hiding-place, and still dwelling on his (man) grievances, hour after hour. A table and some shelves were covered with manuscript papers and with worn pens and a medley of such tokens. Touchingly and awfully drawn together, he (man) and the little mad woman were side by side and, as it were, alone. She (woman) sat on a chair holding his (man) hand, and none of us went close to them.

His (man) voice had faded, with the old expression of his (man) face, with his (man) strength, with his (man) anger, with his (man) resistance to the wrongs that had at last subdued him (man). The faintest shadow of an object full of form and colour is such a picture of it as he (man) was of the man from Shropshire whom we had spoken with before.

He (man) inclined his (man) head to Richard and me and spoke to my guardian.

``Mr. Jarndyce, it is very kind of you to come to see me. I am not long to be seen, I think. I am very glad to take your hand, sir. You are a good man, superior to injustice, and God knows I honour you.'' (guardian)

They shook hands earnestly, and my guardian said some words of comfort to him (man).

``It may seem strange to you, sir,'' (Gridley/Mr. Gridley)
returned Gridley;
``I should not have liked to see you if this had been the first time of our meeting. But you know I made a fight for it, you know I stood up with my single hand against them all, you know I told them the truth to the last, and told them what they were, and what they had done to me; so I don't mind your seeing me, this wreck.'' (Gridley/Mr. Gridley)

``You have been courageous with them many and many a time,'' (guardian)
returned my guardian.

``Sir, I have been,'' (unknown)
with a faint smile.
``I told you what would come of it when I ceased to be so, and see here! Look at us--look at us!'' (He)
He (Gridley) drew the hand Miss Flite held through her (my) arm and brought her (my) something nearer to him (Gridley).

``This ends it. Of all my old associations, of all my old pursuits and hopes, of all the living and the dead world, this one poor soul alone comes natural to me, and I am fit for. There is a tie of many suffering years between us two, and it is the only tie I ever had on earth that Chancery has not broken.'' (unknown)

``Accept my blessing, Gridley,'' (unknown)
said Miss Flite in tears.
``Accept my blessing!'' (unknown)

``I thought, boastfully, that they never could break my heart, Mr. Jarndyce. I was resolved that they should not. I did believe that I could, and would, charge them with being the mockery they were until I died of some bodily disorder. But I am worn out. How long I have been wearing out, I don't know; I seemed to break down in an hour. I hope they may never come to hear of it. I hope everybody here will lead them to believe that I died defying them, consistently and perseveringly, as I did through so many years.'' (Mr. Bucket)

Here Mr. Bucket, who was sitting in a corner by the door, good-naturedly offered such consolation as he (Bucket) could administer.

``Come, come!'' (he)
he (Bucket) said from his (Bucket) corner.
``Don't go on in that way, Mr. Gridley. You are only a little low. We are all of us a little low sometimes. I am. Hold up, hold up! You'll lose your temper with the whole round of 'em, again and again; and I shall take you on a score of warrants yet, if I have luck.'' (He)

He (Bucket) only shook his (Bucket) head.

``Don't shake your head,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket.
``Nod it; that's what I want to see you do. Why, Lord bless your soul, what times we have had together! Haven't I seen you in the Fleet over and over again for contempt? Haven't I come into court, twenty afternoons for no other purpose than to see you pin the Chancellor like a bull-dog? Don't you remember when you first began to threaten the lawyers, and the peace was sworn against you two or three times a week? Ask the little old lady there; she (lady) has been always present. Hold up, Mr. Gridley, hold up, sir!'' (unknown)

``What are you going to do about him (Gridley)?'' (Mr. George/George)
asked George in a low voice.

``I don't know yet,'' (unknown)
said Bucket in the same tone. Then resuming his (Mr.) encouragement, he (Mr.) pursued aloud:
``Worn out, Mr. Gridley? After dodging me for all these weeks and forcing me to climb the roof here like a tom cat and to come to see you as a doctor? That ain't like being worn out. I should think not! Now I tell you what you want. You want excitement, you know, to keep YOU up; that's what YOU want. You're used to it, and you can't do without it. I couldn't myself. Very well, then; here's this warrant got by Mr. Tulkinghorn of Lincoln's Inn Fields, and backed into half-a-dozen counties since. What do you say to coming along with me, upon this warrant, and having a good angry argument before the magistrates? It'll do you good; it'll freshen you up and get you into training for another turn at the Chancellor. Give in? Why, I am surprised to hear a man of your energy talk of giving in. You mustn't do that. You're half the fun of the fair in the Court of Chancery. George, you lend Mr. Gridley a hand, and let's see now whether he (Gridley) won't be better up than down.'' (he)

``He (Gridley) is very weak,'' (the trooper)
said the trooper in a low voice.

``Is he (Gridley)?'' (unknown)
returned Bucket anxiously.
``I only want to rouse him (Gridley). I don't like to see an old acquaintance giving in like this. It would cheer him (acquaintance) up more than anything if I could make him (acquaintance) a little waxy with me. He (acquaintance)'s welcome to drop into me, right and left, if he (acquaintance) likes. I shall never take advantage of it.'' (a scream)

The roof rang with a scream from Miss Flite, which still rings in my ears.

``Oh, no, Gridley!'' (she)
she (Bucket) cried as he (Mr.) fell heavily and calmly back from before her (Bucket).
``Not without my blessing. After so many years!'' (unknown)

The sun was down, the light had gradually stolen from the roof, and the shadow had crept upward. But to me the shadow of that pair, one living and one dead, fell heavier on Richard's departure than the darkness of the darkest night. And through Richard's farewell words I heard it echoed:

``Of all my old associations, of all my old pursuits and hopes, of all the living and the dead world, this one poor soul alone comes natural to me, and I am fit for. There is a tie of many suffering years between us two, and it is the only tie I ever had on earth that Chancery has not broken!'' (I)

CHAPTER XXV

Mrs. Snagsby Sees It All

There is disquietude in Cook's Court, Cursitor Street. Black suspicion hides in that peaceful region. The mass of Cook's Courtiers are in their usual state of mind, no better and no worse; but Mr. Snagsby is changed, and his (Snagsby) little woman knows it.

For Tom-all-Alone's and Lincoln's Inn Fields persist in harnessing themselves, a pair of ungovernable coursers, to the chariot of Mr. Snagsby's imagination; and Mr. Bucket drives; and the passengers are Jo and Mr. Tulkinghorn; and the complete equipage whirls though the law-stationery business at wild speed all round the clock. Even in the little front kitchen where the family meals are taken, it rattles away at a smoking pace from the dinner-table, when Mr. Snagsby pauses in carving the first slice of the leg of mutton baked with potatoes and stares at the kitchen wall.

Mr. Snagsby cannot make out what it is that he (Snagsby) has had to do with. Something is wrong somewhere, but what something, what may come of it, to whom, when, and from which unthought of and unheard of quarter is the puzzle of his (Snagsby) life. His (Snagsby) remote impressions of the robes and coronets, the stars and garters, that sparkle through the surface-dust of Mr. Tulkinghorn's chambers; his (Tulkinghorn) veneration for the mysteries presided over by that best and closest of his (Tulkinghorn) customers, whom all the Inns of Court, all Chancery Lane, and all the legal neighbourhood agree to hold in awe; his (Lane) remembrance of Detective Mr. Bucket with his (Lane) forefinger and his (Lane) confidential manner, impossible to be evaded or declined, persuade him (Lane) that he (Lane) is a party to some dangerous secret without knowing what it is. And it is the fearful peculiarity of this condition that, at any hour of his (Lane) daily life, at any opening of the shop-door, at any pull of the bell, at any entrance of a messenger, or any delivery of a letter, the secret may take air and fire, explode, and blow up--Mr. Bucket only knows whom.

For which reason, whenever a man unknown comes into the shop -LRB-as many men unknown do-RRB- and says,

``Is Mr. Snagsby in?'' (men)
or words to that innocent effect, Mr. Snagsby's heart knocks hard at his (Snagsby) guilty breast. He (Snagsby) undergoes so much from such inquiries that when they are made by boys he (Snagsby) revenges himself by flipping at their ears over the counter and asking the young dogs what they mean by it and why they can't speak out at once? More impracticable men and boys persist in walking into Mr. Snagsby's sleep and terrifying him (Snagsby) with unaccountable questions, so that often when the cock at the little dairy in Cursitor Street breaks out in his (Snagsby) usual absurd way about the morning, Mr. Snagsby finds himself in a crisis of nightmare, with his (Snagsby) little woman shaking him (Snagsby) and saying
``What's the matter with the man!'' (him)

The little woman herself is not the least item in his (Snagsby) difficulty. To know that he (Snagsby) is always keeping a secret from her (woman), that he (Snagsby) has under all circumstances to conceal and hold fast a tender double tooth, which her (woman) sharpness is ever ready to twist out of his (Snagsby) head, gives Mr. Snagsby, in her (woman) dentistical presence, much of the air of a dog who has a reservation from his (Snagsby) master and will look anywhere rather than meet his (Snagsby) eye.

These various signs and tokens, marked by the little woman, are not lost upon her (woman). They impel her (woman) to say,

``Snagsby has something on his (Snagsby) mind!'' (her)
And thus suspicion gets into Cook's Court, Cursitor Street. From suspicion to jealousy, Mrs. Snagsby finds the road as natural and short as from Cook's Court to Chancery Lane. And thus jealousy gets into Cook's Court, Cursitor Street. Once there -LRB-and it was always lurking thereabout-RRB-, it is very active and nimble in Mrs. Snagsby's breast, prompting her (Snagsby) to nocturnal examinations of Mr. Snagsby's pockets; to secret perusals of Mr. Snagsby's letters; to private researches in the day book and ledger, till, cash-box, and iron safe; to watchings at windows, listenings behind doors, and a general putting of this and that together by the wrong end.

Mrs. Snagsby is so perpetually on the alert that the house becomes ghostly with creaking boards and rustling garments. The `prentices think somebody may have been murdered there in bygone times. Guster holds certain loose atoms of an idea -LRB-picked up at Tooting, where they were found floating among the orphans-RRB- that there is buried money underneath the cellar, guarded by an old man with a white beard, who cannot get out for seven thousand years because he (man) said the Lord's Prayer backwards.

``Who was Nimrod?'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
Mrs. Snagsby repeatedly inquires of herself.
``Who was that lady--that creature? And who is that boy?'' (Nimrod)
Now, Nimrod being as dead as the mighty hunter whose name Mrs. Snagsby has appropriated, and the lady being unproducible, she (Snagsby) directs her (Snagsby) mental eye, for the present, with redoubled vigilance to the boy.
``And who,'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
quoth Mrs. Snagsby for the thousand and first time,
``is that boy? Who is that--!'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
And there Mrs. Snagsby is seized with an inspiration.

He (boy) has no respect for Mr. Chadband. No, to be sure, and he (Chadband) wouldn't have, of course. Naturally he (Chadband) wouldn't, under those contagious circumstances. He (Chadband) was invited and appointed by Mr. Chadband--why, Mrs. Snagsby heard it herself with her (Snagsby) own ears!--to come back, and be told where he (Chadband) was to go, to be addressed by Mr. Chadband; and he (Chadband) never came! Why did he (Chadband) never come? Because he (Chadband) was told not to come. Who told him (Chadband) not to come? Who? Ha, ha! Mrs. Snagsby sees it all.

But happily -LRB-and Mrs. Snagsby tightly shakes her (Snagsby) head and tightly smiles-RRB- that boy was met by Mr. Chadband yesterday in the streets; and that boy, as affording a subject which Mr. Chadband desires to improve for the spiritual delight of a select congregation, was seized by Mr. Chadband and threatened with being delivered over to the police unless he (Chadband) showed the reverend gentleman where he (Chadband) lived and unless he (Chadband) entered into, and fulfilled, an undertaking to appear in Cook's Court to-morrow night,

``to--mor--row--night,'' (Cook)
Mrs. Snagsby repeats for mere emphasis with another tight smile and another tight shake of her (Snagsby) head; and to-morrow night that boy will be here, and to-morrow night Mrs. Snagsby will have her (Snagsby) eye upon him (boy) and upon some one else; and oh, you may walk a long while in your secret ways -LRB-says Mrs. Snagsby with haughtiness and scorn-RRB-, but you can't blind ME!

Mrs. Snagsby sounds no timbrel in anybody's ears, but holds her (Snagsby) purpose quietly, and keeps her (Snagsby) counsel. To-morrow comes, the savoury preparations for the Oil Trade come, the evening comes. Comes Mr. Snagsby in his (Snagsby) black coat; come the Chadbands; come -LRB-when the gorging vessel is replete-RRB- the `prentices and Guster, to be edified; comes at last, with his (Snagsby) slouching head, and his (Snagsby) shuffle backward, and his (Snagsby) shuffle forward, and his (Snagsby) shuffle to the right, and his (Snagsby) shuffle to the left, and his (Snagsby) bit of fur cap in his (Snagsby) muddy hand, which he (Snagsby) picks as if it were some mangy bird he (Snagsby) had caught and was plucking before eating raw, Jo, the very, very tough subject Mr. Chadband is to improve.

Mrs. Snagsby screws a watchful glance on Jo as he (Chadband) is brought into the little drawing-room by Guster. He (Chadband) looks at Mr. Snagsby the moment he (Snagsby) comes in. Aha! Why does he (Snagsby) look at Mr. Snagsby? Mr. Snagsby looks at him (Snagsby). Why should he (Snagsby) do that, but that Mrs. Snagsby sees it all? Why else should that look pass between them, why else should Mr. Snagsby be confused and cough a signal cough behind his (Snagsby) hand? It is as clear as crystal that Mr. Snagsby is that boy's father.

``Peace, my friends,'' (reverend)
says Chadband, rising and wiping the oily exudations from his (Snagsby) reverend visage.
``Peace be with us! My friends, why with us? Because,'' (unknown)
with his (Snagsby) fat smile,
``it cannot be against us, because it must be for us; because it is not hardening, because it is softening; because it does not make war like the hawk, but comes home unto us like the dove. Therefore, my friends, peace be with us! My human boy, come forward!'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)

Stretching forth his (Snagsby) flabby paw, Mr. Chadband lays the same on Jo's arm and considers where to station him (Chadband). Jo, very doubtful of his (Chadband) reverend friend's intentions and not at all clear but that something practical and painful is going to be done to him (Chadband), mutters,

``You let me alone. I never said nothink to you. You let me alone.'' (him)

``No, my young friend,'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)
says Chadband smoothly,
``I will not let you alone. And why? Because I am a harvest-labourer, because I am a toiler and a moiler, because you are delivered over unto me and are become as a precious instrument in my hands. My friends, may I so employ this instrument as to use it to your advantage, to your profit, to your gain, to your welfare, to your enrichment! My young friend, sit upon this stool.'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)

Jo, apparently possessed by an impression that the reverend gentleman wants to cut his (gentleman) hair, shields his (gentleman) head with both arms and is got into the required position with great difficulty and every possible manifestation of reluctance.

When he (gentleman) is at last adjusted like a lay-figure, Mr. Chadband, retiring behind the table, holds up his (Chadband) bear's-paw and says,

``My friends!'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)
This is the signal for a general settlement of the audience. The `prentices giggle internally and nudge each other. Guster falls into a staring and vacant state, compounded of a stunned admiration of Mr. Chadband and pity for the friendless outcast whose condition touches her (Chadband) nearly. Mrs. Snagsby silently lays trains of gunpowder. Mrs. Chadband composes herself grimly by the fire and warms her (Chadband) knees, finding that sensation favourable to the reception of eloquence.

It happens that Mr. Chadband has a pulpit habit of fixing some member of his (Chadband) congregation with his (Chadband) eye and fatly arguing his (Chadband) points with that particular person, who is understood to be expected to be moved to an occasional grunt, groan, gasp, or other audible expression of inward working, which expression of inward working, being echoed by some elderly lady in the next pew and so communicated like a game of forfeits through a circle of the more fermentable sinners present, serves the purpose of parliamentary cheering and gets Mr. Chadband's steam up. From mere force of habit, Mr. Chadband in saying

``My friends!'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)
has rested his (Chadband) eye on Mr. Snagsby and proceeds to make that ill-starred stationer, already sufficiently confused, the immediate recipient of his (Chadband) discourse.

``We have here among us, my friends,'' (unknown)
says Chadband,
``a Gentile and a heathen, a dweller in the tents of Tom-all-Alone's and a mover-on upon the surface of the earth. We have here among us, my friends,'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)
and Mr. Chadband, untwisting the point with his (Chadband) dirty thumb-nail, bestows an oily smile on Mr. Snagsby, signifying that he (Snagsby) will throw him (Snagsby) an argumentative back-fall presently if he (Snagsby) be not already down,
``a brother and a boy. Devoid of parents, devoid of relations, devoid of flocks and herds, devoid of gold and silver and of precious stones. Now, my friends, why do I say he (boy) is devoid of these possessions? Why? Why is he (boy)?'' (he)
Mr. Chadband states the question as if he (Chadband) were propounding an entirely new riddle of much ingenuity and merit to Mr. Snagsby and entreating him (Snagsby) not to give it up.

Mr. Snagsby, greatly perplexed by the mysterious look he (Snagsby) received just now from his (Snagsby) little woman--at about the period when Mr. Chadband mentioned the word parents--is tempted into modestly remarking,

``I don't know, I'm sure, sir.'' (the word parents)
On which interruption Mrs. Chadband glares and Mrs. Snagsby says,
``For shame!'' (Mrs. Snagsby)

``I hear a voice,'' (unknown)
says Chadband;
``is it a still small voice, my friends? I fear not, though I fain would hope so--'' (unknown)

``Ah--h!'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
from Mrs. Snagsby.

``Which says, ``I don't know.

'' Then I will tell you why. I say this brother present here among us is devoid of parents, devoid of relations, devoid of flocks and herds, devoid of gold, of silver, and of precious stones because he (brother) is devoid of the light that shines in upon some of us. What is that light? What is it? I ask you, what is that light?'' (I)

Mr. Chadband draws back his (Chadband) head and pauses, but Mr. Snagsby is not to be lured on to his (Snagsby) destruction again. Mr. Chadband, leaning forward over the table, pierces what he (Chadband) has got to follow directly into Mr. Snagsby with the thumb-nail already mentioned.

``It is,'' (unknown)
says Chadband,
``the ray of rays, the sun of suns, the moon of moons, the star of stars. It is the light of Terewth.'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)

Mr. Chadband draws himself up again and looks triumphantly at Mr. Snagsby as if he (Chadband) would be glad to know how he (Chadband) feels after that.

``Of Terewth,'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)
says Mr. Chadband, hitting him (Chadband) again.
``Say not to me that it is NOT the lamp of lamps. I say to you it is. I say to you, a million of times over, it is. It is! I say to you that I will proclaim it to you, whether you like it or not; nay, that the less you like it, the more I will proclaim it to you. With a speaking-trumpet! I say to you that if you rear yourself against it, you shall fall, you shall be bruised, you shall be battered, you shall be flawed, you shall be smashed.'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)

The present effect of this flight of oratory--much admired for its general power by Mr. Chadband's followers--being not only to make Mr. Chadband unpleasantly warm, but to represent the innocent Mr. Snagsby in the light of a determined enemy to virtue, with a forehead of brass and a heart of adamant, that unfortunate tradesman becomes yet more disconcerted and is in a very advanced state of low spirits and false position when Mr. Chadband accidentally finishes him (Chadband).

``My friends,'' (he)
he (Chadband) resumes after dabbing his (Chadband) fat head for some time--and it smokes to such an extent that he (Chadband) seems to light his (Chadband) pocket-handkerchief at it, which smokes, too, after every dab--
``to pursue the subject we are endeavouring with our lowly gifts to improve, let us in a spirit of love inquire what is that Terewth to which I have alluded. For, my young friends,'' (he)
suddenly addressing the `prentices and Guster, to their consternation,
``if I am told by the doctor that calomel or castor-oil is good for me, I may naturally ask what is calomel, and what is castor-oil. I may wish to be informed of that before I dose myself with either or with both. Now, my young friends, what is this Terewth then? Firstly -LRB-in a spirit of love-RRB-, what is the common sort of Terewth--the working clothes--the every-day wear, my young friends? Is it deception?'' (Guster)

``Ah--h!'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
from Mrs. Snagsby.

``Is it suppression?'' (Mrs. Snagsby)

A shiver in the negative from Mrs. Snagsby.

``Is it reservation?'' (Mrs. Snagsby)

A shake of the head from Mrs. Snagsby--very long and very tight.

``No, my friends, it is neither of these. Neither of these names belongs to it. When this young heathen now among us--who is now, my friends, asleep, the seal of indifference and perdition being set upon his (it) eyelids; but do not wake him (it), for it is right that I should have to wrestle, and to combat and to struggle, and to conquer, for his (it) sake--when this young hardened heathen told us a story of a cock, and of a bull, and of a lady, and of a sovereign, was THAT the Terewth? No. Or if it was partly, was it wholly and entirely? No, my friends, no!'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

If Mr. Snagsby could withstand his (Snagsby) little woman's look as it enters at his (Snagsby) eyes, the windows of his (Snagsby) soul, and searches the whole tenement, he (Snagsby) were other than the man he (Snagsby) is. He (Snagsby) cowers and droops.

``Or, my juvenile friends,'' (meek)
says Chadband, descending to the level of their comprehension with a very obtrusive demonstration in his (Snagsby) greasily meek smile of coming a long way downstairs for the purpose, ``if the master of this house was to go forth into the city and there see an eel, and was to come back, and was to call unto him (master) the mistress of this house, and was to say, ``Sarah, rejoice with me, for I have seen an elephant!
'' would THAT be Terewth?'' (I)

Mrs. Snagsby in tears.

``Or put it, my juvenile friends, that he (master) saw an elephant, and returning said ``Lo, the city is barren, I have seen but an eel,

'' would THAT be Terewth?'' (I)

Mrs. Snagsby sobbing loudly.

``Or put it, my juvenile friends,'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
said Chadband, stimulated by the sound,
``that the unnatural parents of this slumbering heathen--for parents he (master) had, my juvenile friends, beyond a doubt--after casting him (master) forth to the wolves and the vultures, and the wild dogs and the young gazelles, and the serpents, went back to their dwellings and had their pipes, and their pots, and their flutings and their dancings, and their malt liquors, and their butcher's meat and poultry, would THAT be Terewth?'' (Mrs. Snagsby)

Mrs. Snagsby replies by delivering herself a prey to spasms, not an unresisting prey, but a crying and a tearing one, so that Cook's Court re-echoes with her (Snagsby) shrieks. Finally, becoming cataleptic, she (Snagsby) has to be carried up the narrow staircase like a grand piano. After unspeakable suffering, productive of the utmost consternation, she (Snagsby) is pronounced, by expresses from the bedroom, free from pain, though much exhausted, in which state of affairs Mr. Snagsby, trampled and crushed in the piano-forte removal, and extremely timid and feeble, ventures to come out from behind the door in the drawing-room.

All this time Jo has been standing on the spot where he (Snagsby) woke up, ever picking his (Snagsby) cap and putting bits of fur in his (Snagsby) mouth. He (Snagsby) spits them out with a remorseful air, for he (Snagsby) feels that it is in his (Snagsby) nature to be an unimprovable reprobate and that it's no good HIS (Snagsby) trying to keep awake, for HE (Snagsby) won't never know nothink. Though it may be, Jo, that there is a history so interesting and affecting even to minds as near the brutes as thine, recording deeds done on this earth for common men, that if the Chadbands, removing their own persons from the light, would but show it thee in simple reverence, would but leave it unimproved, would but regard it as being eloquent enough without their modest aid--it might hold thee awake, and thou might learn from it yet!

Jo never heard of any such book. Its compilers and the Reverend Chadband are all one to him (Chadband), except that he (Chadband) knows the Reverend Chadband and would rather run away from him (Chadband) for an hour than hear him (Chadband) talk for five minutes.

``It an't no good my waiting here no longer,'' (Jo)
thinks Jo.
``Mr. Snagsby an't a-going to say nothink to me to-night.'' (he)
And downstairs he (Chadband) shuffles.

But downstairs is the charitable Guster, holding by the handrail of the kitchen stairs and warding off a fit, as yet doubtfully, the same having been induced by Mrs. Snagsby's screaming. She (Snagsby) has her (Snagsby) own supper of bread and cheese to hand to Jo, with whom she (Jo) ventures to interchange a word or so for the first time.

``Here's something to eat, poor boy,'' (Guster)
says Guster.

``Thank`ee, mum,'' (Jo)
says Jo.

``Are you hungry?'' (unknown)

``Jist!'' (Jo)
says Jo.

``What's gone of your father and your mother, eh?'' (Jo)

Jo stops in the middle of a bite and looks petrified. For this orphan charge of the Christian saint whose shrine was at Tooting has patted him (Christian) on the shoulder, and it is the first time in his (Christian) life that any decent hand has been so laid upon him (Christian).

``I never know'd nothink about 'em,'' (Jo)
says Jo.

``No more didn't I of mine,'' (Guster)
cries Guster. She (Jo) is repressing symptoms favourable to the fit when she (Jo) seems to take alarm at something and vanishes down the stairs.

``Jo,'' (the boy)
whispers the law-stationer softly as the boy lingers on the step.

``Here I am, Mr. Snagsby!'' (unknown)

``I didn't know you were gone--there's another half-crown, Jo. It was quite right of you to say nothing about the lady the other night when we were out together. It would breed trouble. You can't be too quiet, Jo.'' (unknown)

``I am fly, master!'' (unknown)

And so, good night.

A ghostly shade, frilled and night-capped, follows the law-stationer to the room he (boy) came from and glides higher up. And henceforth he (boy) begins, go where he (boy) will, to be attended by another shadow than his (boy) own, hardly less constant than his (boy) own, hardly less quiet than his (boy) own. And into whatsoever atmosphere of secrecy his (boy) own shadow may pass, let all concerned in the secrecy beware! For the watchful Mrs. Snagsby is there too--bone of his (boy) bone, flesh of his (boy) flesh, shadow of his (boy) shadow.

CHAPTER XXVI

Sharpshooters

Wintry morning, looking with dull eyes and sallow face upon the neighbourhood of Leicester Square, finds its inhabitants unwilling to get out of bed. Many of them are not early risers at the brightest of times, being birds of night who roost when the sun is high and are wide awake and keen for prey when the stars shine out. Behind dingy blind and curtain, in upper story and garret, skulking more or less under false names, false hair, false titles, false jewellery, and false histories, a colony of brigands lie in their first sleep. Gentlemen of the green-baize road who could discourse from personal experience of foreign galleys and home treadmills; spies of strong governments that eternally quake with weakness and miserable fear, broken traitors, cowards, bullies, gamesters, shufflers, swindlers, and false witnesses; some not unmarked by the branding-iron beneath their dirty braid; all with more cruelty in them than was in Nero, and more crime than is in Newgate. For howsoever bad the devil can be in fustian or smock-frock -LRB-and he (devil) can be very bad in both-RRB-, he (devil) is a more designing, callous, and intolerable devil when he (devil) sticks a pin in his (devil) shirt-front, calls himself a gentleman, backs a card or colour, plays a game or so of billiards, and knows a little about bills and promissory notes than in any other form he (devil) wears. And in such form Mr. Bucket shall find him (Mr.), when he (Mr.) will, still pervading the tributary channels of Leicester Square.

But the wintry morning wants him (Mr.) not and wakes him (Mr.) not. It wakes Mr. George of the shooting gallery and his (George) familiar. They arise, roll up and stow away their mattresses. Mr. George, having shaved himself before a looking-glass of minute proportions, then marches out, bare-headed and bare-chested, to the pump in the little yard and anon comes back shining with yellow soap, friction, drifting rain, and exceedingly cold water. As he (George) rubs himself upon a large jack-towel, blowing like a military sort of diver just come up, his (diver) hair curling tighter and tighter on his (diver) sunburnt temples the more he (diver) rubs it so that it looks as if it never could be loosened by any less coercive instrument than an iron rake or a curry-comb--as he (diver) rubs, and puffs, and polishes, and blows, turning his (diver) head from side to side the more conveniently to excoriate his (diver) throat, and standing with his (diver) body well bent forward to keep the wet from his (diver) martial legs, Phil, on his (diver) knees lighting a fire, looks round as if it were enough washing for him (diver) to see all that done, and sufficient renovation for one day to take in the superfluous health his (diver) master throws off.

When Mr. George is dry, he (George) goes to work to brush his (George) head with two hard brushes at once, to that unmerciful degree that Phil, shouldering his (Phil) way round the gallery in the act of sweeping it, winks with sympathy. This chafing over, the ornamental part of Mr. George's toilet is soon performed. He (George) fills his (George) pipe, lights it, and marches up and down smoking, as his (George) custom is, while Phil, raising a powerful odour of hot rolls and coffee, prepares breakfast. He (Phil) smokes gravely and marches in slow time. Perhaps this morning's pipe is devoted to the memory of Gridley in his (Gridley) grave.

``And so, Phil,'' (Mr. George/George)
says George of the shooting gallery after several turns in silence,
``you were dreaming of the country last night?'' (Mr. George/George)

Phil, by the by, said as much in a tone of surprise as he (Phil) scrambled out of bed.

``Yes, guv`ner.'' (unknown)

``What was it like?'' (unknown)

``I hardly know what it was like, guv`ner,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
said Phil, considering.

``How did you know it was the country?'' (unknown)

``On account of the grass, I think. And the swans upon it,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
says Phil after further consideration.

``What were the swans doing on the grass?'' (unknown)

``They was a-eating of it, I expect,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
says Phil.

The master resumes his (Phil) march, and the man resumes his (Phil) preparation of breakfast. It is not necessarily a lengthened preparation, being limited to the setting forth of very simple breakfast requisites for two and the broiling of a rasher of bacon at the fire in the rusty grate; but as Phil has to sidle round a considerable part of the gallery for every object he (Phil) wants, and never brings two objects at once, it takes time under the circumstances. At length the breakfast is ready. Phil announcing it, Mr. George knocks the ashes out of his (Phil) pipe on the hob, stands his (Phil) pipe itself in the chimney corner, and sits down to the meal. When he (Phil) has helped himself, Phil follows suit, sitting at the extreme end of the little oblong table and taking his (Phil) plate on his (Phil) knees. Either in humility, or to hide his (Phil) blackened hands, or because it is his (Phil) natural manner of eating.

``The country,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George, plying his (George) knife and fork;
``why, I suppose you never clapped your eyes on the country, Phil?'' (Mr. George/George)

``I see the marshes once,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
says Phil, contentedly eating his (Phil) breakfast.

``What marshes?'' (unknown)

``THE marshes, commander,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
returns Phil.

``Where are they?'' (unknown)

``I don't know where they are,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
says Phil;
``but I see 'em, guv`ner. They was flat. And miste.'' (Phil/Phil Squod)

Governor and commander are interchangeable terms with Phil, expressive of the same respect and deference and applicable to nobody but Mr. George.

``I was born in the country, Phil.'' (unknown)

``Was you indeed, commander?'' (unknown)

``Yes. And bred there.'' (Phil/Phil Squod)

Phil elevates his (Phil) one eyebrow, and after respectfully staring at his (Phil) master to express interest, swallows a great gulp of coffee, still staring at him (Phil).

``There's not a bird's note that I don't know,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George.
``Not many an English leaf or berry that I couldn't name. Not many a tree that I couldn't climb yet if I was put to it. I was a real country boy, once. My good mother lived in the country.'' (unknown)

``She (mother) must have been a fine old lady, guv`ner,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
Phil observes.

``Aye! And not so old either, five and thirty years ago,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George.
``But I'll wager that at ninety she (mother) would be near as upright as me, and near as broad across the shoulders.'' (unknown)

``Did she (mother) die at ninety, guv`ner?'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
inquires Phil.

``No. Bosh! Let her (mother) rest in peace, God bless her (mother)!'' (the trooper)
says the trooper.
``What set me on about country boys, and runaways, and good-for-nothings? You, to be sure! So you never clapped your eyes upon the country--marshes and dreams excepted. Eh?'' (Phil/Phil Squod)

Phil shakes his (Phil) head.

``Do you want to see it?'' (unknown)

``N-no, I don't know as I do, particular,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
says Phil.

``The town's enough for you, eh?'' (unknown)

``Why, you see, commander,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
says Phil,
``I ain't acquainted with anythink else, and I doubt if I ain't a-getting too old to take to novelties.'' (Phil/Phil Squod)

``How old ARE you, Phil?'' (the trooper)
asks the trooper, pausing as he (Phil) conveys his (Phil) smoking saucer to his (Phil) lips.

``I'm something with a eight in it,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
says Phil.
``It can't be eighty. Nor yet eighteen. It's betwixt 'em, somewheres.'' (Mr. George/George)

Mr. George, slowly putting down his (Phil) saucer without tasting its contents, is laughingly beginning,

``Why, what the deuce, Phil--'' (Mr. George/George)
when he (Phil) stops, seeing that Phil is counting on his (Phil) dirty fingers.

``I was just eight,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
says Phil, ``agreeable to the parish calculation, when I went with the tinker. I was sent on a errand, and I see him (Phil) a-sittin under a old buildin with a fire all to himself wery comfortable, and he (Phil) says, ``Would you like to come along a me, my man?'' I says ``Yes,'' and him (Phil) and me and the fire goes home to Clerkenwell together. That was April Fool Day. I was able to count up to ten; and when April Fool Day come round again, I says to myself, ``Now, old chap, you're one and a eight in it.'' April Fool Day after that, I says, ``Now, old chap, you're two and a eight in it.
'' In course of time, I come to ten and a eight in it; two tens and a eight in it. When it got so high, it got the upper hand of me, but this is how I always know there's a eight in it.'' (chap)

``Ah!'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George, resuming his (George) breakfast.
``And where's the tinker?'' (unknown)

``Drink put him (chap) in the hospital, guv`ner, and the hospital put him (guv)--in a glass-case, I HAVE heerd,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
Phil replies mysteriously.

``By that means you got promotion? Took the business, Phil?'' (unknown)

``Yes, commander, I took the business. Such as it was. It wasn't much of a beat--round Saffron Hill, Hatton Garden, Clerkenwell, Smiffeld, and there--poor neighbourhood, where they uses up the kettles till they're past mending. Most of the tramping tinkers used to come and lodge at our place; that was the best part of my master's earnings. But they didn't come to me. I warn't like him (master). He (master) could sing 'em a good song. I couldn't! He (master) could play 'em a tune on any sort of pot you please, so as it was iron or block tin. I never could do nothing with a pot but mend it or bile it--never had a note of music in me. Besides, I was too ill-looking, and their wives complained of me.'' (unknown)

``They were mighty particular. You would pass muster in a crowd, Phil!'' (the trooper)
says the trooper with a pleasant smile.

``No, guv`ner,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
returns Phil, shaking his (Phil) head.
``No, I shouldn't. I was passable enough when I went with the tinker, though nothing to boast of then; but what with blowing the fire with my mouth when I was young, and spileing my complexion, and singeing my hair off, and swallering the smoke, and what with being nat`rally unfort`nate in the way of running against hot metal and marking myself by sich means, and what with having turn-ups with the tinker as I got older, almost whenever he (guv) was too far gone in drink--which was almost always--my beauty was queer, wery queer, even at that time. As to since, what with a dozen years in a dark forge where the men was given to larking, and what with being scorched in a accident at a gas-works, and what with being blowed out of winder case-filling at the firework business, I am ugly enough to be made a show on!'' (Phil/Phil Squod)

Resigning himself to which condition with a perfectly satisfied manner, Phil begs the favour of another cup of coffee. While drinking it, he (Phil) says,

``It was after the case-filling blow-up when I first see you, commander. You remember?'' (he)

``I remember, Phil. You were walking along in the sun.'' (unknown)

``Crawling, guv`ner, again a wall--'' (unknown)

``True, Phil--shouldering your way on--'' (unknown)

``In a night-cap!'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
exclaims Phil, excited.

``In a night-cap--'' (unknown)

``And hobbling with a couple of sticks!'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
cries Phil, still more excited.

``With a couple of sticks. When--'' (Phil/Phil Squod)

``When you stops, you know,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
cries Phil, putting down his (Phil) cup and saucer and hastily removing his (Phil) plate from his (Phil) knees, ``and says to me, ``What, comrade! You have been in the wars!'' I didn't say much to you, commander, then, for I was took by surprise that a person so strong and healthy and bold as you was should stop to speak to such a limping bag of bones as I was. But you says to me, says you, delivering it out of your chest as hearty as possible, so that it was like a glass of something hot, ``What accident have you met with? You have been badly hurt. What's amiss, old boy? Cheer up, and tell us about it!
'' Cheer up! I was cheered already! I says as much to you, you says more to me, I says more to you, you says more to me, and here I am, commander! Here I am, commander!'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
cries Phil, who has started from his (Phil) chair and unaccountably begun to sidle away. ``If a mark's wanted, or if it will improve the business, let the customers take aim at me. They can't spoil MY beauty. I
``M all right. Come on! If they want a man to box at, let 'em box at me. Let 'em knock me well about the head. I don't mind. If they want a light-weight to be throwed for practice, Cornwall, Devonshire, or Lancashire, let 'em throw me. They won't hurt ME. I have been throwed, all sorts of styles, all my life!'' (Phil/Phil Squod)

With this unexpected speech, energetically delivered and accompanied by action illustrative of the various exercises referred to, Phil Squod shoulders his (Squod) way round three sides of the gallery, and abruptly tacking off at his (Squod) commander, makes a butt at him (Squod) with his (Squod) head, intended to express devotion to his (Squod) service. He (Squod) then begins to clear away the breakfast.

Mr. George, after laughing cheerfully and clapping him (George) on the shoulder, assists in these arrangements and helps to get the gallery into business order. That done, he (George) takes a turn at the dumb-bells, and afterwards weighing himself and opining that he (George) is getting

``too fleshy,'' (he)
engages with great gravity in solitary broadsword practice. Meanwhile Phil has fallen to work at his (Phil) usual table, where he (Phil) screws and unscrews, and cleans, and files, and whistles into small apertures, and blackens himself more and more, and seems to do and undo everything that can be done and undone about a gun.

Master and man are at length disturbed by footsteps in the passage, where they make an unusual sound, denoting the arrival of unusual company. These steps, advancing nearer and nearer to the gallery, bring into it a group at first sight scarcely reconcilable with any day in the year but the fifth of November.

It consists of a limp and ugly figure carried in a chair by two bearers and attended by a lean female with a face like a pinched mask, who might be expected immediately to recite the popular verses commemorative of the time when they did contrive to blow Old England up alive but for her (female) keeping her (female) lips tightly and defiantly closed as the chair is put down. At which point the figure in it gasping,

``O Lord! Oh, dear me! I am shaken!'' (unknown)
adds,
``How de do, my dear friend, how de do?'' (Mr. George/George)
Mr. George then descries, in the procession, the venerable Mr. Smallweed out for an airing, attended by his (Smallweed) granddaughter Judy as body-guard.

``Mr. George, my dear friend,'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
says Grandfather Smallweed, removing his (Smallweed) right arm from the neck of one of his (Smallweed) bearers, whom he (Smallweed) has nearly throttled coming along,
``how de do? You're surprised to see me, my dear friend.'' (he)

``I should hardly have been more surprised to have seen your friend in the city,'' (Mr. George/George)
returns Mr. George.

``I am very seldom out,'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
pants Mr. Smallweed.
``I haven't been out for many months. It's inconvenient--and it comes expensive. But I longed so much to see you, my dear Mr. George. How de do, sir?'' (unknown)

``I am well enough,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George.
``I hope you are the same.'' (unknown)

``You can't be too well, my dear friend.'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
Mr. Smallweed takes him (Smallweed) by both hands.
``I have brought my granddaughter Judy. I couldn't keep her (Judy) away. She (Judy) longed so much to see you.'' (unknown)

``Hum! She (Judy) bears it calmly!'' (Mr. George/George)
mutters Mr. George.

``So we got a hackney-cab, and put a chair in it, and just round the corner they lifted me out of the cab and into the chair, and carried me here that I might see my dear friend in his (friend) own establishment! This,'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
says Grandfather Smallweed, alluding to the bearer, who has been in danger of strangulation and who withdraws adjusting his (Smallweed) windpipe,
``is the driver of the cab. He (friend) has nothing extra. It is by agreement included in his (friend) fare. This person,'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
the other bearer,
``we engaged in the street outside for a pint of beer. Which is twopence. Judy, give the person twopence. I was not sure you had a workman of your own here, my dear friend, or we needn't have employed this person.'' (Grandfather)

Grandfather Smallweed refers to Phil with a glance of considerable terror and a half-subdued

``O Lord! Oh, dear me!'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
Nor in his (Phil) apprehension, on the surface of things, without some reason, for Phil, who has never beheld the apparition in the black-velvet cap before, has stopped short with a gun in his (Phil) hand with much of the air of a dead shot intent on picking Mr. Smallweed off as an ugly old bird of the crow species.

``Judy, my child,'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
says Grandfather Smallweed,
``give the person his (Lord) twopence. It's a great deal for what he (Lord) has done.'' (Grandfather Smallweed)

The person, who is one of those extraordinary specimens of human fungus that spring up spontaneously in the western streets of London, ready dressed in an old red jacket, with a

``mission'' (The person)
for holding horses and calling coaches, received his (Smallweed) twopence with anything but transport, tosses the money into the air, catches it over-handed, and retires.

``My dear Mr. George,'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
says Grandfather Smallweed,
``would you be so kind as help to carry me to the fire? I am accustomed to a fire, and I am an old man, and I soon chill. Oh, dear me!'' (Grandfather Smallweed)

His (Smallweed) closing exclamation is jerked out of the venerable gentleman by the suddenness with which Mr. Squod, like a genie, catches him (Squod) up, chair and all, and deposits him (Squod) on the hearth-stone.

``O Lord!'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
says Mr. Smallweed, panting.
``Oh, dear me! Oh, my stars! My dear friend, your workman is very strong--and very prompt. O Lord, he (Lord) is very prompt! Judy, draw me back a little. I'm being scorched in the legs,'' (unknown)
which indeed is testified to the noses of all present by the smell of his (Smallweed) worsted stockings.

The gentle Judy, having backed her (Judy) grandfather a little way from the fire, and having shaken him (grandfather) up as usual, and having released his (grandfather) overshadowed eye from its black-velvet extinguisher, Mr. Smallweed again says,

``Oh, dear me! O Lord!'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
and looking about and meeting Mr. George's glance, again stretches out both hands.

``My dear friend! So happy in this meeting! And this is your establishment? It's a delightful place. It's a picture! You never find that anything goes off here accidentally, do you, my dear friend?'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
adds Grandfather Smallweed, very ill at ease.

``No, no. No fear of that.'' (unknown)

``And your workman. He (workman)--Oh, dear me!--he (workman) never lets anything off without meaning it, does he (workman), my dear friend?'' (unknown)

``He (workman) has never hurt anybody but himself,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George, smiling.

``But he (workman) might, you know. He (workman) seems to have hurt himself a good deal, and he (workman) might hurt somebody else,'' (gentleman)
the old gentleman returns.
``He (workman) mightn't mean it--or he (workman) even might. Mr. George, will you order him (George) to leave his (George) infernal fire-arms alone and go away?'' (the trooper)

Obedient to a nod from the trooper, Phil retires, empty-handed, to the other end of the gallery. Mr. Smallweed, reassured, falls to rubbing his (Smallweed) legs.

``And you're doing well, Mr. George?'' (he)
he (Smallweed) says to the trooper, squarely standing faced about towards him (Smallweed) with his (Smallweed) broadsword in his (Smallweed) hand.
``You are prospering, please the Powers?'' (Mr. George/George)

Mr. George answers with a cool nod, adding,

``Go on. You have not come to say that, I know.'' (Mr. George/George)

``You are so sprightly, Mr. George,'' (the grandfather)
returns the venerable grandfather.
``You are such good company.'' (unknown)

``Ha ha! Go on!'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George.

``My dear friend! But that sword looks awful gleaming and sharp. It might cut somebody, by accident. It makes me shiver, Mr. George. Curse him (George)!'' (the gentleman)
says the excellent old gentleman apart to Judy as the trooper takes a step or two away to lay it aside.
``He (George) owes me money, and might think of paying off old scores in this murdering place. I wish your brimstone grandmother was here, and he (George)'d shave her (grandmother) head off.'' (Mr. George/George)

Mr. George, returning, folds his (George) arms, and looking down at the old man, sliding every moment lower and lower in his (George) chair, says quietly,

``Now for it!'' (the man)

``Ho!'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
cries Mr. Smallweed, rubbing his (Smallweed) hands with an artful chuckle.
``Yes. Now for it. Now for what, my dear friend?'' (unknown)

``For a pipe,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George, who with great composure sets his (George) chair in the chimney-corner, takes his (George) pipe from the grate, fills it and lights it, and falls to smoking peacefully.

This tends to the discomfiture of Mr. Smallweed, who finds it so difficult to resume his (Smallweed) object, whatever it may be, that he (Smallweed) becomes exasperated and secretly claws the air with an impotent vindictiveness expressive of an intense desire to tear and rend the visage of Mr. George. As the excellent old gentleman's nails are long and leaden, and his (George) hands lean and veinous, and his (George) eyes green and watery; and, over and above this, as he (George) continues, while he (George) claws, to slide down in his (George) chair and to collapse into a shapeless bundle, he (George) becomes such a ghastly spectacle, even in the accustomed eyes of Judy, that that young virgin pounces at him (George) with something more than the ardour of affection and so shakes him (George) up and pats and pokes him (George) in divers parts of his (George) body, but particularly in that part which the science of self-defence would call his (George) wind, that in his (George) grievous distress he (George) utters enforced sounds like a paviour's rammer.

When Judy has by these means set him (George) up again in his (George) chair, with a white face and a frosty nose -LRB-but still clawing-RRB-, she (Judy) stretches out her (Judy) weazen forefinger and gives Mr. George one poke in the back. The trooper raising his (trooper) head, she (Judy) makes another poke at her (Judy) esteemed grandfather, and having thus brought them together, stares rigidly at the fire.

``Aye, aye! Ho, ho! U--u--u--ugh!'' (chatters)
chatters Grandfather Smallweed, swallowing his (Smallweed) rage.
``My dear friend!'' (unknown)
-LRB-still clawing-RRB-.

``I tell you what,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George.
``If you want to converse with me, you must speak out. I am one of the roughs, and I can't go about and about. I haven't the art to do it. I am not clever enough. It don't suit me. When you go winding round and round me,'' (the trooper)
says the trooper, putting his (George) pipe between his (George) lips again,
``damme, if I don't feel as if I was being smothered!'' (the trooper)

And he (George) inflates his (George) broad chest to its utmost extent as if to assure himself that he (George) is not smothered yet.

``If you have come to give me a friendly call,'' (Mr. George/George)
continues Mr. George,
``I am obliged to you; how are you? If you have come to see whether there's any property on the premises, look about you; you are welcome. If you want to out with something, out with it!'' (Mr. George/George)

The blooming Judy, without removing her (Judy) gaze from the fire, gives her (Judy) grandfather one ghostly poke.

``You see! It's her (you) opinion too. And why the devil that young woman won't sit down like a Christian,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George with his (George) eyes musingly fixed on Judy,
``I can't comprehend.'' (Judy)

``She (woman) keeps at my side to attend to me, sir,'' (Grandfather)
says Grandfather Smallweed.
``I am an old man, my dear Mr. George, and I need some attention. I can carry my years; I am not a brimstone poll-parrot'' (unknown)
-LRB-snarling and looking unconsciously for the cushion-RRB-,
``but I need attention, my dear friend.'' (unknown)

``Well!'' (the trooper chair)
returns the trooper, wheeling his (trooper) chair to face the old man.
``Now then?'' (unknown)

``My friend in the city, Mr. George, has done a little business with a pupil of yours.'' (unknown)

``Has he (George)?'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George.
``I am sorry to hear it.'' (unknown)

``Yes, sir.'' (Grandfather)
Grandfather Smallweed rubs his (George) legs.
``He (George) is a fine young soldier now, Mr. George, by the name of Carstone. Friends came forward and paid it all up, honourable.'' (unknown)

``Did they?'' (Mr. George/George)
returns Mr. George.
``Do you think your friend in the city would like a piece of advice?'' (unknown)

``I think he (friend) would, my dear friend. From you.'' (unknown)

``I advise him (friend), then, to do no more business in that quarter. There's no more to be got by it. The young gentleman, to my knowledge, is brought to a dead halt.'' (unknown)

``No, no, my dear friend. No, no, Mr. George. No, no, no, sir,'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
remonstrates Grandfather Smallweed, cunningly rubbing his (Smallweed) spare legs.
``Not quite a dead halt, I think. He (George) has good friends, and he (George) is good for his (George) pay, and he (George) is good for the selling price of his (George) commission, and he (George) is good for his (George) chance in a lawsuit, and he (George) is good for his (George) chance in a wife, and--oh, do you know, Mr. George, I think my friend would consider the young gentleman good for something yet?'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
says Grandfather Smallweed, turning up his (Smallweed) velvet cap and scratching his (Smallweed) ear like a monkey.

Mr. George, who has put aside his (George) pipe and sits with an arm on his (George) chair-back, beats a tattoo on the ground with his (George) right foot as if he (George) were not particularly pleased with the turn the conversation has taken.

``But to pass from one subject to another,'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
resumes Mr. Smallweed.
''`To promote the conversation,'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
as a joker might say. To pass, Mr. George, from the ensign to the captain.''

``What are you up to, now?'' (Mr. George/George)
asks Mr. George, pausing with a frown in stroking the recollection of his (George) moustache.
``What captain?'' (unknown)

``Our captain. The captain we know of. Captain Hawdon.'' (unknown)

``Oh! That's it, is it?'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George with a low whistle as he (George) sees both grandfather and granddaughter looking hard at him (George).
``You are there! Well? What about it? Come, I won't be smothered any more. Speak!'' (unknown)

``My dear friend,'' (the man)
returns the old man,
``I was applied--Judy, shake me up a little!--I was applied to yesterday about the captain, and my opinion still is that the captain is not dead.'' (the man)

``Bosh!'' (Mr. George/George)
observes Mr. George.

``What was your remark, my dear friend?'' (the man)
inquires the old man with his (George) hand to his (George) ear.

``Bosh!'' (unknown)

``Ho!'' (Grandfather)
says Grandfather Smallweed.
``Mr. George, of my opinion you can judge for yourself according to the questions asked of me and the reasons given for asking 'em. Now, what do you think the lawyer making the inquiries wants?'' (unknown)

``A job,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George.

``Nothing of the kind!'' (unknown)

``Can't be a lawyer, then,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George, folding his (George) arms with an air of confirmed resolution.

``My dear friend, he (friend) is a lawyer, and a famous one. He (friend) wants to see some fragment in Captain Hawdon's writing. He (Captain) don't want to keep it. He (Captain) only wants to see it and compare it with a writing in his (Captain) possession.'' (unknown)

``Well?'' (unknown)

``Well, Mr. George. Happening to remember the advertisement concerning Captain Hawdon and any information that could be given respecting him (Captain), he (Captain) looked it up and came to me--just as you did, my dear friend. WILL you shake hands? So glad you came that day! I should have missed forming such a friendship if you hadn't come!'' (unknown)

``Well, Mr. Smallweed?'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George again after going through the ceremony with some stiffness.

``I had no such thing. I have nothing but his (Smallweed) signature. Plague pestilence and famine, battle murder and sudden death upon him (Smallweed),'' (the man)
says the old man, making a curse out of one of his (George) few remembrances of a prayer and squeezing up his (George) velvet cap between his (George) angry hands,
``I have half a million of his (Smallweed) signatures, I think! But you,'' (the man)
breathlessly recovering his (George) mildness of speech as Judy re-adjusts the cap on his (George) skittle-ball of a head,
``you, my dear Mr. George, are likely to have some letter or paper that would suit the purpose. Anything would suit the purpose, written in the hand.'' (Judy)

``Some writing in that hand,'' (the trooper)
says the trooper, pondering;
``may be, I have.'' (the trooper)

``My dearest friend!'' (unknown)

``May be, I have not.'' (unknown)

``Ho!'' (Grandfather)
says Grandfather Smallweed, crest-fallen.

``But if I had bushels of it, I would not show as much as would make a cartridge without knowing why.'' (unknown)

``Sir, I have told you why. My dear Mr. George, I have told you why.'' (unknown)

``Not enough,'' (the trooper)
says the trooper, shaking his (trooper) head.
``I must know more, and approve it.'' (unknown)

``Then, will you come to the lawyer? My dear friend, will you come and see the gentleman?'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
urges Grandfather Smallweed, pulling out a lean old silver watch with hands like the leg of a skeleton.
``I told him (friend) it was probable I might call upon him (friend) between ten and eleven this forenoon, and it's now half after ten. Will you come and see the gentleman, Mr. George?'' (unknown)

``Hum!'' (he)
says he (Smallweed) gravely.
``I don't mind that. Though why this should concern you so much, I don't know.'' (unknown)

``Everything concerns me that has a chance in it of bringing anything to light about him (George). Didn't he (George) take us all in? Didn't he (George) owe us immense sums, all round? Concern me? Who can anything about him (George) concern more than me? Not, my dear friend,'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
says Grandfather Smallweed, lowering his (Smallweed) tone,
``that I want YOU to betray anything. Far from it. Are you ready to come, my dear friend?'' (Grandfather Smallweed)

``Aye! I'll come in a moment. I promise nothing, you know.'' (unknown)

``No, my dear Mr. George; no.'' (unknown)

``And you mean to say you're going to give me a lift to this place, wherever it is, without charging for it?'' (Mr. George/George)
Mr. George inquires, getting his (George) hat and thick wash-leather gloves.

This pleasantry so tickles Mr. Smallweed that he (Smallweed) laughs, long and low, before the fire. But ever while he (Smallweed) laughs, he (Smallweed) glances over his (Smallweed) paralytic shoulder at Mr. George and eagerly watches him (George) as he (George) unlocks the padlock of a homely cupboard at the distant end of the gallery, looks here and there upon the higher shelves, and ultimately takes something out with a rustling of paper, folds it, and puts it in his (George) breast. Then Judy pokes Mr. Smallweed once, and Mr. Smallweed pokes Judy once.

``I am ready,'' (the trooper)
says the trooper, coming back.
``Phil, you can carry this old gentleman to his (Phil) coach, and make nothing of him (Phil).'' (unknown)

``Oh, dear me! O Lord! Stop a moment!'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
says Mr. Smallweed.
``He (Lord)'s so very prompt! Are you sure you can do it carefully, my worthy man?'' (Phil/Phil Squod)

Phil makes no reply, but seizing the chair and its load, sidles away, tightly hugged by the now speechless Mr. Smallweed, and bolts along the passage as if he (Smallweed) had an acceptable commission to carry the old gentleman to the nearest volcano. His (Smallweed) shorter trust, however, terminating at the cab, he (Smallweed) deposits him (Smallweed) there; and the fair Judy takes her (Judy) place beside him (Smallweed), and the chair embellishes the roof, and Mr. George takes the vacant place upon the box.

Mr. George is quite confounded by the spectacle he (George) beholds from time to time as he (George) peeps into the cab through the window behind him (George), where the grim Judy is always motionless, and the old gentleman with his (gentleman) cap over one eye is always sliding off the seat into the straw and looking upward at him (gentleman) out of his (gentleman) other eye with a helpless expression of being jolted in the back.

CHAPTER XXVII

More Old Soldiers Than One

Mr. George has not far to ride with folded arms upon the box, for their destination is Lincoln's Inn Fields. When the driver stops his (driver) horses, Mr. George alights, and looking in at the window, says,

``What, Mr. Tulkinghorn's your man, is he (man)?'' (Mr. George/George)

``Yes, my dear friend. Do you know him (friend), Mr. George?'' (unknown)

``Why, I have heard of him (George)--seen him (George) too, I think. But I don't know him (George), and he (George) don't know me.'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)

There ensues the carrying of Mr. Smallweed upstairs, which is done to perfection with the trooper's help. He (Smallweed) is borne into Mr. Tulkinghorn's great room and deposited on the Turkey rug before the fire. Mr. Tulkinghorn is not within at the present moment but will be back directly. The occupant of the pew in the hall, having said thus much, stirs the fire and leaves the triumvirate to warm themselves.

Mr. George is mightily curious in respect of the room. He (George) looks up at the painted ceiling, looks round at the old law-books, contemplates the portraits of the great clients, reads aloud the names on the boxes.

''`Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet,''' (the clients)
Mr. George reads thoughtfully. ``Ha! ``Manor of Chesney Wold.
'' Humph!'' (Chesney)
Mr. George stands looking at these boxes a long while--as if they were pictures--and comes back to the fire repeating,
``Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, and Manor of Chesney Wold, hey?'' (Mr. George/George)

``Worth a mint of money, Mr. George!'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
whispers Grandfather Smallweed, rubbing his (Smallweed) legs.
``Powerfully rich!'' (unknown)

``Who do you mean? This old gentleman, or the Baronet?'' (unknown)

``This gentleman, this gentleman.'' (unknown)

``So I have heard; and knows a thing or two, I'll hold a wager. Not bad quarters, either,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George, looking round again.
``See the strong-box yonder!'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

This reply is cut short by Mr. Tulkinghorn's arrival. There is no change in him (George), of course. Rustily drest, with his (George) spectacles in his (George) hand, and their very case worn threadbare. In manner, close and dry. In voice, husky and low. In face, watchful behind a blind; habitually not uncensorious and contemptuous perhaps. The peerage may have warmer worshippers and faithfuller believers than Mr. Tulkinghorn, after all, if everything were known.

``Good morning, Mr. Smallweed, good morning!'' (he)
he (Tulkinghorn) says as he (Tulkinghorn) comes in.
``You have brought the sergeant, I see. Sit down, sergeant.'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

As Mr. Tulkinghorn takes off his (Tulkinghorn) gloves and puts them in his (Tulkinghorn) hat, he (Tulkinghorn) looks with half-closed eyes across the room to where the trooper stands and says within himself perchance,

``You'll do, my friend!'' (the trooper)

``Sit down, sergeant,'' (he)
he (trooper) repeats as he (trooper) comes to his (trooper) table, which is set on one side of the fire, and takes his (trooper) easy-chair.
``Cold and raw this morning, cold and raw!'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
Mr. Tulkinghorn warms before the bars, alternately, the palms and knuckles of his (Tulkinghorn) hands and looks -LRB-from behind that blind which is always down-RRB- at the trio sitting in a little semicircle before him (Tulkinghorn).

``Now, I can feel what I am about'' (he)
-LRB-as perhaps he (Tulkinghorn) can in two senses-RRB-,
``Mr. Smallweed.'' (he)
The old gentleman is newly shaken up by Judy to bear his (gentleman) part in the conversation.
``You have brought our good friend the sergeant, I see.'' (unknown)

``Yes, sir,'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
returns Mr. Smallweed, very servile to the lawyer's wealth and influence.

``And what does the sergeant say about this business?'' (unknown)

``Mr. George,'' (Grandfather)
says Grandfather Smallweed with a tremulous wave of his (Grandfather) shrivelled hand,
``this is the gentleman, sir.'' (Grandfather)

Mr. George salutes the gentleman but otherwise sits bolt upright and profoundly silent--very forward in his (George) chair, as if the full complement of regulation appendages for a field-day hung about him (George).

Mr. Tulkinghorn proceeds,

``Well, George--I believe your name is George?'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

``It is so, Sir.'' (unknown)

``What do you say, George?'' (unknown)

``I ask your pardon, sir,'' (the trooper)
returns the trooper,
``but I should wish to know what YOU say?'' (the trooper)

``Do you mean in point of reward?'' (unknown)

``I mean in point of everything, sir.'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)

This is so very trying to Mr. Smallweed's temper that he (Smallweed) suddenly breaks out with

``You're a brimstone beast!'' (he)
and as suddenly asks pardon of Mr. Tulkinghorn, excusing himself for this slip of the tongue by saying to Judy,
``I was thinking of your grandmother, my dear.'' (Judy)

``I supposed, sergeant,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
Mr. Tulkinghorn resumes as he (Tulkinghorn) leans on one side of his (Tulkinghorn) chair and crosses his (Tulkinghorn) legs,
``that Mr. Smallweed might have sufficiently explained the matter. It lies in the smallest compass, however. You served under Captain Hawdon at one time, and were his (Captain) attendant in illness, and rendered him (Captain) many little services, and were rather in his (Captain) confidence, I am told. That is so, is it not?'' (he)

``Yes, sir, that is so,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George with military brevity.

``Therefore you may happen to have in your possession something--anything, no matter what; accounts, instructions, orders, a letter, anything--in Captain Hawdon's writing. I wish to compare his (Captain) writing with some that I have. If you can give me the opportunity, you shall be rewarded for your trouble. Three, four, five, guineas, you would consider handsome, I dare say.'' (unknown)

``Noble, my dear friend!'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
cries Grandfather Smallweed, screwing up his (Smallweed) eyes.

``If not, say how much more, in your conscience as a soldier, you can demand. There is no need for you to part with the writing, against your inclination--though I should prefer to have it.'' (Mr. George/George)

Mr. George sits squared in exactly the same attitude, looks at the painted ceiling, and says never a word. The irascible Mr. Smallweed scratches the air.

``The question is,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn in his (Tulkinghorn) methodical, subdued, uninterested way,
``first, whether you have any of Captain Hawdon's writing?'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

``First, whether I have any of Captain Hawdon's writing, sir,'' (Mr. George/George)
repeats Mr. George.

``Secondly, what will satisfy you for the trouble of producing it?'' (unknown)

``Secondly, what will satisfy me for the trouble of producing it, sir,'' (Mr. George/George)
repeats Mr. George.

``Thirdly, you can judge for yourself whether it is at all like that,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn, suddenly handing him (Tulkinghorn) some sheets of written paper tied together.

``Whether it is at all like that, sir. Just so,'' (Mr. George/George)
repeats Mr. George.

All three repetitions Mr. George pronounces in a mechanical manner, looking straight at Mr. Tulkinghorn; nor does he (Tulkinghorn) so much as glance at the affidavit in Jarndyce and Jarndyce, that has been given to him (Jarndyce) for his (Jarndyce) inspection -LRB-though he (Jarndyce) still holds it in his (Jarndyce) hand-RRB-, but continues to look at the lawyer with an air of troubled meditation.

``Well?'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn.
``What do you say?'' (unknown)

``Well, sir,'' (Mr. George/George)
replies Mr. George, rising erect and looking immense,
``I would rather, if you'll excuse me, have nothing to do with this.'' (Mr. George/George)

Mr. Tulkinghorn, outwardly quite undisturbed, demands,

``Why not?'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

``Why, sir,'' (the trooper)
returns the trooper.
``Except on military compulsion, I am not a man of business. Among civilians I am what they call in Scotland a ne'er-do-weel. I have no head for papers, sir. I can stand any fire better than a fire of cross questions. I mentioned to Mr. Smallweed, only an hour or so ago, that when I come into things of this kind I feel as if I was being smothered. And that is my sensation,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George, looking round upon the company,
``at the present moment.'' (Mr. George/George)
