she (Woodcourt) would say, and always with some emotion, for with her (Woodcourt) lofty pedigree she (Woodcourt) had a very affectionate heart,
``was descended from a great Highland family, the MacCoorts of MacCoort. He (Woodcourt) served his (Woodcourt) king and country as an officer in the Royal Highlanders, and he (Woodcourt) died on the field. My son is one of the last representatives of two old families. With the blessing of heaven he (son) will set them up again and unite them with another old family.'' (she)

It was in vain for me to try to change the subject, as I used to try, only for the sake of novelty or perhaps because--but I need not be so particular. Mrs. Woodcourt never would let me change it.

``My dear,'' (she)
she (Woodcourt) said one night,
``you have so much sense and you look at the world in a quiet manner so superior to your time of life that it is a comfort to me to talk to you about these family matters of mine. You don't know much of my son, my dear; but you know enough of him (son), I dare say, to recollect him (son)?'' (she)

``Yes, ma'am. I recollect him (son).'' (unknown)

``Yes, my dear. Now, my dear, I think you are a judge of character, and I should like to have your opinion of him (character).'' (unknown)

``Oh, Mrs. Woodcourt,'' (I)
said I,
``that is so difficult!'' (I)

``Why is it so difficult, my dear?'' (she)
she (Woodcourt) returned.
``I don't see it myself.'' (unknown)

``To give an opinion--'' (unknown)

``On so slight an acquaintance, my dear. THAT

``S true.'' (I)

I didn't mean that, because Mr. Woodcourt had been at our house a good deal altogether and had become quite intimate with my guardian. I said so, and added that he (Woodcourt) seemed to be very clever in his (Woodcourt) profession--we thought--and that his (Woodcourt) kindness and gentleness to Miss Flite were above all praise.

``You do him (acquaintance) justice!'' (Mrs. Woodcourt)
said Mrs. Woodcourt, pressing my hand.
``You define him (acquaintance) exactly. Allan is a dear fellow, and in his (Allan) profession faultless. I say it, though I am his (Allan) mother. Still, I must confess he (Allan) is not without faults, love.'' (unknown)

``None of us are,'' (I.)
said I.

``Ah! But his (Allan) really are faults that he (Allan) might correct, and ought to correct,'' (I.)
returned the sharp old lady, sharply shaking her (Woodcourt) head.
``I am so much attached to you that I may confide in you, my dear, as a third party wholly disinterested, that he (Allan) is fickleness itself.'' (I)

I said I should have thought it hardly possible that he (Woodcourt) could have been otherwise than constant to his (Woodcourt) profession and zealous in the pursuit of it, judging from the reputation he (Woodcourt) had earned.

``You are right again, my dear,'' (the lady)
the old lady retorted,
``but I don't refer to his (Allan) profession, look you.'' (the lady)

``Oh!'' (I.)
said I.

``No,'' (I.)
said she (lady).
``I refer, my dear, to his (Allan) social conduct. He (Allan) is always paying trivial attentions to young ladies, and always has been, ever since he (Allan) was eighteen. Now, my dear, he (Allan) has never really cared for any one of them and has never meant in doing this to do any harm or to express anything but politeness and good nature. Still, it's not right, you know; is it?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (I)
said I, as she (lady) seemed to wait for me.

``And it might lead to mistaken notions, you see, my dear.'' (I)

I supposed it might.

``Therefore, I have told him (Allan) many times that he (Allan) really should be more careful, both in justice to himself and in justice to others. And he (Allan) has always said, ``Mother, I will be; but you know me better than anybody else does, and you know I mean no harm--in short, mean nothing.

'' All of which is very true, my dear, but is no justification. However, as he (Woodcourt) is now gone so far away and for an indefinite time, and as he (Woodcourt) will have good opportunities and introductions, we may consider this past and gone. And you, my dear,'' (I)
said the old lady, who was now all nods and smiles,
``regarding your dear self, my love?'' (the lady love)

``Me, Mrs. Woodcourt?'' (unknown)

``Not to be always selfish, talking of my son, who has gone to seek his (son) fortune and to find a wife--when do you mean to seek YOUR fortune and to find a husband, Miss Summerson? Hey, look you! Now you blush!'' (I)

I don't think I did blush--at all events, it was not important if I did--and I said my present fortune perfectly contented me and I had no wish to change it.

``Shall I tell you what I always think of you and the fortune yet to come for you, my love?'' (Mrs. Woodcourt)
said Mrs. Woodcourt.

``If you believe you are a good prophet,'' (I.)
said I.

``Why, then, it is that you will marry some one very rich and very worthy, much older--five and twenty years, perhaps--than yourself. And you will be an excellent wife, and much beloved, and very happy.'' (I.)

``That is a good fortune,'' (I.)
said I.
``But why is it to be mine?'' (I.)

``My dear,'' (she)
she (Woodcourt) returned,
``there's suitability in it--you are so busy, and so neat, and so peculiarly situated altogether that there's suitability in it, and it will come to pass. And nobody, my love, will congratulate you more sincerely on such a marriage than I shall.'' (she)

It was curious that this should make me uncomfortable, but I think it did. I know it did. It made me for some part of that night uncomfortable. I was so ashamed of my folly that I did not like to confess it even to Ada, and that made me more uncomfortable still. I would have given anything not to have been so much in the bright old lady's confidence if I could have possibly declined it. It gave me the most inconsistent opinions of her (lady). At one time I thought she (lady) was a story-teller, and at another time that she (lady) was the pink of truth. Now I suspected that she (lady) was very cunning, next moment I believed her (lady) honest Welsh heart to be perfectly innocent and simple. And after all, what did it matter to me, and why did it matter to me? Why could not I, going up to bed with my basket of keys, stop to sit down by her (lady) fire and accommodate myself for a little while to her (lady), at least as well as to anybody else, and not trouble myself about the harmless things she (lady) said to me? Impelled towards her (lady), as I certainly was, for I was very anxious that she (lady) should like me and was very glad indeed that she (lady) did, why should I harp afterwards, with actual distress and pain, on every word she (lady) said and weigh it over and over again in twenty scales? Why was it so worrying to me to have her (lady) in our house, and confidential to me every night, when I yet felt that it was better and safer somehow that she (lady) should be there than anywhere else? These were perplexities and contradictions that I could not account for. At least, if I could--but I shall come to all that by and by, and it is mere idleness to go on about it now.

So when Mrs. Woodcourt went away, I was sorry to lose her (Woodcourt) but was relieved too. And then Caddy Jellyby came down, and Caddy brought such a packet of domestic news that it gave us abundant occupation.

First Caddy declared -LRB-and would at first declare nothing else-RRB- that I was the best adviser that ever was known. This, my pet said, was no news at all; and this, I said, of course, was nonsense. Then Caddy told us that she (Jellyby) was going to be married in a month and that if Ada and I would be her (Ada) bridesmaids, she (Ada) was the happiest girl in the world. To be sure, this was news indeed; and I thought we never should have done talking about it, we had so much to say to Caddy, and Caddy had so much to say to us.

It seemed that Caddy's unfortunate papa had got over his (papa) bankruptcy--

``gone through the Gazette,'' (Caddy papa)
was the expression Caddy used, as if it were a tunnel--with the general clemency and commiseration of his (papa) creditors, and had got rid of his (papa) affairs in some blessed manner without succeeding in understanding them, and had given up everything he (papa) possessed -LRB-which was not worth much, I should think, to judge from the state of the furniture-RRB-, and had satisfied every one concerned that he (papa) could do no more, poor man. So, he (papa) had been honourably dismissed to
``the office'' (he)
to begin the world again. What he (papa) did at the office, I never knew; Caddy said he (Caddy) was a
``custom-house and general agent,'' (he)
and the only thing I ever understood about that business was that when he (Caddy) wanted money more than usual he (Caddy) went to the docks to look for it, and hardly ever found it.

As soon as her (I) papa had tranquillized his (papa) mind by becoming this shorn lamb, and they had removed to a furnished lodging in Hatton Garden -LRB-where I found the children, when I afterwards went there, cutting the horse hair out of the seats of the chairs and choking themselves with it-RRB-, Caddy had brought about a meeting between him (Hatton) and old Mr. Turveydrop; and poor Mr. Jellyby, being very humble and meek, had deferred to Mr. Turveydrop's deportment so submissively that they had become excellent friends. By degrees, old Mr. Turveydrop, thus familiarized with the idea of his (Turveydrop) son's marriage, had worked up his (Turveydrop) parental feelings to the height of contemplating that event as being near at hand and had given his (Turveydrop) gracious consent to the young couple commencing housekeeping at the academy in Newman Street when they would.

``And your papa, Caddy. What did he (papa) say?'' (unknown)

``Oh! Poor Pa,'' (unknown)
said Caddy, ``only cried and said he (papa) hoped we might get on better than he (papa) and Ma had got on. He (papa) didn't say so before Prince, he (Prince) only said so to me. And he (Prince) said,
``My poor girl, you have not been very well taught how to make a home for your husband, but unless you mean with all your heart to strive to do it, you had better murder him (husband) than marry him (husband)--if you really love him (husband).''' (unknown)

``And how did you reassure him (husband), Caddy?'' (unknown)

``Why, it was very distressing, you know, to see poor Pa so low and hear him (husband) say such terrible things, and I couldn't help crying myself. But I told him (husband) that I DID mean it with all my heart and that I hoped our house would be a place for him (husband) to come and find some comfort in of an evening and that I hoped and thought I could be a better daughter to him (husband) there than at home. Then I mentioned Peepy's coming to stay with me, and then Pa began to cry again and said the children were Indians.'' (unknown)

``Indians, Caddy?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (unknown)
said Caddy,
``wild Indians. And Pa said'' (she)
--here she (Turveydrop) began to sob, poor girl, not at all like the happiest girl in the world--
``that he (husband) was sensible the best thing that could happen to them was their being all tomahawked together.'' (the girl)

Ada suggested that it was comfortable to know that Mr. Jellyby did not mean these destructive sentiments.

``No, of course I know Pa wouldn't like his (husband) family to be weltering in their blood,'' (I)
said Caddy,
``but he (husband) means that they are very unfortunate in being Ma's children and that he (husband) is very unfortunate in being Ma's husband; and I am sure that's true, though it seems unnatural to say so.'' (I)

I asked Caddy if Mrs. Jellyby knew that her (Jellyby) wedding-day was fixed.

``Oh! You know what Ma is, Esther,'' (she)
she (Jellyby) returned.
``It's impossible to say whether she (Esther) knows it or not. She (Esther) has been told it often enough; and when she (Esther) IS told it, she (Esther) only gives me a placid look, as if I was I don't know what--a steeple in the distance,'' (unknown)
said Caddy with a sudden idea; ``and then she (Esther) shakes her (Esther) head and says ``Oh, Caddy, Caddy, what a tease you are!
'' and goes on with the Borrioboola letters.'' (unknown)

``And about your wardrobe, Caddy?'' (I.)
said I. For she (Jellyby) was under no restraint with us.

``Well, my dear Esther,'' (she)
she (Jellyby) returned, drying her (Jellyby) eyes,
``I must do the best I can and trust to my dear Prince never to have an unkind remembrance of my coming so shabbily to him (Prince). If the question concerned an outfit for Borrioboola, Ma would know all about it and would be quite excited. Being what it is, she (Esther) neither knows nor cares.'' (she)

Caddy was not at all deficient in natural affection for her (Jellyby) mother, but mentioned this with tears as an undeniable fact, which I am afraid it was. We were sorry for the poor dear girl and found so much to admire in the good disposition which had survived under such discouragement that we both at once -LRB-I mean Ada and I-RRB- proposed a little scheme that made her (Ada) perfectly joyful. This was her (Ada) staying with us for three weeks, my staying with her (Ada) for one, and our all three contriving and cutting out, and repairing, and sewing, and saving, and doing the very best we could think of to make the most of her (Ada) stock. My guardian being as pleased with the idea as Caddy was, we took her (Ada) home next day to arrange the matter and brought her (Ada) out again in triumph with her (Ada) boxes and all the purchases that could be squeezed out of a ten-pound note, which Mr. Jellyby had found in the docks I suppose, but which he (Jellyby) at all events gave her (Ada). What my guardian would not have given her (Ada) if we had encouraged him (Jellyby), it would be difficult to say, but we thought it right to compound for no more than her (Ada) wedding-dress and bonnet. He (Jellyby) agreed to this compromise, and if Caddy had ever been happy in her (Ada) life, she (Ada) was happy when we sat down to work.

She (Ada) was clumsy enough with her (Ada) needle, poor girl, and pricked her (Ada) fingers as much as she (Ada) had been used to ink them. She (Ada) could not help reddening a little now and then, partly with the smart and partly with vexation at being able to do no better, but she (Ada) soon got over that and began to improve rapidly. So day after day she (Ada), and my darling, and my little maid Charley, and a milliner out of the town, and I, sat hard at work, as pleasantly as possible.

Over and above this, Caddy was very anxious

``to learn housekeeping,'' (she)
as she (maid) said. Now, mercy upon us! The idea of her (maid) learning housekeeping of a person of my vast experience was such a joke that I laughed, and coloured up, and fell into a comical confusion when she (maid) proposed it. However, I said,
``Caddy, I am sure you are very welcome to learn anything that you can learn of ME, my dear,'' (I)
and I showed her (maid) all my books and methods and all my fidgety ways. You would have supposed that I was showing her (maid) some wonderful inventions, by her (maid) study of them; and if you had seen her (maid), whenever I jingled my housekeeping keys, get up and attend me, certainly you might have thought that there never was a greater imposter than I with a blinder follower than Caddy Jellyby.

So what with working and housekeeping, and lessons to Charley, and backgammon in the evening with my guardian, and duets with Ada, the three weeks slipped fast away. Then I went home with Caddy to see what could be done there, and Ada and Charley remained behind to take care of my guardian.

When I say I went home with Caddy, I mean to the furnished lodging in Hatton Garden. We went to Newman Street two or three times, where preparations were in progress too--a good many, I observed, for enhancing the comforts of old Mr. Turveydrop, and a few for putting the newly married couple away cheaply at the top of the house--but our great point was to make the furnished lodging decent for the wedding-breakfast and to imbue Mrs. Jellyby beforehand with some faint sense of the occasion.

The latter was the more difficult thing of the two because Mrs. Jellyby and an unwholesome boy occupied the front sitting-room -LRB-the back one was a mere closet-RRB-, and it was littered down with waste-paper and Borrioboolan documents, as an untidy stable might be littered with straw. Mrs. Jellyby sat there all day drinking strong coffee, dictating, and holding Borrioboolan interviews by appointment. The unwholesome boy, who seemed to me to be going into a decline, took his (boy) meals out of the house. When Mr. Jellyby came home, he (Jellyby) usually groaned and went down into the kitchen. There he (Jellyby) got something to eat if the servant would give him (servant) anything, and then, feeling that he (servant) was in the way, went out and walked about Hatton Garden in the wet. The poor children scrambled up and tumbled down the house as they had always been accustomed to do.

The production of these devoted little sacrifices in any presentable condition being quite out of the question at a week's notice, I proposed to Caddy that we should make them as happy as we could on her (children) marriage morning in the attic where they all slept, and should confine our greatest efforts to her (children) mama and her (children) mama's room, and a clean breakfast. In truth Mrs. Jellyby required a good deal of attention, the lattice-work up her (Jellyby) back having widened considerably since I first knew her (Jellyby) and her (Jellyby) hair looking like the mane of a dustman's horse.

Thinking that the display of Caddy's wardrobe would be the best means of approaching the subject, I invited Mrs. Jellyby to come and look at it spread out on Caddy's bed in the evening after the unwholesome boy was gone.

``My dear Miss Summerson,'' (she)
said she (Jellyby), rising from her (Jellyby) desk with her (Jellyby) usual sweetness of temper,
``these are really ridiculous preparations, though your assisting them is a proof of your kindness. There is something so inexpressibly absurd to me in the idea of Caddy being married! Oh, Caddy, you silly, silly, silly puss!'' (she)

She (Jellyby) came upstairs with us notwithstanding and looked at the clothes in her (Jellyby) customary far-off manner. They suggested one distinct idea to her (Jellyby), for she (Jellyby) said with her (Jellyby) placid smile, and shaking her (Jellyby) head,

``My good Miss Summerson, at half the cost, this weak child might have been equipped for Africa!'' (she)

On our going downstairs again, Mrs. Jellyby asked me whether this troublesome business was really to take place next Wednesday. And on my replying yes, she (Jellyby) said,

``Will my room be required, my dear Miss Summerson? For it's quite impossible that I can put my papers away.'' (she)

I took the liberty of saying that the room would certainly be wanted and that I thought we must put the papers away somewhere.

``Well, my dear Miss Summerson,'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)
said Mrs. Jellyby,
``you know best, I dare say. But by obliging me to employ a boy, Caddy has embarrassed me to that extent, overwhelmed as I am with public business, that I don't know which way to turn. We have a Ramification meeting, too, on Wednesday afternoon, and the inconvenience is very serious.'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)

``It is not likely to occur again,'' (I)
said I, smiling.
``Caddy will be married but once, probably.'' (unknown)

``That's true,'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)
Mrs. Jellyby replied;
``that's true, my dear. I suppose we must make the best of it!'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)

The next question was how Mrs. Jellyby should be dressed on the occasion. I thought it very curious to see her (Jellyby) looking on serenely from her (Jellyby) writing-table while Caddy and I discussed it, occasionally shaking her (Jellyby) head at us with a half-reproachful smile like a superior spirit who could just bear with our trifling.

The state in which her (Jellyby) dresses were, and the extraordinary confusion in which she (Jellyby) kept them, added not a little to our difficulty; but at length we devised something not very unlike what a common-place mother might wear on such an occasion. The abstracted manner in which Mrs. Jellyby would deliver herself up to having this attire tried on by the dressmaker, and the sweetness with which she (Jellyby) would then observe to me how sorry she (Jellyby) was that I had not turned my thoughts to Africa, were consistent with the rest of her (Jellyby) behaviour.

The lodging was rather confined as to space, but I fancied that if Mrs. Jellyby's household had been the only lodgers in Saint Paul's or Saint Peter's, the sole advantage they would have found in the size of the building would have been its affording a great deal of room to be dirty in. I believe that nothing belonging to the family which it had been possible to break was unbroken at the time of those preparations for Caddy's marriage, that nothing which it had been possible to spoil in any way was unspoilt, and that no domestic object which was capable of collecting dirt, from a dear child's knee to the door-plate, was without as much dirt as could well accumulate upon it.

Poor Mr. Jellyby, who very seldom spoke and almost always sat when he (Jellyby) was at home with his (Jellyby) head against the wall, became interested when he (Jellyby) saw that Caddy and I were attempting to establish some order among all this waste and ruin and took off his (Jellyby) coat to help. But such wonderful things came tumbling out of the closets when they were opened--bits of mouldy pie, sour bottles, Mrs. Jellyby's caps, letters, tea, forks, odd boots and shoes of children, firewood, wafers, saucepan-lids, damp sugar in odds and ends of paper bags, footstools, blacklead brushes, bread, Mrs. Jellyby's bonnets, books with butter sticking to the binding, guttered candle ends put out by being turned upside down in broken candlesticks, nutshells, heads and tails of shrimps, dinner-mats, gloves, coffee-grounds, umbrellas--that he (they) looked frightened, and left off again. But he (they) came regularly every evening and sat without his (they) coat, with his (they) head against the wall, as though he (they) would have helped us if he (they) had known how.

``Poor Pa!'' (me)
said Caddy to me on the night before the great day, when we really had got things a little to rights.
``It seems unkind to leave him (I), Esther. But what could I do if I stayed! Since I first knew you, I have tidied and tidied over and over again, but it's useless. Ma and Africa, together, upset the whole house directly. We never have a servant who don't drink. Ma's ruinous to everything.'' (Mr. Jellyby)

Mr. Jellyby could not hear what she (they) said, but he (Jellyby) seemed very low indeed and shed tears, I thought.

``My heart aches for him (servant); that it does!'' (unknown)
sobbed Caddy.
``I can't help thinking to-night, Esther, how dearly I hope to be happy with Prince, and how dearly Pa hoped, I dare say, to be happy with Ma. What a disappointed life!'' (unknown)

``My dear Caddy!'' (Mr. Jellyby)
said Mr. Jellyby, looking slowly round from the wail. It was the first time, I think, I ever heard him (Jellyby) say three words together.

``Yes, Pa!'' (him)
cried Caddy, going to him (Jellyby) and embracing him (Jellyby) affectionately.

``My dear Caddy,'' (Mr. Jellyby)
said Mr. Jellyby.
``Never have--'' (unknown)

``Not Prince, Pa?'' (unknown)
faltered Caddy.
``Not have Prince?'' (unknown)

``Yes, my dear,'' (Mr. Jellyby)
said Mr. Jellyby.
``Have him (Prince), certainly. But, never have--'' (I)

I mentioned in my account of our first visit in Thavies Inn that Richard described Mr. Jellyby as frequently opening his (Jellyby) mouth after dinner without saying anything. It was a habit of his (Jellyby). He (Jellyby) opened his (Jellyby) mouth now a great many times and shook his (Jellyby) head in a melancholy manner.

``What do you wish me not to have? Don't have what, dear Pa?'' (him)
asked Caddy, coaxing him (Jellyby), with her (Richard) arms round his (Jellyby) neck.

``Never have a mission, my dear child.'' (Mr. Jellyby)

Mr. Jellyby groaned and laid his (Jellyby) head against the wall again, and this was the only time I ever heard him (Jellyby) make any approach to expressing his (Jellyby) sentiments on the Borrioboolan question. I suppose he (Jellyby) had been more talkative and lively once, but he (Jellyby) seemed to have been completely exhausted long before I knew him (Jellyby).

I thought Mrs. Jellyby never would have left off serenely looking over her (Jellyby) papers and drinking coffee that night. It was twelve o'clock before we could obtain possession of the room, and the clearance it required then was so discouraging that Caddy, who was almost tired out, sat down in the middle of the dust and cried. But she (Jellyby) soon cheered up, and we did wonders with it before we went to bed.

In the morning it looked, by the aid of a few flowers and a quantity of soap and water and a little arrangement, quite gay. The plain breakfast made a cheerful show, and Caddy was perfectly charming. But when my darling came, I thought--and I think now--that I never had seen such a dear face as my beautiful pet's.

We made a little feast for the children upstairs, and we put Peepy at the head of the table, and we showed them Caddy in her (children) bridal dress, and they clapped their hands and hurrahed, and Caddy cried to think that she (children) was going away from them and hugged them over and over again until we brought Prince up to fetch her (children) away--when, I am sorry to say, Peepy bit him (Prince). Then there was old Mr. Turveydrop downstairs, in a state of deportment not to be expressed, benignly blessing Caddy and giving my guardian to understand that his (Turveydrop) son's happiness was his (Turveydrop) own parental work and that he (Turveydrop) sacrificed personal considerations to ensure it.

``My dear sir,'' (Mr. Turveydrop/Turveydrop/MR. TURVEYDROP)
said Mr. Turveydrop,
``these young people will live with me; my house is large enough for their accommodation, and they shall not want the shelter of my roof. I could have wished--you will understand the allusion, Mr. Jarndyce, for you remember my illustrious patron the Prince Regent--I could have wished that my son had married into a family where there was more deportment, but the will of heaven be done!'' (Mr. Turveydrop/Turveydrop/MR. TURVEYDROP)

Mr. and Mrs. Pardiggle were of the party--Mr. Pardiggle, an obstinate-looking man with a large waistcoat and stubbly hair, who was always talking in a loud bass voice about his (Pardiggle) mite, or Mrs. Pardiggle's mite, or their five boys' mites. Mr. Quale, with his (Quale) hair brushed back as usual and his (Quale) knobs of temples shining very much, was also there, not in the character of a disappointed lover, but as the accepted of a young--at least, an unmarried--lady, a Miss Wisk, who was also there. Miss Wisk's mission, my guardian said, was to show the world that woman's mission was man's mission and that the only genuine mission of both man and woman was to be always moving declaratory resolutions about things in general at public meetings. The guests were few, but were, as one might expect at Mrs. Jellyby's, all devoted to public objects only. Besides those I have mentioned, there was an extremely dirty lady with her (lady) bonnet all awry and the ticketed price of her (lady) dress still sticking on it, whose neglected home, Caddy told me, was like a filthy wilderness, but whose church was like a fancy fair. A very contentious gentleman, who said it was his (gentleman) mission to be everybody's brother but who appeared to be on terms of coolness with the whole of his (gentleman) large family, completed the party.

A party, having less in common with such an occasion, could hardly have been got together by any ingenuity. Such a mean mission as the domestic mission was the very last thing to be endured among them; indeed, Miss Wisk informed us, with great indignation, before we sat down to breakfast, that the idea of woman's mission lying chiefly in the narrow sphere of home was an outrageous slander on the part of her (woman) tyrant, man. One other singularity was that nobody with a mission--except Mr. Quale, whose mission, as I think I have formerly said, was to be in ecstasies with everybody's mission--cared at all for anybody's mission. Mrs. Pardiggle being as clear that the only one infallible course was her (Pardiggle) course of pouncing upon the poor and applying benevolence to them like a strait-waistcoat; as Miss Wisk was that the only practical thing for the world was the emancipation of woman from the thraldom of her (woman) tyrant, man. Mrs. Jellyby, all the while, sat smiling at the limited vision that could see anything but Borrioboola-Gha.

But I am anticipating now the purport of our conversation on the ride home instead of first marrying Caddy. We all went to church, and Mr. Jellyby gave her (Jellyby) away. Of the air with which old Mr. Turveydrop, with his (Turveydrop) hat under his (Turveydrop) left arm -LRB-the inside presented at the clergyman like a cannon-RRB- and his (Turveydrop) eyes creasing themselves up into his (Turveydrop) wig, stood stiff and high-shouldered behind us bridesmaids during the ceremony, and afterwards saluted us, I could never say enough to do it justice. Miss Wisk, whom I cannot report as prepossessing in appearance, and whose manner was grim, listened to the proceedings, as part of woman's wrongs, with a disdainful face. Mrs. Jellyby, with her (Jellyby) calm smile and her (Jellyby) bright eyes, looked the least concerned of all the company.

We duly came back to breakfast, and Mrs. Jellyby sat at the head of the table and Mr. Jellyby at the foot. Caddy had previously stolen upstairs to hug the children again and tell them that her (Jellyby) name was Turveydrop. But this piece of information, instead of being an agreeable surprise to Peepy, threw him (Jellyby) on his (Jellyby) back in such transports of kicking grief that I could do nothing on being sent for but accede to the proposal that he (Jellyby) should be admitted to the breakfast table. So he (Jellyby) came down and sat in my lap; and Mrs. Jellyby, after saying, in reference to the state of his (Jellyby) pinafore,

``Oh, you naughty Peepy, what a shocking little pig you are!'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)
was not at all discomposed. He (Jellyby) was very good except that he (Jellyby) brought down Noah with him (Jellyby) -LRB-out of an ark I had given him (Jellyby) before we went to church-RRB- and WOULD dip him (Jellyby) head first into the wine-glasses and then put him (Jellyby) in his (Jellyby) mouth.

My guardian, with his (Jellyby) sweet temper and his (Jellyby) quick perception and his (Jellyby) amiable face, made something agreeable even out of the ungenial company. None of them seemed able to talk about anything but his (Jellyby), or her (Jellyby), own one subject, and none of them seemed able to talk about even that as part of a world in which there was anything else; but my guardian turned it all to the merry encouragement of Caddy and the honour of the occasion, and brought us through the breakfast nobly. What we should have done without him (Jellyby), I am afraid to think, for all the company despising the bride and bridegroom and old Mr. Turveydrop--and old Mr. Thurveydrop, in virtue of his (Mr.) deportment, considering himself vastly superior to all the company--it was a very unpromising case.

At last the time came when poor Caddy was to go and when all her (bride) property was packed on the hired coach and pair that was to take her (bride) and her (bride) husband to Gravesend. It affected us to see Caddy clinging, then, to her (bride) deplorable home and hanging on her (bride) mother's neck with the greatest tenderness.

``I am very sorry I couldn't go on writing from dictation, Ma,'' (unknown)
sobbed Caddy.
``I hope you forgive me now.'' (unknown)

``Oh, Caddy, Caddy!'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)
said Mrs. Jellyby.
``I have told you over and over again that I have engaged a boy, and there's an end of it.'' (unknown)

``You are sure you are not the least angry with me, Ma? Say you are sure before I go away, Ma?'' (unknown)

``You foolish Caddy,'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)
returned Mrs. Jellyby,
``do I look angry, or have I inclination to be angry, or time to be angry? How CAN you?'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)

``Take a little care of Pa while I am gone, Mama!'' (Mrs. Jellyby/Jellyby/JELLYBY)

Mrs. Jellyby positively laughed at the fancy.

``You romantic child,'' (she)
said she (Jellyby), lightly patting Caddy's back.
``Go along. I am excellent friends with you. Now, good-bye, Caddy, and be very happy!'' (father)

Then Caddy hung upon her (Jellyby) father and nursed his (father) cheek against hers as if he (father) were some poor dull child in pain. All this took place in the hall. Her (Jellyby) father released her (Jellyby), took out his (father) pocket handkerchief, and sat down on the stairs with his (father) head against the wall. I hope he (father) found some consolation in walls. I almost think he (father) did.

And then Prince took her (Jellyby) arm in his (Prince) and turned with great emotion and respect to his (Prince) father, whose deportment at that moment was overwhelming.

``Thank you over and over again, father!'' (Prince)
said Prince, kissing his (Prince) hand.
``I am very grateful for all your kindness and consideration regarding our marriage, and so, I can assure you, is Caddy.'' (unknown)

``Very,'' (unknown)
sobbed Caddy.
``Ve-ry!'' (unknown)

``My dear son,'' (Mr. Turveydrop/Turveydrop/MR. TURVEYDROP)
said Mr. Turveydrop,
``and dear daughter, I have done my duty. If the spirit of a sainted wooman hovers above us and looks down on the occasion, that, and your constant affection, will be my recompense. You will not fail in YOUR duty, my son and daughter, I believe?'' (Mr. Turveydrop/Turveydrop/MR. TURVEYDROP)

``Dear father, never!'' (Prince)
cried Prince.

``Never, never, dear Mr. Turveydrop!'' (unknown)
said Caddy.

``This,'' (Mr. Turveydrop/Turveydrop/MR. TURVEYDROP)
returned Mr. Turveydrop,
``is as it should be. My children, my home is yours, my heart is yours, my all is yours. I will never leave you; nothing but death shall part us. My dear son, you contemplate an absence of a week, I think?'' (Mr. Turveydrop/Turveydrop/MR. TURVEYDROP)

``A week, dear father. We shall return home this day week.'' (unknown)

``My dear child,'' (Mr. Turveydrop/Turveydrop/MR. TURVEYDROP)
said Mr. Turveydrop,
``let me, even under the present exceptional circumstances, recommend strict punctuality. It is highly important to keep the connexion together; and schools, if at all neglected, are apt to take offence.'' (Mr. Turveydrop/Turveydrop/MR. TURVEYDROP)

``This day week, father, we shall be sure to be home to dinner.'' (unknown)

``Good!'' (Mr. Turveydrop/Turveydrop/MR. TURVEYDROP)
said Mr. Turveydrop.
``You will find fires, my dear Caroline, in your own room, and dinner prepared in my apartment. Yes, yes, Prince!'' (son)
anticipating some self-denying objection on his (Turveydrop) son's part with a great air.
``You and our Caroline will be strange in the upper part of the premises and will, therefore, dine that day in my apartment. Now, bless ye!'' (I)

They drove away, and whether I wondered most at Mrs. Jellyby or at Mr. Turveydrop, I did not know. Ada and my guardian were in the same condition when we came to talk it over. But before we drove away too, I received a most unexpected and eloquent compliment from Mr. Jellyby. He (Jellyby) came up to me in the hall, took both my hands, pressed them earnestly, and opened his (Jellyby) mouth twice. I was so sure of his (Jellyby) meaning that I said, quite flurried,

``You are very welcome, sir. Pray don't mention it!'' (I)

``I hope this marriage is for the best, guardian,'' (I)
said I when we three were on our road home.

``I hope it is, little woman. Patience. We shall see.'' (unknown)

``Is the wind in the east to-day?'' (I)
I ventured to ask him (Jellyby).

He (Jellyby) laughed heartily and answered,

``No.'' (He)

``But it must have been this morning, I think,'' (I)
said I.

He (Jellyby) answered

``No'' (He)
again, and this time my dear girl confidently answered
``No'' (girl)
too and shook the lovely head which, with its blooming flowers against the golden hair, was like the very spring.
``Much YOU know of east winds, my ugly darling,'' (I)
said I, kissing her (girl) in my admiration--I couldn't help it.

Well! It was only their love for me, I know very well, and it is a long time ago. I must write it even if I rub it out again, because it gives me so much pleasure. They said there could be no east wind where Somebody was; they said that wherever Dame Durden went, there was sunshine and summer air.

CHAPTER XXXI

Nurse and Patient

I had not been at home again many days when one evening I went upstairs into my own room to take a peep over Charley's shoulder and see how she (Nurse) was getting on with her (Nurse) copy-book. Writing was a trying business to Charley, who seemed to have no natural power over a pen, but in whose hand every pen appeared to become perversely animated, and to go wrong and crooked, and to stop, and splash, and sidle into corners like a saddle-donkey. It was very odd to see what old letters Charley's young hand had made, they so wrinkled, and shrivelled, and tottering, it so plump and round. Yet Charley was uncommonly expert at other things and had as nimble little fingers as I ever watched.

``Well, Charley,'' (I)
said I, looking over a copy of the letter O in which it was represented as square, triangular, pear-shaped, and collapsed in all kinds of ways,
``we are improving. If we only get to make it round, we shall be perfect, Charley.'' (I)

Then I made one, and Charley made one, and the pen wouldn't join Charley's neatly, but twisted it up into a knot.

``Never mind, Charley. We shall do it in time.'' (Charley)

Charley laid down her (Charley) pen, the copy being finished, opened and shut her (Charley) cramped little hand, looked gravely at the page, half in pride and half in doubt, and got up, and dropped me a curtsy.

``Thank you, miss. If you please, miss, did you know a poor person of the name of Jenny?'' (unknown)

``A brickmaker's wife, Charley? Yes.'' (unknown)

``She (wife) came and spoke to me when I was out a little while ago, and said you knew her (wife), miss. She (wife) asked me if I wasn't the young lady's little maid--meaning you for the young lady, miss--and I said yes, miss.'' (unknown)

``I thought she (lady) had left this neighbourhood altogether, Charley.'' (unknown)

``So she (lady) had, miss, but she (lady)'s come back again to where she (lady) used to live--she (lady) and Liz. Did you know another poor person of the name of Liz, miss?'' (unknown)

``I think I do, Charley, though not by name.'' (unknown)

``That's what she (Liz) said!'' (Charley)
returned Charley.
``They have both come back, miss, and have been tramping high and low.'' (unknown)

``Tramping high and low, have they, Charley?'' (unknown)

``Yes, miss.'' (Charley)
If Charley could only have made the letters in her (Charley) copy as round as the eyes with which she (Charley) looked into my face, they would have been excellent.
``And this poor person came about the house three or four days, hoping to get a glimpse of you, miss--all she (Liz) wanted, she (Liz) said--but you were away. That was when she (Liz) saw me. She (Liz) saw me a-going about, miss,'' (Charley)
said Charley with a short laugh of the greatest delight and pride,
``and she (Liz) thought I looked like your maid!'' (Charley)

``Did she (Liz) though, really, Charley?'' (unknown)

``Yes, miss!'' (Charley)
said Charley.
``Really and truly.'' (Charley)
And Charley, with another short laugh of the purest glee, made her (Charley) eyes very round again and looked as serious as became my maid. I was never tired of seeing Charley in the full enjoyment of that great dignity, standing before me with her (maid) youthful face and figure, and her (maid) steady manner, and her (maid) childish exultation breaking through it now and then in the pleasantest way.

``And where did you see her (Liz), Charley?'' (I.)
said I.

My little maid's countenance fell as she (maid) replied,

``By the doctor's shop, miss.'' (she)
For Charley wore her (maid) black frock yet.

I asked if the brickmaker's wife were ill, but Charley said no. It was some one else. Some one in her (wife) cottage who had tramped down to Saint Albans and was tramping he (Charley) didn't know where. A poor boy, Charley said. No father, no mother, no any one.

``Like as Tom might have been, miss, if Emma and me had died after father,'' (Charley)
said Charley, her (mother) round eyes filling with tears.

``And she (Emma) was getting medicine for him (father), Charley?'' (unknown)

``She (Emma) said, miss,'' (Charley)
returned Charley,
``how that he (Charley) had once done as much for her (Emma).'' (Charley)

My little maid's face was so eager and her (maid) quiet hands were folded so closely in one another as she (maid) stood looking at me that I had no great difficulty in reading her (maid) thoughts.

``Well, Charley,'' (I)
said I,
``it appears to me that you and I can do no better than go round to Jenny's and see what's the matter.'' (I)

The alacrity with which Charley brought my bonnet and veil, and having dressed me, quaintly pinned herself into her (maid) warm shawl and made herself look like a little old woman, sufficiently expressed her (maid) readiness. So Charley and I, without saying anything to any one, went out.

It was a cold, wild night, and the trees shuddered in the wind. The rain had been thick and heavy all day, and with little intermission for many days. None was falling just then, however. The sky had partly cleared, but was very gloomy--even above us, where a few stars were shining. In the north and north-west, where the sun had set three hours before, there was a pale dead light both beautiful and awful; and into it long sullen lines of cloud waved up like a sea stricken immovable as it was heaving. Towards London a lurid glare overhung the whole dark waste, and the contrast between these two lights, and the fancy which the redder light engendered of an unearthly fire, gleaming on all the unseen buildings of the city and on all the faces of its many thousands of wondering inhabitants, was as solemn as might be.

I had no thought that night--none, I am quite sure--of what was soon to happen to me. But I have always remembered since that when we had stopped at the garden-gate to look up at the sky, and when we went upon our way, I had for a moment an undefinable impression of myself as being something different from what I then was. I know it was then and there that I had it. I have ever since connected the feeling with that spot and time and with everything associated with that spot and time, to the distant voices in the town, the barking of a dog, and the sound of wheels coming down the miry hill.

It was Saturday night, and most of the people belonging to the place where we were going were drinking elsewhere. We found it quieter than I had previously seen it, though quite as miserable. The kilns were burning, and a stifling vapour set towards us with a pale-blue glare.

We came to the cottage, where there was a feeble candle in the patched window. We tapped at the door and went in. The mother of the little child who had died was sitting in a chair on one side of the poor fire by the bed; and opposite to her (mother), a wretched boy, supported by the chimney-piece, was cowering on the floor. He (boy) held under his (boy) arm, like a little bundle, a fragment of a fur cap; and as he (boy) tried to warm himself, he (boy) shook until the crazy door and window shook. The place was closer than before and had an unhealthy and a very peculiar smell.

I had not lifted my veil when I first spoke to the woman, which was at the moment of our going in. The boy staggered up instantly and stared at me with a remarkable expression of surprise and terror.

His (boy) action was so quick and my being the cause of it was so evident that I stood still instead of advancing nearer.

``I won't go no more to the berryin ground,'' (the boy)
muttered the boy;
``I ain't a-going there, so I tell you!'' (the boy)

I lifted my veil and spoke to the woman. She (woman) said to me in a low voice,

``Don't mind him (Charley), ma'am. He (Charley)'ll soon come back to his (Charley) head,'' (me)
and said to him (boy),
``Jo, Jo, what's the matter?'' (him)

``I know wot she (Jo)'s come for!'' (the boy)
cried the boy.

``Who?'' (unknown)

``The lady there. She (Jo)'s come to get me to go along with her (Jo) to the berryin ground. I won't go to the berryin ground. I don't like the name on it. She (Jo) might go a-berryin ME.'' (he)
His (boy) shivering came on again, and as he (boy) leaned against the wall, he (boy) shook the hovel.

``He (Charley) has been talking off and on about such like all day, ma'am,'' (Jenny/Will Jenny)
said Jenny softly.
``Why, how you stare! This is MY lady, Jo.'' (unknown)

``Is it?'' (the boy)
returned the boy doubtfully, and surveying me with his (boy) arm held out above his (boy) burning eyes.
``She (Jo) looks to me the t`other one. It ain't the bonnet, nor yet it ain't the gownd, but she (Jo) looks to me the t`other one.'' (Charley)

My little Charley, with her (Jenny) premature experience of illness and trouble, had pulled off her (Jenny) bonnet and shawl and now went quietly up to him (Charley) with a chair and sat him (Charley) down in it like an old sick nurse. Except that no such attendant could have shown him (attendant) Charley's youthful face, which seemed to engage his (attendant) confidence.

``I say!'' (the boy)
said the boy.
``YOU tell me. Ain't the lady the t`other lady?'' (Charley)

Charley shook her (nurse) head as she (nurse) methodically drew his (Charley) rags about him (Charley) and made him (Charley) as warm as she (nurse) could.

``Oh!'' (the boy)
the boy muttered.
``Then I s`pose she (lady) ain't.'' (unknown)

``I came to see if I could do you any good,'' (I.)
said I.
``What is the matter with you?'' (I.)

``I'm a-being froze,'' (the boy)
returned the boy hoarsely, with his (boy) haggard gaze wandering about me, ``and then burnt up, and then froze, and then burnt up, ever so many times in a hour. And my head's all sleepy, and all a-going mad-like--and I'm so dry--and my bones isn't half so much bones as pain.

``When did he (I) come here?'' (I)
I asked the woman.

``This morning, ma'am, I found him (I) at the corner of the town. I had known him (I) up in London yonder. Hadn't I, Jo?'' (unknown)

``Tom-all-Alone's,'' (the boy)
the boy replied.

Whenever he (boy) fixed his (boy) attention or his (boy) eyes, it was only for a very little while. He (boy) soon began to droop his (boy) head again, and roll it heavily, and speak as if he (boy) were half awake.

``When did he (I) come from London?'' (I)
I asked.

``I come from London yes`day,'' (the boy)
said the boy himself, now flushed and hot.
``I'm a-going somewheres.'' (unknown)

``Where is he (I) going?'' (I)
I asked.

``Somewheres,'' (the boy)
repeated the boy in a louder tone.
``I have been moved on, and moved on, more nor ever I was afore, since the t`other one give me the sov`ring. Mrs. Snagsby, she (Snagsby)'s always a-watching, and a-driving of me--what have I done to her (Snagsby)?--and they're all a-watching and a-driving of me. Every one of 'em's doing of it, from the time when I don't get up, to the time when I don't go to bed. And I'm a-going somewheres. That's where I'm a-going. She (Snagsby) told me, down in Tom-all-Alone's, as she (Snagsby) came from Stolbuns, and so I took the Stolbuns Road. It's as good as another.'' (He)

He (boy) always concluded by addressing Charley.

``What is to be done with him (I)?'' (I)
said I, taking the woman aside.
``He (I) could not travel in this state even if he (I) had a purpose and knew where he (I) was going!'' (unknown)

``I know no more, ma'am, than the dead,'' (she)
she (woman) replied, glancing compassionately at him (Charley).
``Perhaps the dead know better, if they could only tell us. I've kept him (I) here all day for pity's sake, and I've given him (I) broth and physic, and Liz has gone to try if any one will take him (I) in -LRB-here's my pretty in the bed--her (Liz) child, but I call it mine-RRB-; but I can't keep him (I) long, for if my husband was to come home and find him (husband) here, he (husband)'d be rough in putting him (husband) out and might do him (husband) a hurt. Hark! Here comes Liz back!'' (The woman)

The other woman came hurriedly in as she (woman) spoke, and the boy got up with a half-obscured sense that he (boy) was expected to be going. When the little child awoke, and when and how Charley got at it, took it out of bed, and began to walk about hushing it, I don't know. There she (woman) was, doing all this in a quiet motherly manner as if she (woman) were living in Mrs. Blinder's attic with Tom and Emma again.

The friend had been here and there, and had been played about from hand to hand, and had come back as she (Emma) went. At first it was too early for the boy to be received into the proper refuge, and at last it was too late. One official sent her (Emma) to another, and the other sent her (Emma) back again to the first, and so backward and forward, until it appeared to me as if both must have been appointed for their skill in evading their duties instead of performing them. And now, after all, she (Emma) said, breathing quickly, for she (Emma) had been running and was frightened too,

``Jenny, your master's on the road home, and mine's not far behind, and the Lord help the boy, for we can do no more for him (Lord)!'' (she)
They put a few halfpence together and hurried them into his (official) hand, and so, in an oblivious, half-thankful, half-insensible way, he (official) shuffled out of the house.

``Give me the child, my dear,'' (mother)
said its mother to Charley,
``and thank you kindly too! Jenny, woman dear, good night! Young lady, if my master don't fall out with me, I'll look down by the kiln by and by, where the boy will be most like, and again in the morning!'' (Charley)
She (mother) hurried off, and presently we passed her (mother) hushing and singing to her (mother) child at her (mother) own door and looking anxiously along the road for her (mother) drunken husband.

I was afraid of staying then to speak to either woman, lest I should bring her (woman) into trouble. But I said to Charley that we must not leave the boy to die. Charley, who knew what to do much better than I did, and whose quickness equalled her (woman) presence of mind, glided on before me, and presently we came up with Jo, just short of the brick-kiln.

I think he (Charley) must have begun his (Charley) journey with some small bundle under his (Charley) arm and must have had it stolen or lost it. For he (Charley) still carried his (Charley) wretched fragment of fur cap like a bundle, though he (Charley) went bare-headed through the rain, which now fell fast. He (Charley) stopped when we called to him (Charley) and again showed a dread of me when I came up, standing with his (Charley) lustrous eyes fixed upon me, and even arrested in his (Charley) shivering fit.

I asked him (Charley) to come with us, and we would take care that he (Charley) had some shelter for the night.

``I don't want no shelter,'' (he)
he (Charley) said;
``I can lay amongst the warm bricks.'' (he)

``But don't you know that people die there?'' (Charley)
replied Charley.

``They dies everywheres,'' (the boy)
said the boy.
``They dies in their lodgings--she (lady) knows where; I showed her (lady)--and they dies down in Tom-all-Alone's in heaps. They dies more than they lives, according to what I see.'' (he)
Then he (boy) hoarsely whispered Charley,
``If she (lady) ain't the t`other one, she (lady) ain't the forrenner. Is there THREE of 'em then?'' (Charley)

Charley looked at me a little frightened. I felt half frightened at myself when the boy glared on me so.

But he (boy) turned and followed when I beckoned to him (boy), and finding that he (boy) acknowledged that influence in me, I led the way straight home. It was not far, only at the summit of the hill. We passed but one man. I doubted if we should have got home without assistance, the boy's steps were so uncertain and tremulous. He (boy) made no complaint, however, and was strangely unconcerned about himself, if I may say so strange a thing.

Leaving him (boy) in the hall for a moment, shrunk into the corner of the window-seat and staring with an indifference that scarcely could be called wonder at the comfort and brightness about him (boy), I went into the drawing-room to speak to my guardian. There I found Mr. Skimpole, who had come down by the coach, as he (coach) frequently did without notice, and never bringing any clothes with him (coach), but always borrowing everything he (coach) wanted.

They came out with me directly to look at the boy. The servants had gathered in the hall too, and he (boy) shivered in the window-seat with Charley standing by him (boy), like some wounded animal that had been found in a ditch.

``This is a sorrowful case,'' (guardian)
said my guardian after asking him (boy) a question or two and touching him (boy) and examining his (boy) eyes.
``What do you say, Harold?'' (unknown)

``You had better turn him (Harold) out,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole.

``What do you mean?'' (guardian)
inquired my guardian, almost sternly.

``My dear Jarndyce,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole,
``you know what I am: I am a child. Be cross to me if I deserve it. But I have a constitutional objection to this sort of thing. I always had, when I was a medical man. He (man)'s not safe, you know. There's a very bad sort of fever about him (man).'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

Mr. Skimpole had retreated from the hall to the drawing-room again and said this in his (Skimpole) airy way, seated on the music-stool as we stood by.

``You'll say it's childish,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
observed Mr. Skimpole, looking gaily at us.
``Well, I dare say it may be; but I AM a child, and I never pretend to be anything else. If you put him (man) out in the road, you only put him (man) where he (man) was before. He (man) will be no worse off than he (man) was, you know. Even make him (man) better off, if you like. Give him (man) sixpence, or five shillings, or five pound ten--you are arithmeticians, and I am not--and get rid of him (man)!'' (unknown)

``And what is he (man) to do then?'' (guardian)
asked my guardian.

``Upon my life,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole, shrugging his (Skimpole) shoulders with his (Skimpole) engaging smile,
``I have not the least idea what he (man) is to do then. But I have no doubt he (man)'ll do it.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

``Now, is it not a horrible reflection,'' (guardian)
said my guardian, to whom I had hastily explained the unavailing efforts of the two women,
``is it not a horrible reflection,'' (the women)
walking up and down and rumpling his (Skimpole) hair,
``that if this wretched creature were a convicted prisoner, his (prisoner) hospital would be wide open to him (prisoner), and he (prisoner) would be as well taken care of as any sick boy in the kingdom?'' (the women)

``My dear Jarndyce,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
returned Mr. Skimpole, ``you'll pardon the simplicity of the question, coming as it does from a creature who is perfectly simple in worldly matters, but why ISN
``T he (Jarndyce) a prisoner then?'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

My guardian stopped and looked at him (Skimpole) with a whimsical mixture of amusement and indignation in his (Skimpole) face.

``Our young friend is not to be suspected of any delicacy, I should imagine,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole, unabashed and candid.
``It seems to me that it would be wiser, as well as in a certain kind of way more respectable, if he (friend) showed some misdirected energy that got him (friend) into prison. There would be more of an adventurous spirit in it, and consequently more of a certain sort of poetry.'' (unknown)

``I believe,'' (guardian)
returned my guardian, resuming his (Skimpole) uneasy walk,
``that there is not such another child on earth as yourself.'' (guardian)

``Do you really?'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole. ``I dare say! But I confess I don't see why our young friend, in his (friend) degree, should not seek to invest himself with such poetry as is open to him (friend). He (friend) is no doubt born with an appetite--probably, when he (friend) is in a safer state of health, he (friend) has an excellent appetite. Very well. At our young friend's natural dinner hour, most likely about noon, our young friend says in effect to society, ``I am hungry; will you have the goodness to produce your spoon and feed me?'' Society, which has taken upon itself the general arrangement of the whole system of spoons and professes to have a spoon for our young friend, does NOT produce that spoon; and our young friend, therefore, says ``You really must excuse me if I seize it.
'' Now, this appears to me a case of misdirected energy, which has a certain amount of reason in it and a certain amount of romance; and I don't know but what I should be more interested in our young friend, as an illustration of such a case, than merely as a poor vagabond--which any one can be.'' (I)

``In the meantime,'' (I)
I ventured to observe,
``he (friend) is getting worse.'' (I)

``In the meantime,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole cheerfully,
``as Miss Summerson, with her (Summerson) practical good sense, observes, he (friend) is getting worse. Therefore I recommend your turning him (friend) out before he (friend) gets still worse.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

The amiable face with which he (Skimpole) said it, I think I shall never forget.

``Of course, little woman,'' (woman guardian state)
observed my guardian, turning to me,
``I can ensure his (friend) admission into the proper place by merely going there to enforce it, though it's a bad state of things when, in his (friend) condition, that is necessary. But it's growing late, and is a very bad night, and the boy is worn out already. There is a bed in the wholesome loft-room by the stable; we had better keep him (boy) there till morning, when he (boy) can be wrapped up and removed. We'll do that.'' (me)

``Oh!'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole, with his (Skimpole) hands upon the keys of the piano as we moved away.
``Are you going back to our young friend?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (guardian)
said my guardian.

``How I envy you your constitution, Jarndyce!'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
returned Mr. Skimpole with playful admiration.
``You don't mind these things; neither does Miss Summerson. You are ready at all times to go anywhere, and do anything. Such is will! I have no will at all--and no won't--simply can't.'' (unknown)

``You can't recommend anything for the boy, I suppose?'' (guardian)
said my guardian, looking back over his (Skimpole) shoulder half angrily; only half angrily, for he (Skimpole) never seemed to consider Mr. Skimpole an accountable being.

``My dear Jarndyce, I observed a bottle of cooling medicine in his (Jarndyce) pocket, and it's impossible for him (Jarndyce) to do better than take it. You can tell them to sprinkle a little vinegar about the place where he (Jarndyce) sleeps and to keep it moderately cool and him (Jarndyce) moderately warm. But it is mere impertinence in me to offer any recommendation. Miss Summerson has such a knowledge of detail and such a capacity for the administration of detail that she (Summerson) knows all about it.'' (Jo)

We went back into the hall and explained to Jo what we proposed to do, which Charley explained to him (Charley) again and which he (Charley) received with the languid unconcern I had already noticed, wearily looking on at what was done as if it were for somebody else. The servants compassionating his (Charley) miserable state and being very anxious to help, we soon got the loft-room ready; and some of the men about the house carried him (Charley) across the wet yard, well wrapped up. It was pleasant to observe how kind they were to him (Charley) and how there appeared to be a general impression among them that frequently calling him (Charley)

``Old Chap'' (him)
was likely to revive his (Charley) spirits. Charley directed the operations and went to and fro between the loft-room and the house with such little stimulants and comforts as we thought it safe to give him (Charley). My guardian himself saw him (Charley) before he (Charley) was left for the night and reported to me when he (Charley) returned to the growlery to write a letter on the boy's behalf, which a messenger was charged to deliver at day-light in the morning, that he (Charley) seemed easier and inclined to sleep. They had fastened his (Charley) door on the outside, he (Charley) said, in case of his (Charley) being delirious, but had so arranged that he (Charley) could not make any noise without being heard.

Ada being in our room with a cold, Mr. Skimpole was left alone all this time and entertained himself by playing snatches of pathetic airs and sometimes singing to them -LRB-as we heard at a distance-RRB- with great expression and feeling. When we rejoined him (Skimpole) in the drawing-room he (Skimpole) said he (Skimpole) would give us a little ballad which had come into his (Skimpole) head

``apropos of our young friend,'' (he)
and he (Skimpole) sang one about a peasant boy,

``Thrown on the wide world, doomed to wander and roam, Bereft of his (friend) parents, bereft of a home.'' (a peasant boy)

quite exquisitely. It was a song that always made him (Skimpole) cry, he (Skimpole) told us.

He (Skimpole) was extremely gay all the rest of the evening, for he (Skimpole) absolutely chirped--those were his (Skimpole) delighted words--when he (Skimpole) thought by what a happy talent for business he (Skimpole) was surrounded. He (Skimpole) gave us, in his (Skimpole) glass of negus,

``Better health to our young friend!'' (He)
and supposed and gaily pursued the case of his (Skimpole) being reserved like Whittington to become Lord Mayor of London. In that event, no doubt, he (Skimpole) would establish the Jarndyce Institution and the Summerson Almshouses, and a little annual Corporation Pilgrimage to St. Albans. He (Skimpole) had no doubt, he (Skimpole) said, that our young friend was an excellent boy in his (friend) way, but his (friend) way was not the Harold Skimpole way; what Harold Skimpole was, Harold Skimpole had found himself, to his (Skimpole) considerable surprise, when he (Skimpole) first made his (Skimpole) own acquaintance; he (Skimpole) had accepted himself with all his (Skimpole) failings and had thought it sound philosophy to make the best of the bargain; and he (Skimpole) hoped we would do the same.

Charley's last report was that the boy was quiet. I could see, from my window, the lantern they had left him (boy) burning quietly; and I went to bed very happy to think that he (boy) was sheltered.

There was more movement and more talking than usual a little before daybreak, and it awoke me. As I was dressing, I looked out of my window and asked one of our men who had been among the active sympathizers last night whether there was anything wrong about the house. The lantern was still burning in the loft-window.

``It's the boy, miss,'' (he)
said he (boy).

``Is he (friend) worse?'' (I)
I inquired.

``Gone, miss.

``Dead!'' (unknown)

``Dead, miss? No. Gone clean off.'' (he)

At what time of the night he (boy) had gone, or how, or why, it seemed hopeless ever to divine. The door remaining as it had been left, and the lantern standing in the window, it could only be supposed that he (boy) had got out by a trap in the floor which communicated with an empty cart-house below. But he (boy) had shut it down again, if that were so; and it looked as if it had not been raised. Nothing of any kind was missing. On this fact being clearly ascertained, we all yielded to the painful belief that delirium had come upon him (boy) in the night and that, allured by some imaginary object or pursued by some imaginary horror, he (boy) had strayed away in that worse than helpless state; all of us, that is to say, but Mr. Skimpole, who repeatedly suggested, in his (Skimpole) usual easy light style, that it had occurred to our young friend that he (friend) was not a safe inmate, having a bad kind of fever upon him (friend), and that he (friend) had with great natural politeness taken himself off.

Every possible inquiry was made, and every place was searched. The brick-kilns were examined, the cottages were visited, the two women were particularly questioned, but they knew nothing of him (friend), and nobody could doubt that their wonder was genuine. The weather had for some time been too wet and the night itself had been too wet to admit of any tracing by footsteps. Hedge and ditch, and wall, and rick and stack, were examined by our men for a long distance round, lest the boy should be lying in such a place insensible or dead; but nothing was seen to indicate that he (boy) had ever been near. From the time when he (boy) was left in the loft-room, he (boy) vanished.

The search continued for five days. I do not mean that it ceased even then, but that my attention was then diverted into a current very memorable to me.

As Charley was at her (I) writing again in my room in the evening, and as I sat opposite to her (I) at work, I felt the table tremble. Looking up, I saw my little maid shivering from head to foot.

``Charley,'' (I)
said I,
``are you so cold?'' (I)

``I think I am, miss,'' (she)
she (maid) replied.
``I don't know what it is. I can't hold myself still. I felt so yesterday at about this same time, miss. Don't be uneasy, I think I'm ill.'' (I)

I heard Ada's voice outside, and I hurried to the door of communication between my room and our pretty sitting-room, and locked it. Just in time, for she (maid) tapped at it while my hand was yet upon the key.

Ada called to me to let her (Ada) in, but I said,

``Not now, my dearest. Go away. There's nothing the matter; I will come to you presently.'' (I)
Ah! It was a long, long time before my darling girl and I were companions again.

Charley fell ill. In twelve hours she (girl) was very ill. I moved her (girl) to my room, and laid her (girl) in my bed, and sat down quietly to nurse her (nurse). I told my guardian all about it, and why I felt it was necessary that I should seclude myself, and my reason for not seeing my darling above all. At first she (nurse) came very often to the door, and called to me, and even reproached me with sobs and tears; but I wrote her (nurse) a long letter saying that she (nurse) made me anxious and unhappy and imploring her (nurse), as she (nurse) loved me and wished my mind to be at peace, to come no nearer than the garden. After that she (nurse) came beneath the window even oftener than she (nurse) had come to the door, and if I had learnt to love her (nurse) dear sweet voice before when we were hardly ever apart, how did I learn to love it then, when I stood behind the window-curtain listening and replying, but not so much as looking out! How did I learn to love it afterwards, when the harder time came!

They put a bed for me in our sitting-room; and by keeping the door wide open, I turned the two rooms into one, now that Ada had vacated that part of the house, and kept them always fresh and airy. There was not a servant in or about the house but was so good that they would all most gladly have come to me at any hour of the day or night without the least fear or unwillingness, but I thought it best to choose one worthy woman who was never to see Ada and whom I could trust to come and go with all precaution. Through her (Ada) means I got out to take the air with my guardian when there was no fear of meeting Ada, and wanted for nothing in the way of attendance, any more than in any other respect.

And thus poor Charley sickened and grew worse, and fell into heavy danger of death, and lay severely ill for many a long round of day and night. So patient she (Ada) was, so uncomplaining, and inspired by such a gentle fortitude that very often as I sat by Charley holding her (Ada) head in my arms--repose would come to her (Ada), so, when it would come to her (Ada) in no other attitude--I silently prayed to our Father in heaven that I might not forget the lesson which this little sister taught me.

I was very sorrowful to think that Charley's pretty looks would change and be disfigured, even if she (sister) recovered--she (sister) was such a child with her (sister) dimpled face--but that thought was, for the greater part, lost in her (sister) greater peril. When she (sister) was at the worst, and her (sister) mind rambled again to the cares of her (sister) father's sick bed and the little children, she (sister) still knew me so far as that she (sister) would be quiet in my arms when she (sister) could lie quiet nowhere else, and murmur out the wanderings of her (sister) mind less restlessly. At those times I used to think, how should I ever tell the two remaining babies that the baby who had learned of her (sister) faithful heart to be a mother to them in their need was dead!

There were other times when Charley knew me well and talked to me, telling me that she (sister) sent her (sister) love to Tom and Emma and that she (sister) was sure Tom would grow up to be a good man. At those times Charley would speak to me of what she (sister) had read to her (sister) father as well as she (sister) could to comfort him (Charley), of that young man carried out to be buried who was the only son of his (son) mother and she (mother) was a widow, of the ruler's daughter raised up by the gracious hand upon her (mother) bed of death. And Charley told me that when her (mother) father died she (mother) had kneeled down and prayed in her (mother) first sorrow that he (Charley) likewise might be raised up and given back to his (Charley) poor children, and that if she (mother) should never get better and should die too, she (mother) thought it likely that it might come into Tom's mind to offer the same prayer for her (mother). Then would I show Tom how these people of old days had been brought back to life on earth, only that we might know our hope to be restored to heaven!

But of all the various times there were in Charley's illness, there was not one when she (mother) lost the gentle qualities I have spoken of. And there were many, many when I thought in the night of the last high belief in the watching angel, and the last higher trust in God, on the part of her (mother) poor despised father.

And Charley did not die. She (mother) flutteringly and slowly turned the dangerous point, after long lingering there, and then began to mend. The hope that never had been given, from the first, of Charley being in outward appearance Charley any more soon began to be encouraged; and even that prospered, and I saw her (mother) growing into her (mother) old childish likeness again.

It was a great morning when I could tell Ada all this as she (Ada) stood out in the garden; and it was a great evening when Charley and I at last took tea together in the next room. But on that same evening, I felt that I was stricken cold.

Happily for both of us, it was not until Charley was safe in bed again and placidly asleep that I began to think the contagion of her (Ada) illness was upon me. I had been able easily to hide what I felt at tea-time, but I was past that already now, and I knew that I was rapidly following in Charley's steps.

I was well enough, however, to be up early in the morning, and to return my darling's cheerful blessing from the garden, and to talk with her (Ada) as long as usual. But I was not free from an impression that I had been walking about the two rooms in the night, a little beside myself, though knowing where I was; and I felt confused at times--with a curious sense of fullness, as if I were becoming too large altogether.

In the evening I was so much worse that I resolved to prepare Charley, with which view I said,

``You're getting quite strong, Charley, are you not?'' (I)

``Oh, quite!'' (Charley)
said Charley.

``Strong enough to be told a secret, I think, Charley?'' (unknown)

``Quite strong enough for that, miss!'' (Charley)
cried Charley. But Charley's face fell in the height of her (Ada) delight, for she (Ada) saw the secret in MY face; and she (Ada) came out of the great chair, and fell upon my bosom, and said
``Oh, miss, it's my doing! It's my doing!'' (she)
and a great deal more out of the fullness of her (Ada) grateful heart.

``Now, Charley,'' (I)
said I after letting her (Ada) go on for a little while,
``if I am to be ill, my great trust, humanly speaking, is in you. And unless you are as quiet and composed for me as you always were for yourself, you can never fulfil it, Charley.'' (I)

``If you'll let me cry a little longer, miss,'' (Charley)
said Charley.
``Oh, my dear, my dear! If you'll only let me cry a little longer. Oh, my dear!'' (she)
--how affectionately and devotedly she (Ada) poured this out as she (Ada) clung to my neck, I never can remember without tears--
``I'll be good.'' (I)

So I let Charley cry a little longer, and it did us both good.

``Trust in me now, if you please, miss,'' (Charley)
said Charley quietly.
``I am listening to everything you say.'' (unknown)

``It's very little at present, Charley. I shall tell your doctor to-night that I don't think I am well and that you are going to nurse me.'' (the child)

For that the poor child thanked me with her (Ada) whole heart.

``And in the morning, when you hear Miss Ada in the garden, if I should not be quite able to go to the window-curtain as usual, do you go, Charley, and say I am asleep--that I have rather tired myself, and am asleep. At all times keep the room as I have kept it, Charley, and let no one come.'' (Charley)

Charley promised, and I lay down, for I was very heavy. I saw the doctor that night and asked the favour of him (Charley) that I wished to ask relative to his (Charley) saying nothing of my illness in the house as yet. I have a very indistinct remembrance of that night melting into day, and of day melting into night again; but I was just able on the first morning to get to the window and speak to my darling.

On the second morning I heard her (Ada) dear voice--Oh, how dear now!--outside; and I asked Charley, with some difficulty -LRB-speech being painful to me-RRB-, to go and say I was asleep. I heard her (Ada) answer softly,

``Don't disturb her (Ada), Charley, for the world!'' (I)

``How does my own Pride look, Charley?'' (I)
I inquired.

``Disappointed, miss,'' (Charley)
said Charley, peeping through the curtain.

``But I know she (Ada) is very beautiful this morning.'' (unknown)

``She (Ada) is indeed, miss,'' (Charley)
answered Charley, peeping.
``Still looking up at the window.'' (God)

With her (Ada) blue clear eyes, God bless them, always loveliest when raised like that!

I called Charley to me and gave her (Ada) her (Ada) last charge.

``Now, Charley, when she (Ada) knows I am ill, she (Ada) will try to make her (Ada) way into the room. Keep her (Ada) out, Charley, if you love me truly, to the last! Charley, if you let her (Ada) in but once, only to look upon me for one moment as I lie here, I shall die.'' (unknown)

``I never will! I never will!'' (she)
she (Ada) promised me.

``I believe it, my dear Charley. And now come and sit beside me for a little while, and touch me with your hand. For I cannot see you, Charley; I am blind.'' (Lincoln)

CHAPTER XXXII

The Appointed Time

It is night in Lincoln's Inn--perplexed and troublous valley of the shadow of the law, where suitors generally find but little day--and fat candles are snuffed out in offices, and clerks have rattled down the crazy wooden stairs and dispersed. The bell that rings at nine o'clock has ceased its doleful clangour about nothing; the gates are shut; and the night-porter, a solemn warder with a mighty power of sleep, keeps guard in his (guard) lodge. From tiers of staircase windows clogged lamps like the eyes of Equity, bleared Argus with a fathomless pocket for every eye and an eye upon it, dimly blink at the stars. In dirty upper casements, here and there, hazy little patches of candlelight reveal where some wise draughtsman and conveyancer yet toils for the entanglement of real estate in meshes of sheep-skin, in the average ratio of about a dozen of sheep to an acre of land. Over which bee-like industry these benefactors of their species linger yet, though office-hours be past, that they may give, for every day, some good account at last.

In the neighbouring court, where the Lord Chancellor of the rag and bottle shop dwells, there is a general tendency towards beer and supper. Mrs. Piper and Mrs. Perkins, whose respective sons, engaged with a circle of acquaintance in the game of hide and seek, have been lying in ambush about the by-ways of Chancery Lane for some hours and scouring the plain of the same thoroughfare to the confusion of passengers--Mrs. Piper and Mrs. Perkins have but now exchanged congratulations on the children being abed, and they still linger on a door-step over a few parting words. Mr. Krook and his (Krook) lodger, and the fact of Mr. Krook's being

``continually in liquor,'' (Krook/Mr. Krook)
and the testamentary prospects of the young man are, as usual, the staple of their conversation. But they have something to say, likewise, of the Harmonic Meeting at the Sol's Arms, where the sound of the piano through the partly opened windows jingles out into the court, and where Little Swills, after keeping the lovers of harmony in a roar like a very Yorick, may now be heard taking the gruff line in a concerted piece and sentimentally adjuring his (Sol) friends and patrons to
``Listen, listen, listen, tew the wa-ter fall!'' (patrons)
Mrs. Perkins and Mrs. Piper compare opinions on the subject of the young lady of professional celebrity who assists at the Harmonic Meetings and who has a space to herself in the manuscript announcement in the window, Mrs. Perkins possessing information that she (Perkins) has been married a year and a half, though announced as Miss M. Melvilleson, the noted siren, and that her (Melvilleson) baby is clandestinely conveyed to the Sol's Arms every night to receive its natural nourishment during the entertainments.
``Sooner than which, myself,'' (Mrs. Perkins/Perkins)
says Mrs. Perkins,
``I would get my living by selling lucifers.'' (Mrs. Perkins/Perkins)
Mrs. Piper, as in duty bound, is of the same opinion, holding that a private station is better than public applause, and thanking heaven for her (Perkins) own -LRB-and, by implication, Mrs. Perkins'-RRB- respectability.
