By this time the pot-boy of the Sol's Arms appearing with her (Perkins) supper-pint well frothed, Mrs. Piper accepts that tankard and retires indoors, first giving a fair good night to Mrs. Perkins, who has had her (Perkins) own pint in her (Perkins) hand ever since it was fetched from the same hostelry by young Perkins before he (Sol) was sent to bed. Now there is a sound of putting up shop-shutters in the court and a smell as of the smoking of pipes; and shooting stars are seen in upper windows, further indicating retirement to rest. Now, too, the policeman begins to push at doors; to try fastenings; to be suspicious of bundles; and to administer his (policeman) beat, on the hypothesis that every one is either robbing or being robbed.

It is a close night, though the damp cold is searching too, and there is a laggard mist a little way up in the air. It is a fine steaming night to turn the slaughter-houses, the unwholesome trades, the sewerage, bad water, and burial-grounds to account, and give the registrar of deaths some extra business. It may be something in the air--there is plenty in it--or it may be something in himself that is in fault; but Mr. Weevle, otherwise Jobling, is very ill at ease. He (Weevle) comes and goes between his (Weevle) own room and the open street door twenty times an hour. He (Weevle) has been doing so ever since it fell dark. Since the Chancellor shut up his (Chancellor) shop, which he (Chancellor) did very early to-night, Mr. Weevle has been down and up, and down and up -LRB-with a cheap tight velvet skull-cap on his (Weevle) head, making his (Weevle) whiskers look out of all proportion-RRB-, oftener than before.

It is no phenomenon that Mr. Snagsby should be ill at ease too, for he (Snagsby) always is so, more or less, under the oppressive influence of the secret that is upon him (Snagsby). Impelled by the mystery of which he (Snagsby) is a partaker and yet in which he (Snagsby) is not a sharer, Mr. Snagsby haunts what seems to be its fountain-head--the rag and bottle shop in the court. It has an irresistible attraction for him (Snagsby). Even now, coming round by the Sol's Arms with the intention of passing down the court, and out at the Chancery Lane end, and so terminating his (Lane) unpremeditated after-supper stroll of ten minutes' long from his (Lane) own door and back again, Mr. Snagsby approaches.

``What, Mr. Weevle?'' (the stationer)
says the stationer, stopping to speak.
``Are YOU there?'' (unknown)

``Aye!'' (Mr. Weevle/Weevle)
says Weevle,
``Here I am, Mr. Snagsby.'' (Mr. Weevle/Weevle)

``Airing yourself, as I am doing, before you go to bed?'' (the stationer)
the stationer inquires.

``Why, there's not much air to be got here; and what there is, is not very freshening,'' (unknown)
Weevle answers, glancing up and down the court.

``Very true, sir. Don't you observe,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby, pausing to sniff and taste the air a little,
``don't you observe, Mr. Weevle, that you're--not to put too fine a point upon it--that you're rather greasy here, sir?'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``Why, I have noticed myself that there is a queer kind of flavour in the place to-night,'' (Mr. Weevle/Weevle)
Mr. Weevle rejoins.
``I suppose it's chops at the Sol's Arms.'' (unknown)

``Chops, do you think? Oh! Chops, eh?'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
Mr. Snagsby sniffs and tastes again.
``Well, sir, I suppose it is. But I should say their cook at the Sol wanted a little looking after. She (Sol) has been burning 'em, sir! And I don't think'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
--Mr. Snagsby sniffs and tastes again and then spits and wipes his (Snagsby) mouth--
``I don't think--not to put too fine a point upon it--that they were quite fresh when they were shown the gridiron.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``That's very likely. It's a tainting sort of weather.'' (unknown)

``It IS a tainting sort of weather,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby,
``and I find it sinking to the spirits.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``By George! I find it gives me the horrors,'' (Mr. Weevle/Weevle)
returns Mr. Weevle.

``Then, you see, you live in a lonesome way, and in a lonesome room, with a black circumstance hanging over it,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby, looking in past the other's shoulder along the dark passage and then falling back a step to look up at the house.
``I couldn't live in that room alone, as you do, sir. I should get so fidgety and worried of an evening, sometimes, that I should be driven to come to the door and stand here sooner than sit there. But then it's very true that you didn't see, in your room, what I saw there. That makes a difference.'' (unknown)

``I know quite enough about it,'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)
returns Tony.

``It's not agreeable, is it?'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
pursues Mr. Snagsby, coughing his (Snagsby) cough of mild persuasion behind his (Snagsby) hand.
``Mr. Krook ought to consider it in the rent. I hope he (Krook) does, I am sure.'' (unknown)

``I hope he (Krook) does,'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)
says Tony.
``But I doubt it.'' (unknown)

``You find the rent too high, do you, sir?'' (returns the stationer)
returns the stationer.
``Rents ARE high about here. I don't know how it is exactly, but the law seems to put things up in price. Not,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
adds Mr. Snagsby with his (Snagsby) apologetic cough,
``that I mean to say a word against the profession I get my living by.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

Mr. Weevle again glances up and down the court and then looks at the stationer. Mr. Snagsby, blankly catching his (Snagsby) eye, looks upward for a star or so and coughs a cough expressive of not exactly seeing his (Snagsby) way out of this conversation.

``It's a curious fact, sir,'' (he)
he (Snagsby) observes, slowly rubbing his (Snagsby) hands,
``that he (Krook) should have been--'' (he)

``Who's he (Krook)?'' (he)
interrupts Mr. Weevle.

``The deceased, you know,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby, twitching his (Snagsby) head and right eyebrow towards the staircase and tapping his (Snagsby) acquaintance on the button.

``Ah, to be sure!'' (he)
returns the other as if he (Snagsby) were not over-fond of the subject.
``I thought we had done with him (Krook).'' (unknown)

``I was only going to say it's a curious fact, sir, that he (Krook) should have come and lived here, and been one of my writers, and then that you should come and live here, and be one of my writers too. Which there is nothing derogatory, but far from it in the appellation,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby, breaking off with a mistrust that he (Snagsby) may have unpolitely asserted a kind of proprietorship in Mr. Weevle,
``because I have known writers that have gone into brewers' houses and done really very respectable indeed. Eminently respectable, sir,'' (Mr. Weevle/Weevle)
adds Mr. Snagsby with a misgiving that he (Snagsby) has not improved the matter.

``It's a curious coincidence, as you say,'' (unknown)
answers Weevle, once more glancing up and down the court.

``Seems a fate in it, don't there?'' (the stationer)
suggests the stationer.

``There does.'' (unknown)

``Just so,'' (the stationer)
observes the stationer with his (Snagsby) confirmatory cough.
``Quite a fate in it. Quite a fate. Well, Mr. Weevle, I am afraid I must bid you good night'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
--Mr. Snagsby speaks as if it made him (Snagsby) desolate to go, though he (Snagsby) has been casting about for any means of escape ever since he (Snagsby) stopped to speak--
``my little woman will be looking for me else. Good night, sir!'' (he)

If Mr. Snagsby hastens home to save his (Snagsby) little woman the trouble of looking for him (Snagsby), he (Snagsby) might set his (Snagsby) mind at rest on that score. His (Snagsby) little woman has had her (woman) eye upon him (Snagsby) round the Sol's Arms all this time and now glides after him (Sol) with a pocket handkerchief wrapped over her (woman) head, honouring Mr. Weevle and his (Weevle) doorway with a searching glance as she (woman) goes past.

``You'll know me again, ma'am, at all events,'' (Mr. Weevle/Weevle)
says Mr. Weevle to himself;
``and I can't compliment you on your appearance, whoever you are, with your head tied up in a bundle. Is this fellow NEVER coming!'' (Mr. Weevle/Weevle)

This fellow approaches as he (Weevle) speaks. Mr. Weevle softly holds up his (Weevle) finger, and draws him (Weevle) into the passage, and closes the street door. Then they go upstairs, Mr. Weevle heavily, and Mr. Guppy -LRB-for it is he (Guppy)-RRB- very lightly indeed. When they are shut into the back room, they speak low.

``I thought you had gone to Jericho at least instead of coming here,'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)
says Tony.

``Why, I said about ten.'' (unknown)

``You said about ten,'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)
Tony repeats.
``Yes, so you did say about ten. But according to my count, it's ten times ten--it's a hundred o'clock. I never had such a night in my life!'' (unknown)

``What has been the matter?'' (unknown)

``That's it!'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)
says Tony. ``Nothing has been the matter. But here have I been stewing and fuming in this jolly old crib till I have had the horrors falling on me as thick as hail. THERE
``S a blessed-looking candle!'' (unknown)
says Tony, pointing to the heavily burning taper on his (Tony) table with a great cabbage head and a long winding-sheet.

``That's easily improved,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
Mr. Guppy observes as he (Guppy) takes the snuffers in hand.

``IS it?'' (returns friend)
returns his (Guppy) friend.
``Not so easily as you think. It has been smouldering like that ever since it was lighted.'' (unknown)

``Why, what's the matter with you, Tony?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
inquires Mr. Guppy, looking at him (Guppy), snuffers in hand, as he (Guppy) sits down with his (Guppy) elbow on the table.

``William Guppy,'' (unknown)
replies the other,
``I am in the downs. It's this unbearably dull, suicidal room--and old Boguey downstairs, I suppose.'' (Mr. Weevle/Weevle)
Mr. Weevle moodily pushes the snuffers-tray from him (Weevle) with his (Weevle) elbow, leans his (Weevle) head on his (Weevle) hand, puts his (Weevle) feet on the fender, and looks at the fire. Mr. Guppy, observing him (Guppy), slightly tosses his (Guppy) head and sits down on the other side of the table in an easy attitude.

``Wasn't that Snagsby talking to you, Tony?'' (unknown)

``Yes, and he (Tony)--yes, it was Snagsby,'' (Mr. Weevle/Weevle)
said Mr. Weevle, altering the construction of his (Weevle) sentence.

``On business?'' (unknown)

``No. No business. He (Tony) was only sauntering by and stopped to prose.'' (unknown)

``I thought it was Snagsby,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy,
``and thought it as well that he (Tony) shouldn't see me, so I waited till he (Tony) was gone.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``There we go again, William G.!'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)
cried Tony, looking up for an instant.
``So mysterious and secret! By George, if we were going to commit a murder, we couldn't have more mystery about it!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Mr. Guppy affects to smile, and with the view of changing the conversation, looks with an admiration, real or pretended, round the room at the Galaxy Gallery of British Beauty, terminating his (Guppy) survey with the portrait of Lady Dedlock over the mantelshelf, in which she (Dedlock) is represented on a terrace, with a pedestal upon the terrace, and a vase upon the pedestal, and her (Dedlock) shawl upon the vase, and a prodigious piece of fur upon the shawl, and her (Dedlock) arm on the prodigious piece of fur, and a bracelet on her (Dedlock) arm.

``That's very like Lady Dedlock,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy.
``It's a speaking likeness.'' (unknown)

``I wish it was,'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)
growls Tony, without changing his (Tony) position.
``I should have some fashionable conversation, here, then.'' (friend)

Finding by this time that his (Tony) friend is not to be wheedled into a more sociable humour, Mr. Guppy puts about upon the ill-used tack and remonstrates with him (Guppy).

``Tony,'' (he)
says he (Guppy),
``I can make allowances for lowness of spirits, for no man knows what it is when it does come upon a man better than I do, and no man perhaps has a better right to know it than a man who has an unrequited image imprinted on his (man) `eart. But there are bounds to these things when an unoffending party is in question, and I will acknowledge to you, Tony, that I don't think your manner on the present occasion is hospitable or quite gentlemanly.'' (he)

``This is strong language, William Guppy,'' (Mr. Weevle/Weevle)
returns Mr. Weevle.

``Sir, it may be,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
retorts Mr. William Guppy,
``but I feel strongly when I use it.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Mr. Weevle admits that he (Weevle) has been wrong and begs Mr. William Guppy to think no more about it. Mr. William Guppy, however, having got the advantage, cannot quite release it without a little more injured remonstrance.

``No! Dash it, Tony,'' (gentleman)
says that gentleman,
``you really ought to be careful how you wound the feelings of a man who has an unrequited image imprinted on his (man) `eart and who is NOT altogether happy in those chords which vibrate to the tenderest emotions. You, Tony, possess in yourself all that is calculated to charm the eye and allure the taste. It is not--happily for you, perhaps, and I may wish that I could say the same--it is not your character to hover around one flower. The ole garden is open to you, and your airy pinions carry you through it. Still, Tony, far be it from me, I am sure, to wound even your feelings without a cause!'' (gentleman)

Tony again entreats that the subject may be no longer pursued, saying emphatically,

``William Guppy, drop it!'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)
Mr. Guppy acquiesces, with the reply,
``I never should have taken it up, Tony, of my own accord.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``And now,'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)
says Tony, stirring the fire,
``touching this same bundle of letters. Isn't it an extraordinary thing of Krook to have appointed twelve o'clock to-night to hand 'em over to me?'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)

``Very. What did he (Krook) do it for?'' (unknown)

``What does he (Krook) do anything for? HE (Krook) don't know. Said to-day was his (Krook) birthday and he (Krook)'d hand 'em over to-night at twelve o'clock. He (Krook)'ll have drunk himself blind by that time. He (Krook) has been at it all day.'' (unknown)

``He (Krook) hasn't forgotten the appointment, I hope?'' (unknown)

``Forgotten? Trust him (Krook) for that. He (Krook) never forgets anything. I saw him (Krook) to-night, about eight--helped him (Krook) to shut up his (Krook) shop--and he (Krook) had got the letters then in his (Krook) hairy cap. He (Krook) pulled it off and showed 'em me. When the shop was closed, he (Krook) took them out of his (Krook) cap, hung his (Krook) cap on the chair-back, and stood turning them over before the fire. I heard him (Krook) a little while afterwards, through the floor here, humming like the wind, the only song he (Krook) knows--about Bibo, and old Charon, and Bibo being drunk when he (Krook) died, or something or other. He (Krook) has been as quiet since as an old rat asleep in his (Krook) hole.'' (unknown)

``And you are to go down at twelve?'' (unknown)

``At twelve. And as I tell you, when you came it seemed to me a hundred.'' (unknown)

``Tony,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy after considering a little with his (Guppy) legs crossed,
``he (Tony) can't read yet, can he (Tony)?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``Read! He (Tony)'ll never read. He (Tony) can make all the letters separately, and he (Tony) knows most of them separately when he (Tony) sees them; he (Tony) has got on that much, under me; but he (Tony) can't put them together. He (Tony)'s too old to acquire the knack of it now--and too drunk.'' (unknown)

``Tony,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy, uncrossing and recrossing his (Guppy) legs,
``how do you suppose he (Tony) spelt out that name of Hawdon?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``He (Tony) never spelt it out. You know what a curious power of eye he (Tony) has and how he (Tony) has been used to employ himself in copying things by eye alone. He (Tony) imitated it, evidently from the direction of a letter, and asked me what it meant.'' (unknown)

``Tony,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy, uncrossing and recrossing his (Guppy) legs again,
``should you say that the original was a man's writing or a woman's?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``A woman's. Fifty to one a lady's--slopes a good deal, and the end of the letter ``n,

'' long and hasty.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Mr. Guppy has been biting his (Guppy) thumb-nail during this dialogue, generally changing the thumb when he (Guppy) has changed the cross leg. As he (Guppy) is going to do so again, he (Guppy) happens to look at his (Guppy) coat-sleeve. It takes his (Guppy) attention. He (Guppy) stares at it, aghast.

``Why, Tony, what on earth is going on in this house to-night? Is there a chimney on fire?'' (unknown)

``Chimney on fire!'' (unknown)

``Ah!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
returns Mr. Guppy.
``See how the soot's falling. See here, on my arm! See again, on the table here! Confound the stuff, it won't blow off--smears like black fat!'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)

They look at one another, and Tony goes listening to the door, and a little way upstairs, and a little way downstairs. Comes back and says it's all right and all quiet, and quotes the remark he (Tony) lately made to Mr. Snagsby about their cooking chops at the Sol's Arms.

``And it was then,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
resumes Mr. Guppy, still glancing with remarkable aversion at the coat-sleeve, as they pursue their conversation before the fire, leaning on opposite sides of the table, with their heads very near together,
``that he (Tony) told you of his (Tony) having taken the bundle of letters from his (Tony) lodger's portmanteau?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``That was the time, sir,'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)
answers Tony, faintly adjusting his (Tony) whiskers.
``Whereupon I wrote a line to my dear boy, the Honourable William Guppy, informing him (Guppy) of the appointment for to-night and advising him (Guppy) not to call before, Boguey being a slyboots.'' (Mr. Weevle/Weevle)

The light vivacious tone of fashionable life which is usually assumed by Mr. Weevle sits so ill upon him (Weevle) to-night that he (Weevle) abandons that and his (Weevle) whiskers together, and after looking over his (Weevle) shoulder, appears to yield himself up a prey to the horrors again.

``You are to bring the letters to your room to read and compare, and to get yourself into a position to tell him (Guppy) all about them. That's the arrangement, isn't it, Tony?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
asks Mr. Guppy, anxiously biting his (Guppy) thumb-nail.

``You can't speak too low. Yes. That's what he (Tony) and I agreed.'' (unknown)

``I tell you what, Tony--'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)

``You can't speak too low,'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)
says Tony once more. Mr. Guppy nods his (Guppy) sagacious head, advances it yet closer, and drops into a whisper.

``I tell you what. The first thing to be done is to make another packet like the real one so that if he (Tony) should ask to see the real one while it's in my possession, you can show him (Tony) the dummy.'' (unknown)

``And suppose he (Tony) detects the dummy as soon as he (Tony) sees it, which with his (Tony) biting screw of an eye is about five hundred times more likely than not,'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)
suggests Tony.

``Then we'll face it out. They don't belong to him (Tony), and they never did. You found that, and you placed them in my hands--a legal friend of yours--for security. If he (friend) forces us to it, they'll be producible, won't they?'' (unknown)

``Ye-es,'' (Mr. Weevle/Weevle)
is Mr. Weevle's reluctant admission.

``Why, Tony,'' (friend)
remonstrates his (Tony) friend,
``how you look! You don't doubt William Guppy? You don't suspect any harm?'' (friend)

``I don't suspect anything more than I know, William,'' (unknown)
returns the other gravely.

``And what do you know?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
urges Mr. Guppy, raising his (Guppy) voice a little; but on his (Guppy) friend's once more warning him (Guppy),
``I tell you, you can't speak too low,'' (him)
he (Guppy) repeats his (Guppy) question without any sound at all, forming with his (Guppy) lips only the words,
``What do you know?'' (he)

``I know three things. First, I know that here we are whispering in secrecy, a pair of conspirators.'' (unknown)

``Well!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy.
``And we had better be that than a pair of noodles, which we should be if we were doing anything else, for it's the only way of doing what we want to do. Secondly?'' (unknown)

``Secondly, it's not made out to me how it's likely to be profitable, after all.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Mr. Guppy casts up his (Guppy) eyes at the portrait of Lady Dedlock over the mantelshelf and replies,

``Tony, you are asked to leave that to the honour of your friend. Besides its being calculated to serve that friend in those chords of the human mind which--which need not be called into agonizing vibration on the present occasion--your friend is no fool. What's that?'' (Lady)

``It's eleven o'clock striking by the bell of Saint Paul's. Listen and you'll hear all the bells in the city jangling.'' (unknown)

Both sit silent, listening to the metal voices, near and distant, resounding from towers of various heights, in tones more various than their situations. When these at length cease, all seems more mysterious and quiet than before. One disagreeable result of whispering is that it seems to evoke an atmosphere of silence, haunted by the ghosts of sound--strange cracks and tickings, the rustling of garments that have no substance in them, and the tread of dreadful feet that would leave no mark on the sea-sand or the winter snow. So sensitive the two friends happen to be that the air is full of these phantoms, and the two look over their shoulders by one consent to see that the door is shut.

``Yes, Tony?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy, drawing nearer to the fire and biting his (Guppy) unsteady thumb-nail.
``You were going to say, thirdly?'' (unknown)

``It's far from a pleasant thing to be plotting about a dead man in the room where he (man) died, especially when you happen to live in it.'' (unknown)

``But we are plotting nothing against him (man), Tony.'' (unknown)

``May be not, still I don't like it. Live here by yourself and see how YOU like it.'' (unknown)

``As to dead men, Tony,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
proceeds Mr. Guppy, evading this proposal,
``there have been dead men in most rooms.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``I know there have, but in most rooms you let them alone, and--and they let you alone,'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)
Tony answers.

The two look at each other again. Mr. Guppy makes a hurried remark to the effect that they may be doing the deceased a service, that he (Guppy) hopes so. There is an oppressive blank until Mr. Weevle, by stirring the fire suddenly, makes Mr. Guppy start as if his (Guppy) heart had been stirred instead.

``Fah! Here's more of this hateful soot hanging about,'' (he)
says he (Guppy).
``Let us open the window a bit and get a mouthful of air. It's too close.'' (He)

He (Guppy) raises the sash, and they both rest on the window-sill, half in and half out of the room. The neighbouring houses are too near to admit of their seeing any sky without craning their necks and looking up, but lights in frowsy windows here and there, and the rolling of distant carriages, and the new expression that there is of the stir of men, they find to be comfortable. Mr. Guppy, noiselessly tapping on the window-sill, resumes his (Guppy) whispering in quite a light-comedy tone.

``By the by, Tony, don't forget old Smallweed,'' (unknown)
meaning the younger of that name.
``I have not let him (Tony) into this, you know. That grandfather of his (grandfather) is too keen by half. It runs in the family.'' (unknown)

``I remember,'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)
says Tony.
``I am up to all that.'' (unknown)

``And as to Krook,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
resumes Mr. Guppy.
``Now, do you suppose he (Krook) really has got hold of any other papers of importance, as he (Krook) has boasted to you, since you have been such allies?'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)

Tony shakes his (Tony) head.

``I don't know. Can't Imagine. If we get through this business without rousing his (Krook) suspicions, I shall be better informed, no doubt. How can I know without seeing them, when he (Krook) don't know himself? He (Krook) is always spelling out words from them, and chalking them over the table and the shop-wall, and asking what this is and what that is; but his (Krook) whole stock from beginning to end may easily be the waste-paper he (Krook) bought it as, for anything I can say. It's a monomania with him (Krook) to think he (Krook) is possessed of documents. He (Krook) has been going to learn to read them this last quarter of a century, I should judge, from what he (Krook) tells me.'' (unknown)

``How did he (Krook) first come by that idea, though? That's the question,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
Mr. Guppy suggests with one eye shut, after a little forensic meditation.
``He (Krook) may have found papers in something he (Krook) bought, where papers were not supposed to be, and may have got it into his (Krook) shrewd head from the manner and place of their concealment that they are worth something.'' (unknown)

``Or he (Krook) may have been taken in, in some pretended bargain. Or he (Krook) may have been muddled altogether by long staring at whatever he (Krook) HAS got, and by drink, and by hanging about the Lord Chancellor's Court and hearing of documents for ever,'' (Mr. Weevle/Weevle)
returns Mr. Weevle.

Mr. Guppy sitting on the window-sill, nodding his (Guppy) head and balancing all these possibilities in his (Guppy) mind, continues thoughtfully to tap it, and clasp it, and measure it with his (Guppy) hand, until he (Guppy) hastily draws his (Guppy) hand away.

``What, in the devil's name,'' (he)
he (Guppy) says,
``is this! Look at my fingers!'' (he)

A thick, yellow liquor defiles them, which is offensive to the touch and sight and more offensive to the smell. A stagnant, sickening oil with some natural repulsion in it that makes them both shudder.

``What have you been doing here? What have you been pouring out of window?'' (unknown)

``I pouring out of window! Nothing, I swear! Never, since I have been here!'' (the lodger)
cries the lodger.

And yet look here--and look here! When he (Guppy) brings the candle here, from the corner of the window-sill, it slowly drips and creeps away down the bricks, here lies in a little thick nauseous pool.

``This is a horrible house,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy, shutting down the window.
``Give me some water or I shall cut my hand off.'' (He)

He (Guppy) so washes, and rubs, and scrubs, and smells, and washes, that he (Guppy) has not long restored himself with a glass of brandy and stood silently before the fire when Saint Paul's bell strikes twelve and all those other bells strike twelve from their towers of various heights in the dark air, and in their many tones. When all is quiet again, the lodger says,

``It's the appointed time at last. Shall I go?'' (the lodger)

Mr. Guppy nods and gives him (Guppy) a

``lucky touch'' (him)
on the back, but not with the washed hand, though it is his (Guppy) right hand.

He (Guppy) goes downstairs, and Mr. Guppy tries to compose himself before the fire for waiting a long time. But in no more than a minute or two the stairs creak and Tony comes swiftly back.

``Have you got them?'' (unknown)

``Got them! No. The old man's not there.'' (He)

He (Tony) has been so horribly frightened in the short interval that his (Tony) terror seizes the other, who makes a rush at him (Tony) and asks loudly,

``What's the matter?'' (him)

``I couldn't make him (man) hear, and I softly opened the door and looked in. And the burning smell is there--and the soot is there, and the oil is there--and he (man) is not there!'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)
Tony ends this with a groan.

Mr. Guppy takes the light. They go down, more dead than alive, and holding one another, push open the door of the back shop. The cat has retreated close to it and stands snarling, not at them, at something on the ground before the fire. There is a very little fire left in the grate, but there is a smouldering, suffocating vapour in the room and a dark, greasy coating on the walls and ceiling. The chairs and table, and the bottle so rarely absent from the table, all stand as usual. On one chair-back hang the old man's hairy cap and coat.

``Look!'' (whispers the lodger)
whispers the lodger, pointing his (man) friend's attention to these objects with a trembling finger.
``I told you so. When I saw him (man) last, he (man) took his (man) cap off, took out the little bundle of old letters, hung his (man) cap on the back of the chair--his (man) coat was there already, for he (man) had pulled that off before he (man) went to put the shutters up--and I left him (man) turning the letters over in his (man) hand, standing just where that crumbled black thing is upon the floor.'' (he)

Is he (man) hanging somewhere? They look up. No.

``See!'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)
whispers Tony.
``At the foot of the same chair there lies a dirty bit of thin red cord that they tie up pens with. That went round the letters. He (man) undid it slowly, leering and laughing at me, before he (man) began to turn them over, and threw it there. I saw it fall.'' (unknown)

``What's the matter with the cat?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy.
``Look at her (I)!'' (unknown)

``Mad, I think. And no wonder in this evil place.'' (unknown)

They advance slowly, looking at all these things. The cat remains where they found her (Tony), still snarling at the something on the ground before the fire and between the two chairs. What is it? Hold up the light.

Here is a small burnt patch of flooring; here is the tinder from a little bundle of burnt paper, but not so light as usual, seeming to be steeped in something; and here is--is it the cinder of a small charred and broken log of wood sprinkled with white ashes, or is it coal? Oh, horror, he (Tony) IS here! And this from which we run away, striking out the light and overturning one another into the street, is all that represents him (Tony).

Help, help, help! Come into this house for heaven's sake! Plenty will come in, but none can help. The Lord Chancellor of that court, true to his (Chancellor) title in his (Chancellor) last act, has died the death of all lord chancellors in all courts and of all authorities in all places under all names soever, where false pretences are made, and where injustice is done. Call the death by any name your Highness will, attribute it to whom you will, or say it might have been prevented how you will, it is the same death eternally--inborn, inbred, engendered in the corrupted humours of the vicious body itself, and that only--spontaneous combustion, and none other of all the deaths that can be died.

CHAPTER XXXIII

Interlopers

Now do those two gentlemen not very neat about the cuffs and buttons who attended the last coroner's inquest at the Sol's Arms reappear in the precincts with surprising swiftness -LRB-being, in fact, breathlessly fetched by the active and intelligent beadle-RRB-, and institute perquisitions through the court, and dive into the Sol's parlour, and write with ravenous little pens on tissue-paper. Now do they note down, in the watches of the night, how the neighbourhood of Chancery Lane was yesterday, at about midnight, thrown into a state of the most intense agitation and excitement by the following alarming and horrible discovery. Now do they set forth how it will doubtless be remembered that some time back a painful sensation was created in the public mind by a case of mysterious death from opium occurring in the first floor of the house occupied as a rag, bottle, and general marine store shop, by an eccentric individual of intemperate habits, far advanced in life, named Krook; and how, by a remarkable coincidence, Krook was examined at the inquest, which it may be recollected was held on that occasion at the Sol's Arms, a well-conducted tavern immediately adjoining the premises in question on the west side and licensed to a highly respectable landlord, Mr. James George Bogsby. Now do they show -LRB-in as many words as possible-RRB- how during some hours of yesterday evening a very peculiar smell was observed by the inhabitants of the court, in which the tragical occurrence which forms the subject of that present account transpired; and which odour was at one time so powerful that Mr. Swills, a comic vocalist professionally engaged by Mr. J. G. Bogsby, has himself stated to our reporter that he (Bogsby) mentioned to Miss M. Melvilleson, a lady of some pretensions to musical ability, likewise engaged by Mr. J. G. Bogsby to sing at a series of concerts called Harmonic Assemblies, or Meetings, which it would appear are held at the Sol's Arms under Mr. Bogsby's direction pursuant to the Act of George the Second, that he (George) -LRB-Mr. Swills-RRB- found his (George) voice seriously affected by the impure state of the atmosphere, his (George) jocose expression at the time being that he (George) was like an empty post-office, for he (George) hadn't a single note in him (George). How this account of Mr. Swills is entirely corroborated by two intelligent married females residing in the same court and known respectively by the names of Mrs. Piper and Mrs. Perkins, both of whom observed the foetid effluvia and regarded them as being emitted from the premises in the occupation of Krook, the unfortunate deceased. All this and a great deal more the two gentlemen who have formed an amicable partnership in the melancholy catastrophe write down on the spot; and the boy population of the court -LRB-out of bed in a moment-RRB- swarm up the shutters of the Sol's Arms parlour, to behold the tops of their heads while they are about it.

The whole court, adult as well as boy, is sleepless for that night, and can do nothing but wrap up its many heads, and talk of the ill-fated house, and look at it. Miss Flite has been bravely rescued from her (they) chamber, as if it were in flames, and accommodated with a bed at the Sol's Arms. The Sol neither turns off its gas nor shuts its door all night, for any kind of public excitement makes good for the Sol and causes the court to stand in need of comfort. The house has not done so much in the stomachic article of cloves or in brandy-and-water warm since the inquest. The moment the pot-boy heard what had happened, he (Sol) rolled up his (Sol) shirt-sleeves tight to his (Sol) shoulders and said,

``There'll be a run upon us!'' (shirt-sleeves)
In the first outcry, young Piper dashed off for the fire-engines and returned in triumph at a jolting gallop perched up aloft on the Phoenix and holding on to that fabulous creature with all his (Sol) might in the midst of helmets and torches. One helmet remains behind after careful investigation of all chinks and crannies and slowly paces up and down before the house in company with one of the two policemen who have likewise been left in charge thereof. To this trio everybody in the court possessed of sixpence has an insatiate desire to exhibit hospitality in a liquid form.

Mr. Weevle and his (Weevle) friend Mr. Guppy are within the bar at the Sol and are worth anything to the Sol that the bar contains if they will only stay there.

``This is not a time,'' (Mr. Bogsby/Mr. J. G. Bogsby)
says Mr. Bogsby,
``to haggle about money,'' (Mr. Bogsby/Mr. J. G. Bogsby)
though he (Bogsby) looks something sharply after it, over the counter;
``give your orders, you two gentlemen, and you're welcome to whatever you put a name to.'' (he)

Thus entreated, the two gentlemen -LRB-Mr. Weevle especially-RRB- put names to so many things that in course of time they find it difficult to put a name to anything quite distinctly, though they still relate to all new-comers some version of the night they have had of it, and of what they said, and what they thought, and what they saw. Meanwhile, one or other of the policemen often flits about the door, and pushing it open a little way at the full length of his (Weevle) arm, looks in from outer gloom. Not that he (Weevle) has any suspicions, but that he (Weevle) may as well know what they are up to in there.

Thus night pursues its leaden course, finding the court still out of bed through the unwonted hours, still treating and being treated, still conducting itself similarly to a court that has had a little money left it unexpectedly. Thus night at length with slow-retreating steps departs, and the lamp-lighter going his (Weevle) rounds, like an executioner to a despotic king, strikes off the little heads of fire that have aspired to lessen the darkness. Thus the day cometh, whether or no.

And the day may discern, even with its dim London eye, that the court has been up all night. Over and above the faces that have fallen drowsily on tables and the heels that lie prone on hard floors instead of beds, the brick and mortar physiognomy of the very court itself looks worn and jaded. And now the neighbourhood, waking up and beginning to hear of what has happened, comes streaming in, half dressed, to ask questions; and the two policemen and the helmet -LRB-who are far less impressible externally than the court-RRB- have enough to do to keep the door.

``Good gracious, gentlemen!'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby, coming up.
``What's this I hear!'' (unknown)

``Why, it's true,'' (the policemen)
returns one of the policemen.
``That's what it is. Now move on here, come!'' (unknown)

``Why, good gracious, gentlemen,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby, somewhat promptly backed away,
``I was at this door last night betwixt ten and eleven o'clock in conversation with the young man who lodges here.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``Indeed?'' (returns the policeman)
returns the policeman.
``You will find the young man next door then. Now move on here, some of you.'' (unknown)

``Not hurt, I hope?'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby.

``Hurt? No. What's to hurt him (Hurt)!'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

Mr. Snagsby, wholly unable to answer this or any question in his (Snagsby) troubled mind, repairs to the Sol's Arms and finds Mr. Weevle languishing over tea and toast with a considerable expression on him (Weevle) of exhausted excitement and exhausted tobacco-smoke.

``And Mr. Guppy likewise!'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
quoth Mr. Snagsby.
``Dear, dear, dear! What a fate there seems in all this! And my lit--'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

Mr. Snagsby's power of speech deserts him (Snagsby) in the formation of the words

``my little woman.'' (him)
For to see that injured female walk into the Sol's Arms at that hour of the morning and stand before the beer-engine, with her (Snagsby) eyes fixed upon him (Sol) like an accusing spirit, strikes him (Sol) dumb.

``My dear,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby when his (Snagsby) tongue is loosened,
``will you take anything? A little--not to put too fine a point upon it--drop of shrub?'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``No,'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
says Mrs. Snagsby.

``My love, you know these two gentlemen?'' (unknown)

``Yes!'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
says Mrs. Snagsby, and in a rigid manner acknowledges their presence, still fixing Mr. Snagsby with her (Snagsby) eye.

The devoted Mr. Snagsby cannot bear this treatment. He (Snagsby) takes Mrs. Snagsby by the hand and leads her (Snagsby) aside to an adjacent cask.

``My little woman, why do you look at me in that way? Pray don't do it.'' (unknown)

``I can't help my looks,'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
says Mrs. Snagsby,
``and if I could I wouldn't.'' (Mrs. Snagsby)

Mr. Snagsby, with his (Snagsby) cough of meekness, rejoins,

``Wouldn't you really, my dear?'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
and meditates. Then coughs his (Snagsby) cough of trouble and says,
``This is a dreadful mystery, my love!'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
still fearfully disconcerted by Mrs. Snagsby's eye.

``It IS,'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
returns Mrs. Snagsby, shaking her (Snagsby) head,
``a dreadful mystery.'' (Mrs. Snagsby)

``My little woman,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
urges Mr. Snagsby in a piteous manner,
``don't for goodness' sake speak to me with that bitter expression and look at me in that searching way! I beg and entreat of you not to do it. Good Lord, you don't suppose that I would go spontaneously combusting any person, my dear?'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``I can't say,'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
returns Mrs. Snagsby.

On a hasty review of his (Snagsby) unfortunate position, Mr. Snagsby

``can't say'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
either. He (Snagsby) is not prepared positively to deny that he (Snagsby) may have had something to do with it. He (Snagsby) has had something--he (Snagsby) don't know what--to do with so much in this connexion that is mysterious that it is possible he (Snagsby) may even be implicated, without knowing it, in the present transaction. He (Snagsby) faintly wipes his (Snagsby) forehead with his (Snagsby) handkerchief and gasps.

``My life,'' (the stationer)
says the unhappy stationer,
``would you have any objections to mention why, being in general so delicately circumspect in your conduct, you come into a wine-vaults before breakfast?'' (the stationer)

``Why do YOU come here?'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
inquires Mrs. Snagsby.

``My dear, merely to know the rights of the fatal accident which has happened to the venerable party who has been--combusted.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
Mr. Snagsby has made a pause to suppress a groan.
``I should then have related them to you, my love, over your French roll.'' (unknown)

``I dare say you would! You relate everything to me, Mr. Snagsby.'' (unknown)

``Every--my lit--'' (Mrs. Snagsby)

``I should be glad,'' (Mrs. Snagsby)
says Mrs. Snagsby after contemplating his (Snagsby) increased confusion with a severe and sinister smile,
``if you would come home with me; I think you may be safer there, Mr. Snagsby, than anywhere else.'' (Mrs. Snagsby)

``My love, I don't know but what I may be, I am sure. I am ready to go.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

Mr. Snagsby casts his (Snagsby) eye forlornly round the bar, gives Messrs. Weevle and Guppy good morning, assures them of the satisfaction with which he (Snagsby) sees them uninjured, and accompanies Mrs. Snagsby from the Sol's Arms. Before night his (Sol) doubt whether he (Sol) may not be responsible for some inconceivable part in the catastrophe which is the talk of the whole neighbourhood is almost resolved into certainty by Mrs. Snagsby's pertinacity in that fixed gaze. His (Sol) mental sufferings are so great that he (Sol) entertains wandering ideas of delivering himself up to justice and requiring to be cleared if innocent and punished with the utmost rigour of the law if guilty.

Mr. Weevle and Mr. Guppy, having taken their breakfast, step into Lincoln's Inn to take a little walk about the square and clear as many of the dark cobwebs out of their brains as a little walk may.

``There can be no more favourable time than the present, Tony,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy after they have broodingly made out the four sides of the square,
``for a word or two between us upon a point on which we must, with very little delay, come to an understanding.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``Now, I tell you what, William G.!'' (companion)
returns the other, eyeing his (Guppy) companion with a bloodshot eye.
``If it's a point of conspiracy, you needn't take the trouble to mention it. I have had enough of that, and I ain't going to have any more. We shall have YOU taking fire next or blowing up with a bang.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

This supposititious phenomenon is so very disagreeable to Mr. Guppy that his (Guppy) voice quakes as he (Guppy) says in a moral way,

``Tony, I should have thought that what we went through last night would have been a lesson to you never to be personal any more as long as you lived.'' (he)
To which Mr. Weevle returns,
``William, I should have thought it would have been a lesson to YOU never to conspire any more as long as you lived.'' (Mr. Weevle/Weevle)
To which Mr. Guppy says,
``Who's conspiring?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
To which Mr. Jobling replies,
``Why, YOU are!'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
To which Mr. Guppy retorts,
``No, I am not.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
To which Mr. Jobling retorts again,
``Yes, you are!'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
To which Mr. Guppy retorts,
``Who says so?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
To which Mr. Jobling retorts,
``I say so!'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
To which Mr. Guppy retorts,
``Oh, indeed?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
To which Mr. Jobling retorts,
``Yes, indeed!'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
And both being now in a heated state, they walk on silently for a while to cool down again.

``Tony,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy then,
``if you heard your friend out instead of flying at him (Tony), you wouldn't fall into mistakes. But your temper is hasty and you are not considerate. Possessing in yourself, Tony, all that is calculated to charm the eye--'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``Oh! Blow the eye!'' (Mr. Weevle/Weevle)
cries Mr. Weevle, cutting him (Guppy) short.
``Say what you have got to say!'' (friend)

Finding his (Guppy) friend in this morose and material condition, Mr. Guppy only expresses the finer feelings of his (Guppy) soul through the tone of injury in which he (Guppy) recommences,

``Tony, when I say there is a point on which we must come to an understanding pretty soon, I say so quite apart from any kind of conspiring, however innocent. You know it is professionally arranged beforehand in all cases that are tried what facts the witnesses are to prove. Is it or is it not desirable that we should know what facts we are to prove on the inquiry into the death of this unfortunate old mo--gentleman?'' (he)
-LRB-Mr. Guppy was going to say
``mogul,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
but thinks
``gentleman'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
better suited to the circumstances.-RRB-

``What facts? THE facts.'' (unknown)

``The facts bearing on that inquiry. Those are'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
--Mr. Guppy tells them off on his (Guppy) fingers--
``what we knew of his (gentleman) habits, when you saw him (gentleman) last, what his (gentleman) condition was then, the discovery that we made, and how we made it.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``Yes,'' (Mr. Weevle/Weevle)
says Mr. Weevle.
``Those are about the facts.'' (unknown)

``We made the discovery in consequence of his (gentleman) having, in his (gentleman) eccentric way, an appointment with you at twelve o'clock at night, when you were to explain some writing to him (gentleman) as you had often done before on account of his (gentleman) not being able to read. I, spending the evening with you, was called down--and so forth. The inquiry being only into the circumstances touching the death of the deceased, it's not necessary to go beyond these facts, I suppose you'll agree?'' (unknown)

``No!'' (Mr. Weevle/Weevle)
returns Mr. Weevle.
``I suppose not.'' (unknown)

``And this is not a conspiracy, perhaps?'' (unknown)
says the injured Guppy.

``No,'' (friend)
returns his (Weevle) friend;
``if it's nothing worse than this, I withdraw the observation.'' (friend)

``Now, Tony,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy, taking his (Guppy) arm again and walking him (Guppy) slowly on,
``I should like to know, in a friendly way, whether you have yet thought over the many advantages of your continuing to live at that place?'' (him)

``What do you mean?'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)
says Tony, stopping.

``Whether you have yet thought over the many advantages of your continuing to live at that place?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
repeats Mr. Guppy, walking him (Guppy) on again.

``At what place? THAT place?'' (unknown)
pointing in the direction of the rag and bottle shop.

Mr. Guppy nods.

``Why, I wouldn't pass another night there for any consideration that you could offer me,'' (Mr. Weevle/Weevle)
says Mr. Weevle, haggardly staring.

``Do you mean it though, Tony?'' (unknown)

``Mean it! Do I look as if I mean it? I feel as if I do; I know that,'' (Mr. Weevle/Weevle)
says Mr. Weevle with a very genuine shudder.

``Then the possibility or probability--for such it must be considered--of your never being disturbed in possession of those effects lately belonging to a lone old man who seemed to have no relation in the world, and the certainty of your being able to find out what he (man) really had got stored up there, don't weigh with you at all against last night, Tony, if I understand you?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy, biting his (Guppy) thumb with the appetite of vexation.

``Certainly not. Talk in that cool way of a fellow's living there?'' (Mr. Weevle/Weevle)
cries Mr. Weevle indignantly.
``Go and live there yourself.'' (unknown)

``Oh! I, Tony!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy, soothing him (Guppy).
``I have never lived there and couldn't get a lodging there now, whereas you have got one.'' (unknown)

``You are welcome to it,'' (friend)
rejoins his (Guppy) friend,
``and--ugh!--you may make yourself at home in it.'' (friend)

``Then you really and truly at this point,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy,
``give up the whole thing, if I understand you, Tony?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``You never,'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)
returns Tony with a most convincing steadfastness,
``said a truer word in all your life. I do!'' (Tony/Jobling/Tony Jobling)

While they are so conversing, a hackney-coach drives into the square, on the box of which vehicle a very tall hat makes itself manifest to the public. Inside the coach, and consequently not so manifest to the multitude, though sufficiently so to the two friends, for the coach stops almost at their feet, are the venerable Mr. Smallweed and Mrs. Smallweed, accompanied by their granddaughter Judy.

An air of haste and excitement pervades the party, and as the tall hat -LRB-surmounting Mr. Smallweed the younger-RRB- alights, Mr. Smallweed the elder pokes his (Smallweed) head out of window and bawls to Mr. Guppy,

``How de do, sir! How de do!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``What do Chick and his (Tony) family want here at this time of the morning, I wonder!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy, nodding to his (Guppy) familiar.

``My dear sir,'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
cries Grandfather Smallweed,
``would you do me a favour? Would you and your friend be so very obleeging as to carry me into the public-house in the court, while Bart and his (Bart) sister bring their grandmother along? Would you do an old man that good turn, sir?'' (Grandfather Smallweed)

Mr. Guppy looks at his (Guppy) friend, repeating inquiringly,

``The public-house in the court?'' (friend)
And they prepare to bear the venerable burden to the Sol's Arms.

``There's your fare!'' (the patriarch)
says the patriarch to the coachman with a fierce grin and shaking his (patriarch) incapable fist at him (patriarch).
``Ask me for a penny more, and I'll have my lawful revenge upon you. My dear young men, be easy with me, if you please. Allow me to catch you round the neck. I won't squeeze you tighter than I can help. Oh, Lord! Oh, dear me! Oh, my bones!'' (the Sol)

It is well that the Sol is not far off, for Mr. Weevle presents an apoplectic appearance before half the distance is accomplished. With no worse aggravation of his (Weevle) symptoms, however, than the utterance of divers croaking sounds expressive of obstructed respiration, he (Weevle) fulfils his (Weevle) share of the porterage and the benevolent old gentleman is deposited by his (Weevle) own desire in the parlour of the Sol's Arms.

``Oh, Lord!'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
gasps Mr. Smallweed, looking about him (Smallweed), breathless, from an arm-chair.
``Oh, dear me! Oh, my bones and back! Oh, my aches and pains! Sit down, you dancing, prancing, shambling, scrambling poll-parrot! Sit down!'' (Mrs. Smallweed)

This little apostrophe to Mrs. Smallweed is occasioned by a propensity on the part of that unlucky old lady whenever she (Smallweed) finds herself on her (Smallweed) feet to amble about and

``set'' (she)
to inanimate objects, accompanying herself with a chattering noise, as in a witch dance. A nervous affection has probably as much to do with these demonstrations as any imbecile intention in the poor old woman, but on the present occasion they are so particularly lively in connexion with the Windsor arm-chair, fellow to that in which Mr. Smallweed is seated, that she (woman) only quite desists when her (woman) grandchildren have held her (woman) down in it, her (woman) lord in the meanwhile bestowing upon her (woman), with great volubility, the endearing epithet of
``a pig-headed jackdaw,'' (her)
repeated a surprising number of times.

``My dear sir,'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
Grandfather Smallweed then proceeds, addressing Mr. Guppy,
``there has been a calamity here. Have you heard of it, either of you?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``Heard of it, sir! Why, we discovered it.'' (unknown)

``You discovered it. You two discovered it! Bart, THEY discovered it!'' (The discoverers)

The two discoverers stare at the Smallweeds, who return the compliment.

``My dear friends,'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
whines Grandfather Smallweed, putting out both his (Smallweed) hands,
``I owe you a thousand thanks for discharging the melancholy office of discovering the ashes of Mrs. Smallweed's brother.'' (Grandfather Smallweed)

``Eh?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy.

``Mrs. Smallweed's brother, my dear friend--her (Smallweed) only relation. We were not on terms, which is to be deplored now, but he (friend) never WOULD be on terms. He (friend) was not fond of us. He (friend) was eccentric--he (friend) was very eccentric. Unless he (friend) has left a will -LRB-which is not at all likely-RRB- I shall take out letters of administration. I have come down to look after the property; it must be sealed up, it must be protected. I have come down,'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
repeats Grandfather Smallweed, hooking the air towards him (Smallweed) with all his (Smallweed) ten fingers at once,
``to look after the property.'' (him)

``I think, Small,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says the disconsolate Mr. Guppy,
``you might have mentioned that the old man was your uncle.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``You two were so close about him (man) that I thought you would like me to be the same,'' (unknown)
returns that old bird with a secretly glistening eye.
``Besides, I wasn't proud of him (man).'' (unknown)

``Besides which, it was nothing to you, you know, whether he (man) was or not,'' (Judy)
says Judy. Also with a secretly glistening eye.

``He (man) never saw me in his (man) life to know me,'' (unknown)
observed Small;
``I don't know why I should introduce HIM, I am sure!'' (unknown)

``No, he (man) never communicated with us, which is to be deplored,'' (gentleman)
the old gentleman strikes in,
``but I have come to look after the property--to look over the papers, and to look after the property. We shall make good our title. It is in the hands of my solicitor. Mr. Tulkinghorn, of Lincoln's Inn Fields, over the way there, is so good as to act as my solicitor; and grass don't grow under HIS (solicitor) feet, I can tell ye. Krook was Mrs. Smallweed's only brother; she (Smallweed) had no relation but Krook, and Krook had no relation but Mrs. Smallweed. I am speaking of your brother, you brimstone black-beetle, that was seventy-six years of age.'' (gentleman)

Mrs. Smallweed instantly begins to shake her (Smallweed) head and pipe up,

``Seventy-six pound seven and sevenpence! Seventy-six thousand bags of money! Seventy-six hundred thousand million of parcels of bank-notes!'' (Mrs. Smallweed)

``Will somebody give me a quart pot?'' (husband)
exclaims her (Smallweed) exasperated husband, looking helplessly about him (husband) and finding no missile within his (husband) reach.
``Will somebody obleege me with a spittoon? Will somebody hand me anything hard and bruising to pelt at her (Smallweed)? You hag, you cat, you dog, you brimstone barker!'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
Here Mr. Smallweed, wrought up to the highest pitch by his (Smallweed) own eloquence, actually throws Judy at her (Judy) grandmother in default of anything else, by butting that young virgin at the old lady with such force as he (Smallweed) can muster and then dropping into his (Smallweed) chair in a heap.

``Shake me up, somebody, if you'll be so good,'' (he)
says the voice from within the faintly struggling bundle into which he (Smallweed) has collapsed.
``I have come to look after the property. Shake me up, and call in the police on duty at the next house to be explained to about the property. My solicitor will be here presently to protect the property. Transportation or the gallows for anybody who shall touch the property!'' (grandchildren)
As his (Smallweed) dutiful grandchildren set him (Smallweed) up, panting, and putting him (Smallweed) through the usual restorative process of shaking and punching, he (Smallweed) still repeats like an echo,
``The--the property! The property! Property!'' (he)

Mr. Weevle and Mr. Guppy look at each other, the former as having relinquished the whole affair, the latter with a discomfited countenance as having entertained some lingering expectations yet. But there is nothing to be done in opposition to the Smallweed interest. Mr. Tulkinghorn's clerk comes down from his (Tulkinghorn) official pew in the chambers to mention to the police that Mr. Tulkinghorn is answerable for its being all correct about the next of kin and that the papers and effects will be formally taken possession of in due time and course. Mr. Smallweed is at once permitted so far to assert his (Smallweed) supremacy as to be carried on a visit of sentiment into the next house and upstairs into Miss Flite's deserted room, where he (Smallweed) looks like a hideous bird of prey newly added to her (clerk) aviary.

The arrival of this unexpected heir soon taking wind in the court still makes good for the Sol and keeps the court upon its mettle. Mrs. Piper and Mrs. Perkins think it hard upon the young man if there really is no will, and consider that a handsome present ought to be made him (man) out of the estate. Young Piper and young Perkins, as members of that restless juvenile circle which is the terror of the foot-passengers in Chancery Lane, crumble into ashes behind the pump and under the archway all day long, where wild yells and hootings take place over their remains. Little Swills and Miss M. Melvilleson enter into affable conversation with their patrons, feeling that these unusual occurrences level the barriers between professionals and non-professionals. Mr. Bogsby puts up

``The popular song of King Death, with chorus by the whole strength of the company,'' (Mr. Bogsby/Mr. J. G. Bogsby)
as the great Harmonic feature of the week and announces in the bill that
``J. G. B. is induced to do so at a considerable extra expense in consequence of a wish which has been very generally expressed at the bar by a large body of respectable individuals and in homage to a late melancholy event which has aroused so much sensation.'' (Mr. Bogsby/Mr. J. G. Bogsby)
There is one point connected with the deceased upon which the court is particularly anxious, namely, that the fiction of a full-sized coffin should be preserved, though there is so little to put in it. Upon the undertaker's stating in the Sol's bar in the course of the day that he (Sol) has received orders to construct
``a six-footer,'' (he)
the general solicitude is much relieved, and it is considered that Mr. Smallweed's conduct does him (Smallweed) great honour.

Out of the court, and a long way out of it, there is considerable excitement too, for men of science and philosophy come to look, and carriages set down doctors at the corner who arrive with the same intent, and there is more learned talk about inflammable gases and phosphuretted hydrogen than the court has ever imagined. Some of these authorities -LRB-of course the wisest-RRB- hold with indignation that the deceased had no business to die in the alleged manner; and being reminded by other authorities of a certain inquiry into the evidence for such deaths reprinted in the sixth volume of the Philosophical Transactions; and also of a book not quite unknown on English medical jurisprudence; and likewise of the Italian case of the Countess Cornelia Baudi as set forth in detail by one Bianchini, prebendary of Verona, who wrote a scholarly work or so and was occasionally heard of in his (authorities) time as having gleams of reason in him (authorities); and also of the testimony of Messrs. Fodere and Mere, two pestilent Frenchmen who WOULD investigate the subject; and further, of the corroborative testimony of Monsieur Le Cat, a rather celebrated French surgeon once upon a time, who had the unpoliteness to live in a house where such a case occurred and even to write an account of it--still they regard the late Mr. Krook's obstinacy in going out of the world by any such by-way as wholly unjustifiable and personally offensive. The less the court understands of all this, the more the court likes it, and the greater enjoyment it has in the stock in trade of the Sol's Arms. Then there comes the artist of a picture newspaper, with a foreground and figures ready drawn for anything from a wreck on the Cornish coast to a review in Hyde Park or a meeting in Manchester, and in Mrs. Perkins' own room, memorable evermore, he (Hyde) then and there throws in upon the block Mr. Krook's house, as large as life; in fact, considerably larger, making a very temple of it. Similarly, being permitted to look in at the door of the fatal chamber, he (Krook) depicts that apartment as three-quarters of a mile long by fifty yards high, at which the court is particularly charmed. All this time the two gentlemen before mentioned pop in and out of every house and assist at the philosophical disputations--go everywhere and listen to everybody--and yet are always diving into the Sol's parlour and writing with the ravenous little pens on the tissue-paper.

At last come the coroner and his (coroner) inquiry, like as before, except that the coroner cherishes this case as being out of the common way and tells the gentlemen of the jury, in his (coroner) private capacity, that

``that would seem to be an unlucky house next door, gentlemen, a destined house; but so we sometimes find it, and these are mysteries we can't account for!'' (the gentlemen)
After which the six-footer comes into action and is much admired.

In all these proceedings Mr. Guppy has so slight a part, except when he (Guppy) gives his (Guppy) evidence, that he (Guppy) is moved on like a private individual and can only haunt the secret house on the outside, where he (Guppy) has the mortification of seeing Mr. Smallweed padlocking the door, and of bitterly knowing himself to be shut out. But before these proceedings draw to a close, that is to say, on the night next after the catastrophe, Mr. Guppy has a thing to say that must be said to Lady Dedlock.

For which reason, with a sinking heart and with that hang-dog sense of guilt upon him (Guppy) which dread and watching enfolded in the Sol's Arms have produced, the young man of the name of Guppy presents himself at the town mansion at about seven o'clock in the evening and requests to see her (Dedlock) ladyship. Mercury replies that she (Dedlock) is going out to dinner; don't he (Guppy) see the carriage at the door? Yes, he (Guppy) does see the carriage at the door; but he (Guppy) wants to see my Lady too.

Mercury is disposed, as he (Guppy) will presently declare to a fellow-gentleman in waiting,

``to pitch into the young man'' (he)
; but his (Guppy) instructions are positive. Therefore he (Guppy) sulkily supposes that the young man must come up into the library. There he (man) leaves the young man in a large room, not over-light, while he (man) makes report of him (man).

Mr. Guppy looks into the shade in all directions, discovering everywhere a certain charred and whitened little heap of coal or wood. Presently he (Guppy) hears a rustling. Is it--? No, it's no ghost, but fair flesh and blood, most brilliantly dressed.

``I have to beg your ladyship's pardon,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
Mr. Guppy stammers, very downcast.
``This is an inconvenient time--'' (She)

``I told you, you could come at any time.'' (She)
She (it) takes a chair, looking straight at him (Guppy) as on the last occasion.

``Thank your ladyship. Your ladyship is very affable.'' (unknown)

``You can sit down.'' (unknown)
There is not much affability in her (it) tone.

``I don't know, your ladyship, that it's worth while my sitting down and detaining you, for I--I have not got the letters that I mentioned when I had the honour of waiting on your ladyship.'' (unknown)

``Have you come merely to say so?'' (unknown)

``Merely to say so, your ladyship.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
Mr. Guppy besides being depressed, disappointed, and uneasy, is put at a further disadvantage by the splendour and beauty of her (it) appearance.

She (it) knows its influence perfectly, has studied it too well to miss a grain of its effect on any one. As she (it) looks at him (Guppy) so steadily and coldly, he (Guppy) not only feels conscious that he (Guppy) has no guide in the least perception of what is really the complexion of her (it) thoughts, but also that he (Guppy) is being every moment, as it were, removed further and further from her (it).

She (it) will not speak, it is plain. So he (Guppy) must.

``In short, your ladyship,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
says Mr. Guppy like a meanly penitent thief,
``the person I was to have had the letters of, has come to a sudden end, and--'' (a thief)
He (Guppy) stops. Lady Dedlock calmly finishes the sentence.

``And the letters are destroyed with the person?'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Mr. Guppy would say no if he (Guppy) could--as he (Guppy) is unable to hide.

``I believe so, your ladyship.'' (he)

If he (Guppy) could see the least sparkle of relief in her (Dedlock) face now? No, he (Guppy) could see no such thing, even if that brave outside did not utterly put him (Guppy) away, and he (Guppy) were not looking beyond it and about it.

He (Guppy) falters an awkward excuse or two for his (Guppy) failure.

``Is this all you have to say?'' (Lady Dedlock/Dedlock)
inquires Lady Dedlock, having heard him (Guppy) out--or as nearly out as he (Guppy) can stumble.

Mr. Guppy thinks that's all.

``You had better be sure that you wish to say nothing more to me, this being the last time you will have the opportunity.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Mr. Guppy is quite sure. And indeed he (Guppy) has no such wish at present, by any means.

``That is enough. I will dispense with excuses. Good evening to you!'' (she)
And she (Dedlock) rings for Mercury to show the young man of the name of Guppy out.

But in that house, in that same moment, there happens to be an old man of the name of Tulkinghorn. And that old man, coming with his (man) quiet footstep to the library, has his (man) hand at that moment on the handle of the door--comes in--and comes face to face with the young man as he (man) is leaving the room.

One glance between the old man and the lady, and for an instant the blind that is always down flies up. Suspicion, eager and sharp, looks out. Another instant, close again.

``I beg your pardon, Lady Dedlock. I beg your pardon a thousand times. It is so very unusual to find you here at this hour. I supposed the room was empty. I beg your pardon!'' (unknown)

``Stay!'' (She)
She (man) negligently calls him (man) back.
``Remain here, I beg. I am going out to dinner. I have nothing more to say to this young man!'' (man)

The disconcerted young man bows, as he (man) goes out, and cringingly hopes that Mr. Tulkinghorn of the Fields is well.

``Aye, aye?'' (the lawyer)
says the lawyer, looking at him (lawyer) from under his (lawyer) bent brows, though he (lawyer) has no need to look again--not he (lawyer).
``From Kenge and Carboy's, surely?'' (unknown)

``Kenge and Carboy's, Mr. Tulkinghorn. Name of Guppy, sir.'' (unknown)

``To be sure. Why, thank you, Mr. Guppy, I am very well!'' (unknown)

``Happy to hear it, sir. You can't be too well, sir, for the credit of the profession.'' (unknown)

``Thank you, Mr. Guppy!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Mr. Guppy sneaks away. Mr. Tulkinghorn, such a foil in his (Tulkinghorn) old-fashioned rusty black to Lady Dedlock's brightness, hands her (Dedlock) down the staircase to her (Dedlock) carriage. He (Tulkinghorn) returns rubbing his (Tulkinghorn) chin, and rubs it a good deal in the course of the evening.

CHAPTER XXXIV

A Turn of the Screw

``Now, what,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George,
``may this be? Is it blank cartridge or ball? A flash in the pan or a shot?'' (Mr. George/George)

An open letter is the subject of the trooper's speculations, and it seems to perplex him (George) mightily. He (George) looks at it at arm's length, brings it close to him (George), holds it in his (George) right hand, holds it in his (George) left hand, reads it with his (George) head on this side, with his (George) head on that side, contracts his (George) eyebrows, elevates them, still cannot satisfy himself. He (George) smooths it out upon the table with his (George) heavy palm, and thoughtfully walking up and down the gallery, makes a halt before it every now and then to come upon it with a fresh eye. Even that won't do.

``Is it,'' (Mr. George/George)
Mr. George still muses,
``blank cartridge or ball?'' (George muses cartridge)

Phil Squod, with the aid of a brush and paint-pot, is employed in the distance whitening the targets, softly whistling in quick-march time and in drum-and-fife manner that he (Squod) must and will go back again to the girl he (Squod) left behind him (Squod).

``Phil!'' (The trooper)
The trooper beckons as he (trooper) calls him (trooper).

Phil approaches in his (Phil) usual way, sidling off at first as if he (Phil) were going anywhere else and then bearing down upon his (Phil) commander like a bayonet-charge. Certain splashes of white show in high relief upon his (Phil) dirty face, and he (Phil) scrapes his (Phil) one eyebrow with the handle of the brush.

``Attention, Phil! Listen to this.'' (unknown)

``Steady, commander, steady.'' (unknown)

''`Sir. Allow me to remind you -LRB-though there is no legal necessity for my doing so, as you are aware-RRB- that the bill at two months' date drawn on yourself by Mr. Matthew Bagnet, and by you accepted, for the sum of ninety-seven pounds four shillings and ninepence, will become due to-morrow, when you will please be prepared to take up the same on presentation. Yours, Joshua Smallweed.'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
What do you make of that, Phil?''

``Mischief, guv`ner.'' (unknown)

``Why?'' (unknown)

``I think,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
replies Phil after pensively tracing out a cross-wrinkle in his (Phil) forehead with the brush-handle,
``that mischeevious consequences is always meant when money's asked for.'' (Phil/Phil Squod)

``Lookye, Phil,'' (the trooper)
says the trooper, sitting on the table.
``First and last, I have paid, I may say, half as much again as this principal in interest and one thing and another.'' (Phil/Phil Squod)

Phil intimates by sidling back a pace or two, with a very unaccountable wrench of his (Phil) wry face, that he (Phil) does not regard the transaction as being made more promising by this incident.

``And lookye further, Phil,'' (the trooper)
says the trooper, staying his (trooper) premature conclusions with a wave of his (trooper) hand.
``There has always been an understanding that this bill was to be what they call renewed. And it has been renewed no end of times. What do you say now?'' (unknown)

``I say that I think the times is come to a end at last.'' (unknown)

``You do? Humph! I am much of the same mind myself.'' (unknown)

``Joshua Smallweed is him (Smallweed) that was brought here in a chair?'' (unknown)

``The same.'' (unknown)

``Guv`ner,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
says Phil with exceeding gravity,
``he (Smallweed)'s a leech in his (Smallweed) dispositions, he (Smallweed)'s a screw and a wice in his (Smallweed) actions, a snake in his (Smallweed) twistings, and a lobster in his (Smallweed) claws.'' (Phil/Phil Squod)

Having thus expressively uttered his (Phil) sentiments, Mr. Squod, after waiting a little to ascertain if any further remark be expected of him (Squod), gets back by his (Squod) usual series of movements to the target he (Squod) has in hand and vigorously signifies through his (Squod) former musical medium that he (Squod) must and he (Squod) will return to that ideal young lady. George, having folded the letter, walks in that direction.

``There IS a way, commander,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
says Phil, looking cunningly at him (Phil),
``of settling this.'' (him)

``Paying the money, I suppose? I wish I could.'' (Phil/Phil Squod)

Phil shakes his (Phil) head.

``No, guv`ner, no; not so bad as that. There IS a way,'' (Phil/Phil Squod)
says Phil with a highly artistic turn of his (Phil) brush;
``what I'm a-doing at present.'' (Phil/Phil Squod)

``Whitewashing.'' (Phil/Phil Squod)

Phil nods.

``A pretty way that would be! Do you know what would become of the Bagnets in that case? Do you know they would be ruined to pay off my old scores? YOU``RE a moral character,'' says the trooper, eyeing him (Phil) in his (Phil) large way with no small indignation;

``upon my life you are, Phil!'' (a character)

Phil, on one knee at the target, is in course of protesting earnestly, though not without many allegorical scoops of his (Phil) brush and smoothings of the white surface round the rim with his (Phil) thumb, that he (Phil) had forgotten the Bagnet responsibility and would not so much as injure a hair of the head of any member of that worthy family when steps are audible in the long passage without, and a cheerful voice is heard to wonder whether George is at home. Phil, with a look at his (Phil) master, hobbles up, saying,

``Here's the guv`ner, Mrs. Bagnet! Here he (Phil) is!'' (master)
and the old girl herself, accompanied by Mr. Bagnet, appears.

The old girl never appears in walking trim, in any season of the year, without a grey cloth cloak, coarse and much worn but very clean, which is, undoubtedly, the identical garment rendered so interesting to Mr. Bagnet by having made its way home to Europe from another quarter of the globe in company with Mrs. Bagnet and an umbrella. The latter faithful appendage is also invariably a part of the old girl's presence out of doors. It is of no colour known in this life and has a corrugated wooden crook for a handle, with a metallic object let into its prow, or beak, resembling a little model of a fanlight over a street door or one of the oval glasses out of a pair of spectacles, which ornamental object has not that tenacious capacity of sticking to its post that might be desired in an article long associated with the British army. The old girl's umbrella is of a flabby habit of waist and seems to be in need of stays--an appearance that is possibly referable to its having served through a series of years at home as a cupboard and on journeys as a carpet bag. She (girl) never puts it up, having the greatest reliance on her (girl) well-proved cloak with its capacious hood, but generally uses the instrument as a wand with which to point out joints of meat or bunches of greens in marketing or to arrest the attention of tradesmen by a friendly poke. Without her (girl) market-basket, which is a sort of wicker well with two flapping lids, she (girl) never stirs abroad. Attended by these her (girl) trusty companions, therefore, her (girl) honest sunburnt face looking cheerily out of a rough straw bonnet, Mrs. Bagnet now arrives, fresh-coloured and bright, in George's Shooting Gallery.

``Well, George, old fellow,'' (she)
says she (Bagnet),
``and how do YOU do, this sunshiny morning?'' (she)

Giving him (George) a friendly shake of the hand, Mrs. Bagnet draws a long breath after her (Bagnet) walk and sits down to enjoy a rest. Having a faculty, matured on the tops of baggage-waggons and in other such positions, of resting easily anywhere, she (Bagnet) perches on a rough bench, unties her (Bagnet) bonnet-strings, pushes back her (Bagnet) bonnet, crosses her (Bagnet) arms, and looks perfectly comfortable.

Mr. Bagnet in the meantime has shaken hands with his (Bagnet) old comrade and with Phil, on whom Mrs. Bagnet likewise bestows a good-humoured nod and smile.

``Now, George,'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
said Mrs. Bagnet briskly,
``here we are, Lignum and myself'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
--she (Bagnet) often speaks of her (Bagnet) husband by this appellation, on account, as it is supposed, of Lignum Vitae having been his (husband) old regimental nickname when they first became acquainted, in compliment to the extreme hardness and toughness of his (husband) physiognomy--
``just looked in, we have, to make it all correct as usual about that security. Give him (George) the new bill to sign, George, and he (George)'ll sign it like a man.'' (Lignum/Lignum Vitae)

``I was coming to you this morning,'' (the trooper)
observes the trooper reluctantly.

``Yes, we thought you'd come to us this morning, but we turned out early and left Woolwich, the best of boys, to mind his (George) sisters and came to you instead--as you see! For Lignum, he (George)'s tied so close now, and gets so little exercise, that a walk does him (George) good. But what's the matter, George?'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
asks Mrs. Bagnet, stopping in her (Bagnet) cheerful talk.
``You don't look yourself.'' (unknown)

``I am not quite myself,'' (the trooper)
returns the trooper;
``I have been a little put out, Mrs. Bagnet.'' (the trooper)

Her (Bagnet) bright quick eye catches the truth directly.

``George!'' (unknown)
holding up her (Bagnet) forefinger.
``Don't tell me there's anything wrong about that security of Lignum's! Don't do it, George, on account of the children!'' (The trooper)

The trooper looks at her (Bagnet) with a troubled visage.

``George,'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
says Mrs. Bagnet, using both her (Bagnet) arms for emphasis and occasionally bringing down her (Bagnet) open hands upon her (Bagnet) knees.
``If you have allowed anything wrong to come to that security of Lignum's, and if you have let him (George) in for it, and if you have put us in danger of being sold up--and I see sold up in your face, George, as plain as print--you have done a shameful action and have deceived us cruelly. I tell you, cruelly, George. There!'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
