Mr. Bagnet, otherwise as immovable as a pump or a lamp-post, puts his (Bagnet) large right hand on the top of his (Bagnet) bald head as if to defend it from a shower-bath and looks with great uneasiness at Mrs. Bagnet.

``George,'' (girl)
says that old girl,
``I wonder at you! George, I am ashamed of you! George, I couldn't have believed you would have done it! I always knew you to be a rolling stone that gathered no moss, but I never thought you would have taken away what little moss there was for Bagnet and the children to lie upon. You know what a hard-working, steady-going chap he (chap) is. You know what Quebec and Malta and Woolwich are, and I never did think you would, or could, have had the heart to serve us so. Oh, George!'' (girl)
Mrs. Bagnet gathers up her (Bagnet) cloak to wipe her (Bagnet) eyes on in a very genuine manner,
``How could you do it?'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

Mrs. Bagnet ceasing, Mr. Bagnet removes his (Bagnet) hand from his (Bagnet) head as if the shower-bath were over and looks disconsolately at Mr. George, who has turned quite white and looks distressfully at the grey cloak and straw bonnet.

``Mat,'' (the trooper)
says the trooper in a subdued voice, addressing him (trooper) but still looking at his (trooper) wife,
``I am sorry you take it so much to heart, because I do hope it's not so bad as that comes to. I certainly have, this morning, received this letter'' (wife)
--which he (trooper) reads aloud--
``but I hope it may be set right yet. As to a rolling stone, why, what you say is true. I AM a rolling stone, and I never rolled in anybody's way, I fully believe, that I rolled the least good to. But it's impossible for an old vagabond comrade to like your wife and family better than I like 'em, Mat, and I trust you'll look upon me as forgivingly as you can. Don't think I've kept anything from you. I haven't had the letter more than a quarter of an hour.'' (he)

``Old girl,'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
murmurs Mr. Bagnet after a short silence,
``will you tell him (Mat) my opinion?'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)

``Oh! Why didn't he (Mat) marry,'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
Mrs. Bagnet answers, half laughing and half crying,
``Joe Pouch's widder in North America? Then he (Mat) wouldn't have got himself into these troubles.'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

``The old girl,'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
says Mr. Bagnet,
``puts it correct--why didn't you?'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)

``Well, she (girl) has a better husband by this time, I hope,'' (the trooper)
returns the trooper.
``Anyhow, here I stand, this present day, NOT married to Joe Pouch's widder. What shall I do? You see all I have got about me. It's not mine; it's yours. Give the word, and I'll sell off every morsel. If I could have hoped it would have brought in nearly the sum wanted, I'd have sold all long ago. Don't believe that I'll leave you or yours in the lurch, Mat. I'd sell myself first. I only wish,'' (the trooper)
says the trooper, giving himself a disparaging blow in the chest,
``that I knew of any one who'd buy such a second-hand piece of old stores.'' (the trooper)

``Old girl,'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
murmurs Mr. Bagnet,
``give him (Mat) another bit of my mind.'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)

``George,'' (the girl)
says the old girl,
``you are not so much to be blamed, on full consideration, except for ever taking this business without the means.'' (the girl)

``And that was like me!'' (the trooper)
observes the penitent trooper, shaking his (Bagnet) head.
``Like me, I know.'' (unknown)

``Silence! The old girl,'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
says Mr. Bagnet,
``is correct--in her (girl) way of giving my opinions--hear me out!'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)

``That was when you never ought to have asked for the security, George, and when you never ought to have got it, all things considered. But what's done can't be undone. You are always an honourable and straightforward fellow, as far as lays in your power, though a little flighty. On the other hand, you can't admit but what it's natural in us to be anxious with such a thing hanging over our heads. So forget and forgive all round, George. Come! Forget and forgive all round!'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

Mrs. Bagnet, giving him (Bagnet) one of her (Bagnet) honest hands and giving her (Bagnet) husband the other, Mr. George gives each of them one of his (George) and holds them while he (George) speaks.

``I do assure you both, there's nothing I wouldn't do to discharge this obligation. But whatever I have been able to scrape together has gone every two months in keeping it up. We have lived plainly enough here, Phil and I. But the gallery don't quite do what was expected of it, and it's not--in short, it's not the mint. It was wrong in me to take it? Well, so it was. But I was in a manner drawn into that step, and I thought it might steady me, and set me up, and you'll try to overlook my having such expectations, and upon my soul, I am very much obliged to you, and very much ashamed of myself.'' (Mr. George/George)
With these concluding words, Mr. George gives a shake to each of the hands he (George) holds, and relinquishing them, backs a pace or two in a broad-chested, upright attitude, as if he (George) had made a final confession and were immediately going to be shot with all military honours.

``George, hear me out!'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
says Mr. Bagnet, glancing at his (Bagnet) wife.
``Old girl, go on!'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)

Mr. Bagnet, being in this singular manner heard out, has merely to observe that the letter must be attended to without any delay, that it is advisable that George and he (George) should immediately wait on Mr. Smallweed in person, and that the primary object is to save and hold harmless Mr. Bagnet, who had none of the money. Mr. George, entirely assenting, puts on his (George) hat and prepares to march with Mr. Bagnet to the enemy's camp.

``Don't you mind a woman's hasty word, George,'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
says Mrs. Bagnet, patting him (Bagnet) on the shoulder.
``I trust my old Lignum to you, and I am sure you'll bring him (George) through it.'' (trooper)

The trooper returns that this is kindly said and that he (trooper) WILL bring Lignum through it somehow. Upon which Mrs. Bagnet, with her (Bagnet) cloak, basket, and umbrella, goes home, bright-eyed again, to the rest of her (Bagnet) family, and the comrades sally forth on the hopeful errand of mollifying Mr. Smallweed.

Whether there are two people in England less likely to come satisfactorily out of any negotiation with Mr. Smallweed than Mr. George and Mr. Matthew Bagnet may be very reasonably questioned. Also, notwithstanding their martial appearance, broad square shoulders, and heavy tread, whether there are within the same limits two more simple and unaccustomed children in all the Smallweedy affairs of life. As they proceed with great gravity through the streets towards the region of Mount Pleasant, Mr. Bagnet, observing his (Bagnet) companion to be thoughtful, considers it a friendly part to refer to Mrs. Bagnet's late sally.

``George, you know the old girl--she (girl)'s as sweet and as mild as milk. But touch her (girl) on the children--or myself--and she (girl)'s off like gunpowder.'' (unknown)

``It does her (girl) credit, Mat!'' (unknown)

``George,'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
says Mr. Bagnet, looking straight before him (Bagnet),
``the old girl--can't do anything--that don't do her (girl) credit. More or less. I never say so. Discipline must be maintained.'' (him)

``She (girl)'s worth her (girl) weight in gold,'' (the trooper)
says the trooper.

``In gold?'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
says Mr. Bagnet.
``I'll tell you what. The old girl's weight--is twelve stone six. Would I take that weight--in any metal--for the old girl? No. Why not? Because the old girl's metal is far more precious--than the preciousest metal. And she (girl)'s ALL metal!'' (unknown)

``You are right, Mat!'' (unknown)

``When she (girl) took me--and accepted of the ring--she (girl) `listed under me and the children--heart and head, for life. She (girl)'s that earnest,'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
says Mr. Bagnet,
``and true to her (girl) colours--that, touch us with a finger--and she (girl) turns out--and stands to her (girl) arms. If the old girl fires wide--once in a way--at the call of duty--look over it, George. For she (girl)'s loyal!'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)

``Why, bless her (girl), Mat,'' (the trooper)
returns the trooper,
``I think the higher of her (girl) for it!'' (the trooper)

``You are right!'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
says Mr. Bagnet with the warmest enthusiasm, though without relaxing the rigidity of a single muscle.
``Think as high of the old girl--as the rock of Gibraltar--and still you'll be thinking low--of such merits. But I never own to it before her (girl). Discipline must be maintained.'' (Mount Pleasant)

These encomiums bring them to Mount Pleasant and to Grandfather Smallweed's house. The door is opened by the perennial Judy, who, having surveyed them from top to toe with no particular favour, but indeed with a malignant sneer, leaves them standing there while she (Judy) consults the oracle as to their admission. The oracle may be inferred to give consent from the circumstance of her (Judy) returning with the words on her (Judy) honey lips that they can come in if they want to it. Thus privileged, they come in and find Mr. Smallweed with his (Smallweed) feet in the drawer of his (Smallweed) chair as if it were a paper foot-bath and Mrs. Smallweed obscured with the cushion like a bird that is not to sing.

``My dear friend,'' (Grandfather)
says Grandfather Smallweed with those two lean affectionate arms of his (Grandfather) stretched forth.
``How de do? How de do? Who is our friend, my dear friend?'' (unknown)

``Why this,'' (Mr. George/George)
returns George, not able to be very conciliatory at first,
``is Matthew Bagnet, who has obliged me in that matter of ours, you know.'' (Mr. George/George)

``Oh! Mr. Bagnet? Surely!'' (The man)
The old man looks at him (man) under his (man) hand.

``Hope you're well, Mr. Bagnet? Fine man, Mr. George! Military air, sir!'' (Mr. George/George)

No chairs being offered, Mr. George brings one forward for Bagnet and one for himself. They sit down, Mr. Bagnet as if he (Bagnet) had no power of bending himself, except at the hips, for that purpose.

``Judy,'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
says Mr. Smallweed,
``bring the pipe.'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)

``Why, I don't know,'' (Mr. George/George)
Mr. George interposes,
``that the young woman need give herself that trouble, for to tell you the truth, I am not inclined to smoke it to-day.'' (Mr. George/George)

``Ain't you?'' (returns the man)
returns the old man.
``Judy, bring the pipe.'' (unknown)

``The fact is, Mr. Smallweed,'' (Mr. George/George)
proceeds George,
``that I find myself in rather an unpleasant state of mind. It appears to me, sir, that your friend in the city has been playing tricks.'' (Mr. George/George)

``Oh, dear no!'' (Grandfather)
says Grandfather Smallweed.
``He (friend) never does that!'' (unknown)

``Don't he (friend)? Well, I am glad to hear it, because I thought it might be HIS (friend) doing. This, you know, I am speaking of. This letter.'' (Grandfather)

Grandfather Smallweed smiles in a very ugly way in recognition of the letter.

``What does it mean?'' (Mr. George/George)
asks Mr. George.

``Judy,'' (the man)
says the old man.
``Have you got the pipe? Give it to me. Did you say what does it mean, my good friend?'' (unknown)

``Aye! Now, come, come, you know, Mr. Smallweed,'' (the trooper)
urges the trooper, constraining himself to speak as smoothly and confidentially as he (George) can, holding the open letter in one hand and resting the broad knuckles of the other on his (George) thigh,
``a good lot of money has passed between us, and we are face to face at the present moment, and are both well aware of the understanding there has always been. I am prepared to do the usual thing which I have done regularly and to keep this matter going. I never got a letter like this from you before, and I have been a little put about by it this morning, because here's my friend Matthew Bagnet, who, you know, had none of the money--'' (he)

``I DON

``T know it, you know,'' (unknown)
says the old man quietly.

``Why, con-found you--it, I mean--I tell you so, don't I?'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes, you tell me so,'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
returns Grandfather Smallweed.
``But I don't know it.'' (unknown)

``Well!'' (the trooper)
says the trooper, swallowing his (Smallweed) fire.
``I know it.'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)

Mr. Smallweed replies with excellent temper,

``Ah! That's quite another thing!'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
And adds,
``But it don't matter. Mr. Bagnet's situation is all one, whether or no.'' (Mr. George/George)

The unfortunate George makes a great effort to arrange the affair comfortably and to propitiate Mr. Smallweed by taking him (Smallweed) upon his (Smallweed) own terms.

``That's just what I mean. As you say, Mr. Smallweed, here's Matthew Bagnet liable to be fixed whether or no. Now, you see, that makes his (Bagnet) good lady very uneasy in her (lady) mind, and me too, for whereas I'm a harum-scarum sort of a good-for-nought that more kicks than halfpence come natural to, why he (Bagnet)'s a steady family man, don't you see? Now, Mr. Smallweed,'' (the trooper confidence)
says the trooper, gaining confidence as he (trooper) proceeds in his (trooper) soldierly mode of doing business,
``although you and I are good friends enough in a certain sort of a way, I am well aware that I can't ask you to let my friend Bagnet off entirely.'' (he)

``Oh, dear, you are too modest. You can ASK me anything, Mr. George.'' (Grandfather)
-LRB-There is an ogreish kind of jocularity in Grandfather Smallweed to-day.-RRB-

``And you can refuse, you mean, eh? Or not you so much, perhaps, as your friend in the city? Ha ha ha!'' (unknown)

``Ha ha ha!'' (Grandfather)
echoes Grandfather Smallweed. In such a very hard manner and with eyes so particularly green that Mr. Bagnet's natural gravity is much deepened by the contemplation of that venerable man.

``Come!'' (Mr. George/George)
says the sanguine George.
``I am glad to find we can be pleasant, because I want to arrange this pleasantly. Here's my friend Bagnet, and here am I. We'll settle the matter on the spot, if you please, Mr. Smallweed, in the usual way. And you'll ease my friend Bagnet's mind, and his (Bagnet) family's mind, a good deal if you'll just mention to him (Bagnet) what our understanding is.'' (unknown)

Here some shrill spectre cries out in a mocking manner,

``Oh, good gracious! Oh!'' (Judy)
Unless, indeed, it be the sportive Judy, who is found to be silent when the startled visitors look round, but whose chin has received a recent toss, expressive of derision and contempt. Mr. Bagnet's gravity becomes yet more profound.

``But I think you asked me, Mr. George'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
--old Smallweed, who all this time has had the pipe in his (Smallweed) hand, is the speaker now--
``I think you asked me, what did the letter mean?'' (George the speaker)

``Why, yes, I did,'' (the trooper)
returns the trooper in his (trooper) off-hand way,
``but I don't care to know particularly, if it's all correct and pleasant.'' (the trooper)

Mr. Smallweed, purposely balking himself in an aim at the trooper's head, throws the pipe on the ground and breaks it to pieces.

``That's what it means, my dear friend. I'll smash you. I'll crumble you. I'll powder you. Go to the devil!'' (The friends)

The two friends rise and look at one another. Mr. Bagnet's gravity has now attained its profoundest point.

``Go to the devil!'' (repeats the man)
repeats the old man.
``I'll have no more of your pipe-smokings and swaggerings. What? You're an independent dragoon, too! Go to my lawyer -LRB-you remember where; you have been there before-RRB- and show your independence now, will you? Come, my dear friend, there's a chance for you. Open the street door, Judy; put these blusterers out! Call in help if they don't go. Put 'em out!'' (He)

He (man) vociferates this so loudly that Mr. Bagnet, laying his (Bagnet) hands on the shoulders of his (Bagnet) comrade before the latter can recover from his (Bagnet) amazement, gets him (Bagnet) on the outside of the street door, which is instantly slammed by the triumphant Judy. Utterly confounded, Mr. George awhile stands looking at the knocker. Mr. Bagnet, in a perfect abyss of gravity, walks up and down before the little parlour window like a sentry and looks in every time he (Bagnet) passes, apparently revolving something in his (Bagnet) mind.

``Come, Mat,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George when he (George) has recovered himself,
``we must try the lawyer. Now, what do you think of this rascal?'' (he)

Mr. Bagnet, stopping to take a farewell look into the parlour, replies with one shake of his (Bagnet) head directed at the interior,

``If my old girl had been here--I'd have told him (rascal)!'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
Having so discharged himself of the subject of his (Bagnet) cogitations, he (Bagnet) falls into step and marches off with the trooper, shoulder to shoulder.

When they present themselves in Lincoln's Inn Fields, Mr. Tulkinghorn is engaged and not to be seen. He (Tulkinghorn) is not at all willing to see them, for when they have waited a full hour, and the clerk, on his (Tulkinghorn) bell being rung, takes the opportunity of mentioning as much, he (Tulkinghorn) brings forth no more encouraging message than that Mr. Tulkinghorn has nothing to say to them and they had better not wait. They do wait, however, with the perseverance of military tactics, and at last the bell rings again and the client in possession comes out of Mr. Tulkinghorn's room.

The client is a handsome old lady, no other than Mrs. Rouncewell, housekeeper at Chesney Wold. She (Rouncewell) comes out of the sanctuary with a fair old-fashioned curtsy and softly shuts the door. She (Rouncewell) is treated with some distinction there, for the clerk steps out of his (Chesney) pew to show her (Rouncewell) through the outer office and to let her (Rouncewell) out. The old lady is thanking him (Chesney) for his (Chesney) attention when she (lady) observes the comrades in waiting.

``I beg your pardon, sir, but I think those gentlemen are military?'' (The clerk George)

The clerk referring the question to them with his (Chesney) eye, and Mr. George not turning round from the almanac over the fire-place. Mr. Bagnet takes upon himself to reply,

``Yes, ma'am. Formerly.'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)

``I thought so. I was sure of it. My heart warms, gentlemen, at the sight of you. It always does at the sight of such. God bless you, gentlemen! You'll excuse an old woman, but I had a son once who went for a soldier. A fine handsome youth he (soldier) was, and good in his (soldier) bold way, though some people did disparage him (soldier) to his (soldier) poor mother. I ask your pardon for troubling you, sir. God bless you, gentlemen!'' (unknown)

``Same to you, ma'am!'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
returns Mr. Bagnet with right good will.

There is something very touching in the earnestness of the old lady's voice and in the tremble that goes through her (lady) quaint old figure. But Mr. George is so occupied with the almanac over the fire-place -LRB-calculating the coming months by it perhaps-RRB- that he (George) does not look round until she (lady) has gone away and the door is closed upon her (lady).

``George,'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
Mr. Bagnet gruffly whispers when he (Bagnet) does turn from the almanac at last. ``Don't be cast down! ``Why, soldiers, why--should we be melancholy, boys?
'' Cheer up, my hearty!'' (soldiers boys)

The clerk having now again gone in to say that they are still there and Mr. Tulkinghorn being heard to return with some irascibility,

``Let 'em come in then!'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
they pass into the great room with the painted ceiling and find him (Tulkinghorn) standing before the fire.

``Now, you men, what do you want? Sergeant, I told you the last time I saw you that I don't desire your company here.'' (Sergeant)

Sergeant replies--dashed within the last few minutes as to his (Sergeant) usual manner of speech, and even as to his (Sergeant) usual carriage--that he (Sergeant) has received this letter, has been to Mr. Smallweed about it, and has been referred there.

``I have nothing to say to you,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
rejoins Mr. Tulkinghorn.
``If you get into debt, you must pay your debts or take the consequences. You have no occasion to come here to learn that, I suppose?'' (Sergeant)

Sergeant is sorry to say that he (Tulkinghorn) is not prepared with the money.

``Very well! Then the other man--this man, if this is he (man)--must pay it for you.'' (Sergeant)

Sergeant is sorry to add that the other man is not prepared with the money either.

``Very well! Then you must pay it between you or you must both be sued for it and both suffer. You have had the money and must refund it. You are not to pocket other people's pounds, shillings, and pence and escape scot-free.'' (The lawyer)

The lawyer sits down in his (lawyer) easy-chair and stirs the fire. Mr. George hopes he (George) will have the goodness to--

``I tell you, sergeant, I have nothing to say to you. I don't like your associates and don't want you here. This matter is not at all in my course of practice and is not in my office. Mr. Smallweed is good enough to offer these affairs to me, but they are not in my way. You must go to Melchisedech's in Clifford's Inn.'' (he)

``I must make an apology to you, sir,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George,
``for pressing myself upon you with so little encouragement--which is almost as unpleasant to me as it can be to you--but would you let me say a private word to you?'' (Mr. George/George)

Mr. Tulkinghorn rises with his (Tulkinghorn) hands in his (Tulkinghorn) pockets and walks into one of the window recesses.

``Now! I have no time to waste.'' (the midst)
In the midst of his (Tulkinghorn) perfect assumption of indifference, he (Tulkinghorn) directs a sharp look at the trooper, taking care to stand with his (Tulkinghorn) own back to the light and to have the other with his (Tulkinghorn) face towards it.

``Well, sir,'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George,
``this man with me is the other party implicated in this unfortunate affair--nominally, only nominally--and my sole object is to prevent his (man) getting into trouble on my account. He (man) is a most respectable man with a wife and family, formerly in the Royal Artillery--'' (Mr. George/George)

``My friend, I don't care a pinch of snuff for the whole Royal Artillery establishment--officers, men, tumbrils, waggons, horses, guns, and ammunition.'' (unknown)

''`Tis likely, sir. But I care a good deal for Bagnet and his (Bagnet) wife and family being injured on my account. And if I could bring them through this matter, I should have no help for it but to give up without any other consideration what you wanted of me the other day.'' (unknown)

``Have you got it here?'' (unknown)

``I have got it here, sir.'' (unknown)

``Sergeant,'' (the lawyer)
the lawyer proceeds in his (lawyer) dry passionless manner, far more hopeless in the dealing with than any amount of vehemence,
``make up your mind while I speak to you, for this is final. After I have finished speaking I have closed the subject, and I won't re-open it. Understand that. You can leave here, for a few days, what you say you have brought here if you choose; you can take it away at once if you choose. In case you choose to leave it here, I can do this for you--I can replace this matter on its old footing, and I can go so far besides as to give you a written undertaking that this man Bagnet shall never be troubled in any way until you have been proceeded against to the utmost, that your means shall be exhausted before the creditor looks to his (Bagnet). This is in fact all but freeing him (Bagnet). Have you decided?'' (the lawyer)

The trooper puts his (trooper) hand into his (trooper) breast and answers with a long breath,

``I must do it, sir.'' (The trooper)

So Mr. Tulkinghorn, putting on his (Tulkinghorn) spectacles, sits down and writes the undertaking, which he (Tulkinghorn) slowly reads and explains to Bagnet, who has all this time been staring at the ceiling and who puts his (Bagnet) hand on his (Bagnet) bald head again, under this new verbal shower-bath, and seems exceedingly in need of the old girl through whom to express his (Bagnet) sentiments. The trooper then takes from his (trooper) breast-pocket a folded paper, which he (trooper) lays with an unwilling hand at the lawyer's elbow.

''`Tis only a letter of instructions, sir. The last I ever had from him (trooper).'' (the lawyer)

Look at a millstone, Mr. George, for some change in its expression, and you will find it quite as soon as in the face of Mr. Tulkinghorn when he (Tulkinghorn) opens and reads the letter! He (Tulkinghorn) refolds it and lays it in his (Tulkinghorn) desk with a countenance as unperturbable as death.

Nor has he (Tulkinghorn) anything more to say or do but to nod once in the same frigid and discourteous manner and to say briefly,

``You can go. Show these men out, there!'' (he)
Being shown out, they repair to Mr. Bagnet's residence to dine.

Boiled beef and greens constitute the day's variety on the former repast of boiled pork and greens, and Mrs. Bagnet serves out the meal in the same way and seasons it with the best of temper, being that rare sort of old girl that she (girl) receives Good to her (girl) arms without a hint that it might be Better and catches light from any little spot of darkness near her (girl). The spot on this occasion is the darkened brow of Mr. George; he (George) is unusually thoughtful and depressed. At first Mrs. Bagnet trusts to the combined endearments of Quebec and Malta to restore him (George), but finding those young ladies sensible that their existing Bluffy is not the Bluffy of their usual frolicsome acquaintance, she (Bagnet) winks off the light infantry and leaves him (acquaintance) to deploy at leisure on the open ground of the domestic hearth.

But he (acquaintance) does not. He (acquaintance) remains in close order, clouded and depressed. During the lengthy cleaning up and pattening process, when he (acquaintance) and Mr. Bagnet are supplied with their pipes, he (Bagnet) is no better than he (Bagnet) was at dinner. He (Bagnet) forgets to smoke, looks at the fire and ponders, lets his (Bagnet) pipe out, fills the breast of Mr. Bagnet with perturbation and dismay by showing that he (Bagnet) has no enjoyment of tobacco.

Therefore when Mrs. Bagnet at last appears, rosy from the invigorating pail, and sits down to her (Bagnet) work, Mr. Bagnet growls,

``Old girl!'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
and winks monitions to her (Bagnet) to find out what's the matter.

``Why, George!'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
says Mrs. Bagnet, quietly threading her (Bagnet) needle.
``How low you are!'' (unknown)

``Am I? Not good company? Well, I am afraid I am not.'' (unknown)

``He (George) ain't at all like Bluffy, mother!'' (unknown)
cries little Malta.

``Because he (George) ain't well, I think, mother,'' (unknown)
adds Quebec.

``Sure that's a bad sign not to be like Bluffy, too!'' (returns the trooper)
returns the trooper, kissing the young damsels.
``But it's true,'' (unknown)
with a sigh,
``true, I am afraid. These little ones are always right!'' (unknown)

``George,'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
says Mrs. Bagnet, working busily,
``if I thought you cross enough to think of anything that a shrill old soldier's wife--who could have bitten her (wife) tongue off afterwards and ought to have done it almost--said this morning, I don't know what I shouldn't say to you now.'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

``My kind soul of a darling,'' (the trooper)
returns the trooper.
``Not a morsel of it.'' (unknown)

``Because really and truly, George, what I said and meant to say was that I trusted Lignum to you and was sure you'd bring him (George) through it. And you HAVE brought him (George) through it, noble!'' (unknown)

``Thankee, my dear!'' (Mr. George/George)
says George.
``I am glad of your good opinion.'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

In giving Mrs. Bagnet's hand, with her (Bagnet) work in it, a friendly shake--for she (Bagnet) took her (Bagnet) seat beside him (George)--the trooper's attention is attracted to her (Bagnet) face. After looking at it for a little while as she (Bagnet) plies her (Bagnet) needle, he (George) looks to young Woolwich, sitting on his (George) stool in the corner, and beckons that fifer to him (George).

``See there, my boy,'' (Mr. George/George)
says George, very gently smoothing the mother's hair with his (George) hand,
``there's a good loving forehead for you! All bright with love of you, my boy. A little touched by the sun and the weather through following your father about and taking care of you, but as fresh and wholesome as a ripe apple on a tree.'' (the mother)

Mr. Bagnet's face expresses, so far as in its wooden material lies, the highest approbation and acquiescence.

``The time will come, my boy,'' (the trooper)
pursues the trooper, ``when this hair of your mother's will be grey, and this forehead all crossed and re-crossed with wrinkles, and a fine old lady she (lady)'ll be then. Take care, while you are young, that you can think in those days, ``I never whitened a hair of her (lady) dear head--I never marked a sorrowful line in her (lady) face!
'' For of all the many things that you can think of when you are a man, you had better have THAT by you, Woolwich!'' (I)

Mr. George concludes by rising from his (George) chair, seating the boy beside his (George) mother in it, and saying, with something of a hurry about him (George), that he (George)'ll smoke his (George) pipe in the street a bit.

CHAPTER XXXV

Esther's Narrative

I lay ill through several weeks, and the usual tenor of my life became like an old remembrance. But this was not the effect of time so much as of the change in all my habits made by the helplessness and inaction of a sick-room. Before I had been confined to it many days, everything else seemed to have retired into a remote distance where there was little or no separation between the various stages of my life which had been really divided by years. In falling ill, I seemed to have crossed a dark lake and to have left all my experiences, mingled together by the great distance, on the healthy shore.

My housekeeping duties, though at first it caused me great anxiety to think that they were unperformed, were soon as far off as the oldest of the old duties at Greenleaf or the summer afternoons when I went home from school with my portfolio under my arm, and my childish shadow at my side, to my godmother's house. I had never known before how short life really was and into how small a space the mind could put it.

While I was very ill, the way in which these divisions of time became confused with one another distressed my mind exceedingly. At once a child, an elder girl, and the little woman I had been so happy as, I was not only oppressed by cares and difficulties adapted to each station, but by the great perplexity of endlessly trying to reconcile them. I suppose that few who have not been in such a condition can quite understand what I mean or what painful unrest arose from this source.

For the same reason I am almost afraid to hint at that time in my disorder--it seemed one long night, but I believe there were both nights and days in it--when I laboured up colossal staircases, ever striving to reach the top, and ever turned, as I have seen a worm in a garden path, by some obstruction, and labouring again. I knew perfectly at intervals, and I think vaguely at most times, that I was in my bed; and I talked with Charley, and felt her (I) touch, and knew her (I) very well; yet I would find myself complaining,

``Oh, more of these never-ending stairs, Charley--more and more--piled up to the sky', I think!'' (I)
and labouring on again.

Dare I hint at that worse time when, strung together somewhere in great black space, there was a flaming necklace, or ring, or starry circle of some kind, of which I was one of the beads! And when my only prayer was to be taken off from the rest and when it was such inexplicable agony and misery to be a part of the dreadful thing?

Perhaps the less I say of these sick experiences, the less tedious and the more intelligible I shall be. I do not recall them to make others unhappy or because I am now the least unhappy in remembering them. It may be that if we knew more of such strange afflictions we might be the better able to alleviate their intensity.

The repose that succeeded, the long delicious sleep, the blissful rest, when in my weakness I was too calm to have any care for myself and could have heard -LRB-or so I think now-RRB- that I was dying, with no other emotion than with a pitying love for those I left behind--this state can be perhaps more widely understood. I was in this state when I first shrunk from the light as it twinkled on me once more, and knew with a boundless joy for which no words are rapturous enough that I should see again.

I had heard my Ada crying at the door, day and night; I had heard her (Ada) calling to me that I was cruel and did not love her (Ada); I had heard her (Ada) praying and imploring to be let in to nurse and comfort me and to leave my bedside no more; but I had only said, when I could speak,

``Never, my sweet girl, never!'' (I)
and I had over and over again reminded Charley that she (Ada) was to keep my darling from the room whether I lived or died. Charley had been true to me in that time of need, and with her (Ada) little hand and her (Ada) great heart had kept the door fast.

But now, my sight strengthening and the glorious light coming every day more fully and brightly on me, I could read the letters that my dear wrote to me every morning and evening and could put them to my lips and lay my cheek upon them with no fear of hurting her (Ada). I could see my little maid, so tender and so careful, going about the two rooms setting everything in order and speaking cheerfully to Ada from the open window again. I could understand the stillness in the house and the thoughtfulness it expressed on the part of all those who had always been so good to me. I could weep in the exquisite felicity of my heart and be as happy in my weakness as ever I had been in my strength.

By and by my strength began to be restored. Instead of lying, with so strange a calmness, watching what was done for me, as if it were done for some one else whom I was quietly sorry for, I helped it a little, and so on to a little more and much more, until I became useful to myself, and interested, and attached to life again.

How well I remember the pleasant afternoon when I was raised in bed with pillows for the first time to enjoy a great tea-drinking with Charley! The little creature--sent into the world, surely, to minister to the weak and sick--was so happy, and so busy, and stopped so often in her (I) preparations to lay her (I) head upon my bosom, and fondle me, and cry with joyful tears she (I) was so glad, she (I) was so glad, that I was obliged to say,

``Charley, if you go on in this way, I must lie down again, my darling, for I am weaker than I thought I was!'' (I)
So Charley became as quiet as a mouse and took her (I) bright face here and there across and across the two rooms, out of the shade into the divine sunshine, and out of the sunshine into the shade, while I watched her (I) peacefully. When all her (I) preparations were concluded and the pretty tea-table with its little delicacies to tempt me, and its white cloth, and its flowers, and everything so lovingly and beautifully arranged for me by Ada downstairs, was ready at the bedside, I felt sure I was steady enough to say something to Charley that was not new to my thoughts.

First I complimented Charley on the room, and indeed it was so fresh and airy, so spotless and neat, that I could scarce believe I had been lying there so long. This delighted Charley, and her (Ada) face was brighter than before.

``Yet, Charley,'' (I)
said I, looking round,
``I miss something, surely, that I am accustomed to?'' (I)

Poor little Charley looked round too and pretended to shake her (Ada) head as if there were nothing absent.

``Are the pictures all as they used to be?'' (I)
I asked her (Ada).

``Every one of them, miss,'' (Charley)
said Charley.

``And the furniture, Charley?'' (unknown)

``Except where I have moved it about to make more room, miss.'' (unknown)

``And yet,'' (I)
said I,
``I miss some familiar object. Ah, I know what it is, Charley! It's the looking-glass.'' (I)

Charley got up from the table, making as if she (Ada) had forgotten something, and went into the next room; and I heard her (Ada) sob there.

I had thought of this very often. I was now certain of it. I could thank God that it was not a shock to me now. I called Charley back, and when she (Ada) came--at first pretending to smile, but as she (Ada) drew nearer to me, looking grieved--I took her (Ada) in my arms and said,

``It matters very little, Charley. I hope I can do without my old face very well.'' (her)

I was presently so far advanced as to be able to sit up in a great chair and even giddily to walk into the adjoining room, leaning on Charley. The mirror was gone from its usual place in that room too, but what I had to bear was none the harder to bear for that.

My guardian had throughout been earnest to visit me, and there was now no good reason why I should deny myself that happiness. He (Charley) came one morning, and when he (Charley) first came in, could only hold me in his (Charley) embrace and say,

``My dear, dear girl!'' (me)
I had long known--who could know better?--what a deep fountain of affection and generosity his (Charley) heart was; and was it not worth my trivial suffering and change to fill such a place in it?
``Oh, yes!'' (I)
I thought.
``He (Charley) has seen me, and he (Charley) loves me better than he (Charley) did; he (Charley) has seen me and is even fonder of me than he (Charley) was before; and what have I to mourn for!'' (He)

He (Charley) sat down by me on the sofa, supporting me with his (Charley) arm. For a little while he (Charley) sat with his (Charley) hand over his (Charley) face, but when he (Charley) removed it, fell into his (Charley) usual manner. There never can have been, there never can be, a pleasanter manner.

``My little woman,'' (he)
said he (Charley),
``what a sad time this has been. Such an inflexible little woman, too, through all!'' (he)

``Only for the best, guardian,'' (I.)
said I.

``For the best?'' (I.)
he (Charley) repeated tenderly.
``Of course, for the best. But here have Ada and I been perfectly forlorn and miserable; here has your friend Caddy been coming and going late and early; here has every one about the house been utterly lost and dejected; here has even poor Rick been writing--to ME too--in his (Rick) anxiety for you!'' (I)

I had read of Caddy in Ada's letters, but not of Richard. I told him (Richard) so.

``Why, no, my dear,'' (he)
he (Richard) replied.
``I have thought it better not to mention it to her (Ada).'' (unknown)

``And you speak of his (Rick) writing to YOU,'' (I)
said I, repeating his (Richard) emphasis.
``As if it were not natural for him (Rick) to do so, guardian; as if he (Rick) could write to a better friend!'' (unknown)

``He (Rick) thinks he (Rick) could, my love,'' (guardian)
returned my guardian,
``and to many a better. The truth is, he (Rick) wrote to me under a sort of protest while unable to write to you with any hope of an answer--wrote coldly, haughtily, distantly, resentfully. Well, dearest little woman, we must look forbearingly on it. He (Rick) is not to blame. Jarndyce and Jarndyce has warped him (Jarndyce) out of himself and perverted me in his (Jarndyce) eyes. I have known it do as bad deeds, and worse, many a time. If two angels could be concerned in it, I believe it would change their nature.'' (guardian)

``It has not changed yours, guardian.'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes, it has, my dear,'' (he)
he (Richard) said laughingly.
``It has made the south wind easterly, I don't know how often. Rick mistrusts and suspects me--goes to lawyers, and is taught to mistrust and suspect me. Hears I have conflicting interests, claims clashing against his (Rick) and what not. Whereas, heaven knows that if I could get out of the mountains of wiglomeration on which my unfortunate name has been so long bestowed -LRB-which I can't-RRB- or could level them by the extinction of my own original right -LRB-which I can't either, and no human power ever can, anyhow, I believe, to such a pass have we got-RRB-, I would do it this hour. I would rather restore to poor Rick his (Rick) proper nature than be endowed with all the money that dead suitors, broken, heart and soul, upon the wheel of Chancery, have left unclaimed with the Accountant-General--and that's money enough, my dear, to be cast into a pyramid, in memory of Chancery's transcendent wickedness.'' (unknown)

``IS it possible, guardian,'' (I)
I asked, amazed,
``that Richard can be suspicious of you?'' (I)

``Ah, my love, my love,'' (he)
he (Richard) said,
``it is in the subtle poison of such abuses to breed such diseases. His (Richard) blood is infected, and objects lose their natural aspects in his (Richard) sight. It is not HIS (Richard) fault.'' (he)

``But it is a terrible misfortune, guardian.'' (unknown)

``It is a terrible misfortune, little woman, to be ever drawn within the influences of Jarndyce and Jarndyce. I know none greater. By little and little he (Jarndyce) has been induced to trust in that rotten reed, and it communicates some portion of its rottenness to everything around him (Jarndyce). But again I say with all my soul, we must be patient with poor Rick and not blame him (Rick). What a troop of fine fresh hearts like his (Rick) have I seen in my time turned by the same means!'' (I)

I could not help expressing something of my wonder and regret that his (Richard) benevolent, disinterested intentions had prospered so little.

``We must not say so, Dame Durden,'' (he)
he (Richard) cheerfully replied;
``Ada is the happier, I hope, and that is much. I did think that I and both these young creatures might be friends instead of distrustful foes and that we might so far counter-act the suit and prove too strong for it. But it was too much to expect. Jarndyce and Jarndyce was the curtain of Rick's cradle.'' (he)

``But, guardian, may we not hope that a little experience will teach him (Rick) what a false and wretched thing it is?'' (unknown)

``We WILL hope so, my Esther,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
said Mr. Jarndyce,
``and that it may not teach him (Rick) so too late. In any case we must not be hard on him (Rick). There are not many grown and matured men living while we speak, good men too, who if they were thrown into this same court as suitors would not be vitally changed and depreciated within three years--within two--within one. How can we stand amazed at poor Rick? A young man so unfortunate,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
here he (Jarndyce) fell into a lower tone, as if he (Jarndyce) were thinking aloud,
``cannot at first believe -LRB-who could?-RRB- that Chancery is what it is. He (Rick) looks to it, flushed and fitfully, to do something with his (Rick) interests and bring them to some settlement. It procrastinates, disappoints, tries, tortures him (Rick); wears out his (Rick) sanguine hopes and patience, thread by thread; but he (Rick) still looks to it, and hankers after it, and finds his (Rick) whole world treacherous and hollow. Well, well, well! Enough of this, my dear!'' (he)

He (Jarndyce) had supported me, as at first, all this time, and his (Jarndyce) tenderness was so precious to me that I leaned my head upon his (Jarndyce) shoulder and loved him (Jarndyce) as if he (Jarndyce) had been my father. I resolved in my own mind in this little pause, by some means, to see Richard when I grew strong and try to set him (Richard) right.

``There are better subjects than these,'' (guardian)
said my guardian,
``for such a joyful time as the time of our dear girl's recovery. And I had a commission to broach one of them as soon as I should begin to talk. When shall Ada come to see you, my love?'' (guardian)

I had been thinking of that too. A little in connexion with the absent mirrors, but not much, for I knew my loving girl would be changed by no change in my looks.

``Dear guardian,'' (I)
said I,
``as I have shut her (Ada) out so long--though indeed, indeed, she (Ada) is like the light to me--'' (I)

``I know it well, Dame Durden, well.'' (I)

He (Richard) was so good, his (Richard) touch expressed such endearing compassion and affection, and the tone of his (Richard) voice carried such comfort into my heart that I stopped for a little while, quite unable to go on.

``Yes, yes, you are tired,'' (he)
said he (Richard).
``Rest a little.'' (unknown)

``As I have kept Ada out so long,'' (I)
I began afresh after a short while,
``I think I should like to have my own way a little longer, guardian. It would be best to be away from here before I see her (Ada). If Charley and I were to go to some country lodging as soon as I can move, and if I had a week there in which to grow stronger and to be revived by the sweet air and to look forward to the happiness of having Ada with me again, I think it would be better for us.'' (I)

I hope it was not a poor thing in me to wish to be a little more used to my altered self before I met the eyes of the dear girl I longed so ardently to see, but it is the truth. I did. He (Richard) understood me, I was sure; but I was not afraid of that. If it were a poor thing, I knew he (Richard) would pass it over.

``Our spoilt little woman,'' (guardian)
said my guardian,
``shall have her (woman) own way even in her (woman) inflexibility, though at the price, I know, of tears downstairs. And see here! Here is Boythorn, heart of chivalry, breathing such ferocious vows as never were breathed on paper before, that if you don't go and occupy his (Boythorn) whole house, he (Boythorn) having already turned out of it expressly for that purpose, by heaven and by earth he (Boythorn)'ll pull it down and not leave one brick standing on another!'' (guardian)

And my guardian put a letter in my hand, without any ordinary beginning such as

``My dear Jarndyce,'' (guardian)
but rushing at once into the words,
``I swear if Miss Summerson do not come down and take possession of my house, which I vacate for her (Boythorn) this day at one o'clock, P.M.,'' (guardian)
and then with the utmost seriousness, and in the most emphatic terms, going on to make the extraordinary declaration he (Richard) had quoted. We did not appreciate the writer the less for laughing heartily over it, and we settled that I should send him (Richard) a letter of thanks on the morrow and accept his (Richard) offer. It was a most agreeable one to me, for all the places I could have thought of, I should have liked to go to none so well as Chesney Wold.

``Now, little housewife,'' (guardian)
said my guardian, looking at his (Wold) watch,
``I was strictly timed before I came upstairs, for you must not be tired too soon; and my time has waned away to the last minute. I have one other petition. Little Miss Flite, hearing a rumour that you were ill, made nothing of walking down here--twenty miles, poor soul, in a pair of dancing shoes--to inquire. It was heaven's mercy we were at home, or she (housewife) would have walked back again.'' (guardian)

The old conspiracy to make me happy! Everybody seemed to be in it!

``Now, pet,'' (guardian)
said my guardian,
``if it would not be irksome to you to admit the harmless little creature one afternoon before you save Boythorn's otherwise devoted house from demolition, I believe you would make her (housewife) prouder and better pleased with herself than I--though my eminent name is Jarndyce--could do in a lifetime.'' (guardian)

I have no doubt he (Wold) knew there would be something in the simple image of the poor afflicted creature that would fall like a gentle lesson on my mind at that time. I felt it as he (Wold) spoke to me. I could not tell him (Wold) heartily enough how ready I was to receive her (I). I had always pitied her (I), never so much as now. I had always been glad of my little power to soothe her (I) under her (I) calamity, but never, never, half so glad before.

We arranged a time for Miss Flite to come out by the coach and share my early dinner. When my guardian left me, I turned my face away upon my couch and prayed to be forgiven if I, surrounded by such blessings, had magnified to myself the little trial that I had to undergo. The childish prayer of that old birthday when I had aspired to be industrious, contented, and true-hearted and to do good to some one and win some love to myself if I could came back into my mind with a reproachful sense of all the happiness I had since enjoyed and all the affectionate hearts that had been turned towards me. If I were weak now, what had I profited by those mercies? I repeated the old childish prayer in its old childish words and found that its old peace had not departed from it.

My guardian now came every day. In a week or so more I could walk about our rooms and hold long talks with Ada from behind the window-curtain. Yet I never saw her (Ada), for I had not as yet the courage to look at the dear face, though I could have done so easily without her (Ada) seeing me.

On the appointed day Miss Flite arrived. The poor little creature ran into my room quite forgetful of her (Ada) usual dignity, and crying from her (Ada) very heart of hearts,

``My dear Fitz Jarndyce!'' (The creature)
fell upon my neck and kissed me twenty times.

``Dear me!'' (she)
said she (Ada), putting her (Ada) hand into her (Ada) reticule,
``I have nothing here but documents, my dear Fitz Jarndyce; I must borrow a pocket handkerchief.'' (she)

Charley gave her (Ada) one, and the good creature certainly made use of it, for she (Ada) held it to her (Ada) eyes with both hands and sat so, shedding tears for the next ten minutes.

``With pleasure, my dear Fitz Jarndyce,'' (she)
she (Ada) was careful to explain.
``Not the least pain. Pleasure to see you well again. Pleasure at having the honour of being admitted to see you. I am so much fonder of you, my love, than of the Chancellor. Though I DO attend court regularly. By the by, my dear, mentioning pocket handkerchiefs--'' (Charley)

Miss Flite here looked at Charley, who had been to meet her (Ada) at the place where the coach stopped. Charley glanced at me and looked unwilling to pursue the suggestion.

``Ve-ry right!'' (unknown)
said Miss Flite,
``Ve-ry correct. Truly! Highly indiscreet of me to mention it; but my dear Miss Fitz Jarndyce, I am afraid I am at times -LRB-between ourselves, you wouldn't think it-RRB- a little--rambling you know,'' (unknown)
said Miss Flite, touching her (Ada) forehead.
``Nothing more.'' (unknown)

``What were you going to tell me?'' (I)
said I, smiling, for I saw she (Ada) wanted to go on.
``You have roused my curiosity, and now you must gratify it.'' (Charley)

Miss Flite looked at Charley for advice in this important crisis, who said,

``If you please, ma'am, you had better tell then,'' (Charley)
and therein gratified Miss Flite beyond measure.

``So sagacious, our young friend,'' (she)
said she (Ada) to me in her (Ada) mysterious way.
``Diminutive. But ve-ry sagacious! Well, my dear, it's a pretty anecdote. Nothing more. Still I think it charming. Who should follow us down the road from the coach, my dear, but a poor person in a very ungenteel bonnet--'' (Charley)

``Jenny, if you please, miss,'' (Charley)
said Charley.

``Just so!'' (unknown)
Miss Flite acquiesced with the greatest suavity.
``Jenny. Ye-es! And what does she (Jenny) tell our young friend but that there has been a lady with a veil inquiring at her (Jenny) cottage after my dear Fitz Jarndyce's health and taking a handkerchief away with her (Jenny) as a little keepsake merely because it was my amiable Fitz Jarndyce's! Now, you know, so very prepossessing in the lady with the veil!'' (unknown)

``If you please, miss,'' (Charley)
said Charley, to whom I looked in some astonishment,
``Jenny says that when her (Jenny) baby died, you left a handkerchief there, and that she (Jenny) put it away and kept it with the baby's little things. I think, if you please, partly because it was yours, miss, and partly because it had covered the baby.'' (I)

``Diminutive,'' (Charley)
whispered Miss Flite, making a variety of motions about her (Ada) own forehead to express intellect in Charley.
``But exceedingly sagacious! And so dear! My love, she (Jenny)'s clearer than any counsel I ever heard!'' (unknown)

``Yes, Charley,'' (I)
I returned.
``I remember it. Well?'' (unknown)

``Well, miss,'' (Charley)
said Charley,
``and that's the handkerchief the lady took. And Jenny wants you to know that she (Jenny) wouldn't have made away with it herself for a heap of money but that the lady took it and left some money instead. Jenny don't know her (Jenny) at all, if you please, miss!'' (Charley)

``Why, who can she (Jenny) be?'' (I.)
said I.

``My love,'' (I.)
Miss Flite suggested, advancing her (Ada) lips to my ear with her (Ada) most mysterious look,
``in MY opinion--don't mention this to our diminutive friend--she (MY)'s the Lord Chancellor's wife. He (Chancellor)'s married, you know. And I understand she (MY) leads him (Chancellor) a terrible life. Throws his (Chancellor) lordship's papers into the fire, my dear, if he (Chancellor) won't pay the jeweller!'' (I.)

I did not think very much about this lady then, for I had an impression that it might be Caddy. Besides, my attention was diverted by my visitor, who was cold after her (lady) ride and looked hungry and who, our dinner being brought in, required some little assistance in arraying herself with great satisfaction in a pitiable old scarf and a much-worn and often-mended pair of gloves, which she (lady) had brought down in a paper parcel. I had to preside, too, over the entertainment, consisting of a dish of fish, a roast fowl, a sweetbread, vegetables, pudding, and Madeira; and it was so pleasant to see how she (lady) enjoyed it, and with what state and ceremony she (lady) did honour to it, that I was soon thinking of nothing else.

When we had finished and had our little dessert before us, embellished by the hands of my dear, who would yield the superintendence of everything prepared for me to no one, Miss Flite was so very chatty and happy that I thought I would lead her (lady) to her (lady) own history, as she (lady) was always pleased to talk about herself. I began by saying

``You have attended on the Lord Chancellor many years, Miss Flite?'' (I)

``Oh, many, many, many years, my dear. But I expect a judgment. Shortly.'' (me)

There was an anxiety even in her (lady) hopefulness that made me doubtful if I had done right in approaching the subject. I thought I would say no more about it.

``My father expected a judgment,'' (unknown)
said Miss Flite.
``My brother. My sister. They all expected a judgment. The same that I expect.'' (unknown)

``They are all--'' (unknown)

``Ye-es. Dead of course, my dear,'' (she)
said she (lady).

As I saw she (lady) would go on, I thought it best to try to be serviceable to her (lady) by meeting the theme rather than avoiding it.

``Would it not be wiser,'' (I)
said I,
``to expect this judgment no more?'' (I)

``Why, my dear,'' (she)
she (lady) answered promptly,
``of course it would!'' (she)

``And to attend the court no more?'' (unknown)

``Equally of course,'' (she)
said she (lady).
``Very wearing to be always in expectation of what never comes, my dear Fitz Jarndyce! Wearing, I assure you, to the bone!'' (She)

She (lady) slightly showed me her (lady) arm, and it was fearfully thin indeed.

``But, my dear,'' (she)
she (lady) went on in her (lady) mysterious way, ``there's a dreadful attraction in the place. Hush! Don't mention it to our diminutive friend when she (our) comes in. Or it may frighten her (our). With good reason. There's a cruel attraction in the place. You CAN
``T leave it. And you MUST expect.'' (I)

I tried to assure her (lady) that this was not so. She (lady) heard me patiently and smilingly, but was ready with her (lady) own answer.

``Aye, aye, aye! You think so because I am a little rambling. Ve-ry absurd, to be a little rambling, is it not? Ve-ry confusing, too. To the head. I find it so. But, my dear, I have been there many years, and I have noticed. It's the mace and seal upon the table.'' (she)

What could they do, did she (lady) think? I mildly asked her (lady).

``Draw,'' (unknown)
returned Miss Flite.
``Draw people on, my dear. Draw peace out of them. Sense out of them. Good looks out of them. Good qualities out of them. I have felt them even drawing my rest away in the night. Cold and glittering devils!'' (She)

She (lady) tapped me several times upon the arm and nodded good-humouredly as if she (lady) were anxious I should understand that I had no cause to fear her (lady), though she (lady) spoke so gloomily, and confided these awful secrets to me.

``Let me see,'' (she)
said she (lady).
``I'll tell you my own case. Before they ever drew me--before I had ever seen them--what was it I used to do? Tambourine playing? No. Tambour work. I and my sister worked at tambour work. Our father and our brother had a builder's business. We all lived together. Ve-ry respectably, my dear! First, our father was drawn--slowly. Home was drawn with him (father). In a few years he (father) was a fierce, sour, angry bankrupt without a kind word or a kind look for any one. He (father) had been so different, Fitz Jarndyce. He (Jarndyce) was drawn to a debtors' prison. There he (Jarndyce) died. Then our brother was drawn--swiftly--to drunkenness. And rags. And death. Then my sister was drawn. Hush! Never ask to what! Then I was ill and in misery, and heard, as I had often heard before, that this was all the work of Chancery. When I got better, I went to look at the monster. And then I found out how it was, and I was drawn to stay there.'' (she)

Having got over her (lady) own short narrative, in the delivery of which she (lady) had spoken in a low, strained voice, as if the shock were fresh upon her (lady), she (lady) gradually resumed her (lady) usual air of amiable importance.

``You don't quite credit me, my dear! Well, well! You will, some day. I am a little rambling. But I have noticed. I have seen many new faces come, unsuspicious, within the influence of the mace and seal in these many years. As my father's came there. As my brother's. As my sister's. As my own. I hear Conversation Kenge and the rest of them say to the new faces, ``Here's little Miss Flite. Oh, you are new here; and you must come and be presented to little Miss Flite!

'' Ve-ry good. Proud I am sure to have the honour! And we all laugh. But, Fitz Jarndyce, I know what will happen. I know, far better than they do, when the attraction has begun. I know the signs, my dear. I saw them begin in Gridley. And I saw them end. Fitz Jarndyce, my love,'' (unknown)
speaking low again,
``I saw them beginning in our friend the ward in Jarndyce. Let some one hold him (Jarndyce) back. Or he (Jarndyce)'ll be drawn to ruin.'' (She)

She (lady) looked at me in silence for some moments, with her (lady) face gradually softening into a smile. Seeming to fear that she (lady) had been too gloomy, and seeming also to lose the connexion in her (lady) mind, she (lady) said politely as she (lady) sipped her (lady) glass of wine,

``Yes, my dear, as I was saying, I expect a judgment shortly. Then I shall release my birds, you know, and confer estates.'' (she)

I was much impressed by her (lady) allusion to Richard and by the sad meaning, so sadly illustrated in her (lady) poor pinched form, that made its way through all her (lady) incoherence. But happily for her (lady), she (lady) was quite complacent again now and beamed with nods and smiles.

``But, my dear,'' (she)
she (lady) said, gaily, reaching another hand to put it upon mine.
``You have not congratulated me on my physician. Positively not once, yet!'' (I)

I was obliged to confess that I did not quite know what she (lady) meant.

``My physician, Mr. Woodcourt, my dear, who was so exceedingly attentive to me. Though his (Woodcourt) services were rendered quite gratuitously. Until the Day of Judgment. I mean THE judgment that will dissolve the spell upon me of the mace and seal.'' (unknown)

``Mr. Woodcourt is so far away, now,'' (I)
said I,
``that I thought the time for such congratulation was past, Miss Flite.'' (I)

``But, my child,'' (she)
she (lady) returned,
``is it possible that you don't know what has happened?'' (she)

``No,'' (I.)
said I.

``Not what everybody has been talking of, my beloved Fitz Jarndyce!'' (I.)

``No,'' (I.)
said I.
``You forget how long I have been here.'' (I.)

``True! My dear, for the moment--true. I blame myself. But my memory has been drawn out of me, with everything else, by what I mentioned. Ve-ry strong influence, is it not? Well, my dear, there has been a terrible shipwreck over in those East Indian seas.'' (unknown)

``Mr. Woodcourt shipwrecked!'' (unknown)

``Don't be agitated, my dear. He (Woodcourt) is safe. An awful scene. Death in all shapes. Hundreds of dead and dying. Fire, storm, and darkness. Numbers of the drowning thrown upon a rock. There, and through it all, my dear physician was a hero. Calm and brave through everything. Saved many lives, never complained in hunger and thirst, wrapped naked people in his (physician) spare clothes, took the lead, showed them what to do, governed them, tended the sick, buried the dead, and brought the poor survivors safely off at last! My dear, the poor emaciated creatures all but worshipped him (physician). They fell down at his (physician) feet when they got to the land and blessed him (physician). The whole country rings with it. Stay! Where's my bag of documents? I have got it there, and you shall read it, you shall read it!'' (I)

And I DID read all the noble history, though very slowly and imperfectly then, for my eyes were so dimmed that I could not see the words, and I cried so much that I was many times obliged to lay down the long account she (lady) had cut out of the newspaper. I felt so triumphant ever to have known the man who had done such generous and gallant deeds, I felt such glowing exultation in his (man) renown, I so admired and loved what he (man) had done, that I envied the storm-worn people who had fallen at his (man) feet and blessed him (man) as their preserver. I could myself have kneeled down then, so far away, and blessed him (man) in my rapture that he (man) should be so truly good and brave. I felt that no one--mother, sister, wife--could honour him (man) more than I. I did, indeed!

My poor little visitor made me a present of the account, and when as the evening began to close in she (wife) rose to take her (wife) leave, lest she (wife) should miss the coach by which she (wife) was to return, she (wife) was still full of the shipwreck, which I had not yet sufficiently composed myself to understand in all its details.

``My dear,'' (she)
said she (wife) as she (wife) carefully folded up her (wife) scarf and gloves,
``my brave physician ought to have a title bestowed upon him (physician). And no doubt he (physician) will. You are of that opinion?'' (she)

That he (coach) well deserved one, yes. That he (coach) would ever have one, no.

``Why not, Fitz Jarndyce?'' (she)
she (wife) asked rather sharply.

I said it was not the custom in England to confer titles on men distinguished by peaceful services, however good and great, unless occasionally when they consisted of the accumulation of some very large amount of money.

``Why, good gracious,'' (unknown)
said Miss Flite,
``how can you say that? Surely you know, my dear, that all the greatest ornaments of England in knowledge, imagination, active humanity, and improvement of every sort are added to its nobility! Look round you, my dear, and consider. YOU must be rambling a little now, I think, if you don't know that this is the great reason why titles will always last in the land!'' (I)

I am afraid she (wife) believed what she (wife) said, for there were moments when she (wife) was very mad indeed.

And now I must part with the little secret I have thus far tried to keep. I had thought, sometimes, that Mr. Woodcourt loved me and that if he (Woodcourt) had been richer he (Woodcourt) would perhaps have told me that he (Woodcourt) loved me before he (Woodcourt) went away. I had thought, sometimes, that if he (Woodcourt) had done so, I should have been glad of it. But how much better it was now that this had never happened! What should I have suffered if I had had to write to him (Woodcourt) and tell him (Woodcourt) that the poor face he (Woodcourt) had known as mine was quite gone from me and that I freely released him (Woodcourt) from his (Woodcourt) bondage to one whom he (Woodcourt) had never seen!

Oh, it was so much better as it was! With a great pang mercifully spared me, I could take back to my heart my childish prayer to be all he (Woodcourt) had so brightly shown himself; and there was nothing to be undone: no chain for me to break or for him (Woodcourt) to drag; and I could go, please God, my lowly way along the path of duty, and he (God) could go his (God) nobler way upon its broader road; and though we were apart upon the journey, I might aspire to meet him (God), unselfishly, innocently, better far than he (God) had thought me when I found some favour in his (God) eyes, at the journey's end.

CHAPTER XXXVI

Chesney Wold

Charley and I did not set off alone upon our expedition into Lincolnshire. My guardian had made up his (Charley) mind not to lose sight of me until I was safe in Mr. Boythorn's house, so he (Boythorn) accompanied us, and we were two days upon the road. I found every breath of air, and every scent, and every flower and leaf and blade of grass, and every passing cloud, and everything in nature, more beautiful and wonderful to me than I had ever found it yet. This was my first gain from my illness. How little I had lost, when the wide world was so full of delight for me.

My guardian intending to go back immediately, we appointed, on our way down, a day when my dear girl should come. I wrote her (girl) a letter, of which he (I) took charge, and he (I) left us within half an hour of our arrival at our destination, on a delightful evening in the early summer-time.

If a good fairy had built the house for me with a wave of her (fairy) wand, and I had been a princess and her (fairy) favoured god-child, I could not have been more considered in it. So many preparations were made for me and such an endearing remembrance was shown of all my little tastes and likings that I could have sat down, overcome, a dozen times before I had revisited half the rooms. I did better than that, however, by showing them all to Charley instead. Charley's delight calmed mine; and after we had had a walk in the garden, and Charley had exhausted her (fairy) whole vocabulary of admiring expressions, I was as tranquilly happy as I ought to have been. It was a great comfort to be able to say to myself after tea,

``Esther, my dear, I think you are quite sensible enough to sit down now and write a note of thanks to your host.'' (He)
He (Charley) had left a note of welcome for me, as sunny as his (Charley) own face, and had confided his (Charley) bird to my care, which I knew to be his (Charley) highest mark of confidence. Accordingly I wrote a little note to him (Charley) in London, telling him (Charley) how all his (Charley) favourite plants and trees were looking, and how the most astonishing of birds had chirped the honours of the house to me in the most hospitable manner, and how, after singing on my shoulder, to the inconceivable rapture of my little maid, he (Charley) was then at roost in the usual corner of his (Charley) cage, but whether dreaming or no I could not report. My note finished and sent off to the post, I made myself very busy in unpacking and arranging; and I sent Charley to bed in good time and told her (maid) I should want her (maid) no more that night.

For I had not yet looked in the glass and had never asked to have my own restored to me. I knew this to be a weakness which must be overcome, but I had always said to myself that I would begin afresh when I got to where I now was. Therefore I had wanted to be alone, and therefore I said, now alone, in my own room,

``Esther, if you are to be happy, if you are to have any right to pray to be true-hearted, you must keep your word, my dear.'' (I)
I was quite resolved to keep it, but I sat down for a little while first to reflect upon all my blessings. And then I said my prayers and thought a little more.

My hair had not been cut off, though it had been in danger more than once. It was long and thick. I let it down, and shook it out, and went up to the glass upon the dressing-table. There was a little muslin curtain drawn across it. I drew it back and stood for a moment looking through such a veil of my own hair that I could see nothing else. Then I put my hair aside and looked at the reflection in the mirror, encouraged by seeing how placidly it looked at me. I was very much changed--oh, very, very much. At first my face was so strange to me that I think I should have put my hands before it and started back but for the encouragement I have mentioned. Very soon it became more familiar, and then I knew the extent of the alteration in it better than I had done at first. It was not like what I had expected, but I had expected nothing definite, and I dare say anything definite would have surprised me.

I had never been a beauty and had never thought myself one, but I had been very different from this. It was all gone now. Heaven was so good to me that I could let it go with a few not bitter tears and could stand there arranging my hair for the night quite thankfully.

One thing troubled me, and I considered it for a long time before I went to sleep. I had kept Mr. Woodcourt's flowers. When they were withered I had dried them and put them in a book that I was fond of. Nobody knew this, not even Ada. I was doubtful whether I had a right to preserve what he (Woodcourt) had sent to one so different--whether it was generous towards him (Woodcourt) to do it. I wished to be generous to him (Woodcourt), even in the secret depths of my heart, which he (Woodcourt) would never know, because I could have loved him (Woodcourt)--could have been devoted to him (Woodcourt). At last I came to the conclusion that I might keep them if I treasured them only as a remembrance of what was irrevocably past and gone, never to be looked back on any more, in any other light. I hope this may not seem trivial. I was very much in earnest.

I took care to be up early in the morning and to be before the glass when Charley came in on tiptoe.

``Dear, dear, miss!'' (Charley)
cried Charley, starting.
``Is that you?'' (unknown)

``Yes, Charley,'' (I)
said I, quietly putting up my hair.
``And I am very well indeed, and very happy.'' (I)

I saw it was a weight off Charley's mind, but it was a greater weight off mine. I knew the worst now and was composed to it. I shall not conceal, as I go on, the weaknesses I could not quite conquer, but they always passed from me soon and the happier frame of mind stayed by me faithfully.

Wishing to be fully re-established in my strength and my good spirits before Ada came, I now laid down a little series of plans with Charley for being in the fresh air all day long. We were to be out before breakfast, and were to dine early, and were to be out again before and after dinner, and were to talk in the garden after tea, and were to go to rest betimes, and were to climb every hill and explore every road, lane, and field in the neighbourhood. As to restoratives and strengthening delicacies, Mr. Boythorn's good housekeeper was for ever trotting about with something to eat or drink in her (housekeeper) hand; I could not even be heard of as resting in the park but she (housekeeper) would come trotting after me with a basket, her (housekeeper) cheerful face shining with a lecture on the importance of frequent nourishment. Then there was a pony expressly for my riding, a chubby pony with a short neck and a mane all over his (Boythorn) eyes who could canter--when he (Boythorn) would--so easily and quietly that he (Boythorn) was a treasure. In a very few days he (Boythorn) would come to me in the paddock when I called him (Boythorn), and eat out of my hand, and follow me about. We arrived at such a capital understanding that when he (Boythorn) was jogging with me lazily, and rather obstinately, down some shady lane, if I patted his (Boythorn) neck and said,

``Stubbs, I am surprised you don't canter when you know how much I like it; and I think you might oblige me, for you are only getting stupid and going to sleep,'' (I)
he (Boythorn) would give his (Boythorn) head a comical shake or two and set off directly, while Charley would stand still and laugh with such enjoyment that her (Boythorn) laughter was like music. I don't know who had given Stubbs his (Stubbs) name, but it seemed to belong to him (Stubbs) as naturally as his (Stubbs) rough coat. Once we put him (Stubbs) in a little chaise and drove him (Stubbs) triumphantly through the green lanes for five miles; but all at once, as we were extolling him (Stubbs) to the skies, he (Stubbs) seemed to take it ill that he (Stubbs) should have been accompanied so far by the circle of tantalizing little gnats that had been hovering round and round his (Stubbs) ears the whole way without appearing to advance an inch, and stopped to think about it. I suppose he (Stubbs) came to the decision that it was not to be borne, for he (Stubbs) steadily refused to move until I gave the reins to Charley and got out and walked, when he (Charley) followed me with a sturdy sort of good humour, putting his (Charley) head under my arm and rubbing his (Charley) ear against my sleeve. It was in vain for me to say,
``Now, Stubbs, I feel quite sure from what I know of you that you will go on if I ride a little while,'' (me)
for the moment I left him (Charley), he (Charley) stood stock still again. Consequently I was obliged to lead the way, as before; and in this order we returned home, to the great delight of the village.

Charley and I had reason to call it the most friendly of villages, I am sure, for in a week's time the people were so glad to see us go by, though ever so frequently in the course of a day, that there were faces of greeting in every cottage. I had known many of the grown people before and almost all the children, but now the very steeple began to wear a familiar and affectionate look. Among my new friends was an old old woman who lived in such a little thatched and whitewashed dwelling that when the outside shutter was turned up on its hinges, it shut up the whole house-front. This old lady had a grandson who was a sailor, and I wrote a letter to him (sailor) for her (lady) and drew at the top of it the chimney-corner in which she (lady) had brought him (sailor) up and where his (sailor) old stool yet occupied its old place. This was considered by the whole village the most wonderful achievement in the world, but when an answer came back all the way from Plymouth, in which he (sailor) mentioned that he (sailor) was going to take the picture all the way to America, and from America would write again, I got all the credit that ought to have been given to the post-office and was invested with the merit of the whole system.

Thus, what with being so much in the air, playing with so many children, gossiping with so many people, sitting on invitation in so many cottages, going on with Charley's education, and writing long letters to Ada every day, I had scarcely any time to think about that little loss of mine and was almost always cheerful. If I did think of it at odd moments now and then, I had only to be busy and forget it. I felt it more than I had hoped I should once when a child said,

``Mother, why is the lady not a pretty lady now like she (lady) used to be?'' (a child)
But when I found the child was not less fond of me, and drew its soft hand over my face with a kind of pitying protection in its touch, that soon set me up again. There were many little occurrences which suggested to me, with great consolation, how natural it is to gentle hearts to be considerate and delicate towards any inferiority. One of these particularly touched me. I happened to stroll into the little church when a marriage was just concluded, and the young couple had to sign the register.

The bridegroom, to whom the pen was handed first, made a rude cross for his (bridegroom) mark; the bride, who came next, did the same. Now, I had known the bride when I was last there, not only as the prettiest girl in the place, but as having quite distinguished herself in the school, and I could not help looking at her (girl) with some surprise. She (girl) came aside and whispered to me, while tears of honest love and admiration stood in her (girl) bright eyes,

``He (Stubbs)'s a dear good fellow, miss; but he (Stubbs) can't write yet--he (Stubbs)'s going to learn of me--and I wouldn't shame him (Stubbs) for the world!'' (me)
Why, what had I to fear, I thought, when there was this nobility in the soul of a labouring man's daughter!

The air blew as freshly and revivingly upon me as it had ever blown, and the healthy colour came into my new face as it had come into my old one. Charley was wonderful to see, she (daughter) was so radiant and so rosy; and we both enjoyed the whole day and slept soundly the whole night.

There was a favourite spot of mine in the park-woods of Chesney Wold where a seat had been erected commanding a lovely view. The wood had been cleared and opened to improve this point of sight, and the bright sunny landscape beyond was so beautiful that I rested there at least once every day. A picturesque part of the Hall, called the Ghost's Walk, was seen to advantage from this higher ground; and the startling name, and the old legend in the Dedlock family which I had heard from Mr. Boythorn accounting for it, mingled with the view and gave it something of a mysterious interest in addition to its real charms. There was a bank here, too, which was a famous one for violets; and as it was a daily delight of Charley's to gather wild flowers, she (I) took as much to the spot as I did.

It would be idle to inquire now why I never went close to the house or never went inside it. The family were not there, I had heard on my arrival, and were not expected. I was far from being incurious or uninterested about the building; on the contrary, I often sat in this place wondering how the rooms ranged and whether any echo like a footstep really did resound at times, as the story said, upon the lonely Ghost's Walk.
