The indefinable feeling with which Lady Dedlock had impressed me may have had some influence in keeping me from the house even when she (Dedlock) was absent. I am not sure. Her (Dedlock) face and figure were associated with it, naturally; but I cannot say that they repelled me from it, though something did. For whatever reason or no reason, I had never once gone near it, down to the day at which my story now arrives.

I was resting at my favourite point after a long ramble, and Charley was gathering violets at a little distance from me. I had been looking at the Ghost's Walk lying in a deep shade of masonry afar off and picturing to myself the female shape that was said to haunt it when I became aware of a figure approaching through the wood. The perspective was so long and so darkened by leaves, and the shadows of the branches on the ground made it so much more intricate to the eye, that at first I could not discern what figure it was. By little and little it revealed itself to be a woman's--a lady's--Lady Dedlock's. She (Dedlock) was alone and coming to where I sat with a much quicker step, I observed to my surprise, than was usual with her (Dedlock).

I was fluttered by her (Dedlock) being unexpectedly so near -LRB-she (Dedlock) was almost within speaking distance before I knew her (Dedlock)-RRB- and would have risen to continue my walk. But I could not. I was rendered motionless. Not so much by her (Dedlock) hurried gesture of entreaty, not so much by her (Dedlock) quick advance and outstretched hands, not so much by the great change in her (Dedlock) manner and the absence of her (Dedlock) haughty self-restraint, as by a something in her (Dedlock) face that I had pined for and dreamed of when I was a little child, something I had never seen in any face, something I had never seen in hers before.

A dread and faintness fell upon me, and I called to Charley. Lady Dedlock stopped upon the instant and changed back almost to what I had known her (Dedlock).

``Miss Summerson, I am afraid I have startled you,'' (she)
she (Dedlock) said, now advancing slowly.
``You can scarcely be strong yet. You have been very ill, I know. I have been much concerned to hear it.'' (I)

I could no more have removed my eyes from her (Dedlock) pale face than I could have stirred from the bench on which I sat. She (Dedlock) gave me her (Dedlock) hand, and its deadly coldness, so at variance with the enforced composure of her (Dedlock) features, deepened the fascination that overpowered me. I cannot say what was in my whirling thoughts.

``You are recovering again?'' (she)
she (Dedlock) asked kindly.

``I was quite well but a moment ago, Lady Dedlock.'' (unknown)

``Is this your young attendant?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``Will you send her (Lady) on before and walk towards your house with me?'' (unknown)

``Charley,'' (I)
said I,
``take your flowers home, and I will follow you directly.'' (I)

Charley, with her (Dedlock) best curtsy, blushingly tied on her (Dedlock) bonnet and went her (Dedlock) way. When she (Dedlock) was gone, Lady Dedlock sat down on the seat beside me.

I cannot tell in any words what the state of my mind was when I saw in her (Dedlock) hand my handkerchief with which I had covered the dead baby.

I looked at her (Dedlock), but I could not see her (Dedlock), I could not hear her (Dedlock), I could not draw my breath. The beating of my heart was so violent and wild that I felt as if my life were breaking from me. But when she (Dedlock) caught me to her (Dedlock) breast, kissed me, wept over me, compassionated me, and called me back to myself; when she (Dedlock) fell down on her (Dedlock) knees and cried to me,

``Oh, my child, my child, I am your wicked and unhappy mother! Oh, try to forgive me!'' (me)
--when I saw her (Dedlock) at my feet on the bare earth in her (Dedlock) great agony of mind, I felt, through all my tumult of emotion, a burst of gratitude to the providence of God that I was so changed as that I never could disgrace her (Dedlock) by any trace of likeness, as that nobody could ever now look at me and look at her (Dedlock) and remotely think of any near tie between us.

I raised my mother up, praying and beseeching her (mother) not to stoop before me in such affliction and humiliation. I did so in broken, incoherent words, for besides the trouble I was in, it frightened me to see her (mother) at MY feet. I told her (MY)--or I tried to tell her (MY)--that if it were for me, her (MY) child, under any circumstances to take upon me to forgive her (MY), I did it, and had done it, many, many years. I told her (MY) that my heart overflowed with love for her (MY), that it was natural love which nothing in the past had changed or could change. That it was not for me, then resting for the first time on my mother's bosom, to take her (mother) to account for having given me life, but that my duty was to bless her (mother) and receive her (mother), though the whole world turned from her (mother), and that I only asked her (mother) leave to do it. I held my mother in my embrace, and she (mother) held me in hers, and among the still woods in the silence of the summer day there seemed to be nothing but our two troubled minds that was not at peace.

``To bless and receive me,'' (mother)
groaned my mother,
``it is far too late. I must travel my dark road alone, and it will lead me where it will. From day to day, sometimes from hour to hour, I do not see the way before my guilty feet. This is the earthly punishment I have brought upon myself. I bear it, and I hide it.'' (mother)

Even in the thinking of her (mother) endurance, she (mother) drew her (mother) habitual air of proud indifference about her (mother) like a veil, though she (mother) soon cast it off again.

``I must keep this secret, if by any means it can be kept, not wholly for myself. I have a husband, wretched and dishonouring creature that I am!'' (she)

These words she (mother) uttered with a suppressed cry of despair, more terrible in its sound than any shriek. Covering her (mother) face with her (mother) hands, she (mother) shrank down in my embrace as if she (mother) were unwilling that I should touch her (mother); nor could I, by my utmost persuasions or by any endearments I could use, prevail upon her (mother) to rise. She (mother) said, no, no, no, she (mother) could only speak to me so; she (mother) must be proud and disdainful everywhere else; she (mother) would be humbled and ashamed there, in the only natural moments of her (mother) life.

My unhappy mother told me that in my illness she (mother) had been nearly frantic. She (mother) had but then known that her (mother) child was living. She (mother) could not have suspected me to be that child before. She (mother) had followed me down here to speak to me but once in all her (mother) life. We never could associate, never could communicate, never probably from that time forth could interchange another word on earth. She (mother) put into my hands a letter she (mother) had written for my reading only and said when I had read it and destroyed it--but not so much for her (mother) sake, since she (mother) asked nothing, as for her (mother) husband's and my own--I must evermore consider her (mother) as dead. If I could believe that she (mother) loved me, in this agony in which I saw her (mother), with a mother's love, she (mother) asked me to do that, for then I might think of her (mother) with a greater pity, imagining what she (mother) suffered. She (mother) had put herself beyond all hope and beyond all help. Whether she (mother) preserved her (mother) secret until death or it came to be discovered and she (mother) brought dishonour and disgrace upon the name she (mother) had taken, it was her (mother) solitary struggle always; and no affection could come near her (mother), and no human creature could render her (mother) any aid.

``But is the secret safe so far?'' (I)
I asked.
``Is it safe now, dearest mother?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (mother)
replied my mother.
``It has been very near discovery. It was saved by an accident. It may be lost by another accident--to-morrow, any day.'' (unknown)

``Do you dread a particular person?'' (unknown)

``Hush! Do not tremble and cry so much for me. I am not worthy of these tears,'' (mother)
said my mother, kissing my hands.
``I dread one person very much.'' (unknown)

``An enemy?'' (unknown)

``Not a friend. One who is too passionless to be either. He (friend) is Sir Leicester Dedlock's lawyer, mechanically faithful without attachment, and very jealous of the profit, privilege, and reputation of being master of the mysteries of great houses.'' (unknown)

``Has he (master) any suspicions?'' (unknown)

``Many.'' (unknown)

``Not of you?'' (I)
I said alarmed.

``Yes! He (master) is always vigilant and always near me. I may keep him (master) at a standstill, but I can never shake him (master) off.'' (unknown)

``Has he (master) so little pity or compunction?'' (unknown)

``He (master) has none, and no anger. He (master) is indifferent to everything but his (master) calling. His (master) calling is the acquisition of secrets and the holding possession of such power as they give him (master), with no sharer or opponent in it.'' (unknown)

``Could you trust in him (opponent)?'' (unknown)

``I shall never try. The dark road I have trodden for so many years will end where it will. I follow it alone to the end, whatever the end be. It may be near, it may be distant; while the road lasts, nothing turns me.'' (unknown)

``Dear mother, are you so resolved?'' (unknown)

``I AM resolved. I have long outbidden folly with folly, pride with pride, scorn with scorn, insolence with insolence, and have outlived many vanities with many more. I will outlive this danger, and outdie it, if I can. It has closed around me almost as awfully as if these woods of Chesney Wold had closed around the house, but my course through it is the same. I have but one; I can have but one.'' (unknown)

``Mr. Jarndyce--'' (I)
I was beginning when my mother hurriedly inquired,
``Does HE (Jarndyce) suspect?'' (mother)

``No,'' (I.)
said I.
``No, indeed! Be assured that he (Jarndyce) does not!'' (I.)
And I told her (mother) what he (mother) had related to me as his (mother) knowledge of my story.
``But he (Jarndyce) is so good and sensible,'' (I)
said I,
``that perhaps if he (Jarndyce) knew--'' (I)

My mother, who until this time had made no change in her (mother) position, raised her (mother) hand up to my lips and stopped me.

``Confide fully in him (Jarndyce),'' (she)
she (mother) said after a little while.
``You have my free consent--a small gift from such a mother to her (mother) injured child!--but do not tell me of it. Some pride is left in me even yet.'' (I)

I explained, as nearly as I could then, or can recall now--for my agitation and distress throughout were so great that I scarcely understood myself, though every word that was uttered in the mother's voice, so unfamiliar and so melancholy to me, which in my childhood I had never learned to love and recognize, had never been sung to sleep with, had never heard a blessing from, had never had a hope inspired by, made an enduring impression on my memory--I say I explained, or tried to do it, how I had only hoped that Mr. Jarndyce, who had been the best of fathers to me, might be able to afford some counsel and support to her (mother). But my mother answered no, it was impossible; no one could help her (mother). Through the desert that lay before her (mother), she (mother) must go alone.

``My child, my child!'' (she)
she (mother) said.
``For the last time! These kisses for the last time! These arms upon my neck for the last time! We shall meet no more. To hope to do what I seek to do, I must be what I have been so long. Such is my reward and doom. If you hear of Lady Dedlock, brilliant, prosperous, and flattered, think of your wretched mother, conscience-stricken, underneath that mask! Think that the reality is in her (mother) suffering, in her (mother) useless remorse, in her (mother) murdering within her (mother) breast the only love and truth of which it is capable! And then forgive her (mother) if you can, and cry to heaven to forgive her (mother), which it never can!'' (she)

We held one another for a little space yet, but she (mother) was so firm that she (mother) took my hands away, and put them back against my breast, and with a last kiss as she (mother) held them there, released them, and went from me into the wood. I was alone, and calm and quiet below me in the sun and shade lay the old house, with its terraces and turrets, on which there had seemed to me to be such complete repose when I first saw it, but which now looked like the obdurate and unpitying watcher of my mother's misery.

Stunned as I was, as weak and helpless at first as I had ever been in my sick chamber, the necessity of guarding against the danger of discovery, or even of the remotest suspicion, did me service. I took such precautions as I could to hide from Charley that I had been crying, and I constrained myself to think of every sacred obligation that there was upon me to be careful and collected. It was not a little while before I could succeed or could even restrain bursts of grief, but after an hour or so I was better and felt that I might return. I went home very slowly and told Charley, whom I found at the gate looking for me, that I had been tempted to extend my walk after Lady Dedlock had left me and that I was over-tired and would lie down. Safe in my own room, I read the letter. I clearly derived from it--and that was much then--that I had not been abandoned by my mother. Her (mother) elder and only sister, the godmother of my childhood, discovering signs of life in me when I had been laid aside as dead, had in her (mother) stern sense of duty, with no desire or willingness that I should live, reared me in rigid secrecy and had never again beheld my mother's face from within a few hours of my birth. So strangely did I hold my place in this world that until within a short time back I had never, to my own mother's knowledge, breathed--had been buried--had never been endowed with life--had never borne a name. When she (mother) had first seen me in the church she (mother) had been startled and had thought of what would have been like me if it had ever lived, and had lived on, but that was all then.

What more the letter told me needs not to be repeated here. It has its own times and places in my story.

My first care was to burn what my mother had written and to consume even its ashes. I hope it may not appear very unnatural or bad in me that I then became heavily sorrowful to think I had ever been reared. That I felt as if I knew it would have been better and happier for many people if indeed I had never breathed. That I had a terror of myself as the danger and the possible disgrace of my own mother and of a proud family name. That I was so confused and shaken as to be possessed by a belief that it was right and had been intended that I should die in my birth, and that it was wrong and not intended that I should be then alive.

These are the real feelings that I had. I fell asleep worn out, and when I awoke I cried afresh to think that I was back in the world with my load of trouble for others. I was more than ever frightened of myself, thinking anew of her (my) against whom I was a witness, of the owner of Chesney Wold, of the new and terrible meaning of the old words now moaning in my ear like a surge upon the shore,

``Your mother, Esther, was your disgrace, and you are hers. The time will come--and soon enough--when you will understand this better, and will feel it too, as no one save a woman can.'' (Chesney Wold)
With them, those other words returned,
``Pray daily that the sins of others be not visited upon your head.'' (I)
I could not disentangle all that was about me, and I felt as if the blame and the shame were all in me, and the visitation had come down.

The day waned into a gloomy evening, overcast and sad, and I still contended with the same distress. I went out alone, and after walking a little in the park, watching the dark shades falling on the trees and the fitful flight of the bats, which sometimes almost touched me, was attracted to the house for the first time. Perhaps I might not have gone near it if I had been in a stronger frame of mind. As it was, I took the path that led close by it.

I did not dare to linger or to look up, but I passed before the terrace garden with its fragrant odours, and its broad walks, and its well-kept beds and smooth turf; and I saw how beautiful and grave it was, and how the old stone balustrades and parapets, and wide flights of shallow steps, were seamed by time and weather; and how the trained moss and ivy grew about them, and around the old stone pedestal of the sun-dial; and I heard the fountain falling. Then the way went by long lines of dark windows diversified by turreted towers and porches of eccentric shapes, where old stone lions and grotesque monsters bristled outside dens of shadow and snarled at the evening gloom over the escutcheons they held in their grip. Thence the path wound underneath a gateway, and through a court-yard where the principal entrance was -LRB-I hurried quickly on-RRB-, and by the stables where none but deep voices seemed to be, whether in the murmuring of the wind through the strong mass of ivy holding to a high red wall, or in the low complaining of the weathercock, or in the barking of the dogs, or in the slow striking of a clock. So, encountering presently a sweet smell of limes, whose rustling I could hear, I turned with the turning of the path to the south front, and there above me were the balustrades of the Ghost's Walk and one lighted window that might be my mother's.

The way was paved here, like the terrace overhead, and my footsteps from being noiseless made an echoing sound upon the flags. Stopping to look at nothing, but seeing all I did see as I went, I was passing quickly on, and in a few moments should have passed the lighted window, when my echoing footsteps brought it suddenly into my mind that there was a dreadful truth in the legend of the Ghost's Walk, that it was I who was to bring calamity upon the stately house and that my warning feet were haunting it even then. Seized with an augmented terror of myself which turned me cold, I ran from myself and everything, retraced the way by which I had come, and never paused until I had gained the lodge-gate, and the park lay sullen and black behind me.

Not before I was alone in my own room for the night and had again been dejected and unhappy there did I begin to know how wrong and thankless this state was. But from my darling who was coming on the morrow, I found a joyful letter, full of such loving anticipation that I must have been of marble if it had not moved me; from my guardian, too, I found another letter, asking me to tell Dame Durden, if I should see that little woman anywhere, that they had moped most pitiably without her (woman), that the housekeeping was going to rack and ruin, that nobody else could manage the keys, and that everybody in and about the house declared it was not the same house and was becoming rebellious for her (woman) return. Two such letters together made me think how far beyond my deserts I was beloved and how happy I ought to be. That made me think of all my past life; and that brought me, as it ought to have done before, into a better condition.

For I saw very well that I could not have been intended to die, or I should never have lived; not to say should never have been reserved for such a happy life. I saw very well how many things had worked together for my welfare, and that if the sins of the fathers were sometimes visited upon the children, the phrase did not mean what I had in the morning feared it meant. I knew I was as innocent of my birth as a queen of hers and that before my Heavenly Father I should not be punished for birth nor a queen rewarded for it. I had had experience, in the shock of that very day, that I could, even thus soon, find comforting reconcilements to the change that had fallen on me. I renewed my resolutions and prayed to be strengthened in them, pouring out my heart for myself and for my unhappy mother and feeling that the darkness of the morning was passing away. It was not upon my sleep; and when the next day's light awoke me, it was gone.

My dear girl was to arrive at five o'clock in the afternoon. How to help myself through the intermediate time better than by taking a long walk along the road by which she (girl) was to come, I did not know; so Charley and I and Stubbs--Stubbs saddled, for we never drove him (Stubbs) after the one great occasion--made a long expedition along that road and back. On our return, we held a great review of the house and garden and saw that everything was in its prettiest condition, and had the bird out ready as an important part of the establishment.

There were more than two full hours yet to elapse before she (girl) could come, and in that interval, which seemed a long one, I must confess I was nervously anxious about my altered looks. I loved my darling so well that I was more concerned for their effect on her (girl) than on any one. I was not in this slight distress because I at all repined--I am quite certain I did not, that day--but, I thought, would she (girl) be wholly prepared? When she (girl) first saw me, might she (girl) not be a little shocked and disappointed? Might it not prove a little worse than she (girl) expected? Might she (girl) not look for her (girl) old Esther and not find her (girl)? Might she (girl) not have to grow used to me and to begin all over again?

I knew the various expressions of my sweet girl's face so well, and it was such an honest face in its loveliness, that I was sure beforehand she (girl) could not hide that first look from me. And I considered whether, if it should signify any one of these meanings, which was so very likely, could I quite answer for myself?

Well, I thought I could. After last night, I thought I could. But to wait and wait, and expect and expect, and think and think, was such bad preparation that I resolved to go along the road again and meet her (girl).

So I said to Charley,

``Charley, I will go by myself and walk along the road until she (woman) comes.'' (Charley)
Charley highly approving of anything that pleased me, I went and left her (girl) at home.

But before I got to the second milestone, I had been in so many palpitations from seeing dust in the distance -LRB-though I knew it was not, and could not, be the coach yet-RRB- that I resolved to turn back and go home again. And when I had turned, I was in such fear of the coach coming up behind me -LRB-though I still knew that it neither would, nor could, do any such thing-RRB- that I ran the greater part of the way to avoid being overtaken.

Then, I considered, when I had got safe back again, this was a nice thing to have done! Now I was hot and had made the worst of it instead of the best.

At last, when I believed there was at least a quarter of an hour more yet, Charley all at once cried out to me as I was trembling in the garden,

``Here she (woman) comes, miss! Here she (woman) is!'' (I)

I did not mean to do it, but I ran upstairs into my room and hid myself behind the door. There I stood trembling, even when I heard my darling calling as she (I) came upstairs,

``Esther, my dear, my love, where are you? Little woman, dear Dame Durden!'' (she)

She (I) ran in, and was running out again when she (I) saw me. Ah, my angel girl! The old dear look, all love, all fondness, all affection. Nothing else in it--no, nothing, nothing!

Oh, how happy I was, down upon the floor, with my sweet beautiful girl down upon the floor too, holding my scarred face to her (girl) lovely cheek, bathing it with tears and kisses, rocking me to and fro like a child, calling me by every tender name that she (girl) could think of, and pressing me to her (girl) faithful heart.

CHAPTER XXXVII

Jarndyce and Jarndyce

If the secret I had to keep had been mine, I must have confided it to Ada before we had been long together. But it was not mine, and I did not feel that I had a right to tell it, even to my guardian, unless some great emergency arose. It was a weight to bear alone; still my present duty appeared to be plain, and blest in the attachment of my dear, I did not want an impulse and encouragement to do it. Though often when she (Ada) was asleep and all was quiet, the remembrance of my mother kept me waking and made the night sorrowful, I did not yield to it at another time; and Ada found me what I used to be--except, of course, in that particular of which I have said enough and which I have no intention of mentioning any more just now, if I can help it.

The difficulty that I felt in being quite composed that first evening when Ada asked me, over our work, if the family were at the house, and when I was obliged to answer yes, I believed so, for Lady Dedlock had spoken to me in the woods the day before yesterday, was great. Greater still when Ada asked me what she (Ada) had said, and when I replied that she (Ada) had been kind and interested, and when Ada, while admitting her (Ada) beauty and elegance, remarked upon her (Ada) proud manner and her (Ada) imperious chilling air. But Charley helped me through, unconsciously, by telling us that Lady Dedlock had only stayed at the house two nights on her (Dedlock) way from London to visit at some other great house in the next county and that she (Dedlock) had left early on the morning after we had seen her (Dedlock) at our view, as we called it. Charley verified the adage about little pitchers, I am sure, for she (Dedlock) heard of more sayings and doings in a day than would have come to my ears in a month.

We were to stay a month at Mr. Boythorn's. My pet had scarcely been there a bright week, as I recollect the time, when one evening after we had finished helping the gardener in watering his (gardener) flowers, and just as the candles were lighted, Charley, appearing with a very important air behind Ada's chair, beckoned me mysteriously out of the room.

``Oh! If you please, miss,'' (Charley)
said Charley in a whisper, with her (Ada) eyes at their roundest and largest.
``You're wanted at the Dedlock Arms.'' (unknown)

``Why, Charley,'' (I)
said I,
``who can possibly want me at the public-house?'' (I)

``I don't know, miss,'' (Charley)
returned Charley, putting her (Ada) head forward and folding her (Ada) hands tight upon the band of her (Ada) little apron, which she (Ada) always did in the enjoyment of anything mysterious or confidential,
``but it's a gentleman, miss, and his (Charley) compliments, and will you please to come without saying anything about it.'' (she)

``Whose compliments, Charley?'' (unknown)

``His (Charley)`n, miss,'' (Charley)
returned Charley, whose grammatical education was advancing, but not very rapidly.

``And how do you come to be the messenger, Charley?'' (unknown)

``I am not the messenger, if you please, miss,'' (maid)
returned my little maid.
``It was W. Grubble, miss.'' (unknown)

``And who is W. Grubble, Charley?'' (unknown)

``Mister Grubble, miss,'' (Charley)
returned Charley.
``Don't you know, miss? The Dedlock Arms, by W. Grubble,'' (Charley)
which Charley delivered as if she (maid) were slowly spelling out the sign.

``Aye? The landlord, Charley?'' (unknown)

``Yes, miss. If you please, miss, his (Charley) wife is a beautiful woman, but she (wife) broke her (wife) ankle, and it never joined. And her (wife) brother's the sawyer that was put in the cage, miss, and they expect he (brother)'ll drink himself to death entirely on beer,'' (Charley)
said Charley.

Not knowing what might be the matter, and being easily apprehensive now, I thought it best to go to this place by myself. I bade Charley be quick with my bonnet and veil and my shawl, and having put them on, went away down the little hilly street, where I was as much at home as in Mr. Boythorn's garden.

Mr. Grubble was standing in his (Grubble) shirt-sleeves at the door of his (Grubble) very clean little tavern waiting for me. He (Grubble) lifted off his (Grubble) hat with both hands when he (Grubble) saw me coming, and carrying it so, as if it were an iron vessel -LRB-it looked as heavy-RRB-, preceded me along the sanded passage to his (Grubble) best parlour, a neat carpeted room with more plants in it than were quite convenient, a coloured print of Queen Caroline, several shells, a good many tea-trays, two stuffed and dried fish in glass cases, and either a curious egg or a curious pumpkin -LRB-but I don't know which, and I doubt if many people did-RRB- hanging from his (Grubble) ceiling. I knew Mr. Grubble very well by sight, from his (Grubble) often standing at his (Grubble) door. A pleasant-looking, stoutish, middle-aged man who never seemed to consider himself cozily dressed for his (Grubble) own fire-side without his (Grubble) hat and top-boots, but who never wore a coat except at church.

He (Grubble) snuffed the candle, and backing away a little to see how it looked, backed out of the room--unexpectedly to me, for I was going to ask him (Grubble) by whom he (Grubble) had been sent. The door of the opposite parlour being then opened, I heard some voices, familiar in my ears I thought, which stopped. A quick light step approached the room in which I was, and who should stand before me but Richard!

``My dear Esther!'' (he)
he (Richard) said.
``My best friend!'' (he)
And he (Richard) really was so warm-hearted and earnest that in the first surprise and pleasure of his (Richard) brotherly greeting I could scarcely find breath to tell him (Richard) that Ada was well.

``Answering my very thoughts--always the same dear girl!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard, leading me to a chair and seating himself beside me.

I put my veil up, but not quite.

``Always the same dear girl!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard just as heartily as before.

I put up my veil altogether, and laying my hand on Richard's sleeve and looking in his (Richard) face, told him (Richard) how much I thanked him (Richard) for his (Richard) kind welcome and how greatly I rejoiced to see him (Richard), the more so because of the determination I had made in my illness, which I now conveyed to him (Richard).

``My love,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard,
``there is no one with whom I have a greater wish to talk than you, for I want you to understand me.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``And I want you, Richard,'' (I)
said I, shaking my head,
``to understand some one else.'' (I)

``Since you refer so immediately to John Jarndyce,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard,
''--I suppose you mean him (Richard)?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``Of course I do.'' (unknown)

``Then I may say at once that I am glad of it, because it is on that subject that I am anxious to be understood. By you, mind--you, my dear! I am not accountable to Mr. Jarndyce or Mr. Anybody.'' (I)

I was pained to find him (Richard) taking this tone, and he (Richard) observed it.

``Well, well, my dear,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard,
``we won't go into that now. I want to appear quietly in your country-house here, with you under my arm, and give my charming cousin a surprise. I suppose your loyalty to John Jarndyce will allow that?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``My dear Richard,'' (I)
I returned,
``you know you would be heartily welcome at his (Richard) house--your home, if you will but consider it so; and you are as heartily welcome here!'' (I)

``Spoken like the best of little women!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
cried Richard gaily.

I asked him (Richard) how he (Richard) liked his (Richard) profession.

``Oh, I like it well enough!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard.
``It's all right. It does as well as anything else, for a time. I don't know that I shall care about it when I come to be settled, but I can sell out then and--however, never mind all that botheration at present.'' (unknown)

So young and handsome, and in all respects so perfectly the opposite of Miss Flite! And yet, in the clouded, eager, seeking look that passed over him (Richard), so dreadfully like her (it)!

``I am in town on leave just now,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard.

``Indeed?'' (unknown)

``Yes. I have run over to look after my--my Chancery interests before the long vacation,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard, forcing a careless laugh.
``We are beginning to spin along with that old suit at last, I promise you.'' (I)

No wonder that I shook my head!

``As you say, it's not a pleasant subject.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
Richard spoke with the same shade crossing his (Richard) face as before.
``Let it go to the four winds for to-night. Puff! Gone! Who do you suppose is with me?'' (unknown)

``Was it Mr. Skimpole's voice I heard?'' (unknown)

``That's the man! He (man) does me more good than anybody. What a fascinating child it is!'' (I)

I asked Richard if any one knew of their coming down together. He (Richard) answered, no, nobody. He (Richard) had been to call upon the dear old infant--so he (Richard) called Mr. Skimpole--and the dear old infant had told him (Richard) where we were, and he (Richard) had told the dear old infant he (Richard) was bent on coming to see us, and the dear old infant had directly wanted to come too; and so he (Richard) had brought him (Richard).

``And he (man) is worth--not to say his (man) sordid expenses--but thrice his (man) weight in gold,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard.
``He (man) is such a cheery fellow. No worldliness about him (man). Fresh and green-hearted!'' (I)

I certainly did not see the proof of Mr. Skimpole's worldliness in his (Richard) having his (Richard) expenses paid by Richard, but I made no remark about that. Indeed, he (Richard) came in and turned our conversation. He (Richard) was charmed to see me, said he (Richard) had been shedding delicious tears of joy and sympathy at intervals for six weeks on my account, had never been so happy as in hearing of my progress, began to understand the mixture of good and evil in the world now, felt that he (Richard) appreciated health the more when somebody else was ill, didn't know but what it might be in the scheme of things that A should squint to make B happier in looking straight or that C should carry a wooden leg to make D better satisfied with his (Richard) flesh and blood in a silk stocking.

``My dear Miss Summerson, here is our friend Richard,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole, ``full of the brightest visions of the future, which he (Richard) evokes out of the darkness of Chancery. Now that's delightful, that's inspiriting, that's full of poetry! In old times the woods and solitudes were made joyous to the shepherd by the imaginary piping and dancing of Pan and the nymphs. This present shepherd, our pastoral Richard, brightens the dull Inns of Court by making Fortune and her (Summerson) train sport through them to the melodious notes of a judgment from the bench. That's very pleasant, you know! Some ill-conditioned growling fellow may say to me, ``What's the use of these legal and equitable abuses? How do you defend them?'' I reply, ``My growling friend, I DON
``T defend them, but they are very agreeable to me. There is a shepherd--youth, a friend of mine, who transmutes them into something highly fascinating to my simplicity. I don't say it is for this that they exist--for I am a child among you worldly grumblers, and not called upon to account to you or myself for anything--but it may be so.''' (I)

I began seriously to think that Richard could scarcely have found a worse friend than this. It made me uneasy that at such a time when he (Richard) most required some right principle and purpose he (Richard) should have this captivating looseness and putting-off of everything, this airy dispensing with all principle and purpose, at his (Richard) elbow. I thought I could understand how such a nature as my guardian's, experienced in the world and forced to contemplate the miserable evasions and contentions of the family misfortune, found an immense relief in Mr. Skimpole's avowal of his (Skimpole) weaknesses and display of guileless candour; but I could not satisfy myself that it was as artless as it seemed or that it did not serve Mr. Skimpole's idle turn quite as well as any other part, and with less trouble.

They both walked back with me, and Mr. Skimpole leaving us at the gate, I walked softly in with Richard and said,

``Ada, my love, I have brought a gentleman to visit you.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
It was not difficult to read the blushing, startled face. She (Skimpole) loved him (Richard) dearly, and he (Richard) knew it, and I knew it. It was a very transparent business, that meeting as cousins only.

I almost mistrusted myself as growing quite wicked in my suspicions, but I was not so sure that Richard loved her (Skimpole) dearly. He (Richard) admired her (Skimpole) very much--any one must have done that--and I dare say would have renewed their youthful engagement with great pride and ardour but that he (Richard) knew how she (Skimpole) would respect her (Skimpole) promise to my guardian. Still I had a tormenting idea that the influence upon him (Richard) extended even here, that he (Richard) was postponing his (Richard) best truth and earnestness in this as in all things until Jarndyce and Jarndyce should be off his (Jarndyce) mind. Ah me! What Richard would have been without that blight, I never shall know now!

He (Richard) told Ada, in his (Richard) most ingenuous way, that he (Richard) had not come to make any secret inroad on the terms she (Ada) had accepted -LRB-rather too implicitly and confidingly, he (Richard) thought-RRB- from Mr. Jarndyce, that he (Jarndyce) had come openly to see her (Ada) and to see me and to justify himself for the present terms on which he (Jarndyce) stood with Mr. Jarndyce. As the dear old infant would be with us directly, he (Jarndyce) begged that I would make an appointment for the morning, when he (Jarndyce) might set himself right through the means of an unreserved conversation with me. I proposed to walk with him (Jarndyce) in the park at seven o'clock, and this was arranged. Mr. Skimpole soon afterwards appeared and made us merry for an hour. He (Skimpole) particularly requested to see little Coavinses -LRB-meaning Charley-RRB- and told her (me), with a patriarchal air, that he (Charley) had given her (me) late father all the business in his (Charley) power and that if one of her (me) little brothers would make haste to get set up in the same profession, he (Charley) hoped he (Charley) should still be able to put a good deal of employment in his (Charley) way.

``For I am constantly being taken in these nets,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole, looking beamingly at us over a glass of wine-and-water,
``and am constantly being bailed out--like a boat. Or paid off--like a ship's company. Somebody always does it for me. I can't do it, you know, for I never have any money. But somebody does it. I get out by somebody's means; I am not like the starling; I get out. If you were to ask me who somebody is, upon my word I couldn't tell you. Let us drink to somebody. God bless him (God)!'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

Richard was a little late in the morning, but I had not to wait for him (Richard) long, and we turned into the park. The air was bright and dewy and the sky without a cloud. The birds sang delightfully; the sparkles in the fern, the grass, and trees, were exquisite to see; the richness of the woods seemed to have increased twenty-fold since yesterday, as if, in the still night when they had looked so massively hushed in sleep, Nature, through all the minute details of every wonderful leaf, had been more wakeful than usual for the glory of that day.

``This is a lovely place,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard, looking round.
``None of the jar and discord of law-suits here!'' (unknown)

But there was other trouble.

``I tell you what, my dear girl,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard,
``when I get affairs in general settled, I shall come down here, I think, and rest.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``Would it not be better to rest now?'' (I)
I asked.

``Oh, as to resting NOW,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard,
``or as to doing anything very definite NOW, that's not easy. In short, it can't be done; I can't do it at least.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``Why not?'' (I.)
said I.

``You know why not, Esther. If you were living in an unfinished house, liable to have the roof put on or taken off--to be from top to bottom pulled down or built up--to-morrow, next day, next week, next month, next year--you would find it hard to rest or settle. So do I. Now? There's no now for us suitors.'' (I.)

I could almost have believed in the attraction on which my poor little wandering friend had expatiated when I saw again the darkened look of last night. Terrible to think it had in it also a shade of that unfortunate man who had died.

``My dear Richard,'' (I)
said I,
``this is a bad beginning of our conversation.'' (I)

``I knew you would tell me so, Dame Durden.'' (unknown)

``And not I alone, dear Richard. It was not I who cautioned you once never to found a hope or expectation on the family curse.'' (unknown)

``There you come back to John Jarndyce!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard impatiently.
``Well! We must approach him (Jarndyce) sooner or later, for he (Jarndyce) is the staple of what I have to say, and it's as well at once. My dear Esther, how can you be so blind? Don't you see that he (Jarndyce) is an interested party and that it may be very well for him (Jarndyce) to wish me to know nothing of the suit, and care nothing about it, but that it may not be quite so well for me?'' (unknown)

``Oh, Richard,'' (I)
I remonstrated,
``is it possible that you can ever have seen him (Richard) and heard him (Richard), that you can ever have lived under his (Richard) roof and known him (Richard), and can yet breathe, even to me in this solitary place where there is no one to hear us, such unworthy suspicions?'' (I)

He (Richard) reddened deeply, as if his (Richard) natural generosity felt a pang of reproach. He (Richard) was silent for a little while before he (Richard) replied in a subdued voice,

``Esther, I am sure you know that I am not a mean fellow and that I have some sense of suspicion and distrust being poor qualities in one of my years.'' (he)

``I know it very well,'' (I.)
said I.
``I am not more sure of anything.'' (I.)

``That's a dear girl,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
retorted Richard,
``and like you, because it gives me comfort. I had need to get some scrap of comfort out of all this business, for it's a bad one at the best, as I have no occasion to tell you.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``I know perfectly,'' (I.)
said I.
``I know as well, Richard--what shall I say? as well as you do--that such misconstructions are foreign to your nature. And I know, as well as you know, what so changes it.'' (I.)

``Come, sister, come,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard a little more gaily,
``you will be fair with me at all events. If I have the misfortune to be under that influence, so has he (Richard). If it has a little twisted me, it may have a little twisted him (Richard) too. I don't say that he (Richard) is not an honourable man, out of all this complication and uncertainty; I am sure he (Richard) is. But it taints everybody. You know it taints everybody. You have heard him (Richard) say so fifty times. Then why should HE (Richard) escape?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``Because,'' (I)
said I,
``his (Richard) is an uncommon character, and he (Richard) has resolutely kept himself outside the circle, Richard.'' (I)

``Oh, because and because!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
replied Richard in his (Richard) vivacious way.
``I am not sure, my dear girl, but that it may be wise and specious to preserve that outward indifference. It may cause other parties interested to become lax about their interests; and people may die off, and points may drag themselves out of memory, and many things may smoothly happen that are convenient enough.'' (I)

I was so touched with pity for Richard that I could not reproach him (Richard) any more, even by a look. I remembered my guardian's gentleness towards his (Richard) errors and with what perfect freedom from resentment he (Richard) had spoken of them.

``Esther,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
Richard resumed,
``you are not to suppose that I have come here to make underhanded charges against John Jarndyce. I have only come to justify myself. What I say is, it was all very well and we got on very well while I was a boy, utterly regardless of this same suit; but as soon as I began to take an interest in it and to look into it, then it was quite another thing. Then John Jarndyce discovers that Ada and I must break off and that if I don't amend that very objectionable course, I am not fit for her (Ada). Now, Esther, I don't mean to amend that very objectionable course: I will not hold John Jarndyce's favour on those unfair terms of compromise, which he (Jarndyce) has no right to dictate. Whether it pleases him (Jarndyce) or displeases him (Jarndyce), I must maintain my rights and Ada's. I have been thinking about it a good deal, and this is the conclusion I have come to.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

Poor dear Richard! He (Richard) had indeed been thinking about it a good deal. His (Richard) face, his (Richard) voice, his (Richard) manner, all showed that too plainly.

``So I tell him (Jarndyce) honourably -LRB-you are to know I have written to him (Jarndyce) about all this-RRB- that we are at issue and that we had better be at issue openly than covertly. I thank him (Jarndyce) for his (Jarndyce) goodwill and his (Jarndyce) protection, and he (Jarndyce) goes his (Jarndyce) road, and I go mine. The fact is, our roads are not the same. Under one of the wills in dispute, I should take much more than he (Jarndyce). I don't mean to say that it is the one to be established, but there it is, and it has its chance.'' (unknown)

``I have not to learn from you, my dear Richard,'' (I)
said I,
``of your letter. I had heard of it already without an offended or angry word.'' (I)

``Indeed?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
replied Richard, softening.
``I am glad I said he (Richard) was an honourable man, out of all this wretched affair. But I always say that and have never doubted it. Now, my dear Esther, I know these views of mine appear extremely harsh to you, and will to Ada when you tell her (Ada) what has passed between us. But if you had gone into the case as I have, if you had only applied yourself to the papers as I did when I was at Kenge's, if you only knew what an accumulation of charges and counter-charges, and suspicions and cross-suspicions, they involve, you would think me moderate in comparison.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps so,'' (I.)
said I.
``But do you think that, among those many papers, there is much truth and justice, Richard?'' (I.)

``There is truth and justice somewhere in the case, Esther--'' (I.)

``Or was once, long ago,'' (I.)
said I.

``Is--is--must be somewhere,'' (I.)
pursued Richard impetuously,
``and must be brought out. To allow Ada to be made a bribe and hush-money of is not the way to bring it out. You say the suit is changing me; John Jarndyce says it changes, has changed, and will change everybody who has any share in it. Then the greater right I have on my side when I resolve to do all I can to bring it to an end.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``All you can, Richard! Do you think that in these many years no others have done all they could? Has the difficulty grown easier because of so many failures?'' (unknown)

``It can't last for ever,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
returned Richard with a fierceness kindling in him (Richard) which again presented to me that last sad reminder.
``I am young and earnest, and energy and determination have done wonders many a time. Others have only half thrown themselves into it. I devote myself to it. I make it the object of my life.'' (unknown)

``Oh, Richard, my dear, so much the worse, so much the worse!'' (unknown)

``No, no, no, don't you be afraid for me,'' (he)
he (Richard) returned affectionately.
``You're a dear, good, wise, quiet, blessed girl; but you have your prepossessions. So I come round to John Jarndyce. I tell you, my good Esther, when he (Jarndyce) and I were on those terms which he (Jarndyce) found so convenient, we were not on natural terms.'' (unknown)

``Are division and animosity your natural terms, Richard?'' (unknown)

``No, I don't say that. I mean that all this business puts us on unnatural terms, with which natural relations are incompatible. See another reason for urging it on! I may find out when it's over that I have been mistaken in John Jarndyce. My head may be clearer when I am free of it, and I may then agree with what you say to-day. Very well. Then I shall acknowledge it and make him (Jarndyce) reparation.'' (unknown)

Everything postponed to that imaginary time! Everything held in confusion and indecision until then!

``Now, my best of confidantes,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard,
``I want my cousin Ada to understand that I am not captious, fickle, and wilful about John Jarndyce, but that I have this purpose and reason at my back. I wish to represent myself to her (Ada) through you, because she (Ada) has a great esteem and respect for her (Ada) cousin John; and I know you will soften the course I take, even though you disapprove of it; and--and in short,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard, who had been hesitating through these words,
``I--I don't like to represent myself in this litigious, contentious, doubting character to a confiding girl like Ada.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

I told him (Richard) that he (Richard) was more like himself in those latter words than in anything he (Richard) had said yet.

``Why,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
acknowledged Richard,
``that may be true enough, my love. I rather feel it to be so. But I shall be able to give myself fair-play by and by. I shall come all right again, then, don't you be afraid.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

I asked him (Richard) if this were all he (Richard) wished me to tell Ada.

``Not quite,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard. ``I am bound not to withhold from her (Ada) that John Jarndyce answered my letter in his (Jarndyce) usual manner, addressing me as ``My dear Rick,
'' trying to argue me out of my opinions, and telling me that they should make no difference in him (Richard). -LRB-All very well of course, but not altering the case.-RRB- I also want Ada to know that if I see her (Ada) seldom just now, I am looking after her (Ada) interests as well as my own--we two being in the same boat exactly--and that I hope she (Ada) will not suppose from any flying rumours she (Ada) may hear that I am at all light-headed or imprudent; on the contrary, I am always looking forward to the termination of the suit, and always planning in that direction. Being of age now and having taken the step I have taken, I consider myself free from any accountability to John Jarndyce; but Ada being still a ward of the court, I don't yet ask her (Ada) to renew our engagement. When she (Ada) is free to act for herself, I shall be myself once more and we shall both be in very different worldly circumstances, I believe. If you tell her (Ada) all this with the advantage of your considerate way, you will do me a very great and a very kind service, my dear Esther; and I shall knock Jarndyce and Jarndyce on the head with greater vigour. Of course I ask for no secrecy at Bleak House.'' (Rick)

``Richard,'' (I)
said I,
``you place great confidence in me, but I fear you will not take advice from me?'' (I)

``It's impossible that I can on this subject, my dear girl. On any other, readily.'' (unknown)

As if there were any other in his (Jarndyce) life! As if his (Jarndyce) whole career and character were not being dyed one colour!

``But I may ask you a question, Richard?'' (unknown)

``I think so,'' (he)
said he (Jarndyce), laughing.
``I don't know who may not, if you may not.'' (unknown)

``You say, yourself, you are not leading a very settled life.'' (unknown)

``How can I, my dear Esther, with nothing settled!'' (unknown)

``Are you in debt again?'' (unknown)

``Why, of course I am,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard, astonished at my simplicity.

``Is it of course?'' (unknown)

``My dear child, certainly. I can't throw myself into an object so completely without expense. You forget, or perhaps you don't know, that under either of the wills Ada and I take something. It's only a question between the larger sum and the smaller. I shall be within the mark any way. Bless your heart, my excellent girl,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard, quite amused with me,
``I shall be all right! I shall pull through, my dear!'' (me)

I felt so deeply sensible of the danger in which he (Richard) stood that I tried, in Ada's name, in my guardian's, in my own, by every fervent means that I could think of, to warn him (Richard) of it and to show him (Richard) some of his (Richard) mistakes. He (Richard) received everything I said with patience and gentleness, but it all rebounded from him (Richard) without taking the least effect. I could not wonder at this after the reception his (Richard) preoccupied mind had given to my guardian's letter, but I determined to try Ada's influence yet.

So when our walk brought us round to the village again, and I went home to breakfast, I prepared Ada for the account I was going to give her (Ada) and told her (Ada) exactly what reason we had to dread that Richard was losing himself and scattering his (Richard) whole life to the winds. It made her (Ada) very unhappy, of course, though she (Ada) had a far, far greater reliance on his (Richard) correcting his (Richard) errors than I could have--which was so natural and loving in my dear!--and she (Ada) presently wrote him (Richard) this little letter:

My dearest cousin,

Esther has told me all you said to her (Esther) this morning. I write this to repeat most earnestly for myself all that she (Esther) said to you and to let you know how sure I am that you will sooner or later find our cousin John a pattern of truth, sincerity, and goodness, when you will deeply, deeply grieve to have done him (John) -LRB-without intending it-RRB- so much wrong.

I do not quite know how to write what I wish to say next, but I trust you will understand it as I mean it. I have some fears, my dearest cousin, that it may be partly for my sake you are now laying up so much unhappiness for yourself--and if for yourself, for me. In case this should be so, or in case you should entertain much thought of me in what you are doing, I most earnestly entreat and beg you to desist. You can do nothing for my sake that will make me half so happy as for ever turning your back upon the shadow in which we both were born. Do not be angry with me for saying this. Pray, pray, dear Richard, for my sake, and for your own, and in a natural repugnance for that source of trouble which had its share in making us both orphans when we were very young, pray, pray, let it go for ever. We have reason to know by this time that there is no good in it and no hope, that there is nothing to be got from it but sorrow.

My dearest cousin, it is needless for me to say that you are quite free and that it is very likely you may find some one whom you will love much better than your first fancy. I am quite sure, if you will let me say so, that the object of your choice would greatly prefer to follow your fortunes far and wide, however moderate or poor, and see you happy, doing your duty and pursuing your chosen way, than to have the hope of being, or even to be, very rich with you -LRB-if such a thing were possible-RRB- at the cost of dragging years of procrastination and anxiety and of your indifference to other aims. You may wonder at my saying this so confidently with so little knowledge or experience, but I know it for a certainty from my own heart.

Ever, my dearest cousin, your most affectionate

Ada

This note brought Richard to us very soon, but it made little change in him (Richard) if any. We would fairly try, he (Richard) said, who was right and who was wrong--he (Richard) would show us--we should see! He (Richard) was animated and glowing, as if Ada's tenderness had gratified him (Richard); but I could only hope, with a sigh, that the letter might have some stronger effect upon his (Richard) mind on re-perusal than it assuredly had then.

As they were to remain with us that day and had taken their places to return by the coach next morning, I sought an opportunity of speaking to Mr. Skimpole. Our out-of-door life easily threw one in my way, and I delicately said that there was a responsibility in encouraging Richard.

``Responsibility, my dear Miss Summerson?'' (he)
he (Richard) repeated, catching at the word with the pleasantest smile.
``I am the last man in the world for such a thing. I never was responsible in my life--I can't be.'' (unknown)

``I am afraid everybody is obliged to be,'' (I)
said I timidly enough, he (Richard) being so much older and more clever than I.

``No, really?'' (I.)
said Mr. Skimpole, receiving this new light with a most agreeable jocularity of surprise.
``But every man's not obliged to be solvent? I am not. I never was. See, my dear Miss Summerson,'' (he)
he (Skimpole) took a handful of loose silver and halfpence from his (Skimpole) pocket,
``there's so much money. I have not an idea how much. I have not the power of counting. Call it four and ninepence--call it four pound nine. They tell me I owe more than that. I dare say I do. I dare say I owe as much as good-natured people will let me owe. If they don't stop, why should I? There you have Harold Skimpole in little. If that's responsibility, I am responsible.'' (a handful halfpence)

The perfect ease of manner with which he (Skimpole) put the money up again and looked at me with a smile on his (Skimpole) refined face, as if he (Skimpole) had been mentioning a curious little fact about somebody else, almost made me feel as if he (Skimpole) really had nothing to do with it.

``Now, when you mention responsibility,'' (he)
he (Skimpole) resumed, ``I am disposed to say that I never had the happiness of knowing any one whom I should consider so refreshingly responsible as yourself. You appear to me to be the very touchstone of responsibility. When I see you, my dear Miss Summerson, intent upon the perfect working of the whole little orderly system of which you are the centre, I feel inclined to say to myself--in fact I do say to myself very often--THAT
``S responsibility!'' (I)

It was difficult, after this, to explain what I meant; but I persisted so far as to say that we all hoped he (Skimpole) would check and not confirm Richard in the sanguine views he (Richard) entertained just then.

``Most willingly,'' (he)
he (Richard) retorted, ``if I could. But, my dear Miss Summerson, I have no art, no disguise. If he (I) takes me by the hand and leads me through Westminster Hall in an airy procession after fortune, I must go. If he (I) says, ``Skimpole, join the dance!
'' I must join it. Common sense wouldn't, I know, but I have NO common sense.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

It was very unfortunate for Richard, I said.

``Do you think so!'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
returned Mr. Skimpole. ``Don't say that, don't say that. Let us suppose him (I) keeping company with Common Sense--an excellent man--a good deal wrinkled--dreadfully practical--change for a ten-pound note in every pocket--ruled account-book in his (I) hand--say, upon the whole, resembling a tax-gatherer. Our dear Richard, sanguine, ardent, overleaping obstacles, bursting with poetry like a young bud, says to this highly respectable companion, ``I see a golden prospect before me; it's very bright, it's very beautiful, it's very joyous; here I go, bounding over the landscape to come at it!
'' The respectable companion instantly knocks him (companion) down with the ruled account-book; tells him (companion) in a literal, prosaic way that he (companion) sees no such thing; shows him (companion) it's nothing but fees, fraud, horsehair wigs, and black gowns. Now you know that's a painful change--sensible in the last degree, I have no doubt, but disagreeable. I can't do it. I haven't got the ruled account-book, I have none of the tax-gathering elements in my composition, I am not at all respectable, and I don't want to be. Odd perhaps, but so it is!'' (I)

It was idle to say more, so I proposed that we should join Ada and Richard, who were a little in advance, and I gave up Mr. Skimpole in despair. He (Skimpole) had been over the Hall in the course of the morning and whimsically described the family pictures as we walked. There were such portentous shepherdesses among the Ladies Dedlock dead and gone, he (Skimpole) told us, that peaceful crooks became weapons of assault in their hands. They tended their flocks severely in buckram and powder and put their sticking-plaster patches on to terrify commoners as the chiefs of some other tribes put on their war-paint. There was a Sir Somebody Dedlock, with a battle, a sprung-mine, volumes of smoke, flashes of lightning, a town on fire, and a stormed fort, all in full action between his (Skimpole) horse's two hind legs, showing, he (Skimpole) supposed, how little a Dedlock made of such trifles. The whole race he (Skimpole) represented as having evidently been, in life, what he (Skimpole) called

``stuffed people'' (he)
--a large collection, glassy eyed, set up in the most approved manner on their various twigs and perches, very correct, perfectly free from animation, and always in glass cases.

I was not so easy now during any reference to the name but that I felt it a relief when Richard, with an exclamation of surprise, hurried away to meet a stranger whom he (Richard) first descried coming slowly towards us.

``Dear me!'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole.
``Vholes!'' (that a friend)

We asked if that were a friend of Richard's.

``Friend and legal adviser,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole.
``Now, my dear Miss Summerson, if you want common sense, responsibility, and respectability, all united--if you want an exemplary man--Vholes is THE man.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

We had not known, we said, that Richard was assisted by any gentleman of that name.

``When he (man) emerged from legal infancy,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
returned Mr. Skimpole,
``he (man) parted from our conversational friend Kenge and took up, I believe, with Vholes. Indeed, I know he (Vholes) did, because I introduced him (Vholes) to Vholes.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

``Had you known him (Vholes) long?'' (Ada)
asked Ada.

``Vholes? My dear Miss Clare, I had had that kind of acquaintance with him (acquaintance) which I have had with several gentlemen of his (acquaintance) profession. He (acquaintance) had done something or other in a very agreeable, civil manner--taken proceedings, I think, is the expression--which ended in the proceeding of his (acquaintance) taking ME. Somebody was so good as to step in and pay the money--something and fourpence was the amount; I forget the pounds and shillings, but I know it ended with fourpence, because it struck me at the time as being so odd that I could owe anybody fourpence--and after that I brought them together. Vholes asked me for the introduction, and I gave it. Now I come to think of it,'' (he)
he (Skimpole) looked inquiringly at us with his (Skimpole) frankest smile as he (Skimpole) made the discovery,
``Vholes bribed me, perhaps? He (acquaintance) gave me something and called it commission. Was it a five-pound note? Do you know, I think it MUST have been a five-pound note!'' (he)

His (Skimpole) further consideration of the point was prevented by Richard's coming back to us in an excited state and hastily representing Mr. Vholes--a sallow man with pinched lips that looked as if they were cold, a red eruption here and there upon his (Vholes) face, tall and thin, about fifty years of age, high-shouldered, and stooping. Dressed in black, black-gloved, and buttoned to the chin, there was nothing so remarkable in him (Vholes) as a lifeless manner and a slow, fixed way he (Vholes) had of looking at Richard.

``I hope I don't disturb you, ladies,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
said Mr. Vholes, and now I observed that he (Vholes) was further remarkable for an inward manner of speaking.
``I arranged with Mr. Carstone that he (Carstone) should always know when his (Carstone) cause was in the Chancellor's paper, and being informed by one of my clerks last night after post time that it stood, rather unexpectedly, in the paper for to-morrow, I put myself into the coach early this morning and came down to confer with him (coach).'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard, flushed, and looking triumphantly at Ada and me,
``we don't do these things in the old slow way now. We spin along now! Mr. Vholes, we must hire something to get over to the post town in, and catch the mail to-night, and go up by it!'' (me)

``Anything you please, sir,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
returned Mr. Vholes.
``I am quite at your service.'' (unknown)

``Let me see,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard, looking at his (Vholes) watch.
``If I run down to the Dedlock, and get my portmanteau fastened up, and order a gig, or a chaise, or whatever's to be got, we shall have an hour then before starting. I'll come back to tea. Cousin Ada, will you and Esther take care of Mr. Vholes when I am gone?'' (He)

He (Vholes) was away directly, in his (Vholes) heat and hurry, and was soon lost in the dusk of evening. We who were left walked on towards the house.

``Is Mr. Carstone's presence necessary to-morrow, Sir?'' (I.)
said I.
``Can it do any good?'' (I.)

``No, miss,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
Mr. Vholes replied.
``I am not aware that it can.'' (Both Ada)

Both Ada and I expressed our regret that he (Vholes) should go, then, only to be disappointed.

``Mr. Carstone has laid down the principle of watching his (Carstone) own interests,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
said Mr. Vholes,
``and when a client lays down his (client) own principle, and it is not immoral, it devolves upon me to carry it out. I wish in business to be exact and open. I am a widower with three daughters--Emma, Jane, and Caroline--and my desire is so to discharge the duties of life as to leave them a good name. This appears to be a pleasant spot, miss.'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)

The remark being made to me in consequence of my being next him (Vholes) as we walked, I assented and enumerated its chief attractions.

``Indeed?'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
said Mr. Vholes.
``I have the privilege of supporting an aged father in the Vale of Taunton--his (father) native place--and I admire that country very much. I had no idea there was anything so attractive here.'' (I)

To keep up the conversation, I asked Mr. Vholes if he (Vholes) would like to live altogether in the country.

``There, miss,'' (he)
said he (Vholes),
``you touch me on a tender string. My health is not good -LRB-my digestion being much impaired-RRB-, and if I had only myself to consider, I should take refuge in rural habits, especially as the cares of business have prevented me from ever coming much into contact with general society, and particularly with ladies' society, which I have most wished to mix in. But with my three daughters, Emma, Jane, and Caroline--and my aged father--I cannot afford to be selfish. It is true I have no longer to maintain a dear grandmother who died in her (grandmother) hundred and second year, but enough remains to render it indispensable that the mill should be always going.'' (he)

It required some attention to hear him (Vholes) on account of his (Vholes) inward speaking and his (Vholes) lifeless manner.

``You will excuse my having mentioned my daughters,'' (he)
he (Vholes) said.
``They are my weak point. I wish to leave the poor girls some little independence, as well as a good name.'' (Mr. Boythorn/Boythorn/Lawrence Boythorn)

We now arrived at Mr. Boythorn's house, where the tea-table, all prepared, was awaiting us. Richard came in restless and hurried shortly afterwards, and leaning over Mr. Vholes's chair, whispered something in his (Vholes) ear. Mr. Vholes replied aloud--or as nearly aloud I suppose as he (Vholes) had ever replied to anything--

``You will drive me, will you, sir? It is all the same to me, sir. Anything you please. I am quite at your service.'' (he)

We understood from what followed that Mr. Skimpole was to be left until the morning to occupy the two places which had been already paid for. As Ada and I were both in low spirits concerning Richard and very sorry so to part with him (Richard), we made it as plain as we politely could that we should leave Mr. Skimpole to the Dedlock Arms and retire when the night-travellers were gone.

Richard's high spirits carrying everything before them, we all went out together to the top of the hill above the village, where he (Richard) had ordered a gig to wait and where we found a man with a lantern standing at the head of the gaunt pale horse that had been harnessed to it.

I never shall forget those two seated side by side in the lantern's light, Richard all flush and fire and laughter, with the reins in his (Richard) hand; Mr. Vholes quite still, black-gloved, and buttoned up, looking at him (Vholes) as if he (Vholes) were looking at his (Vholes) prey and charming it. I have before me the whole picture of the warm dark night, the summer lightning, the dusty track of road closed in by hedgerows and high trees, the gaunt pale horse with his (Vholes) ears pricked up, and the driving away at speed to Jarndyce and Jarndyce.

My dear girl told me that night how Richard's being thereafter prosperous or ruined, befriended or deserted, could only make this difference to her (girl), that the more he (Richard) needed love from one unchanging heart, the more love that unchanging heart would have to give him (Richard); how he (Richard) thought of her (girl) through his (Richard) present errors, and she (girl) would think of him (Richard) at all times--never of herself if she (girl) could devote herself to him (Richard), never of her (girl) own delights if she (girl) could minister to his (minister).

And she (girl) kept her (girl) word?

I look along the road before me, where the distance already shortens and the journey's end is growing visible; and true and good above the dead sea of the Chancery suit and all the ashy fruit it cast ashore, I think I see my darling.

CHAPTER XXXVIII

A Struggle

When our time came for returning to Bleak House again, we were punctual to the day and were received with an overpowering welcome. I was perfectly restored to health and strength, and finding my housekeeping keys laid ready for me in my room, rang myself in as if I had been a new year, with a merry little peal.

``Once more, duty, duty, Esther,'' (I)
said I;
``and if you are not overjoyed to do it, more than cheerfully and contentedly, through anything and everything, you ought to be. That's all I have to say to you, my dear!'' (I)

The first few mornings were mornings of so much bustle and business, devoted to such settlements of accounts, such repeated journeys to and fro between the growlery and all other parts of the house, so many rearrangements of drawers and presses, and such a general new beginning altogether, that I had not a moment's leisure. But when these arrangements were completed and everything was in order, I paid a visit of a few hours to London, which something in the letter I had destroyed at Chesney Wold had induced me to decide upon in my own mind.

I made Caddy Jellyby--her (Jellyby) maiden name was so natural to me that I always called her (Jellyby) by it--the pretext for this visit and wrote her (Jellyby) a note previously asking the favour of her (Jellyby) company on a little business expedition. Leaving home very early in the morning, I got to London by stage-coach in such good time that I got to Newman Street with the day before me.

Caddy, who had not seen me since her (Jellyby) wedding-day, was so glad and so affectionate that I was half inclined to fear I should make her (Jellyby) husband jealous. But he (husband) was, in his (husband) way, just as bad--I mean as good; and in short it was the old story, and nobody would leave me any possibility of doing anything meritorious.

The elder Mr. Turveydrop was in bed, I found, and Caddy was milling his (Turveydrop) chocolate, which a melancholy little boy who was an apprentice--it seemed such a curious thing to be apprenticed to the trade of dancing--was waiting to carry upstairs. Her (Jellyby) father-in-law was extremely kind and considerate, Caddy told me, and they lived most happily together. -LRB-When she (Jellyby) spoke of their living together, she (Jellyby) meant that the old gentleman had all the good things and all the good lodging, while she (Jellyby) and her (Jellyby) husband had what they could get, and were poked into two corner rooms over the Mews.-RRB-

``And how is your mama, Caddy?'' (I.)
said I.

``Why, I hear of her (mama), Esther,'' (I.)
replied Caddy,
``through Pa, but I see very little of her (Esther). We are good friends, I am glad to say, but Ma thinks there is something absurd in my having married a dancing-master, and she (Esther) is rather afraid of its extending to her (Esther).'' (I.)

It struck me that if Mrs. Jellyby had discharged her (Jellyby) own natural duties and obligations before she (Jellyby) swept the horizon with a telescope in search of others, she (Jellyby) would have taken the best precautions against becoming absurd, but I need scarcely observe that I kept this to myself.

``And your papa, Caddy?'' (unknown)

``He (papa) comes here every evening,'' (unknown)
returned Caddy,
``and is so fond of sitting in the corner there that it's a treat to see him (papa).'' (I)

Looking at the corner, I plainly perceived the mark of Mr. Jellyby's head against the wall. It was consolatory to know that he (Jellyby) had found such a resting-place for it.

``And you, Caddy,'' (I)
said I,
``you are always busy, I'll be bound?'' (I)

``Well, my dear,'' (unknown)
returned Caddy,
``I am indeed, for to tell you a grand secret, I am qualifying myself to give lessons. Prince's health is not strong, and I want to be able to assist him (Prince). What with schools, and classes here, and private pupils, AND the apprentices, he (Prince) really has too much to do, poor fellow!'' (the apprentices)

The notion of the apprentices was still so odd to me that I asked Caddy if there were many of them.

``Four,'' (unknown)
said Caddy.
``One in-door, and three out. They are very good children; only when they get together they WILL play--children-like--instead of attending to their work. So the little boy you saw just now waltzes by himself in the empty kitchen, and we distribute the others over the house as well as we can.'' (unknown)

``That is only for their steps, of course?'' (I.)
said I.

``Only for their steps,'' (I.)
said Caddy.
``In that way they practise, so many hours at a time, whatever steps they happen to be upon. They dance in the academy, and at this time of year we do figures at five every morning.'' (unknown)

``Why, what a laborious life!'' (I)
I exclaimed.

``I assure you, my dear,'' (unknown)
returned Caddy, smiling,
``when the out-door apprentices ring us up in the morning -LRB-the bell rings into our room, not to disturb old Mr. Turveydrop-RRB-, and when I put up the window and see them standing on the door-step with their little pumps under their arms, I am actually reminded of the Sweeps.'' (me)

All this presented the art to me in a singular light, to be sure. Caddy enjoyed the effect of her (Jellyby) communication and cheerfully recounted the particulars of her (Jellyby) own studies.

``You see, my dear, to save expense I ought to know something of the piano, and I ought to know something of the kit too, and consequently I have to practise those two instruments as well as the details of our profession. If Ma had been like anybody else, I might have had some little musical knowledge to begin upon. However, I hadn't any; and that part of the work is, at first, a little discouraging, I must allow. But I have a very good ear, and I am used to drudgery--I have to thank Ma for that, at all events--and where there's a will there's a way, you know, Esther, the world over.'' (unknown)
Saying these words, Caddy laughingly sat down at a little jingling square piano and really rattled off a quadrille with great spirit. Then she (Jellyby) good-humouredly and blushingly got up again, and while she (Jellyby) still laughed herself, said,
``Don't laugh at me, please; that's a dear girl!'' (she)

I would sooner have cried, but I did neither. I encouraged her (Jellyby) and praised her (Jellyby) with all my heart. For I conscientiously believed, dancing-master's wife though she (wife) was, and dancing-mistress though in her (wife) limited ambition she (wife) aspired to be, she (wife) had struck out a natural, wholesome, loving course of industry and perseverance that was quite as good as a mission.

``My dear,'' (unknown)
said Caddy, delighted,
``you can't think how you cheer me. I shall owe you, you don't know how much. What changes, Esther, even in my small world! You recollect that first night, when I was so unpolite and inky? Who would have thought, then, of my ever teaching people to dance, of all other possibilities and impossibilities!'' (husband Caddy)

Her (wife) husband, who had left us while we had this chat, now coming back, preparatory to exercising the apprentices in the ball-room, Caddy informed me she (wife) was quite at my disposal. But it was not my time yet, I was glad to tell her (wife), for I should have been vexed to take her (wife) away then. Therefore we three adjourned to the apprentices together, and I made one in the dance.

The apprentices were the queerest little people. Besides the melancholy boy, who, I hoped, had not been made so by waltzing alone in the empty kitchen, there were two other boys and one dirty little limp girl in a gauzy dress. Such a precocious little girl, with such a dowdy bonnet on -LRB-that, too, of a gauzy texture-RRB-, who brought her (girl) sandalled shoes in an old threadbare velvet reticule. Such mean little boys, when they were not dancing, with string, and marbles, and cramp-bones in their pockets, and the most untidy legs and feet--and heels particularly.

I asked Caddy what had made their parents choose this profession for them. Caddy said she (girl) didn't know; perhaps they were designed for teachers, perhaps for the stage. They were all people in humble circumstances, and the melancholy boy's mother kept a ginger-beer shop.
