General burst of cousinly indignation. Volumnia thinks it is really high time, you know, for somebody in power to step in and do something strong. Debilitated cousin thinks--country's going--Dayvle--steeple-chase pace.

``I beg,'' (unknown)
says Sir Leicester in a breathless condition,
``that we may not comment further on this circumstance. Comment is superfluous. My Lady, let me suggest in reference to that young woman--'' (Lady)

``I have no intention,'' (Lady)
observes my Lady from her (Lady) window in a low but decided tone,
``of parting with her (woman).'' (Lady)

``That was not my meaning,'' (unknown)
returns Sir Leicester.
``I am glad to hear you say so. I would suggest that as you think her (woman) worthy of your patronage, you should exert your influence to keep her (woman) from these dangerous hands. You might show her (woman) what violence would be done in such association to her (woman) duties and principles, and you might preserve her (woman) for a better fate. You might point out to her (woman) that she (woman) probably would, in good time, find a husband at Chesney Wold by whom she (woman) would not be--'' (Leicester Dedlock/Leicester/Dedlock)
Sir Leicester adds, after a moment's consideration,
``dragged from the altars of her (woman) forefathers.'' (Leicester Dedlock/Leicester/Dedlock)

These remarks he (cousin) offers with his (cousin) unvarying politeness and deference when he (cousin) addresses himself to his (cousin) wife. She (wife) merely moves her (wife) head in reply. The moon is rising, and where she (wife) sits there is a little stream of cold pale light, in which her (wife) head is seen.

``It is worthy of remark,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn,
``however, that these people are, in their way, very proud.'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

``Proud?'' (unknown)
Sir Leicester doubts his (Tulkinghorn) hearing.

``I should not be surprised if they all voluntarily abandoned the girl--yes, lover and all--instead of her (girl) abandoning them, supposing she (girl) remained at Chesney Wold under such circumstances.'' (unknown)

``Well!'' (unknown)
says Sir Leicester tremulously.
``Well! You should know, Mr. Tulkinghorn. You have been among them.'' (unknown)

``Really, Sir Leicester,'' (the lawyer)
returns the lawyer,
``I state the fact. Why, I could tell you a story--with Lady Dedlock's permission.'' (the lawyer)

Her (wife) head concedes it, and Volumnia is enchanted. A story! Oh, he (lawyer) is going to tell something at last! A ghost in it, Volumnia hopes?

``No. Real flesh and blood.'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
Mr. Tulkinghorn stops for an instant and repeats with some little emphasis grafted upon his (Tulkinghorn) usual monotony,
``Real flesh and blood, Miss Dedlock. Sir Leicester, these particulars have only lately become known to me. They are very brief. They exemplify what I have said. I suppress names for the present. Lady Dedlock will not think me ill-bred, I hope?'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

By the light of the fire, which is low, he (Tulkinghorn) can be seen looking towards the moonlight. By the light of the moon Lady Dedlock can be seen, perfectly still.

``A townsman of this Mrs. Rouncewell, a man in exactly parallel circumstances as I am told, had the good fortune to have a daughter who attracted the notice of a great lady. I speak of really a great lady, not merely great to him (man), but married to a gentleman of your condition, Sir Leicester.'' (unknown)

Sir Leicester condescendingly says,

``Yes, Mr. Tulkinghorn,'' (she)
implying that then she (Lady) must have appeared of very considerable moral dimensions indeed in the eyes of an iron-master.

``The lady was wealthy and beautiful, and had a liking for the girl, and treated her (girl) with great kindness, and kept her (girl) always near her (girl). Now this lady preserved a secret under all her (lady) greatness, which she (lady) had preserved for many years. In fact, she (lady) had in early life been engaged to marry a young rake--he (Tulkinghorn) was a captain in the army--nothing connected with whom came to any good. She (lady) never did marry him (Tulkinghorn), but she (lady) gave birth to a child of which he (Tulkinghorn) was the father.'' (he)

By the light of the fire he (Tulkinghorn) can be seen looking towards the moonlight. By the moonlight, Lady Dedlock can be seen in profile, perfectly still.

``The captain in the army being dead, she (lady) believed herself safe; but a train of circumstances with which I need not trouble you led to discovery. As I received the story, they began in an imprudence on her (lady) own part one day when she (lady) was taken by surprise, which shows how difficult it is for the firmest of us -LRB-she (lady) was very firm-RRB- to be always guarded. There was great domestic trouble and amazement, you may suppose; I leave you to imagine, Sir Leicester, the husband's grief. But that is not the present point. When Mr. Rouncewell's townsman heard of the disclosure, he (Rouncewell) no more allowed the girl to be patronized and honoured than he (Rouncewell) would have suffered her (girl) to be trodden underfoot before his (Rouncewell) eyes. Such was his (Rouncewell) pride, that he (Rouncewell) indignantly took her (girl) away, as if from reproach and disgrace. He (Rouncewell) had no sense of the honour done him (Rouncewell) and his (Rouncewell) daughter by the lady's condescension; not the least. He (Rouncewell) resented the girl's position, as if the lady had been the commonest of commoners. That is the story. I hope Lady Dedlock will excuse its painful nature.'' (unknown)

There are various opinions on the merits, more or less conflicting with Volumnia's. That fair young creature cannot believe there ever was any such lady and rejects the whole history on the threshold. The majority incline to the debilitated cousin's sentiment, which is in few words--

``no business--Rouncewell's fernal townsman.'' (the cousin)
Sir Leicester generally refers back in his (cousin) mind to Wat Tyler and arranges a sequence of events on a plan of his (cousin) own.

There is not much conversation in all, for late hours have been kept at Chesney Wold since the necessary expenses elsewhere began, and this is the first night in many on which the family have been alone. It is past ten when Sir Leicester begs Mr. Tulkinghorn to ring for candles. Then the stream of moonlight has swelled into a lake, and then Lady Dedlock for the first time moves, and rises, and comes forward to a table for a glass of water. Winking cousins, bat-like in the candle glare, crowd round to give it; Volumnia -LRB-always ready for something better if procurable-RRB- takes another, a very mild sip of which contents her (Dedlock); Lady Dedlock, graceful, self-possessed, looked after by admiring eyes, passes away slowly down the long perspective by the side of that nymph, not at all improving her (Dedlock) as a question of contrast.

CHAPTER XLI

In Mr. Tulkinghorn's Room

Mr. Tulkinghorn arrives in his (Tulkinghorn) turret-room a little breathed by the journey up, though leisurely performed. There is an expression on his (Tulkinghorn) face as if he (Tulkinghorn) had discharged his (Tulkinghorn) mind of some grave matter and were, in his (Tulkinghorn) close way, satisfied. To say of a man so severely and strictly self-repressed that he (Tulkinghorn) is triumphant would be to do him (Tulkinghorn) as great an injustice as to suppose him (Tulkinghorn) troubled with love or sentiment or any romantic weakness. He (Tulkinghorn) is sedately satisfied. Perhaps there is a rather increased sense of power upon him (Tulkinghorn) as he (Tulkinghorn) loosely grasps one of his (Tulkinghorn) veinous wrists with his (Tulkinghorn) other hand and holding it behind his (Tulkinghorn) back walks noiselessly up and down.

There is a capacious writing-table in the room on which is a pretty large accumulation of papers. The green lamp is lighted, his (Tulkinghorn) reading-glasses lie upon the desk, the easy-chair is wheeled up to it, and it would seem as though he (Tulkinghorn) had intended to bestow an hour or so upon these claims on his (Tulkinghorn) attention before going to bed. But he (Tulkinghorn) happens not to be in a business mind. After a glance at the documents awaiting his (Tulkinghorn) notice--with his (Tulkinghorn) head bent low over the table, the old man's sight for print or writing being defective at night--he (Tulkinghorn) opens the French window and steps out upon the leads. There he (Tulkinghorn) again walks slowly up and down in the same attitude, subsiding, if a man so cool may have any need to subside, from the story he (man) has related downstairs.

The time was once when men as knowing as Mr. Tulkinghorn would walk on turret-tops in the starlight and look up into the sky to read their fortunes there. Hosts of stars are visible to-night, though their brilliancy is eclipsed by the splendour of the moon. If he (Tulkinghorn) be seeking his (Tulkinghorn) own star as he (Tulkinghorn) methodically turns and turns upon the leads, it should be but a pale one to be so rustily represented below. If he (Tulkinghorn) be tracing out his (Tulkinghorn) destiny, that may be written in other characters nearer to his (Tulkinghorn) hand.

As he (Tulkinghorn) paces the leads with his (Tulkinghorn) eyes most probably as high above his (Tulkinghorn) thoughts as they are high above the earth, he (Tulkinghorn) is suddenly stopped in passing the window by two eyes that meet his (Tulkinghorn) own. The ceiling of his (Tulkinghorn) room is rather low; and the upper part of the door, which is opposite the window, is of glass. There is an inner baize door, too, but the night being warm he (Tulkinghorn) did not close it when he (Tulkinghorn) came upstairs. These eyes that meet his (Tulkinghorn) own are looking in through the glass from the corridor outside. He (Tulkinghorn) knows them well. The blood has not flushed into his (Tulkinghorn) face so suddenly and redly for many a long year as when he (Tulkinghorn) recognizes Lady Dedlock.

He (Tulkinghorn) steps into the room, and she (Dedlock) comes in too, closing both the doors behind her (Dedlock). There is a wild disturbance--is it fear or anger?--in her (Dedlock) eyes. In her (Dedlock) carriage and all else she (Dedlock) looks as she (Dedlock) looked downstairs two hours ago.

Is it fear or is it anger now? He (Tulkinghorn) cannot be sure. Both might be as pale, both as intent.

``Lady Dedlock?'' (She)

She (Dedlock) does not speak at first, nor even when she (Dedlock) has slowly dropped into the easy-chair by the table. They look at each other, like two pictures.

``Why have you told my story to so many persons?'' (unknown)

``Lady Dedlock, it was necessary for me to inform you that I knew it.'' (unknown)

``How long have you known it?'' (unknown)

``I have suspected it a long while--fully known it a little while.'' (unknown)

``Months?'' (unknown)

``Days.'' (He)

He (Tulkinghorn) stands before her (Dedlock) with one hand on a chair-back and the other in his (Tulkinghorn) old-fashioned waistcoat and shirt-frill, exactly as he (Tulkinghorn) has stood before her (Dedlock) at any time since her (Dedlock) marriage. The same formal politeness, the same composed deference that might as well be defiance; the whole man the same dark, cold object, at the same distance, which nothing has ever diminished.

``Is this true concerning the poor girl?'' (He)

He (man) slightly inclines and advances his (man) head as not quite understanding the question.

``You know what you related. Is it true? Do her (girl) friends know my story also? Is it the town-talk yet? Is it chalked upon the walls and cried in the streets?'' (unknown)

So! Anger, and fear, and shame. All three contending. What power this woman has to keep these raging passions down! Mr. Tulkinghorn's thoughts take such form as he (Tulkinghorn) looks at her (woman), with his (Tulkinghorn) ragged grey eyebrows a hair's breadth more contracted than usual under her (woman) gaze.

``No, Lady Dedlock. That was a hypothetical case, arising out of Sir Leicester's unconsciously carrying the matter with so high a hand. But it would be a real case if they knew--what we know.'' (unknown)

``Then they do not know it yet?'' (unknown)

``No.'' (unknown)

``Can I save the poor girl from injury before they know it?'' (unknown)

``Really, Lady Dedlock,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
Mr. Tulkinghorn replies,
``I cannot give a satisfactory opinion on that point.'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

And he (Tulkinghorn) thinks, with the interest of attentive curiosity, as he (Tulkinghorn) watches the struggle in her (woman) breast,

``The power and force of this woman are astonishing!'' (he)

``Sir,'' (she)
she (woman) says, for the moment obliged to set her (woman) lips with all the energy she (woman) has, that she (woman) may speak distinctly,
``I will make it plainer. I do not dispute your hypothetical case. I anticipated it, and felt its truth as strongly as you can do, when I saw Mr. Rouncewell here. I knew very well that if he (Rouncewell) could have had the power of seeing me as I was, he (Rouncewell) would consider the poor girl tarnished by having for a moment been, although most innocently, the subject of my great and distinguished patronage. But I have an interest in her (girl), or I should rather say--no longer belonging to this place--I had, and if you can find so much consideration for the woman under your foot as to remember that, she (woman) will be very sensible of your mercy.'' (she)

Mr. Tulkinghorn, profoundly attentive, throws this off with a shrug of self-depreciation and contracts his (Tulkinghorn) eyebrows a little more.

``You have prepared me for my exposure, and I thank you for that too. Is there anything that you require of me? Is there any claim that I can release or any charge or trouble that I can spare my husband in obtaining HIS (husband) release by certifying to the exactness of your discovery? I will write anything, here and now, that you will dictate. I am ready to do it.'' (she)

And she (woman) would do it, thinks the lawyer, watchful of the firm hand with which she (woman) takes the pen!

``I will not trouble you, Lady Dedlock. Pray spare yourself.'' (unknown)

``I have long expected this, as you know. I neither wish to spare myself nor to be spared. You can do nothing worse to me than you have done. Do what remains now.'' (unknown)

``Lady Dedlock, there is nothing to be done. I will take leave to say a few words when you have finished.'' (unknown)

Their need for watching one another should be over now, but they do it all this time, and the stars watch them both through the opened window. Away in the moonlight lie the woodland fields at rest, and the wide house is as quiet as the narrow one. The narrow one! Where are the digger and the spade, this peaceful night, destined to add the last great secret to the many secrets of the Tulkinghorn existence? Is the man born yet, is the spade wrought yet? Curious questions to consider, more curious perhaps not to consider, under the watching stars upon a summer night.

``Of repentance or remorse or any feeling of mine,'' (Lady Dedlock/Dedlock)
Lady Dedlock presently proceeds,
``I say not a word. If I were not dumb, you would be deaf. Let that go by. It is not for your ears.'' (Lady Dedlock/Dedlock)

He (man) makes a feint of offering a protest, but she (Dedlock) sweeps it away with her (Dedlock) disdainful hand.

``Of other and very different things I come to speak to you. My jewels are all in their proper places of keeping. They will be found there. So, my dresses. So, all the valuables I have. Some ready money I had with me, please to say, but no large amount. I did not wear my own dress, in order that I might avoid observation. I went to be henceforward lost. Make this known. I leave no other charge with you.'' (unknown)

``Excuse me, Lady Dedlock,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn, quite unmoved.
``I am not sure that I understand you. You want--'' (unknown)

``To be lost to all here. I leave Chesney Wold to-night. I go this hour.'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

Mr. Tulkinghorn shakes his (Tulkinghorn) head. She (Dedlock) rises, but he (Tulkinghorn), without moving hand from chair-back or from old-fashioned waistcoat and shirt-frill, shakes his (Tulkinghorn) head.

``What? Not go as I have said?'' (unknown)

``No, Lady Dedlock,'' (he)
he (Tulkinghorn) very calmly replies.

``Do you know the relief that my disappearance will be? Have you forgotten the stain and blot upon this place, and where it is, and who it is?'' (unknown)

``No, Lady Dedlock, not by any means.'' (she)

Without deigning to rejoin, she (Dedlock) moves to the inner door and has it in her (Dedlock) hand when he (Tulkinghorn) says to her (Dedlock), without himself stirring hand or foot or raising his (Tulkinghorn) voice,

``Lady Dedlock, have the goodness to stop and hear me, or before you reach the staircase I shall ring the alarm-bell and rouse the house. And then I must speak out before every guest and servant, every man and woman, in it.'' (her)

He (Tulkinghorn) has conquered her (Dedlock). She (Dedlock) falters, trembles, and puts her (Dedlock) hand confusedly to her (Dedlock) head. Slight tokens these in any one else, but when so practised an eye as Mr. Tulkinghorn's sees indecision for a moment in such a subject, he (Tulkinghorn) thoroughly knows its value.

He (Tulkinghorn) promptly says again,

``Have the goodness to hear me, Lady Dedlock,'' (He)
and motions to the chair from which she (Dedlock) has risen. She (Dedlock) hesitates, but he (Tulkinghorn) motions again, and she (Dedlock) sits down.

``The relations between us are of an unfortunate description, Lady Dedlock; but as they are not of my making, I will not apologize for them. The position I hold in reference to Sir Leicester is so well known to you that I can hardly imagine but that I must long have appeared in your eyes the natural person to make this discovery.'' (unknown)

``Sir,'' (she)
she (Dedlock) returns without looking up from the ground on which her (Dedlock) eyes are now fixed,
``I had better have gone. It would have been far better not to have detained me. I have no more to say.'' (she)

``Excuse me, Lady Dedlock, if I add a little more to hear.'' (unknown)

``I wish to hear it at the window, then. I can't breathe where I am.'' (she)

His (Tulkinghorn) jealous glance as she (Dedlock) walks that way betrays an instant's misgiving that she (Dedlock) may have it in her (Dedlock) thoughts to leap over, and dashing against ledge and cornice, strike her (Dedlock) life out upon the terrace below. But a moment's observation of her (Dedlock) figure as she (Dedlock) stands in the window without any support, looking out at the stars--not up--gloomily out at those stars which are low in the heavens, reassures him (Tulkinghorn). By facing round as she (Dedlock) has moved, he (Tulkinghorn) stands a little behind her (Dedlock).

``Lady Dedlock, I have not yet been able to come to a decision satisfactory to myself on the course before me. I am not clear what to do or how to act next. I must request you, in the meantime, to keep your secret as you have kept it so long and not to wonder that I keep it too.'' (He)

He (Tulkinghorn) pauses, but she (Dedlock) makes no reply.

``Pardon me, Lady Dedlock. This is an important subject. You are honouring me with your attention?'' (unknown)

``I am.'' (unknown)

``Thank you. I might have known it from what I have seen of your strength of character. I ought not to have asked the question, but I have the habit of making sure of my ground, step by step, as I go on. The sole consideration in this unhappy case is Sir Leicester.'' (unknown)

``Then why,'' (she)
she (Dedlock) asks in a low voice and without removing her (Dedlock) gloomy look from those distant stars,
``do you detain me in his (character) house?'' (she)

``Because he (character) IS the consideration. Lady Dedlock, I have no occasion to tell you that Sir Leicester is a very proud man, that his (man) reliance upon you is implicit, that the fall of that moon out of the sky would not amaze him (man) more than your fall from your high position as his (man) wife.'' (She)

She (Dedlock) breathes quickly and heavily, but she (Dedlock) stands as unflinchingly as ever he (Tulkinghorn) has seen her (Dedlock) in the midst of her (Dedlock) grandest company.

``I declare to you, Lady Dedlock, that with anything short of this case that I have, I would as soon have hoped to root up by means of my own strength and my own hands the oldest tree on this estate as to shake your hold upon Sir Leicester and Sir Leicester's trust and confidence in you. And even now, with this case, I hesitate. Not that he (man) could doubt -LRB-that, even with him (man), is impossible-RRB-, but that nothing can prepare him (man) for the blow.'' (unknown)

``Not my flight?'' (she)
she (Dedlock) returned.
``Think of it again.'' (unknown)

``Your flight, Lady Dedlock, would spread the whole truth, and a hundred times the whole truth, far and wide. It would be impossible to save the family credit for a day. It is not to be thought of.'' (unknown)

There is a quiet decision in his (Tulkinghorn) reply which admits of no remonstrance.

``When I speak of Sir Leicester being the sole consideration, he (man) and the family credit are one. Sir Leicester and the baronetcy, Sir Leicester and Chesney Wold, Sir Leicester and his (Wold) ancestors and his (Wold) patrimony'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
--Mr. Tulkinghorn very dry here--
``are, I need not say to you, Lady Dedlock, inseparable.'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

``Go on!'' (unknown)

``Therefore,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn, pursuing his (Tulkinghorn) case in his (Tulkinghorn) jog-trot style,
``I have much to consider. This is to be hushed up if it can be. How can it be, if Sir Leicester is driven out of his (Wold) wits or laid upon a death-bed? If I inflicted this shock upon him (Wold) to-morrow morning, how could the immediate change in him (Wold) be accounted for? What could have caused it? What could have divided you? Lady Dedlock, the wall-chalking and the street-crying would come on directly, and you are to remember that it would not affect you merely -LRB-whom I cannot at all consider in this business-RRB- but your husband, Lady Dedlock, your husband.'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

He (Tulkinghorn) gets plainer as he (Tulkinghorn) gets on, but not an atom more emphatic or animated.

``There is another point of view,'' (he)
he (Tulkinghorn) continues,
``in which the case presents itself. Sir Leicester is devoted to you almost to infatuation. He (husband) might not be able to overcome that infatuation, even knowing what we know. I am putting an extreme case, but it might be so. If so, it were better that he (husband) knew nothing. Better for common sense, better for him (husband), better for me. I must take all this into account, and it combines to render a decision very difficult.'' (he)

She (Dedlock) stands looking out at the same stars without a word. They are beginning to pale, and she (Dedlock) looks as if their coldness froze her (Dedlock).

``My experience teaches me,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn, who has by this time got his (Tulkinghorn) hands in his (Tulkinghorn) pockets and is going on in his (Tulkinghorn) business consideration of the matter like a machine.
``My experience teaches me, Lady Dedlock, that most of the people I know would do far better to leave marriage alone. It is at the bottom of three fourths of their troubles. So I thought when Sir Leicester married, and so I always have thought since. No more about that. I must now be guided by circumstances. In the meanwhile I must beg you to keep your own counsel, and I will keep mine.'' (unknown)

``I am to drag my present life on, holding its pains at your pleasure, day by day?'' (she)
she (Dedlock) asks, still looking at the distant sky.

``Yes, I am afraid so, Lady Dedlock.'' (unknown)

``It is necessary, you think, that I should be so tied to the stake?'' (unknown)

``I am sure that what I recommend is necessary.'' (unknown)

``I am to remain on this gaudy platform on which my miserable deception has been so long acted, and it is to fall beneath me when you give the signal?'' (she)
she (Dedlock) said slowly.

``Not without notice, Lady Dedlock. I shall take no step without forewarning you.'' (She)

She (Dedlock) asks all her (Dedlock) questions as if she (Dedlock) were repeating them from memory or calling them over in her (Dedlock) sleep.

``We are to meet as usual?'' (unknown)

``Precisely as usual, if you please.'' (unknown)

``And I am to hide my guilt, as I have done so many years?'' (unknown)

``As you have done so many years. I should not have made that reference myself, Lady Dedlock, but I may now remind you that your secret can be no heavier to you than it was, and is no worse and no better than it was. I know it certainly, but I believe we have never wholly trusted each other.'' (She)

She (Dedlock) stands absorbed in the same frozen way for some little time before asking,

``Is there anything more to be said to-night?'' (She)

``Why,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
Mr. Tulkinghorn returns methodically as he (Tulkinghorn) softly rubs his (Tulkinghorn) hands,
``I should like to be assured of your acquiescence in my arrangements, Lady Dedlock.'' (he)

``You may be assured of it.'' (unknown)

``Good. And I would wish in conclusion to remind you, as a business precaution, in case it should be necessary to recall the fact in any communication with Sir Leicester, that throughout our interview I have expressly stated my sole consideration to be Sir Leicester's feelings and honour and the family reputation. I should have been happy to have made Lady Dedlock a prominent consideration, too, if the case had admitted of it; but unfortunately it does not.'' (unknown)

``I can attest your fidelity, sir.'' (she)

Both before and after saying it she (Dedlock) remains absorbed, but at length moves, and turns, unshaken in her (Dedlock) natural and acquired presence, towards the door. Mr. Tulkinghorn opens both the doors exactly as he (Tulkinghorn) would have done yesterday, or as he (Tulkinghorn) would have done ten years ago, and makes his (Tulkinghorn) old-fashioned bow as she (Dedlock) passes out. It is not an ordinary look that he (Tulkinghorn) receives from the handsome face as it goes into the darkness, and it is not an ordinary movement, though a very slight one, that acknowledges his (Tulkinghorn) courtesy. But as he (Tulkinghorn) reflects when he (Tulkinghorn) is left alone, the woman has been putting no common constraint upon herself.

He (Tulkinghorn) would know it all the better if he (Tulkinghorn) saw the woman pacing her (woman) own rooms with her (woman) hair wildly thrown from her (woman) flung-back face, her (woman) hands clasped behind her (woman) head, her (woman) figure twisted as if by pain. He (Tulkinghorn) would think so all the more if he (Tulkinghorn) saw the woman thus hurrying up and down for hours, without fatigue, without intermission, followed by the faithful step upon the Ghost's Walk. But he (Tulkinghorn) shuts out the now chilled air, draws the window-curtain, goes to bed, and falls asleep. And truly when the stars go out and the wan day peeps into the turret-chamber, finding him (Tulkinghorn) at his (Tulkinghorn) oldest, he (Tulkinghorn) looks as if the digger and the spade were both commissioned and would soon be digging.

The same wan day peeps in at Sir Leicester pardoning the repentant country in a majestically condescending dream; and at the cousins entering on various public employments, principally receipt of salary; and at the chaste Volumnia, bestowing a dower of fifty thousand pounds upon a hideous old general with a mouth of false teeth like a pianoforte too full of keys, long the admiration of Bath and the terror of every other community. Also into rooms high in the roof, and into offices in court-yards, and over stables, where humbler ambition dreams of bliss, in keepers' lodges, and in holy matrimony with Will or Sally. Up comes the bright sun, drawing everything up with it--the Wills and Sallys, the latent vapour in the earth, the drooping leaves and flowers, the birds and beasts and creeping things, the gardeners to sweep the dewy turf and unfold emerald velvet where the roller passes, the smoke of the great kitchen fire wreathing itself straight and high into the lightsome air. Lastly, up comes the flag over Mr. Tulkinghorn's unconscious head cheerfully proclaiming that Sir Leicester and Lady Dedlock are in their happy home and that there is hospitality at the place in Lincolnshire.

CHAPTER XLII

In Mr. Tulkinghorn's Chambers

From the verdant undulations and the spreading oaks of the Dedlock property, Mr. Tulkinghorn transfers himself to the stale heat and dust of London. His (Tulkinghorn) manner of coming and going between the two places is one of his (Tulkinghorn) impenetrabilities. He (Tulkinghorn) walks into Chesney Wold as if it were next door to his (Tulkinghorn) chambers and returns to his (Tulkinghorn) chambers as if he (Tulkinghorn) had never been out of Lincoln's Inn Fields. He (Tulkinghorn) neither changes his (Tulkinghorn) dress before the journey nor talks of it afterwards. He (Tulkinghorn) melted out of his (Tulkinghorn) turret-room this morning, just as now, in the late twilight, he (Tulkinghorn) melts into his (Tulkinghorn) own square.

Like a dingy London bird among the birds at roost in these pleasant fields, where the sheep are all made into parchment, the goats into wigs, and the pasture into chaff, the lawyer, smoke-dried and faded, dwelling among mankind but not consorting with them, aged without experience of genial youth, and so long used to make his (lawyer) cramped nest in holes and corners of human nature that he (lawyer) has forgotten its broader and better range, comes sauntering home. In the oven made by the hot pavements and hot buildings, he (lawyer) has baked himself dryer than usual; and he (lawyer) has in his (lawyer) thirsty mind his (lawyer) mellowed port-wine half a century old.

The lamplighter is skipping up and down his (lawyer) ladder on Mr. Tulkinghorn's side of the Fields when that high-priest of noble mysteries arrives at his (lawyer) own dull court-yard. He (lawyer) ascends the door-steps and is gliding into the dusky hall when he (lawyer) encounters, on the top step, a bowing and propitiatory little man.

``Is that Snagsby?'' (unknown)

``Yes, sir. I hope you are well, sir. I was just giving you up, sir, and going home.'' (unknown)

``Aye? What is it? What do you want with me?'' (unknown)

``Well, sir,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby, holding his (Snagsby) hat at the side of his (Snagsby) head in his (Snagsby) deference towards his (Snagsby) best customer,
``I was wishful to say a word to you, sir.'' (customer)

``Can you say it here?'' (unknown)

``Perfectly, sir.'' (unknown)

``Say it then.'' (The lawyer)
The lawyer turns, leans his (Snagsby) arms on the iron railing at the top of the steps, and looks at the lamplighter lighting the court-yard.

``It is relating,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby in a mysterious low voice,
``it is relating--not to put too fine a point upon it--to the foreigner, sir!'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

Mr. Tulkinghorn eyes him (Tulkinghorn) with some surprise.

``What foreigner?'' (unknown)

``The foreign female, sir. French, if I don't mistake? I am not acquainted with that language myself, but I should judge from her (female) manners and appearance that she (female) was French; anyways, certainly foreign. Her (female) that was upstairs, sir, when Mr. Bucket and me had the honour of waiting upon you with the sweeping-boy that night.'' (unknown)

``Oh! Yes, yes. Mademoiselle Hortense.'' (unknown)

``Indeed, sir?'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
Mr. Snagsby coughs his (Snagsby) cough of submission behind his (Snagsby) hat.
``I am not acquainted myself with the names of foreigners in general, but I have no doubt it WOULD be that.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
Mr. Snagsby appears to have set out in this reply with some desperate design of repeating the name, but on reflection coughs again to excuse himself.

``And what can you have to say, Snagsby,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
demands Mr. Tulkinghorn,
``about her (Hortense)?'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

``Well, sir,'' (the stationer)
returns the stationer, shading his (Tulkinghorn) communication with his (Tulkinghorn) hat,
``it falls a little hard upon me. My domestic happiness is very great--at least, it's as great as can be expected, I'm sure--but my little woman is rather given to jealousy. Not to put too fine a point upon it, she (woman) is very much given to jealousy. And you see, a foreign female of that genteel appearance coming into the shop, and hovering--I should be the last to make use of a strong expression if I could avoid it, but hovering, sir--in the court--you know it is--now ain't it? I only put it to yourself, sir.'' (the stationer)

Mr. Snagsby, having said this in a very plaintive manner, throws in a cough of general application to fill up all the blanks.

``Why, what do you mean?'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
asks Mr. Tulkinghorn.

``Just so, sir,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
returns Mr. Snagsby;
``I was sure you would feel it yourself and would excuse the reasonableness of MY feelings when coupled with the known excitableness of my little woman. You see, the foreign female--which you mentioned her (female) name just now, with quite a native sound I am sure--caught up the word Snagsby that night, being uncommon quick, and made inquiry, and got the direction and come at dinner-time. Now Guster, our young woman, is timid and has fits, and she (woman), taking fright at the foreigner's looks--which are fierce--and at a grinding manner that she (woman) has of speaking--which is calculated to alarm a weak mind--gave way to it, instead of bearing up against it, and tumbled down the kitchen stairs out of one into another, such fits as I do sometimes think are never gone into, or come out of, in any house but ours. Consequently there was by good fortune ample occupation for my little woman, and only me to answer the shop. When she (woman) DID say that Mr. Tulkinghorn, being always denied to her (woman) by his (Tulkinghorn) employer -LRB-which I had no doubt at the time was a foreign mode of viewing a clerk-RRB-, she (clerk) would do herself the pleasure of continually calling at my place until she (clerk) was let in here. Since then she (clerk) has been, as I began by saying, hovering, hovering, sir'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
--Mr. Snagsby repeats the word with pathetic emphasis--
``in the court. The effects of which movement it is impossible to calculate. I shouldn't wonder if it might have already given rise to the painfullest mistakes even in the neighbours' minds, not mentioning -LRB-if such a thing was possible-RRB- my little woman. Whereas, goodness knows,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby, shaking his (Snagsby) head,
``I never had an idea of a foreign female, except as being formerly connected with a bunch of brooms and a baby, or at the present time with a tambourine and earrings. I never had, I do assure you, sir!'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

Mr. Tulkinghorn had listened gravely to this complaint and inquires when the stationer has finished,

``And that's all, is it, Snagsby?'' (the stationer)

``Why yes, sir, that's all,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
says Mr. Snagsby, ending with a cough that plainly adds,
``and it's enough too--for me.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``I don't know what Mademoiselle Hortense may want or mean, unless she (Hortense) is mad,'' (the lawyer)
says the lawyer.

``Even if she (Hortense) was, you know, sir,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
Mr. Snagsby pleads,
``it wouldn't be a consolation to have some weapon or another in the form of a foreign dagger planted in the family.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

``No,'' (unknown)
says the other.
``Well, well! This shall be stopped. I am sorry you have been inconvenienced. If she (Hortense) comes again, send her (Hortense) here.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

Mr. Snagsby, with much bowing and short apologetic coughing, takes his (Snagsby) leave, lightened in heart. Mr. Tulkinghorn goes upstairs, saying to himself,

``These women were created to give trouble the whole earth over. The mistress not being enough to deal with, here's the maid now! But I will be short with THIS jade at least!'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

So saying, he (Tulkinghorn) unlocks his (Tulkinghorn) door, gropes his (Tulkinghorn) way into his (Tulkinghorn) murky rooms, lights his (Tulkinghorn) candles, and looks about him (Tulkinghorn). It is too dark to see much of the Allegory overhead there, but that importunate Roman, who is for ever toppling out of the clouds and pointing, is at his (Roman) old work pretty distinctly. Not honouring him (Roman) with much attention, Mr. Tulkinghorn takes a small key from his (Tulkinghorn) pocket, unlocks a drawer in which there is another key, which unlocks a chest in which there is another, and so comes to the cellar-key, with which he (Tulkinghorn) prepares to descend to the regions of old wine. He (Tulkinghorn) is going towards the door with a candle in his (Tulkinghorn) hand when a knock comes.

``Who's this? Aye, aye, mistress, it's you, is it? You appear at a good time. I have just been hearing of you. Now! What do you want?'' (He)

He (Tulkinghorn) stands the candle on the chimney-piece in the clerk's hall and taps his (Tulkinghorn) dry cheek with the key as he (Tulkinghorn) addresses these words of welcome to Mademoiselle Hortense. That feline personage, with her (Hortense) lips tightly shut and her (Hortense) eyes looking out at him (Tulkinghorn) sideways, softly closes the door before replying.

``I have had great deal of trouble to find you, sir.'' (unknown)

``HAVE you!'' (unknown)

``I have been here very often, sir. It has always been said to me, he (mistress) is not at home, he (mistress) is engage, he (mistress) is this and that, he (mistress) is not for you.'' (unknown)

``Quite right, and quite true.'' (unknown)

``Not true. Lies!'' (Mademoiselle Hortense/Mademoiselle/Hortense)

At times there is a suddenness in the manner of Mademoiselle Hortense so like a bodily spring upon the subject of it that such subject involuntarily starts and fails back. It is Mr. Tulkinghorn's case at present, though Mademoiselle Hortense, with her (Hortense) eyes almost shut up -LRB-but still looking out sideways-RRB-, is only smiling contemptuously and shaking her (Hortense) head.

``Now, mistress,'' (the lawyer)
says the lawyer, tapping the key hastily upon the chimney-piece.
``If you have anything to say, say it, say it.'' (unknown)

``Sir, you have not use me well. You have been mean and shabby.'' (unknown)

``Mean and shabby, eh?'' (returns the lawyer)
returns the lawyer, rubbing his (lawyer) nose with the key.

``Yes. What is it that I tell you? You know you have. You have attrapped me--catched me--to give you information; you have asked me to show you the dress of mine my Lady must have wore that night, you have prayed me to come in it here to meet that boy. Say! Is it not?'' (Mademoiselle Hortense/Mademoiselle/Hortense)
Mademoiselle Hortense makes another spring.

``You are a vixen, a vixen!'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
Mr. Tulkinghorn seems to meditate as he (Tulkinghorn) looks distrustfully at her (Hortense), then he (Tulkinghorn) replies,
``Well, wench, well. I paid you.'' (he)

``You paid me!'' (she)
she (Hortense) repeats with fierce disdain.
``Two sovereign! I have not change them, I re-fuse them, I des-pise them, I throw them from me!'' (she)
Which she (Hortense) literally does, taking them out of her (Hortense) bosom as she (Hortense) speaks and flinging them with such violence on the floor that they jerk up again into the light before they roll away into corners and slowly settle down there after spinning vehemently.

``Now!'' (Mademoiselle Hortense/Mademoiselle/Hortense)
says Mademoiselle Hortense, darkening her (Hortense) large eyes again.
``You have paid me? Eh, my God, oh yes!'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

Mr. Tulkinghorn rubs his (Tulkinghorn) head with the key while she (Hortense) entertains herself with a sarcastic laugh.

``You must be rich, my fair friend,'' (he)
he (Tulkinghorn) composedly observes,
``to throw money about in that way!'' (he)

``I AM rich,'' (she)
she (Hortense) returns.
``I am very rich in hate. I hate my Lady, of all my heart. You know that.'' (unknown)

``Know it? How should I know it?'' (unknown)

``Because you have known it perfectly before you prayed me to give you that information. Because you have known perfectly that I was en-r-r-r-raged!'' (unknown)
It appears impossible for mademoiselle to roll the letter
``r'' (she)
sufficiently in this word, notwithstanding that she (Hortense) assists her (Hortense) energetic delivery by clenching both her (Hortense) hands and setting all her (Hortense) teeth.

``Oh! I knew that, did I?'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn, examining the wards of the key.

``Yes, without doubt. I am not blind. You have made sure of me because you knew that. You had reason! I det-est her (Lady).'' (Mademoiselle Hortense/Mademoiselle/Hortense)
Mademoiselle folds her (Mademoiselle) arms and throws this last remark at him (Tulkinghorn) over one of her (Mademoiselle) shoulders.

``Having said this, have you anything else to say, mademoiselle?'' (unknown)

``I am not yet placed. Place me well. Find me a good condition! If you cannot, or do not choose to do that, employ me to pursue her (Lady), to chase her (Lady), to disgrace and to dishonour her (Lady). I will help you well, and with a good will. It is what YOU do. Do I not know that?'' (unknown)

``You appear to know a good deal,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
Mr. Tulkinghorn retorts.

``Do I not? Is it that I am so weak as to believe, like a child, that I come here in that dress to rec-eive that boy only to decide a little bet, a wager? Eh, my God, oh yes!'' (unknown)
In this reply, down to the word
``wager'' (unknown)
inclusive, mademoiselle has been ironically polite and tender, then as suddenly dashed into the bitterest and most defiant scorn, with her (Mademoiselle) black eyes in one and the same moment very nearly shut and staringly wide open.

``Now, let us see,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn, tapping his (Tulkinghorn) chin with the key and looking imperturbably at her (Mademoiselle),
``how this matter stands.'' (her)

``Ah! Let us see,'' (unknown)
mademoiselle assents, with many angry and tight nods of her (Mademoiselle) head.

``You come here to make a remarkably modest demand, which you have just stated, and it not being conceded, you will come again.'' (unknown)

``And again,'' (unknown)
says mademoiselle with more tight and angry nods.
``And yet again. And yet again. And many times again. In effect, for ever!'' (unknown)

``And not only here, but you will go to Mr. Snagsby's too, perhaps? That visit not succeeding either, you will go again perhaps?'' (unknown)

``And again,'' (unknown)
repeats mademoiselle, cataleptic with determination.
``And yet again. And yet again. And many times again. In effect, for ever!'' (unknown)

``Very well. Now, Mademoiselle Hortense, let me recommend you to take the candle and pick up that money of yours. I think you will find it behind the clerk's partition in the corner yonder.'' (She)

She (Mademoiselle) merely throws a laugh over her (Mademoiselle) shoulder and stands her (Mademoiselle) ground with folded arms.

``You will not, eh?'' (unknown)

``No, I will not!'' (unknown)

``So much the poorer you; so much the richer I! Look, mistress, this is the key of my wine-cellar. It is a large key, but the keys of prisons are larger. In this city there are houses of correction -LRB-where the treadmills are, for women-RRB-, the gates of which are very strong and heavy, and no doubt the keys too. I am afraid a lady of your spirit and activity would find it an inconvenience to have one of those keys turned upon her (lady) for any length of time. What do you think?'' (unknown)

``I think,'' (unknown)
mademoiselle replies without any action and in a clear, obliging voice,
``that you are a miserable wretch.'' (unknown)

``Probably,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
returns Mr. Tulkinghorn, quietly blowing his (Tulkinghorn) nose.
``But I don't ask what you think of myself; I ask what you think of the prison.'' (unknown)

``Nothing. What does it matter to me?'' (unknown)

``Why, it matters this much, mistress,'' (the lawyer)
says the lawyer, deliberately putting away his (Tulkinghorn) handkerchief and adjusting his (Tulkinghorn) frill;
``the law is so despotic here that it interferes to prevent any of our good English citizens from being troubled, even by a lady's visits against his (mistress) desire. And on his (mistress) complaining that he (mistress) is so troubled, it takes hold of the troublesome lady and shuts her (lady) up in prison under hard discipline. Turns the key upon her (lady), mistress.'' (the lawyer)
Illustrating with the cellar-key.

``Truly?'' (unknown)
returns mademoiselle in the same pleasant voice.
``That is droll! But--my faith!--still what does it matter to me?'' (unknown)

``My fair friend,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn,
``make another visit here, or at Mr. Snagsby's, and you shall learn.'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

``In that case you will send me to the prison, perhaps?'' (unknown)

``Perhaps.'' (her)

It would be contradictory for one in mademoiselle's state of agreeable jocularity to foam at the mouth, otherwise a tigerish expansion thereabouts might look as if a very little more would make her (Mademoiselle) do it.

``In a word, mistress,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
says Mr. Tulkinghorn,
``I am sorry to be unpolite, but if you ever present yourself uninvited here--or there--again, I will give you over to the police. Their gallantry is great, but they carry troublesome people through the streets in an ignominious manner, strapped down on a board, my good wench.'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)

``I will prove you,'' (unknown)
whispers mademoiselle, stretching out her (Mademoiselle) hand,
``I will try if you dare to do it!'' (unknown)

``And if,'' (the lawyer)
pursues the lawyer without minding her (Mademoiselle),
``I place you in that good condition of being locked up in jail, it will be some time before you find yourself at liberty again.'' (her)

``I will prove you,'' (unknown)
repeats mademoiselle in her (Mademoiselle) former whisper.

``And now,'' (the lawyer)
proceeds the lawyer, still without minding her (Mademoiselle),
``you had better go. Think twice before you come here again.'' (her)

``Think you,'' (she)
she (Mademoiselle) answers,
``twice two hundred times!'' (she)

``You were dismissed by your lady, you know,'' (Mr. Tulkinghorn/Tulkinghorn)
Mr. Tulkinghorn observes, following her (Mademoiselle) out upon the staircase,
``as the most implacable and unmanageable of women. Now turn over a new leaf and take warning by what I say to you. For what I say, I mean; and what I threaten, I will do, mistress.'' (her)

She (Mademoiselle) goes down without answering or looking behind her (Mademoiselle). When she (Mademoiselle) is gone, he (Tulkinghorn) goes down too, and returning with his (Tulkinghorn) cobweb-covered bottle, devotes himself to a leisurely enjoyment of its contents, now and then, as he (Tulkinghorn) throws his (Tulkinghorn) head back in his (Tulkinghorn) chair, catching sight of the pertinacious Roman pointing from the ceiling.

CHAPTER XLIII

Esther's Narrative

It matters little now how much I thought of my living mother who had told me evermore to consider her (mother) dead. I could not venture to approach her (mother) or to communicate with her (mother) in writing, for my sense of the peril in which her (mother) life was passed was only to be equalled by my fears of increasing it. Knowing that my mere existence as a living creature was an unforeseen danger in her (mother) way, I could not always conquer that terror of myself which had seized me when I first knew the secret. At no time did I dare to utter her (mother) name. I felt as if I did not even dare to hear it. If the conversation anywhere, when I was present, took that direction, as it sometimes naturally did, I tried not to hear: I mentally counted, repeated something that I knew, or went out of the room. I am conscious now that I often did these things when there can have been no danger of her (mother) being spoken of, but I did them in the dread I had of hearing anything that might lead to her (mother) betrayal, and to her (mother) betrayal through me.

It matters little now how often I recalled the tones of my mother's voice, wondered whether I should ever hear it again as I so longed to do, and thought how strange and desolate it was that it should be so new to me. It matters little that I watched for every public mention of my mother's name; that I passed and repassed the door of her (mother) house in town, loving it, but afraid to look at it; that I once sat in the theatre when my mother was there and saw me, and when we were so wide asunder before the great company of all degrees that any link or confidence between us seemed a dream. It is all, all over. My lot has been so blest that I can relate little of myself which is not a story of goodness and generosity in others. I may well pass that little and go on.

When we were settled at home again, Ada and I had many conversations with my guardian of which Richard was the theme. My dear girl was deeply grieved that he (Richard) should do their kind cousin so much wrong, but she (girl) was so faithful to Richard that she (girl) could not bear to blame him (Richard) even for that. My guardian was assured of it, and never coupled his (Richard) name with a word of reproof.

``Rick is mistaken, my dear,'' (he)
he (Richard) would say to her (girl).
``Well, well! We have all been mistaken over and over again. We must trust to you and time to set him (Rick) right.'' (he)

We knew afterwards what we suspected then, that he (Richard) did not trust to time until he (Richard) had often tried to open Richard's eyes. That he (Richard) had written to him (Richard), gone to him (Richard), talked with him (Richard), tried every gentle and persuasive art his (Richard) kindness could devise. Our poor devoted Richard was deaf and blind to all. If he (Richard) were wrong, he (Richard) would make amends when the Chancery suit was over. If he (Richard) were groping in the dark, he (Richard) could not do better than do his (Richard) utmost to clear away those clouds in which so much was confused and obscured. Suspicion and misunderstanding were the fault of the suit? Then let him (Richard) work the suit out and come through it to his (Richard) right mind. This was his (Richard) unvarying reply. Jarndyce and Jarndyce had obtained such possession of his (Jarndyce) whole nature that it was impossible to place any consideration before him (Jarndyce) which he (Jarndyce) did not, with a distorted kind of reason, make a new argument in favour of his (Jarndyce) doing what he (Jarndyce) did.

``So that it is even more mischievous,'' (guardian)
said my guardian once to me,
``to remonstrate with the poor dear fellow than to leave him (Rick) alone.'' (me)

I took one of these opportunities of mentioning my doubts of Mr. Skimpole as a good adviser for Richard.

``Adviser!'' (guardian)
returned my guardian, laughing,
``My dear, who would advise with Skimpole?'' (guardian)

``Encourager would perhaps have been a better word,'' (I.)
said I.

``Encourager!'' (I.)
returned my guardian again.
``Who could be encouraged by Skimpole?'' (unknown)

``Not Richard?'' (I)
I asked.

``No,'' (he)
he (Richard) replied.
``Such an unworldly, uncalculating, gossamer creature is a relief to him (Richard) and an amusement. But as to advising or encouraging or occupying a serious station towards anybody or anything, it is simply not to be thought of in such a child as Skimpole.'' (unknown)

``Pray, cousin John,'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)
said Ada, who had just joined us and now looked over my shoulder,
``what made him (John) such a child?'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)

``What made him (John) such a child?'' (guardian)
inquired my guardian, rubbing his (Richard) head, a little at a loss.

``Yes, cousin John.'' (unknown)

``Why,'' (he)
he (Richard) slowly replied, roughening his (Richard) head more and more,
``he (John) is all sentiment, and--and susceptibility, and--and sensibility, and--and imagination. And these qualities are not regulated in him (John), somehow. I suppose the people who admired him (John) for them in his (John) youth attached too much importance to them and too little to any training that would have balanced and adjusted them, and so he (John) became what he (John) is. Hey?'' (he)
said my guardian, stopping short and looking at us hopefully.
``What do you think, you two?'' (Ada)

Ada, glancing at me, said she (Ada) thought it was a pity he (Richard) should be an expense to Richard.

``So it is, so it is,'' (guardian)
returned my guardian hurriedly.
``That must not be. We must arrange that. I must prevent it. That will never do.'' (I)

And I said I thought it was to be regretted that he (Richard) had ever introduced Richard to Mr. Vholes for a present of five pounds.

``Did he (John)?'' (guardian)
said my guardian with a passing shade of vexation on his (Vholes) face.
``But there you have the man. There you have the man! There is nothing mercenary in that with him (man). He (man) has no idea of the value of money. He (man) introduces Rick, and then he (man) is good friends with Mr. Vholes and borrows five pounds of him (Vholes). He (Vholes) means nothing by it and thinks nothing of it. He (Vholes) told you himself, I'll be bound, my dear?'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes!'' (I.)
said I.

``Exactly!'' (I.)
cried my guardian, quite triumphant.
``There you have the man! If he (man) had meant any harm by it or was conscious of any harm in it, he (man) wouldn't tell it. He (man) tells it as he (man) does it in mere simplicity. But you shall see him (man) in his (man) own home, and then you'll understand him (man) better. We must pay a visit to Harold Skimpole and caution him (Skimpole) on these points. Lord bless you, my dears, an infant, an infant!'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

In pursuance of this plan, we went into London on an early day and presented ourselves at Mr. Skimpole's door.

He (Skimpole) lived in a place called the Polygon, in Somers Town, where there were at that time a number of poor Spanish refugees walking about in cloaks, smoking little paper cigars. Whether he (Skimpole) was a better tenant than one might have supposed, in consequence of his (Skimpole) friend Somebody always paying his (Skimpole) rent at last, or whether his (Skimpole) inaptitude for business rendered it particularly difficult to turn him (Skimpole) out, I don't know; but he (Skimpole) had occupied the same house some years. It was in a state of dilapidation quite equal to our expectation. Two or three of the area railings were gone, the water-butt was broken, the knocker was loose, the bell-handle had been pulled off a long time to judge from the rusty state of the wire, and dirty footprints on the steps were the only signs of its being inhabited.

A slatternly full-blown girl who seemed to be bursting out at the rents in her (girl) gown and the cracks in her (girl) shoes like an over-ripe berry answered our knock by opening the door a very little way and stopping up the gap with her (girl) figure. As she (girl) knew Mr. Jarndyce -LRB-indeed Ada and I both thought that she (Ada) evidently associated him (Jarndyce) with the receipt of her (Ada) wages-RRB-, she (Ada) immediately relented and allowed us to pass in. The lock of the door being in a disabled condition, she (Ada) then applied herself to securing it with the chain, which was not in good action either, and said would we go upstairs?

We went upstairs to the first floor, still seeing no other furniture than the dirty footprints. Mr. Jarndyce without further ceremony entered a room there, and we followed. It was dingy enough and not at all clean, but furnished with an odd kind of shabby luxury, with a large footstool, a sofa, and plenty of cushions, an easy-chair, and plenty of pillows, a piano, books, drawing materials, music, newspapers, and a few sketches and pictures. A broken pane of glass in one of the dirty windows was papered and wafered over, but there was a little plate of hothouse nectarines on the table, and there was another of grapes, and another of sponge-cakes, and there was a bottle of light wine. Mr. Skimpole himself reclined upon the sofa in a dressing-gown, drinking some fragrant coffee from an old china cup--it was then about mid-day--and looking at a collection of wallflowers in the balcony.

He (Skimpole) was not in the least disconcerted by our appearance, but rose and received us in his (Skimpole) usual airy manner.

``Here I am, you see!'' (he)
he (Skimpole) said when we were seated, not without some little difficulty, the greater part of the chairs being broken.
``Here I am! This is my frugal breakfast. Some men want legs of beef and mutton for breakfast; I don't. Give me my peach, my cup of coffee, and my claret; I am content. I don't want them for themselves, but they remind me of the sun. There's nothing solar about legs of beef and mutton. Mere animal satisfaction!'' (unknown)

``This is our friend's consulting-room -LRB-or would be, if he (friend) ever prescribed-RRB-, his (friend) sanctum, his (friend) studio,'' (guardian)
said my guardian to us.

``Yes,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole, turning his (Skimpole) bright face about,
``this is the bird's cage. This is where the bird lives and sings. They pluck his (friend) feathers now and then and clip his (friend) wings, but he (friend) sings, he (friend) sings!'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

He (Skimpole) handed us the grapes, repeating in his (Skimpole) radiant way,

``He (friend) sings! Not an ambitious note, but still he (friend) sings.'' (He)

``These are very fine,'' (guardian)
said my guardian.
``A present?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (he)
he (Skimpole) answered. ``No! Some amiable gardener sells them. His (gardener) man wanted to know, when he (gardener) brought them last evening, whether he (gardener) should wait for the money. ``Really, my friend,'' I said, ``I think not--if your time is of any value to you.
'' I suppose it was, for he (Skimpole) went away.'' (I)

My guardian looked at us with a smile, as though he (Skimpole) asked us,

``Is it possible to be worldly with this baby?'' (he)

``This is a day,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole, gaily taking a little claret in a tumbler,
``that will ever be remembered here. We shall call it Saint Clare and Saint Summerson day. You must see my daughters. I have a blue-eyed daughter who is my Beauty daughter, I have a Sentiment daughter, and I have a Comedy daughter. You must see them all. They'll be enchanted.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

He (Skimpole) was going to summon them when my guardian interposed and asked him (Skimpole) to pause a moment, as he (Skimpole) wished to say a word to him (Skimpole) first.

``My dear Jarndyce,'' (he)
he (Skimpole) cheerfully replied, going back to his (Skimpole) sofa, ``as many moments as you please. Time is no object here. We never know what o'clock it is, and we never care. Not the way to get on in life, you'll tell me? Certainly. But we DON
``T get on in life. We don't pretend to do it.'' (guardian)

My guardian looked at us again, plainly saying,

``You hear him (Jarndyce)?'' (guardian)

``Now, Harold,'' (he)
he (Skimpole) began,
``the word I have to say relates to Rick.'' (he)

``The dearest friend I have!'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
returned Mr. Skimpole cordially.
``I suppose he (friend) ought not to be my dearest friend, as he (friend) is not on terms with you. But he (friend) is, I can't help it; he (friend) is full of youthful poetry, and I love him (friend). If you don't like it, I can't help it. I love him (friend).'' (he)

The engaging frankness with which he (Skimpole) made this declaration really had a disinterested appearance and captivated my guardian, if not, for the moment, Ada too.

``You are welcome to love him (friend) as much as you like,'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)
returned Mr. Jarndyce,
``but we must save his (friend) pocket, Harold.'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)

``Oh!'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole.
``His (friend) pocket? Now you are coming to what I don't understand.'' (he)
Taking a little more claret and dipping one of the cakes in it, he (Skimpole) shook his (Skimpole) head and smiled at Ada and me with an ingenuous foreboding that he (Skimpole) never could be made to understand.

``If you go with him (friend) here or there,'' (guardian)
said my guardian plainly,
``you must not let him (friend) pay for both.'' (guardian)

``My dear Jarndyce,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
returned Mr. Skimpole, his (Skimpole) genial face irradiated by the comicality of this idea,
``what am I to do? If he (Jarndyce) takes me anywhere, I must go. And how can I pay? I never have any money. If I had any money, I don't know anything about it. Suppose I say to a man, how much? Suppose the man says to me seven and sixpence? I know nothing about seven and sixpence. It is impossible for me to pursue the subject with any consideration for the man. I don't go about asking busy people what seven and sixpence is in Moorish--which I don't understand. Why should I go about asking them what seven and sixpence is in Money--which I don't understand?'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

``Well,'' (guardian)
said my guardian, by no means displeased with this artless reply,
``if you come to any kind of journeying with Rick, you must borrow the money of me -LRB-never breathing the least allusion to that circumstance-RRB-, and leave the calculation to him (Rick).'' (guardian)

``My dear Jarndyce,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
returned Mr. Skimpole,
``I will do anything to give you pleasure, but it seems an idle form--a superstition. Besides, I give you my word, Miss Clare and my dear Miss Summerson, I thought Mr. Carstone was immensely rich. I thought he (Carstone) had only to make over something, or to sign a bond, or a draft, or a cheque, or a bill, or to put something on a file somewhere, to bring down a shower of money.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

``Indeed it is not so, sir,'' (Ada)
said Ada.
``He (Carstone) is poor.'' (unknown)

``No, really?'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
returned Mr. Skimpole with his (Skimpole) bright smile. ``You surprise me.

``And not being the richer for trusting in a rotten reed,'' (guardian)
said my guardian, laying his (Skimpole) hand emphatically on the sleeve of Mr. Skimpole's dressing-gown,
``be you very careful not to encourage him (Carstone) in that reliance, Harold.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

``My dear good friend,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
returned Mr. Skimpole,
``and my dear Miss Simmerson, and my dear Miss Clare, how can I do that? It's business, and I don't know business. It is he (friend) who encourages me. He (friend) emerges from great feats of business, presents the brightest prospects before me as their result, and calls upon me to admire them. I do admire them--as bright prospects. But I know no more about them, and I tell him (friend) so.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

The helpless kind of candour with which he (Skimpole) presented this before us, the light-hearted manner in which he (Skimpole) was amused by his (Skimpole) innocence, the fantastic way in which he (Skimpole) took himself under his (Skimpole) own protection and argued about that curious person, combined with the delightful ease of everything he (Skimpole) said exactly to make out my guardian's case. The more I saw of him (Skimpole), the more unlikely it seemed to me, when he (Skimpole) was present, that he (Skimpole) could design, conceal, or influence anything; and yet the less likely that appeared when he (Skimpole) was not present, and the less agreeable it was to think of his (Skimpole) having anything to do with any one for whom I cared.

Hearing that his (Skimpole) examination -LRB-as he (Skimpole) called it-RRB- was now over, Mr. Skimpole left the room with a radiant face to fetch his (Skimpole) daughters -LRB-his (Skimpole) sons had run away at various times-RRB-, leaving my guardian quite delighted by the manner in which he (Skimpole) had vindicated his (Skimpole) childish character. He (Skimpole) soon came back, bringing with him (Skimpole) the three young ladies and Mrs. Skimpole, who had once been a beauty but was now a delicate high-nosed invalid suffering under a complication of disorders.

``This,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole,
``is my Beauty daughter, Arethusa--plays and sings odds and ends like her (daughter) father. This is my Sentiment daughter, Laura--plays a little but don't sing. This is my Comedy daughter, Kitty--sings a little but don't play. We all draw a little and compose a little, and none of us have any idea of time or money.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

Mrs. Skimpole sighed, I thought, as if she (Skimpole) would have been glad to strike out this item in the family attainments. I also thought that she (Skimpole) rather impressed her (Skimpole) sigh upon my guardian and that she (Skimpole) took every opportunity of throwing in another.

``It is pleasant,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole, turning his (Skimpole) sprightly eyes from one to the other of us,
``and it is whimsically interesting to trace peculiarities in families. In this family we are all children, and I am the youngest.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

The daughters, who appeared to be very fond of him (Skimpole), were amused by this droll fact, particularly the Comedy daughter.

``My dears, it is true,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole,
``is it not? So it is, and so it must be, because like the dogs in the hymn, `it is our nature to.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
Now, here is Miss Summerson with a fine administrative capacity and a knowledge of details perfectly surprising. It will sound very strange in Miss Summerson's ears, I dare say, that we know nothing about chops in this house. But we don't, not the least. We can't cook anything whatever. A needle and thread we don't know how to use. We admire the people who possess the practical wisdom we want, but we don't quarrel with them. Then why should they quarrel with us? Live and let live, we say to them. Live upon your practical wisdom, and let us live upon you!''

He (I) laughed, but as usual seemed quite candid and really to mean what he (I) said.

``We have sympathy, my roses,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole,
``sympathy for everything. Have we not?'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

``Oh, yes, papa!'' (the daughters)
cried the three daughters.

``In fact, that is our family department,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole,
``in this hurly-burly of life. We are capable of looking on and of being interested, and we DO look on, and we ARE interested. What more can we do? Here is my Beauty daughter, married these three years. Now I dare say her (daughter) marrying another child, and having two more, was all wrong in point of political economy, but it was very agreeable. We had our little festivities on those occasions and exchanged social ideas. She (daughter) brought her (daughter) young husband home one day, and they and their young fledglings have their nest upstairs. I dare say at some time or other Sentiment and Comedy will bring THEIR husbands home and have THEIR nests upstairs too. So we get on, we don't know how, but somehow.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

She (We) looked very young indeed to be the mother of two children, and I could not help pitying both her (We) and them. It was evident that the three daughters had grown up as they could and had had just as little haphazard instruction as qualified them to be their father's playthings in his (father) idlest hours. His (father) pictorial tastes were consulted, I observed, in their respective styles of wearing their hair, the Beauty daughter being in the classic manner, the Sentiment daughter luxuriant and flowing, and the Comedy daughter in the arch style, with a good deal of sprightly forehead, and vivacious little curls dotted about the corners of her (daughter) eyes. They were dressed to correspond, though in a most untidy and negligent way.

Ada and I conversed with these young ladies and found them wonderfully like their father. In the meanwhile Mr. Jarndyce -LRB-who had been rubbing his (Jarndyce) head to a great extent, and hinted at a change in the wind-RRB- talked with Mrs. Skimpole in a corner, where we could not help hearing the chink of money. Mr. Skimpole had previously volunteered to go home with us and had withdrawn to dress himself for the purpose.

``My roses,'' (he)
he (Skimpole) said when he (Skimpole) came back,
``take care of mama. She (mama) is poorly to-day. By going home with Mr. Jarndyce for a day or two, I shall hear the larks sing and preserve my amiability. It has been tried, you know, and would be tried again if I remained at home.'' (he)

``That bad man!'' (the Comedy daughter)
said the Comedy daughter.

``At the very time when he (man) knew papa was lying ill by his (man) wallflowers, looking at the blue sky,'' (Laura)
Laura complained.

``And when the smell of hay was in the air!'' (Arethusa)
said Arethusa.

``It showed a want of poetry in the man,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
Mr. Skimpole assented, but with perfect good humour.
``It was coarse. There was an absence of the finer touches of humanity in it! My daughters have taken great offence,'' (he)
he (Skimpole) explained to us,
``at an honest man--'' (he)

``Not honest, papa. Impossible!'' (he)
they all three protested.

``At a rough kind of fellow--a sort of human hedgehog rolled up,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole, ``who is a baker in this neighbourhood and from whom we borrowed a couple of arm-chairs. We wanted a couple of arm-chairs, and we hadn't got them, and therefore of course we looked to a man who HAD got them, to lend them. Well! This morose person lent them, and we wore them out. When they were worn out, he (man) wanted them back. He (man) had them back. He (man) was contented, you will say. Not at all. He (man) objected to their being worn. I reasoned with him (man), and pointed out his (man) mistake. I said, ``Can you, at your time of life, be so headstrong, my friend, as to persist that an arm-chair is a thing to put upon a shelf and look at? That it is an object to contemplate, to survey from a distance, to consider from a point of sight? Don't you KNOW that these arm-chairs were borrowed to be sat upon?'' He (Skimpole) was unreasonable and unpersuadable and used intemperate language. Being as patient as I am at this minute, I addressed another appeal to him (Skimpole). I said, ``Now, my good man, however our business capacities may vary, we are all children of one great mother, Nature. On this blooming summer morning here you see me' -LRB-I was on the sofa-RRB- `with flowers before me, fruit upon the table, the cloudless sky above me, the air full of fragrance, contemplating Nature. I entreat you, by our common brotherhood, not to interpose between me and a subject so sublime, the absurd figure of an angry baker!
'' But he (Skimpole) did,'' (an baker)
said Mr. Skimpole, raising his (Skimpole) laughing eyes in playful astonishment;
``he (baker) did interpose that ridiculous figure, and he (baker) does, and he (baker) will again. And therefore I am very glad to get out of his (baker) way and to go home with my friend Jarndyce.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

It seemed to escape his (Skimpole) consideration that Mrs. Skimpole and the daughters remained behind to encounter the baker, but this was so old a story to all of them that it had become a matter of course. He (Skimpole) took leave of his (Skimpole) family with a tenderness as airy and graceful as any other aspect in which he (Skimpole) showed himself and rode away with us in perfect harmony of mind. We had an opportunity of seeing through some open doors, as we went downstairs, that his (Skimpole) own apartment was a palace to the rest of the house.

I could have no anticipation, and I had none, that something very startling to me at the moment, and ever memorable to me in what ensued from it, was to happen before this day was out. Our guest was in such spirits on the way home that I could do nothing but listen to him (guest) and wonder at him (guest); nor was I alone in this, for Ada yielded to the same fascination. As to my guardian, the wind, which had threatened to become fixed in the east when we left Somers Town, veered completely round before we were a couple of miles from it.

Whether of questionable childishness or not in any other matters, Mr. Skimpole had a child's enjoyment of change and bright weather. In no way wearied by his (Skimpole) sallies on the road, he (Skimpole) was in the drawing-room before any of us; and I heard him (Skimpole) at the piano while I was yet looking after my housekeeping, singing refrains of barcaroles and drinking songs, Italian and German, by the score.

We were all assembled shortly before dinner, and he (Skimpole) was still at the piano idly picking out in his (Skimpole) luxurious way little strains of music, and talking between whiles of finishing some sketches of the ruined old Verulam wall to-morrow, which he (Skimpole) had begun a year or two ago and had got tired of, when a card was brought in and my guardian read aloud in a surprised voice,

``Sir Leicester Dedlock!'' (guardian)

The visitor was in the room while it was yet turning round with me and before I had the power to stir. If I had had it, I should have hurried away. I had not even the presence of mind, in my giddiness, to retire to Ada in the window, or to see the window, or to know where it was. I heard my name and found that my guardian was presenting me before I could move to a chair.

``Pray be seated, Sir Leicester.'' (unknown)

``Mr. Jarndyce,'' (he)
said Sir Leicester in reply as he (visitor) bowed and seated himself,
``I do myself the honour of calling here--'' (he)

``You do ME the honour, Sir Leicester.'' (he)

``Thank you--of calling here on my road from Lincolnshire to express my regret that any cause of complaint, however strong, that I may have against a gentleman who--who is known to you and has been your host, and to whom therefore I will make no farther reference, should have prevented you, still more ladies under your escort and charge, from seeing whatever little there may be to gratify a polite and refined taste at my house, Chesney Wold.'' (unknown)

``You are exceedingly obliging, Sir Leicester, and on behalf of those ladies -LRB-who are present-RRB- and for myself, I thank you very much.'' (unknown)

``It is possible, Mr. Jarndyce, that the gentleman to whom, for the reasons I have mentioned, I refrain from making further allusion--it is possible, Mr. Jarndyce, that that gentleman may have done me the honour so far to misapprehend my character as to induce you to believe that you would not have been received by my local establishment in Lincolnshire with that urbanity, that courtesy, which its members are instructed to show to all ladies and gentlemen who present themselves at that house. I merely beg to observe, sir, that the fact is the reverse.'' (guardian)

My guardian delicately dismissed this remark without making any verbal answer.

``It has given me pain, Mr. Jarndyce,'' (unknown)
Sir Leicester weightily proceeded.
``I assure you, sir, it has given--me--pain--to learn from the housekeeper at Chesney Wold that a gentleman who was in your company in that part of the county, and who would appear to possess a cultivated taste for the fine arts, was likewise deterred by some such cause from examining the family pictures with that leisure, that attention, that care, which he (gentleman) might have desired to bestow upon them and which some of them might possibly have repaid.'' (he)
Here he (visitor) produced a card and read, with much gravity and a little trouble, through his (visitor) eye-glass,
``Mr. Hirrold--Herald--Harold--Skampling--Skumpling--I beg your pardon--Skimpole.'' (he)

``This is Mr. Harold Skimpole,'' (guardian)
said my guardian, evidently surprised.

``Oh!'' (unknown)
exclaimed Sir Leicester,
``I am happy to meet Mr. Skimpole and to have the opportunity of tendering my personal regrets. I hope, sir, that when you again find yourself in my part of the county, you will be under no similar sense of restraint.'' (unknown)

``You are very obliging, Sir Leicester Dedlock. So encouraged, I shall certainly give myself the pleasure and advantage of another visit to your beautiful house. The owners of such places as Chesney Wold,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole with his (Skimpole) usual happy and easy air,
``are public benefactors. They are good enough to maintain a number of delightful objects for the admiration and pleasure of us poor men; and not to reap all the admiration and pleasure that they yield is to be ungrateful to our benefactors.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

Sir Leicester seemed to approve of this sentiment highly.

``An artist, sir?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
returned Mr. Skimpole.
``A perfectly idle man. A mere amateur.'' (unknown)

Sir Leicester seemed to approve of this even more. He (Skimpole) hoped he (Skimpole) might have the good fortune to be at Chesney Wold when Mr. Skimpole next came down into Lincolnshire. Mr. Skimpole professed himself much flattered and honoured.

``Mr. Skimpole mentioned,'' (guardian)
pursued Sir Leicester, addressing himself again to my guardian,
``mentioned to the housekeeper, who, as he (Skimpole) may have observed, is an old and attached retainer of the family--'' (guardian)

-LRB-

``That is, when I walked through the house the other day, on the occasion of my going down to visit Miss Summerson and Miss Clare,'' (guardian)
Mr. Skimpole airily explained to us.-RRB-

''--That the friend with whom he (Skimpole) had formerly been staying there was Mr. Jarndyce.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
Sir Leicester bowed to the bearer of that name.
``And hence I became aware of the circumstance for which I have professed my regret. That this should have occurred to any gentleman, Mr. Jarndyce, but especially a gentleman formerly known to Lady Dedlock, and indeed claiming some distant connexion with her (Dedlock), and for whom -LRB-as I learn from my Lady herself-RRB- she (Lady) entertains a high respect, does, I assure you, give--me--pain.'' (unknown)

``Pray say no more about it, Sir Leicester,'' (guardian)
returned my guardian.
``I am very sensible, as I am sure we all are, of your consideration. Indeed the mistake was mine, and I ought to apologize for it.'' (I)
