He (Bagnet) has bought two specimens of poultry, which, if there be any truth in adages, were certainly not caught with chaff, to be prepared for the spit; he (Bagnet) has amazed and rejoiced the family by their unlooked-for production; he (Bagnet) is himself directing the roasting of the poultry; and Mrs. Bagnet, with her (Bagnet) wholesome brown fingers itching to prevent what she (Bagnet) sees going wrong, sits in her (Bagnet) gown of ceremony, an honoured guest.

Quebec and Malta lay the cloth for dinner, while Woolwich, serving, as beseems him (guest), under his (guest) father, keeps the fowls revolving. To these young scullions Mrs. Bagnet occasionally imparts a wink, or a shake of the head, or a crooked face, as they made mistakes.

``At half after one.'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
Says Mr. Bagnet.
``To the minute. They'll be done.'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

Mrs. Bagnet, with anguish, beholds one of them at a standstill before the fire and beginning to burn.

``You shall have a dinner, old girl,'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
says Mr. Bagnet.
``Fit for a queen.'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

Mrs. Bagnet shows her (Bagnet) white teeth cheerfully, but to the perception of her (Bagnet) son, betrays so much uneasiness of spirit that he (Bagnet) is impelled by the dictates of affection to ask her (Bagnet), with his (Bagnet) eyes, what is the matter, thus standing, with his (Bagnet) eyes wide open, more oblivious of the fowls than before, and not affording the least hope of a return to consciousness. Fortunately his (Bagnet) elder sister perceives the cause of the agitation in Mrs. Bagnet's breast and with an admonitory poke recalls him (Bagnet). The stopped fowls going round again, Mrs. Bagnet closes her (Bagnet) eyes in the intensity of her (Bagnet) relief.

``George will look us up,'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
says Mr. Bagnet.
``At half after four. To the moment. How many years, old girl. Has George looked us up. This afternoon?'' (unknown)

``Ah, Lignum, Lignum, as many as make an old woman of a young one, I begin to think. Just about that, and no less,'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
returns Mrs. Bagnet, laughing and shaking her (Bagnet) head.

``Old girl,'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
says Mr. Bagnet,
``never mind. You'd be as young as ever you was. If you wasn't younger. Which you are. As everybody knows.'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)

Quebec and Malta here exclaim, with clapping of hands, that Bluffy is sure to bring mother something, and begin to speculate on what it will be.

``Do you know, Lignum,'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
says Mrs. Bagnet, casting a glance on the table-cloth, and winking
``salt!'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
at Malta with her (Bagnet) right eye, and shaking the pepper away from Quebec with her (Bagnet) head, ``I begin to think George is in the roving way again.

``George,'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
returns Mr. Bagnet,
``will never desert. And leave his (George) old comrade. In the lurch. Don't be afraid of it.'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)

``No, Lignum. No. I don't say he (George) will. I don't think he (George) will. But if he (George) could get over this money trouble of his (George), I believe he (George) would be off.'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)

Mr. Bagnet asks why.

``Well,'' (wife)
returns his (Bagnet) wife, considering,
``George seems to me to be getting not a little impatient and restless. I don't say but what he (George)'s as free as ever. Of course he (George) must be free or he (George) wouldn't be George, but he (George) smarts and seems put out.'' (wife)

``He (George)'s extra-drilled,'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
says Mr. Bagnet.
``By a lawyer. Who would put the devil out.'' (unknown)

``There's something in that,'' (wife)
his (Bagnet) wife assents;
``but so it is, Lignum.'' (wife)

Further conversation is prevented, for the time, by the necessity under which Mr. Bagnet finds himself of directing the whole force of his (Bagnet) mind to the dinner, which is a little endangered by the dry humour of the fowls in not yielding any gravy, and also by the made gravy acquiring no flavour and turning out of a flaxen complexion. With a similar perverseness, the potatoes crumble off forks in the process of peeling, upheaving from their centres in every direction, as if they were subject to earthquakes. The legs of the fowls, too, are longer than could be desired, and extremely scaly. Overcoming these disadvantages to the best of his (Bagnet) ability, Mr. Bagnet at last dishes and they sit down at table, Mrs. Bagnet occupying the guest's place at his (Bagnet) right hand.

It is well for the old girl that she (Bagnet) has but one birthday in a year, for two such indulgences in poultry might be injurious. Every kind of finer tendon and ligament that is in the nature of poultry to possess is developed in these specimens in the singular form of guitar-strings. Their limbs appear to have struck roots into their breasts and bodies, as aged trees strike roots into the earth. Their legs are so hard as to encourage the idea that they must have devoted the greater part of their long and arduous lives to pedestrian exercises and the walking of matches. But Mr. Bagnet, unconscious of these little defects, sets his (Bagnet) heart on Mrs. Bagnet eating a most severe quantity of the delicacies before her (Bagnet); and as that good old girl would not cause him (Bagnet) a moment's disappointment on any day, least of all on such a day, for any consideration, she (Bagnet) imperils her (Bagnet) digestion fearfully. How young Woolwich cleans the drum-sticks without being of ostrich descent, his (Bagnet) anxious mother is at a loss to understand.

The old girl has another trial to undergo after the conclusion of the repast in sitting in state to see the room cleared, the hearth swept, and the dinner-service washed up and polished in the backyard. The great delight and energy with which the two young ladies apply themselves to these duties, turning up their skirts in imitation of their mother and skating in and out on little scaffolds of pattens, inspire the highest hopes for the future, but some anxiety for the present. The same causes lead to confusion of tongues, a clattering of crockery, a rattling of tin mugs, a whisking of brooms, and an expenditure of water, all in excess, while the saturation of the young ladies themselves is almost too moving a spectacle for Mrs. Bagnet to look upon with the calmness proper to her (Bagnet) position. At last the various cleansing processes are triumphantly completed; Quebec and Malta appear in fresh attire, smiling and dry; pipes, tobacco, and something to drink are placed upon the table; and the old girl enjoys the first peace of mind she (girl) ever knows on the day of this delightful entertainment.

When Mr. Bagnet takes his (Bagnet) usual seat, the hands of the clock are very near to half-past four; as they mark it accurately, Mr. Bagnet announces,

``George! Military time.'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)

It is George, and he (Bagnet) has hearty congratulations for the old girl -LRB-whom he (Bagnet) kisses on the great occasion-RRB-, and for the children, and for Mr. Bagnet.

``Happy returns to all!'' (Mr. George/George)
says Mr. George.

``But, George, old man!'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
cries Mrs. Bagnet, looking at him (George) curiously.
``What's come to you?'' (unknown)

``Come to me?'' (unknown)

``Ah! You are so white, George--for you--and look so shocked. Now don't he (George), Lignum?'' (unknown)

``George,'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
says Mr. Bagnet,
``tell the old girl. What's the matter.'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)

``I didn't know I looked white,'' (the trooper)
says the trooper, passing his (Bagnet) hand over his (Bagnet) brow,
``and I didn't know I looked shocked, and I'm sorry I do. But the truth is, that boy who was taken in at my place died yesterday afternoon, and it has rather knocked me over.'' (the trooper)

``Poor creetur!'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
says Mrs. Bagnet with a mother's pity.
``Is he (boy) gone? Dear, dear!'' (unknown)

``I didn't mean to say anything about it, for it's not birthday talk, but you have got it out of me, you see, before I sit down. I should have roused up in a minute,'' (the trooper)
says the trooper, making himself speak more gaily,
``but you're so quick, Mrs. Bagnet.'' (the trooper)

``You're right. The old girl,'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
says Mr. Bagnet.
``Is as quick. As powder.'' (unknown)

``And what's more, she (girl)'s the subject of the day, and we'll stick to her (girl),'' (Mr. George/George)
cries Mr. George.
``See here, I have brought a little brooch along with me. It's a poor thing, you know, but it's a keepsake. That's all the good it is, Mrs. Bagnet.'' (Mr. George/George)

Mr. George produces his (George) present, which is greeted with admiring leapings and clappings by the young family, and with a species of reverential admiration by Mr. Bagnet.

``Old girl,'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
says Mr. Bagnet.
``Tell him (You) my opinion of it.'' (unknown)

``Why, it's a wonder, George!'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
Mrs. Bagnet exclaims.
``It's the beautifullest thing that ever was seen!'' (unknown)

``Good!'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
says Mr. Bagnet.
``My opinion.'' (unknown)

``It's so pretty, George,'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
cries Mrs. Bagnet, turning it on all sides and holding it out at arm's length,
``that it seems too choice for me.'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

``Bad!'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
says Mr. Bagnet.
``Not my opinion.'' (unknown)

``But whatever it is, a hundred thousand thanks, old fellow,'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
says Mrs. Bagnet, her (Bagnet) eyes sparkling with pleasure and her (Bagnet) hand stretched out to him (Bagnet);
``and though I have been a crossgrained soldier's wife to you sometimes, George, we are as strong friends, I am sure, in reality, as ever can be. Now you shall fasten it on yourself, for good luck, if you will, George.'' (him)

The children close up to see it done, and Mr. Bagnet looks over young Woolwich's head to see it done with an interest so maturely wooden, yet pleasantly childish, that Mrs. Bagnet cannot help laughing in her (Bagnet) airy way and saying,

``Oh, Lignum, Lignum, what a precious old chap you are!'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
But the trooper fails to fasten the brooch. His (trooper) hand shakes, he (trooper) is nervous, and it falls off.
``Would any one believe this?'' (he)
says he (trooper), catching it as it drops and looking round.
``I am so out of sorts that I bungle at an easy job like this!'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

Mrs. Bagnet concludes that for such a case there is no remedy like a pipe, and fastening the brooch herself in a twinkling, causes the trooper to be inducted into his (trooper) usual snug place and the pipes to be got into action.

``If that don't bring you round, George,'' (she)
says she (Bagnet),
``just throw your eye across here at your present now and then, and the two together MUST do it.'' (she)

``You ought to do it of yourself,'' (Mr. George/George)
George answers; ``I know that very well, Mrs. Bagnet. I'll tell you how, one way and another, the blues have got to be too many for me. Here was this poor lad.
``Twas dull work to see him (lad) dying as he (lad) did, and not be able to help him (lad).'' (unknown)

``What do you mean, George? You did help him (George). You took him (George) under your roof.'' (unknown)

``I helped him (George) so far, but that's little. I mean, Mrs. Bagnet, there he (George) was, dying without ever having been taught much more than to know his (George) right hand from his (George) left. And he (George) was too far gone to be helped out of that.'' (unknown)

``Ah, poor creetur!'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
says Mrs. Bagnet.

``Then,'' (the trooper)
says the trooper, not yet lighting his (trooper) pipe, and passing his (trooper) heavy hand over his (trooper) hair,
``that brought up Gridley in a man's mind. His (Gridley) was a bad case too, in a different way. Then the two got mixed up in a man's mind with a flinty old rascal who had to do with both. And to think of that rusty carbine, stock and barrel, standing up on end in his (rascal) corner, hard, indifferent, taking everything so evenly--it made flesh and blood tingle, I do assure you.'' (the trooper)

``My advice to you,'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
returns Mrs. Bagnet,
``is to light your pipe and tingle that way. It's wholesomer and comfortabler, and better for the health altogether.'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

``You're right,'' (the trooper)
says the trooper,
``and I'll do it.'' (the trooper)

So he (trooper) does it, though still with an indignant gravity that impresses the young Bagnets, and even causes Mr. Bagnet to defer the ceremony of drinking Mrs. Bagnet's health, always given by himself on these occasions in a speech of exemplary terseness. But the young ladies having composed what Mr. Bagnet is in the habit of calling

``the mixtur,'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
and George's pipe being now in a glow, Mr. Bagnet considers it his (Bagnet) duty to proceed to the toast of the evening. He (Bagnet) addresses the assembled company in the following terms.

``George. Woolwich. Quebec. Malta. This is her (your) birthday. Take a day's march. And you won't find such another. Here's towards her (your)!'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

The toast having been drunk with enthusiasm, Mrs. Bagnet returns thanks in a neat address of corresponding brevity. This model composition is limited to the three words

``And wishing yours!'' (the girl)
which the old girl follows up with a nod at everybody in succession and a well-regulated swig of the mixture. This she (girl) again follows up, on the present occasion, by the wholly unexpected exclamation,
``Here's a man!'' (she)

Here IS a man, much to the astonishment of the little company, looking in at the parlour-door. He (man) is a sharp-eyed man--a quick keen man--and he (man) takes in everybody's look at him (man), all at once, individually and collectively, in a manner that stamps him (man) a remarkable man.

``George,'' (the man nodding)
says the man, nodding,
``how do you find yourself?'' (the man nodding)

``Why, it's Bucket!'' (Mr. George/George)
cries Mr. George.

``Yes,'' (the man)
says the man, coming in and closing the door.
``I was going down the street here when I happened to stop and look in at the musical instruments in the shop-window--a friend of mine is in want of a second-hand wiolinceller of a good tone--and I saw a party enjoying themselves, and I thought it was you in the corner; I thought I couldn't be mistaken. How goes the world with you, George, at the present moment? Pretty smooth? And with you, ma'am? And with you, governor? And Lord,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket, opening his (Mr.) arms,
``here's children too! You may do anything with me if you only show me children. Give us a kiss, my pets. No occasion to inquire who YOUR father and mother is. Never saw such a likeness in my life!'' (Mr.)

Mr. Bucket, not unwelcome, has sat himself down next to Mr. George and taken Quebec and Malta on his (George) knees.

``You pretty dears,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket,
``give us another kiss; it's the only thing I'm greedy in. Lord bless you, how healthy you look! And what may be the ages of these two, ma'am? I should put 'em down at the figures of about eight and ten.'' (Mr.)

``You're very near, sir,'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
says Mrs. Bagnet.

``I generally am near,'' (Mr.)
returns Mr. Bucket,
``being so fond of children. A friend of mine has had nineteen of 'em, ma'am, all by one mother, and she (mother)'s still as fresh and rosy as the morning. Not so much so as yourself, but, upon my soul, she (mother) comes near you! And what do you call these, my darling?'' (Mr.)
pursues Mr. Bucket, pinching Malta's cheeks.
``These are peaches, these are. Bless your heart! And what do you think about father? Do you think father could recommend a second-hand wiolinceller of a good tone for Mr. Bucket's friend, my dear? My name's Bucket. Ain't that a funny name?'' (family)

These blandishments have entirely won the family heart. Mrs. Bagnet forgets the day to the extent of filling a pipe and a glass for Mr. Bucket and waiting upon him (Mr.) hospitably. She (Bagnet) would be glad to receive so pleasant a character under any circumstances, but she (Bagnet) tells him (character) that as a friend of George's she (Bagnet) is particularly glad to see him (George) this evening, for George has not been in his (George) usual spirits.

``Not in his (Bucket) usual spirits?'' (Mr.)
exclaims Mr. Bucket.
``Why, I never heard of such a thing! What's the matter, George? You don't intend to tell me you've been out of spirits. What should you be out of spirits for? You haven't got anything on your mind, you know.'' (unknown)

``Nothing particular,'' (the trooper)
returns the trooper.

``I should think not,'' (Mr.)
rejoins Mr. Bucket.
``What could you have on your mind, you know! And have these pets got anything on THEIR minds, eh? Not they, but they'll be upon the minds of some of the young fellows, some of these days, and make 'em precious low-spirited. I ain't much of a prophet, but I can tell you that, ma'am.'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

Mrs. Bagnet, quite charmed, hopes Mr. Bucket has a family of his (Bucket) own.

``There, ma'am!'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.
``Would you believe it? No, I haven't. My wife and a lodger constitute my family. Mrs. Bucket is as fond of children as myself and as wishful to have 'em, but no. So it is. Worldly goods are divided unequally, and man must not repine. What a very nice backyard, ma'am! Any way out of that yard, now?'' (unknown)

There is no way out of that yard.

``Ain't there really?'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.
``I should have thought there might have been. Well, I don't know as I ever saw a backyard that took my fancy more. Would you allow me to look at it? Thank you. No, I see there's no way out. But what a very good-proportioned yard it is!'' (Mr. Bucket)

Having cast his (Mr.) sharp eye all about it, Mr. Bucket returns to his (Bucket) chair next his (Bucket) friend Mr. George and pats Mr. George affectionately on the shoulder.

``How are your spirits now, George?'' (unknown)

``All right now,'' (the trooper)
returns the trooper.

``That's your sort!'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.
``Why should you ever have been otherwise? A man of your fine figure and constitution has no right to be out of spirits. That ain't a chest to be out of spirits, is it, ma'am? And you haven't got anything on your mind, you know, George; what could you have on your mind!'' (Mr.)

Somewhat harping on this phrase, considering the extent and variety of his (Mr.) conversational powers, Mr. Bucket twice or thrice repeats it to the pipe he (Mr.) lights, and with a listening face that is particularly his (Mr.) own. But the sun of his (Mr.) sociality soon recovers from this brief eclipse and shines again.

``And this is brother, is it, my dears?'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket, referring to Quebec and Malta for information on the subject of young Woolwich.
``And a nice brother he (brother) is--half-brother I mean to say. For he (brother)'s too old to be your boy, ma'am.'' (unknown)

``I can certify at all events that he (brother) is not anybody else's,'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
returns Mrs. Bagnet, laughing.

``Well, you do surprise me! Yet he (brother)'s like you, there's no denying. Lord, he (Lord)'s wonderfully like you! But about what you may call the brow, you know, THERE his (Lord) father comes out!'' (Mr.)
Mr. Bucket compares the faces with one eye shut up, while Mr. Bagnet smokes in stolid satisfaction.

This is an opportunity for Mrs. Bagnet to inform him (Bagnet) that the boy is George's godson.

``George's godson, is he (George)?'' (Mr.)
rejoins Mr. Bucket with extreme cordiality.
``I must shake hands over again with George's godson. Godfather and godson do credit to one another. And what do you intend to make of him (George), ma'am? Does he (George) show any turn for any musical instrument?'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)

Mr. Bagnet suddenly interposes,

``Plays the fife. Beautiful.'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)

``Would you believe it, governor,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket, struck by the coincidence, ``that when I was a boy I played the fife myself? Not in a scientific way, as I expect he (boy) does, but by ear. Lord bless you! ``British Grenadiers'--there's a tune to warm an Englishman up! COULD you give us
``British Grenadiers,'' (fellow)
my fine fellow?''

Nothing could be more acceptable to the little circle than this call upon young Woolwich, who immediately fetches his (Mr.) fife and performs the stirring melody, during which performance Mr. Bucket, much enlivened, beats time and never fails to come in sharp with the burden,

``British Gra-a-anadeers!'' (Mr.)
In short, he (Mr.) shows so much musical taste that Mr. Bagnet actually takes his (Bagnet) pipe from his (Bagnet) lips to express his (Bagnet) conviction that he (Bagnet) is a singer. Mr. Bucket receives the harmonious impeachment so modestly, confessing how that he (Mr.) did once chaunt a little, for the expression of the feelings of his (Mr.) own bosom, and with no presumptuous idea of entertaining his (Mr.) friends, that he (Mr.) is asked to sing. Not to be behindhand in the sociality of the evening, he (Mr.) complies and gives them
``Believe Me, if All Those Endearing Young Charms.'' (he)
This ballad, he (Mr.) informs Mrs. Bagnet, he (Mr.) considers to have been his (Mr.) most powerful ally in moving the heart of Mrs. Bucket when a maiden, and inducing her (Bagnet) to approach the altar--Mr. Bucket's own words are
``to come up to the scratch.'' (Mr. Bucket)

This sparkling stranger is such a new and agreeable feature in the evening that Mr. George, who testified no great emotions of pleasure on his (George) entrance, begins, in spite of himself, to be rather proud of him (George). He (George) is so friendly, is a man of so many resources, and so easy to get on with, that it is something to have made him (George) known there. Mr. Bagnet becomes, after another pipe, so sensible of the value of his (Bagnet) acquaintance that he (Bagnet) solicits the honour of his (Bagnet) company on the old girl's next birthday. If anything can more closely cement and consolidate the esteem which Mr. Bucket has formed for the family, it is the discovery of the nature of the occasion. He (Mr.) drinks to Mrs. Bagnet with a warmth approaching to rapture, engages himself for that day twelvemonth more than thankfully, makes a memorandum of the day in a large black pocket-book with a girdle to it, and breathes a hope that Mrs. Bucket and Mrs. Bagnet may before then become, in a manner, sisters. As he (Mr.) says himself, what is public life without private ties? He (Mr.) is in his (Mr.) humble way a public man, but it is not in that sphere that he (Mr.) finds happiness. No, it must be sought within the confines of domestic bliss.

It is natural, under these circumstances, that he (Mr.), in his (Mr.) turn, should remember the friend to whom he (Mr.) is indebted for so promising an acquaintance. And he (Mr.) does. He (Mr.) keeps very close to him (Mr.). Whatever the subject of the conversation, he (Mr.) keeps a tender eye upon him (Mr.). He (Mr.) waits to walk home with him (Mr.). He (Mr.) is interested in his (Mr.) very boots and observes even them attentively as Mr. George sits smoking cross-legged in the chimney-corner.

At length Mr. George rises to depart. At the same moment Mr. Bucket, with the secret sympathy of friendship, also rises. He (Mr.) dotes upon the children to the last and remembers the commission he (Mr.) has undertaken for an absent friend.

``Respecting that second-hand wiolinceller, governor--could you recommend me such a thing?'' (unknown)

``Scores,'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
says Mr. Bagnet.

``I am obliged to you,'' (Mr. Bucket)
returns Mr. Bucket, squeezing his (Bucket) hand.
``You're a friend in need. A good tone, mind you! My friend is a regular dab at it. Ecod, he (friend) saws away at Mozart and Handel and the rest of the big-wigs like a thorough workman. And you needn't,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket in a considerate and private voice,
``you needn't commit yourself to too low a figure, governor. I don't want to pay too large a price for my friend, but I want you to have your proper percentage and be remunerated for your loss of time. That is but fair. Every man must live, and ought to it.'' (Mr.)

Mr. Bagnet shakes his (Bagnet) head at the old girl to the effect that they have found a jewel of price.

``Suppose I was to give you a look in, say, at half arter ten to-morrow morning. Perhaps you could name the figures of a few wiolincellers of a good tone?'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.

Nothing easier. Mr. and Mrs. Bagnet both engage to have the requisite information ready and even hint to each other at the practicability of having a small stock collected there for approval.

``Thank you,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket,
``thank you. Good night, ma'am. Good night, governor. Good night, darlings. I am much obliged to you for one of the pleasantest evenings I ever spent in my life.'' (Mr.)

They, on the contrary, are much obliged to him (Mr.) for the pleasure he (Mr.) has given them in his (Mr.) company; and so they part with many expressions of goodwill on both sides.

``Now George, old boy,'' (Mr. Bucket)
says Mr. Bucket, taking his (Bucket) arm at the shop-door,
``come along!'' (Mr. Bucket)
As they go down the little street and the Bagnets pause for a minute looking after them, Mrs. Bagnet remarks to the worthy Lignum that Mr. Bucket
``almost clings to George like, and seems to be really fond of him (George).'' (Mr.)

The neighbouring streets being narrow and ill-paved, it is a little inconvenient to walk there two abreast and arm in arm. Mr. George therefore soon proposes to walk singly. But Mr. Bucket, who cannot make up his (Mr.) mind to relinquish his (Mr.) friendly hold, replies,

``Wait half a minute, George. I should wish to speak to you first.'' (Mr.)
Immediately afterwards, he (Mr.) twists him (Mr.) into a public-house and into a parlour, where he (Mr.) confronts him (Mr.) and claps his (Mr.) own back against the door.

``Now, George,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket,
``duty is duty, and friendship is friendship. I never want the two to clash if I can help it. I have endeavoured to make things pleasant to-night, and I put it to you whether I have done it or not. You must consider yourself in custody, George.'' (Mr.)

``Custody? What for?'' (the trooper thunderstruck)
returns the trooper, thunderstruck.

``Now, George,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket, urging a sensible view of the case upon him (Mr.) with his (Mr.) fat forefinger,
``duty, as you know very well, is one thing, and conversation is another. It's my duty to inform you that any observations you may make will be liable to be used against you. Therefore, George, be careful what you say. You don't happen to have heard of a murder?'' (him)

``Murder!'' (unknown)

``Now, George,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket, keeping his (Mr.) forefinger in an impressive state of action,
``bear in mind what I've said to you. I ask you nothing. You've been in low spirits this afternoon. I say, you don't happen to have heard of a murder?'' (Mr.)

``No. Where has there been a murder?'' (unknown)

``Now, George,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket,
``don't you go and commit yourself. I'm a-going to tell you what I want you for. There has been a murder in Lincoln's Inn Fields--gentleman of the name of Tulkinghorn. He (Lincoln) was shot last night. I want you for that.'' (Mr.)

The trooper sinks upon a seat behind him (Mr.), and great drops start out upon his (Mr.) forehead, and a deadly pallor overspreads his (Mr.) face.

``Bucket! It's not possible that Mr. Tulkinghorn has been killed and that you suspect ME?'' (unknown)

``George,'' (Mr. Bucket)
returns Mr. Bucket, keeping his (Bucket) forefinger going,
``it is certainly possible, because it's the case. This deed was done last night at ten o'clock. Now, you know where you were last night at ten o'clock, and you'll be able to prove it, no doubt.'' (Mr. Bucket)

``Last night! Last night?'' (repeats the trooper)
repeats the trooper thoughtfully. Then it flashes upon him (Bucket).
``Why, great heaven, I was there last night!'' (unknown)

``So I have understood, George,'' (Mr.)
returns Mr. Bucket with great deliberation.
``So I have understood. Likewise you've been very often there. You've been seen hanging about the place, and you've been heard more than once in a wrangle with him (George), and it's possible--I don't say it's certainly so, mind you, but it's possible--that he (George) may have been heard to call you a threatening, murdering, dangerous fellow.'' (trooper)

The trooper gasps as if he (Mr.) would admit it all if he (Mr.) could speak.

``Now, George,'' (Mr. Bucket)
continues Mr. Bucket, putting his (Bucket) hat upon the table with an air of business rather in the upholstery way than otherwise,
``my wish is, as it has been all the evening, to make things pleasant. I tell you plainly there's a reward out, of a hundred guineas, offered by Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet. You and me have always been pleasant together; but I have got a duty to discharge; and if that hundred guineas is to be made, it may as well be made by me as any other man. On all of which accounts, I should hope it was clear to you that I must have you, and that I'm damned if I don't have you. Am I to call in any assistance, or is the trick done?'' (Mr. Bucket)

Mr. George has recovered himself and stands up like a soldier.

``Come,'' (he)
he (George) says;
``I am ready.'' (he)

``George,'' (Mr. Bucket)
continues Mr. Bucket,
``wait a bit!'' (Mr. Bucket)
With his (Bucket) upholsterer manner, as if the trooper were a window to be fitted up, he (trooper) takes from his (trooper) pocket a pair of handcuffs.
``This is a serious charge, George, and such is my duty.'' (The trooper)

The trooper flushes angrily and hesitates a moment, but holds out his (trooper) two hands, clasped together, and says,

``There! Put them on!'' (The trooper)

Mr. Bucket adjusts them in a moment.

``How do you find them? Are they comfortable? If not, say so, for I wish to make things as pleasant as is consistent with my duty, and I've got another pair in my pocket.'' (he)
This remark he (Mr.) offers like a most respectable tradesman anxious to execute an order neatly and to the perfect satisfaction of his (Mr.) customer.
``They'll do as they are? Very well! Now, you see, George'' (he)
--he (Mr.) takes a cloak from a corner and begins adjusting it about the trooper's neck--
``I was mindful of your feelings when I come out, and brought this on purpose. There! Who's the wiser?'' (the trooper)

``Only I,'' (the trooper)
returns the trooper,
``but as I know it, do me one more good turn and pull my hat over my eyes.'' (the trooper)

``Really, though! Do you mean it? Ain't it a pity? It looks so.'' (unknown)

``I can't look chance men in the face with these things on,'' (Mr. George/George)
Mr. George hurriedly replies.
``Do, for God's sake, pull my hat forward.'' (Mr.)

So strongly entreated, Mr. Bucket complies, puts his (Mr.) own hat on, and conducts his (Mr.) prize into the streets, the trooper marching on as steadily as usual, though with his (trooper) head less erect, and Mr. Bucket steering him (Mr.) with his (Mr.) elbow over the crossings and up the turnings.

CHAPTER L

Esther's Narrative

It happened that when I came home from Deal I found a note from Caddy Jellyby -LRB-as we always continued to call her (Jellyby)-RRB-, informing me that her (Jellyby) health, which had been for some time very delicate, was worse and that she (Jellyby) would be more glad than she (Jellyby) could tell me if I would go to see her (Jellyby). It was a note of a few lines, written from the couch on which she (Jellyby) lay and enclosed to me in another from her (Jellyby) husband, in which he (husband) seconded her (Jellyby) entreaty with much solicitude. Caddy was now the mother, and I the godmother, of such a poor little baby--such a tiny old-faced mite, with a countenance that seemed to be scarcely anything but cap-border, and a little lean, long-fingered hand, always clenched under its chin. It would lie in this attitude all day, with its bright specks of eyes open, wondering -LRB-as I used to imagine-RRB- how it came to be so small and weak. Whenever it was moved it cried, but at all other times it was so patient that the sole desire of its life appeared to be to lie quiet and think. It had curious little dark veins in its face and curious little dark marks under its eyes like faint remembrances of poor Caddy's inky days, and altogether, to those who were not used to it, it was quite a piteous little sight.

But it was enough for Caddy that SHE was used to it. The projects with which she (its) beguiled her (its) illness, for little Esther's education, and little Esther's marriage, and even for her (Esther) own old age as the grandmother of little Esther's little Esthers, was so prettily expressive of devotion to this pride of her (Esther) life that I should be tempted to recall some of them but for the timely remembrance that I am getting on irregularly as it is.

To return to the letter. Caddy had a superstition about me which had been strengthening in her (Esther) mind ever since that night long ago when she (Esther) had lain asleep with her (Esther) head in my lap. She (Esther) almost--I think I must say quite--believed that I did her (Esther) good whenever I was near her (Esther). Now although this was such a fancy of the affectionate girl's that I am almost ashamed to mention it, still it might have all the force of a fact when she (girl) was really ill. Therefore I set off to Caddy, with my guardian's consent, post-haste; and she (girl) and Prince made so much of me that there never was anything like it.

Next day I went again to sit with her (girl), and next day I went again. It was a very easy journey, for I had only to rise a little earlier in the morning, and keep my accounts, and attend to housekeeping matters before leaving home.

But when I had made these three visits, my guardian said to me, on my return at night,

``Now, little woman, little woman, this will never do. Constant dropping will wear away a stone, and constant coaching will wear out a Dame Durden. We will go to London for a while and take possession of our old lodgings.'' (me)

``Not for me, dear guardian,'' (I)
said I,
``for I never feel tired,'' (I)
which was strictly true. I was only too happy to be in such request.

``For me then,'' (guardian)
returned my guardian,
``or for Ada, or for both of us. It is somebody's birthday to-morrow, I think.'' (guardian)

``Truly I think it is,'' (I)
said I, kissing my darling, who would be twenty-one to-morrow.

``Well,'' (guardian)
observed my guardian, half pleasantly, half seriously,
``that's a great occasion and will give my fair cousin some necessary business to transact in assertion of her (Ada) independence, and will make London a more convenient place for all of us. So to London we will go. That being settled, there is another thing--how have you left Caddy?'' (guardian)

``Very unwell, guardian. I fear it will be some time before she (Ada) regains her (Ada) health and strength.'' (unknown)

``What do you call some time, now?'' (guardian)
asked my guardian thoughtfully.

``Some weeks, I am afraid.'' (unknown)

``Ah!'' (He)
He (guardian) began to walk about the room with his (guardian) hands in his (guardian) pockets, showing that he (guardian) had been thinking as much.
``Now, what do you say about her (Ada) doctor? Is he (doctor) a good doctor, my love?'' (I)

I felt obliged to confess that I knew nothing to the contrary but that Prince and I had agreed only that evening that we would like his (Prince) opinion to be confirmed by some one.

``Well, you know,'' (guardian)
returned my guardian quickly,
``there's Woodcourt.'' (guardian)

I had not meant that, and was rather taken by surprise. For a moment all that I had had in my mind in connexion with Mr. Woodcourt seemed to come back and confuse me.

``You don't object to him (doctor), little woman?'' (unknown)

``Object to him (doctor), guardian? Oh no!'' (unknown)

``And you don't think the patient would object to him (patient)?'' (I)

So far from that, I had no doubt of her (I) being prepared to have a great reliance on him (Woodcourt) and to like him (Woodcourt) very much. I said that he (Woodcourt) was no stranger to her (I) personally, for she (I) had seen him (Woodcourt) often in his (Woodcourt) kind attendance on Miss Flite.

``Very good,'' (guardian)
said my guardian.
``He (patient) has been here to-day, my dear, and I will see him (patient) about it to-morrow.'' (I)

I felt in this short conversation--though I did not know how, for she (I) was quiet, and we interchanged no look--that my dear girl well remembered how merrily she (girl) had clasped me round the waist when no other hands than Caddy's had brought me the little parting token. This caused me to feel that I ought to tell her (girl), and Caddy too, that I was going to be the mistress of Bleak House and that if I avoided that disclosure any longer I might become less worthy in my own eyes of its master's love. Therefore, when we went upstairs and had waited listening until the clock struck twelve in order that only I might be the first to wish my darling all good wishes on her (mistress) birthday and to take her (mistress) to my heart, I set before her (mistress), just as I had set before myself, the goodness and honour of her (mistress) cousin John and the happy life that was in store for me. If ever my darling were fonder of me at one time than another in all our intercourse, she (mistress) was surely fondest of me that night. And I was so rejoiced to know it and so comforted by the sense of having done right in casting this last idle reservation away that I was ten times happier than I had been before. I had scarcely thought it a reservation a few hours ago, but now that it was gone I felt as if I understood its nature better.

Next day we went to London. We found our old lodging vacant, and in half an hour were quietly established there, as if we had never gone away. Mr. Woodcourt dined with us to celebrate my darling's birthday, and we were as pleasant as we could be with the great blank among us that Richard's absence naturally made on such an occasion. After that day I was for some weeks--eight or nine as I remember--very much with Caddy, and thus it fell out that I saw less of Ada at this time than any other since we had first come together, except the time of my own illness. She (Ada) often came to Caddy's, but our function there was to amuse and cheer her (Ada), and we did not talk in our usual confidential manner. Whenever I went home at night we were together, but Caddy's rest was broken by pain, and I often remained to nurse her (nurse).

With her (nurse) husband and her (nurse) poor little mite of a baby to love and their home to strive for, what a good creature Caddy was! So self-denying, so uncomplaining, so anxious to get well on their account, so afraid of giving trouble, and so thoughtful of the unassisted labours of her (nurse) husband and the comforts of old Mr. Turveydrop; I had never known the best of her (nurse) until now. And it seemed so curious that her (nurse) pale face and helpless figure should be lying there day after day where dancing was the business of life, where the kit and the apprentices began early every morning in the ball-room, and where the untidy little boy waltzed by himself in the kitchen all the afternoon.

At Caddy's request I took the supreme direction of her (nurse) apartment, trimmed it up, and pushed her (nurse), couch and all, into a lighter and more airy and more cheerful corner than she (nurse) had yet occupied; then, every day, when we were in our neatest array, I used to lay my small small namesake in her (nurse) arms and sit down to chat or work or read to her (nurse). It was at one of the first of these quiet times that I told Caddy about Bleak House.

We had other visitors besides Ada. First of all we had Prince, who in his (Prince) hurried intervals of teaching used to come softly in and sit softly down, with a face of loving anxiety for Caddy and the very little child. Whatever Caddy's condition really was, she (Ada) never failed to declare to Prince that she (Ada) was all but well--which I, heaven forgive me, never failed to confirm. This would put Prince in such good spirits that he (Prince) would sometimes take the kit from his (Prince) pocket and play a chord or two to astonish the baby, which I never knew it to do in the least degree, for my tiny namesake never noticed it at all.

Then there was Mrs. Jellyby. She (Jellyby) would come occasionally, with her (Jellyby) usual distraught manner, and sit calmly looking miles beyond her (Jellyby) grandchild as if her (Jellyby) attention were absorbed by a young Borrioboolan on its native shores. As bright-eyed as ever, as serene, and as untidy, she (Jellyby) would say,

``Well, Caddy, child, and how do you do to-day?'' (she)
And then would sit amiably smiling and taking no notice of the reply or would sweetly glide off into a calculation of the number of letters she (Jellyby) had lately received and answered or of the coffee-bearing power of Borrioboola-Gha. This she (Jellyby) would always do with a serene contempt for our limited sphere of action, not to be disguised.

Then there was old Mr. Turveydrop, who was from morning to night and from night to morning the subject of innumerable precautions. If the baby cried, it was nearly stifled lest the noise should make him (Turveydrop) uncomfortable. If the fire wanted stirring in the night, it was surreptitiously done lest his (Turveydrop) rest should be broken. If Caddy required any little comfort that the house contained, she (Jellyby) first carefully discussed whether he (Turveydrop) was likely to require it too. In return for this consideration he (Turveydrop) would come into the room once a day, all but blessing it--showing a condescension, and a patronage, and a grace of manner in dispensing the light of his (Turveydrop) high-shouldered presence from which I might have supposed him (Turveydrop) -LRB-if I had not known better-RRB- to have been the benefactor of Caddy's life.

``My Caroline,'' (he)
he (benefactor) would say, making the nearest approach that he (benefactor) could to bending over her (Jellyby).
``Tell me that you are better to-day.'' (unknown)

``Oh, much better, thank you, Mr. Turveydrop,'' (unknown)
Caddy would reply.

``Delighted! Enchanted! And our dear Miss Summerson. She (Summerson) is not quite prostrated by fatigue?'' (he)
Here he (benefactor) would crease up his (benefactor) eyelids and kiss his (benefactor) fingers to me, though I am happy to say he (benefactor) had ceased to be particular in his (benefactor) attentions since I had been so altered.

``Not at all,'' (I)
I would assure him (benefactor).

``Charming! We must take care of our dear Caroline, Miss Summerson. We must spare nothing that will restore her (Summerson). We must nourish her (Summerson). My dear Caroline'' (he)
--he (benefactor) would turn to his (benefactor) daughter-in-law with infinite generosity and protection--
``want for nothing, my love. Frame a wish and gratify it, my daughter. Everything this house contains, everything my room contains, is at your service, my dear. Do not,'' (daughter-in-law)
he (benefactor) would sometimes add in a burst of deportment,
``even allow my simple requirements to be considered if they should at any time interfere with your own, my Caroline. Your necessities are greater than mine.'' (he)

He (benefactor) had established such a long prescriptive right to this deportment -LRB-his (benefactor) son's inheritance from his (benefactor) mother-RRB- that I several times knew both Caddy and her (mother) husband to be melted to tears by these affectionate self-sacrifices.

``Nay, my dears,'' (he)
he (benefactor) would remonstrate; and when I saw Caddy's thin arm about his (benefactor) fat neck as he (benefactor) said it, I would be melted too, though not by the same process.
``Nay, nay! I have promised never to leave ye. Be dutiful and affectionate towards me, and I ask no other return. Now, bless ye! I am going to the Park.'' (He)

He (benefactor) would take the air there presently and get an appetite for his (benefactor) hotel dinner. I hope I do old Mr. Turveydrop no wrong, but I never saw any better traits in him (Turveydrop) than these I faithfully record, except that he (Turveydrop) certainly conceived a liking for Peepy and would take the child out walking with great pomp, always on those occasions sending him (Turveydrop) home before he (Turveydrop) went to dinner himself, and occasionally with a halfpenny in his (Turveydrop) pocket. But even this disinterestedness was attended with no inconsiderable cost, to my knowledge, for before Peepy was sufficiently decorated to walk hand in hand with the professor of deportment, he (professor) had to be newly dressed, at the expense of Caddy and her (child) husband, from top to toe.

Last of our visitors, there was Mr. Jellyby. Really when he (Jellyby) used to come in of an evening, and ask Caddy in his (Jellyby) meek voice how she (child) was, and then sit down with his (Jellyby) head against the wall, and make no attempt to say anything more, I liked him (Jellyby) very much. If he (Jellyby) found me bustling about doing any little thing, he (Jellyby) sometimes half took his (Jellyby) coat off, as if with an intention of helping by a great exertion; but he (Jellyby) never got any further. His (Jellyby) sole occupation was to sit with his (Jellyby) head against the wall, looking hard at the thoughtful baby; and I could not quite divest my mind of a fancy that they understood one another.

I have not counted Mr. Woodcourt among our visitors because he (Woodcourt) was now Caddy's regular attendant. She (they) soon began to improve under his (Woodcourt) care, but he (Woodcourt) was so gentle, so skilful, so unwearying in the pains he (Woodcourt) took that it is not to be wondered at, I am sure. I saw a good deal of Mr. Woodcourt during this time, though not so much as might be supposed, for knowing Caddy to be safe in his (Woodcourt) hands, I often slipped home at about the hours when he (Woodcourt) was expected. We frequently met, notwithstanding. I was quite reconciled to myself now, but I still felt glad to think that he (Woodcourt) was sorry for me, and he (Woodcourt) still WAS sorry for me I believed. He (Woodcourt) helped Mr. Badger in his (Woodcourt) professional engagements, which were numerous, and had as yet no settled projects for the future.

It was when Caddy began to recover that I began to notice a change in my dear girl. I cannot say how it first presented itself to me, because I observed it in many slight particulars which were nothing in themselves and only became something when they were pieced together. But I made it out, by putting them together, that Ada was not so frankly cheerful with me as she (Ada) used to be. Her (Ada) tenderness for me was as loving and true as ever; I did not for a moment doubt that; but there was a quiet sorrow about her (Ada) which she (Ada) did not confide to me, and in which I traced some hidden regret.

Now, I could not understand this, and I was so anxious for the happiness of my own pet that it caused me some uneasiness and set me thinking often. At length, feeling sure that Ada suppressed this something from me lest it should make me unhappy too, it came into my head that she (Ada) was a little grieved--for me--by what I had told her (Ada) about Bleak House.

How I persuaded myself that this was likely, I don't know. I had no idea that there was any selfish reference in my doing so. I was not grieved for myself: I was quite contented and quite happy. Still, that Ada might be thinking--for me, though I had abandoned all such thoughts--of what once was, but was now all changed, seemed so easy to believe that I believed it.

What could I do to reassure my darling -LRB-I considered then-RRB- and show her (Ada) that I had no such feelings? Well! I could only be as brisk and busy as possible, and that I had tried to be all along. However, as Caddy's illness had certainly interfered, more or less, with my home duties--though I had always been there in the morning to make my guardian's breakfast, and he (Caddy) had a hundred times laughed and said there must be two little women, for his (Caddy) little woman was never missing--I resolved to be doubly diligent and gay. So I went about the house humming all the tunes I knew, and I sat working and working in a desperate manner, and I talked and talked, morning, noon, and night.

And still there was the same shade between me and my darling.

``So, Dame Trot,'' (guardian)
observed my guardian, shutting up his (Caddy) book one night when we were all three together,
``so Woodcourt has restored Caddy Jellyby to the full enjoyment of life again?'' (guardian)

``Yes,'' (I)
I said;
``and to be repaid by such gratitude as hers is to be made rich, guardian.'' (I)

``I wish it was,'' (he)
he (Caddy) returned,
``with all my heart.'' (he)

So did I too, for that matter. I said so.

``Aye! We would make him (Woodcourt) as rich as a Jew if we knew how. Would we not, little woman?'' (I)

I laughed as I worked and replied that I was not sure about that, for it might spoil him (Caddy), and he (Caddy) might not be so useful, and there might be many who could ill spare him (Caddy). As Miss Flite, and Caddy herself, and many others.

``True,'' (guardian)
said my guardian.
``I had forgotten that. But we would agree to make him (Woodcourt) rich enough to live, I suppose? Rich enough to work with tolerable peace of mind? Rich enough to have his (Rich) own happy home and his (Rich) own household gods--and household goddess, too, perhaps?'' (I)

That was quite another thing, I said. We must all agree in that.

``To be sure,'' (guardian)
said my guardian.
``All of us. I have a great regard for Woodcourt, a high esteem for him (Rich); and I have been sounding him (Rich) delicately about his (Rich) plans. It is difficult to offer aid to an independent man with that just kind of pride which he (Rich) possesses. And yet I would be glad to do it if I might or if I knew how. He (Rich) seems half inclined for another voyage. But that appears like casting such a man away.'' (unknown)

``It might open a new world to him (man),'' (I.)
said I.

``So it might, little woman,'' (I.)
my guardian assented.
``I doubt if he (man) expects much of the old world. Do you know I have fancied that he (man) sometimes feels some particular disappointment or misfortune encountered in it. You never heard of anything of that sort?'' (I)

I shook my head.

``Humph,'' (guardian)
said my guardian.
``I am mistaken, I dare say.'' (I)
As there was a little pause here, which I thought, for my dear girl's satisfaction, had better be filled up, I hummed an air as I worked which was a favourite with my guardian.

``And do you think Mr. Woodcourt will make another voyage?'' (I)
I asked him (Caddy) when I had hummed it quietly all through.

``I don't quite know what to think, my dear, but I should say it was likely at present that he (Woodcourt) will give a long trip to another country.'' (unknown)

``I am sure he (Woodcourt) will take the best wishes of all our hearts with him (Woodcourt) wherever he (Woodcourt) goes,'' (I)
said I;
``and though they are not riches, he (Woodcourt) will never be the poorer for them, guardian, at least.'' (I)

``Never, little woman,'' (he)
he (Caddy) replied.

I was sitting in my usual place, which was now beside my guardian's chair. That had not been my usual place before the letter, but it was now. I looked up to Ada, who was sitting opposite, and I saw, as she (Ada) looked at me, that her (Ada) eyes were filled with tears and that tears were falling down her (Ada) face. I felt that I had only to be placid and merry once for all to undeceive my dear and set her (Ada) loving heart at rest. I really was so, and I had nothing to do but to be myself.

So I made my sweet girl lean upon my shoulder--how little thinking what was heavy on her (girl) mind!--and I said she (girl) was not quite well, and put my arm about her (girl), and took her (girl) upstairs. When we were in our own room, and when she (girl) might perhaps have told me what I was so unprepared to hear, I gave her (girl) no encouragement to confide in me; I never thought she (girl) stood in need of it.

``Oh, my dear good Esther,'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)
said Ada,
``if I could only make up my mind to speak to you and my cousin John when you are together!'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)

``Why, my love!'' (I)
I remonstrated.
``Ada, why should you not speak to us!'' (Ada)

Ada only dropped her (Ada) head and pressed me closer to her (Ada) heart.

``You surely don't forget, my beauty,'' (I)
said I, smiling,
``what quiet, old-fashioned people we are and how I have settled down to be the discreetest of dames? You don't forget how happily and peacefully my life is all marked out for me, and by whom? I am certain that you don't forget by what a noble character, Ada. That can never be.'' (I)

``No, never, Esther.'' (unknown)

``Why then, my dear,'' (I)
said I,
``there can be nothing amiss--and why should you not speak to us?'' (I)

``Nothing amiss, Esther?'' (Ada)
returned Ada.
``Oh, when I think of all these years, and of his (character) fatherly care and kindness, and of the old relations among us, and of you, what shall I do, what shall I do!'' (I)

I looked at my child in some wonder, but I thought it better not to answer otherwise than by cheering her (Ada), and so I turned off into many little recollections of our life together and prevented her (Ada) from saying more. When she (Ada) lay down to sleep, and not before, I returned to my guardian to say good night, and then I came back to Ada and sat near her (Ada) for a little while.

She (Ada) was asleep, and I thought as I looked at her (Ada) that she (Ada) was a little changed. I had thought so more than once lately. I could not decide, even looking at her (Ada) while she (Ada) was unconscious, how she (Ada) was changed, but something in the familiar beauty of her (Ada) face looked different to me. My guardian's old hopes of her (Ada) and Richard arose sorrowfully in my mind, and I said to myself,

``She (Esther) has been anxious about him (character),'' (I)
and I wondered how that love would end.

When I had come home from Caddy's while she (Ada) was ill, I had often found Ada at work, and she (Ada) had always put her (Ada) work away, and I had never known what it was. Some of it now lay in a drawer near her (Ada), which was not quite closed. I did not open the drawer, but I still rather wondered what the work could be, for it was evidently nothing for herself.

And I noticed as I kissed my dear that she (Ada) lay with one hand under her (Ada) pillow so that it was hidden.

How much less amiable I must have been than they thought me, how much less amiable than I thought myself, to be so preoccupied with my own cheerfulness and contentment as to think that it only rested with me to put my dear girl right and set her (girl) mind at peace!

But I lay down, self-deceived, in that belief. And I awoke in it next day to find that there was still the same shade between me and my darling.

CHAPTER LI

Enlightened

When Mr. Woodcourt arrived in London, he (Woodcourt) went, that very same day, to Mr. Vholes's in Symond's Inn. For he (Symond) never once, from the moment when I entreated him (Symond) to be a friend to Richard, neglected or forgot his (Richard) promise. He (Richard) had told me that he (Richard) accepted the charge as a sacred trust, and he (Richard) was ever true to it in that spirit.

He (Richard) found Mr. Vholes in his (Richard) office and informed Mr. Vholes of his (Richard) agreement with Richard that he (Richard) should call there to learn his (Richard) address.

``Just so, sir,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
said Mr. Vholes. ``Mr. C.``s address is not a hundred miles from here, sir, Mr. C.
``s address is not a hundred miles from here. Would you take a seat, sir?'' (Mr. C.)

Mr. Woodcourt thanked Mr. Vholes, but he (Woodcourt) had no business with him (Woodcourt) beyond what he (Woodcourt) had mentioned.

``Just so, sir. I believe, sir,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
said Mr. Vholes, still quietly insisting on the seat by not giving the address,
``that you have influence with Mr. C. Indeed I am aware that you have.'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)

``I was not aware of it myself,'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
returned Mr. Woodcourt;
``but I suppose you know best.'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)

``Sir,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
rejoined Mr. Vholes, self-contained as usual, voice and all,
``it is a part of my professional duty to know best. It is a part of my professional duty to study and to understand a gentleman who confides his (gentleman) interests to me. In my professional duty I shall not be wanting, sir, if I know it. I may, with the best intentions, be wanting in it without knowing it; but not if I know it, sir.'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)

Mr. Woodcourt again mentioned the address.

``Give me leave, sir,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
said Mr. Vholes.
``Bear with me for a moment. Sir, Mr. C. is playing for a considerable stake, and cannot play without--need I say what?'' (unknown)

``Money, I presume?'' (unknown)

``Sir,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
said Mr. Vholes, ``to be honest with you -LRB-honesty being my golden rule, whether I gain by it or lose, and I find that I generally lose-RRB-, money is the word. Now, sir, upon the chances of Mr. C.``s game I express to you no opinion, NO opinion. It might be highly impolitic in Mr. C., after playing so long and so high, to leave off; it might be the reverse; I say nothing. No, sir,'' said Mr. Vholes, bringing his (Vholes) hand flat down upon his (Vholes) desk in a positive manner,
``nothing.'' (unknown)

``You seem to forget,'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
returned Mr. Woodcourt,
``that I ask you to say nothing and have no interest in anything you say.'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)

``Pardon me, sir!'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
retorted Mr. Vholes.
``You do yourself an injustice. No, sir! Pardon me! You shall not--shall not in my office, if I know it--do yourself an injustice. You are interested in anything, and in everything, that relates to your friend. I know human nature much better, sir, than to admit for an instant that a gentleman of your appearance is not interested in whatever concerns his (gentleman) friend.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
replied Mr. Woodcourt,
``that may be. I am particularly interested in his (gentleman) address.'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)

``The number, sir,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
said Mr. Vholes parenthetically,
``I believe I have already mentioned. If Mr. C. is to continue to play for this considerable stake, sir, he (C.) must have funds. Understand me! There are funds in hand at present. I ask for nothing; there are funds in hand. But for the onward play, more funds must be provided, unless Mr. C. is to throw away what he (C.) has already ventured, which is wholly and solely a point for his (C.) consideration. This, sir, I take the opportunity of stating openly to you as the friend of Mr. C. Without funds I shall always be happy to appear and act for Mr. C. to the extent of all such costs as are safe to be allowed out of the estate, not beyond that. I could not go beyond that, sir, without wronging some one. I must either wrong my three dear girls or my venerable father, who is entirely dependent on me, in the Vale of Taunton; or some one. Whereas, sir, my resolution is -LRB-call it weakness or folly if you please-RRB- to wrong no one.'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)

Mr. Woodcourt rather sternly rejoined that he (Vholes) was glad to hear it.

``I wish, sir,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
said Mr. Vholes,
``to leave a good name behind me. Therefore I take every opportunity of openly stating to a friend of Mr. C. how Mr. C. is situated. As to myself, sir, the labourer is worthy of his (labourer) hire. If I undertake to put my shoulder to the wheel, I do it, and I earn what I get. I am here for that purpose. My name is painted on the door outside, with that object.'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)

``And Mr. Carstone's address, Mr. Vholes?'' (unknown)

``Sir,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
returned Mr. Vholes, ``as I believe I have already mentioned, it is next door. On the second story you will find Mr. C.
``s apartments. Mr. C. desires to be near his (Mr.) professional adviser, and I am far from objecting, for I court inquiry.'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)

Upon this Mr. Woodcourt wished Mr. Vholes good day and went in search of Richard, the change in whose appearance he (Richard) began to understand now but too well.

He (Richard) found him (Richard) in a dull room, fadedly furnished, much as I had found him (Richard) in his (Richard) barrack-room but a little while before, except that he (Richard) was not writing but was sitting with a book before him (Richard), from which his (Richard) eyes and thoughts were far astray. As the door chanced to be standing open, Mr. Woodcourt was in his (Woodcourt) presence for some moments without being perceived, and he (Woodcourt) told me that he (Woodcourt) never could forget the haggardness of his (Woodcourt) face and the dejection of his (Woodcourt) manner before he (Woodcourt) was aroused from his (Woodcourt) dream.

``Woodcourt, my dear fellow,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
cried Richard, starting up with extended hands,
``you come upon my vision like a ghost.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``A friendly one,'' (he)
he (Richard) replied,
``and only waiting, as they say ghosts do, to be addressed. How does the mortal world go?'' (he)
They were seated now, near together.

``Badly enough, and slowly enough,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard,
``speaking at least for my part of it.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``What part is that?'' (unknown)

``The Chancery part.'' (unknown)

``I never heard,'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
returned Mr. Woodcourt, shaking his (Woodcourt) head,
``of its going well yet.'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)

``Nor I,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard moodily.
``Who ever did?'' (He)
He (Richard) brightened again in a moment and said with his (Richard) natural openness,
``Woodcourt, I should be sorry to be misunderstood by you, even if I gained by it in your estimation. You must know that I have done no good this long time. I have not intended to do much harm, but I seem to have been capable of nothing else. It may be that I should have done better by keeping out of the net into which my destiny has worked me, but I think not, though I dare say you will soon hear, if you have not already heard, a very different opinion. To make short of a long story, I am afraid I have wanted an object; but I have an object now--or it has me--and it is too late to discuss it. Take me as I am, and make the best of me.'' (He)

``A bargain,'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
said Mr. Woodcourt.
``Do as much by me in return.'' (unknown)

``Oh! You,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
returned Richard,
``you can pursue your art for its own sake, and can put your hand upon the plough and never turn, and can strike a purpose out of anything. You and I are very different creatures.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

He (Woodcourt) spoke regretfully and lapsed for a moment into his (Woodcourt) weary condition.

``Well, well!'' (he)
he (Woodcourt) cried, shaking it off.
``Everything has an end. We shall see! So you will take me as I am, and make the best of me?'' (unknown)

``Aye! Indeed I will.'' (unknown)
They shook hands upon it laughingly, but in deep earnestness. I can answer for one of them with my heart of hearts.

``You come as a godsend,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard,
``for I have seen nobody here yet but Vholes. Woodcourt, there is one subject I should like to mention, for once and for all, in the beginning of our treaty. You can hardly make the best of me if I don't. You know, I dare say, that I have an attachment to my cousin Ada?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

Mr. Woodcourt replied that I had hinted as much to him (Woodcourt).

``Now pray,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
returned Richard,
``don't think me a heap of selfishness. Don't suppose that I am splitting my head and half breaking my heart over this miserable Chancery suit for my own rights and interests alone. Ada's are bound up with mine; they can't be separated; Vholes works for both of us. Do think of that!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

He (Richard) was so very solicitous on this head that Mr. Woodcourt gave him (Woodcourt) the strongest assurances that he (Woodcourt) did him (Woodcourt) no injustice.

``You see,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard, with something pathetic in his (Richard) manner of lingering on the point, though it was off-hand and unstudied,
``to an upright fellow like you, bringing a friendly face like yours here, I cannot bear the thought of appearing selfish and mean. I want to see Ada righted, Woodcourt, as well as myself; I want to do my utmost to right her (Ada), as well as myself; I venture what I can scrape together to extricate her (Ada), as well as myself. Do, I beseech you, think of that!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

Afterwards, when Mr. Woodcourt came to reflect on what had passed, he (Woodcourt) was so very much impressed by the strength of Richard's anxiety on this point that in telling me generally of his (Richard) first visit to Symond's Inn he (Richard) particularly dwelt upon it. It revived a fear I had had before that my dear girl's little property would be absorbed by Mr. Vholes and that Richard's justification to himself would be sincerely this. It was just as I began to take care of Caddy that the interview took place, and I now return to the time when Caddy had recovered and the shade was still between me and my darling.

I proposed to Ada that morning that we should go and see Richard. It a little surprised me to find that she (Ada) hesitated and was not so radiantly willing as I had expected.

``My dear,'' (I)
said I,
``you have not had any difference with Richard since I have been so much away?'' (I)

``No, Esther.'' (unknown)

``Not heard of him (Richard), perhaps?'' (I.)
said I.

``Yes, I have heard of him (Richard),'' (I.)
said Ada.

Such tears in her (Ada) eyes, and such love in her (Ada) face. I could not make my darling out. Should I go to Richard's by myself? I said. No, Ada thought I had better not go by myself. Would she (Ada) go with me? Yes, Ada thought she (Ada) had better go with me. Should we go now? Yes, let us go now. Well, I could not understand my darling, with the tears in her (Ada) eyes and the love in her (Ada) face!

We were soon equipped and went out. It was a sombre day, and drops of chill rain fell at intervals. It was one of those colourless days when everything looks heavy and harsh. The houses frowned at us, the dust rose at us, the smoke swooped at us, nothing made any compromise about itself or wore a softened aspect. I fancied my beautiful girl quite out of place in the rugged streets, and I thought there were more funerals passing along the dismal pavements than I had ever seen before.

We had first to find out Symond's Inn. We were going to inquire in a shop when Ada said she (Ada) thought it was near Chancery Lane.

``We are not likely to be far out, my love, if we go in that direction,'' (I)
said I. So to Chancery Lane we went, and there, sure enough, we saw it written up. Symond's Inn.

We had next to find out the number.

``Or Mr. Vholes's office will do,'' (I)
I recollected,
``for Mr. Vholes's office is next door.'' (I)
Upon which Ada said, perhaps that was Mr. Vholes's office in the corner there. And it really was.

Then came the question, which of the two next doors? I was going for the one, and my darling was going for the other; and my darling was right again. So up we went to the second story, when we came to Richard's name in great white letters on a hearse-like panel.

I should have knocked, but Ada said perhaps we had better turn the handle and go in. Thus we came to Richard, poring over a table covered with dusty bundles of papers which seemed to me like dusty mirrors reflecting his (Richard) own mind. Wherever I looked I saw the ominous words that ran in it repeated. Jarndyce and Jarndyce.

He (Jarndyce) received us very affectionately, and we sat down.

``If you had come a little earlier,'' (he)
he (Jarndyce) said,
``you would have found Woodcourt here. There never was such a good fellow as Woodcourt is. He (fellow) finds time to look in between-whiles, when anybody else with half his (fellow) work to do would be thinking about not being able to come. And he (fellow) is so cheery, so fresh, so sensible, so earnest, so--everything that I am not, that the place brightens whenever he (fellow) comes, and darkens whenever he (fellow) goes again.'' (he)

``God bless him (God),'' (I)
I thought,
``for his (God) truth to me!'' (I)

``He (God) is not so sanguine, Ada,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
continued Richard, casting his (Richard) dejected look over the bundles of papers,
``as Vholes and I are usually, but he (God) is only an outsider and is not in the mysteries. We have gone into them, and he (God) has not. He (God) can't be expected to know much of such a labyrinth.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

As his (Richard) look wandered over the papers again and he (Richard) passed his (Richard) two hands over his (Richard) head, I noticed how sunken and how large his (Richard) eyes appeared, how dry his (Richard) lips were, and how his (Richard) finger-nails were all bitten away.

``Is this a healthy place to live in, Richard, do you think?'' (I. sun)
said I.

``Why, my dear Minerva,'' (I. sun)
answered Richard with his (Richard) old gay laugh,
``it is neither a rural nor a cheerful place; and when the sun shines here, you may lay a pretty heavy wager that it is shining brightly in an open spot. But it's well enough for the time. It's near the offices and near Vholes.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``Perhaps,'' (I)
I hinted,
``a change from both--'' (I)

``Might do me good?'' (I)
said Richard, forcing a laugh as he (Richard) finished the sentence.
``I shouldn't wonder! But it can only come in one way now--in one of two ways, I should rather say. Either the suit must be ended, Esther, or the suitor. But it shall be the suit, my dear girl, the suit, my dear girl!'' (Ada)

These latter words were addressed to Ada, who was sitting nearest to him (Richard). Her (Ada) face being turned away from me and towards him (Richard), I could not see it.

``We are doing very well,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
pursued Richard.
``Vholes will tell you so. We are really spinning along. Ask Vholes. We are giving them no rest. Vholes knows all their windings and turnings, and we are upon them everywhere. We have astonished them already. We shall rouse up that nest of sleepers, mark my words!'' (me)

His (Richard) hopefulness had long been more painful to me than his (Richard) despondency; it was so unlike hopefulness, had something so fierce in its determination to be it, was so hungry and eager, and yet so conscious of being forced and unsustainable that it had long touched me to the heart. But the commentary upon it now indelibly written in his (Richard) handsome face made it far more distressing than it used to be. I say indelibly, for I felt persuaded that if the fatal cause could have been for ever terminated, according to his (Richard) brightest visions, in that same hour, the traces of the premature anxiety, self-reproach, and disappointment it had occasioned him (Richard) would have remained upon his (Richard) features to the hour of his (Richard) death.

``The sight of our dear little woman,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard, Ada still remaining silent and quiet,
``is so natural to me, and her (woman) compassionate face is so like the face of old days--'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)

Ah! No, no. I smiled and shook my head.

''--So exactly like the face of old days,'' (I)
said Richard in his (Richard) cordial voice, and taking my hand with the brotherly regard which nothing ever changed,
``that I can't make pretences with her (woman). I fluctuate a little; that's the truth. Sometimes I hope, my dear, and sometimes I--don't quite despair, but nearly. I get,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard, relinquishing my hand gently and walking across the room,
``so tired!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

He (Richard) took a few turns up and down and sunk upon the sofa.

``I get,'' (he)
he (Richard) repeated gloomily,
``so tired. It is such weary, weary work!'' (he)

He (Richard) was leaning on his (Richard) arm saying these words in a meditative voice and looking at the ground when my darling rose, put off her (I) bonnet, kneeled down beside him (Richard) with her (I) golden hair falling like sunlight on his (Richard) head, clasped her (I) two arms round his (Richard) neck, and turned her (I) face to me. Oh, what a loving and devoted face I saw!

``Esther, dear,'' (she)
she (I) said very quietly,
``I am not going home again.'' (she)

A light shone in upon me all at once.

``Never any more. I am going to stay with my dear husband. We have been married above two months. Go home without me, my own Esther; I shall never go home any more!'' (unknown)
With those words my darling drew his (Richard) head down on her (I) breast and held it there. And if ever in my life I saw a love that nothing but death could change, I saw it then before me.

``Speak to Esther, my dearest,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard, breaking the silence presently.
``Tell her (Esther) how it was.'' (I)

I met her (I) before she (I) could come to me and folded her (I) in my arms. We neither of us spoke, but with her (I) cheek against my own I wanted to hear nothing.

``My pet,'' (I.)
said I.
``My love. My poor, poor girl!'' (I.)
I pitied her (I) so much. I was very fond of Richard, but the impulse that I had upon me was to pity her (I) so much.

``Esther, will you forgive me? Will my cousin John forgive me?'' (unknown)

``My dear,'' (I)
said I,
``to doubt it for a moment is to do him (John) a great wrong. And as to me!'' (I)
Why, as to me, what had I to forgive!

I dried my sobbing darling's eyes and sat beside her (I) on the sofa, and Richard sat on my other side; and while I was reminded of that so different night when they had first taken me into their confidence and had gone on in their own wild happy way, they told me between them how it was.

``All I had was Richard's,'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)
Ada said;
``and Richard would not take it, Esther, and what could I do but be his (Richard) wife when I loved him (Richard) dearly!'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)

``And you were so fully and so kindly occupied, excellent Dame Durden,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard,
``that how could we speak to you at such a time! And besides, it was not a long-considered step. We went out one morning and were married.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``And when it was done, Esther,'' (unknown)
said my darling,
``I was always thinking how to tell you and what to do for the best. And sometimes I thought you ought to know it directly, and sometimes I thought you ought not to know it and keep it from my cousin John; and I could not tell what to do, and I fretted very much.'' (I)

How selfish I must have been not to have thought of this before! I don't know what I said now. I was so sorry, and yet I was so fond of them and so glad that they were fond of me; I pitied them so much, and yet I felt a kind of pride in their loving one another. I never had experienced such painful and pleasurable emotion at one time, and in my own heart I did not know which predominated. But I was not there to darken their way; I did not do that.

When I was less foolish and more composed, my darling took her (I) wedding-ring from her (I) bosom, and kissed it, and put it on. Then I remembered last night and told Richard that ever since her (I) marriage she (I) had worn it at night when there was no one to see. Then Ada blushingly asked me how did I know that, my dear. Then I told Ada how I had seen her (Ada) hand concealed under her (Ada) pillow and had little thought why, my dear. Then they began telling me how it was all over again, and I began to be sorry and glad again, and foolish again, and to hide my plain old face as much as I could lest I should put them out of heart.

Thus the time went on until it became necessary for me to think of returning. When that time arrived it was the worst of all, for then my darling completely broke down. She (Ada) clung round my neck, calling me by every dear name she (Ada) could think of and saying what should she (Ada) do without me! Nor was Richard much better; and as for me, I should have been the worst of the three if I had not severely said to myself,

``Now Esther, if you do, I'll never speak to you again!'' (I)

``Why, I declare,'' (I)
said I,
``I never saw such a wife. I don't think she (wife) loves her (wife) husband at all. Here, Richard, take my child, for goodness' sake.'' (I)
But I held her (Ada) tight all the while, and could have wept over her (Ada) I don't know how long.

``I give this dear young couple notice,'' (I)
said I,
``that I am only going away to come back to-morrow and that I shall be always coming backwards and forwards until Symond's Inn is tired of the sight of me. So I shall not say good-bye, Richard. For what would be the use of that, you know, when I am coming back so soon!'' (I)

I had given my darling to him (Richard) now, and I meant to go; but I lingered for one more look of the precious face which it seemed to rive my heart to turn from.

So I said -LRB-in a merry, bustling manner-RRB- that unless they gave me some encouragement to come back, I was not sure that I could take that liberty, upon which my dear girl looked up, faintly smiling through her (girl) tears, and I folded her (girl) lovely face between my hands, and gave it one last kiss, and laughed, and ran away.

And when I got downstairs, oh, how I cried! It almost seemed to me that I had lost my Ada for ever. I was so lonely and so blank without her (Ada), and it was so desolate to be going home with no hope of seeing her (Ada) there, that I could get no comfort for a little while as I walked up and down in a dim corner sobbing and crying.

I came to myself by and by, after a little scolding, and took a coach home. The poor boy whom I had found at St. Albans had reappeared a short time before and was lying at the point of death; indeed, was then dead, though I did not know it. My guardian had gone out to inquire about him (boy) and did not return to dinner. Being quite alone, I cried a little again, though on the whole I don't think I behaved so very, very ill.

It was only natural that I should not be quite accustomed to the loss of my darling yet. Three or four hours were not a long time after years.
