But my mind dwelt so much upon the uncongenial scene in which I had left her (my), and I pictured it as such an overshadowed stony-hearted one, and I so longed to be near her (my) and taking some sort of care of her (my), that I determined to go back in the evening only to look up at her (my) windows.

It was foolish, I dare say, but it did not then seem at all so to me, and it does not seem quite so even now. I took Charley into my confidence, and we went out at dusk. It was dark when we came to the new strange home of my dear girl, and there was a light behind the yellow blinds. We walked past cautiously three or four times, looking up, and narrowly missed encountering Mr. Vholes, who came out of his (Vholes) office while we were there and turned his (Vholes) head to look up too before going home. The sight of his (Vholes) lank black figure and the lonesome air of that nook in the dark were favourable to the state of my mind. I thought of the youth and love and beauty of my dear girl, shut up in such an ill-assorted refuge, almost as if it were a cruel place.

It was very solitary and very dull, and I did not doubt that I might safely steal upstairs. I left Charley below and went up with a light foot, not distressed by any glare from the feeble oil lanterns on the way. I listened for a few moments, and in the musty rotting silence of the house believed that I could hear the murmur of their young voices. I put my lips to the hearse-like panel of the door as a kiss for my dear and came quietly down again, thinking that one of these days I would confess to the visit.

And it really did me good, for though nobody but Charley and I knew anything about it, I somehow felt as if it had diminished the separation between Ada and me and had brought us together again for those moments. I went back, not quite accustomed yet to the change, but all the better for that hovering about my darling.

My guardian had come home and was standing thoughtfully by the dark window. When I went in, his (Charley) face cleared and he (Charley) came to his (Charley) seat, but he (Charley) caught the light upon my face as I took mine.

``Little woman,'' (he)
said he (Charley),
``You have been crying.'' (he)

``Why, yes, guardian,'' (I)
said I,
``I am afraid I have been, a little. Ada has been in such distress, and is so very sorry, guardian.'' (I)

I put my arm on the back of his (Charley) chair, and I saw in his (Charley) glance that my words and my look at her (Charley) empty place had prepared him (Charley).

``Is she (Ada) married, my dear?'' (I)

I told him (Charley) all about it and how her (Charley) first entreaties had referred to his (Charley) forgiveness.

``She (Ada) has no need of it,'' (he)
said he (Charley).
``Heaven bless her (Ada) and her (Ada) husband!'' (her)
But just as my first impulse had been to pity her (Charley), so was his (Charley).
``Poor girl, poor girl! Poor Rick! Poor Ada!'' (he)

Neither of us spoke after that, until he (Charley) said with a sigh,

``Well, well, my dear! Bleak House is thinning fast.'' (he)

``But its mistress remains, guardian.'' (I)
Though I was timid about saying it, I ventured because of the sorrowful tone in which he (Charley) had spoken.
``She (mistress) will do all she (mistress) can to make it happy,'' (I.)
said I.

``She (mistress) will succeed, my love!'' (I.)

The letter had made no difference between us except that the seat by his (Charley) side had come to be mine; it made none now. He (Charley) turned his (Charley) old bright fatherly look upon me, laid his (Charley) hand on my hand in his (Charley) old way, and said again,

``She (mistress) will succeed, my dear. Nevertheless, Bleak House is thinning fast, O little woman!'' (me)

I was sorry presently that this was all we said about that. I was rather disappointed. I feared I might not quite have been all I had meant to be since the letter and the answer.

CHAPTER LII

Obstinacy

But one other day had intervened when, early in the morning as we were going to breakfast, Mr. Woodcourt came in haste with the astounding news that a terrible murder had been committed for which Mr. George had been apprehended and was in custody. When he (George) told us that a large reward was offered by Sir Leicester Dedlock for the murderer's apprehension, I did not in my first consternation understand why; but a few more words explained to me that the murdered person was Sir Leicester's lawyer, and immediately my mother's dread of him (lawyer) rushed into my remembrance.

This unforeseen and violent removal of one whom she (mother) had long watched and distrusted and who had long watched and distrusted her (mother), one for whom she (mother) could have had few intervals of kindness, always dreading in him (lawyer) a dangerous and secret enemy, appeared so awful that my first thoughts were of her (mother). How appalling to hear of such a death and be able to feel no pity! How dreadful to remember, perhaps, that she (mother) had sometimes even wished the old man away who was so swiftly hurried out of life!

Such crowding reflections, increasing the distress and fear I always felt when the name was mentioned, made me so agitated that I could scarcely hold my place at the table. I was quite unable to follow the conversation until I had had a little time to recover. But when I came to myself and saw how shocked my guardian was and found that they were earnestly speaking of the suspected man and recalling every favourable impression we had formed of him (man) out of the good we had known of him (man), my interest and my fears were so strongly aroused in his (man) behalf that I was quite set up again.

``Guardian, you don't think it possible that he (Rick) is justly accused?'' (unknown)

``My dear, I CAN

``T think so. This man whom we have seen so open-hearted and compassionate, who with the might of a giant has the gentleness of a child, who looks as brave a fellow as ever lived and is so simple and quiet with it, this man justly accused of such a crime? I can't believe it. It's not that I don't or I won't. I can't!'' (unknown)

``And I can't,'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
said Mr. Woodcourt.
``Still, whatever we believe or know of him (man), we had better not forget that some appearances are against him (man). He (man) bore an animosity towards the deceased gentleman. He (man) has openly mentioned it in many places. He (man) is said to have expressed himself violently towards him (man), and he (man) certainly did about him (man), to my knowledge. He (man) admits that he (man) was alone on the scene of the murder within a few minutes of its commission. I sincerely believe him (man) to be as innocent of any participation in it as I am, but these are all reasons for suspicion falling upon him (man).'' (unknown)

``True,'' (guardian)
said my guardian. And he (Woodcourt) added, turning to me,
``It would be doing him (man) a very bad service, my dear, to shut our eyes to the truth in any of these respects.'' (me)

I felt, of course, that we must admit, not only to ourselves but to others, the full force of the circumstances against him (Woodcourt). Yet I knew withal -LRB-I could not help saying-RRB- that their weight would not induce us to desert him (Woodcourt) in his (Woodcourt) need.

``Heaven forbid!'' (guardian)
returned my guardian.
``We will stand by him (man), as he (man) himself stood by the two poor creatures who are gone.'' (He)
He (Woodcourt) meant Mr. Gridley and the boy, to both of whom Mr. George had given shelter.

Mr. Woodcourt then told us that the trooper's man had been with him (man) before day, after wandering about the streets all night like a distracted creature. That one of the trooper's first anxieties was that we should not suppose him (trooper) guilty. That he (trooper) had charged his (trooper) messenger to represent his (trooper) perfect innocence with every solemn assurance he (trooper) could send us. That Mr. Woodcourt had only quieted the man by undertaking to come to our house very early in the morning with these representations. He (Woodcourt) added that he (Woodcourt) was now upon his (Woodcourt) way to see the prisoner himself.

My guardian said directly he (Woodcourt) would go too. Now, besides that I liked the retired soldier very much and that he (soldier) liked me, I had that secret interest in what had happened which was only known to my guardian. I felt as if it came close and near to me. It seemed to become personally important to myself that the truth should be discovered and that no innocent people should be suspected, for suspicion, once run wild, might run wilder.

In a word, I felt as if it were my duty and obligation to go with them. My guardian did not seek to dissuade me, and I went.

It was a large prison with many courts and passages so like one another and so uniformly paved that I seemed to gain a new comprehension, as I passed along, of the fondness that solitary prisoners, shut up among the same staring walls from year to year, have had--as I have read--for a weed or a stray blade of grass. In an arched room by himself, like a cellar upstairs, with walls so glaringly white that they made the massive iron window-bars and iron-bound door even more profoundly black than they were, we found the trooper standing in a corner. He (trooper) had been sitting on a bench there and had risen when he (trooper) heard the locks and bolts turn.

When he (trooper) saw us, he (trooper) came forward a step with his (trooper) usual heavy tread, and there stopped and made a slight bow. But as I still advanced, putting out my hand to him (trooper), he (trooper) understood us in a moment.

``This is a load off my mind, I do assure you, miss and gentlemen,'' (he)
said he (trooper), saluting us with great heartiness and drawing a long breath.
``And now I don't so much care how it ends.'' (He)

He (trooper) scarcely seemed to be the prisoner. What with his (trooper) coolness and his (trooper) soldierly bearing, he (trooper) looked far more like the prison guard.

``This is even a rougher place than my gallery to receive a lady in,'' (Mr. George/George)
said Mr. George,
``but I know Miss Summerson will make the best of it.'' (Mr. George/George)
As he (George) handed me to the bench on which he (George) had been sitting, I sat down, which seemed to give him (George) great satisfaction.

``I thank you, miss,'' (he)
said he (George).

``Now, George,'' (guardian)
observed my guardian,
``as we require no new assurances on your part, so I believe we need give you none on ours.'' (guardian)

``Not at all, sir. I thank you with all my heart. If I was not innocent of this crime, I couldn't look at you and keep my secret to myself under the condescension of the present visit. I feel the present visit very much. I am not one of the eloquent sort, but I feel it, Miss Summerson and gentlemen, deeply.'' (He)

He (George) laid his (George) hand for a moment on his (George) broad chest and bent his (George) head to us. Although he (George) squared himself again directly, he (George) expressed a great amount of natural emotion by these simple means.

``First,'' (guardian)
said my guardian,
``can we do anything for your personal comfort, George?'' (guardian)

``For which, sir?'' (he)
he (George) inquired, clearing his (George) throat.

``For your personal comfort. Is there anything you want that would lessen the hardship of this confinement?'' (unknown)

``Well, sir,'' (Mr. George/George)
replied George, after a little cogitation,
``I am equally obliged to you, but tobacco being against the rules, I can't say that there is.'' (Mr. George/George)

``You will think of many little things perhaps, by and by. Whenever you do, George, let us know.'' (unknown)

``Thank you, sir. Howsoever,'' (Mr. George/George)
observed Mr. George with one of his (George) sunburnt smiles,
``a man who has been knocking about the world in a vagabond kind of a way as long as I have gets on well enough in a place like the present, so far as that goes.'' (Mr. George/George)

``Next, as to your case,'' (guardian)
observed my guardian.

``Exactly so, sir,'' (Mr. George/George)
returned Mr. George, folding his (George) arms upon his (George) breast with perfect self-possession and a little curiosity.

``How does it stand now?'' (unknown)

``Why, sir, it is under remand at present. Bucket gives me to understand that he (man) will probably apply for a series of remands from time to time until the case is more complete. How it is to be made more complete I don't myself see, but I dare say Bucket will manage it somehow.'' (unknown)

``Why, heaven save us, man,'' (guardian)
exclaimed my guardian, surprised into his (George) old oddity and vehemence,
``you talk of yourself as if you were somebody else!'' (guardian)

``No offence, sir,'' (Mr. George/George)
said Mr. George. ``I am very sensible of your kindness. But I don't see how an innocent man is to make up his (man) mind to this kind of thing without knocking his (man) head against the walls unless he (man) takes it in that point of view.

``That is true enough to a certain extent,'' (guardian)
returned my guardian, softened.
``But my good fellow, even an innocent man must take ordinary precautions to defend himself.'' (unknown)

``Certainly, sir. And I have done so. I have stated to the magistrates, ``Gentlemen, I am as innocent of this charge as yourselves; what has been stated against me in the way of facts is perfectly true; I know no more about it.

'' I intend to continue stating that, sir. What more can I do? It's the truth.'' (I)

``But the mere truth won't do,'' (guardian)
rejoined my guardian.

``Won't it indeed, sir? Rather a bad look-out for me!'' (Mr. George/George)
Mr. George good-humouredly observed.

``You must have a lawyer,'' (guardian)
pursued my guardian.
``We must engage a good one for you.'' (unknown)

``I ask your pardon, sir,'' (Mr. George/George)
said Mr. George with a step backward.
``I am equally obliged. But I must decidedly beg to be excused from anything of that sort.'' (unknown)

``You won't have a lawyer?'' (unknown)

``No, sir.'' (Mr. George/George)
Mr. George shook his (George) head in the most emphatic manner.
``I thank you all the same, sir, but--no lawyer!'' (unknown)

``Why not?'' (unknown)

``I don't take kindly to the breed,'' (Mr. George/George)
said Mr. George.
``Gridley didn't. And--if you'll excuse my saying so much--I should hardly have thought you did yourself, sir.'' (unknown)

``That's equity,'' (guardian)
my guardian explained, a little at a loss;
``that's equity, George.'' (guardian)

``Is it, indeed, sir?'' (the trooper)
returned the trooper in his (George) off-hand manner.
``I am not acquainted with those shades of names myself, but in a general way I object to the breed.'' (he)

Unfolding his (George) arms and changing his (George) position, he (George) stood with one massive hand upon the table and the other on his (George) hip, as complete a picture of a man who was not to be moved from a fixed purpose as ever I saw. It was in vain that we all three talked to him (man) and endeavoured to persuade him (man); he (man) listened with that gentleness which went so well with his (man) bluff bearing, but was evidently no more shaken by our representations that his (man) place of confinement was.

``Pray think, once more, Mr. George,'' (I.)
said I.
``Have you no wish in reference to your case?'' (I.)

``I certainly could wish it to be tried, miss,'' (he)
he (man) returned,
``by court-martial; but that is out of the question, as I am well aware. If you will be so good as to favour me with your attention for a couple of minutes, miss, not more, I'll endeavour to explain myself as clearly as I can.'' (he)

He (man) looked at us all three in turn, shook his (man) head a little as if he (man) were adjusting it in the stock and collar of a tight uniform, and after a moment's reflection went on.

``You see, miss, I have been handcuffed and taken into custody and brought here. I am a marked and disgraced man, and here I am. My shooting gallery is rummaged, high and low, by Bucket; such property as I have--`tis small--is turned this way and that till it don't know itself; and -LRB-as aforesaid-RRB- here I am! I don't particular complain of that. Though I am in these present quarters through no immediately preceding fault of mine, I can very well understand that if I hadn't gone into the vagabond way in my youth, this wouldn't have happened. It HAS happened. Then comes the question how to meet it.'' (He)

He (man) rubbed his (man) swarthy forehead for a moment with a good-humoured look and said apologetically,

``I am such a short-winded talker that I must think a bit.'' (He)
Having thought a bit, he (man) looked up again and resumed.

``How to meet it. Now, the unfortunate deceased was himself a lawyer and had a pretty tight hold of me. I don't wish to rake up his (lawyer) ashes, but he (lawyer) had, what I should call if he (lawyer) was living, a devil of a tight hold of me. I don't like his (lawyer) trade the better for that. If I had kept clear of his (lawyer) trade, I should have kept outside this place. But that's not what I mean. Now, suppose I had killed him (lawyer). Suppose I really had discharged into his (lawyer) body any one of those pistols recently fired off that Bucket has found at my place, and dear me, might have found there any day since it has been my place. What should I have done as soon as I was hard and fast here? Got a lawyer.'' (He)

He (man) stopped on hearing some one at the locks and bolts and did not resume until the door had been opened and was shut again. For what purpose opened, I will mention presently.

``I should have got a lawyer, and he (lawyer) would have said -LRB-as I have often read in the newspapers-RRB-,

``My client says nothing, my client reserves his (client) defence': my client this, that, and t`other. Well, `tis not the custom of that breed to go straight, according to my opinion, or to think that other men do. Say I am innocent and I get a lawyer. He (lawyer) would be as likely to believe me guilty as not; perhaps more. What would he (lawyer) do, whether or not? Act as if I was--shut my mouth up, tell me not to commit myself, keep circumstances back, chop the evidence small, quibble, and get me off perhaps! But, Miss Summerson, do I care for getting off in that way; or would I rather be hanged in my own way--if you'll excuse my mentioning anything so disagreeable to a lady?'' (He)

He (man) had warmed into his (man) subject now, and was under no further necessity to wait a bit.

``I would rather be hanged in my own way. And I mean to be! I don't intend to say,'' (unknown)
looking round upon us with his (man) powerful arms akimbo and his (man) dark eyebrows raised,
``that I am more partial to being hanged than another man. What I say is, I must come off clear and full or not at all. Therefore, when I hear stated against me what is true, I say it's true; and when they tell me, `whatever you say will be used,'' (I)
I tell them I don't mind that; I mean it to be used. If they can't make me innocent out of the whole truth, they are not likely to do it out of anything less, or anything else. And if they are, it's worth nothing to me.''

Taking a pace or two over the stone floor, he (man) came back to the table and finished what he (man) had to say.

``I thank you, miss and gentlemen both, many times for your attention, and many times more for your interest. That's the plain state of the matter as it points itself out to a mere trooper with a blunt broadsword kind of a mind. I have never done well in life beyond my duty as a soldier, and if the worst comes after all, I shall reap pretty much as I have sown. When I got over the first crash of being seized as a murderer--it don't take a rover who has knocked about so much as myself so very long to recover from a crash--I worked my way round to what you find me now. As such I shall remain. No relations will be disgraced by me or made unhappy for me, and--and that's all I've got to say.'' (another man)

The door had been opened to admit another soldier-looking man of less prepossessing appearance at first sight and a weather-tanned, bright-eyed wholesome woman with a basket, who, from her (woman) entrance, had been exceedingly attentive to all Mr. George had said. Mr. George had received them with a familiar nod and a friendly look, but without any more particular greeting in the midst of his (George) address. He (George) now shook them cordially by the hand and said,

``Miss Summerson and gentlemen, this is an old comrade of mine, Matthew Bagnet. And this is his (Bagnet) wife, Mrs. Bagnet.'' (He)

Mr. Bagnet made us a stiff military bow, and Mrs. Bagnet dropped us a curtsy.

``Real good friends of mine, they are,'' (Mr. George/George)
sald Mr. George.
``It was at their house I was taken.'' (unknown)

``With a second-hand wiolinceller,'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
Mr. Bagnet put in, twitching his (Bagnet) head angrily.
``Of a good tone. For a friend. That money was no object to.'' (unknown)

``Mat,'' (Mr. George/George)
said Mr. George,
``you have heard pretty well all I have been saying to this lady and these two gentlemen. I know it meets your approval?'' (Mr. George/George)

Mr. Bagnet, after considering, referred the point to his (Bagnet) wife.

``Old girl,'' (he)
said he (Bagnet).
``Tell him (Mat). Whether or not. It meets my approval.'' (unknown)

``Why, George,'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
exclaimed Mrs. Bagnet, who had been unpacking her (Bagnet) basket, in which there was a piece of cold pickled pork, a little tea and sugar, and a brown loaf,
``you ought to know it don't. You ought to know it's enough to drive a person wild to hear you. You won't be got off this way, and you won't be got off that way--what do you mean by such picking and choosing? It's stuff and nonsense, George.'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

``Don't be severe upon me in my misfortunes, Mrs. Bagnet,'' (the trooper)
said the trooper lightly.

``Oh! Bother your misfortunes,'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
cried Mrs. Bagnet,
``if they don't make you more reasonable than that comes to. I never was so ashamed in my life to hear a man talk folly as I have been to hear you talk this day to the present company. Lawyers? Why, what but too many cooks should hinder you from having a dozen lawyers if the gentleman recommended them to you.'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

``This is a very sensible woman,'' (guardian)
said my guardian.
``I hope you will persuade him (gentleman), Mrs. Bagnet.'' (unknown)

``Persuade him (gentleman), sir?'' (she)
she (Bagnet) returned.
``Lord bless you, no. You don't know George. Now, there!'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
Mrs. Bagnet left her (Bagnet) basket to point him (trooper) out with both her (Bagnet) bare brown hands.
``There he (George) stands! As self-willed and as determined a man, in the wrong way, as ever put a human creature under heaven out of patience! You could as soon take up and shoulder an eight and forty pounder by your own strength as turn that man when he (man) has got a thing into his (man) head and fixed it there. Why, don't I know him (man)!'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
cried Mrs. Bagnet.
``Don't I know you, George! You don't mean to set up for a new character with ME after all these years, I hope?'' (husband)

Her (Bagnet) friendly indignation had an exemplary effect upon her (Bagnet) husband, who shook his (husband) head at the trooper several times as a silent recommendation to him (husband) to yield. Between whiles, Mrs. Bagnet looked at me; and I understood from the play of her (Bagnet) eyes that she (Bagnet) wished me to do something, though I did not comprehend what.

``But I have given up talking to you, old fellow, years and years,'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
said Mrs. Bagnet as she (Bagnet) blew a little dust off the pickled pork, looking at me again;
``and when ladies and gentlemen know you as well as I do, they'll give up talking to you too. If you are not too headstrong to accept of a bit of dinner, here it is.'' (me)

``I accept it with many thanks,'' (the trooper)
returned the trooper.

``Do you though, indeed?'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
said Mrs. Bagnet, continuing to grumble on good-humouredly.
``I'm sure I'm surprised at that. I wonder you don't starve in your own way also. It would only be like you. Perhaps you'll set your mind upon THAT next.'' (she)
Here she (Bagnet) again looked at me, and I now perceived from her (Bagnet) glances at the door and at me, by turns, that she (Bagnet) wished us to retire and to await her (Bagnet) following us outside the prison. Communicating this by similar means to my guardian and Mr. Woodcourt, I rose.

``We hope you will think better of it, Mr. George,'' (I)
said I,
``and we shall come to see you again, trusting to find you more reasonable.'' (I)

``More grateful, Miss Summerson, you can't find me,'' (he)
he (Woodcourt) returned.

``But more persuadable we can, I hope,'' (I.)
said I.
``And let me entreat you to consider that the clearing up of this mystery and the discovery of the real perpetrator of this deed may be of the last importance to others besides yourself.'' (I.)

He (Woodcourt) heard me respectfully but without much heeding these words, which I spoke a little turned from him (Woodcourt), already on my way to the door; he (Woodcourt) was observing -LRB-this they afterwards told me-RRB- my height and figure, which seemed to catch his (Woodcourt) attention all at once.

''`Tis curious,'' (me)
said he (Woodcourt).
``And yet I thought so at the time!'' (guardian)

My guardian asked him (Woodcourt) what he (Woodcourt) meant.

``Why, sir,'' (he)
he (Woodcourt) answered,
``when my ill fortune took me to the dead man's staircase on the night of his (man) murder, I saw a shape so like Miss Summerson's go by me in the dark that I had half a mind to speak to it.'' (he)

For an instant I felt such a shudder as I never felt before or since and hope I shall never feel again.

``It came downstairs as I went up,'' (the trooper window)
said the trooper,
``and crossed the moonlighted window with a loose black mantle on; I noticed a deep fringe to it. However, it has nothing to do with the present subject, excepting that Miss Summerson looked so like it at the moment that it came into my head.'' (the trooper window)

I cannot separate and define the feelings that arose in me after this; it is enough that the vague duty and obligation I had felt upon me from the first of following the investigation was, without my distinctly daring to ask myself any question, increased, and that I was indignantly sure of there being no possibility of a reason for my being afraid.

We three went out of the prison and walked up and down at some short distance from the gate, which was in a retired place. We had not waited long when Mr. and Mrs. Bagnet came out too and quickly joined us.

There was a tear in each of Mrs. Bagnet's eyes, and her (Bagnet) face was flushed and hurried.

``I didn't let George see what I thought about it, you know, miss,'' (she)
was her (Bagnet) first remark when she (Bagnet) came up,
``but he (George)'s in a bad way, poor old fellow!'' (she)

``Not with care and prudence and good help,'' (guardian)
said my guardian.

``A gentleman like you ought to know best, sir,'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
returned Mrs. Bagnet, hurriedly drying her (Bagnet) eyes on the hem of her (Bagnet) grey cloak,
``but I am uneasy for him (gentleman). He (gentleman) has been so careless and said so much that he (gentleman) never meant. The gentlemen of the juries might not understand him (gentleman) as Lignum and me do. And then such a number of circumstances have happened bad for him (gentleman), and such a number of people will be brought forward to speak against him (gentleman), and Bucket is so deep.'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

``With a second-hand wiolinceller. And said he (gentleman) played the fife. When a boy,'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
Mr. Bagnet added with great solemnity.

``Now, I tell you, miss,'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
said Mrs. Bagnet;
``and when I say miss, I mean all! Just come into the corner of the wall and I'll tell you!'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

Mrs. Bagnet hurried us into a more secluded place and was at first too breathless to proceed, occasioning Mr. Bagnet to say,

``Old girl! Tell 'em!'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)

``Why, then, miss,'' (the girl)
the old girl proceeded, untying the strings of her (girl) bonnet for more air,
``you could as soon move Dover Castle as move George on this point unless you had got a new power to move him (George) with. And I have got it!'' (the girl)

``You are a jewel of a woman,'' (guardian)
said my guardian.
``Go on!'' (unknown)

``Now, I tell you, miss,'' (she)
she (girl) proceeded, clapping her (girl) hands in her (girl) hurry and agitation a dozen times in every sentence,
``that what he (George) says concerning no relations is all bosh. They don't know of him (George), but he (George) does know of them. He (George) has said more to me at odd times than to anybody else, and it warn't for nothing that he (George) once spoke to my Woolwich about whitening and wrinkling mothers' heads. For fifty pounds he (George) had seen his (George) mother that day. She (mother)'s alive and must be brought here straight!'' (dozen)

Instantly Mrs. Bagnet put some pins into her (Bagnet) mouth and began pinning up her (Bagnet) skirts all round a little higher than the level of her (Bagnet) grey cloak, which she (Bagnet) accomplished with surpassing dispatch and dexterity.

``Lignum,'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
said Mrs. Bagnet,
``you take care of the children, old man, and give me the umbrella! I'm away to Lincolnshire to bring that old lady here.'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

``But, bless the woman,'' (guardian)
cried my guardian with his (Bagnet) hand in his (Bagnet) pocket,
``how is she (woman) going? What money has she (woman) got?'' (guardian)

Mrs. Bagnet made another application to her (Bagnet) skirts and brought forth a leathern purse in which she (Bagnet) hastily counted over a few shillings and which she (Bagnet) then shut up with perfect satisfaction.

``Never you mind for me, miss. I'm a soldier's wife and accustomed to travel my own way. Lignum, old boy,'' (him)
kissing him (Bagnet),
``one for yourself, three for the children. Now I'm away into Lincolnshire after George's mother!'' (him)

And she (Bagnet) actually set off while we three stood looking at one another lost in amazement. She (Bagnet) actually trudged away in her (Bagnet) grey cloak at a sturdy pace, and turned the corner, and was gone.

``Mr. Bagnet,'' (guardian)
said my guardian.
``Do you mean to let her (mother) go in that way?'' (unknown)

``Can't help it,'' (he)
he (Bagnet) returned. ``Made her (mother) way home once from another quarter of the world. With the same grey cloak. And same umbrella. Whatever the old girl says, do. Do it! Whenever the old girl says, I
``LL do it. She (girl) does it.'' (unknown)

``Then she (girl) is as honest and genuine as she (girl) looks,'' (guardian)
rejoined my guardian,
``and it is impossible to say more for her (girl).'' (guardian)

``She (girl)'s Colour-Sergeant of the Nonpareil battalion,'' (Mr. Bagnet/Bagnet/Matthew Bagnet)
said Mr. Bagnet, looking at us over his (Bagnet) shoulder as he (Bagnet) went his (Bagnet) way also.
``And there's not such another. But I never own to it before her (girl). Discipline must be maintained.'' (Mr.)

CHAPTER LIII

The Track

Mr. Bucket and his (Mr.) fat forefinger are much in consultation together under existing circumstances. When Mr. Bucket has a matter of this pressing interest under his (Bucket) consideration, the fat forefinger seems to rise, to the dignity of a familiar demon. He (demon) puts it to his (demon) ears, and it whispers information; he (demon) puts it to his (demon) lips, and it enjoins him (demon) to secrecy; he (demon) rubs it over his (demon) nose, and it sharpens his (demon) scent; he (demon) shakes it before a guilty man, and it charms him (demon) to his (demon) destruction. The Augurs of the Detective Temple invariably predict that when Mr. Bucket and that finger are in much conference, a terrible avenger will be heard of before long.

Otherwise mildly studious in his (Mr.) observation of human nature, on the whole a benignant philosopher not disposed to be severe upon the follies of mankind, Mr. Bucket pervades a vast number of houses and strolls about an infinity of streets, to outward appearance rather languishing for want of an object. He (Mr.) is in the friendliest condition towards his (Mr.) species and will drink with most of them. He (Mr.) is free with his (Mr.) money, affable in his (Mr.) manners, innocent in his (Mr.) conversation--but through the placid stream of his (Mr.) life there glides an under-current of forefinger.

Time and place cannot bind Mr. Bucket. Like man in the abstract, he (Mr.) is here to-day and gone to-morrow--but, very unlike man indeed, he (man) is here again the next day. This evening he (man) will be casually looking into the iron extinguishers at the door of Sir Leicester Dedlock's house in town; and to-morrow morning he (man) will be walking on the leads at Chesney Wold, where erst the old man walked whose ghost is propitiated with a hundred guineas. Drawers, desks, pockets, all things belonging to him (man), Mr. Bucket examines. A few hours afterwards, he (Mr.) and the Roman will be alone together comparing forefingers.

It is likely that these occupations are irreconcilable with home enjoyment, but it is certain that Mr. Bucket at present does not go home. Though in general he (Bucket) highly appreciates the society of Mrs. Bucket--a lady of a natural detective genius, which if it had been improved by professional exercise, might have done great things, but which has paused at the level of a clever amateur--he (detective) holds himself aloof from that dear solace. Mrs. Bucket is dependent on their lodger -LRB-fortunately an amiable lady in whom she (lady) takes an interest-RRB- for companionship and conversation.

A great crowd assembles in Lincoln's Inn Fields on the day of the funeral. Sir Leicester Dedlock attends the ceremony in person; strictly speaking, there are only three other human followers, that is to say, Lord Doodle, William Buffy, and the debilitated cousin -LRB-thrown in as a make-weight-RRB-, but the amount of inconsolable carriages is immense. The peerage contributes more four-wheeled affliction than has ever been seen in that neighbourhood. Such is the assemblage of armorial bearings on coach panels that the Herald's College might be supposed to have lost its father and mother at a blow. The Duke of Foodle sends a splendid pile of dust and ashes, with silver wheel-boxes, patent axles, all the last improvements, and three bereaved worms, six feet high, holding on behind, in a bunch of woe. All the state coachmen in London seem plunged into mourning; and if that dead old man of the rusty garb be not beyond a taste in horseflesh -LRB-which appears impossible-RRB-, it must be highly gratified this day.

Quiet among the undertakers and the equipages and the calves of so many legs all steeped in grief, Mr. Bucket sits concealed in one of the inconsolable carriages and at his (Bucket) ease surveys the crowd through the lattice blinds. He (Bucket) has a keen eye for a crowd--as for what not?--and looking here and there, now from this side of the carriage, now from the other, now up at the house windows, now along the people's heads, nothing escapes him (Bucket).

``And there you are, my partner, eh?'' (Mr. Bucket)
says Mr. Bucket to himself, apostrophizing Mrs. Bucket, stationed, by his (Bucket) favour, on the steps of the deceased's house.
``And so you are. And so you are! And very well indeed you are looking, Mrs. Bucket!'' (unknown)

The procession has not started yet, but is waiting for the cause of its assemblage to be brought out. Mr. Bucket, in the foremost emblazoned carriage, uses his (Mr.) two fat forefingers to hold the lattice a hair's breadth open while he (Mr.) looks.

And it says a great deal for his (Mr.) attachment, as a husband, that he (Mr.) is still occupied with Mrs. B.

``There you are, my partner, eh?'' (he)
he (Mr.) murmuringly repeats.
``And our lodger with you. I'm taking notice of you, Mrs. Bucket; I hope you're all right in your health, my dear!'' (Mr.)

Not another word does Mr. Bucket say, but sits with most attentive eyes until the sacked depository of noble secrets is brought down--Where are all those secrets now? Does he (Mr.) keep them yet? Did they fly with him (Mr.) on that sudden journey?--and until the procession moves, and Mr. Bucket's view is changed. After which he (Bucket) composes himself for an easy ride and takes note of the fittings of the carriage in case he (Bucket) should ever find such knowledge useful.

Contrast enough between Mr. Tulkinghorn shut up in his (Tulkinghorn) dark carriage and Mr. Bucket shut up in HIS (Bucket). Between the immeasurable track of space beyond the little wound that has thrown the one into the fixed sleep which jolts so heavily over the stones of the streets, and the narrow track of blood which keeps the other in the watchful state expressed in every hair of his (Bucket) head! But it is all one to both; neither is troubled about that.

Mr. Bucket sits out the procession in his (Bucket) own easy manner and glides from the carriage when the opportunity he (Bucket) has settled with himself arrives. He (Bucket) makes for Sir Leicester Dedlock's, which is at present a sort of home to him (Bucket), where he (Bucket) comes and goes as he (Bucket) likes at all hours, where he (Bucket) is always welcome and made much of, where he (Bucket) knows the whole establishment, and walks in an atmosphere of mysterious greatness.

No knocking or ringing for Mr. Bucket. He (Mr.) has caused himself to be provided with a key and can pass in at his (Mr.) pleasure. As he (Mr.) is crossing the hall, Mercury informs him (Mr.),

``Here's another letter for you, Mr. Bucket, come by post,'' (him)
and gives it him (Mr.).

``Another one, eh?'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.

If Mercury should chance to be possessed by any lingering curiosity as to Mr. Bucket's letters, that wary person is not the man to gratify it. Mr. Bucket looks at him (Mr.) as if his (Mr.) face were a vista of some miles in length and he (Mr.) were leisurely contemplating the same.

``Do you happen to carry a box?'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.

Unfortunately Mercury is no snuff-taker.

``Could you fetch me a pinch from anywheres?'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.
``Thankee. It don't matter what it is; I'm not particular as to the kind. Thankee!'' (somebody)

Having leisurely helped himself from a canister borrowed from somebody downstairs for the purpose, and having made a considerable show of tasting it, first with one side of his (Mr.) nose and then with the other, Mr. Bucket, with much deliberation, pronounces it of the right sort and goes on, letter in hand.

Now although Mr. Bucket walks upstairs to the little library within the larger one with the face of a man who receives some scores of letters every day, it happens that much correspondence is not incidental to his (Mr.) life. He (Mr.) is no great scribe, rather handling his (Mr.) pen like the pocket-staff he (Mr.) carries about with him (Mr.) always convenient to his (Mr.) grasp, and discourages correspondence with himself in others as being too artless and direct a way of doing delicate business. Further, he (Mr.) often sees damaging letters produced in evidence and has occasion to reflect that it was a green thing to write them. For these reasons he (Mr.) has very little to do with letters, either as sender or receiver. And yet he (Mr.) has received a round half-dozen within the last twenty-four hours.

``And this,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket, spreading it out on the table,
``is in the same hand, and consists of the same two words.'' (Mr.)

What two words?

He (Mr.) turns the key in the door, ungirdles his (Mr.) black pocket-book -LRB-book of fate to many-RRB-, lays another letter by it, and reads, boldly written in each,

``Lady Dedlock.'' (He)

``Yes, yes,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.
``But I could have made the money without this anonymous information.'' (he)

Having put the letters in his (Mr.) book of fate and girdled it up again, he (Mr.) unlocks the door just in time to admit his (Mr.) dinner, which is brought upon a goodly tray with a decanter of sherry. Mr. Bucket frequently observes, in friendly circles where there is no restraint, that he (Mr.) likes a toothful of your fine old brown East Inder sherry better than anything you can offer him (Mr.). Consequently he (Mr.) fills and empties his (Mr.) glass with a smack of his (Mr.) lips and is proceeding with his (Mr.) refreshment when an idea enters his (Mr.) mind.

Mr. Bucket softly opens the door of communication between that room and the next and looks in. The library is deserted, and the fire is sinking low. Mr. Bucket's eye, after taking a pigeon-flight round the room, alights upon a table where letters are usually put as they arrive. Several letters for Sir Leicester are upon it. Mr. Bucket draws near and examines the directions.

``No,'' (he)
he (Mr.) says,
``there's none in that hand. It's only me as is written to. I can break it to Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, to-morrow.'' (he)

With that he (Mr.) returns to finish his (Mr.) dinner with a good appetite, and after a light nap, is summoned into the drawing-room. Sir Leicester has received him (Mr.) there these several evenings past to know whether he (Mr.) has anything to report. The debilitated cousin -LRB-much exhausted by the funeral-RRB- and Volumnia are in attendance.

Mr. Bucket makes three distinctly different bows to these three people. A bow of homage to Sir Leicester, a bow of gallantry to Volumnia, and a bow of recognition to the debilitated Cousin, to whom it airily says,

``You are a swell about town, and you know me, and I know you.'' (the Cousin)
Having distributed these little specimens of his (Cousin) tact, Mr. Bucket rubs his (Bucket) hands.

``Have you anything new to communicate, officer?'' (unknown)
inquires Sir Leicester.
``Do you wish to hold any conversation with me in private?'' (unknown)

``Why--not to-night, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet.'' (unknown)

``Because my time,'' (Mr.)
pursues Sir Leicester,
``is wholly at your disposal with a view to the vindication of the outraged majesty of the law.'' (Mr.)

Mr. Bucket coughs and glances at Volumnia, rouged and necklaced, as though he (Mr.) would respectfully observe,

``I do assure you, you're a pretty creetur. I've seen hundreds worse looking at your time of life, I have indeed.'' (he)

The fair Volumnia, not quite unconscious perhaps of the humanizing influence of her (Bucket) charms, pauses in the writing of cocked-hat notes and meditatively adjusts the pearl necklace. Mr. Bucket prices that decoration in his (Mr.) mind and thinks it as likely as not that Volumnia is writing poetry.

``If I have not,'' (unknown)
pursues Sir Leicester,
``in the most emphatic manner, adjured you, officer, to exercise your utmost skill in this atrocious case, I particularly desire to take the present opportunity of rectifying any omission I may have made. Let no expense be a consideration. I am prepared to defray all charges. You can incur none in pursuit of the object you have undertaken that I shall hesitate for a moment to bear.'' (Mr. Bucket)

Mr. Bucket made Sir Leicester's bow again as a response to this liberality.

``My mind,'' (Leicester Dedlock/Leicester/Dedlock)
Sir Leicester adds with a generous warmth,
``has not, as may be easily supposed, recovered its tone since the late diabolical occurrence. It is not likely ever to recover its tone. But it is full of indignation to-night after undergoing the ordeal of consigning to the tomb the remains of a faithful, a zealous, a devoted adherent.'' (Leicester Dedlock/Leicester/Dedlock)

Sir Leicester's voice trembles and his (Bucket) grey hair stirs upon his (Bucket) head. Tears are in his (Bucket) eyes; the best part of his (Bucket) nature is aroused.

``I declare,'' (he)
he (Bucket) says,
``I solemnly declare that until this crime is discovered and, in the course of justice, punished, I almost feel as if there were a stain upon my name. A gentleman who has devoted a large portion of his (gentleman) life to me, a gentleman who has devoted the last day of his (gentleman) life to me, a gentleman who has constantly sat at my table and slept under my roof, goes from my house to his (gentleman) own, and is struck down within an hour of his (gentleman) leaving my house. I cannot say but that he (gentleman) may have been followed from my house, watched at my house, even first marked because of his (gentleman) association with my house--which may have suggested his (gentleman) possessing greater wealth and being altogether of greater importance than his (gentleman) own retiring demeanour would have indicated. If I cannot with my means and influence and my position bring all the perpetrators of such a crime to light, I fail in the assertion of my respect for that gentleman's memory and of my fidelity towards one who was ever faithful to me.'' (he)

While he (Bucket) makes this protestation with great emotion and earnestness, looking round the room as if he (Bucket) were addressing an assembly, Mr. Bucket glances at him (Bucket) with an observant gravity in which there might be, but for the audacity of the thought, a touch of compassion.

``The ceremony of to-day,'' (he)
continues Sir Leicester,
``strikingly illustrative of the respect in which my deceased friend'' (he)
--he (Bucket) lays a stress upon the word, for death levels all distinctions--
``was held by the flower of the land, has, I say, aggravated the shock I have received from this most horrible and audacious crime. If it were my brother who had committed it, I would not spare him (brother).'' (he)

Mr. Bucket looks very grave. Volumnia remarks of the deceased that he (Mr.) was the trustiest and dearest person!

``You must feel it as a deprivation to you, miss,'' (Mr.)
replies Mr. Bucket soothingly,
``no doubt. He (brother) was calculated to BE a deprivation, I'm sure he (brother) was.'' (Mr.)

Volumnia gives Mr. Bucket to understand, in reply, that her (Mr.) sensitive mind is fully made up never to get the better of it as long as she (Mr.) lives, that her (Mr.) nerves are unstrung for ever, and that she (Mr.) has not the least expectation of ever smiling again. Meanwhile she (Mr.) folds up a cocked hat for that redoubtable old general at Bath, descriptive of her (Mr.) melancholy condition.

``It gives a start to a delicate female,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket sympathetically,
``but it'll wear off.'' (Mr.)

Volumnia wishes of all things to know what is doing? Whether they are going to convict, or whatever it is, that dreadful soldier? Whether he (soldier) had any accomplices, or whatever the thing is called in the law? And a great deal more to the like artless purpose.

``Why you see, miss,'' (Mr. Bucket)
returns Mr. Bucket, bringing the finger into persuasive action--and such is his (Bucket) natural gallantry that he (Bucket) had almost said
``my dear'' (he)
--
``it ain't easy to answer those questions at the present moment. Not at the present moment. I've kept myself on this case, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet,'' (he)
whom Mr. Bucket takes into the conversation in right of his (Bucket) importance,
``morning, noon, and night. But for a glass or two of sherry, I don't think I could have had my mind so much upon the stretch as it has been. I COULD answer your questions, miss, but duty forbids it. Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, will very soon be made acquainted with all that has been traced. And I hope that he (I) may find it'' (Mr. Bucket)
--Mr. Bucket again looks grave--
``to his (I) satisfaction.'' (Mr. Bucket)

The debilitated cousin only hopes some fler'll be executed--zample. Thinks more interest's wanted--get man hanged presentime--than get man place ten thousand a year. Hasn't a doubt--zample--far better hang wrong fler than no fler.

``YOU know life, you know, sir,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket with a complimentary twinkle of his (Mr.) eye and crook of his (Mr.) finger,
``and you can confirm what I've mentioned to this lady. YOU don't want to be told that from information I have received I have gone to work. You're up to what a lady can't be expected to be up to. Lord! Especially in your elevated station of society, miss,'' (crook)
says Mr. Bucket, quite reddening at another narrow escape from
``my dear.'' (Mr.)

``The officer, Volumnia,'' (Mr.)
observes Sir Leicester,
``is faithful to his (officer) duty, and perfectly right.'' (Mr.)

Mr. Bucket murmurs,

``Glad to have the honour of your approbation, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet.'' (Mr.)

``In fact, Volumnia,'' (unknown)
proceeds Sir Leicester,
``it is not holding up a good model for imitation to ask the officer any such questions as you have put to him (officer). He (officer) is the best judge of his (officer) own responsibility; he (officer) acts upon his (officer) responsibility. And it does not become us, who assist in making the laws, to impede or interfere with those who carry them into execution. Or,'' (he)
says Sir Leicester somewhat sternly, for Volumnia was going to cut in before he (Mr.) had rounded his (Mr.) sentence,
``or who vindicate their outraged majesty.'' (he)

Volumnia with all humility explains that she (Mr.) had not merely the plea of curiosity to urge -LRB-in common with the giddy youth of her (Mr.) sex in general-RRB- but that she (Mr.) is perfectly dying with regret and interest for the darling man whose loss they all deplore.

``Very well, Volumnia,'' (unknown)
returns Sir Leicester.
``Then you cannot be too discreet.'' (Mr. Bucket)

Mr. Bucket takes the opportunity of a pause to be heard again.

``Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, I have no objections to telling this lady, with your leave and among ourselves, that I look upon the case as pretty well complete. It is a beautiful case--a beautiful case--and what little is wanting to complete it, I expect to be able to supply in a few hours.'' (unknown)

``I am very glad indeed to hear it,'' (unknown)
says Sir Leicester.
``Highly creditable to you.'' (unknown)

``Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet,'' (Mr. Bucket)
returns Mr. Bucket very seriously,
``I hope it may at one and the same time do me credit and prove satisfactory to all. When I depict it as a beautiful case, you see, miss,'' (Mr. Bucket)
Mr. Bucket goes on, glancing gravely at Sir Leicester,
``I mean from my point of view. As considered from other points of view, such cases will always involve more or less unpleasantness. Very strange things comes to our knowledge in families, miss; bless your heart, what you would think to be phenomenons, quite.'' (Mr. Bucket)

Volumnia, with her (Mr.) innocent little scream, supposes so.

``Aye, and even in gen-teel families, in high families, in great families,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket, again gravely eyeing Sir Leicester aside.
``I have had the honour of being employed in high families before, and you have no idea--come, I'll go so far as to say not even YOU have any idea, sir,'' (the cousin)
this to the debilitated cousin,
``what games goes on!'' (the cousin)

The cousin, who has been casting sofa-pillows on his (cousin) head, in a prostration of boredom yawns,

``Vayli,'' (The cousin)
being the used-up for
``very likely.'' (The cousin)

Sir Leicester, deeming it time to dismiss the officer, here majestically interposes with the words,

``Very good. Thank you!'' (the officer)
and also with a wave of his (officer) hand, implying not only that there is an end of the discourse, but that if high families fall into low habits they must take the consequences.
``You will not forget, officer,'' (he)
he (officer) adds with condescension,
``that I am at your disposal when you please.'' (he)

Mr. Bucket -LRB-still grave-RRB- inquires if to-morrow morning, now, would suit, in case he (Mr.) should be as for`ard as he (Mr.) expects to be. Sir Leicester replies,

``All times are alike to me.'' (Mr.)
Mr. Bucket makes his (Mr.) three bows and is withdrawing when a forgotten point occurs to him (Mr.).

``Might I ask, by the by,'' (he)
he (Mr.) says in a low voice, cautiously returning,
``who posted the reward-bill on the staircase.'' (he)

``I ordered it to be put up there,'' (unknown)
replies Sir Leicester.

``Would it be considered a liberty, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, if I was to ask you why?'' (unknown)

``Not at all. I chose it as a conspicuous part of the house. I think it cannot be too prominently kept before the whole establishment. I wish my people to be impressed with the enormity of the crime, the determination to punish it, and the hopelessness of escape. At the same time, officer, if you in your better knowledge of the subject see any objection--'' (Mr. Bucket)

Mr. Bucket sees none now; the bill having been put up, had better not be taken down. Repeating his (Bucket) three bows he (Bucket) withdraws, closing the door on Volumnia's little scream, which is a preliminary to her (Mr.) remarking that that charmingly horrible person is a perfect Blue Chamber.

In his (Bucket) fondness for society and his (Bucket) adaptability to all grades, Mr. Bucket is presently standing before the hall-fire--bright and warm on the early winter night--admiring Mercury.

``Why, you're six foot two, I suppose?'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.

``Three,'' (unknown)
says Mercury.

``Are you so much? But then, you see, you're broad in proportion and don't look it. You're not one of the weak-legged ones, you ain't. Was you ever modelled now?'' (Mr. Bucket)
Mr. Bucket asks, conveying the expression of an artist into the turn of his (Bucket) eye and head.

Mercury never was modelled.

``Then you ought to be, you know,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket;
``and a friend of mine that you'll hear of one day as a Royal Academy sculptor would stand something handsome to make a drawing of your proportions for the marble. My Lady's out, ain't she (Lady)?'' (Mr.)

``Out to dinner.'' (unknown)

``Goes out pretty well every day, don't she (Lady)?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``Not to be wondered at!'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.
``Such a fine woman as her (woman), so handsome and so graceful and so elegant, is like a fresh lemon on a dinner-table, ornamental wherever she (woman) goes. Was your father in the same way of life as yourself?'' (unknown)

Answer in the negative.

``Mine was,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.
``My father was first a page, then a footman, then a butler, then a steward, then an inn-keeper. Lived universally respected, and died lamented. Said with his (Said) last breath that he (Said) considered service the most honourable part of his (Said) career, and so it was. I've a brother in service, AND a brother-in-law. My Lady a good temper?'' (unknown)

Mercury replies,

``As good as you can expect.'' (unknown)

``Ah!'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.
``A little spoilt? A little capricious? Lord! What can you anticipate when they're so handsome as that? And we like 'em all the better for it, don't we?'' (a man)

Mercury, with his (Mr.) hands in the pockets of his (Mr.) bright peach-blossom small-clothes, stretches his (Mr.) symmetrical silk legs with the air of a man of gallantry and can't deny it. Come the roll of wheels and a violent ringing at the bell.

``Talk of the angels,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.
``Here she (Lady) is!'' (she)

The doors are thrown open, and she (Mr.) passes through the hall. Still very pale, she (Mr.) is dressed in slight mourning and wears two beautiful bracelets. Either their beauty or the beauty of her (Mr.) arms is particularly attractive to Mr. Bucket. He (Mr.) looks at them with an eager eye and rattles something in his (Mr.) pocket--halfpence perhaps.

Noticing him (Mr.) at his (Mr.) distance, she (Mr.) turns an inquiring look on the other Mercury who has brought her (Mr.) home.

``Mr. Bucket, my Lady.'' (Mr.)

Mr. Bucket makes a leg and comes forward, passing his (Mr.) familiar demon over the region of his (Mr.) mouth.

``Are you waiting to see Sir Leicester?'' (unknown)

``No, my Lady, I've seen him (Mr.)!'' (unknown)

``Have you anything to say to me?'' (unknown)

``Not just at present, my Lady.'' (unknown)

``Have you made any new discoveries?'' (unknown)

``A few, my Lady.'' (unknown)

This is merely in passing. She (Mr.) scarcely makes a stop, and sweeps upstairs alone. Mr. Bucket, moving towards the staircase-foot, watches her (Mr.) as she (Mr.) goes up the steps the old man came down to his (man) grave, past murderous groups of statuary repeated with their shadowy weapons on the wall, past the printed bill, which she (Mr.) looks at going by, out of view.

``She (Lady)'s a lovely woman, too, she (Lady) really is,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket, coming back to Mercury.
``Don't look quite healthy though.'' (him)

Is not quite healthy, Mercury informs him (Mr.). Suffers much from headaches.

Really? That's a pity! Walking, Mr. Bucket would recommend for that. Well, she (Mr.) tries walking, Mercury rejoins. Walks sometimes for two hours when she (Mr.) has them bad. By night, too.

``Are you sure you're quite so much as six foot three?'' (Mr.)
asks Mr. Bucket.
``Begging your pardon for interrupting you a moment?'' (unknown)

Not a doubt about it.

``You're so well put together that I shouldn't have thought it. But the household troops, though considered fine men, are built so straggling. Walks by night, does she (Lady)? When it's moonlight, though?'' (unknown)

Oh, yes. When it's moonlight! Of course. Oh, of course! Conversational and acquiescent on both sides.

``I suppose you ain't in the habit of walking yourself?'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.
``Not much time for it, I should say?'' (unknown)

Besides which, Mercury don't like it. Prefers carriage exercise.

``To be sure,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.
``That makes a difference. Now I think of it,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket, warming his (Mr.) hands and looking pleasantly at the blaze,
``she (Lady) went out walking the very night of this business.'' (Mr.)

``To be sure she (Lady) did! I let her (Lady) into the garden over the way.'' (unknown)

``And left her (Lady) there. Certainly you did. I saw you doing it.'' (unknown)

``I didn't see YOU,'' (unknown)
says Mercury.

``I was rather in a hurry,'' (Mr. Bucket)
returns Mr. Bucket,
``for I was going to visit a aunt of mine that lives at Chelsea--next door but two to the old original Bun House--ninety year old the old lady is, a single woman, and got a little property. Yes, I chanced to be passing at the time. Let's see. What time might it be? It wasn't ten.'' (Mr. Bucket)

``Half-past nine.'' (unknown)

``You're right. So it was. And if I don't deceive myself, my Lady was muffled in a loose black mantle, with a deep fringe to it?'' (unknown)

``Of course she (Lady) was.'' (she)

Of course she (Mr.) was. Mr. Bucket must return to a little work he (Bucket) has to get on with upstairs, but he (Bucket) must shake hands with Mercury in acknowledgment of his (Bucket) agreeable conversation, and will he (Bucket)--this is all he (Bucket) asks--will he (Bucket), when he (Bucket) has a leisure half-hour, think of bestowing it on that Royal Academy sculptor, for the advantage of both parties?

CHAPTER LIV

Springing a Mine

Refreshed by sleep, Mr. Bucket rises betimes in the morning and prepares for a field-day. Smartened up by the aid of a clean shirt and a wet hairbrush, with which instrument, on occasions of ceremony, he (Mr.) lubricates such thin locks as remain to him (Mr.) after his (Mr.) life of severe study, Mr. Bucket lays in a breakfast of two mutton chops as a foundation to work upon, together with tea, eggs, toast, and marmalade on a corresponding scale. Having much enjoyed these strengthening matters and having held subtle conference with his (Bucket) familiar demon, he (Bucket) confidently instructs Mercury

``just to mention quietly to Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, that whenever he (it)'s ready for me, I'm ready for him (it).'' (he)
A gracious message being returned that Sir Leicester will expedite his (Bucket) dressing and join Mr. Bucket in the library within ten minutes, Mr. Bucket repairs to that apartment and stands before the fire with his (Mr.) finger on his (Mr.) chin, looking at the blazing coals.

Thoughtful Mr. Bucket is, as a man may be with weighty work to do, but composed, sure, confident. From the expression of his (Mr.) face he (Mr.) might be a famous whist-player for a large stake--say a hundred guineas certain--with the game in his (Mr.) hand, but with a high reputation involved in his (Mr.) playing his (Mr.) hand out to the last card in a masterly way. Not in the least anxious or disturbed is Mr. Bucket when Sir Leicester appears, but he (Mr.) eyes the baronet aside as he (Mr.) comes slowly to his (Mr.) easy-chair with that observant gravity of yesterday in which there might have been yesterday, but for the audacity of the idea, a touch of compassion.

``I am sorry to have kept you waiting, officer, but I am rather later than my usual hour this morning. I am not well. The agitation and the indignation from which I have recently suffered have been too much for me. I am subject to--gout'' (Leicester Dedlock/Leicester/Dedlock)
--Sir Leicester was going to say indisposition and would have said it to anybody else, but Mr. Bucket palpably knows all about it--
``and recent circumstances have brought it on.'' (Mr.)

As he (Mr.) takes his (Mr.) seat with some difficulty and with an air of pain, Mr. Bucket draws a little nearer, standing with one of his (Mr.) large hands on the library-table.

``I am not aware, officer,'' (Leicester Dedlock/Leicester/Dedlock)
Sir Leicester observes; raising his (Mr.) eyes to his (Mr.) face,
``whether you wish us to be alone, but that is entirely as you please. If you do, well and good. If not, Miss Dedlock would be interested--'' (Leicester Dedlock/Leicester/Dedlock)

``Why, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet,'' (Mr. Bucket)
returns Mr. Bucket with his (Bucket) head persuasively on one side and his (Bucket) forefinger pendant at one ear like an earring,
``we can't be too private just at present. You will presently see that we can't be too private. A lady, under the circumstances, and especially in Miss Dedlock's elevated station of society, can't but be agreeable to me, but speaking without a view to myself, I will take the liberty of assuring you that I know we can't be too private.'' (Mr. Bucket)

``That is enough.'' (unknown)

``So much so, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet,'' (Mr.)
Mr. Bucket resumes,
``that I was on the point of asking your permission to turn the key in the door.'' (Mr.)

``By all means.'' (Mr.)
Mr. Bucket skilfully and softly takes that precaution, stooping on his (Mr.) knee for a moment from mere force of habit so to adjust the key in the lock as that no one shall peep in from the outerside.

``Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, I mentioned yesterday evening that I wanted but a very little to complete this case. I have now completed it and collected proof against the person who did this crime.'' (unknown)

``Against the soldier?'' (unknown)

``No, Sir Leicester Dedlock; not the soldier.'' (unknown)

Sir Leicester looks astounded and inquires,

``Is the man in custody?'' (Mr. Bucket)

Mr. Bucket tells him (Bucket), after a pause,

``It was a woman.'' (him)

Sir Leicester leans back in his (Bucket) chair, and breathlessly ejaculates,

``Good heaven!'' (Leicester Dedlock/Leicester/Dedlock)

``Now, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet,'' (Mr.)
Mr. Bucket begins, standing over him (Mr.) with one hand spread out on the library-table and the forefinger of the other in impressive use,
``it's my duty to prepare you for a train of circumstances that may, and I go so far as to say that will, give you a shock. But Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, you are a gentleman, and I know what a gentleman is and what a gentleman is capable of. A gentleman can bear a shock when it must come, boldly and steadily. A gentleman can make up his (gentleman) mind to stand up against almost any blow. Why, take yourself, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet. If there's a blow to be inflicted on you, you naturally think of your family. You ask yourself, how would all them ancestors of yours, away to Julius Caesar--not to go beyond him (Caesar) at present--have borne that blow; you remember scores of them that would have borne it well; and you bear it well on their accounts, and to maintain the family credit. That's the way you argue, and that's the way you act, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet.'' (him)

Sir Leicester, leaning back in his (Mr.) chair and grasping the elbows, sits looking at him (Mr.) with a stony face.

``Now, Sir Leicester Dedlock,'' (Mr.)
proceeds Mr. Bucket,
``thus preparing you, let me beg of you not to trouble your mind for a moment as to anything having come to MY knowledge. I know so much about so many characters, high and low, that a piece of information more or less don't signify a straw. I don't suppose there's a move on the board that would surprise ME, and as to this or that move having taken place, why my knowing it is no odds at all, any possible move whatever -LRB-provided it's in a wrong direction-RRB- being a probable move according to my experience. Therefore, what I say to you, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, is, don't you go and let yourself be put out of the way because of my knowing anything of your family affairs.'' (Mr.)

``I thank you for your preparation,'' (unknown)
returns Sir Leicester after a silence, without moving hand, foot, or feature,
``which I hope is not necessary; though I give it credit for being well intended. Be so good as to go on. Also'' (Leicester Dedlock/Leicester/Dedlock)
--Sir Leicester seems to shrink in the shadow of his (Mr.) figure--
``also, to take a seat, if you have no objection.'' (Leicester Dedlock/Leicester/Dedlock)

None at all. Mr. Bucket brings a chair and diminishes his (Mr.) shadow.

``Now, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, with this short preface I come to the point. Lady Dedlock--'' (him)

Sir Leicester raises himself in his (Mr.) seat and stares at him (Mr.) fiercely. Mr. Bucket brings the finger into play as an emollient.

``Lady Dedlock, you see she (Lady)'s universally admired. That's what her (Lady) ladyship is; she (Lady)'s universally admired,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.

``I would greatly prefer, officer,'' (Leicester Dedlock/Leicester/Dedlock)
Sir Leicester returns stiffly,
``my Lady's name being entirely omitted from this discussion.'' (Leicester Dedlock/Leicester/Dedlock)

``So would I, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, but--it's impossible.'' (unknown)

``Impossible?'' (Mr. Bucket)

Mr. Bucket shakes his (Bucket) relentless head.

``Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, it's altogether impossible. What I have got to say is about her (Lady) ladyship. She (Lady) is the pivot it all turns on.'' (unknown)

``Officer,'' (a lip)
retorts Sir Leicester with a fiery eye and a quivering lip,
``you know your duty. Do your duty, but be careful not to overstep it. I would not suffer it. I would not endure it. You bring my Lady's name into this communication upon your responsibility--upon your responsibility. My Lady's name is not a name for common persons to trifle with!'' (a lip)

``Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, I say what I must say, and no more.'' (unknown)

``I hope it may prove so. Very well. Go on. Go on, sir!'' (him)
Glancing at the angry eyes which now avoid him (Bucket) and at the angry figure trembling from head to foot, yet striving to be still, Mr. Bucket feels his (Bucket) way with his (Bucket) forefinger and in a low voice proceeds.

``Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, it becomes my duty to tell you that the deceased Mr. Tulkinghorn long entertained mistrusts and suspicions of Lady Dedlock.'' (unknown)

``If he (Tulkinghorn) had dared to breathe them to me, sir--which he (Tulkinghorn) never did--I would have killed him (Tulkinghorn) myself!'' (Sir Leicester)
exclaims Sir Leicester, striking his (Leicester) hand upon the table. But in the very heat and fury of the act he (Leicester) stops, fixed by the knowing eyes of Mr. Bucket, whose forefinger is slowly going and who, with mingled confidence and patience, shakes his (Mr.) head.

``Sir Leicester Dedlock, the deceased Mr. Tulkinghorn was deep and close, and what he (Tulkinghorn) fully had in his (Tulkinghorn) mind in the very beginning I can't quite take upon myself to say. But I know from his (Tulkinghorn) lips that he (Tulkinghorn) long ago suspected Lady Dedlock of having discovered, through the sight of some handwriting--in this very house, and when you yourself, Sir Leicester Dedlock, were present--the existence, in great poverty, of a certain person who had been her (Dedlock) lover before you courted her (Dedlock) and who ought to have been her (Dedlock) husband.'' (Mr.)
Mr. Bucket stops and deliberately repeats,
``Ought to have been her (Dedlock) husband, not a doubt about it. I know from his (husband) lips that when that person soon afterwards died, he (husband) suspected Lady Dedlock of visiting his (husband) wretched lodging and his (husband) wretched grave, alone and in secret. I know from my own inquiries and through my eyes and ears that Lady Dedlock did make such visit in the dress of her (Dedlock) own maid, for the deceased Mr. Tulkinghorn employed me to reckon up her (Dedlock) ladyship--if you'll excuse my making use of the term we commonly employ--and I reckoned her (Dedlock) up, so far, completely. I confronted the maid in the chambers in Lincoln's Inn Fields with a witness who had been Lady Dedlock's guide, and there couldn't be the shadow of a doubt that she (Dedlock) had worn the young woman's dress, unknown to her (Dedlock). Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, I did endeavour to pave the way a little towards these unpleasant disclosures yesterday by saying that very strange things happened even in high families sometimes. All this, and more, has happened in your own family, and to and through your own Lady. It's my belief that the deceased Mr. Tulkinghorn followed up these inquiries to the hour of his (Tulkinghorn) death and that he (Tulkinghorn) and Lady Dedlock even had bad blood between them upon the matter that very night. Now, only you put that to Lady Dedlock, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, and ask her (Dedlock) ladyship whether, even after he (Tulkinghorn) had left here, she (Dedlock) didn't go down to his (Tulkinghorn) chambers with the intention of saying something further to him (Tulkinghorn), dressed in a loose black mantle with a deep fringe to it.'' (Mr.)

Sir Leicester sits like a statue, gazing at the cruel finger that is probing the life-blood of his (Mr.) heart.

``You put that to her (Dedlock) ladyship, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, from me, Inspector Bucket of the Detective. And if her (Dedlock) ladyship makes any difficulty about admitting of it, you tell her (Dedlock) that it's no use, that Inspector Bucket knows it and knows that she (Dedlock) passed the soldier as you called him (soldier) -LRB-though he (soldier)'s not in the army now-RRB- and knows that she (Dedlock) knows she (Dedlock) passed him (soldier) on the staircase. Now, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, why do I relate all this?'' (Leicester Dedlock/Leicester/Dedlock)

Sir Leicester, who has covered his (Mr.) face with his (Mr.) hands, uttering a single groan, requests him (Mr.) to pause for a moment. By and by he (Mr.) takes his (Mr.) hands away, and so preserves his (Mr.) dignity and outward calmness, though there is no more colour in his (Mr.) face than in his (Mr.) white hair, that Mr. Bucket is a little awed by him (Mr.). Something frozen and fixed is upon his (Mr.) manner, over and above its usual shell of haughtiness, and Mr. Bucket soon detects an unusual slowness in his (Mr.) speech, with now and then a curious trouble in beginning, which occasions him (Mr.) to utter inarticulate sounds. With such sounds he (Mr.) now breaks silence, soon, however, controlling himself to say that he (Mr.) does not comprehend why a gentleman so faithful and zealous as the late Mr. Tulkinghorn should have communicated to him (Tulkinghorn) nothing of this painful, this distressing, this unlooked-for, this overwhelming, this incredible intelligence.

``Again, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet,'' (Mr. Bucket)
returns Mr. Bucket,
``put it to her (Dedlock) ladyship to clear that up. Put it to her (Dedlock) ladyship, if you think it right, from Inspector Bucket of the Detective. You'll find, or I'm much mistaken, that the deceased Mr. Tulkinghorn had the intention of communicating the whole to you as soon as he (Tulkinghorn) considered it ripe, and further, that he (Tulkinghorn) had given her (Dedlock) ladyship so to understand. Why, he (Tulkinghorn) might have been going to reveal it the very morning when I examined the body! You don't know what I'm going to say and do five minutes from this present time, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet; and supposing I was to be picked off now, you might wonder why I hadn't done it, don't you see?'' (Mr. Bucket)

True. Sir Leicester, avoiding, with some trouble those obtrusive sounds, says,

``True.'' (unknown)
At this juncture a considerable noise of voices is heard in the hall. Mr. Bucket, after listening, goes to the library-door, softly unlocks and opens it, and listens again. Then he (Mr.) draws in his (Mr.) head and whispers hurriedly but composedly,
``Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, this unfortunate family affair has taken air, as I expected it might, the deceased Mr. Tulkinghorn being cut down so sudden. The chance to hush it is to let in these people now in a wrangle with your footmen. Would you mind sitting quiet--on the family account--while I reckon 'em up? And would you just throw in a nod when I seem to ask you for it?'' (he)

Sir Leicester indistinctly answers,

``Officer. The best you can, the best you can!'' (Mr.)
and Mr. Bucket, with a nod and a sagacious crook of the forefinger, slips down into the hall, where the voices quickly die away. He (Mr.) is not long in returning; a few paces ahead of Mercury and a brother deity also powdered and in peach-blossomed smalls, who bear between them a chair in which is an incapable old man. Another man and two women come behind. Directing the pitching of the chair in an affable and easy manner, Mr. Bucket dismisses the Mercuries and locks the door again. Sir Leicester looks on at this invasion of the sacred precincts with an icy stare.

``Now, perhaps you may know me, ladies and gentlemen,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket in a confidential voice.
``I am Inspector Bucket of the Detective, I am; and this,'' (staff)
producing the tip of his (Mr.) convenient little staff from his (Mr.) breast-pocket,
``is my authority. Now, you wanted to see Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet. Well! You do see him (Inspector), and mind you, it ain't every one as is admitted to that honour. Your name, old gentleman, is Smallweed; that's what your name is; I know it well.'' (staff)

``Well, and you never heard any harm of it!'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
cries Mr. Smallweed in a shrill loud voice.

``You don't happen to know why they killed the pig, do you?'' (Mr. Bucket)
retorts Mr. Bucket with a steadfast look, but without loss of temper.

``No!'' (unknown)

``Why, they killed him (gentleman),'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket,
``on account of his (gentleman) having so much cheek. Don't YOU get into the same position, because it isn't worthy of you. You ain't in the habit of conversing with a deaf person, are you?'' (Mr.)

``Yes,'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
snarls Mr. Smallweed,
``my wife's deaf.'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)

``That accounts for your pitching your voice so high. But as she (wife) ain't here; just pitch it an octave or two lower, will you, and I'll not only be obliged to you, but it'll do you more credit,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.
``This other gentleman is in the preaching line, I think?'' (unknown)

``Name of Chadband,'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
Mr. Smallweed puts in, speaking henceforth in a much lower key.

``Once had a friend and brother serjeant of the same name,'' (Mr. Bucket)
says Mr. Bucket, offering his (Bucket) hand,
``and consequently feel a liking for it. Mrs. Chadband, no doubt?'' (Mr. Bucket)

``And Mrs. Snagsby,'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
Mr. Smallweed introduces.

``Husband a law-stationer and a friend of my own,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.
``Love him (Husband) like a brother! Now, what's up?'' (unknown)

``Do you mean what business have we come upon?'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
Mr. Smallweed asks, a little dashed by the suddenness of this turn.

``Ah! You know what I mean. Let us hear what it's all about in presence of Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet. Come.'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)

Mr. Smallweed, beckoning Mr. Chadband, takes a moment's counsel with him (Smallweed) in a whisper. Mr. Chadband, expressing a considerable amount of oil from the pores of his (Chadband) forehead and the palms of his (Chadband) hands, says aloud,

``Yes. You first!'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)
and retires to his (Chadband) former place.

``I was the client and friend of Mr. Tulkinghorn,'' (Grandfather Smallweed)
pipes Grandfather Smallweed then;
``I did business with him (Tulkinghorn). I was useful to him (Tulkinghorn), and he (Tulkinghorn) was useful to me. Krook, dead and gone, was my brother-in-law. He (Krook) was own brother to a brimstone magpie--leastways Mrs. Smallweed. I come into Krook's property. I examined all his (Krook) papers and all his (Krook) effects. They was all dug out under my eyes. There was a bundle of letters belonging to a dead and gone lodger as was hid away at the back of a shelf in the side of Lady Jane's bed--his (Krook) cat's bed. He (Krook) hid all manner of things away, everywheres. Mr. Tulkinghorn wanted 'em and got 'em, but I looked 'em over first. I'm a man of business, and I took a squint at 'em. They was letters from the lodger's sweetheart, and she (sweetheart) signed Honoria. Dear me, that's not a common name, Honoria, is it? There's no lady in this house that signs Honoria is there? Oh, no, I don't think so! Oh, no, I don't think so! And not in the same hand, perhaps? Oh, no, I don't think so!'' (Grandfather Smallweed)

Here Mr. Smallweed, seized with a fit of coughing in the midst of his (Smallweed) triumph, breaks off to ejaculate,

``Oh, dear me! Oh, Lord! I'm shaken all to pieces!'' (the midst)

``Now, when you're ready,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket after awaiting his (Mr.) recovery,
``to come to anything that concerns Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, here the gentleman sits, you know.'' (Mr.)

``Haven't I come to it, Mr. Bucket?'' (Grandfather)
cries Grandfather Smallweed.
``Isn't the gentleman concerned yet? Not with Captain Hawdon, and his (Captain) ever affectionate Honoria, and their child into the bargain? Come, then, I want to know where those letters are. That concerns me, if it don't concern Sir Leicester Dedlock. I will know where they are. I won't have 'em disappear so quietly. I handed 'em over to my friend and solicitor, Mr. Tulkinghorn, not to anybody else.'' (unknown)

``Why, he (Tulkinghorn) paid you for them, you know, and handsome too,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.

``I don't care for that. I want to know who's got 'em. And I tell you what we want--what we all here want, Mr. Bucket. We want more painstaking and search-making into this murder. We know where the interest and the motive was, and you have not done enough. If George the vagabond dragoon had any hand in it, he (George) was only an accomplice, and was set on. You know what I mean as well as any man.'' (unknown)

``Now I tell you what,'' (Mr.)
