says Mr. Bucket, instantaneously altering his (Mr.) manner, coming close to him (Mr.), and communicating an extraordinary fascination to the forefinger,
``I am damned if I am a-going to have my case spoilt, or interfered with, or anticipated by so much as half a second of time by any human being in creation. YOU want more painstaking and search-making! YOU do? Do you see this hand, and do you think that I don't know the right time to stretch it out and put it on the arm that fired that shot?'' (him)

Such is the dread power of the man, and so terribly evident it is that he (man) makes no idle boast, that Mr. Smallweed begins to apologize. Mr. Bucket, dismissing his (Mr.) sudden anger, checks him (Mr.).

``The advice I give you is, don't you trouble your head about the murder. That's my affair. You keep half an eye on the newspapers, and I shouldn't wonder if you was to read something about it before long, if you look sharp. I know my business, and that's all I've got to say to you on that subject. Now about those letters. You want to know who's got 'em. I don't mind telling you. I have got 'em. Is that the packet?'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)

Mr. Smallweed looks, with greedy eyes, at the little bundle Mr. Bucket produces from a mysterious part of his (Mr.) coat, and identifies it as the same.

``What have you got to say next?'' (Mr.)
asks Mr. Bucket.
``Now, don't open your mouth too wide, because you don't look handsome when you do it.'' (unknown)

``I want five hundred pound.'' (unknown)

``No, you don't; you mean fifty,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket humorously.

It appears, however, that Mr. Smallweed means five hundred.

``That is, I am deputed by Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, to consider -LRB-without admitting or promising anything-RRB- this bit of business,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket--Sir Leicester mechanically bows his (Mr.) head--
``and you ask me to consider a proposal of five hundred pounds. Why, it's an unreasonable proposal! Two fifty would be bad enough, but better than that. Hadn't you better say two fifty?'' (Mr.)

Mr. Smallweed is quite clear that he (Smallweed) had better not.

``Then,'' (Mr. Bucket)
says Mr. Bucket,
``let's hear Mr. Chadband. Lord! Many a time I've heard my old fellow-serjeant of that name; and a moderate man he (man) was in all respects, as ever I come across!'' (Mr. Bucket)

Thus invited, Mr. Chadband steps forth, and after a little sleek smiling and a little oil-grinding with the palms of his (Bucket) hands, delivers himself as follows,

``My friends, we are now--Rachael, my wife, and I--in the mansions of the rich and great. Why are we now in the mansions of the rich and great, my friends? Is it because we are invited? Because we are bidden to feast with them, because we are bidden to rejoice with them, because we are bidden to play the lute with them, because we are bidden to dance with them? No. Then why are we here, my friends? Air we in possession of a sinful secret, and do we require corn, and wine, and oil, or what is much the same thing, money, for the keeping thereof? Probably so, my friends.'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)

``You're a man of business, you are,'' (Mr.)
returns Mr. Bucket, very attentive,
``and consequently you're going on to mention what the nature of your secret is. You are right. You couldn't do better.'' (Mr.)

``Let us then, my brother, in a spirit of love,'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)
says Mr. Chadband with a cunning eye,
``proceed unto it. Rachael, my wife, advance!'' (Mr. Chadband/Chadband)

Mrs. Chadband, more than ready, so advances as to jostle her (Chadband) husband into the background and confronts Mr. Bucket with a hard, frowning smile.

``Since you want to know what we know,'' (she)
says she (Chadband),
``I'll tell you. I helped to bring up Miss Hawdon, her (Rachael) ladyship's daughter. I was in the service of her (Rachael) ladyship's sister, who was very sensitive to the disgrace her (Rachael) ladyship brought upon her (Rachael), and gave out, even to her (Rachael) ladyship, that the child was dead--she (Rachael) WAS very nearly so--when she (Rachael) was born. But she (Rachael)'s alive, and I know her (Rachael).'' (she)
With these words, and a laugh, and laying a bitter stress on the word
``ladyship,'' (Mrs. Chadband)
Mrs. Chadband folds her (Chadband) arms and looks implacably at Mr. Bucket.

``I suppose now,'' (officer)
returns that officer,
``YOU will be expecting a twenty-pound note or a present of about that figure?'' (officer)

Mrs. Chadband merely laughs and contemptuously tells him (Mr.) he (Mr.) can

``offer'' (he)
twenty pence.

``My friend the law-stationer's good lady, over there,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket, luring Mrs. Snagsby forward with the finger.
``What may YOUR game be, ma'am?'' (Mrs. Snagsby)

Mrs. Snagsby is at first prevented, by tears and lamentations, from stating the nature of her (Snagsby) game, but by degrees it confusedly comes to light that she (Snagsby) is a woman overwhelmed with injuries and wrongs, whom Mr. Snagsby has habitually deceived, abandoned, and sought to keep in darkness, and whose chief comfort, under her (Snagsby) afflictions, has been the sympathy of the late Mr. Tulkinghorn, who showed so much commiseration for her (Snagsby) on one occasion of his (Tulkinghorn) calling in Cook's Court in the absence of her (Snagsby) perjured husband that she (Snagsby) has of late habitually carried to him (Tulkinghorn) all her (Snagsby) woes. Everybody it appears, the present company excepted, has plotted against Mrs. Snagsby's peace. There is Mr. Guppy, clerk to Kenge and Carboy, who was at first as open as the sun at noon, but who suddenly shut up as close as midnight, under the influence--no doubt--of Mr. Snagsby's suborning and tampering. There is Mr. Weevle, friend of Mr. Guppy, who lived mysteriously up a court, owing to the like coherent causes. There was Krook, deceased; there was Nimrod, deceased; and there was Jo, deceased; and they were

``all in it.'' (Jo)
In what, Mrs. Snagsby does not with particularity express, but she (Snagsby) knows that Jo was Mr. Snagsby's son,
``as well as if a trumpet had spoken it,'' (Jo Snagsby son)
and she (Jo) followed Mr. Snagsby when he (Snagsby) went on his (Snagsby) last visit to the boy, and if he (Snagsby) was not his (Snagsby) son why did he (Snagsby) go? The one occupation of her (Jo) life has been, for some time back, to follow Mr. Snagsby to and fro, and up and down, and to piece suspicious circumstances together--and every circumstance that has happened has been most suspicious; and in this way she (Jo) has pursued her (Jo) object of detecting and confounding her (Jo) false husband, night and day. Thus did it come to pass that she (Jo) brought the Chadbands and Mr. Tulkinghorn together, and conferred with Mr. Tulkinghorn on the change in Mr. Guppy, and helped to turn up the circumstances in which the present company are interested, casually, by the wayside, being still and ever on the great high road that is to terminate in Mr. Snagsby's full exposure and a matrimonial separation. All this, Mrs. Snagsby, as an injured woman, and the friend of Mrs. Chadband, and the follower of Mr. Chadband, and the mourner of the late Mr. Tulkinghorn, is here to certify under the seal of confidence, with every possible confusion and involvement possible and impossible, having no pecuniary motive whatever, no scheme or project but the one mentioned, and bringing here, and taking everywhere, her (Snagsby) own dense atmosphere of dust, arising from the ceaseless working of her (Snagsby) mill of jealousy.

While this exordium is in hand--and it takes some time--Mr. Bucket, who has seen through the transparency of Mrs. Snagsby's vinegar at a glance, confers with his (Bucket) familiar demon and bestows his (Bucket) shrewd attention on the Chadbands and Mr. Smallweed. Sir Leicester Dedlock remains immovable, with the same icy surface upon him (Smallweed), except that he (Smallweed) once or twice looks towards Mr. Bucket, as relying on that officer alone of all mankind.

``Very good,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.
``Now I understand you, you know, and being deputed by Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, to look into this little matter,'' (unknown)
again Sir Leicester mechanically bows in confirmation of the statement,
``can give it my fair and full attention. Now I won't allude to conspiring to extort money or anything of that sort, because we are men and women of the world here, and our object is to make things pleasant. But I tell you what I DO wonder at; I am surprised that you should think of making a noise below in the hall. It was so opposed to your interests. That's what I look at.'' (unknown)

``We wanted to get in,'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
pleads Mr. Smallweed.

``Why, of course you wanted to get in,'' (Mr.)
Mr. Bucket asserts with cheerfulness;
``but for a old gentleman at your time of life--what I call truly venerable, mind you!--with his (gentleman) wits sharpened, as I have no doubt they are, by the loss of the use of his (gentleman) limbs, which occasions all his (gentleman) animation to mount up into his (gentleman) head, not to consider that if he (gentleman) don't keep such a business as the present as close as possible it can't be worth a mag to him (gentleman), is so curious! You see your temper got the better of you; that's where you lost ground,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket in an argumentative and friendly way.

``I only said I wouldn't go without one of the servants came up to Sir Leicester Dedlock,'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
returns Mr. Smallweed.

``That's it! That's where your temper got the better of you. Now, you keep it under another time and you'll make money by it. Shall I ring for them to carry you down?'' (unknown)

``When are we to hear more of this?'' (Mrs. Chadband)
Mrs. Chadband sternly demands.

``Bless your heart for a true woman! Always curious, your delightful sex is!'' (Mr.)
replies Mr. Bucket with gallantry.
``I shall have the pleasure of giving you a call to-morrow or next day--not forgetting Mr. Smallweed and his (Smallweed) proposal of two fifty.'' (unknown)

``Five hundred!'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
exclaims Mr. Smallweed.

``All right! Nominally five hundred.'' (Mr.)
Mr. Bucket has his (Mr.) hand on the bell-rope.
``SHALL I wish you good day for the present on the part of myself and the gentleman of the house?'' (he)
he (Mr.) asks in an insinuating tone.

Nobody having the hardihood to object to his (Mr.) doing so, he (Mr.) does it, and the party retire as they came up. Mr. Bucket follows them to the door, and returning, says with an air of serious business,

``Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, it's for you to consider whether or not to buy this up. I should recommend, on the whole, it's being bought up myself; and I think it may be bought pretty cheap. You see, that little pickled cowcumber of a Mrs. Snagsby has been used by all sides of the speculation and has done a deal more harm in bringing odds and ends together than if she (Snagsby) had meant it. Mr. Tulkinghorn, deceased, he (Tulkinghorn) held all these horses in his (Tulkinghorn) hand and could have drove 'em his (Tulkinghorn) own way, I haven't a doubt; but he (Tulkinghorn) was fetched off the box head-foremost, and now they have got their legs over the traces, and are all dragging and pulling their own ways. So it is, and such is life. The cat's away, and the mice they play; the frost breaks up, and the water runs. Now, with regard to the party to be apprehended.'' (Mr.)

Sir Leicester seems to wake, though his (Mr.) eyes have been wide open, and he (Mr.) looks intently at Mr. Bucket as Mr. Bucket refers to his (Mr.) watch.

``The party to be apprehended is now in this house,'' (Mr.)
proceeds Mr. Bucket, putting up his (Mr.) watch with a steady hand and with rising spirits,
``and I'm about to take her (Tulkinghorn) into custody in your presence. Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, don't you say a word nor yet stir. There'll be no noise and no disturbance at all. I'll come back in the course of the evening, if agreeable to you, and endeavour to meet your wishes respecting this unfortunate family matter and the nobbiest way of keeping it quiet. Now, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, don't you be nervous on account of the apprehension at present coming off. You shall see the whole case clear, from first to last.'' (spirits)

Mr. Bucket rings, goes to the door, briefly whispers Mercury, shuts the door, and stands behind it with his (Mr.) arms folded. After a suspense of a minute or two the door slowly opens and a Frenchwoman enters. Mademoiselle Hortense.

The moment she (Hortense) is in the room Mr. Bucket claps the door to and puts his (Mr.) back against it. The suddenness of the noise occasions her (Hortense) to turn, and then for the first time she (Hortense) sees Sir Leicester Dedlock in his (Mr.) chair.

``I ask you pardon,'' (she)
she (Hortense) mutters hurriedly.
``They tell me there was no one here.'' (Mr.)

Her (Hortense) step towards the door brings her (Hortense) front to front with Mr. Bucket. Suddenly a spasm shoots across her (Hortense) face and she (Hortense) turns deadly pale.

``This is my lodger, Sir Leicester Dedlock,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket, nodding at her (Hortense).
``This foreign young woman has been my lodger for some weeks back.'' (unknown)

``What do Sir Leicester care for that, you think, my angel?'' (unknown)
returns mademoiselle in a jocular strain.

``Why, my angel,'' (Mr.)
returns Mr. Bucket,
``we shall see.'' (Mr.)

Mademoiselle Hortense eyes him (Mr.) with a scowl upon her (Hortense) tight face, which gradually changes into a smile of scorn,

``You are very mysterieuse. Are you drunk?'' (him)

``Tolerable sober, my angel,'' (Mr.)
returns Mr. Bucket.

``I come from arriving at this so detestable house with your wife. Your wife have left me since some minutes. They tell me downstairs that your wife is here. I come here, and your wife is not here. What is the intention of this fool's play, say then?'' (unknown)
mademoiselle demands, with her (Hortense) arms composedly crossed, but with something in her (Hortense) dark cheek beating like a clock.

Mr. Bucket merely shakes the finger at her (Hortense).

``Ah, my God, you are an unhappy idiot!'' (unknown)
cries mademoiselle with a toss of her (Hortense) head and a laugh.
``Leave me to pass downstairs, great pig.'' (unknown)
With a stamp of her (Hortense) foot and a menace.

``Now, mademoiselle,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket in a cool determined way,
``you go and sit down upon that sofy.'' (Mr.)

``I will not sit down upon nothing,'' (she)
she (Hortense) replies with a shower of nods.

``Now, mademoiselle,'' (Mr.)
repeats Mr. Bucket, making no demonstration except with the finger,
``you sit down upon that sofy.'' (Mr.)

``Why?'' (unknown)

``Because I take you into custody on a charge of murder, and you don't need to be told it. Now, I want to be polite to one of your sex and a foreigner if I can. If I can't, I must be rough, and there's rougher ones outside. What I am to be depends on you. So I recommend you, as a friend, afore another half a blessed moment has passed over your head, to go and sit down upon that sofy.'' (Mademoiselle Hortense/Mademoiselle/Hortense)

Mademoiselle complies, saying in a concentrated voice while that something in her (Mademoiselle) cheek beats fast and hard,

``You are a devil.'' (Mademoiselle Hortense/Mademoiselle/Hortense)

``Now, you see,'' (Mr.)
Mr. Bucket proceeds approvingly,
``you're comfortable and conducting yourself as I should expect a foreign young woman of your sense to do. So I'll give you a piece of advice, and it's this, don't you talk too much. You're not expected to say anything here, and you can't keep too quiet a tongue in your head. In short, the less you PARLAY, the better, you know.'' (Mr.)
Mr. Bucket is very complacent over this French explanation.

Mademoiselle, with that tigerish expansion of the mouth and her (Mademoiselle) black eyes darting fire upon him (Mr.), sits upright on the sofa in a rigid state, with her (Mademoiselle) hands clenched--and her (Mademoiselle) feet too, one might suppose--muttering,

``Oh, you Bucket, you are a devil!'' (him)

``Now, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket, and from this time forth the finger never rests,
``this young woman, my lodger, was her (woman) ladyship's maid at the time I have mentioned to you; and this young woman, besides being extraordinary vehement and passionate against her (woman) ladyship after being discharged--'' (Mr.)

``Lie!'' (Mr.)
cries mademoiselle.
``I discharge myself.'' (unknown)

``Now, why don't you take my advice?'' (Mr.)
returns Mr. Bucket in an impressive, almost in an imploring, tone.
``I'm surprised at the indiscreetness you commit. You'll say something that'll be used against you, you know. You're sure to come to it. Never you mind what I say till it's given in evidence. It is not addressed to you.'' (unknown)

``Discharge, too,'' (unknown)
cries mademoiselle furiously,
``by her (woman) ladyship! Eh, my faith, a pretty ladyship! Why, I r-r-r-ruin my character by remaining with a ladyship so infame!'' (unknown)

``Upon my soul I wonder at you!'' (Mr.)
Mr. Bucket remonstrates.
``I thought the French were a polite nation, I did, really. Yet to hear a female going on like that before Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet!'' (unknown)

``He (character) is a poor abused!'' (unknown)
cries mademoiselle.
``I spit upon his (character) house, upon his (character) name, upon his (character) imbecility,'' (she)
all of which she (Mademoiselle) makes the carpet represent.
``Oh, that he (character) is a great man! Oh, yes, superb! Oh, heaven! Bah!'' (unknown)

``Well, Sir Leicester Dedlock,'' (Mr.)
proceeds Mr. Bucket,
``this intemperate foreigner also angrily took it into her (I) head that she (I) had established a claim upon Mr. Tulkinghorn, deceased, by attending on the occasion I told you of at his (Tulkinghorn) chambers, though she (I) was liberally paid for her (I) time and trouble.'' (Mr.)

``Lie!'' (unknown)
cries mademoiselle.
``I ref-use his (Tulkinghorn) money all togezzer.'' (unknown)

``If you WILL PARLAY, you know,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket parenthetically,
``you must take the consequences. Now, whether she (I) became my lodger, Sir Leicester Dedlock, with any deliberate intention then of doing this deed and blinding me, I give no opinion on; but she (I) lived in my house in that capacity at the time that she (I) was hovering about the chambers of the deceased Mr. Tulkinghorn with a view to a wrangle, and likewise persecuting and half frightening the life out of an unfortunate stationer.'' (Mr.)

``Lie!'' (unknown)
cries mademoiselle.
``All lie!'' (unknown)

``The murder was committed, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, and you know under what circumstances. Now, I beg of you to follow me close with your attention for a minute or two. I was sent for, and the case was entrusted to me. I examined the place, and the body, and the papers, and everything. From information I received -LRB-from a clerk in the same house-RRB- I took George into custody as having been seen hanging about there on the night, and at very nigh the time of the murder, also as having been overheard in high words with the deceased on former occasions--even threatening him (George), as the witness made out. If you ask me, Sir Leicester Dedlock, whether from the first I believed George to be the murderer, I tell you candidly no, but he (George) might be, notwithstanding, and there was enough against him (George) to make it my duty to take him (George) and get him (George) kept under remand. Now, observe!'' (Mr.)

As Mr. Bucket bends forward in some excitement--for him (Mr.)--and inaugurates what he (Mr.) is going to say with one ghostly beat of his (Mr.) forefinger in the air, Mademoiselle Hortense fixes her (Hortense) black eyes upon him (Mr.) with a dark frown and sets her (Hortense) dry lips closely and firmly together.

``I went home, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, at night and found this young woman having supper with my wife, Mrs. Bucket. She (wife) had made a mighty show of being fond of Mrs. Bucket from her (wife) first offering herself as our lodger, but that night she (wife) made more than ever--in fact, overdid it. Likewise she (wife) overdid her (wife) respect, and all that, for the lamented memory of the deceased Mr. Tulkinghorn. By the living Lord it flashed upon me, as I sat opposite to her (wife) at the table and saw her (wife) with a knife in her (wife) hand, that she (wife) had done it!'' (Mademoiselle Hortense/Mademoiselle/Hortense)

Mademoiselle is hardly audible in straining through her (Mademoiselle) teeth and lips the words,

``You are a devil.'' (Mademoiselle Hortense/Mademoiselle/Hortense)

``Now where,'' (Mr. Bucket)
pursues Mr. Bucket,
``had she (wife) been on the night of the murder? She (wife) had been to the theayter. -LRB-She (wife) really was there, I have since found, both before the deed and after it.-RRB- I knew I had an artful customer to deal with and that proof would be very difficult; and I laid a trap for her (wife)--such a trap as I never laid yet, and such a venture as I never made yet. I worked it out in my mind while I was talking to her (wife) at supper. When I went upstairs to bed, our house being small and this young woman's ears sharp, I stuffed the sheet into Mrs. Bucket's mouth that she (woman) shouldn't say a word of surprise and told her (woman) all about it. My dear, don't you give your mind to that again, or I shall link your feet together at the ankles.'' (Mr. Bucket)
Mr. Bucket, breaking off, has made a noiseless descent upon mademoiselle and laid his (Bucket) heavy hand upon her (Mademoiselle) shoulder.

``What is the matter with you now?'' (she)
she (Mademoiselle) asks him (Bucket).

``Don't you think any more,'' (Mr.)
returns Mr. Bucket with admonitory finger,
``of throwing yourself out of window. That's what's the matter with me. Come! Just take my arm. You needn't get up; I'll sit down by you. Now take my arm, will you? I'm a married man, you know; you're acquainted with my wife. Just take my arm.'' (Mr.)

Vainly endeavouring to moisten those dry lips, with a painful sound she (Mademoiselle) struggles with herself and complies.

``Now we're all right again. Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, this case could never have been the case it is but for Mrs. Bucket, who is a woman in fifty thousand--in a hundred and fifty thousand! To throw this young woman off her (woman) guard, I have never set foot in our house since, though I've communicated with Mrs. Bucket in the baker's loaves and in the milk as often as required. My whispered words to Mrs. Bucket when she (woman) had the sheet in her (woman) mouth were, ``My dear, can you throw her (woman) off continually with natural accounts of my suspicions against George, and this, and that, and t`other? Can you do without rest and keep watch upon her (woman) night and day? Can you undertake to say,

``She (woman) shall do nothing without my knowledge, she (woman) shall be my prisoner without suspecting it, she (woman) shall no more escape from me than from death, and her (woman) life shall be my life, and her (woman) soul my soul, till I have got her (woman), if she (woman) did this murder?'' (me)
Mrs. Bucket says to me, as well as she (Mademoiselle) could speak on account of the sheet,
``Bucket, I can!'' (she)
And she (Mademoiselle) has acted up to it glorious!''

``Lies!'' (unknown)
mademoiselle interposes.
``All lies, my friend!'' (unknown)

``Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, how did my calculations come out under these circumstances? When I calculated that this impetuous young woman would overdo it in new directions, was I wrong or right? I was right. What does she (woman) try to do? Don't let it give you a turn? To throw the murder on her (woman) ladyship.'' (unknown)

Sir Leicester rises from his (Mr.) chair and staggers down again.

``And she (woman) got encouragement in it from hearing that I was always here, which was done a-purpose. Now, open that pocket-book of mine, Sir Leicester Dedlock, if I may take the liberty of throwing it towards you, and look at the letters sent to me, each with the two words ``Lady Dedlock' in it. Open the one directed to yourself, which I stopped this very morning, and read the three words

``Lady Dedlock, Murderess' in it. These letters have been falling about like a shower of lady-birds. What do you say now to Mrs. Bucket, from her (Lady) spy-place having seen them all `written by this young woman? What do you say to Mrs. Bucket having, within this half-hour, secured the corresponding ink and paper, fellow half-sheets and what not? What do you say to Mrs. Bucket having watched the posting of 'em every one by this young woman, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet?'' (I)
Mr. Bucket asks, triumphant in his (Bucket) admiration of his (Bucket) lady's genius.

Two things are especially observable as Mr. Bucket proceeds to a conclusion. First, that he (Mr.) seems imperceptibly to establish a dreadful right of property in mademoiselle. Secondly, that the very atmosphere she (genius) breathes seems to narrow and contract about her (genius) as if a close net or a pall were being drawn nearer and yet nearer around her (genius) breathless figure.

``There is no doubt that her (woman) ladyship was on the spot at the eventful period,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket,
``and my foreign friend here saw her (woman), I believe, from the upper part of the staircase. Her (woman) ladyship and George and my foreign friend were all pretty close on one another's heels. But that don't signify any more, so I'll not go into it. I found the wadding of the pistol with which the deceased Mr. Tulkinghorn was shot. It was a bit of the printed description of your house at Chesney Wold. Not much in that, you'll say, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet. No. But when my foreign friend here is so thoroughly off her (woman) guard as to think it a safe time to tear up the rest of that leaf, and when Mrs. Bucket puts the pieces together and finds the wadding wanting, it begins to look like Queer Street.'' (Mr.)

``These are very long lies,'' (unknown)
mademoiselle interposes.
``You prose great deal. Is it that you have almost all finished, or are you speaking always?'' (unknown)

``Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet,'' (Mr. Bucket)
proceeds Mr. Bucket, who delights in a full title and does violence to himself when he (Bucket) dispenses with any fragment of it,
``the last point in the case which I am now going to mention shows the necessity of patience in our business, and never doing a thing in a hurry. I watched this young woman yesterday without her (woman) knowledge when she (woman) was looking at the funeral, in company with my wife, who planned to take her (woman) there; and I had so much to convict her (woman), and I saw such an expression in her (woman) face, and my mind so rose against her (woman) malice towards her (woman) ladyship, and the time was altogether such a time for bringing down what you may call retribution upon her (woman), that if I had been a younger hand with less experience, I should have taken her (woman), certain. Equally, last night, when her (woman) ladyship, as is so universally admired I am sure, come home looking--why, Lord, a man might almost say like Venus rising from the ocean--it was so unpleasant and inconsistent to think of her (woman) being charged with a murder of which she (woman) was innocent that I felt quite to want to put an end to the job. What should I have lost? Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, I should have lost the weapon. My prisoner here proposed to Mrs. Bucket, after the departure of the funeral, that they should go per bus a little ways into the country and take tea at a very decent house of entertainment. Now, near that house of entertainment there's a piece of water. At tea, my prisoner got up to fetch her (woman) pocket handkercher from the bedroom where the bonnets was; she (woman) was rather a long time gone and came back a little out of wind. As soon as they came home this was reported to me by Mrs. Bucket, along with her (woman) observations and suspicions. I had the piece of water dragged by moonlight, in presence of a couple of our men, and the pocket pistol was brought up before it had been there half-a-dozen hours. Now, my dear, put your arm a little further through mine, and hold it steady, and I shan't hurt you!'' (he)

In a trice Mr. Bucket snaps a handcuff on her (genius) wrist.

``That's one,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.
``Now the other, darling. Two, and all told!'' (He)

He (Mr.) rises; she (genius) rises too.

``Where,'' (she)
she (genius) asks him (Mr.), darkening her (genius) large eyes until their drooping lids almost conceal them--and yet they stare,
``where is your false, your treacherous, and cursed wife?'' (him)

``She (wife)'s gone forrard to the Police Office,'' (Mr.)
returns Mr. Bucket.
``You'll see her (wife) there, my dear.'' (unknown)

``I would like to kiss her (wife)!'' (Mademoiselle Hortense/Mademoiselle/Hortense)
exclaims Mademoiselle Hortense, panting tigress-like.

``You'd bite her (wife), I suspect,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.

``I would!'' (unknown)
making her (Hortense) eyes very large.
``I would love to tear her (wife) limb from limb.'' (unknown)

``Bless you, darling,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket with the greatest composure,
``I'm fully prepared to hear that. Your sex have such a surprising animosity against one another when you do differ. You don't mind me half so much, do you?'' (Mr.)

``No. Though you are a devil still.'' (unknown)

``Angel and devil by turns, eh?'' (Mr.)
cries Mr. Bucket.
``But I am in my regular employment, you must consider. Let me put your shawl tidy. I've been lady's maid to a good many before now. Anything wanting to the bonnet? There's a cab at the door.'' (Mademoiselle Hortense/Mademoiselle/Hortense)

Mademoiselle Hortense, casting an indignant eye at the glass, shakes herself perfectly neat in one shake and looks, to do her (Hortense) justice, uncommonly genteel.

``Listen then, my angel,'' (she)
says she (Hortense) after several sarcastic nods.
``You are very spiritual. But can you restore him (angel) back to life?'' (Mr.)

Mr. Bucket answers,

``Not exactly.'' (Mr.)

``That is droll. Listen yet one time. You are very spiritual. Can you make a honourable lady of her (lady)?'' (unknown)

``Don't be so malicious,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.

``Or a haughty gentleman of HIM?'' (unknown)
cries mademoiselle, referring to Sir Leicester with ineffable disdain.
``Eh! Oh, then regard him (gentleman)! The poor infant! Ha! Ha! Ha!'' (unknown)

``Come, come, why this is worse PARLAYING than the other,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.
``Come along!'' (unknown)

``You cannot do these things? Then you can do as you please with me. It is but the death, it is all the same. Let us go, my angel. Adieu, you old man, grey. I pity you, and I despise you!'' (she)

With these last words she (Hortense) snaps her (Hortense) teeth together as if her (Hortense) mouth closed with a spring. It is impossible to describe how Mr. Bucket gets her (Hortense) out, but he (Bucket) accomplishes that feat in a manner so peculiar to himself, enfolding and pervading her (Hortense) like a cloud, and hovering away with her (Hortense) as if he (Bucket) were a homely Jupiter and she (Hortense) the object of his (Bucket) affections.

Sir Leicester, left alone, remains in the same attitude, as though he (Bucket) were still listening and his (Bucket) attention were still occupied. At length he (Bucket) gazes round the empty room, and finding it deserted, rises unsteadily to his (Bucket) feet, pushes back his (Bucket) chair, and walks a few steps, supporting himself by the table. Then he (Bucket) stops, and with more of those inarticulate sounds, lifts up his (Bucket) eyes and seems to stare at something.

Heaven knows what he (Bucket) sees. The green, green woods of Chesney Wold, the noble house, the pictures of his (Wold) forefathers, strangers defacing them, officers of police coarsely handling his (Wold) most precious heirlooms, thousands of fingers pointing at him (Wold), thousands of faces sneering at him (Wold). But if such shadows flit before him (Wold) to his (Wold) bewilderment, there is one other shadow which he (Wold) can name with something like distinctness even yet and to which alone he (Wold) addresses his (Wold) tearing of his (Wold) white hair and his (Wold) extended arms.

It is she (Wold) in association with whom, saving that she (Wold) has been for years a main fibre of the root of his (Wold) dignity and pride, he (Wold) has never had a selfish thought. It is she (Wold) whom he (Wold) has loved, admired, honoured, and set up for the world to respect. It is she (Wold) who, at the core of all the constrained formalities and conventionalities of his (Wold) life, has been a stock of living tenderness and love, susceptible as nothing else is of being struck with the agony he (Wold) feels. He (Wold) sees her (Wold), almost to the exclusion of himself, and cannot bear to look upon her (Wold) cast down from the high place she (Wold) has graced so well.

And even to the point of his (Wold) sinking on the ground, oblivious of his (Wold) suffering, he (Wold) can yet pronounce her (Wold) name with something like distinctness in the midst of those intrusive sounds, and in a tone of mourning and compassion rather than reproach.

CHAPTER LV

Flight

Inspector Bucket of the Detective has not yet struck his (Detective) great blow, as just now chronicled, but is yet refreshing himself with sleep preparatory to his (Detective) field-day, when through the night and along the freezing wintry roads a chaise and pair comes out of Lincolnshire, making its way towards London.

Railroads shall soon traverse all this country, and with a rattle and a glare the engine and train shall shoot like a meteor over the wide night-landscape, turning the moon paler; but as yet such things are non-existent in these parts, though not wholly unexpected. Preparations are afoot, measurements are made, ground is staked out. Bridges are begun, and their not yet united piers desolately look at one another over roads and streams like brick and mortar couples with an obstacle to their union; fragments of embankments are thrown up and left as precipices with torrents of rusty carts and barrows tumbling over them; tripods of tall poles appear on hilltops, where there are rumours of tunnels; everything looks chaotic and abandoned in full hopelessness. Along the freezing roads, and through the night, the post-chaise makes its way without a railroad on its mind.

Mrs. Rouncewell, so many years housekeeper at Chesney Wold, sits within the chaise; and by her (Rouncewell) side sits Mrs. Bagnet with her (Rouncewell) grey cloak and umbrella. The old girl would prefer the bar in front, as being exposed to the weather and a primitive sort of perch more in accordance with her (girl) usual course of travelling, but Mrs. Rouncewell is too thoughtful of her (Rouncewell) comfort to admit of her (Rouncewell) proposing it. The old lady cannot make enough of the old girl. She (girl) sits, in her (girl) stately manner, holding her (girl) hand, and regardless of its roughness, puts it often to her (girl) lips.

``You are a mother, my dear soul,'' (she)
says she (girl) many times,
``and you found out my George's mother!'' (she)

``Why, George,'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
returns Mrs. Bagnet,
``was always free with me, ma'am, and when he (George) said at our house to my Woolwich that of all the things my Woolwich could have to think of when he (George) grew to be a man, the comfortablest would be that he (George) had never brought a sorrowful line into his (George) mother's face or turned a hair of her (mother) head grey, then I felt sure, from his (George) way, that something fresh had brought his (George) own mother into his (George) mind. I had often known him (George) say to me, in past times, that he (George) had behaved bad to her (mother).'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

``Never, my dear!'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)
returns Mrs. Rouncewell, bursting into tears.
``My blessing on him (George), never! He (George) was always fond of me, and loving to me, was my George! But he (George) had a bold spirit, and he (George) ran a little wild and went for a soldier. And I know he (George) waited at first, in letting us know about himself, till he (George) should rise to be an officer; and when he (George) didn't rise, I know he (George) considered himself beneath us, and wouldn't be a disgrace to us. For he (George) had a lion heart, had my George, always from a baby!'' (The lady)

The old lady's hands stray about her (Rouncewell) as of yore, while she (Rouncewell) recalls, all in a tremble, what a likely lad, what a fine lad, what a gay good-humoured clever lad he (lad) was; how they all took to him (lad) down at Chesney Wold; how Sir Leicester took to him (Chesney) when he (Chesney) was a young gentleman; how the dogs took to him (Chesney); how even the people who had been angry with him (Chesney) forgave him (Chesney) the moment he (Chesney) was gone, poor boy. And now to see him (Chesney) after all, and in a prison too! And the broad stomacher heaves, and the quaint upright old-fashioned figure bends under its load of affectionate distress.

Mrs. Bagnet, with the instinctive skill of a good warm heart, leaves the old housekeeper to her (Bagnet) emotions for a little while--not without passing the back of her (Bagnet) hand across her (Bagnet) own motherly eyes--and presently chirps up in her (Bagnet) cheery manner, ``So I says to George when I goes to call him (George) in to tea -LRB-he (George) pretended to be smoking his (George) pipe outside-RRB-, ``What ails you this afternoon, George, for gracious sake? I have seen all sorts, and I have seen you pretty often in season and out of season, abroad and at home, and I never see you so melancholy penitent.'' ``Why, Mrs. Bagnet,

'' says George, `it's because I AM melancholy and penitent both, this afternoon, that you see me so.'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
``What have you done, old fellow?'' (I)
I says.
``Why, Mrs. Bagnet,'' (Mr. George/George)
says George, shaking his (George) head, `what I have done has been done this many a long year, and is best not tried to be undone now. If I ever get to heaven it won't be for being a good son to a widowed mother; I say no more.'' Now, ma'am, when George says to me that it's best not tried to be undone now, I have my thoughts as I have often had before, and I draw it out of George how he (George) comes to have such things on him (George) that afternoon. Then George tells me that he (George) has seen by chance, at the lawyer's office, a fine old lady that has brought his (George) mother plain before him (George), and he (George) runs on about that old lady till he (George) quite forgets himself and paints her (lady) picture to me as she (lady) used to be, years upon years back. So I says to George when he (George) has done, who is this old lady he (George) has seen? And George tells me it's Mrs. Rouncewell, housekeeper for more than half a century to the Dedlock family down at Chesney Wold in Lincolnshire. George has frequently told me before that he (George)'s a Lincolnshire man, and I says to my old Lignum that night,
``Lignum, that's his (fellow) mother for five and for-ty pound!''' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

All this Mrs. Bagnet now relates for the twentieth time at least within the last four hours. Trilling it out like a kind of bird, with a pretty high note, that it may be audible to the old lady above the hum of the wheels.

``Bless you, and thank you,'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)
says Mrs. Rouncewell.
``Bless you, and thank you, my worthy soul!'' (unknown)

``Dear heart!'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)
cries Mrs. Bagnet in the most natural manner.
``No thanks to me, I am sure. Thanks to yourself, ma'am, for being so ready to pay 'em! And mind once more, ma'am, what you had best do on finding George to be your own son is to make him (George)--for your sake--have every sort of help to put himself in the right and clear himself of a charge of which he (George) is as innocent as you or me. It won't do to have truth and justice on his (George) side; he (George) must have law and lawyers,'' (the girl)
exclaims the old girl, apparently persuaded that the latter form a separate establishment and have dissolved partnership with truth and justice for ever and a day.

``He (George) shall have,'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)
says Mrs. Rouncewell,
``all the help that can be got for him (George) in the world, my dear. I will spend all I have, and thankfully, to procure it. Sir Leicester will do his (George) best, the whole family will do their best. I--I know something, my dear; and will make my own appeal, as his (George) mother parted from him (George) all these years, and finding him (George) in a jail at last.'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)

The extreme disquietude of the old housekeeper's manner in saying this, her (Rouncewell) broken words, and her (Rouncewell) wringing of her (Rouncewell) hands make a powerful impression on Mrs. Bagnet and would astonish her (Bagnet) but that she (Bagnet) refers them all to her (Bagnet) sorrow for her (Bagnet) son's condition. And yet Mrs. Bagnet wonders too why Mrs. Rouncewell should murmur so distractedly,

``My Lady, my Lady, my Lady!'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)
over and over again.

The frosty night wears away, and the dawn breaks, and the post-chaise comes rolling on through the early mist like the ghost of a chaise departed. It has plenty of spectral company in ghosts of trees and hedges, slowly vanishing and giving place to the realities of day. London reached, the travellers alight, the old housekeeper in great tribulation and confusion, Mrs. Bagnet quite fresh and collected--as she (Bagnet) would be if her (Bagnet) next point, with no new equipage and outfit, were the Cape of Good Hope, the Island of Ascension, Hong Kong, or any other military station.

But when they set out for the prison where the trooper is confined, the old lady has managed to draw about her (lady), with her (lady) lavender-coloured dress, much of the staid calmness which is its usual accompaniment. A wonderfully grave, precise, and handsome piece of old china she (lady) looks, though her (lady) heart beats fast and her (lady) stomacher is ruffled more than even the remembrance of this wayward son has ruffled it these many years.

Approaching the cell, they find the door opening and a warder in the act of coming out. The old girl promptly makes a sign of entreaty to him (warder) to say nothing; assenting with a nod, he (warder) suffers them to enter as he (warder) shuts the door.

So George, who is writing at his (George) table, supposing himself to be alone, does not raise his (George) eyes, but remains absorbed. The old housekeeper looks at him (George), and those wandering hands of hers are quite enough for Mrs. Bagnet's confirmation, even if she (Bagnet) could see the mother and the son together, knowing what she (Bagnet) knows, and doubt their relationship.

Not a rustle of the housekeeper's dress, not a gesture, not a word betrays her (housekeeper). She (housekeeper) stands looking at him (son) as he (son) writes on, all unconscious, and only her (housekeeper) fluttering hands give utterance to her (housekeeper) emotions. But they are very eloquent, very, very eloquent. Mrs. Bagnet understands them. They speak of gratitude, of joy, of grief, of hope; of inextinguishable affection, cherished with no return since this stalwart man was a stripling; of a better son loved less, and this son loved so fondly and so proudly; and they speak in such touching language that Mrs. Bagnet's eyes brim up with tears and they run glistening down her (Bagnet) sun-brown face.

``George Rouncewell! Oh, my dear child, turn and look at me!'' (The trooper)

The trooper starts up, clasps his (trooper) mother round the neck, and falls down on his (trooper) knees before her (Bagnet). Whether in a late repentance, whether in the first association that comes back upon him (trooper), he (trooper) puts his (trooper) hands together as a child does when it says its prayers, and raising them towards her (Bagnet) breast, bows down his (trooper) head, and cries.

``My George, my dearest son! Always my favourite, and my favourite still, where have you been these cruel years and years? Grown such a man too, grown such a fine strong man. Grown so like what I knew he (man) must be, if it pleased God he (God) was alive!'' (She)

She (Bagnet) can ask, and he (trooper) can answer, nothing connected for a time. All that time the old girl, turned away, leans one arm against the whitened wall, leans her (girl) honest forehead upon it, wipes her (girl) eyes with her (girl) serviceable grey cloak, and quite enjoys herself like the best of old girls as she (girl) is.

``Mother,'' (the trooper)
says the trooper when they are more composed,
``forgive me first of all, for I know my need of it.'' (the trooper)

Forgive him (trooper)! She (girl) does it with all her (girl) heart and soul. She (girl) always has done it. She (girl) tells him (trooper) how she (girl) has had it written in her (girl) will, these many years, that he (trooper) was her (girl) beloved son George. She (girl) has never believed any ill of him (George), never. If she (girl) had died without this happiness--and she (girl) is an old woman now and can't look to live very long--she (girl) would have blessed him (George) with her (girl) last breath, if she (girl) had had her (girl) senses, as her (girl) beloved son George.

``Mother, I have been an undutiful trouble to you, and I have my reward; but of late years I have had a kind of glimmering of a purpose in me too. When I left home I didn't care much, mother--I am afraid not a great deal--for leaving; and went away and `listed, harum-scarum, making believe to think that I cared for nobody, no not I, and that nobody cared for me.'' (The trooper)

The trooper has dried his (trooper) eyes and put away his (trooper) handkerchief, but there is an extraordinary contrast between his (trooper) habitual manner of expressing himself and carrying himself and the softened tone in which he (trooper) speaks, interrupted occasionally by a half-stifled sob.

``So I wrote a line home, mother, as you too well know, to say I had `listed under another name, and I went abroad. Abroad, at one time I thought I would write home next year, when I might be better off; and when that year was out, I thought I would write home next year, when I might be better off; and when that year was out again, perhaps I didn't think much about it. So on, from year to year, through a service of ten years, till I began to get older, and to ask myself why should I ever write.'' (unknown)

``I don't find any fault, child--but not to ease my mind, George? Not a word to your loving mother, who was growing older too?'' (the trooper)

This almost overturns the trooper afresh, but he (trooper) sets himself up with a great, rough, sounding clearance of his (trooper) throat.

``Heaven forgive me, mother, but I thought there would be small consolation then in hearing anything about me. There were you, respected and esteemed. There was my brother, as I read in chance North Country papers now and then, rising to be prosperous and famous. There was I a dragoon, roving, unsettled, not self-made like him (brother), but self-unmade--all my earlier advantages thrown away, all my little learning unlearnt, nothing picked up but what unfitted me for most things that I could think of. What business had I to make myself known? After letting all that time go by me, what good could come of it? The worst was past with you, mother. I knew by that time -LRB-being a man-RRB- how you had mourned for me, and wept for me, and prayed for me; and the pain was over, or was softened down, and I was better in your mind as it was.'' (The lady)

The old lady sorrowfully shakes her (lady) head, and taking one of his (trooper) powerful hands, lays it lovingly upon her (lady) shoulder.

``No, I don't say that it was so, mother, but that I made it out to be so. I said just now, what good could come of it? Well, my dear mother, some good might have come of it to myself--and there was the meanness of it. You would have sought me out; you would have purchased my discharge; you would have taken me down to Chesney Wold; you would have brought me and my brother and my brother's family together; you would all have considered anxiously how to do something for me and set me up as a respectable civilian. But how could any of you feel sure of me when I couldn't so much as feel sure of myself? How could you help regarding as an incumbrance and a discredit to you an idle dragooning chap who was an incumbrance and a discredit to himself, excepting under discipline? How could I look my brother's children in the face and pretend to set them an example--I, the vagabond boy who had run away from home and been the grief and unhappiness of my mother's life? ``No, George.'' Such were my words, mother, when I passed this in review before me:

``You have made your bed. Now, lie upon it.''' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)

Mrs. Rouncewell, drawing up her (Rouncewell) stately form, shakes her (Rouncewell) head at the old girl with a swelling pride upon her (Rouncewell), as much as to say,

``I told you so!'' (her)
The old girl relieves her (girl) feelings and testifies her (girl) interest in the conversation by giving the trooper a great poke between the shoulders with her (girl) umbrella; this action she (girl) afterwards repeats, at intervals, in a species of affectionate lunacy, never failing, after the administration of each of these remonstrances, to resort to the whitened wall and the grey cloak again.

``This was the way I brought myself to think, mother, that my best amends was to lie upon that bed I had made, and die upon it. And I should have done it -LRB-though I have been to see you more than once down at Chesney Wold, when you little thought of me-RRB- but for my old comrade's wife here, who I find has been too many for me. But I thank her (wife) for it. I thank you for it, Mrs. Bagnet, with all my heart and might.'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

To which Mrs. Bagnet responds with two pokes.

And now the old lady impresses upon her (lady) son George, her (lady) own dear recovered boy, her (lady) joy and pride, the light of her (lady) eyes, the happy close of her (lady) life, and every fond name she (lady) can think of, that he (George) must be governed by the best advice obtainable by money and influence, that he (George) must yield up his (George) case to the greatest lawyers that can be got, that he (George) must act in this serious plight as he (George) shall be advised to act and must not be self-willed, however right, but must promise to think only of his (George) poor old mother's anxiety and suffering until he (George) is released, or he (George) will break her (mother) heart.

``Mother, `tis little enough to consent to,'' (the trooper)
returns the trooper, stopping her (mother) with a kiss;
``tell me what I shall do, and I'll make a late beginning and do it. Mrs. Bagnet, you'll take care of my mother, I know?'' (the trooper)

A very hard poke from the old girl's umbrella.

``If you'll bring her (Bagnet) acquainted with Mr. Jarndyce and Miss Summerson, she (Bagnet) will find them of her (Bagnet) way of thinking, and they will give her (Bagnet) the best advice and assistance.'' (unknown)

``And, George,'' (the lady)
says the old lady,
``we must send with all haste for your brother. He (George) is a sensible sound man as they tell me--out in the world beyond Chesney Wold, my dear, though I don't know much of it myself--and will be of great service.'' (the lady)

``Mother,'' (the trooper)
returns the trooper,
``is it too soon to ask a favour?'' (the trooper)

``Surely not, my dear.'' (unknown)

``Then grant me this one great favour. Don't let my brother know.'' (unknown)

``Not know what, my dear?'' (unknown)

``Not know of me. In fact, mother, I can't bear it; I can't make up my mind to it. He (brother) has proved himself so different from me and has done so much to raise himself while I've been soldiering that I haven't brass enough in my composition to see him (brother) in this place and under this charge. How could a man like him (man) be expected to have any pleasure in such a discovery? It's impossible. No, keep my secret from him (man), mother; do me a greater kindness than I deserve and keep my secret from my brother, of all men.'' (unknown)

``But not always, dear George?'' (unknown)

``Why, mother, perhaps not for good and all--though I may come to ask that too--but keep it now, I do entreat you. If it's ever broke to him (George) that his (George) rip of a brother has turned up, I could wish,'' (the trooper)
says the trooper, shaking his (trooper) head very doubtfully,
``to break it myself and be governed as to advancing or retreating by the way in which he (George) seems to take it.'' (the trooper)

As he (trooper) evidently has a rooted feeling on this point, and as the depth of it is recognized in Mrs. Bagnet's face, his (trooper) mother yields her (mother) implicit assent to what he (trooper) asks. For this he (trooper) thanks her (mother) kindly.

``In all other respects, my dear mother, I'll be as tractable and obedient as you can wish; on this one alone, I stand out. So now I am ready even for the lawyers. I have been drawing up,'' (he)
he (trooper) glances at his (trooper) writing on the table,
``an exact account of what I knew of the deceased and how I came to be involved in this unfortunate affair. It's entered, plain and regular, like an orderly-book; not a word in it but what's wanted for the facts. I did intend to read it, straight on end, whensoever I was called upon to say anything in my defence. I hope I may be let to do it still; but I have no longer a will of my own in this case, and whatever is said or done, I give my promise not to have any.'' (he)

Matters being brought to this so far satisfactory pass, and time being on the wane, Mrs. Bagnet proposes a departure. Again and again the old lady hangs upon her (lady) son's neck, and again and again the trooper holds her (lady) to his (trooper) broad chest.

``Where are you going to take my mother, Mrs. Bagnet?'' (unknown)

``I am going to the town house, my dear, the family house. I have some business there that must be looked to directly,'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)
Mrs. Rouncewell answers.

``Will you see my mother safe there in a coach, Mrs. Bagnet? But of course I know you will. Why should I ask it!'' (Mrs. Bagnet/Bagnet)

Why indeed, Mrs. Bagnet expresses with the umbrella.

``Take her (Bagnet), my old friend, and take my gratitude along with you. Kisses to Quebec and Malta, love to my godson, a hearty shake of the hand to Lignum, and this for yourself, and I wish it was ten thousand pound in gold, my dear!'' (the trooper)
So saying, the trooper puts his (trooper) lips to the old girl's tanned forehead, and the door shuts upon him (trooper) in his (trooper) cell.

No entreaties on the part of the good old housekeeper will induce Mrs. Bagnet to retain the coach for her (Bagnet) own conveyance home. Jumping out cheerfully at the door of the Dedlock mansion and handing Mrs. Rouncewell up the steps, the old girl shakes hands and trudges off, arriving soon afterwards in the bosom of the Bagnet family and falling to washing the greens as if nothing had happened.

My Lady is in that room in which she (Lady) held her (Lady) last conference with the murdered man, and is sitting where she (Lady) sat that night, and is looking at the spot where he (man) stood upon the hearth studying her (Lady) so leisurely, when a tap comes at the door. Who is it? Mrs. Rouncewell. What has brought Mrs. Rouncewell to town so unexpectedly?

``Trouble, my Lady. Sad trouble. Oh, my Lady, may I beg a word with you?'' (this woman)

What new occurrence is it that makes this tranquil old woman tremble so? Far happier than her (woman) Lady, as her (woman) Lady has often thought, why does she (woman) falter in this manner and look at her (woman) with such strange mistrust?

``What is the matter? Sit down and take your breath.'' (unknown)

``Oh, my Lady, my Lady. I have found my son--my youngest, who went away for a soldier so long ago. And he (soldier) is in prison.'' (unknown)

``For debt?'' (unknown)

``Oh, no, my Lady; I would have paid any debt, and joyful.'' (unknown)

``For what is he (soldier) in prison then?'' (unknown)

``Charged with a murder, my Lady, of which he (soldier) is as innocent as--as I am. Accused of the murder of Mr. Tulkinghorn.'' (she)

What does she (woman) mean by this look and this imploring gesture? Why does she (woman) come so close? What is the letter that she (woman) holds?

``Lady Dedlock, my dear Lady, my good Lady, my kind Lady! You must have a heart to feel for me, you must have a heart to forgive me. I was in this family before you were born. I am devoted to it. But think of my dear son wrongfully accused.'' (unknown)

``I do not accuse him (son).'' (unknown)

``No, my Lady, no. But others do, and he (son) is in prison and in danger. Oh, Lady Dedlock, if you can say but a word to help to clear him (son), say it!'' (unknown)

What delusion can this be? What power does she (woman) suppose is in the person she (woman) petitions to avert this unjust suspicion, if it be unjust? Her (woman) Lady's handsome eyes regard her (Lady) with astonishment, almost with fear.

``My Lady, I came away last night from Chesney Wold to find my son in my old age, and the step upon the Ghost's Walk was so constant and so solemn that I never heard the like in all these years. Night after night, as it has fallen dark, the sound has echoed through your rooms, but last night it was awfullest. And as it fell dark last night, my Lady, I got this letter.'' (unknown)

``What letter is it?'' (unknown)

``Hush! Hush!'' (The housekeeper)
The housekeeper looks round and answers in a frightened whisper,
``My Lady, I have not breathed a word of it, I don't believe what's written in it, I know it can't be true, I am sure and certain that it is not true. But my son is in danger, and you must have a heart to pity me. If you know of anything that is not known to others, if you have any suspicion, if you have any clue at all, and any reason for keeping it in your own breast, oh, my dear Lady, think of me, and conquer that reason, and let it be known! This is the most I consider possible. I know you are not a hard lady, but you go your own way always without help, and you are not familiar with your friends; and all who admire you--and all do--as a beautiful and elegant lady, know you to be one far away from themselves who can't be approached close. My Lady, you may have some proud or angry reasons for disdaining to utter something that you know; if so, pray, oh, pray, think of a faithful servant whose whole life has been passed in this family which she (Lady) dearly loves, and relent, and help to clear my son! My Lady, my good Lady,'' (The housekeeper)
the old housekeeper pleads with genuine simplicity,
``I am so humble in my place and you are by nature so high and distant that you may not think what I feel for my child, but I feel so much that I have come here to make so bold as to beg and pray you not to be scornful of us if you can do us any right or justice at this fearful time!'' (housekeeper)

Lady Dedlock raises her (Dedlock) without one word, until she (Dedlock) takes the letter from her (Dedlock) hand.

``Am I to read this?'' (unknown)

``When I am gone, my Lady, if you please, and then remembering the most that I consider possible.'' (unknown)

``I know of nothing I can do. I know of nothing I reserve that can affect your son. I have never accused him (son).'' (unknown)

``My Lady, you may pity him (son) the more under a false accusation after reading the letter.'' (The housekeeper)

The old housekeeper leaves her (housekeeper) with the letter in her (housekeeper) hand. In truth she (housekeeper) is not a hard lady naturally, and the time has been when the sight of the venerable figure suing to her (lady) with such strong earnestness would have moved her (lady) to great compassion. But so long accustomed to suppress emotion and keep down reality, so long schooled for her (lady) own purposes in that destructive school which shuts up the natural feelings of the heart like flies in amber and spreads one uniform and dreary gloss over the good and bad, the feeling and the unfeeling, the sensible and the senseless, she (lady) had subdued even her (lady) wonder until now.

She (lady) opens the letter. Spread out upon the paper is a printed account of the discovery of the body as it lay face downward on the floor, shot through the heart; and underneath is written her (lady) own name, with the word

``murderess'' (unknown)
attached.

It falls out of her (lady) hand. How long it may have lain upon the ground she (lady) knows not, but it lies where it fell when a servant stands before her (lady) announcing the young man of the name of Guppy. The words have probably been repeated several times, for they are ringing in her (lady) head before she (lady) begins to understand them.

``Let him (son) come in!'' (He)

He (servant) comes in. Holding the letter in her (lady) hand, which she (lady) has taken from the floor, she (lady) tries to collect her (lady) thoughts. In the eyes of Mr. Guppy she (lady) is the same Lady Dedlock, holding the same prepared, proud, chilling state.

``Your ladyship may not be at first disposed to excuse this visit from one who has never been welcome to your ladyship'' (he)
--which he (Guppy) don't complain of, for he (Guppy) is bound to confess that there never has been any particular reason on the face of things why he (Guppy) should be--
``but I hope when I mention my motives to your ladyship you will not find fault with me,'' (he)
says Mr. Guppy.

``Do so.'' (unknown)

``Thank your ladyship. I ought first to explain to your ladyship,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
Mr. Guppy sits on the edge of a chair and puts his (Guppy) hat on the carpet at his (Guppy) feet,
``that Miss Summerson, whose image, as I formerly mentioned to your ladyship, was at one period of my life imprinted on my `eart until erased by circumstances over which I had no control, communicated to me, after I had the pleasure of waiting on your ladyship last, that she (Summerson) particularly wished me to take no steps whatever in any manner at all relating to her (Summerson). And Miss Summerson's wishes being to me a law -LRB-except as connected with circumstances over which I have no control-RRB-, I consequently never expected to have the distinguished honour of waiting on your ladyship again.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

And yet he (Guppy) is here now, Lady Dedlock moodily reminds him (Guppy).

``And yet I am here now,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
Mr. Guppy admits.
``My object being to communicate to your ladyship, under the seal of confidence, why I am here.'' (He)

He (Guppy) cannot do so, she (Dedlock) tells him (Guppy), too plainly or too briefly.

``Nor can I,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
Mr. Guppy returns with a sense of injury upon him (Guppy),
``too particularly request your ladyship to take particular notice that it's no personal affair of mine that brings me here. I have no interested views of my own to serve in coming here. If it was not for my promise to Miss Summerson and my keeping of it sacred--I, in point of fact, shouldn't have darkened these doors again, but should have seen 'em further first.'' (him)

Mr. Guppy considers this a favourable moment for sticking up his (Guppy) hair with both hands.

``Your ladyship will remember when I mention it that the last time I was here I run against a party very eminent in our profession and whose loss we all deplore. That party certainly did from that time apply himself to cutting in against me in a way that I will call sharp practice, and did make it, at every turn and point, extremely difficult for me to be sure that I hadn't inadvertently led up to something contrary to Miss Summerson's wishes. Self-praise is no recommendation, but I may say for myself that I am not so bad a man of business neither.'' (Lady Dedlock/Dedlock)

Lady Dedlock looks at him (Guppy) in stern inquiry. Mr. Guppy immediately withdraws his (Guppy) eyes from her (Dedlock) face and looks anywhere else.

``Indeed, it has been made so hard,'' (he)
he (Guppy) goes on,
``to have any idea what that party was up to in combination with others that until the loss which we all deplore I was gravelled--an expression which your ladyship, moving in the higher circles, will be so good as to consider tantamount to knocked over. Small likewise--a name by which I refer to another party, a friend of mine that your ladyship is not acquainted with--got to be so close and double-faced that at times it wasn't easy to keep one's hands off his (friend) `ead. However, what with the exertion of my humble abilities, and what with the help of a mutual friend by the name of Mr. Tony Weevle -LRB-who is of a high aristocratic turn and has your ladyship's portrait always hanging up in his (Mr.) room-RRB-, I have now reasons for an apprehension as to which I come to put your ladyship upon your guard. First, will your ladyship allow me to ask you whether you have had any strange visitors this morning? I don't mean fashionable visitors, but such visitors, for instance, as Miss Barbary's old servant, or as a person without the use of his (servant) lower extremities, carried upstairs similarly to a guy?'' (he)

``No!'' (unknown)

``Then I assure your ladyship that such visitors have been here and have been received here. Because I saw them at the door, and waited at the corner of the square till they came out, and took half an hour's turn afterwards to avoid them.'' (unknown)

``What have I to do with that, or what have you? I do not understand you. What do you mean?'' (unknown)

``Your ladyship, I come to put you on your guard. There may be no occasion for it. Very well. Then I have only done my best to keep my promise to Miss Summerson. I strongly suspect -LRB-from what Small has dropped, and from what we have corkscrewed out of him (guard)-RRB- that those letters I was to have brought to your ladyship were not destroyed when I supposed they were. That if there was anything to be blown upon, it IS blown upon. That the visitors I have alluded to have been here this morning to make money of it. And that the money is made, or making.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Mr. Guppy picks up his (Guppy) hat and rises.

``Your ladyship, you know best whether there's anything in what I say or whether there's nothing. Something or nothing, I have acted up to Miss Summerson's wishes in letting things alone and in undoing what I had begun to do, as far as possible; that's sufficient for me. In case I should be taking a liberty in putting your ladyship on your guard when there's no necessity for it, you will endeavour, I should hope, to outlive my presumption, and I shall endeavour to outlive your disapprobation. I now take my farewell of your ladyship, and assure you that there's no danger of your ever being waited on by me again.'' (She)

She (Dedlock) scarcely acknowledges these parting words by any look, but when he (Guppy) has been gone a little while, she (Dedlock) rings her (Dedlock) bell.

``Where is Sir Leicester?'' (he)

Mercury reports that he (Guppy) is at present shut up in the library alone.

``Has Sir Leicester had any visitors this morning?'' (unknown)

Several, on business. Mercury proceeds to a description of them, which has been anticipated by Mr. Guppy. Enough; he (Guppy) may go.

So! All is broken down. Her (Dedlock) name is in these many mouths, her (Dedlock) husband knows his (husband) wrongs, her (Dedlock) shame will be published--may be spreading while she (Dedlock) thinks about it--and in addition to the thunderbolt so long foreseen by her (Dedlock), so unforeseen by him (husband), she (Dedlock) is denounced by an invisible accuser as the murderess of her (Dedlock) enemy.

Her (Dedlock) enemy he (husband) was, and she (Dedlock) has often, often, often wished him (husband) dead. Her (Dedlock) enemy he (husband) is, even in his (husband) grave. This dreadful accusation comes upon her (Dedlock) like a new torment at his (husband) lifeless hand. And when she (Dedlock) recalls how she (Dedlock) was secretly at his (husband) door that night, and how she (Dedlock) may be represented to have sent her (Dedlock) favourite girl away so soon before merely to release herself from observation, she (Dedlock) shudders as if the hangman's hands were at her (Dedlock) neck.

She (Dedlock) has thrown herself upon the floor and lies with her (Dedlock) hair all wildly scattered and her (Dedlock) face buried in the cushions of a couch. She (Dedlock) rises up, hurries to and fro, flings herself down again, and rocks and moans. The horror that is upon her (Dedlock) is unutterable. If she (Dedlock) really were the murderess, it could hardly be, for the moment, more intense.

For as her (Dedlock) murderous perspective, before the doing of the deed, however subtle the precautions for its commission, would have been closed up by a gigantic dilatation of the hateful figure, preventing her (Dedlock) from seeing any consequences beyond it; and as those consequences would have rushed in, in an unimagined flood, the moment the figure was laid low--which always happens when a murder is done; so, now she (Dedlock) sees that when he (Dedlock) used to be on the watch before her (Dedlock), and she (Dedlock) used to think,

``if some mortal stroke would but fall on this old man and take him (man) from my way!'' (she)
it was but wishing that all he (Dedlock) held against her (Dedlock) in his (Dedlock) hand might be flung to the winds and chance-sown in many places. So, too, with the wicked relief she (Dedlock) has felt in his (Dedlock) death. What was his (Dedlock) death but the key-stone of a gloomy arch removed, and now the arch begins to fall in a thousand fragments, each crushing and mangling piecemeal!

Thus, a terrible impression steals upon and overshadows her (Dedlock) that from this pursuer, living or dead--obdurate and imperturbable before her (Dedlock) in his (pursuer) well-remembered shape, or not more obdurate and imperturbable in his (pursuer) coffin-bed--there is no escape but in death. Hunted, she (Dedlock) flies. The complication of her (Dedlock) shame, her (Dedlock) dread, remorse, and misery, overwhelms her (Dedlock) at its height; and even her (Dedlock) strength of self-reliance is overturned and whirled away like a leaf before a mighty wind.

She (Dedlock) hurriedly addresses these lines to her (Dedlock) husband, seals, and leaves them on her (Dedlock) table:

If I am sought for, or accused of, his (husband) murder, believe that I am wholly innocent. Believe no other good of me, for I am innocent of nothing else that you have heard, or will hear, laid to my charge. He (husband) prepared me, on that fatal night, for his (husband) disclosure of my guilt to you. After he (husband) had left me, I went out on pretence of walking in the garden where I sometimes walk, but really to follow him (husband) and make one last petition that he (husband) would not protract the dreadful suspense on which I have been racked by him (husband), you do not know how long, but would mercifully strike next morning.

I found his (husband) house dark and silent. I rang twice at his (husband) door, but there was no reply, and I came home.

I have no home left. I will encumber you no more. May you, in your just resentment, be able to forget the unworthy woman on whom you have wasted a most generous devotion--who avoids you only with a deeper shame than that with which she (woman) hurries from herself--and who writes this last adieu.

She (woman) veils and dresses quickly, leaves all her (woman) jewels and her (woman) money, listens, goes downstairs at a moment when the hall is empty, opens and shuts the great door, flutters away in the shrill frosty wind.

CHAPTER LVI

Pursuit

Impassive, as behoves its high breeding, the Dedlock town house stares at the other houses in the street of dismal grandeur and gives no outward sign of anything going wrong within. Carriages rattle, doors are battered at, the world exchanges calls; ancient charmers with skeleton throats and peachy cheeks that have a rather ghastly bloom upon them seen by daylight, when indeed these fascinating creatures look like Death and the Lady fused together, dazzle the eyes of men. Forth from the frigid mews come easily swinging carriages guided by short-legged coachmen in flaxen wigs, deep sunk into downy hammercloths, and up behind mount luscious Mercuries bearing sticks of state and wearing cocked hats broadwise, a spectacle for the angels.

The Dedlock town house changes not externally, and hours pass before its exalted dullness is disturbed within. But Volumnia the fair, being subject to the prevalent complaint of boredom and finding that disorder attacking her (Lady) spirits with some virulence, ventures at length to repair to the library for change of scene. Her (Lady) gentle tapping at the door producing no response, she (Lady) opens it and peeps in; seeing no one there, takes possession.

The sprightly Dedlock is reputed, in that grass-grown city of the ancients, Bath, to be stimulated by an urgent curiosity which impels her (Lady) on all convenient and inconvenient occasions to sidle about with a golden glass at her (Lady) eye, peering into objects of every description. Certain it is that she (Lady) avails herself of the present opportunity of hovering over her (Lady) kinsman's letters and papers like a bird, taking a short peck at this document and a blink with her (Lady) head on one side at that document, and hopping about from table to table with her (Lady) glass at her (Lady) eye in an inquisitive and restless manner. In the course of these researches she (Lady) stumbles over something, and turning her (Lady) glass in that direction, sees her (Lady) kinsman lying on the ground like a felled tree.

Volumnia's pet little scream acquires a considerable augmentation of reality from this surprise, and the house is quickly in commotion. Servants tear up and down stairs, bells are violently rung, doctors are sent for, and Lady Dedlock is sought in all directions, but not found. Nobody has seen or heard her (Dedlock) since she (Dedlock) last rang her (Dedlock) bell. Her (Dedlock) letter to Sir Leicester is discovered on her (Dedlock) table, but it is doubtful yet whether he (kinsman) has not received another missive from another world requiring to be personally answered, and all the living languages, and all the dead, are as one to him (kinsman).

They lay him (kinsman) down upon his (kinsman) bed, and chafe, and rub, and fan, and put ice to his (kinsman) head, and try every means of restoration. Howbeit, the day has ebbed away, and it is night in his (kinsman) room before his (kinsman) stertorous breathing lulls or his (kinsman) fixed eyes show any consciousness of the candle that is occasionally passed before them. But when this change begins, it goes on; and by and by he (kinsman) nods or moves his (kinsman) eyes or even his (kinsman) hand in token that he (kinsman) hears and comprehends.

He (kinsman) fell down, this morning, a handsome stately gentleman, somewhat infirm, but of a fine presence, and with a well-filled face. He (kinsman) lies upon his (kinsman) bed, an aged man with sunken cheeks, the decrepit shadow of himself. His (kinsman) voice was rich and mellow and he (kinsman) had so long been thoroughly persuaded of the weight and import to mankind of any word he (kinsman) said that his (kinsman) words really had come to sound as if there were something in them. But now he (kinsman) can only whisper, and what he (kinsman) whispers sounds like what it is--mere jumble and jargon.

His (kinsman) favourite and faithful housekeeper stands at his (kinsman) bedside. It is the first act he (kinsman) notices, and he (kinsman) clearly derives pleasure from it. After vainly trying to make himself understood in speech, he (kinsman) makes signs for a pencil. So inexpressively that they cannot at first understand him (kinsman); it is his (kinsman) old housekeeper who makes out what he (kinsman) wants and brings in a slate.

After pausing for some time, he (kinsman) slowly scrawls upon it in a hand that is not his (kinsman),

``Chesney Wold?'' (he)

No, she (housekeeper) tells him (kinsman); he (kinsman) is in London. He (kinsman) was taken ill in the library this morning. Right thankful she (housekeeper) is that she (housekeeper) happened to come to London and is able to attend upon him (kinsman).

``It is not an illness of any serious consequence, Sir Leicester. You will be much better to-morrow, Sir Leicester. All the gentlemen say so.'' (unknown)
This, with the tears coursing down her (housekeeper) fair old face.

After making a survey of the room and looking with particular attention all round the bed where the doctors stand, he (kinsman) writes,

``My Lady.'' (he)

``My Lady went out, Sir Leicester, before you were taken ill, and don't know of your illness yet.'' (He)

He (kinsman) points again, in great agitation, at the two words. They all try to quiet him (kinsman), but he (kinsman) points again with increased agitation. On their looking at one another, not knowing what to say, he (kinsman) takes the slate once more and writes

``My Lady. For God's sake, where?'' (he)
And makes an imploring moan.

It is thought better that his (kinsman) old housekeeper should give him (kinsman) Lady Dedlock's letter, the contents of which no one knows or can surmise. She (Dedlock) opens it for him (kinsman) and puts it out for his (kinsman) perusal. Having read it twice by a great effort, he (kinsman) turns it down so that it shall not be seen and lies moaning. He (kinsman) passes into a kind of relapse or into a swoon, and it is an hour before he (kinsman) opens his (kinsman) eyes, reclining on his (kinsman) faithful and attached old servant's arm. The doctors know that he (kinsman) is best with her (Dedlock), and when not actively engaged about him (kinsman), stand aloof.

The slate comes into requisition again, but the word he (kinsman) wants to write he (kinsman) cannot remember. His (kinsman) anxiety, his (kinsman) eagerness, and affliction at this pass are pitiable to behold. It seems as if he (kinsman) must go mad in the necessity he (kinsman) feels for haste and the inability under which he (kinsman) labours of expressing to do what or to fetch whom. He (kinsman) has written the letter B, and there stopped. Of a sudden, in the height of his (kinsman) misery, he (kinsman) puts Mr. before it. The old housekeeper suggests Bucket. Thank heaven! That's his (kinsman) meaning.

Mr. Bucket is found to be downstairs, by appointment. Shall he (Mr.) come up?

There is no possibility of misconstruing Sir Leicester's burning wish to see him (Mr.) or the desire he (Mr.) signifies to have the room cleared of every one but the housekeeper. It is speedily done, and Mr. Bucket appears. Of all men upon earth, Sir Leicester seems fallen from his (Bucket) high estate to place his (Bucket) sole trust and reliance upon this man.

``Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, I'm sorry to see you like this. I hope you'll cheer up. I'm sure you will, on account of the family credit.'' (Leicester Dedlock/Leicester/Dedlock)
