Sir Leicester puts her (housekeeper) letter in his (Bucket) hands and looks intently in his (Bucket) face while he (Bucket) reads it. A new intelligence comes into Mr. Bucket's eye as he (Bucket) reads on; with one hook of his (Bucket) finger, while that eye is still glancing over the words, he (Bucket) indicates,

``Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, I understand you.'' (he)

Sir Leicester writes upon the slate.

``Full forgiveness. Find--'' (Mr. Bucket)
Mr. Bucket stops his (Bucket) hand.

``Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, I'll find her (Lady). But my search after her (Lady) must be begun out of hand. Not a minute must be lost.'' (he)

With the quickness of thought, he (Bucket) follows Sir Leicester Dedlock's look towards a little box upon a table.

``Bring it here, Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet? Certainly. Open it with one of these here keys? Certainly. The littlest key? TO be sure. Take the notes out? So I will. Count 'em? That's soon done. Twenty and thirty's fifty, and twenty's seventy, and fifty's one twenty, and forty's one sixty. Take 'em for expenses? That I'll do, and render an account of course. Don't spare money? No I won't.'' (Mr.)

The velocity and certainty of Mr. Bucket's interpretation on all these heads is little short of miraculous. Mrs. Rouncewell, who holds the light, is giddy with the swiftness of his (Mr.) eyes and hands as he (Mr.) starts up, furnished for his (Mr.) journey.

``You're George's mother, old lady; that's about what you are, I believe?'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket aside, with his (Mr.) hat already on and buttoning his (Mr.) coat.

``Yes, sir, I am his (George) distressed mother.'' (unknown)

``So I thought, according to what he (George) mentioned to me just now. Well, then, I'll tell you something. You needn't be distressed no more. Your son's all right. Now, don't you begin a-crying, because what you've got to do is to take care of Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, and you won't do that by crying. As to your son, he (son)'s all right, I tell you; and he (son) sends his (son) loving duty, and hoping you're the same. He (son)'s discharged honourable; that's about what HE (son) is; with no more imputation on his (son) character than there is on yours, and yours is a tidy one, I

``LL bet a pound. You may trust me, for I took your son. He (son) conducted himself in a game way, too, on that occasion; and he (son)'s a fine-made man, and you're a fine-made old lady, and you're a mother and son, the pair of you, as might be showed for models in a caravan. Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, what you've trusted to me I'll go through with. Don't you be afraid of my turning out of my way, right or left, or taking a sleep, or a wash, or a shave till I have found what I go in search of. Say everything as is kind and forgiving on your part? Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, I will. And I wish you better, and these family affairs smoothed over--as, Lord, many other family affairs equally has been, and equally will be, to the end of time.'' (Mr.)

With this peroration, Mr. Bucket, buttoned up, goes quietly out, looking steadily before him (Mr.) as if he (Mr.) were already piercing the night in quest of the fugitive.

His (Mr.) first step is to take himself to Lady Dedlock's rooms and look all over them for any trifling indication that may help him (Mr.). The rooms are in darkness now; and to see Mr. Bucket with a wax-light in his (Mr.) hand, holding it above his (Mr.) head and taking a sharp mental inventory of the many delicate objects so curiously at variance with himself, would be to see a sight--which nobody DOES see, as he (Mr.) is particular to lock himself in.

``A spicy boudoir, this,'' (Mr. Bucket)
says Mr. Bucket, who feels in a manner furbished up in his (Bucket) French by the blow of the morning.
``Must have cost a sight of money. Rum articles to cut away from, these; she (I) must have been hard put to it!'' (he)

Opening and shutting table-drawers and looking into caskets and jewel-cases, he (Bucket) sees the reflection of himself in various mirrors, and moralizes thereon.

``One might suppose I was a-moving in the fashionable circles and getting myself up for almac's,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket.
``I begin to think I must be a swell in the Guards without knowing it.'' (he)

Ever looking about, he (Mr.) has opened a dainty little chest in an inner drawer. His (Mr.) great hand, turning over some gloves which it can scarcely feel, they are so light and soft within it, comes upon a white handkerchief.

``Hum! Let's have a look at YOU,'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket, putting down the light.
``What should YOU be kept by yourself for? What's YOUR motive? Are you her (I) ladyship's property, or somebody else's? You've got a mark upon you somewheres or another, I suppose?'' (He)

He (Mr.) finds it as he (Mr.) speaks,

``Esther Summerson.'' (he)

``Oh!'' (Mr.)
says Mr. Bucket, pausing, with his (Mr.) finger at his (Mr.) ear.
``Come, I'll take YOU.'' (He)

He (Mr.) completes his (Mr.) observations as quietly and carefully as he (Mr.) has carried them on, leaves everything else precisely as he (Mr.) found it, glides away after some five minutes in all, and passes into the street. With a glance upward at the dimly lighted windows of Sir Leicester's room, he (Mr.) sets off, full-swing, to the nearest coach-stand, picks out the horse for his (Mr.) money, and directs to be driven to the shooting gallery. Mr. Bucket does not claim to be a scientific judge of horses, but he (Mr.) lays out a little money on the principal events in that line, and generally sums up his (Mr.) knowledge of the subject in the remark that when he (Mr.) sees a horse as can go, he (Mr.) knows him (Mr.).

His (Mr.) knowledge is not at fault in the present instance. Clattering over the stones at a dangerous pace, yet thoughtfully bringing his (Mr.) keen eyes to bear on every slinking creature whom he (Mr.) passes in the midnight streets, and even on the lights in upper windows where people are going or gone to bed, and on all the turnings that he (Mr.) rattles by, and alike on the heavy sky, and on the earth where the snow lies thin--for something may present itself to assist him (Mr.), anywhere--he (Mr.) dashes to his (Mr.) destination at such a speed that when he (Mr.) stops the horse half smothers him (Mr.) in a cloud of steam.

``Unbear him (somebody) half a moment to freshen him (somebody) up, and I'll be back.'' (He)

He (Mr.) runs up the long wooden entry and finds the trooper smoking his (Mr.) pipe.

``I thought I should, George, after what you have gone through, my lad. I haven't a word to spare. Now, honour! All to save a woman. Miss Summerson that was here when Gridley died--that was the name, I know--all right--where does she (Summerson) live?'' (The trooper)

The trooper has just come from there and gives him (Mr.) the address, near Oxford Street.

``You won't repent it, George. Good night!'' (He)

He (Mr.) is off again, with an impression of having seen Phil sitting by the frosty fire staring at him (Phil) open-mouthed, and gallops away again, and gets out in a cloud of steam again.

Mr. Jarndyce, the only person up in the house, is just going to bed, rises from his (Jarndyce) book on hearing the rapid ringing at the bell, and comes down to the door in his (Jarndyce) dressing-gown.

``Don't be alarmed, sir.'' (visitor)
In a moment his (Jarndyce) visitor is confidential with him (Jarndyce) in the hall, has shut the door, and stands with his (Jarndyce) hand upon the lock.
``I've had the pleasure of seeing you before. Inspector Bucket. Look at that handkerchief, sir, Miss Esther Summerson's. Found it myself put away in a drawer of Lady Dedlock's, quarter of an hour ago. Not a moment to lose. Matter of life or death. You know Lady Dedlock?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``There has been a discovery there to-day. Family affairs have come out. Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, has had a fit--apoplexy or paralysis--and couldn't be brought to, and precious time has been lost. Lady Dedlock disappeared this afternoon and left a letter for him (Dedlock) that looks bad. Run your eye over it. Here it is!'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)

Mr. Jarndyce, having read it, asks him (Jarndyce) what he (Jarndyce) thinks.

``I don't know. It looks like suicide. Anyways, there's more and more danger, every minute, of its drawing to that. I'd give a hundred pound an hour to have got the start of the present time. Now, Mr. Jarndyce, I am employed by Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, to follow her (Dedlock) and find her (Dedlock), to save her (Dedlock) and take her (Dedlock) his (Jarndyce) forgiveness. I have money and full power, but I want something else. I want Miss Summerson.'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)

Mr. Jarndyce in a troubled voice repeats,

``Miss Summerson?'' (Mr. Jarndyce/Jarndyce)

``Now, Mr. Jarndyce'' (Mr. Bucket)
--Mr. Bucket has read his (Bucket) face with the greatest attention all along--
``I speak to you as a gentleman of a humane heart, and under such pressing circumstances as don't often happen. If ever delay was dangerous, it's dangerous now; and if ever you couldn't afterwards forgive yourself for causing it, this is the time. Eight or ten hours, worth, as I tell you, a hundred pound apiece at least, have been lost since Lady Dedlock disappeared. I am charged to find her (Dedlock). I am Inspector Bucket. Besides all the rest that's heavy on her (Dedlock), she (Dedlock) has upon her (Dedlock), as she (Dedlock) believes, suspicion of murder. If I follow her (Dedlock) alone, she (Dedlock), being in ignorance of what Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, has communicated to me, may be driven to desperation. But if I follow her (Dedlock) in company with a young lady, answering to the description of a young lady that she (lady) has a tenderness for--I ask no question, and I say no more than that--she (lady) will give me credit for being friendly. Let me come up with her (lady) and be able to have the hold upon her (lady) of putting that young lady for`ard, and I'll save her (lady) and prevail with her (lady) if she (lady) is alive. Let me come up with her (lady) alone--a hard matter--and I'll do my best, but I don't answer for what the best may be. Time flies; it's getting on for one o'clock. When one strikes, there's another hour gone, and it's worth a thousand pound now instead of a hundred.'' (Mr. Bucket)

This is all true, and the pressing nature of the case cannot be questioned. Mr. Jarndyce begs him (Jarndyce) to remain there while he (Jarndyce) speaks to Miss Summerson. Mr. Bucket says he (Bucket) will, but acting on his (Bucket) usual principle, does no such thing, following upstairs instead and keeping his (Bucket) man in sight. So he (Bucket) remains, dodging and lurking about in the gloom of the staircase while they confer. In a very little time Mr. Jarndyce comes down and tells him (Jarndyce) that Miss Summerson will join him (Jarndyce) directly and place herself under his (Jarndyce) protection to accompany him (Jarndyce) where he (Jarndyce) pleases. Mr. Bucket, satisfied, expresses high approval and awaits her (Summerson) coming at the door.

There he (Mr.) mounts a high tower in his (Mr.) mind and looks out far and wide. Many solitary figures he (Mr.) perceives creeping through the streets; many solitary figures out on heaths, and roads, and lying under haystacks. But the figure that he (Mr.) seeks is not among them. Other solitaries he (Mr.) perceives, in nooks of bridges, looking over; and in shadowed places down by the river's level; and a dark, dark, shapeless object drifting with the tide, more solitary than all, clings with a drowning hold on his (Mr.) attention.

Where is she (Mr.)? Living or dead, where is she (Mr.)? If, as he (Mr.) folds the handkerchief and carefully puts it up, it were able with an enchanted power to bring before him (Mr.) the place where she (Mr.) found it and the night-landscape near the cottage where it covered the little child, would he (Mr.) descry her (Mr.) there? On the waste where the brick-kilns are burning with a pale blue flare, where the straw-roofs of the wretched huts in which the bricks are made are being scattered by the wind, where the clay and water are hard frozen and the mill in which the gaunt blind horse goes round all day looks like an instrument of human torture--traversing this deserted, blighted spot there is a lonely figure with the sad world to itself, pelted by the snow and driven by the wind, and cast out, it would seem, from all companionship. It is the figure of a woman, too; but it is miserably dressed, and no such clothes ever came through the hall and out at the great door of the Dedlock mansion.

CHAPTER LVII

Esther's Narrative

I had gone to bed and fallen asleep when my guardian knocked at the door of my room and begged me to get up directly. On my hurrying to speak to him (my) and learn what had happened, he (my) told me, after a word or two of preparation, that there had been a discovery at Sir Leicester Dedlock's. That my mother had fled, that a person was now at our door who was empowered to convey to her (mother) the fullest assurances of affectionate protection and forgiveness if he (my) could possibly find her (mother), and that I was sought for to accompany him (my) in the hope that my entreaties might prevail upon her (mother) if his (my) failed. Something to this general purpose I made out, but I was thrown into such a tumult of alarm, and hurry and distress, that in spite of every effort I could make to subdue my agitation, I did not seem, to myself, fully to recover my right mind until hours had passed.

But I dressed and wrapped up expeditiously without waking Charley or any one and went down to Mr. Bucket, who was the person entrusted with the secret. In taking me to him (Bucket) my guardian told me this, and also explained how it was that he (Bucket) had come to think of me. Mr. Bucket, in a low voice, by the light of my guardian's candle, read to me in the hall a letter that my mother had left upon her (mother) table; and I suppose within ten minutes of my having been aroused I was sitting beside him (Mr.), rolling swiftly through the streets.

His (Mr.) manner was very keen, and yet considerate when he (Mr.) explained to me that a great deal might depend on my being able to answer, without confusion, a few questions that he (Mr.) wished to ask me. These were, chiefly, whether I had had much communication with my mother -LRB-to whom he (Mr.) only referred as Lady Dedlock-RRB-, when and where I had spoken with her (Lady) last, and how she (Lady) had become possessed of my handkerchief. When I had satisfied him (Mr.) on these points, he (Mr.) asked me particularly to consider--taking time to think--whether within my knowledge there was any one, no matter where, in whom she (Lady) might be at all likely to confide under circumstances of the last necessity. I could think of no one but my guardian. But by and by I mentioned Mr. Boythorn. He (Boythorn) came into my mind as connected with his (Boythorn) old chivalrous manner of mentioning my mother's name and with what my guardian had informed me of his (Boythorn) engagement to her (mother) sister and his (Boythorn) unconscious connexion with her (mother) unhappy story.

My companion had stopped the driver while we held this conversation, that we might the better hear each other. He (companion) now told him (companion) to go on again and said to me, after considering within himself for a few moments, that he (companion) had made up his (companion) mind how to proceed. He (companion) was quite willing to tell me what his (companion) plan was, but I did not feel clear enough to understand it.

We had not driven very far from our lodgings when we stopped in a by-street at a public-looking place lighted up with gas. Mr. Bucket took me in and sat me in an arm-chair by a bright fire. It was now past one, as I saw by the clock against the wall. Two police officers, looking in their perfectly neat uniform not at all like people who were up all night, were quietly writing at a desk; and the place seemed very quiet altogether, except for some beating and calling out at distant doors underground, to which nobody paid any attention.

A third man in uniform, whom Mr. Bucket called and to whom he (Bucket) whispered his (Bucket) instructions, went out; and then the two others advised together while one wrote from Mr. Bucket's subdued dictation. It was a description of my mother that they were busy with, for Mr. Bucket brought it to me when it was done and read it in a whisper. It was very accurate indeed.

The second officer, who had attended to it closely, then copied it out and called in another man in uniform -LRB-there were several in an outer room-RRB-, who took it up and went away with it. All this was done with the greatest dispatch and without the waste of a moment; yet nobody was at all hurried. As soon as the paper was sent out upon its travels, the two officers resumed their former quiet work of writing with neatness and care. Mr. Bucket thoughtfully came and warmed the soles of his (Mr.) boots, first one and then the other, at the fire.

``Are you well wrapped up, Miss Summerson?'' (he)
he (Mr.) asked me as his (Mr.) eyes met mine.
``It's a desperate sharp night for a young lady to be out in.'' (I)

I told him (Mr.) I cared for no weather and was warmly clothed.

``It may be a long job,'' (he)
he (Mr.) observed;
``but so that it ends well, never mind, miss.'' (he)

``I pray to heaven it may end well!'' (I)
said I.

He (Mr.) nodded comfortingly.

``You see, whatever you do, don't you go and fret yourself. You keep yourself cool and equal for anything that may happen, and it'll be the better for you, the better for me, the better for Lady Dedlock, and the better for Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet.'' (He)

He (Mr.) was really very kind and gentle, and as he (Mr.) stood before the fire warming his (Mr.) boots and rubbing his (Mr.) face with his (Mr.) forefinger, I felt a confidence in his (Mr.) sagacity which reassured me. It was not yet a quarter to two when I heard horses' feet and wheels outside.

``Now, Miss Summerson,'' (he)
said he (Mr.),
``we are off, if you please!'' (he)

He (Mr.) gave me his (Mr.) arm, and the two officers courteously bowed me out, and we found at the door a phaeton or barouche with a postilion and post horses. Mr. Bucket handed me in and took his (Mr.) own seat on the box. The man in uniform whom he (man) had sent to fetch this equipage then handed him (man) up a dark lantern at his (man) request, and when he (man) had given a few directions to the driver, we rattled away.

I was far from sure that I was not in a dream. We rattled with great rapidity through such a labyrinth of streets that I soon lost all idea where we were, except that we had crossed and re-crossed the river, and still seemed to be traversing a low-lying, waterside, dense neighbourhood of narrow thoroughfares chequered by docks and basins, high piles of warehouses, swing-bridges, and masts of ships. At length we stopped at the corner of a little slimy turning, which the wind from the river, rushing up it, did not purify; and I saw my companion, by the light of his (companion) lantern, in conference with several men who looked like a mixture of police and sailors. Against the mouldering wall by which they stood, there was a bill, on which I could discern the words,

``Found Drowned'' (I)
; and this and an inscription about drags possessed me with the awful suspicion shadowed forth in our visit to that place.

I had no need to remind myself that I was not there by the indulgence of any feeling of mine to increase the difficulties of the search, or to lessen its hopes, or enhance its delays. I remained quiet, but what I suffered in that dreadful spot I never can forget. And still it was like the horror of a dream. A man yet dark and muddy, in long swollen sodden boots and a hat like them, was called out of a boat and whispered with Mr. Bucket, who went away with him (Bucket) down some slippery steps--as if to look at something secret that he (Bucket) had to show. They came back, wiping their hands upon their coats, after turning over something wet; but thank God it was not what I feared!

After some further conference, Mr. Bucket -LRB-whom everybody seemed to know and defer to-RRB- went in with the others at a door and left me in the carriage, while the driver walked up and down by his (driver) horses to warm himself. The tide was coming in, as I judged from the sound it made, and I could hear it break at the end of the alley with a little rush towards me. It never did so--and I thought it did so, hundreds of times, in what can have been at the most a quarter of an hour, and probably was less--but the thought shuddered through me that it would cast my mother at the horses' feet.

Mr. Bucket came out again, exhorting the others to be vigilant, darkened his (Bucket) lantern, and once more took his (Bucket) seat.

``Don't you be alarmed, Miss Summerson, on account of our coming down here,'' (he)
he (Bucket) said, turning to me.
``I only want to have everything in train and to know that it is in train by looking after it myself. Get on, my lad!'' (unknown)

We appeared to retrace the way we had come. Not that I had taken note of any particular objects in my perturbed state of mind, but judging from the general character of the streets. We called at another office or station for a minute and crossed the river again. During the whole of this time, and during the whole search, my companion, wrapped up on the box, never relaxed in his (companion) vigilance a single moment; but when we crossed the bridge he (companion) seemed, if possible, to be more on the alert than before. He (companion) stood up to look over the parapet, he (companion) alighted and went back after a shadowy female figure that flitted past us, and he (companion) gazed into the profound black pit of water with a face that made my heart die within me. The river had a fearful look, so overcast and secret, creeping away so fast between the low flat lines of shore--so heavy with indistinct and awful shapes, both of substance and shadow; so death-like and mysterious. I have seen it many times since then, by sunlight and by moonlight, but never free from the impressions of that journey. In my memory the lights upon the bridge are always burning dim, the cutting wind is eddying round the homeless woman whom we pass, the monotonous wheels are whirling on, and the light of the carriage-lamps reflected back looks palely in upon me--a face rising out of the dreaded water.

Clattering and clattering through the empty streets, we came at length from the pavement on to dark smooth roads and began to leave the houses behind us. After a while I recognized the familiar way to Saint Albans. At Barnet fresh horses were ready for us, and we changed and went on. It was very cold indeed, and the open country was white with snow, though none was falling then.

``An old acquaintance of yours, this road, Miss Summerson,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket cheerfully.

``Yes,'' (I)
I returned.
``Have you gathered any intelligence?'' (unknown)

``None that can be quite depended on as yet,'' (he)
he (Mr.) answered,
``but it's early times as yet.'' (he)

He (Mr.) had gone into every late or early public-house where there was a light -LRB-they were not a few at that time, the road being then much frequented by drovers-RRB- and had got down to talk to the turnpike-keepers. I had heard him (Mr.) ordering drink, and chinking money, and making himself agreeable and merry everywhere; but whenever he (Mr.) took his (Mr.) seat upon the box again, his (Mr.) face resumed its watchful steady look, and he (Mr.) always said to the driver in the same business tone,

``Get on, my lad!'' (the driver)

With all these stoppages, it was between five and six o'clock and we were yet a few miles short of Saint Albans when he (Saint) came out of one of these houses and handed me in a cup of tea.

``Drink it, Miss Summerson, it'll do you good. You're beginning to get more yourself now, ain't you?'' (I)

I thanked him (Saint) and said I hoped so.

``You was what you may call stunned at first,'' (he)
he (Saint) returned;
``and Lord, no wonder! Don't speak loud, my dear. It's all right. She (Summerson)'s on ahead.'' (he)

I don't know what joyful exclamation I made or was going to make, but he (Saint) put up his (Saint) finger and I stopped myself.

``Passed through here on foot this evening about eight or nine. I heard of her (Summerson) first at the archway toll, over at Highgate, but couldn't make quite sure. Traced her (Summerson) all along, on and off. Picked her (Summerson) up at one place, and dropped her (Summerson) at another; but she (Summerson)'s before us now, safe. Take hold of this cup and saucer, ostler. Now, if you wasn't brought up to the butter trade, look out and see if you can catch half a crown in your t`other hand. One, two, three, and there you are! Now, my lad, try a gallop!'' (Saint)

We were soon in Saint Albans and alighted a little before day, when I was just beginning to arrange and comprehend the occurrences of the night and really to believe that they were not a dream. Leaving the carriage at the posting-house and ordering fresh horses to be ready, my companion gave me his (companion) arm, and we went towards home.

``As this is your regular abode, Miss Summerson, you see,'' (he)
he (companion) observed,
``I should like to know whether you've been asked for by any stranger answering the description, or whether Mr. Jarndyce has. I don't much expect it, but it might be.'' (he)

As we ascended the hill, he (companion) looked about him (companion) with a sharp eye--the day was now breaking--and reminded me that I had come down it one night, as I had reason for remembering, with my little servant and poor Jo, whom he (servant) called Toughey.

I wondered how he (servant) knew that.

``When you passed a man upon the road, just yonder, you know,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket.

Yes, I remembered that too, very well.

``That was me,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket.

Seeing my surprise, he (Mr.) went on,

``I drove down in a gig that afternoon to look after that boy. You might have heard my wheels when you came out to look after him (boy) yourself, for I was aware of you and your little maid going up when I was walking the horse down. Making an inquiry or two about him (boy) in the town, I soon heard what company he (boy) was in and was coming among the brick-fields to look for him (boy) when I observed you bringing him (boy) home here.'' (he)

``Had he (boy) committed any crime?'' (I)
I asked.

``None was charged against him (boy),'' (Mr. Bucket)
said Mr. Bucket, coolly lifting off his (Bucket) hat,
``but I suppose he (boy) wasn't over-particular. No. What I wanted him (boy) for was in connexion with keeping this very matter of Lady Dedlock quiet. He (boy) had been making his (boy) tongue more free than welcome as to a small accidental service he (boy) had been paid for by the deceased Mr. Tulkinghorn; and it wouldn't do, at any sort of price, to have him (Tulkinghorn) playing those games. So having warned him (Tulkinghorn) out of London, I made an afternoon of it to warn him (Tulkinghorn) to keep out of it now he (Tulkinghorn) WAS away, and go farther from it, and maintain a bright look-out that I didn't catch him (Tulkinghorn) coming back again.'' (Mr. Bucket)

``Poor creature!'' (I.)
said I.

``Poor enough,'' (I.)
assented Mr. Bucket,
``and trouble enough, and well enough away from London, or anywhere else. I was regularly turned on my back when I found him (Tulkinghorn) taken up by your establishment, I do assure you.'' (Mr. Bucket)

I asked him (Bucket) why.

``Why, my dear?'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket.
``Naturally there was no end to his (Tulkinghorn) tongue then. He (Tulkinghorn) might as well have been born with a yard and a half of it, and a remnant over.'' (I)

Although I remember this conversation now, my head was in confusion at the time, and my power of attention hardly did more than enable me to understand that he (Mr.) entered into these particulars to divert me. With the same kind intention, manifestly, he (Mr.) often spoke to me of indifferent things, while his (Mr.) face was busy with the one object that we had in view. He (Mr.) still pursued this subject as we turned in at the garden-gate.

``Ah!'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket.
``Here we are, and a nice retired place it is. Puts a man in mind of the country house in the Woodpecker-tapping, that was known by the smoke which so gracefully curled. They're early with the kitchen fire, and that denotes good servants. But what you've always got to be careful of with servants is who comes to see 'em; you never know what they're up to if you don't know that. And another thing, my dear. Whenever you find a young man behind the kitchen-door, you give that young man in charge on suspicion of being secreted in a dwelling-house with an unlawful purpose.'' (unknown)

We were now in front of the house; he (Mr.) looked attentively and closely at the gravel for footprints before he (Mr.) raised his (Mr.) eyes to the windows.

``Do you generally put that elderly young gentleman in the same room when he (gentleman)'s on a visit here, Miss Summerson?'' (he)
he (Mr.) inquired, glancing at Mr. Skimpole's usual chamber.

``You know Mr. Skimpole!'' (I.)
said I.

``What do you call him (Skimpole) again?'' (I.)
returned Mr. Bucket, bending down his (Bucket) ear.
``Skimpole, is it? I've often wondered what his (Skimpole) name might be. Skimpole. Not John, I should say, nor yet Jacob?'' (unknown)

``Harold,'' (I)
I told him (Bucket).

``Harold. Yes. He (Harold)'s a queer bird is Harold,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket, eyeing me with great expression.

``He (Harold) is a singular character,'' (I.)
said I.

``No idea of money,'' (I.)
observed Mr. Bucket.
``He (Harold) takes it, though!'' (I)

I involuntarily returned for answer that I perceived Mr. Bucket knew him (Mr.).

``Why, now I'll tell you, Miss Summerson,'' (he)
he (Mr.) replied. ``Your mind will be all the better for not running on one point too continually, and I'll tell you for a change. It was him (Harold) as pointed out to me where Toughey was. I made up my mind that night to come to the door and ask for Toughey, if that was all; but willing to try a move or so first, if any such was on the board, I just pitched up a morsel of gravel at that window where I saw a shadow. As soon as Harold opens it and I have had a look at him (Harold), thinks I, you're the man for me. So I smoothed him (man) down a bit about not wanting to disturb the family after they was gone to bed and about its being a thing to be regretted that charitable young ladies should harbour vagrants; and then, when I pretty well understood his (man) ways, I said I should consider a fypunnote well bestowed if I could relieve the premises of Toughey without causing any noise or trouble. Then says he (man), lifting up his (man) eyebrows in the gayest way, ``It's no use mentioning a fypunnote to me, my friend, because I'm a mere child in such matters and have no idea of money.'' Of course I understood what his (Mr.) taking it so easy meant; and being now quite sure he (Mr.) was the man for me, I wrapped the note round a little stone and threw it up to him (Mr.). Well! He (Mr.) laughs and beams, and looks as innocent as you like, and says, ``But I don't know the value of these things. What am I to DO with this?'' ``Spend it, sir,'' says I. ``But I shall be taken in,
'' he (Mr.) says, `they won't give me the right change, I shall lose it, it's no use to me.'' (I)
Lord, you never saw such a face as he (Lord) carried it with! Of course he (Lord) told me where to find Toughey, and I found him (Lord).''

I regarded this as very treacherous on the part of Mr. Skimpole towards my guardian and as passing the usual bounds of his (Skimpole) childish innocence.

``Bounds, my dear?'' (Mr.)
returned Mr. Bucket. ``Bounds? Now, Miss Summerson, I'll give you a piece of advice that your husband will find useful when you are happily married and have got a family about you. Whenever a person says to you that they are as innocent as can be in all concerning money, look well after your own money, for they are dead certain to collar it if they can. Whenever a person proclaims to you ``In worldly matters I'm a child,
'' you consider that that person is only a-crying off from being held accountable and that you have got that person's number, and it's Number One. Now, I am not a poetical man myself, except in a vocal way when it goes round a company, but I'm a practical one, and that's my experience. So's this rule. Fast and loose in one thing, fast and loose in everything. I never knew it fail. No more will you. Nor no one. With which caution to the unwary, my dear, I take the liberty of pulling this here bell, and so go back to our business.'' (a child)

I believe it had not been for a moment out of his (man) mind, any more than it had been out of my mind, or out of his (man) face. The whole household were amazed to see me, without any notice, at that time in the morning, and so accompanied; and their surprise was not diminished by my inquiries. No one, however, had been there. It could not be doubted that this was the truth.

``Then, Miss Summerson,'' (companion)
said my companion,
``we can't be too soon at the cottage where those brickmakers are to be found. Most inquiries there I leave to you, if you'll be so good as to make 'em. The naturalest way is the best way, and the naturalest way is your own way.'' (companion)

We set off again immediately. On arriving at the cottage, we found it shut up and apparently deserted, but one of the neighbours who knew me and who came out when I was trying to make some one hear informed me that the two women and their husbands now lived together in another house, made of loose rough bricks, which stood on the margin of the piece of ground where the kilns were and where the long rows of bricks were drying. We lost no time in repairing to this place, which was within a few hundred yards; and as the door stood ajar, I pushed it open.

There were only three of them sitting at breakfast, the child lying asleep on a bed in the corner. It was Jenny, the mother of the dead child, who was absent. The other woman rose on seeing me; and the men, though they were, as usual, sulky and silent, each gave me a morose nod of recognition. A look passed between them when Mr. Bucket followed me in, and I was surprised to see that the woman evidently knew him (Mr.).

I had asked leave to enter of course. Liz -LRB-the only name by which I knew her (Liz)-RRB- rose to give me her (Liz) own chair, but I sat down on a stool near the fire, and Mr. Bucket took a corner of the bedstead. Now that I had to speak and was among people with whom I was not familiar, I became conscious of being hurried and giddy. It was very difficult to begin, and I could not help bursting into tears.

``Liz,'' (I)
said I,
``I have come a long way in the night and through the snow to inquire after a lady--'' (I)

``Who has been here, you know,'' (I)
Mr. Bucket struck in, addressing the whole group with a composed propitiatory face;
``that's the lady the young lady means. The lady that was here last night, you know.'' (Mr.)

``And who told YOU as there was anybody here?'' (Jenny/Will Jenny)
inquired Jenny's husband, who had made a surly stop in his (husband) eating to listen and now measured him (husband) with his (husband) eye.

``A person of the name of Michael Jackson, with a blue welveteen waistcoat with a double row of mother of pearl buttons,'' (Mr.)
Mr. Bucket immediately answered.

``He (Jackson) had as good mind his (Jackson) own business, whoever he (Jackson) is,'' (the man)
growled the man.

``He (Jackson)'s out of employment, I believe,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket apologetically for Michael Jackson,
``and so gets talking.'' (Michael Jackson/Michael)

The woman had not resumed her (woman) chair, but stood faltering with her (woman) hand upon its broken back, looking at me. I thought she (woman) would have spoken to me privately if she (woman) had dared. She (woman) was still in this attitude of uncertainty when her (woman) husband, who was eating with a lump of bread and fat in one hand and his (husband) clasp-knife in the other, struck the handle of his (husband) knife violently on the table and told her (woman) with an oath to mind HER own business at any rate and sit down.

``I should like to have seen Jenny very much,'' (I)
said I,
``for I am sure she (Jenny) would have told me all she (Jenny) could about this lady, whom I am very anxious indeed--you cannot think how anxious--to overtake. Will Jenny be here soon? Where is she (Jenny)?'' (I)

The woman had a great desire to answer, but the man, with another oath, openly kicked at her (woman) foot with his (man) heavy boot. He (man) left it to Jenny's husband to say what he (man) chose, and after a dogged silence the latter turned his (man) shaggy head towards me.

``I'm not partial to gentlefolks coming into my place, as you've heerd me say afore now, I think, miss. I let their places be, and it's curious they can't let my place be. There'd be a pretty shine made if I was to go a-wisitin THEM, I think. Howsoever, I don't so much complain of you as of some others, and I'm agreeable to make you a civil answer, though I give notice that I'm not a-going to be drawed like a badger. Will Jenny be here soon? No she (Jenny) won't. Where is she (Jenny)? She (Jenny)'s gone up to Lunnun.'' (unknown)

``Did she (Jenny) go last night?'' (I)
I asked.

``Did she (Jenny) go last night? Ah! She (Jenny) went last night,'' (he)
he (man) answered with a sulky jerk of his (man) head.

``But was she (Jenny) here when the lady came? And what did the lady say to her (lady)? And where is the lady gone? I beg and pray you to be so kind as to tell me,'' (I)
said I,
``for I am in great distress to know.'' (I)

``If my master would let me speak, and not say a word of harm--'' (the woman)
the woman timidly began.

``Your master,'' (husband)
said her (woman) husband, muttering an imprecation with slow emphasis,
``will break your neck if you meddle with wot don't concern you.'' (husband)

After another silence, the husband of the absent woman, turning to me again, answered me with his (husband) usual grumbling unwillingness.

``Wos Jenny here when the lady come? Yes, she (Jenny) wos here when the lady come. Wot did the lady say to her (lady)? Well, I'll tell you wot the lady said to her (lady). She (lady) said, ``You remember me as come one time to talk to you about the young lady as had been a-wisiting of you? You remember me as give you somethink handsome for a handkercher wot she (lady) had left?

'' Ah, she (woman) remembered. So we all did. Well, then, wos that young lady up at the house now? No, she (lady) warn't up at the house now. Well, then, lookee here. The lady was upon a journey all alone, strange as we might think it, and could she (lady) rest herself where you're a setten for a hour or so. Yes she (lady) could, and so she (lady) did. Then she (lady) went--it might be at twenty minutes past eleven, and it might be at twenty minutes past twelve; we ain't got no watches here to know the time by, nor yet clocks. Where did she (lady) go? I don't know where she (lady) go'd. She (lady) went one way, and Jenny went another; one went right to Lunnun, and t`other went right from it. That's all about it. Ask this man. He (man) heerd it all, and see it all. He (man) knows.'' (she)

The other man repeated,

``That's all about it.'' (The man all)

``Was the lady crying?'' (I)
I inquired.

``Devil a bit,'' (the man)
returned the first man.
``Her (lady) shoes was the worse, and her (lady) clothes was the worse, but she (lady) warn't--not as I see.'' (The woman)

The woman sat with her (woman) arms crossed and her (woman) eyes upon the ground. Her (woman) husband had turned his (husband) seat a little so as to face her (woman) and kept his (husband) hammer-like hand upon the table as if it were in readiness to execute his (husband) threat if she (woman) disobeyed him (husband).

``I hope you will not object to my asking your wife,'' (I)
said I,
``how the lady looked.'' (I)

``Come, then!'' (he)
he (husband) gruffly cried to her (woman).
``You hear what she (lady) says. Cut it short and tell her (lady).'' (unknown)

``Bad,'' (the woman)
replied the woman.
``Pale and exhausted. Very bad.'' (unknown)

``Did she (lady) speak much?'' (unknown)

``Not much, but her (lady) voice was hoarse.'' (She)

She (woman) answered, looking all the while at her (woman) husband for leave.

``Was she (lady) faint?'' (I.)
said I.
``Did she (lady) eat or drink here?'' (I.)

``Go on!'' (the husband)
said the husband in answer to her (woman) look.
``Tell her (lady) and cut it short.'' (unknown)

``She (lady) had a little water, miss, and Jenny fetched her (Jenny) some bread and tea. But she (Jenny) hardly touched it.'' (unknown)

``And when she (Jenny) went from here,'' (I)
I was proceeding, when Jenny's husband impatiently took me up.

``When she (Jenny) went from here, she (Jenny) went right away nor`ard by the high road. Ask on the road if you doubt me, and see if it warn't so. Now, there's the end. That's all about it.'' (I)

I glanced at my companion, and finding that he (companion) had already risen and was ready to depart, thanked them for what they had told me, and took my leave. The woman looked full at Mr. Bucket as he (Bucket) went out, and he (Bucket) looked full at her (woman).

``Now, Miss Summerson,'' (he)
he (Bucket) said to me as we walked quickly away.
``They've got her (Summerson) ladyship's watch among 'em. That's a positive fact.'' (unknown)

``You saw it?'' (I)
I exclaimed.

``Just as good as saw it,'' (he)
he (Bucket) returned.
``Else why should he (They) talk about his (They) `twenty minutes past' and about his (They) having no watch to tell the time by? Twenty minutes! He (They) don't usually cut his (They) time so fine as that. If he (They) comes to half-hours, it's as much as HE (They) does. Now, you see, either her (Summerson) ladyship gave him (They) that watch or he (They) took it. I think she (Summerson) gave it him (They). Now, what should she (Summerson) give it him (They) for? What should she (Summerson) give it him (They) for?'' (He)

He (Bucket) repeated this question to himself several times as we hurried on, appearing to balance between a variety of answers that arose in his (Bucket) mind.

``If time could be spared,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket,
``which is the only thing that can't be spared in this case, I might get it out of that woman; but it's too doubtful a chance to trust to under present circumstances. They are up to keeping a close eye upon her (woman), and any fool knows that a poor creetur like her (woman), beaten and kicked and scarred and bruised from head to foot, will stand by the husband that ill uses her (woman) through thick and thin. There's something kept back. It's a pity but what we had seen the other woman.'' (Mr.)

I regretted it exceedingly, for she (woman) was very grateful, and I felt sure would have resisted no entreaty of mine.

``It's possible, Miss Summerson,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket, pondering on it,
``that her (Summerson) ladyship sent her (Summerson) up to London with some word for you, and it's possible that her (Summerson) husband got the watch to let her (Summerson) go. It don't come out altogether so plain as to please me, but it's on the cards. Now, I don't take kindly to laying out the money of Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, on these roughs, and I don't see my way to the usefulness of it at present. No! So far our road, Miss Summerson, is for`ard--straight ahead--and keeping everything quiet!'' (Mr.)

We called at home once more that I might send a hasty note to my guardian, and then we hurried back to where we had left the carriage. The horses were brought out as soon as we were seen coming, and we were on the road again in a few minutes.

It had set in snowing at daybreak, and it now snowed hard. The air was so thick with the darkness of the day and the density of the fall that we could see but a very little way in any direction. Although it was extremely cold, the snow was but partially frozen, and it churned--with a sound as if it were a beach of small shells--under the hoofs of the horses into mire and water. They sometimes slipped and floundered for a mile together, and we were obliged to come to a standstill to rest them. One horse fell three times in this first stage, and trembled so and was so shaken that the driver had to dismount from his (driver) saddle and lead him (driver) at last.

I could eat nothing and could not sleep, and I grew so nervous under those delays and the slow pace at which we travelled that I had an unreasonable desire upon me to get out and walk. Yielding to my companion's better sense, however, I remained where I was. All this time, kept fresh by a certain enjoyment of the work in which he (companion) was engaged, he (companion) was up and down at every house we came to, addressing people whom he (companion) had never beheld before as old acquaintances, running in to warm himself at every fire he (companion) saw, talking and drinking and shaking hands at every bar and tap, friendly with every waggoner, wheelwright, blacksmith, and toll-taker, yet never seeming to lose time, and always mounting to the box again with his (blacksmith) watchful, steady face and his (blacksmith) business-like

``Get on, my lad!'' (blacksmith)

When we were changing horses the next time, he (blacksmith) came from the stable-yard, with the wet snow encrusted upon him (blacksmith) and dropping off him (blacksmith)--plashing and crashing through it to his (blacksmith) wet knees as he (blacksmith) had been doing frequently since we left Saint Albans--and spoke to me at the carriage side.

``Keep up your spirits. It's certainly true that she (Summerson) came on here, Miss Summerson. There's not a doubt of the dress by this time, and the dress has been seen here.'' (unknown)

``Still on foot?'' (I.)
said I.

``Still on foot. I think the gentleman you mentioned must be the point she (Summerson)'s aiming at, and yet I don't like his (gentleman) living down in her (Summerson) own part of the country neither.'' (I.)

``I know so little,'' (I.)
said I.
``There may be some one else nearer here, of whom I never heard.'' (I.)

``That's true. But whatever you do, don't you fall a-crying, my dear; and don't you worry yourself no more than you can help. Get on, my lad!'' (unknown)

The sleet fell all that day unceasingly, a thick mist came on early, and it never rose or lightened for a moment. Such roads I had never seen. I sometimes feared we had missed the way and got into the ploughed grounds or the marshes. If I ever thought of the time I had been out, it presented itself as an indefinite period of great duration, and I seemed, in a strange way, never to have been free from the anxiety under which I then laboured.

As we advanced, I began to feel misgivings that my companion lost confidence. He (companion) was the same as before with all the roadside people, but he (companion) looked graver when he (companion) sat by himself on the box. I saw his (companion) finger uneasily going across and across his (companion) mouth during the whole of one long weary stage. I overheard that he (companion) began to ask the drivers of coaches and other vehicles coming towards us what passengers they had seen in other coaches and vehicles that were in advance. Their replies did not encourage him (companion). He (companion) always gave me a reassuring beck of his (companion) finger and lift of his (companion) eyelid as he (companion) got upon the box again, but he (companion) seemed perplexed now when he (companion) said,

``Get on, my lad!'' (he)

At last, when we were changing, he (companion) told me that he (companion) had lost the track of the dress so long that he (companion) began to be surprised. It was nothing, he (companion) said, to lose such a track for one while, and to take it up for another while, and so on; but it had disappeared here in an unaccountable manner, and we had not come upon it since. This corroborated the apprehensions I had formed, when he (companion) began to look at direction-posts, and to leave the carriage at cross roads for a quarter of an hour at a time while he (companion) explored them. But I was not to be down-hearted, he (companion) told me, for it was as likely as not that the next stage might set us right again.

The next stage, however, ended as that one ended; we had no new clue. There was a spacious inn here, solitary, but a comfortable substantial building, and as we drove in under a large gateway before I knew it, where a landlady and her (landlady) pretty daughters came to the carriage-door, entreating me to alight and refresh myself while the horses were making ready, I thought it would be uncharitable to refuse. They took me upstairs to a warm room and left me there.

It was at the corner of the house, I remember, looking two ways. On one side to a stable-yard open to a by-road, where the ostlers were unharnessing the splashed and tired horses from the muddy carriage, and beyond that to the by-road itself, across which the sign was heavily swinging; on the other side to a wood of dark pine-trees. Their branches were encumbered with snow, and it silently dropped off in wet heaps while I stood at the window. Night was setting in, and its bleakness was enhanced by the contrast of the pictured fire glowing and gleaming in the window-pane. As I looked among the stems of the trees and followed the discoloured marks in the snow where the thaw was sinking into it and undermining it, I thought of the motherly face brightly set off by daughters that had just now welcomed me and of MY mother lying down in such a wood to die.

I was frightened when I found them all about me, but I remembered that before I fainted I tried very hard not to do it; and that was some little comfort. They cushioned me up on a large sofa by the fire, and then the comely landlady told me that I must travel no further to-night, but must go to bed. But this put me into such a tremble lest they should detain me there that she (mother) soon recalled her (mother) words and compromised for a rest of half an hour.

A good endearing creature she (mother) was. She (mother) and her (mother) three fair girls, all so busy about me. I was to take hot soup and broiled fowl, while Mr. Bucket dried himself and dined elsewhere; but I could not do it when a snug round table was presently spread by the fireside, though I was very unwilling to disappoint them. However, I could take some toast and some hot negus, and as I really enjoyed that refreshment, it made some recompense.

Punctual to the time, at the half-hour's end the carriage came rumbling under the gateway, and they took me down, warmed, refreshed, comforted by kindness, and safe -LRB-I assured them-RRB- not to faint any more. After I had got in and had taken a grateful leave of them all, the youngest daughter--a blooming girl of nineteen, who was to be the first married, they had told me--got upon the carriage step, reached in, and kissed me. I have never seen her (daughter), from that hour, but I think of her (daughter) to this hour as my friend.

The transparent windows with the fire and light, looking so bright and warm from the cold darkness out of doors, were soon gone, and again we were crushing and churning the loose snow. We went on with toil enough, but the dismal roads were not much worse than they had been, and the stage was only nine miles. My companion smoking on the box--I had thought at the last inn of begging him (companion) to do so when I saw him (companion) standing at a great fire in a comfortable cloud of tobacco--was as vigilant as ever and as quickly down and up again when we came to any human abode or any human creature. He (companion) had lighted his (companion) little dark lantern, which seemed to be a favourite with him (companion), for we had lamps to the carriage; and every now and then he (companion) turned it upon me to see that I was doing well. There was a folding-window to the carriage-head, but I never closed it, for it seemed like shutting out hope.

We came to the end of the stage, and still the lost trace was not recovered. I looked at him (companion) anxiously when we stopped to change, but I knew by his (companion) yet graver face as he (companion) stood watching the ostlers that he (companion) had heard nothing. Almost in an instant afterwards, as I leaned back in my seat, he (companion) looked in, with his (companion) lighted lantern in his (companion) hand, an excited and quite different man.

``What is it?'' (I)
said I, starting.
``Is she (Summerson) here?'' (unknown)

``No, no. Don't deceive yourself, my dear. Nobody's here. But I've got it!'' (unknown)

The crystallized snow was in his (companion) eyelashes, in his (companion) hair, lying in ridges on his (companion) dress. He (companion) had to shake it from his (companion) face and get his (companion) breath before he (companion) spoke to me.

``Now, Miss Summerson,'' (he)
said he (companion), beating his (companion) finger on the apron,
``don't you be disappointed at what I'm a-going to do. You know me. I'm Inspector Bucket, and you can trust me. We've come a long way; never mind. Four horses out there for the next stage up! Quick!'' (he)

There was a commotion in the yard, and a man came running out of the stables to know if he (man) meant up or down.

``Up, I tell you! Up! Ain't it English? Up!'' (unknown)

``Up?'' (I)
said I, astonished.
``To London! Are we going back?'' (unknown)

``Miss Summerson,'' (he)
he (man) answered,
``back. Straight back as a die. You know me. Don't be afraid. I'll follow the other, by G--'' (he)

``The other?'' (I)
I repeated.
``Who?'' (unknown)

``You called her (Summerson) Jenny, didn't you? I'll follow her (Summerson). Bring those two pair out here for a crown a man. Wake up, some of you!'' (unknown)

``You will not desert this lady we are in search of; you will not abandon her (lady) on such a night and in such a state of mind as I know her (lady) to be in!'' (I)
said I, in an agony, and grasping his (man) hand.

``You are right, my dear, I won't. But I'll follow the other. Look alive here with them horses. Send a man for`ard in the saddle to the next stage, and let him (man) send another for`ard again, and order four on, up, right through. My darling, don't you be afraid!'' (he)

These orders and the way in which he (man) ran about the yard urging them caused a general excitement that was scarcely less bewildering to me than the sudden change. But in the height of the confusion, a mounted man galloped away to order the relays, and our horses were put to with great speed.

``My dear,'' (Mr. Bucket)
said Mr. Bucket, jumping to his (Bucket) seat and looking in again,
''--you'll excuse me if I'm too familiar--don't you fret and worry yourself no more than you can help. I say nothing else at present; but you know me, my dear; now, don't you?'' (Mr. Bucket)

I endeavoured to say that I knew he (Bucket) was far more capable than I of deciding what we ought to do, but was he (Bucket) sure that this was right? Could I not go forward by myself in search of--I grasped his (Bucket) hand again in my distress and whispered it to him (Bucket)--of my own mother.

``My dear,'' (he)
he (Bucket) answered,
``I know, I know, and would I put you wrong, do you think? Inspector Bucket. Now you know me, don't you?'' (he)

What could I say but yes!

``Then you keep up as good a heart as you can, and you rely upon me for standing by you, no less than by Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet. Now, are you right there?'' (unknown)

``All right, sir!'' (unknown)

``Off she (I) goes, then. And get on, my lads!'' (unknown)

We were again upon the melancholy road by which we had come, tearing up the miry sleet and thawing snow as if they were torn up by a waterwheel.

CHAPTER LVIII

A Wintry Day and Night

Still impassive, as behoves its breeding, the Dedlock town house carries itself as usual towards the street of dismal grandeur. There are powdered heads from time to time in the little windows of the hall, looking out at the untaxed powder falling all day from the sky; and in the same conservatory there is peach blossom turning itself exotically to the great hall fire from the nipping weather out of doors. It is given out that my Lady has gone down into Lincolnshire, but is expected to return presently.

Rumour, busy overmuch, however, will not go down into Lincolnshire. It persists in flitting and chattering about town. It knows that that poor unfortunate man, Sir Leicester, has been sadly used. It hears, my dear child, all sorts of shocking things. It makes the world of five miles round quite merry. Not to know that there is something wrong at the Dedlocks' is to augur yourself unknown. One of the peachy-cheeked charmers with the skeleton throats is already apprised of all the principal circumstances that will come out before the Lords on Sir Leicester's application for a bill of divorce.

At Blaze and Sparkle's the jewellers and at Sheen and Gloss's the mercers, it is and will be for several hours the topic of the age, the feature of the century. The patronesses of those establishments, albeit so loftily inscrutable, being as nicely weighed and measured there as any other article of the stock-in-trade, are perfectly understood in this new fashion by the rawest hand behind the counter.

``Our people, Mr. Jones,'' (Blaze Sparkle)
said Blaze and Sparkle to the hand in question on engaging him (Sheen),
``our people, sir, are sheep--mere sheep. Where two or three marked ones go, all the rest follow. Keep those two or three in your eye, Mr. Jones, and you have the flock.'' (him)
So, likewise, Sheen and Gloss to THEIR Jones, in reference to knowing where to have the fashionable people and how to bring what they -LRB-Sheen and Gloss-RRB- choose into fashion. On similar unerring principles, Mr. Sladdery the librarian, and indeed the great farmer of gorgeous sheep, admits this very day,
``Why yes, sir, there certainly ARE reports concerning Lady Dedlock, very current indeed among my high connexion, sir. You see, my high connexion must talk about something, sir; and it's only to get a subject into vogue with one or two ladies I could name to make it go down with the whole. Just what I should have done with those ladies, sir, in the case of any novelty you had left to me to bring in, they have done of themselves in this case through knowing Lady Dedlock and being perhaps a little innocently jealous of her (Dedlock) too, sir. You'll find, sir, that this topic will be very popular among my high connexion. If it had been a speculation, sir, it would have brought money. And when I say so, you may trust to my being right, sir, for I have made it my business to study my high connexion and to be able to wind it up like a clock, sir.'' (the farmer)

Thus rumour thrives in the capital, and will not go down into Lincolnshire. By half-past five, post meridian, Horse Guards' time, it has even elicited a new remark from the Honourable Mr. Stables, which bids fair to outshine the old one, on which he (Mr.) has so long rested his (Mr.) colloquial reputation. This sparkling sally is to the effect that although he (Mr.) always knew she (librarian) was the best-groomed woman in the stud, he (Mr.) had no idea she (librarian) was a bolter. It is immensely received in turf-circles.

At feasts and festivals also, in firmaments she (librarian) has often graced, and among constellations she (librarian) outshone but yesterday, she (librarian) is still the prevalent subject. What is it? Who is it? When was it? Where was it? How was it? She (librarian) is discussed by her (librarian) dear friends with all the genteelest slang in vogue, with the last new word, the last new manner, the last new drawl, and the perfection of polite indifference. A remarkable feature of the theme is that it is found to be so inspiring that several people come out upon it who never came out before--positively say things! William Buffy carries one of these smartnesses from the place where he (librarian) dines down to the House, where the Whip for his (librarian) party hands it about with his (librarian) snuff-box to keep men together who want to be off, with such effect that the Speaker -LRB-who has had it privately insinuated into his (Speaker) own ear under the corner of his (Speaker) wig-RRB- cries,

``Order at the bar!'' (the Speaker)
three times without making an impression.

And not the least amazing circumstance connected with her (Buffy) being vaguely the town talk is that people hovering on the confines of Mr. Sladdery's high connexion, people who know nothing and ever did know nothing about her (Buffy), think it essential to their reputation to pretend that she (Buffy) is their topic too, and to retail her (Buffy) at second-hand with the last new word and the last new manner, and the last new drawl, and the last new polite indifference, and all the rest of it, all at second-hand but considered equal to new in inferior systems and to fainter stars. If there be any man of letters, art, or science among these little dealers, how noble in him (man) to support the feeble sisters on such majestic crutches!

So goes the wintry day outside the Dedlock mansion. How within it?

Sir Leicester, lying in his (man) bed, can speak a little, though with difficulty and indistinctness. He (man) is enjoined to silence and to rest, and they have given him (man) some opiate to lull his (man) pain, for his (man) old enemy is very hard with him (man). He (man) is never asleep, though sometimes he (man) seems to fall into a dull waking doze. He (man) caused his (man) bedstead to be moved out nearer to the window when he (man) heard it was such inclement weather, and his (man) head to be so adjusted that he (man) could see the driving snow and sleet. He (man) watches it as it falls, throughout the whole wintry day.

Upon the least noise in the house, which is kept hushed, his (man) hand is at the pencil. The old housekeeper, sitting by him (man), knows what he (man) would write and whispers,

``No, he (it) has not come back yet, Sir Leicester. It was late last night when he (it) went. He (it) has been but a little time gone yet.'' (he)

He (man) withdraws his (man) hand and falls to looking at the sleet and snow again until they seem, by being long looked at, to fall so thick and fast that he (man) is obliged to close his (man) eyes for a minute on the giddy whirl of white flakes and icy blots.

He (man) began to look at them as soon as it was light. The day is not yet far spent when he (man) conceives it to be necessary that her (housekeeper) rooms should be prepared for her (housekeeper). It is very cold and wet. Let there be good fires. Let them know that she (housekeeper) is expected. Please see to it yourself. He (man) writes to this purpose on his (man) slate, and Mrs. Rouncewell with a heavy heart obeys.

``For I dread, George,'' (the lady)
the old lady says to her (lady) son, who waits below to keep her (lady) company when she (lady) has a little leisure,
``I dread, my dear, that my Lady will never more set foot within these walls.'' (she)

``That's a bad presentiment, mother.'' (unknown)

``Nor yet within the walls of Chesney Wold, my dear.'' (unknown)

``That's worse. But why, mother?'' (unknown)

``When I saw my Lady yesterday, George, she (Lady) looked to me--and I may say at me too--as if the step on the Ghost's Walk had almost walked her (Lady) down.'' (unknown)

``Come, come! You alarm yourself with old-story fears, mother.'' (unknown)

``No I don't, my dear. No I don't. It's going on for sixty year that I have been in this family, and I never had any fears for it before. But it's breaking up, my dear; the great old Dedlock family is breaking up.'' (unknown)

``I hope not, mother.'' (unknown)

``I am thankful I have lived long enough to be with Sir Leicester in this illness and trouble, for I know I am not too old nor too useless to be a welcomer sight to him (I) than anybody else in my place would be. But the step on the Ghost's Walk will walk my Lady down, George; it has been many a day behind her (Lady), and now it will pass her (Lady) and go on.'' (unknown)

``Well, mother dear, I say again, I hope not.'' (unknown)

``Ah, so do I, George,'' (lady)
the old lady returns, shaking her (lady) head and parting her (lady) folded hands.
``But if my fears come true, and he (George) has to know it, who will tell him (George)!'' (unknown)

``Are these her (mother) rooms?'' (unknown)

``These are my Lady's rooms, just as she (mother) left them.'' (unknown)

``Why, now,'' (the trooper)
says the trooper, glancing round him (trooper) and speaking in a lower voice,
``I begin to understand how you come to think as you do think, mother. Rooms get an awful look about them when they are fitted up, like these, for one person you are used to see in them, and that person is away under any shadow, let alone being God knows where.'' (him)

He (trooper) is not far out. As all partings foreshadow the great final one, so, empty rooms, bereft of a familiar presence, mournfully whisper what your room and what mine must one day be. My Lady's state has a hollow look, thus gloomy and abandoned; and in the inner apartment, where Mr. Bucket last night made his (Bucket) secret perquisition, the traces of her (Lady) dresses and her (Lady) ornaments, even the mirrors accustomed to reflect them when they were a portion of herself, have a desolate and vacant air. Dark and cold as the wintry day is, it is darker and colder in these deserted chambers than in many a hut that will barely exclude the weather; and though the servants heap fires in the grates and set the couches and the chairs within the warm glass screens that let their ruddy light shoot through to the furthest corners, there is a heavy cloud upon the rooms which no light will dispel.

The old housekeeper and her (housekeeper) son remain until the preparations are complete, and then she (housekeeper) returns upstairs. Volumnia has taken Mrs. Rouncewell's place in the meantime, though pearl necklaces and rouge pots, however calculated to embellish Bath, are but indifferent comforts to the invalid under present circumstances. Volumnia, not being supposed to know -LRB-and indeed not knowing-RRB- what is the matter, has found it a ticklish task to offer appropriate observations and consequently has supplied their place with distracting smoothings of the bed-linen, elaborate locomotion on tiptoe, vigilant peeping at her (Rouncewell) kinsman's eyes, and one exasperating whisper to herself of,

``He (God) is asleep.'' (kinsman)
In disproof of which superfluous remark Sir Leicester has indignantly written on the slate,
``I am not.'' (the housekeeper)

Yielding, therefore, the chair at the bedside to the quaint old housekeeper, Volumnia sits at a table a little removed, sympathetically sighing. Sir Leicester watches the sleet and snow and listens for the returning steps that he (kinsman) expects. In the ears of his (kinsman) old servant, looking as if she (housekeeper) had stepped out of an old picture-frame to attend a summoned Dedlock to another world, the silence is fraught with echoes of her (housekeeper) own words,

``Who will tell him (God)!'' (she)

He (kinsman) has been under his (kinsman) valet's hands this morning to be made presentable and is as well got up as the circumstances will allow. He (kinsman) is propped with pillows, his (kinsman) grey hair is brushed in its usual manner, his (kinsman) linen is arranged to a nicety, and he (kinsman) is wrapped in a responsible dressing-gown. His (kinsman) eye-glass and his (kinsman) watch are ready to his (kinsman) hand. It is necessary--less to his (kinsman) own dignity now perhaps than for her (housekeeper) sake--that he (kinsman) should be seen as little disturbed and as much himself as may be. Women will talk, and Volumnia, though a Dedlock, is no exceptional case. He (kinsman) keeps her (housekeeper) here, there is little doubt, to prevent her (housekeeper) talking somewhere else. He (kinsman) is very ill, but he (kinsman) makes his (kinsman) present stand against distress of mind and body most courageously.

The fair Volumnia, being one of those sprightly girls who cannot long continue silent without imminent peril of seizure by the dragon Boredom, soon indicates the approach of that monster with a series of undisguisable yawns. Finding it impossible to suppress those yawns by any other process than conversation, she (housekeeper) compliments Mrs. Rouncewell on her (housekeeper) son, declaring that he (son) positively is one of the finest figures she (housekeeper) ever saw and as soldierly a looking person, she (housekeeper) should think, as what's his (son) name, her (housekeeper) favourite Life Guardsman--the man she (housekeeper) dotes on, the dearest of creatures--who was killed at Waterloo.

Sir Leicester hears this tribute with so much surprise and stares about him (son) in such a confused way that Mrs. Rouncewell feels it necessary to explain.

``Miss Dedlock don't speak of my eldest son, Sir Leicester, but my youngest. I have found him (son). He (son) has come home.'' (unknown)

Sir Leicester breaks silence with a harsh cry.

``George? Your son George come home, Mrs. Rouncewell?'' (The housekeeper)

The old housekeeper wipes her (housekeeper) eyes.

``Thank God. Yes, Sir Leicester.'' (him)

Does this discovery of some one lost, this return of some one so long gone, come upon him (son) as a strong confirmation of his (son) hopes? Does he (son) think,

``Shall I not, with the aid I have, recall her (Rouncewell) safely after this, there being fewer hours in her (Rouncewell) case than there are years in his (God)?'' (he)

It is of no use entreating him (son); he (son) is determined to speak now, and he (son) does. In a thick crowd of sounds, but still intelligibly enough to be understood.

``Why did you not tell me, Mrs. Rouncewell?'' (unknown)

``It happened only yesterday, Sir Leicester, and I doubted your being well enough to be talked to of such things.'' (scream)

Besides, the giddy Volumnia now remembers with her (housekeeper) little scream that nobody was to have known of his (son) being Mrs. Rouncewell's son and that she (Rouncewell) was not to have told. But Mrs. Rouncewell protests, with warmth enough to swell the stomacher, that of course she (Rouncewell) would have told Sir Leicester as soon as he (son) got better.

``Where is your son George, Mrs. Rouncewell?'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)
asks Sir Leicester,

Mrs. Rouncewell, not a little alarmed by his (son) disregard of the doctor's injunctions, replies, in London.

``Where in London?'' (Mrs. Rouncewell/Rouncewell)

Mrs. Rouncewell is constrained to admit that he (son) is in the house.

``Bring him (son) here to my room. Bring him (son) directly.'' (The lady)

The old lady can do nothing but go in search of him (son). Sir Leicester, with such power of movement as he (son) has, arranges himself a little to receive him (son). When he (son) has done so, he (son) looks out again at the falling sleet and snow and listens again for the returning steps. A quantity of straw has been tumbled down in the street to deaden the noises there, and she (Rouncewell) might be driven to the door perhaps without his (son) hearing wheels.

He (son) is lying thus, apparently forgetful of his (son) newer and minor surprise, when the housekeeper returns, accompanied by her (housekeeper) trooper son. Mr. George approaches softly to the bedside, makes his (George) bow, squares his (George) chest, and stands, with his (George) face flushed, very heartily ashamed of himself.

``Good heaven, and it is really George Rouncewell!'' (unknown)
exclaims Sir Leicester.
``Do you remember me, George?'' (The trooper)

The trooper needs to look at him (trooper) and to separate this sound from that sound before he (trooper) knows what he (trooper) has said, but doing this and being a little helped by his (trooper) mother, he (trooper) replies,

``I must have a very bad memory, indeed, Sir Leicester, if I failed to remember you.'' (he)

``When I look at you, George Rouncewell,'' (He)
Sir Leicester observes with difficulty,
``I see something of a boy at Chesney Wold--I remember well--very well.'' (He)

He (trooper) looks at the trooper until tears come into his (trooper) eyes, and then he (trooper) looks at the sleet and snow again.

``I ask your pardon, Sir Leicester,'' (the trooper)
says the trooper,
``but would you accept of my arms to raise you up? You would lie easier, Sir Leicester, if you would allow me to move you.'' (the trooper)

``If you please, George Rouncewell; if you will be so good.'' (The trooper)

The trooper takes him (trooper) in his (trooper) arms like a child, lightly raises him (trooper), and turns him (trooper) with his (trooper) face more towards the window.

``Thank you. You have your mother's gentleness,'' (unknown)
returns Sir Leicester,
``and your own strength. Thank you.'' (He)

He (trooper) signs to him (trooper) with his (trooper) hand not to go away. George quietly remains at the bedside, waiting to be spoken to.

``Why did you wish for secrecy?'' (unknown)
It takes Sir Leicester some time to ask this.

``Truly I am not much to boast of, Sir Leicester, and I--I should still, Sir Leicester, if you was not so indisposed--which I hope you will not be long--I should still hope for the favour of being allowed to remain unknown in general. That involves explanations not very hard to be guessed at, not very well timed here, and not very creditable to myself. However opinions may differ on a variety of subjects, I should think it would be universally agreed, Sir Leicester, that I am not much to boast of.'' (unknown)

``You have been a soldier,'' (Mr. George/George)
observes Sir Leicester,
``and a faithful one.'' (Mr. George/George)

George makes his (George) military bow.

``As far as that goes, Sir Leicester, I have done my duty under discipline, and it was the least I could do.'' (unknown)

``You find me,'' (him)
says Sir Leicester, whose eyes are much attracted towards him (George),
``far from well, George Rouncewell.'' (him)

``I am very sorry both to hear it and to see it, Sir Leicester.'' (unknown)

``I am sure you are. No. In addition to my older malady, I have had a sudden and bad attack. Something that deadens,'' (Mr. George/George)
making an endeavour to pass one hand down one side,
``and confuses,'' (Mr. George/George)
touching his (George) lips.

George, with a look of assent and sympathy, makes another bow. The different times when they were both young men -LRB-the trooper much the younger of the two-RRB- and looked at one another down at Chesney Wold arise before them both and soften both.

Sir Leicester, evidently with a great determination to say, in his (Chesney) own manner, something that is on his (Chesney) mind before relapsing into silence, tries to raise himself among his (Chesney) pillows a little more. George, observant of the action, takes him (George) in his (George) arms again and places him (George) as he (George) desires to be.

``Thank you, George. You are another self to me. You have often carried my spare gun at Chesney Wold, George. You are familiar to me in these strange circumstances, very familiar.'' (He)
He (George) has put Sir Leicester's sounder arm over his (George) shoulder in lifting him (George) up, and Sir Leicester is slow in drawing it away again as he (George) says these words.

``I was about to add,'' (he)
he (George) presently goes on,
``I was about to add, respecting this attack, that it was unfortunately simultaneous with a slight misunderstanding between my Lady and myself. I do not mean that there was any difference between us -LRB-for there has been none-RRB-, but that there was a misunderstanding of certain circumstances important only to ourselves, which deprives me, for a little while, of my Lady's society. She (Lady) has found it necessary to make a journey--I trust will shortly return. Volumnia, do I make myself intelligible? The words are not quite under my command in the manner of pronouncing them.'' (he)

Volumnia understands him (George) perfectly, and in truth he (George) delivers himself with far greater plainness than could have been supposed possible a minute ago. The effort by which he (George) does so is written in the anxious and labouring expression of his (George) face. Nothing but the strength of his (George) purpose enables him (George) to make it.

``Therefore, Volumnia, I desire to say in your presence--and in the presence of my old retainer and friend, Mrs. Rouncewell, whose truth and fidelity no one can question, and in the presence of her (Rouncewell) son George, who comes back like a familiar recollection of my youth in the home of my ancestors at Chesney Wold--in case I should relapse, in case I should not recover, in case I should lose both my speech and the power of writing, though I hope for better things--'' (The housekeeper)

The old housekeeper weeping silently; Volumnia in the greatest agitation, with the freshest bloom on her (housekeeper) cheeks; the trooper with his (trooper) arms folded and his (trooper) head a little bent, respectfully attentive.

``Therefore I desire to say, and to call you all to witness--beginning, Volumnia, with yourself, most solemnly--that I am on unaltered terms with Lady Dedlock. That I assert no cause whatever of complaint against her (Dedlock). That I have ever had the strongest affection for her (Dedlock), and that I retain it undiminished. Say this to herself, and to every one. If you ever say less than this, you will be guilty of deliberate falsehood to me.'' (she)

Volumnia tremblingly protests that she (housekeeper) will observe his (trooper) injunctions to the letter.

``My Lady is too high in position, too handsome, too accomplished, too superior in most respects to the best of those by whom she (Lady) is surrounded, not to have her (Lady) enemies and traducers, I dare say. Let it be known to them, as I make it known to you, that being of sound mind, memory, and understanding, I revoke no disposition I have made in her (Lady) favour. I abridge nothing I have ever bestowed upon her (Lady). I am on unaltered terms with her (Lady), and I recall--having the full power to do it if I were so disposed, as you see--no act I have done for her (Lady) advantage and happiness.'' (unknown)

His (trooper) formal array of words might have at any other time, as it has often had, something ludicrous in it, but at this time it is serious and affecting. His (trooper) noble earnestness, his (trooper) fidelity, his (trooper) gallant shielding of her (housekeeper), his (trooper) generous conquest of his (trooper) own wrong and his (trooper) own pride for her (housekeeper) sake, are simply honourable, manly, and true. Nothing less worthy can be seen through the lustre of such qualities in the commonest mechanic, nothing less worthy can be seen in the best-born gentleman. In such a light both aspire alike, both rise alike, both children of the dust shine equally.

Overpowered by his (gentleman) exertions, he (gentleman) lays his (gentleman) head back on his (gentleman) pillows and closes his (gentleman) eyes for not more than a minute, when he (gentleman) again resumes his (gentleman) watching of the weather and his (gentleman) attention to the muffled sounds.
