In the rendering of those little services, and in the manner of their acceptance, the trooper has become installed as necessary to him (trooper). Nothing has been said, but it is quite understood. He (trooper) falls a step or two backward to be out of sight and mounts guard a little behind his (trooper) mother's chair.

The day is now beginning to decline. The mist and the sleet into which the snow has all resolved itself are darker, and the blaze begins to tell more vividly upon the room walls and furniture. The gloom augments; the bright gas springs up in the streets; and the pertinacious oil lamps which yet hold their ground there, with their source of life half frozen and half thawed, twinkle gaspingly like fiery fish out of water--as they are. The world, which has been rumbling over the straw and pulling at the bell,

``to inquire,'' (friend)
begins to go home, begins to dress, to dine, to discuss its dear friend with all the last new modes, as already mentioned.

Now does Sir Leicester become worse, restless, uneasy, and in great pain. Volumnia, lighting a candle -LRB-with a predestined aptitude for doing something objectionable-RRB-, is bidden to put it out again, for it is not yet dark enough. Yet it is very dark too, as dark as it will be all night. By and by she (it) tries again. No! Put it out. It is not dark enough yet.

His (friend) old housekeeper is the first to understand that he (friend) is striving to uphold the fiction with himself that it is not growing late.

``Dear Sir Leicester, my honoured master,'' (she)
she (housekeeper) softly whispers,
``I must, for your own good, and my duty, take the freedom of begging and praying that you will not lie here in the lone darkness watching and waiting and dragging through the time. Let me draw the curtains, and light the candles, and make things more comfortable about you. The church-clocks will strike the hours just the same, Sir Leicester, and the night will pass away just the same. My Lady will come back, just the same.'' (she)

``I know it, Mrs. Rouncewell, but I am weak--and he (it) has been so long gone.'' (unknown)

``Not so very long, Sir Leicester. Not twenty-four hours yet.'' (unknown)

``But that is a long time. Oh, it is a long time!'' (He)

He (friend) says it with a groan that wrings her (housekeeper) heart.

She (housekeeper) knows that this is not a period for bringing the rough light upon him (friend); she (housekeeper) thinks his (friend) tears too sacred to be seen, even by her (housekeeper). Therefore she (housekeeper) sits in the darkness for a while without a word, then gently begins to move about, now stirring the fire, now standing at the dark window looking out. Finally he (friend) tells her (housekeeper), with recovered self-command,

``As you say, Mrs. Rouncewell, it is no worse for being confessed. It is getting late, and they are not come. Light the room!'' (her)
When it is lighted and the weather shut out, it is only left to him (friend) to listen.

But they find that however dejected and ill he (friend) is, he (friend) brightens when a quiet pretence is made of looking at the fires in her (housekeeper) rooms and being sure that everything is ready to receive her (housekeeper). Poor pretence as it is, these allusions to her (housekeeper) being expected keep up hope within him (friend).

Midnight comes, and with it the same blank. The carriages in the streets are few, and other late sounds in that neighbourhood there are none, unless a man so very nomadically drunk as to stray into the frigid zone goes brawling and bellowing along the pavement. Upon this wintry night it is so still that listening to the intense silence is like looking at intense darkness. If any distant sound be audible in this case, it departs through the gloom like a feeble light in that, and all is heavier than before.

The corporation of servants are dismissed to bed -LRB-not unwilling to go, for they were up all last night-RRB-, and only Mrs. Rouncewell and George keep watch in Sir Leicester's room. As the night lags tardily on--or rather when it seems to stop altogether, at between two and three o'clock--they find a restless craving on him (George) to know more about the weather, now he (George) cannot see it. Hence George, patrolling regularly every half-hour to the rooms so carefully looked after, extends his (George) march to the hall-door, looks about him (George), and brings back the best report he (George) can make of the worst of nights, the sleet still falling and even the stone footways lying ankle-deep in icy sludge.

Volumnia, in her (George) room up a retired landing on the staircase--the second turning past the end of the carving and gilding, a cousinly room containing a fearful abortion of a portrait of Sir Leicester banished for its crimes, and commanding in the day a solemn yard planted with dried-up shrubs like antediluvian specimens of black tea--is a prey to horrors of many kinds. Not last nor least among them, possibly, is a horror of what may befall her (George) little income in the event, as she (George) expresses it,

``of anything happening'' (she)
to Sir Leicester. Anything, in this sense, meaning one thing only; and that the last thing that can happen to the consciousness of any baronet in the known world.

An effect of these horrors is that Volumnia finds she (George) cannot go to bed in her (George) own room or sit by the fire in her (George) own room, but must come forth with her (George) fair head tied up in a profusion of shawl, and her (George) fair form enrobed in drapery, and parade the mansion like a ghost, particularly haunting the rooms, warm and luxurious, prepared for one who still does not return. Solitude under such circumstances being not to be thought of, Volumnia is attended by her (George) maid, who, impressed from her (George) own bed for that purpose, extremely cold, very sleepy, and generally an injured maid as condemned by circumstances to take office with a cousin, when she (maid) had resolved to be maid to nothing less than ten thousand a year, has not a sweet expression of countenance.

The periodical visits of the trooper to these rooms, however, in the course of his (trooper) patrolling is an assurance of protection and company both to mistress and maid, which renders them very acceptable in the small hours of the night. Whenever he (trooper) is heard advancing, they both make some little decorative preparation to receive him (trooper); at other times they divide their watches into short scraps of oblivion and dialogues not wholly free from acerbity, as to whether Miss Dedlock, sitting with her (maid) feet upon the fender, was or was not falling into the fire when rescued -LRB-to her (maid) great displeasure-RRB- by her (maid) guardian genius the maid.

``How is Sir Leicester now, Mr. George?'' (unknown)
inquires Volumnia, adjusting her (maid) cowl over her (maid) head.

``Why, Sir Leicester is much the same, miss. He (George) is very low and ill, and he (George) even wanders a little sometimes.'' (unknown)

``Has he (George) asked for me?'' (unknown)
inquires Volumnia tenderly.

``Why, no, I can't say he (George) has, miss. Not within my hearing, that is to say.'' (unknown)

``This is a truly sad time, Mr. George.'' (unknown)

``It is indeed, miss. Hadn't you better go to bed?'' (unknown)

``You had a deal better go to bed, Miss Dedlock,'' (the maid)
quoth the maid sharply.

But Volumnia answers No! No! She (maid) may be asked for, she (maid) may be wanted at a moment's notice. She (maid) never should forgive herself

``if anything was to happen'' (She)
and she (maid) was not on the spot. She (maid) declines to enter on the question, mooted by the maid, how the spot comes to be there, and not in her (maid) room -LRB-which is nearer to Sir Leicester's-RRB-, but staunchly declares that on the spot she (maid) will remain. Volumnia further makes a merit of not having
``closed an eye'' (she)
--as if she (maid) had twenty or thirty--though it is hard to reconcile this statement with her (maid) having most indisputably opened two within five minutes.

But when it comes to four o'clock, and still the same blank, Volumnia's constancy begins to fail her (maid), or rather it begins to strengthen, for she (maid) now considers that it is her (maid) duty to be ready for the morrow, when much may be expected of her (maid), that, in fact, howsoever anxious to remain upon the spot, it may be required of her (maid), as an act of self-devotion, to desert the spot. So when the trooper reappears with his (trooper),

``Hadn't you better go to bed, miss?'' (the trooper)
and when the maid protests, more sharply than before,
``You had a deal better go to bed, Miss Dedlock!'' (maid)
she (maid) meekly rises and says,
``Do with me what you think best!'' (she)

Mr. George undoubtedly thinks it best to escort her (maid) on his (George) arm to the door of her (maid) cousinly chamber, and the maid as undoubtedly thinks it best to hustle her (maid) into bed with mighty little ceremony. Accordingly, these steps are taken; and now the trooper, in his (trooper) rounds, has the house to himself.

There is no improvement in the weather. From the portico, from the eaves, from the parapet, from every ledge and post and pillar, drips the thawed snow. It has crept, as if for shelter, into the lintels of the great door--under it, into the corners of the windows, into every chink and crevice of retreat, and there wastes and dies. It is falling still; upon the roof, upon the skylight, even through the skylight, and drip, drip, drip, with the regularity of the Ghost's Walk, on the stone floor below.

The trooper, his (trooper) old recollections awakened by the solitary grandeur of a great house--no novelty to him (trooper) once at Chesney Wold--goes up the stairs and through the chief rooms, holding up his (chief) light at arm's length. Thinking of his (chief) varied fortunes within the last few weeks, and of his (chief) rustic boyhood, and of the two periods of his (chief) life so strangely brought together across the wide intermediate space; thinking of the murdered man whose image is fresh in his (man) mind; thinking of the lady who has disappeared from these very rooms and the tokens of whose recent presence are all here; thinking of the master of the house upstairs and of the foreboding,

``Who will tell him (George)!'' (the master)
he (master) looks here and looks there, and reflects how he (master) MIGHT see something now, which it would tax his (master) boldness to walk up to, lay his (master) hand upon, and prove to be a fancy. But it is all blank, blank as the darkness above and below, while he (master) goes up the great staircase again, blank as the oppressive silence.

``All is still in readiness, George Rouncewell?'' (unknown)

``Quite orderly and right, Sir Leicester.'' (unknown)

``No word of any kind?'' (The trooper)

The trooper shakes his (trooper) head.

``No letter that can possibly have been overlooked?'' (he)

But he (trooper) knows there is no such hope as that and lays his (trooper) head down without looking for an answer.

Very familiar to him (trooper), as he (trooper) said himself some hours ago, George Rouncewell lifts him (Rouncewell) into easier positions through the long remainder of the blank wintry night, and equally familiar with his (Rouncewell) unexpressed wish, extinguishes the light and undraws the curtains at the first late break of day. The day comes like a phantom. Cold, colourless, and vague, it sends a warning streak before it of a deathlike hue, as if it cried out,

``Look what I am bringing you who watch there! Who will tell him (Rouncewell)!'' (Esther/Miss Summerson/Esther Summerson)

CHAPTER LIX

Esther's Narrative

It was three o'clock in the morning when the houses outside London did at last begin to exclude the country and to close us in with streets. We had made our way along roads in a far worse condition than when we had traversed them by daylight, both the fall and the thaw having lasted ever since; but the energy of my companion never slackened. It had only been, as I thought, of less assistance than the horses in getting us on, and it had often aided them. They had stopped exhausted half-way up hills, they had been driven through streams of turbulent water, they had slipped down and become entangled with the harness; but he (companion) and his (companion) little lantern had been always ready, and when the mishap was set right, I had never heard any variation in his (companion) cool,

``Get on, my lads!'' (I)

The steadiness and confidence with which he (companion) had directed our journey back I could not account for. Never wavering, he (companion) never even stopped to make an inquiry until we were within a few miles of London. A very few words, here and there, were then enough for him (companion); and thus we came, at between three and four o'clock in the morning, into Islington.

I will not dwell on the suspense and anxiety with which I reflected all this time that we were leaving my mother farther and farther behind every minute. I think I had some strong hope that he (companion) must be right and could not fail to have a satisfactory object in following this woman, but I tormented myself with questioning it and discussing it during the whole journey. What was to ensue when we found her (woman) and what could compensate us for this loss of time were questions also that I could not possibly dismiss; my mind was quite tortured by long dwelling on such reflections when we stopped.

We stopped in a high-street where there was a coach-stand. My companion paid our two drivers, who were as completely covered with splashes as if they had been dragged along the roads like the carriage itself, and giving them some brief direction where to take it, lifted me out of it and into a hackney-coach he (companion) had chosen from the rest.

``Why, my dear!'' (he)
he (companion) said as he (companion) did this.
``How wet you are!'' (I)

I had not been conscious of it. But the melted snow had found its way into the carriage, and I had got out two or three times when a fallen horse was plunging and had to be got up, and the wet had penetrated my dress. I assured him (companion) it was no matter, but the driver, who knew him (driver), would not be dissuaded by me from running down the street to his (driver) stable, whence he (driver) brought an armful of clean dry straw. They shook it out and strewed it well about me, and I found it warm and comfortable.

``Now, my dear,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket, with his (Mr.) head in at the window after I was shut up.
``We're a-going to mark this person down. It may take a little time, but you don't mind that. You're pretty sure that I've got a motive. Ain't you?'' (I)

I little thought what it was, little thought in how short a time I should understand it better, but I assured him (Mr.) that I had confidence in him (Mr.).

``So you may have, my dear,'' (he)
he (Mr.) returned.
``And I tell you what! If you only repose half as much confidence in me as I repose in you after what I've experienced of you, that'll do. Lord! You're no trouble at all. I never see a young woman in any station of society--and I've seen many elevated ones too--conduct herself like you have conducted yourself since you was called out of your bed. You're a pattern, you know, that's what you are,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket warmly;
``you're a pattern.'' (Mr.)

I told him (Mr.) I was very glad, as indeed I was, to have been no hindrance to him (Mr.), and that I hoped I should be none now.

``My dear,'' (he)
he (Mr.) returned,
``when a young lady is as mild as she (lady)'s game, and as game as she (lady)'s mild, that's all I ask, and more than I expect. She (lady) then becomes a queen, and that's about what you are yourself.'' (he)

With these encouraging words--they really were encouraging to me under those lonely and anxious circumstances--he (Mr.) got upon the box, and we once more drove away. Where we drove I neither knew then nor have ever known since, but we appeared to seek out the narrowest and worst streets in London. Whenever I saw him (Mr.) directing the driver, I was prepared for our descending into a deeper complication of such streets, and we never failed to do so.

Sometimes we emerged upon a wider thoroughfare or came to a larger building than the generality, well lighted. Then we stopped at offices like those we had visited when we began our journey, and I saw him (Mr.) in consultation with others. Sometimes he (Mr.) would get down by an archway or at a street corner and mysteriously show the light of his (Mr.) little lantern. This would attract similar lights from various dark quarters, like so many insects, and a fresh consultation would be held. By degrees we appeared to contract our search within narrower and easier limits. Single police-officers on duty could now tell Mr. Bucket what he (Bucket) wanted to know and point to him (Bucket) where to go. At last we stopped for a rather long conversation between him (Bucket) and one of these men, which I supposed to be satisfactory from his (Bucket) manner of nodding from time to time. When it was finished he (Bucket) came to me looking very busy and very attentive.

``Now, Miss Summerson,'' (he)
he (Bucket) said to me,
``you won't be alarmed whatever comes off, I know. It's not necessary for me to give you any further caution than to tell you that we have marked this person down and that you may be of use to me before I know it myself. I don't like to ask such a thing, my dear, but would you walk a little way?'' (me)

Of course I got out directly and took his (Bucket) arm.

``It ain't so easy to keep your feet,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket,
``but take time.'' (Mr.)

Although I looked about me confusedly and hurriedly as we crossed the street, I thought I knew the place.

``Are we in Holborn?'' (I)
I asked him (Bucket).

``Yes,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket.
``Do you know this turning?'' (unknown)

``It looks like Chancery Lane.'' (unknown)

``And was christened so, my dear,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket.

We turned down it, and as we went shuffling through the sleet, I heard the clocks strike half-past five. We passed on in silence and as quickly as we could with such a foot-hold, when some one coming towards us on the narrow pavement, wrapped in a cloak, stopped and stood aside to give me room. In the same moment I heard an exclamation of wonder and my own name from Mr. Woodcourt. I knew his (Woodcourt) voice very well.

It was so unexpected and so--I don't know what to call it, whether pleasant or painful--to come upon it after my feverish wandering journey, and in the midst of the night, that I could not keep back the tears from my eyes. It was like hearing his (Woodcourt) voice in a strange country.

``My dear Miss Summerson, that you should be out at this hour, and in such weather!'' (He)

He (Woodcourt) had heard from my guardian of my having been called away on some uncommon business and said so to dispense with any explanation. I told him (Woodcourt) that we had but just left a coach and were going--but then I was obliged to look at my companion.

``Why, you see, Mr. Woodcourt'' (he)
--he (companion) had caught the name from me--
``we are a-going at present into the next street. Inspector Bucket.'' (me)

Mr. Woodcourt, disregarding my remonstrances, had hurriedly taken off his (Woodcourt) cloak and was putting it about me.

``That's a good move, too,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket, assisting,
``a very good move.'' (Mr.)

``May I go with you?'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
said Mr. Woodcourt. I don't know whether to me or to my companion.

``Why, Lord!'' (Mr.)
exclaimed Mr. Bucket, taking the answer on himself.
``Of course you may.'' (me)

It was all said in a moment, and they took me between them, wrapped in the cloak.

``I have just left Richard,'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
said Mr. Woodcourt.
``I have been sitting with him (Richard) since ten o'clock last night.'' (unknown)

``Oh, dear me, he (Richard) is ill!'' (unknown)

``No, no, believe me; not ill, but not quite well. He (Richard) was depressed and faint--you know he (Richard) gets so worried and so worn sometimes--and Ada sent to me of course; and when I came home I found her (Ada) note and came straight here. Well! Richard revived so much after a little while, and Ada was so happy and so convinced of its being my doing, though God knows I had little enough to do with it, that I remained with him (God) until he (God) had been fast asleep some hours. As fast asleep as she (Ada) is now, I hope!'' (I)

His (Woodcourt) friendly and familiar way of speaking of them, his (Woodcourt) unaffected devotion to them, the grateful confidence with which I knew he (Woodcourt) had inspired my darling, and the comfort he (Woodcourt) was to her (Mr.); could I separate all this from his (Woodcourt) promise to me? How thankless I must have been if it had not recalled the words he (Woodcourt) said to me when he (Woodcourt) was so moved by the change in my appearance:

``I will accept him (God) as a trust, and it shall be a sacred one!'' (he)

We now turned into another narrow street.

``Mr. Woodcourt,'' (Mr. Bucket)
said Mr. Bucket, who had eyed him (Bucket) closely as we came along,
``our business takes us to a law-stationer's here, a certain Mr. Snagsby's. What, you know him (Snagsby), do you?'' (him)
He (Bucket) was so quick that he (Bucket) saw it in an instant.

``Yes, I know a little of him (Snagsby) and have called upon him (Snagsby) at this place.'' (unknown)

``Indeed, sir?'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket.
``Then you will be so good as to let me leave Miss Summerson with you for a moment while I go and have half a word with him (Snagsby)?'' (The police-officer)

The last police-officer with whom he (Mr.) had conferred was standing silently behind us. I was not aware of it until he (Mr.) struck in on my saying I heard some one crying.

``Don't be alarmed, miss,'' (he)
he (Mr.) returned.
``It's Snagsby's servant.'' (unknown)

``Why, you see,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket,
``the girl's subject to fits, and has 'em bad upon her (girl) to-night. A most contrary circumstance it is, for I want certain information out of that girl, and she (girl) must be brought to reason somehow.'' (Mr.)

``At all events, they wouldn't be up yet if it wasn't for her (girl), Mr. Bucket,'' (the man)
said the other man.
``She (girl)'s been at it pretty well all night, sir.'' (unknown)

``Well, that's true,'' (he)
he (Mr.) returned.
``My light's burnt out. Show yours a moment.'' (I)

All this passed in a whisper a door or two from the house in which I could faintly hear crying and moaning. In the little round of light produced for the purpose, Mr. Bucket went up to the door and knocked. The door was opened after he (Bucket) had knocked twice, and he (Bucket) went in, leaving us standing in the street.

``Miss Summerson,'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
said Mr. Woodcourt,
``if without obtruding myself on your confidence I may remain near you, pray let me do so.'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)

``You are truly kind,'' (I)
I answered.
``I need wish to keep no secret of my own from you; if I keep any, it is another's.'' (unknown)

``I quite understand. Trust me, I will remain near you only so long as I can fully respect it.'' (unknown)

``I trust implicitly to you,'' (I)
I said.
``I know and deeply feel how sacredly you keep your promise.'' (Mr.)

After a short time the little round of light shone out again, and Mr. Bucket advanced towards us in it with his (Mr.) earnest face.

``Please to come in, Miss Summerson,'' (he)
he (Mr.) said,
``and sit down by the fire. Mr. Woodcourt, from information I have received I understand you are a medical man. Would you look to this girl and see if anything can be done to bring her (girl) round. She (girl) has a letter somewhere that I particularly want. It's not in her (girl) box, and I think it must be about her (girl); but she (girl) is so twisted and clenched up that she (girl) is difficult to handle without hurting.'' (he)

We all three went into the house together; although it was cold and raw, it smelt close too from being up all night. In the passage behind the door stood a scared, sorrowful-looking little man in a grey coat who seemed to have a naturally polite manner and spoke meekly.

``Downstairs, if you please, Mr. Bucket,'' (he)
said he (man).
``The lady will excuse the front kitchen; we use it as our workaday sitting-room. The back is Guster's bedroom, and in it she (lady)'s a-carrying on, poor thing, to a frightful extent!'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

We went downstairs, followed by Mr. Snagsby, as I soon found the little man to be. In the front kitchen, sitting by the fire, was Mrs. Snagsby, with very red eyes and a very severe expression of face.

``My little woman,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
said Mr. Snagsby, entering behind us,
``to wave--not to put too fine a point upon it, my dear--hostilities for one single moment in the course of this prolonged night, here is Inspector Bucket, Mr. Woodcourt, and a lady.'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)

She (Snagsby) looked very much astonished, as she (Snagsby) had reason for doing, and looked particularly hard at me.

``My little woman,'' (Mr. Snagsby/Snagsby)
said Mr. Snagsby, sitting down in the remotest corner by the door, as if he (Snagsby) were taking a liberty,
``it is not unlikely that you may inquire of me why Inspector Bucket, Mr. Woodcourt, and a lady call upon us in Cook's Court, Cursitor Street, at the present hour. I don't know. I have not the least idea. If I was to be informed, I should despair of understanding, and I'd rather not be told.'' (he)

He (Snagsby) appeared so miserable, sitting with his (Snagsby) head upon his (Snagsby) hand, and I appeared so unwelcome, that I was going to offer an apology when Mr. Bucket took the matter on himself.

``Now, Mr. Snagsby,'' (he)
said he (Bucket),
``the best thing you can do is to go along with Mr. Woodcourt to look after your Guster--'' (he)

``My Guster, Mr. Bucket!'' (he)
cried Mr. Snagsby.
``Go on, sir, go on. I shall be charged with that next.'' (unknown)

``And to hold the candle,'' (Mr.)
pursued Mr. Bucket without correcting himself,
``or hold her (Snagsby), or make yourself useful in any way you're asked. Which there's not a man alive more ready to do, for you're a man of urbanity and suavity, you know, and you've got the sort of heart that can feel for another. Mr. Woodcourt, would you be so good as see to her (Snagsby), and if you can get that letter from her (Snagsby), to let me have it as soon as ever you can?'' (Mr.)

As they went out, Mr. Bucket made me sit down in a corner by the fire and take off my wet shoes, which he (Bucket) turned up to dry upon the fender, talking all the time.

``Don't you be at all put out, miss, by the want of a hospitable look from Mrs. Snagsby there, because she (Snagsby)'s under a mistake altogether. She (Snagsby)'ll find that out sooner than will be agreeable to a lady of her (lady) generally correct manner of forming her (lady) thoughts, because I'm a-going to explain it to her (lady).'' (he)
Here, standing on the hearth with his (Bucket) wet hat and shawls in his (Bucket) hand, himself a pile of wet, he (Bucket) turned to Mrs. Snagsby. ``Now, the first thing that I say to you, as a married woman possessing what you may call charms, you know--``Believe Me, if All Those Endearing,
'' and cetrer--you're well acquainted with the song, because it's in vain for you to tell me that you and good society are strangers--charms--attractions, mind you, that ought to give you confidence in yourself--is, that you've done it.'' (Mrs. Snagsby)

Mrs. Snagsby looked rather alarmed, relented a little and faltered, what did Mr. Bucket mean.

``What does Mr. Bucket mean?'' (he)
he (Mr.) repeated, and I saw by his (Mr.) face that all the time he (Mr.) talked he (Mr.) was listening for the discovery of the letter, to my own great agitation, for I knew then how important it must be;
``I'll tell you what he (Mr.) means, ma'am. Go and see Othello acted. That's the tragedy for you.'' (I)

Mrs. Snagsby consciously asked why.

``Why?'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket.
``Because you'll come to that if you don't look out. Why, at the very moment while I speak, I know what your mind's not wholly free from respecting this young lady. But shall I tell you who this young lady is? Now, come, you're what I call an intellectual woman--with your soul too large for your body, if you come to that, and chafing it--and you know me, and you recollect where you saw me last, and what was talked of in that circle. Don't you? Yes! Very well. This young lady is that young lady.'' (Mrs. Snagsby)

Mrs. Snagsby appeared to understand the reference better than I did at the time.

``And Toughey--him (you) as you call Jo--was mixed up in the same business, and no other; and the law-writer that you know of was mixed up in the same business, and no other; and your husband, with no more knowledge of it than your great grandfather, was mixed up -LRB-by Mr. Tulkinghorn, deceased, his (Tulkinghorn) best customer-RRB- in the same business, and no other; and the whole bileing of people was mixed up in the same business, and no other. And yet a married woman, possessing your attractions, shuts her (woman) eyes -LRB-and sparklers too-RRB-, and goes and runs her (woman) delicate-formed head against a wall. Why, I am ashamed of you! -LRB-I expected Mr. Woodcourt might have got it by this time.-RRB-'' (Mrs. Snagsby)

Mrs. Snagsby shook her (Snagsby) head and put her (Snagsby) handkerchief to her (Snagsby) eyes.

``Is that all?'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket excitedly.
``No. See what happens. Another person mixed up in that business and no other, a person in a wretched state, comes here to-night and is seen a-speaking to your maid-servant; and between her (woman) and your maid-servant there passes a paper that I would give a hundred pound for, down. What do you do? You hide and you watch 'em, and you pounce upon that maid-servant--knowing what she (woman)'s subject to and what a little thing will bring 'em on--in that surprising manner and with that severity that, by the Lord, she (woman) goes off and keeps off, when a life may be hanging upon that girl's words!'' (He)

He (Mr.) so thoroughly meant what he (Mr.) said now that I involuntarily clasped my hands and felt the room turning away from me. But it stopped. Mr. Woodcourt came in, put a paper into his (Woodcourt) hand, and went away again.

``Now, Mrs. Snagsby, the only amends you can make,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket, rapidly glancing at it,
``is to let me speak a word to this young lady in private here. And if you know of any help that you can give to that gentleman in the next kitchen there or can think of any one thing that's likelier than another to bring the girl round, do your swiftest and best!'' (Mr.)
In an instant she (Snagsby) was gone, and he (Mr.) had shut the door.
``Now my dear, you're steady and quite sure of yourself?'' (unknown)

``Quite,'' (I.)
said I.

``Whose writing is that?'' (I.)

It was my mother's. A pencil-writing, on a crushed and torn piece of paper, blotted with wet. Folded roughly like a letter, and directed to me at my guardian's.

``You know the hand,'' (he)
he (Mr.) said,
``and if you are firm enough to read it to me, do! But be particular to a word.'' (he)

It had been written in portions, at different times. I read what follows:

I came to the cottage with two objects. First, to see the dear one, if I could, once more--but only to see her (mother)--not to speak to her (mother) or let her (mother) know that I was near. The other object, to elude pursuit and to be lost. Do not blame the mother for her (mother) share. The assistance that she (mother) rendered me, she (mother) rendered on my strongest assurance that it was for the dear one's good. You remember her (mother) dead child. The men's consent I bought, but her (mother) help was freely given.

'''I came.'' (I)
That was written,'' said my companion,
``when she (girl) rested there. It bears out what I made of it. I was right.'' (unknown)

The next was written at another time:

I have wandered a long distance, and for many hours, and I know that I must soon die. These streets! I have no purpose but to die. When I left, I had a worse, but I am saved from adding that guilt to the rest. Cold, wet, and fatigue are sufficient causes for my being found dead, but I shall die of others, though I suffer from these. It was right that all that had sustained me should give way at once and that I should die of terror and my conscience.

``Take courage,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket.
``There's only a few words more.'' (unknown)

Those, too, were written at another time. To all appearance, almost in the dark:

I have done all I could do to be lost. I shall be soon forgotten so, and shall disgrace him (Mr.) least. I have nothing about me by which I can be recognized. This paper I part with now. The place where I shall lie down, if I can get so far, has been often in my mind. Farewell. Forgive.

Mr. Bucket, supporting me with his (Mr.) arm, lowered me gently into my chair.

``Cheer up! Don't think me hard with you, my dear, but as soon as ever you feel equal to it, get your shoes on and be ready.'' (I)

I did as he (Mr.) required, but I was left there a long time, praying for my unhappy mother. They were all occupied with the poor girl, and I heard Mr. Woodcourt directing them and speaking to her (girl) often. At length he (Woodcourt) came in with Mr. Bucket and said that as it was important to address her (girl) gently, he (Bucket) thought it best that I should ask her (girl) for whatever information we desired to obtain. There was no doubt that she (girl) could now reply to questions if she (girl) were soothed and not alarmed. The questions, Mr. Bucket said, were how she (girl) came by the letter, what passed between her (girl) and the person who gave her (girl) the letter, and where the person went. Holding my mind as steadily as I could to these points, I went into the next room with them. Mr. Woodcourt would have remained outside, but at my solicitation went in with us.

The poor girl was sitting on the floor where they had laid her (girl) down. They stood around her (girl), though at a little distance, that she (girl) might have air. She (girl) was not pretty and looked weak and poor, but she (girl) had a plaintive and a good face, though it was still a little wild. I kneeled on the ground beside her (girl) and put her (girl) poor head upon my shoulder, whereupon she (girl) drew her (girl) arm round my neck and burst into tears.

``My poor girl,'' (I)
said I, laying my face against her (girl) forehead, for indeed I was crying too, and trembling,
``it seems cruel to trouble you now, but more depends on our knowing something about this letter than I could tell you in an hour.'' (I)

She (girl) began piteously declaring that she (girl) didn't mean any harm, she (girl) didn't mean any harm, Mrs. Snagsby!

``We are all sure of that,'' (I.)
said I.
``But pray tell me how you got it.'' (I.)

``Yes, dear lady, I will, and tell you true. I'll tell true, indeed, Mrs. Snagsby.'' (unknown)

``I am sure of that,'' (I.)
said I.
``And how was it?'' (I.)

``I had been out on an errand, dear lady--long after it was dark--quite late; and when I came home, I found a common-looking person, all wet and muddy, looking up at our house. When she (lady) saw me coming in at the door, she (lady) called me back and said did I live here. And I said yes, and she (lady) said she (lady) knew only one or two places about here, but had lost her (lady) way and couldn't find them. Oh, what shall I do, what shall I do! They won't believe me! She (lady) didn't say any harm to me, and I didn't say any harm to her (lady), indeed, Mrs. Snagsby!'' (mistress)

It was necessary for her (girl) mistress to comfort her (girl)--which she (girl) did, I must say, with a good deal of contrition--before she (girl) could be got beyond this.

``She (lady) could not find those places,'' (I.)
said I.

``No!'' (I.)
cried the girl, shaking her (girl) head.
``No! Couldn't find them. And she (lady) was so faint, and lame, and miserable, Oh so wretched, that if you had seen her (lady), Mr. Snagsby, you'd have given her (lady) half a crown, I know!'' (unknown)

``Well, Guster, my girl,'' (he)
said he (I.), at first not knowing what to say.
``I hope I should.'' (unknown)

``And yet she (girl) was so well spoken,'' (the girl)
said the girl, looking at me with wide open eyes,
``that it made a person's heart bleed. And so she (girl) said to me, did I know the way to the burying ground? And I asked her (girl) which burying ground. And she (girl) said, the poor burying ground. And so I told her (girl) I had been a poor child myself, and it was according to parishes. But she (girl) said she (girl) meant a poor burying ground not very far from here, where there was an archway, and a step, and an iron gate.'' (me)

As I watched her (girl) face and soothed her (girl) to go on, I saw that Mr. Bucket received this with a look which I could not separate from one of alarm.

``Oh, dear, dear!'' (the girl)
cried the girl, pressing her (girl) hair back with her (girl) hands.
``What shall I do, what shall I do! She (girl) meant the burying ground where the man was buried that took the sleeping-stuff--that you came home and told us of, Mr. Snagsby--that frightened me so, Mrs. Snagsby. Oh, I am frightened again. Hold me!'' (unknown)

``You are so much better now,'' (I.)
sald I.
``Pray, pray tell me more.'' (I.)

``Yes I will, yes I will! But don't be angry with me, that's a dear lady, because I have been so ill.'' (her)

Angry with her (girl), poor soul!

``There! Now I will, now I will. So she (lady) said, could I tell her (lady) how to find it, and I said yes, and I told her (lady); and she (lady) looked at me with eyes like almost as if she (lady) was blind, and herself all waving back. And so she (lady) took out the letter, and showed it me, and said if she (lady) was to put that in the post-office, it would be rubbed out and not minded and never sent; and would I take it from her (lady), and send it, and the messenger would be paid at the house. And so I said yes, if it was no harm, and she (lady) said no--no harm. And so I took it from her (lady), and she (lady) said she (lady) had nothing to give me, and I said I was poor myself and consequently wanted nothing. And so she (lady) said God bless you, and went.'' (unknown)

``And did she (lady) go--'' (the girl)

``Yes,'' (the girl)
cried the girl, anticipating the inquiry.
``Yes! She (lady) went the way I had shown her (lady). Then I came in, and Mrs. Snagsby came behind me from somewhere and laid hold of me, and I was frightened.'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)

Mr. Woodcourt took her (girl) kindly from me. Mr. Bucket wrapped me up, and immediately we were in the street. Mr. Woodcourt hesitated, but I said,

``Don't leave me now!'' (I)
and Mr. Bucket added,
``You'll be better with us, we may want you; don't lose time!'' (Mr. Bucket)

I have the most confused impressions of that walk. I recollect that it was neither night nor day, that morning was dawning but the street-lamps were not yet put out, that the sleet was still falling and that all the ways were deep with it. I recollect a few chilled people passing in the streets. I recollect the wet house-tops, the clogged and bursting gutters and water-spouts, the mounds of blackened ice and snow over which we passed, the narrowness of the courts by which we went. At the same time I remember that the poor girl seemed to be yet telling her (girl) story audibly and plainly in my hearing, that I could feel her (girl) resting on my arm, that the stained house-fronts put on human shapes and looked at me, that great water-gates seemed to be opening and closing in my head or in the air, and that the unreal things were more substantial than the real.

At last we stood under a dark and miserable covered way, where one lamp was burning over an iron gate and where the morning faintly struggled in. The gate was closed. Beyond it was a burial ground--a dreadful spot in which the night was very slowly stirring, but where I could dimly see heaps of dishonoured graves and stones, hemmed in by filthy houses with a few dull lights in their windows and on whose walls a thick humidity broke out like a disease. On the step at the gate, drenched in the fearful wet of such a place, which oozed and splashed down everywhere, I saw, with a cry of pity and horror, a woman lying--Jenny, the mother of the dead child.

I ran forward, but they stopped me, and Mr. Woodcourt entreated me with the greatest earnestness, even with tears, before I went up to the figure to listen for an instant to what Mr. Bucket said. I did so, as I thought. I did so, as I am sure.

``Miss Summerson, you'll understand me, if you think a moment. They changed clothes at the cottage.'' (unknown)

They changed clothes at the cottage. I could repeat the words in my mind, and I knew what they meant of themselves, but I attached no meaning to them in any other connexion.

``And one returned,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket,
``and one went on. And the one that went on only went on a certain way agreed upon to deceive and then turned across country and went home. Think a moment!'' (Mr.)

I could repeat this in my mind too, but I had not the least idea what it meant. I saw before me, lying on the step, the mother of the dead child. She (mother) lay there with one arm creeping round a bar of the iron gate and seeming to embrace it. She (mother) lay there, who had so lately spoken to my mother. She (mother) lay there, a distressed, unsheltered, senseless creature. She (mother) who had brought my mother's letter, who could give me the only clue to where my mother was; she (mother), who was to guide us to rescue and save her (mother) whom we had sought so far, who had come to this condition by some means connected with my mother that I could not follow, and might be passing beyond our reach and help at that moment; she (mother) lay there, and they stopped me! I saw but did not comprehend the solemn and compassionate look in Mr. Woodcourt's face. I saw but did not comprehend his (Woodcourt) touching the other on the breast to keep him (Woodcourt) back. I saw him (Woodcourt) stand uncovered in the bitter air, with a reverence for something. But my understanding for all this was gone.

I even heard it said between them,

``Shall she (Summerson) go?'' (I)

``She (Summerson) had better go. Her (Summerson) hands should be the first to touch her (Summerson). They have a higher right than ours.'' (I)

I passed on to the gate and stooped down. I lifted the heavy head, put the long dank hair aside, and turned the face. And it was my mother, cold and dead.

CHAPTER LX

Perspective

I proceed to other passages of my narrative. From the goodness of all about me I derived such consolation as I can never think of unmoved. I have already said so much of myself, and so much still remains, that I will not dwell upon my sorrow. I had an illness, but it was not a long one; and I would avoid even this mention of it if I could quite keep down the recollection of their sympathy.

I proceed to other passages of my narrative.

During the time of my illness, we were still in London, where Mrs. Woodcourt had come, on my guardian's invitation, to stay with us. When my guardian thought me well and cheerful enough to talk with him (myself) in our old way--though I could have done that sooner if he (myself) would have believed me--I resumed my work and my chair beside his (myself). He (myself) had appointed the time himself, and we were alone.

``Dame Trot,'' (he)
said he (myself), receiving me with a kiss,
``welcome to the growlery again, my dear. I have a scheme to develop, little woman. I propose to remain here, perhaps for six months, perhaps for a longer time--as it may be. Quite to settle here for a while, in short.'' (me)

``And in the meanwhile leave Bleak House?'' (I.)
said I.

``Aye, my dear? Bleak House,'' (I.)
he (myself) returned,
``must learn to take care of itself.'' (he)

I thought his (myself) tone sounded sorrowful, but looking at him (myself), I saw his (myself) kind face lighted up by its pleasantest smile.

``Bleak House,'' (he)
he (myself) repeated--and his (myself) tone did NOT sound sorrowful, I found--
``must learn to take care of itself. It is a long way from Ada, my dear, and Ada stands much in need of you.'' (I)

``It's like you, guardian,'' (I)
said I,
``to have been taking that into consideration for a happy surprise to both of us.'' (I)

``Not so disinterested either, my dear, if you mean to extol me for that virtue, since if you were generally on the road, you could be seldom with me. And besides, I wish to hear as much and as often of Ada as I can in this condition of estrangement from poor Rick. Not of her (Ada) alone, but of him (Rick) too, poor fellow.'' (unknown)

``Have you seen Mr. Woodcourt, this morning, guardian?'' (unknown)

``I see Mr. Woodcourt every morning, Dame Durden.'' (unknown)

``Does he (Durden) still say the same of Richard?'' (unknown)

``Just the same. He (Richard) knows of no direct bodily illness that he (Richard) has; on the contrary, he (Richard) believes that he (Richard) has none. Yet he (Richard) is not easy about him (Richard); who CAN be?'' (girl)

My dear girl had been to see us lately every day, some times twice in a day. But we had foreseen, all along, that this would only last until I was quite myself. We knew full well that her (girl) fervent heart was as full of affection and gratitude towards her (girl) cousin John as it had ever been, and we acquitted Richard of laying any injunctions upon her (girl) to stay away; but we knew on the other hand that she (girl) felt it a part of her (girl) duty to him (Richard) to be sparing of her (girl) visits at our house. My guardian's delicacy had soon perceived this and had tried to convey to her (girl) that he (Richard) thought she (girl) was right.

``Dear, unfortunate, mistaken Richard,'' (I.)
said I.
``When will he (Richard) awake from his (Richard) delusion!'' (I.)

``He (Richard) is not in the way to do so now, my dear,'' (guardian)
replied my guardian.
``The more he (Richard) suffers, the more averse he (Richard) will be to me, having made me the principal representative of the great occasion of his (Richard) suffering.'' (I)

I could not help adding,

``So unreasonably!'' (I)

``Ah, Dame Trot, Dame Trot,'' (guardian)
returned my guardian,
``what shall we find reasonable in Jarndyce and Jarndyce! Unreason and injustice at the top, unreason and injustice at the heart and at the bottom, unreason and injustice from beginning to end--if it ever has an end--how should poor Rick, always hovering near it, pluck reason out of it? He (Rick) no more gathers grapes from thorns or figs from thistles than older men did in old times.'' (guardian)

His (Richard) gentleness and consideration for Richard whenever we spoke of him (Richard) touched me so that I was always silent on this subject very soon.

``I suppose the Lord Chancellor, and the Vice Chancellors, and the whole Chancery battery of great guns would be infinitely astonished by such unreason and injustice in one of their suitors,'' (guardian)
pursued my guardian.
``When those learned gentlemen begin to raise moss-roses from the powder they sow in their wigs, I shall begin to be astonished too!'' (He)

He (Richard) checked himself in glancing towards the window to look where the wind was and leaned on the back of my chair instead.

``Well, well, little woman! To go on, my dear. This rock we must leave to time, chance, and hopeful circumstance. We must not shipwreck Ada upon it. She (Ada) cannot afford, and he (Chancellor) cannot afford, the remotest chance of another separation from a friend. Therefore I have particularly begged of Woodcourt, and I now particularly beg of you, my dear, not to move this subject with Rick. Let it rest. Next week, next month, next year, sooner or later, he (Rick) will see me with clearer eyes. I can wait.'' (I)

But I had already discussed it with him (Richard), I confessed; and so, I thought, had Mr. Woodcourt.

``So he (Rick) tells me,'' (guardian)
returned my guardian.
``Very good. He (Rick) has made his (Rick) protest, and Dame Durden has made hers, and there is nothing more to be said about it. Now I come to Mrs. Woodcourt. How do you like her (Woodcourt), my dear?'' (I)

In answer to this question, which was oddly abrupt, I said I liked her (I) very much and thought she (I) was more agreeable than she (I) used to be.

``I think so too,'' (guardian)
said my guardian.
``Less pedigree? Not so much of Morgan ap--what's his (Morgan) name?'' (I)

That was what I meant, I acknowledged, though he (Woodcourt) was a very harmless person, even when we had had more of him (Woodcourt).

``Still, upon the whole, he (Morgan) is as well in his (Morgan) native mountains,'' (guardian)
said my guardian.
``I agree with you. Then, little woman, can I do better for a time than retain Mrs. Woodcourt here?'' (unknown)

No. And yet--

My guardian looked at me, waiting for what I had to say.

I had nothing to say. At least I had nothing in my mind that I could say. I had an undefined impression that it might have been better if we had had some other inmate, but I could hardly have explained why even to myself. Or, if to myself, certainly not to anybody else.

``You see,'' (guardian)
said my guardian,
``our neighbourhood is in Woodcourt's way, and he (Morgan) can come here to see her (Woodcourt) as often as he (Morgan) likes, which is agreeable to them both; and she (Woodcourt) is familiar to us and fond of you.'' (guardian)

Yes. That was undeniable. I had nothing to say against it. I could not have suggested a better arrangement, but I was not quite easy in my mind. Esther, Esther, why not? Esther, think!

``It is a very good plan indeed, dear guardian, and we could not do better.'' (unknown)

``Sure, little woman?'' (unknown)

Quite sure. I had had a moment's time to think, since I had urged that duty on myself, and I was quite sure.

``Good,'' (guardian)
said my guardian.
``It shall be done. Carried unanimously.'' (unknown)

``Carried unanimously,'' (I)
I repeated, going on with my work.

It was a cover for his (guardian) book-table that I happened to be ornamenting. It had been laid by on the night preceding my sad journey and never resumed. I showed it to him (guardian) now, and he (guardian) admired it highly. After I had explained the pattern to him (guardian) and all the great effects that were to come out by and by, I thought I would go back to our last theme.

``You said, dear guardian, when we spoke of Mr. Woodcourt before Ada left us, that you thought he (Woodcourt) would give a long trial to another country. Have you been advising him (Woodcourt) since?'' (unknown)

``Yes, little woman, pretty often.'' (unknown)

``Has he (Woodcourt) decided to do so?'' (unknown)

``I rather think not.'' (unknown)

``Some other prospect has opened to him (Woodcourt), perhaps?'' (I.)
said I.

``Why--yes--perhaps,'' (I.)
returned my guardian, beginning his (guardian) answer in a very deliberate manner.
``About half a year hence or so, there is a medical attendant for the poor to be appointed at a certain place in Yorkshire. It is a thriving place, pleasantly situated--streams and streets, town and country, mill and moor--and seems to present an opening for such a man. I mean a man whose hopes and aims may sometimes lie -LRB-as most men's sometimes do, I dare say-RRB- above the ordinary level, but to whom the ordinary level will be high enough after all if it should prove to be a way of usefulness and good service leading to no other. All generous spirits are ambitious, I suppose, but the ambition that calmly trusts itself to such a road, instead of spasmodically trying to fly over it, is of the kind I care for. It is Woodcourt's kind.'' (unknown)

``And will he (Woodcourt) get this appointment?'' (I)
I asked.

``Why, little woman,'' (guardian)
returned my guardian, smiling,
``not being an oracle, I cannot confidently say, but I think so. His (Woodcourt) reputation stands very high; there were people from that part of the country in the shipwreck; and strange to say, I believe the best man has the best chance. You must not suppose it to be a fine endowment. It is a very, very commonplace affair, my dear, an appointment to a great amount of work and a small amount of pay; but better things will gather about it, it may be fairly hoped.'' (guardian)

``The poor of that place will have reason to bless the choice if it falls on Mr. Woodcourt, guardian.'' (unknown)

``You are right, little woman; that I am sure they will.'' (he)

We said no more about it, nor did he (guardian) say a word about the future of Bleak House. But it was the first time I had taken my seat at his (guardian) side in my mourning dress, and that accounted for it, I considered.

I now began to visit my dear girl every day in the dull dark corner where she (girl) lived. The morning was my usual time, but whenever I found I had an hour or so to spare, I put on my bonnet and bustled off to Chancery Lane. They were both so glad to see me at all hours, and used to brighten up so when they heard me opening the door and coming in -LRB-being quite at home, I never knocked-RRB-, that I had no fear of becoming troublesome just yet.

On these occasions I frequently found Richard absent. At other times he (Richard) would be writing or reading papers in the cause at that table of his (Richard), so covered with papers, which was never disturbed. Sometimes I would come upon him (Richard) lingering at the door of Mr. Vholes's office. Sometimes I would meet him (Richard) in the neighbourhood lounging about and biting his (Richard) nails. I often met him (Richard) wandering in Lincoln's Inn, near the place where I had first seen him (Richard), oh how different, how different!

That the money Ada brought him (Richard) was melting away with the candles I used to see burning after dark in Mr. Vholes's office I knew very well. It was not a large amount in the beginning, he (Vholes) had married in debt, and I could not fail to understand, by this time, what was meant by Mr. Vholes's shoulder being at the wheel--as I still heard it was. My dear made the best of housekeepers and tried hard to save, but I knew that they were getting poorer and poorer every day.

She (Ada) shone in the miserable corner like a beautiful star. She (Ada) adorned and graced it so that it became another place. Paler than she (Ada) had been at home, and a little quieter than I had thought natural when she (Ada) was yet so cheerful and hopeful, her (Ada) face was so unshadowed that I half believed she (Ada) was blinded by her (Ada) love for Richard to his (Richard) ruinous career.

I went one day to dine with them while I was under this impression. As I turned into Symond's Inn, I met little Miss Flite coming out. She (Ada) had been to make a stately call upon the wards in Jarndyce, as she (Ada) still called them, and had derived the highest gratification from that ceremony. Ada had already told me that she (Ada) called every Monday at five o'clock, with one little extra white bow in her (Ada) bonnet, which never appeared there at any other time, and with her (Ada) largest reticule of documents on her (Ada) arm.

``My dear!'' (she)
she (Ada) began.
``So delighted! How do you do! So glad to see you. And you are going to visit our interesting Jarndyce wards? TO be sure! Our beauty is at home, my dear, and will be charmed to see you.'' (unknown)

``Then Richard is not come in yet?'' (I.)
said I.
``I am glad of that, for I was afraid of being a little late.'' (I.)

``No, he (Richard) is not come in,'' (unknown)
returned Miss Flite. ``He (Richard) has had a long day in court. I left him (Richard) there with Vholes. You don't like Vholes, I hope? DON
``T like Vholes. Dan-gerous man!'' (unknown)

``I am afraid you see Richard oftener than ever now,'' (I.)
said I.

``My dearest,'' (I.)
returned Miss Flite,
``daily and hourly. You know what I told you of the attraction on the Chancellor's table? My dear, next to myself he (Chancellor) is the most constant suitor in court. He (Chancellor) begins quite to amuse our little party. Ve-ry friendly little party, are we not?'' (I.)

It was miserable to hear this from her (Ada) poor mad lips, though it was no surprise.

``In short, my valued friend,'' (unknown)
pursued Miss Flite, advancing her (Ada) lips to my ear with an air of equal patronage and mystery,
``I must tell you a secret. I have made him (friend) my executor. Nominated, constituted, and appointed him (friend). In my will. Ye-es.'' (unknown)

``Indeed?'' (I.)
said I.

``Ye-es,'' (I.)
repeated Miss Flite in her (Ada) most genteel accents,
``my executor, administrator, and assign. -LRB-Our Chancery phrases, my love.-RRB- I have reflected that if I should wear out, he (administrator) will be able to watch that judgment. Being so very regular in his (administrator) attendance.'' (I.)

It made me sigh to think of him (my).

``I did at one time mean,'' (unknown)
said Miss Flite, echoing the sigh,
``to nominate, constitute, and appoint poor Gridley. Also very regular, my charming girl. I assure you, most exemplary! But he (Gridley) wore out, poor man, so I have appointed his (Gridley) successor. Don't mention it. This is in confidence.'' (She)

She (Ada) carefully opened her (Ada) reticule a little way and showed me a folded piece of paper inside as the appointment of which she (Ada) spoke.

``Another secret, my dear. I have added to my collection of birds.'' (unknown)

``Really, Miss Flite?'' (I)
said I, knowing how it pleased her (Ada) to have her (Ada) confidence received with an appearance of interest.

She (Ada) nodded several times, and her (Ada) face became overcast and gloomy.

``Two more. I call them the Wards in Jarndyce. They are caged up with all the others. With Hope, Joy, Youth, Peace, Rest, Life, Dust, Ashes, Waste, Want, Ruin, Despair, Madness, Death, Cunning, Folly, Words, Wigs, Rags, Sheepskin, Plunder, Precedent, Jargon, Gammon, and Spinach!'' (me)

The poor soul kissed me with the most troubled look I had ever seen in her (Ada) and went her (Ada) way. Her (Ada) manner of running over the names of her (Ada) birds, as if she (Ada) were afraid of hearing them even from her (Ada) own lips, quite chilled me.

This was not a cheering preparation for my visit, and I could have dispensed with the company of Mr. Vholes, when Richard -LRB-who arrived within a minute or two after me-RRB- brought him (Richard) to share our dinner. Although it was a very plain one, Ada and Richard were for some minutes both out of the room together helping to get ready what we were to eat and drink. Mr. Vholes took that opportunity of holding a little conversation in a low voice with me. He (Vholes) came to the window where I was sitting and began upon Symond's Inn.

``A dull place, Miss Summerson, for a life that is not an official one,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
said Mr. Vholes, smearing the glass with his (Vholes) black glove to make it clearer for me.

``There is not much to see here,'' (I.)
said I.

``Nor to hear, miss,'' (I.)
returned Mr. Vholes.
``A little music does occasionally stray in, but we are not musical in the law and soon eject it. I hope Mr. Jarndyce is as well as his (Jarndyce) friends could wish him (Jarndyce)?'' (I)

I thanked Mr. Vholes and said he (Vholes) was quite well.

``I have not the pleasure to be admitted among the number of his (Jarndyce) friends myself,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
said Mr. Vholes,
``and I am aware that the gentlemen of our profession are sometimes regarded in such quarters with an unfavourable eye. Our plain course, however, under good report and evil report, and all kinds of prejudice -LRB-we are the victims of prejudice-RRB-, is to have everything openly carried on. How do you find Mr. C. looking, Miss Summerson?'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)

``He (Mr.) looks very ill. Dreadfully anxious.'' (unknown)

``Just so,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
said Mr. Vholes.

He (Vholes) stood behind me with his (Vholes) long black figure reaching nearly to the ceiling of those low rooms, feeling the pimples on his (Vholes) face as if they were ornaments and speaking inwardly and evenly as though there were not a human passion or emotion in his (Vholes) nature.

``Mr. Woodcourt is in attendance upon Mr. C., I believe?'' (he)
he (Vholes) resumed.

``Mr. Woodcourt is his (Woodcourt) disinterested friend,'' (I)
I answered.

``But I mean in professional attendance, medical attendance.'' (unknown)

``That can do little for an unhappy mind,'' (I.)
said I.

``Just so,'' (I.)
said Mr. Vholes.

So slow, so eager, so bloodless and gaunt, I felt as if Richard were wasting away beneath the eyes of this adviser and there were something of the vampire in him (Richard).

``Miss Summerson,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
said Mr. Vholes, very slowly rubbing his (Vholes) gloved hands, as if, to his (Vholes) cold sense of touch, they were much the same in black kid or out of it,
``this was an ill-advised marriage of Mr. C.'s.'' (kid)

I begged he (Vholes) would excuse me from discussing it. They had been engaged when they were both very young, I told him (Vholes) -LRB-a little indignantly-RRB- and when the prospect before them was much fairer and brighter. When Richard had not yielded himself to the unhappy influence which now darkened his (Richard) life.

``Just so,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
assented Mr. Vholes again. ``Still, with a view to everything being openly carried on, I will, with your permission, Miss Summerson, observe to you that I consider this a very ill-advised marriage indeed. I owe the opinion not only to Mr. C.
``s connexions, against whom I should naturally wish to protect myself, but also to my own reputation--dear to myself as a professional man aiming to keep respectable; dear to my three girls at home, for whom I am striving to realize some little independence; dear, I will even say, to my aged father, whom it is my privilege to support.'' (unknown)

``It would become a very different marriage, a much happier and better marriage, another marriage altogether, Mr. Vholes,'' (I)
said I,
``if Richard were persuaded to turn his (Richard) back on the fatal pursuit in which you are engaged with him (Richard).'' (I)

Mr. Vholes, with a noiseless cough--or rather gasp--into one of his (Vholes) black gloves, inclined his (Vholes) head as if he (Vholes) did not wholly dispute even that.

``Miss Summerson,'' (he)
he (Vholes) said, ``it may be so; and I freely admit that the young lady who has taken Mr. C.``s name upon herself in so ill-advised a manner--you will I am sure not quarrel with me for throwing out that remark again, as a duty I owe to Mr. C.``s connexions--is a highly genteel young lady. Business has prevented me from mixing much with general society in any but a professional character; still I trust I am competent to perceive that she (lady) is a highly genteel young lady. As to beauty, I am not a judge of that myself, and I never did give much attention to it from a boy, but I dare say the young lady is equally eligible in that point of view. She (lady) is considered so -LRB-I have heard-RRB- among the clerks in the Inn, and it is a point more in their way than in mine. In reference to Mr. C.
``s pursuit of his (C.) interests--'' (unknown)

``Oh! His (C.) interests, Mr. Vholes!'' (unknown)

``Pardon me,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
returned Mr. Vholes, going on in exactly the same inward and dispassionate manner. ``Mr. C. takes certain interests under certain wills disputed in the suit. It is a term we use. In reference to Mr. C,``s pursuit of his (Mr.) interests, I mentioned to you, Miss Summerson, the first time I had the pleasure of seeing you, in my desire that everything should be openly carried on--I used those words, for I happened afterwards to note them in my diary, which is producible at any time--I mentioned to you that Mr. C. had laid down the principle of watching his (C.) own interests, and that when a client of mine laid down a principle which was not of an immoral -LRB-that is to say, unlawful-RRB- nature, it devolved upon me to carry it out. I HAVE carried it out; I do carry it out. But I will not smooth things over to any connexion of Mr. C.``s on any account. As open as I was to Mr. Jarndyce, I am to you. I regard it in the light of a professional duty to be so, though it can be charged to no one. I openly say, unpalatable as it may be, that I consider Mr. C.
``s affairs in a very bad way, that I consider Mr. C. himself in a very bad way, and that I regard this as an exceedingly ill-advised marriage. Am I here, sir? Yes, I thank you; I am here, Mr. C., and enjoying the pleasure of some agreeable conversation with Miss Summerson, for which I have to thank you very much, sir!'' (He)

He (Vholes) broke off thus in answer to Richard, who addressed him (Richard) as he (Richard) came into the room. By this time I too well understood Mr. Vholes's scrupulous way of saving himself and his (Vholes) respectability not to feel that our worst fears did but keep pace with his (Vholes) client's progress.

We sat down to dinner, and I had an opportunity of observing Richard, anxiously. I was not disturbed by Mr. Vholes -LRB-who took off his (Vholes) gloves to dine-RRB-, though he (Vholes) sat opposite to me at the small table, for I doubt if, looking up at all, he (Vholes) once removed his (Vholes) eyes from his (Vholes) host's face. I found Richard thin and languid, slovenly in his (Richard) dress, abstracted in his (Richard) manner, forcing his (Richard) spirits now and then, and at other intervals relapsing into a dull thoughtfulness. About his (Richard) large bright eyes that used to be so merry there was a wanness and a restlessness that changed them altogether. I cannot use the expression that he (Richard) looked old. There is a ruin of youth which is not like age, and into such a ruin Richard's youth and youthful beauty had all fallen away.

He (Richard) ate little and seemed indifferent what it was, showed himself to be much more impatient than he (Richard) used to be, and was quick even with Ada. I thought at first that his (Richard) old light-hearted manner was all gone, but it shone out of him (Richard) sometimes as I had occasionally known little momentary glimpses of my own old face to look out upon me from the glass. His (Richard) laugh had not quite left him (Richard) either, but it was like the echo of a joyful sound, and that is always sorrowful.

Yet he (Richard) was as glad as ever, in his (Richard) old affectionate way, to have me there, and we talked of the old times pleasantly. These did not appear to be interesting to Mr. Vholes, though he (Vholes) occasionally made a gasp which I believe was his (Vholes) smile. He (Vholes) rose shortly after dinner and said that with the permission of the ladies he (Vholes) would retire to his (Vholes) office.

``Always devoted to business, Vholes!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
cried Richard.

``Yes, Mr. C.,'' (he)
he (Richard) returned,
``the interests of clients are never to be neglected, sir. They are paramount in the thoughts of a professional man like myself, who wishes to preserve a good name among his (man) fellow-practitioners and society at large. My denying myself the pleasure of the present agreeable conversation may not be wholly irrespective of your own interests, Mr. C.'' (he)

Richard expressed himself quite sure of that and lighted Mr. Vholes out. On his (Vholes) return he (Vholes) told us, more than once, that Vholes was a good fellow, a safe fellow, a man who did what he (Vholes) pretended to do, a very good fellow indeed! He (Vholes) was so defiant about it that it struck me he (Vholes) had begun to doubt Mr. Vholes.

Then he (Vholes) threw himself on the sofa, tired out; and Ada and I put things to rights, for they had no other servant than the woman who attended to the chambers. My dear girl had a cottage piano there and quietly sat down to sing some of Richard's favourites, the lamp being first removed into the next room, as he (Richard) complained of its hurting his (Richard) eyes.

I sat between them, at my dear girl's side, and felt very melancholy listening to her (girl) sweet voice. I think Richard did too; I think he (Richard) darkened the room for that reason. She (girl) had been singing some time, rising between whiles to bend over him (Richard) and speak to him (Richard), when Mr. Woodcourt came in. Then he (Woodcourt) sat down by Richard and half playfully, half earnestly, quite naturally and easily, found out how he (Richard) felt and where he (Richard) had been all day. Presently he (Richard) proposed to accompany him (Richard) in a short walk on one of the bridges, as it was a moonlight airy night; and Richard readily consenting, they went out together.

They left my dear girl still sitting at the piano and me still sitting beside her (girl). When they were gone out, I drew my arm round her (girl) waist. She (girl) put her (girl) left hand in mine -LRB-I was sitting on that side-RRB-, but kept her (girl) right upon the keys, going over and over them without striking any note.

``Esther, my dearest,'' (she)
she (girl) said, breaking silence,
``Richard is never so well and I am never so easy about him (Richard) as when he (Richard) is with Allan Woodcourt. We have to thank you for that.'' (she)

I pointed out to my darling how this could scarcely be, because Mr. Woodcourt had come to her (girl) cousin John's house and had known us all there, and because he (Woodcourt) had always liked Richard, and Richard had always liked him (Richard), and--and so forth.

``All true,'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)
said Ada,
``but that he (Richard) is such a devoted friend to us we owe to you.'' (Ada/Miss Clare/Clare)

I thought it best to let my dear girl have her (girl) way and to say no more about it. So I said as much. I said it lightly, because I felt her (girl) trembling.

``Esther, my dearest, I want to be a good wife, a very, very good wife indeed. You shall teach me.'' (I)

I teach! I said no more, for I noticed the hand that was fluttering over the keys, and I knew that it was not I who ought to speak, that it was she (girl) who had something to say to me.

``When I married Richard I was not insensible to what was before him (I). I had been perfectly happy for a long time with you, and I had never known any trouble or anxiety, so loved and cared for, but I understood the danger he (I) was in, dear Esther.'' (unknown)

``I know, I know, my darling.'' (unknown)

``When we were married I had some little hope that I might be able to convince him (I) of his (I) mistake, that he (I) might come to regard it in a new way as my husband and not pursue it all the more desperately for my sake--as he (I) does. But if I had not had that hope, I would have married him (I) just the same, Esther. Just the same!'' (I)

In the momentary firmness of the hand that was never still--a firmness inspired by the utterance of these last words, and dying away with them--I saw the confirmation of her (girl) earnest tones.

``You are not to think, my dearest Esther, that I fail to see what you see and fear what you fear. No one can understand him (I) better than I do. The greatest wisdom that ever lived in the world could scarcely know Richard better than my love does.'' (She)

She (girl) spoke so modestly and softly and her (girl) trembling hand expressed such agitation as it moved to and fro upon the silent notes! My dear, dear girl!

``I see him (Richard) at his (Richard) worst every day. I watch him (Richard) in his (Richard) sleep. I know every change of his (Richard) face. But when I married Richard I was quite determined, Esther, if heaven would help me, never to show him (I) that I grieved for what he (I) did and so to make him (I) more unhappy. I want him (I), when he (I) comes home, to find no trouble in my face. I want him (I), when he (I) looks at me, to see what he (I) loved in me. I married him (I) to do this, and this supports me.'' (I)

I felt her (girl) trembling more. I waited for what was yet to come, and I now thought I began to know what it was.

``And something else supports me, Esther.'' (She)

She (girl) stopped a minute. Stopped speaking only; her (girl) hand was still in motion.

``I look forward a little while, and I don't know what great aid may come to me. When Richard turns his (Richard) eyes upon me then, there may be something lying on my breast more eloquent than I have been, with greater power than mine to show him (Richard) his (Richard) true course and win him (Richard) back.'' (unknown)

Her (girl) hand stopped now. She (girl) clasped me in her (girl) arms, and I clasped her (girl) in mine.

``If that little creature should fail too, Esther, I still look forward. I look forward a long while, through years and years, and think that then, when I am growing old, or when I am dead perhaps, a beautiful woman, his (Richard) daughter, happily married, may be proud of him (Richard) and a blessing to him (Richard). Or that a generous brave man, as handsome as he (man) used to be, as hopeful, and far more happy, may walk in the sunshine with him (man), honouring his (man) grey head and saying to himself,

``I thank God this is my father! Ruined by a fatal inheritance, and restored through me!''' (girl)

Oh, my sweet girl, what a heart was that which beat so fast against me!

``These hopes uphold me, my dear Esther, and I know they will. Though sometimes even they depart from me before a dread that arises when I look at Richard.'' (I)

I tried to cheer my darling, and asked her (girl) what it was. Sobbing and weeping, she (girl) replied,

``That he (Richard) may not live to see his (Richard) child.'' (she)

CHAPTER LXI

A Discovery

The days when I frequented that miserable corner which my dear girl brightened can never fade in my remembrance. I never see it, and I never wish to see it now; I have been there only once since, but in my memory there is a mournful glory shining on the place which will shine for ever.

Not a day passed without my going there, of course. At first I found Mr. Skimpole there, on two or three occasions, idly playing the piano and talking in his (Skimpole) usual vivacious strain. Now, besides my very much mistrusting the probability of his (Skimpole) being there without making Richard poorer, I felt as if there were something in his (Richard) careless gaiety too inconsistent with what I knew of the depths of Ada's life. I clearly perceived, too, that Ada shared my feelings. I therefore resolved, after much thinking of it, to make a private visit to Mr. Skimpole and try delicately to explain myself. My dear girl was the great consideration that made me bold.

I set off one morning, accompanied by Charley, for Somers Town. As I approached the house, I was strongly inclined to turn back, for I felt what a desperate attempt it was to make an impression on Mr. Skimpole and how extremely likely it was that he (Skimpole) would signally defeat me. However, I thought that being there, I would go through with it. I knocked with a trembling hand at Mr. Skimpole's door--literally with a hand, for the knocker was gone--and after a long parley gained admission from an Irishwoman, who was in the area when I knocked, breaking up the lid of a water-butt with a poker to light the fire with.

Mr. Skimpole, lying on the sofa in his (Skimpole) room, playing the flute a little, was enchanted to see me. Now, who should receive me, he (Skimpole) asked. Who would I prefer for mistress of the ceremonies? Would I have his (Skimpole) Comedy daughter, his (Skimpole) Beauty daughter, or his (Skimpole) Sentiment daughter? Or would I have all the daughters at once in a perfect nosegay?

I replied, half defeated already, that I wished to speak to himself only if he (Skimpole) would give me leave.

``My dear Miss Summerson, most joyfully! Of course,'' (he)
he (Skimpole) said, bringing his (Skimpole) chair nearer mine and breaking into his (Skimpole) fascinating smile,
``of course it's not business. Then it's pleasure!'' (he)

I said it certainly was not business that I came upon, but it was not quite a pleasant matter.

``Then, my dear Miss Summerson,'' (he)
said he (Skimpole) with the frankest gaiety,
``don't allude to it. Why should you allude to anything that is NOT a pleasant matter? I never do. And you are a much pleasanter creature, in every point of view, than I. You are perfectly pleasant; I am imperfectly pleasant; then, if I never allude to an unpleasant matter, how much less should you! So that's disposed of, and we will talk of something else.'' (he)

Although I was embarrassed, I took courage to intimate that I still wished to pursue the subject.

``I should think it a mistake,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole with his (Skimpole) airy laugh,
``if I thought Miss Summerson capable of making one. But I don't!'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

``Mr. Skimpole,'' (I)
said I, raising my eyes to his (Skimpole),
``I have so often heard you say that you are unacquainted with the common affairs of life--'' (I)

``Meaning our three banking-house friends, L, S, and who's the junior partner? D?'' (I)
said Mr. Skimpole, brightly.
``Not an idea of them!'' (unknown)

''--That perhaps,'' (I)
I went on,
``you will excuse my boldness on that account. I think you ought most seriously to know that Richard is poorer than he (Richard) was.'' (I)

``Dear me!'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole.
``So am I, they tell me.'' (unknown)

``And in very embarrassed circumstances.'' (unknown)

``Parallel case, exactly!'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole with a delighted countenance.

``This at present naturally causes Ada much secret anxiety, and as I think she (Ada) is less anxious when no claims are made upon her (Ada) by visitors, and as Richard has one uneasiness always heavy on his (Richard) mind, it has occurred to me to take the liberty of saying that--if you would--not--'' (I)

I was coming to the point with great difficulty when he (Skimpole) took me by both hands and with a radiant face and in the liveliest way anticipated it.

``Not go there? Certainly not, my dear Miss Summerson, most assuredly not. Why SHOULD I go there? When I go anywhere, I go for pleasure. I don't go anywhere for pain, because I was made for pleasure. Pain comes to ME when it wants me. Now, I have had very little pleasure at our dear Richard's lately, and your practical sagacity demonstrates why. Our young friends, losing the youthful poetry which was once so captivating in them, begin to think, ``This is a man who wants pounds.'' So I am; I always want pounds; not for myself, but because tradespeople always want them of me. Next, our young friends begin to think, becoming mercenary, ``This is the man who HAD pounds, who borrowed them,

'' which I did. I always borrow pounds. So our young friends, reduced to prose -LRB-which is much to be regretted-RRB-, degenerate in their power of imparting pleasure to me. Why should I go to see them, therefore? Absurd!'' (This the man)

Through the beaming smile with which he (our) regarded me as he (our) reasoned thus, there now broke forth a look of disinterested benevolence quite astonishing.

``Besides,'' (he)
he (our) said, pursuing his (our) argument in his (our) tone of light-hearted conviction, ``if I don't go anywhere for pain--which would be a perversion of the intention of my being, and a monstrous thing to do--why should I go anywhere to be the cause of pain?
