If I went to see our young friends in their present ill-regulated state of mind, I should give them pain. The associations with me would be disagreeable. They might say, ``This is the man who had pounds and who can't pay pounds,
'' which I can't, of course; nothing could be more out of the question! Then kindness requires that I shouldn't go near them--and I won't.'' (This the man)

He (our) finished by genially kissing my hand and thanking me. Nothing but Miss Summerson's fine tact, he (our) said, would have found this out for him (our).

I was much disconcerted, but I reflected that if the main point were gained, it mattered little how strangely he (our) perverted everything leading to it. I had determined to mention something else, however, and I thought I was not to be put off in that.

``Mr. Skimpole,'' (I)
said I,
``I must take the liberty of saying before I conclude my visit that I was much surprised to learn, on the best authority, some little time ago, that you knew with whom that poor boy left Bleak House and that you accepted a present on that occasion. I have not mentioned it to my guardian, for I fear it would hurt him (boy) unnecessarily; but I may say to you that I was much surprised.'' (I)

``No? Really surprised, my dear Miss Summerson?'' (he)
he (our) returned inquiringly, raising his (our) pleasant eyebrows.

``Greatly surprised.'' (He)

He (our) thought about it for a little while with a highly agreeable and whimsical expression of face, then quite gave it up and said in his (our) most engaging manner,

``You know what a child I am. Why surprised?'' (He)

I was reluctant to enter minutely into that question, but as he (our) begged I would, for he (our) was really curious to know, I gave him (our) to understand in the gentlest words I could use that his (our) conduct seemed to involve a disregard of several moral obligations. He (our) was much amused and interested when he (our) heard this and said,

``No, really?'' (he)
with ingenuous simplicity.

``You know I don't intend to be responsible. I never could do it. Responsibility is a thing that has always been above me--or below me,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole.
``I don't even know which; but as I understand the way in which my dear Miss Summerson -LRB-always remarkable for her (Summerson) practical good sense and clearness-RRB- puts this case, I should imagine it was chiefly a question of money, do you know?'' (I)

I incautiously gave a qualified assent to this.

``Ah! Then you see,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole, shaking his (Skimpole) head,
``I am hopeless of understanding it.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

I suggested, as I rose to go, that it was not right to betray my guardian's confidence for a bribe.

``My dear Miss Summerson,'' (he)
he (Skimpole) returned with a candid hilarity that was all his (Skimpole) own,
``I can't be bribed.'' (he)

``Not by Mr. Bucket?'' (I.)
said I.

``No,'' (I.)
said he (Skimpole).
``Not by anybody. I don't attach any value to money. I don't care about it, I don't know about it, I don't want it, I don't keep it--it goes away from me directly. How can I be bribed?'' (I)

I showed that I was of a different opinion, though I had not the capacity for arguing the question.

``On the contrary,'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)
said Mr. Skimpole,
``I am exactly the man to be placed in a superior position in such a case as that. I am above the rest of mankind in such a case as that. I can act with philosophy in such a case as that. I am not warped by prejudices, as an Italian baby is by bandages. I am as free as the air. I feel myself as far above suspicion as Caesar's wife.'' (Mr. Skimpole/Skimpole/Harold Skimpole)

Anything to equal the lightness of his (Skimpole) manner and the playful impartiality with which he (Skimpole) seemed to convince himself, as he (Skimpole) tossed the matter about like a ball of feathers, was surely never seen in anybody else!

``Observe the case, my dear Miss Summerson. Here is a boy received into the house and put to bed in a state that I strongly object to. The boy being in bed, a man arrives--like the house that Jack built. Here is the man who demands the boy who is received into the house and put to bed in a state that I strongly object to. Here is a bank-note produced by the man who demands the boy who is received into the house and put to bed in a state that I strongly object to. Here is the Skimpole who accepts the bank-note produced by the man who demands the boy who is received into the house and put to bed in a state that I strongly object to. Those are the facts. Very well. Should the Skimpole have refused the note? WHY should the Skimpole have refused the note? Skimpole protests to Bucket, ``What's this for? I don't understand it, it is of no use to me, take it away.

'' Bucket still entreats Skimpole to accept it. Are there reasons why Skimpole, not being warped by prejudices, should accept it? Yes. Skimpole perceives them. What are they? Skimpole reasons with himself, this is a tamed lynx, an active police-officer, an intelligent man, a person of a peculiarly directed energy and great subtlety both of conception and execution, who discovers our friends and enemies for us when they run away, recovers our property for us when we are robbed, avenges us comfortably when we are murdered. This active police-officer and intelligent man has acquired, in the exercise of his (man) art, a strong faith in money; he (man) finds it very useful to him (man), and he (man) makes it very useful to society. Shall I shake that faith in Bucket because I want it myself; shall I deliberately blunt one of Bucket's weapons; shall I positively paralyse Bucket in his (man) next detective operation? And again. If it is blameable in Skimpole to take the note, it is blameable in Bucket to offer the note--much more blameable in Bucket, because he (man) is the knowing man. Now, Skimpole wishes to think well of Bucket; Skimpole deems it essential, in its little place, to the general cohesion of things, that he (Skimpole) SHOULD think well of Bucket. The state expressly asks him (Skimpole) to trust to Bucket. And he (Skimpole) does. And that's all he (Skimpole) does!'' (me)

I had nothing to offer in reply to this exposition and therefore took my leave. Mr. Skimpole, however, who was in excellent spirits, would not hear of my returning home attended only by

``Little Coavinses,'' (spirits)
and accompanied me himself. He (Skimpole) entertained me on the way with a variety of delightful conversation and assured me, at parting, that he (Skimpole) should never forget the fine tact with which I had found that out for him (Skimpole) about our young friends.

As it so happened that I never saw Mr. Skimpole again, I may at once finish what I know of his (Skimpole) history. A coolness arose between him (Skimpole) and my guardian, based principally on the foregoing grounds and on his (Skimpole) having heartlessly disregarded my guardian's entreaties -LRB-as we afterwards learned from Ada-RRB- in reference to Richard. His (Richard) being heavily in my guardian's debt had nothing to do with their separation. He (Richard) died some five years afterwards and left a diary behind him (Richard), with letters and other materials towards his (Richard) life, which was published and which showed him (Richard) to have been the victim of a combination on the part of mankind against an amiable child. It was considered very pleasant reading, but I never read more of it myself than the sentence on which I chanced to light on opening the book. It was this:

``Jarndyce, in common with most other men I have known, is the incarnation of selfishness.'' (I)

And now I come to a part of my story touching myself very nearly indeed, and for which I was quite unprepared when the circumstance occurred. Whatever little lingerings may have now and then revived in my mind associated with my poor old face had only revived as belonging to a part of my life that was gone--gone like my infancy or my childhood. I have suppressed none of my many weaknesses on that subject, but have written them as faithfully as my memory has recalled them. And I hope to do, and mean to do, the same down to the last words of these pages, which I see now not so very far before me.

The months were gliding away, and my dear girl, sustained by the hopes she (girl) had confided in me, was the same beautiful star in the miserable corner. Richard, more worn and haggard, haunted the court day after day, listlessly sat there the whole day long when he (Richard) knew there was no remote chance of the suit being mentioned, and became one of the stock sights of the place. I wonder whether any of the gentlemen remembered him (Richard) as he (Richard) was when he (Richard) first went there.

So completely was he (Richard) absorbed in his (Richard) fixed idea that he (Richard) used to avow in his (Richard) cheerful moments that he (Richard) should never have breathed the fresh air now

``but for Woodcourt.'' (he)
It was only Mr. Woodcourt who could occasionally divert his (Woodcourt) attention for a few hours at a time and rouse him (Woodcourt), even when he (Woodcourt) sunk into a lethargy of mind and body that alarmed us greatly, and the returns of which became more frequent as the months went on. My dear girl was right in saying that he (Woodcourt) only pursued his (Woodcourt) errors the more desperately for her (girl) sake. I have no doubt that his (Woodcourt) desire to retrieve what he (Woodcourt) had lost was rendered the more intense by his (Woodcourt) grief for his (Woodcourt) young wife, and became like the madness of a gamester.

I was there, as I have mentioned, at all hours. When I was there at night, I generally went home with Charley in a coach; sometimes my guardian would meet me in the neighbourhood, and we would walk home together. One evening he (coach) had arranged to meet me at eight o'clock. I could not leave, as I usually did, quite punctually at the time, for I was working for my dear girl and had a few stitches more to do to finish what I was about; but it was within a few minutes of the hour when I bundled up my little work-basket, gave my darling my last kiss for the night, and hurried downstairs. Mr. Woodcourt went with me, as it was dusk.

When we came to the usual place of meeting--it was close by, and Mr. Woodcourt had often accompanied me before--my guardian was not there. We waited half an hour, walking up and down, but there were no signs of him (Woodcourt). We agreed that he (Woodcourt) was either prevented from coming or that he (Woodcourt) had come and gone away, and Mr. Woodcourt proposed to walk home with me.

It was the first walk we had ever taken together, except that very short one to the usual place of meeting. We spoke of Richard and Ada the whole way. I did not thank him (Richard) in words for what he (Richard) had done--my appreciation of it had risen above all words then--but I hoped he (Richard) might not be without some understanding of what I felt so strongly.

Arriving at home and going upstairs, we found that my guardian was out and that Mrs. Woodcourt was out too. We were in the very same room into which I had brought my blushing girl when her (girl) youthful lover, now her (girl) so altered husband, was the choice of her (girl) young heart, the very same room from which my guardian and I had watched them going away through the sunlight in the fresh bloom of their hope and promise.

We were standing by the opened window looking down into the street when Mr. Woodcourt spoke to me. I learned in a moment that he (Woodcourt) loved me. I learned in a moment that my scarred face was all unchanged to him (Woodcourt). I learned in a moment that what I had thought was pity and compassion was devoted, generous, faithful love. Oh, too late to know it now, too late, too late. That was the first ungrateful thought I had. Too late.

``When I returned,'' (he)
he (Woodcourt) told me,
``when I came back, no richer than when I went away, and found you newly risen from a sick bed, yet so inspired by sweet consideration for others and so free from a selfish thought--'' (me)

``Oh, Mr. Woodcourt, forbear, forbear!'' (me)
I entreated him (Woodcourt).
``I do not deserve your high praise. I had many selfish thoughts at that time, many!'' (unknown)

``Heaven knows, beloved of my life,'' (he)
said he (Woodcourt),
``that my praise is not a lover's praise, but the truth. You do not know what all around you see in Esther Summerson, how many hearts she (Summerson) touches and awakens, what sacred admiration and what love she (Summerson) wins.'' (he)

``Oh, Mr. Woodcourt,'' (I)
cried I,
``it is a great thing to win love, it is a great thing to win love! I am proud of it, and honoured by it; and the hearing of it causes me to shed these tears of mingled joy and sorrow--joy that I have won it, sorrow that I have not deserved it better; but I am not free to think of yours.'' (I)

I said it with a stronger heart, for when he (Woodcourt) praised me thus and when I heard his (Woodcourt) voice thrill with his (Woodcourt) belief that what he (Woodcourt) said was true, I aspired to be more worthy of it. It was not too late for that. Although I closed this unforeseen page in my life to-night, I could be worthier of it all through my life. And it was a comfort to me, and an impulse to me, and I felt a dignity rise up within me that was derived from him (Woodcourt) when I thought so.

He (Woodcourt) broke the silence.

``I should poorly show the trust that I have in the dear one who will evermore be as dear to me as now'' (he)
--and the deep earnestness with which he (Woodcourt) said it at once strengthened me and made me weep--
``if, after her (it) assurance that she (it) is not free to think of my love, I urged it. Dear Esther, let me only tell you that the fond idea of you which I took abroad was exalted to the heavens when I came home. I have always hoped, in the first hour when I seemed to stand in any ray of good fortune, to tell you this. I have always feared that I should tell it you in vain. My hopes and fears are both fulfilled to-night. I distress you. I have said enough.'' (me)

Something seemed to pass into my place that was like the angel he (angel) thought me, and I felt so sorrowful for the loss he (angel) had sustained! I wished to help him (angel) in his (angel) trouble, as I had wished to do when he (angel) showed that first commiseration for me.

``Dear Mr. Woodcourt,'' (I)
said I,
``before we part to-night, something is left for me to say. I never could say it as I wish--I never shall--but--'' (I)

I had to think again of being more deserving of his (angel) love and his (angel) affliction before I could go on.

''--I am deeply sensible of your generosity, and I shall treasure its remembrance to my dying hour. I know full well how changed I am, I know you are not unacquainted with my history, and I know what a noble love that is which is so faithful. What you have said to me could have affected me so much from no other lips, for there are none that could give it such a value to me. It shall not be lost. It shall make me better.'' (I)

He (my) covered his (my) eyes with his (my) hand and turned away his (my) head. How could I ever be worthy of those tears?

``If, in the unchanged intercourse we shall have together--in tending Richard and Ada, and I hope in many happier scenes of life--you ever find anything in me which you can honestly think is better than it used to be, believe that it will have sprung up from to-night and that I shall owe it to you. And never believe, dear dear Mr. Woodcourt, never believe that I forget this night or that while my heart beats it can be insensible to the pride and joy of having been beloved by you.'' (He)

He (my) took my hand and kissed it. He (my) was like himself again, and I felt still more encouraged.

``I am induced by what you said just now,'' (I)
said I,
``to hope that you have succeeded in your endeavour.'' (I)

``I have,'' (he)
he (my) answered.
``With such help from Mr. Jarndyce as you who know him (Jarndyce) so well can imagine him (Jarndyce) to have rendered me, I have succeeded.'' (unknown)

``Heaven bless him (Jarndyce) for it,'' (I)
said I, giving him (my) my hand;
``and heaven bless you in all you do!'' (him)

``I shall do it better for the wish,'' (he)
he (my) answered;
``it will make me enter on these new duties as on another sacred trust from you.'' (he)

``Ah! Richard!'' (I)
I exclaimed involuntarily,
``What will he (Richard) do when you are gone!'' (I)

``I am not required to go yet; I would not desert him (Richard), dear Miss Summerson, even if I were.'' (I)

One other thing I felt it needful to touch upon before he (my) left me. I knew that I should not be worthier of the love I could not take if I reserved it.

``Mr. Woodcourt,'' (I)
said I,
``you will be glad to know from my lips before I say good night that in the future, which is clear and bright before me, I am most happy, most fortunate, have nothing to regret or desire.'' (I)

It was indeed a glad hearing to him (my), he (my) replied.

``From my childhood I have been,'' (I)
said I,
``the object of the untiring goodness of the best of human beings, to whom I am so bound by every tie of attachment, gratitude, and love, that nothing I could do in the compass of a life could express the feelings of a single day.'' (I)

``I share those feelings,'' (he)
he (my) returned.
``You speak of Mr. Jarndyce.'' (unknown)

``You know his (Jarndyce) virtues well,'' (I)
said I,
``but few can know the greatness of his (Jarndyce) character as I know it. All its highest and best qualities have been revealed to me in nothing more brightly than in the shaping out of that future in which I am so happy. And if your highest homage and respect had not been his (Jarndyce) already--which I know they are--they would have been his (Jarndyce), I think, on this assurance and in the feeling it would have awakened in you towards him (Jarndyce) for my sake.'' (I)

He (my) fervently replied that indeed indeed they would have been. I gave him (my) my hand again.

``Good night,'' (I)
I said,
``Good-bye.'' (I)

``The first until we meet to-morrow, the second as a farewell to this theme between us for ever.'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``Good night; good-bye.'' (He)

He (my) left me, and I stood at the dark window watching the street. His (my) love, in all its constancy and generosity, had come so suddenly upon me that he (my) had not left me a minute when my fortitude gave way again and the street was blotted out by my rushing tears.

But they were not tears of regret and sorrow. No. He (my) had called me the beloved of his (my) life and had said I would be evermore as dear to him (my) as I was then, and I felt as if my heart would not hold the triumph of having heard those words. My first wild thought had died away. It was not too late to hear them, for it was not too late to be animated by them to be good, true, grateful, and contented. How easy my path, how much easier than his (my)!

CHAPTER LXII

Another Discovery

I had not the courage to see any one that night. I had not even the courage to see myself, for I was afraid that my tears might a little reproach me. I went up to my room in the dark, and prayed in the dark, and lay down in the dark to sleep. I had no need of any light to read my guardian's letter by, for I knew it by heart. I took it from the place where I kept it, and repeated its contents by its own clear light of integrity and love, and went to sleep with it on my pillow.

I was up very early in the morning and called Charley to come for a walk. We bought flowers for the breakfast-table, and came back and arranged them, and were as busy as possible. We were so early that I had a good time still for Charley's lesson before breakfast; Charley -LRB-who was not in the least improved in the old defective article of grammar-RRB- came through it with great applause; and we were altogether very notable. When my guardian appeared he (Charley) said,

``Why, little woman, you look fresher than your flowers!'' (he)
And Mrs. Woodcourt repeated and translated a passage from the Mewlinnwillinwodd expressive of my being like a mountain with the sun upon it.

This was all so pleasant that I hope it made me still more like the mountain than I had been before. After breakfast I waited my opportunity and peeped about a little until I saw my guardian in his (Charley) own room--the room of last night--by himself. Then I made an excuse to go in with my housekeeping keys, shutting the door after me.

``Well, Dame Durden?'' (guardian)
said my guardian; the post had brought him (Charley) several letters, and he (Charley) was writing.
``You want money?'' (unknown)

``No, indeed, I have plenty in hand.'' (unknown)

``There never was such a Dame Durden,'' (guardian)
said my guardian,
``for making money last.'' (guardian)

He (Charley) had laid down his (Charley) pen and leaned back in his (Charley) chair looking at me. I have often spoken of his (Charley) bright face, but I thought I had never seen it look so bright and good. There was a high happiness upon it which made me think,

``He (Durden) has been doing some great kindness this morning.'' (me)

``There never was,'' (guardian)
said my guardian, musing as he (Charley) smiled upon me,
``such a Dame Durden for making money last.'' (me)

He (Charley) had never yet altered his (Charley) old manner. I loved it and him (Charley) so much that when I now went up to him (Charley) and took my usual chair, which was always put at his (Charley) side--for sometimes I read to him (Charley), and sometimes I talked to him (Charley), and sometimes I silently worked by him (Charley)--I hardly liked to disturb it by laying my hand on his (Charley) breast. But I found I did not disturb it at all.

``Dear guardian,'' (I)
said I,
``I want to speak to you. Have I been remiss in anything?'' (I)

``Remiss in anything, my dear!'' (unknown)

``Have I not been what I have meant to be since--I brought the answer to your letter, guardian?'' (unknown)

``You have been everything I could desire, my love.'' (unknown)

``I am very glad indeed to hear that,'' (I)
I returned.
``You know, you said to me, was this the mistress of Bleak House. And I said, yes.'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (guardian)
said my guardian, nodding his (Charley) head. He (Charley) had put his (Charley) arm about me as if there were something to protect me from and looked in my face, smiling.

``Since then,'' (I)
said I,
``we have never spoken on the subject except once.'' (I)

``And then I said Bleak House was thinning fast; and so it was, my dear.'' (unknown)

``And I said,'' (I)
I timidly reminded him (Charley),
``but its mistress remained.'' (him)

He (Charley) still held me in the same protecting manner and with the same bright goodness in his (Charley) face.

``Dear guardian,'' (I)
said I,
``I know how you have felt all that has happened, and how considerate you have been. As so much time has passed, and as you spoke only this morning of my being so well again, perhaps you expect me to renew the subject. Perhaps I ought to do so. I will be the mistress of Bleak House when you please.'' (I)

``See,'' (he)
he (Charley) returned gaily,
``what a sympathy there must be between us! I have had nothing else, poor Rick excepted--it's a large exception--in my mind. When you came in, I was full of it. When shall we give Bleak House its mistress, little woman?'' (he)

``When you please.'' (unknown)

``Next month?'' (unknown)

``Next month, dear guardian.'' (unknown)

``The day on which I take the happiest and best step of my life--the day on which I shall be a man more exulting and more enviable than any other man in the world--the day on which I give Bleak House its little mistress--shall be next month then,'' (guardian)
said my guardian.

I put my arms round his (Charley) neck and kissed him (Charley) just as I had done on the day when I brought my answer.

A servant came to the door to announce Mr. Bucket, which was quite unnecessary, for Mr. Bucket was already looking in over the servant's shoulder.

``Mr. Jarndyce and Miss Summerson,'' (he)
said he (Bucket), rather out of breath,
``with all apologies for intruding, WILL you allow me to order up a person that's on the stairs and that objects to being left there in case of becoming the subject of observations in his (Jarndyce) absence? Thank you. Be so good as chair that there member in this direction, will you?'' (he)
said Mr. Bucket, beckoning over the banisters.

This singular request produced an old man in a black skull-cap, unable to walk, who was carried up by a couple of bearers and deposited in the room near the door. Mr. Bucket immediately got rid of the bearers, mysteriously shut the door, and bolted it.

``Now you see, Mr. Jarndyce,'' (he)
he (Mr.) then began, putting down his (Mr.) hat and opening his (Mr.) subject with a flourish of his (Mr.) well-remembered finger,
``you know me, and Miss Summerson knows me. This gentleman likewise knows me, and his (gentleman) name is Smallweed. The discounting line is his (gentleman) line principally, and he (gentleman)'s what you may call a dealer in bills. That's about what YOU are, you know, ain't you?'' (he)
said Mr. Bucket, stopping a little to address the gentleman in question, who was exceedingly suspicious of him (Mr.).

He (Mr.) seemed about to dispute this designation of himself when he (Mr.) was seized with a violent fit of coughing.

``Now, moral, you know!'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket, improving the accident.
``Don't you contradict when there ain't no occasion, and you won't be took in that way. Now, Mr. Jarndyce, I address myself to you. I've been negotiating with this gentleman on behalf of Sir Leicester Dedlock, Baronet, and one way and another I've been in and out and about his (gentleman) premises a deal. His (gentleman) premises are the premises formerly occupied by Krook, marine store dealer--a relation of this gentleman's that you saw in his (gentleman) lifetime if I don't mistake?'' (guardian)

My guardian replied,

``Yes.'' (guardian)

``Well! You are to understand,'' (Mr. Bucket)
said Mr. Bucket,
``that this gentleman he (gentleman) come into Krook's property, and a good deal of magpie property there was. Vast lots of waste-paper among the rest. Lord bless you, of no use to nobody!'' (Mr. Bucket)

The cunning of Mr. Bucket's eye and the masterly manner in which he (Mr.) contrived, without a look or a word against which his (Mr.) watchful auditor could protest, to let us know that he (Mr.) stated the case according to previous agreement and could say much more of Mr. Smallweed if he (Smallweed) thought it advisable, deprived us of any merit in quite understanding him (Smallweed). His (Smallweed) difficulty was increased by Mr. Smallweed's being deaf as well as suspicious and watching his (Smallweed) face with the closest attention.

``Among them odd heaps of old papers, this gentleman, when he (gentleman) comes into the property, naturally begins to rummage, don't you see?'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket.

``To which? Say that again,'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
cried Mr. Smallweed in a shrill, sharp voice.

``To rummage,'' (Mr.)
repeated Mr. Bucket.
``Being a prudent man and accustomed to take care of your own affairs, you begin to rummage among the papers as you have come into; don't you?'' (unknown)

``Of course I do,'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
cried Mr. Smallweed.

``Of course you do,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket conversationally,
``and much to blame you would be if you didn't. And so you chance to find, you know,'' (Mr.)
Mr. Bucket went on, stooping over him (Mr.) with an air of cheerful raillery which Mr. Smallweed by no means reciprocated,
``and so you chance to find, you know, a paper with the signature of Jarndyce to it. Don't you?'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)

Mr. Smallweed glanced with a troubled eye at us and grudgingly nodded assent.

``And coming to look at that paper at your full leisure and convenience--all in good time, for you're not curious to read it, and why should you be?--what do you find it to be but a will, you see. That's the drollery of it,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket with the same lively air of recalling a joke for the enjoyment of Mr. Smallweed, who still had the same crest-fallen appearance of not enjoying it at all;
``what do you find it to be but a will?'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)

``I don't know that it's good as a will or as anything else,'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
snarled Mr. Smallweed.

Mr. Bucket eyed the old man for a moment--he (Mr.) had slipped and shrunk down in his (Mr.) chair into a mere bundle--as if he (Mr.) were much disposed to pounce upon him (Mr.); nevertheless, he (Mr.) continued to bend over him (Mr.) with the same agreeable air, keeping the corner of one of his (Mr.) eyes upon us.

``Notwithstanding which,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket,
``you get a little doubtful and uncomfortable in your mind about it, having a very tender mind of your own.'' (Mr.)

``Eh? What do you say I have got of my own?'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
asked Mr. Smallweed with his (Mr.) hand to his (Mr.) ear.

``A very tender mind.'' (unknown)

``Ho! Well, go on,'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
said Mr. Smallweed.

``And as you've heard a good deal mentioned regarding a celebrated Chancery will case of the same name, and as you know what a card Krook was for buying all manner of old pieces of furniter, and books, and papers, and what not, and never liking to part with 'em, and always a-going to teach himself to read, you begin to think--and you never was more correct in your born days--

``Ecod, if I don't look about me, I may get into trouble regarding this will.''' (unknown)

``Now, mind how you put it, Bucket,'' (the man)
cried the old man anxiously with his (Smallweed) hand at his (Smallweed) ear.
``Speak up; none of your brimstone tricks. Pick me up; I want to hear better. Oh, Lord, I am shaken to bits!'' (Mr. Bucket)

Mr. Bucket had certainly picked him (Bucket) up at a dart. However, as soon as he (Bucket) could be heard through Mr. Smallweed's coughing and his (Smallweed) vicious ejaculations of

``Oh, my bones! Oh, dear! I've no breath in my body! I'm worse than the chattering, clattering, brimstone pig at home!'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
Mr. Bucket proceeded in the same convivial manner as before.

``So, as I happen to be in the habit of coming about your premises, you take me into your confidence, don't you?'' (I)

I think it would be impossible to make an admission with more ill will and a worse grace than Mr. Smallweed displayed when he (Smallweed) admitted this, rendering it perfectly evident that Mr. Bucket was the very last person he (Bucket) would have thought of taking into his (Bucket) confidence if he (Bucket) could by any possibility have kept him (Bucket) out of it.

``And I go into the business with you--very pleasant we are over it; and I confirm you in your well-founded fears that you will get yourself into a most precious line if you don't come out with that there will,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket emphatically;
``and accordingly you arrange with me that it shall be delivered up to this present Mr. Jarndyce, on no conditions. If it should prove to be valuable, you trusting yourself to him (Jarndyce) for your reward; that's about where it is, ain't it?'' (Mr.)

``That's what was agreed,'' (Mr. Smallweed/Smallweed)
Mr. Smallweed assented with the same bad grace.

``In consequence of which,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket, dismissing his (Mr.) agreeable manner all at once and becoming strictly business-like,
``you've got that will upon your person at the present time, and the only thing that remains for you to do is just to out with it!'' (Mr.)

Having given us one glance out of the watching corner of his (Mr.) eye, and having given his (Mr.) nose one triumphant rub with his (Mr.) forefinger, Mr. Bucket stood with his (Bucket) eyes fastened on his (Bucket) confidential friend and his (Bucket) hand stretched forth ready to take the paper and present it to my guardian. It was not produced without much reluctance and many declarations on the part of Mr. Smallweed that he (Smallweed) was a poor industrious man and that he (Smallweed) left it to Mr. Jarndyce's honour not to let him (Smallweed) lose by his (Smallweed) honesty. Little by little he (Smallweed) very slowly took from a breast-pocket a stained, discoloured paper which was much singed upon the outside and a little burnt at the edges, as if it had long ago been thrown upon a fire and hastily snatched off again. Mr. Bucket lost no time in transferring this paper, with the dexterity of a conjuror, from Mr. Smallweed to Mr. Jarndyce. As he (Jarndyce) gave it to my guardian, he (Jarndyce) whispered behind his (Jarndyce) fingers,

``Hadn't settled how to make their market of it. Quarrelled and hinted about it. I laid out twenty pound upon it. First the avaricious grandchildren split upon him (Jarndyce) on account of their objections to his (Jarndyce) living so unreasonably long, and then they split on one another. Lord! There ain't one of the family that wouldn't sell the other for a pound or two, except the old lady--and she (lady)'s only out of it because she (lady)'s too weak in her (lady) mind to drive a bargain.'' (he)

``Mr Bucket,'' (guardian)
said my guardian aloud,
``whatever the worth of this paper may be to any one, my obligations are great to you; and if it be of any worth, I hold myself bound to see Mr. Smallweed remunerated accordingly.'' (guardian)

``Not according to your merits, you know,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Bucket in friendly explanation to Mr. Smallweed.
``Don't you be afraid of that. According to its value.'' (unknown)

``That is what I mean,'' (guardian)
said my guardian.
``You may observe, Mr. Bucket, that I abstain from examining this paper myself. The plain truth is, I have forsworn and abjured the whole business these many years, and my soul is sick of it. But Miss Summerson and I will immediately place the paper in the hands of my solicitor in the cause, and its existence shall be made known without delay to all other parties interested.'' (unknown)

``Mr. Jarndyce can't say fairer than that, you understand,'' (Mr.)
observed Mr. Bucket to his (Mr.) fellow-visitor.
``And it being now made clear to you that nobody's a-going to be wronged--which must be a great relief to YOUR mind--we may proceed with the ceremony of chairing you home again.'' (He)

He (Mr.) unbolted the door, called in the bearers, wished us good morning, and with a look full of meaning and a crook of his (crook) finger at parting went his (crook) way.

We went our way too, which was to Lincoln's Inn, as quickly as possible. Mr. Kenge was disengaged, and we found him (Kenge) at his (Kenge) table in his (Kenge) dusty room with the inexpressive-looking books and the piles of papers. Chairs having been placed for us by Mr. Guppy, Mr. Kenge expressed the surprise and gratification he (Kenge) felt at the unusual sight of Mr. Jarndyce in his (Jarndyce) office. He (Jarndyce) turned over his (Jarndyce) double eye-glass as he (Jarndyce) spoke and was more Conversation Kenge than ever.

``I hope,'' (Mr. Kenge)
said Mr. Kenge,
``that the genial influence of Miss Summerson,'' (Mr. Kenge)
he (Kenge) bowed to me,
``may have induced Mr. Jarndyce,'' (me)
he (Kenge) bowed to him (Kenge),
``to forego some little of his (Jarndyce) animosity towards a cause and towards a court which are--shall I say, which take their place in the stately vista of the pillars of our profession?'' (him)

``I am inclined to think,'' (guardian)
returned my guardian,
``that Miss Summerson has seen too much of the effects of the court and the cause to exert any influence in their favour. Nevertheless, they are a part of the occasion of my being here. Mr. Kenge, before I lay this paper on your desk and have done with it, let me tell you how it has come into my hands.'' (guardian)

He (Kenge) did so shortly and distinctly.

``It could not, sir,'' (Mr. Kenge)
said Mr. Kenge,
``have been stated more plainly and to the purpose if it had been a case at law.'' (Mr. Kenge)

``Did you ever know English law, or equity either, plain and to the purpose?'' (guardian)
said my guardian.

``Oh, fie!'' (Mr. Kenge)
said Mr. Kenge.

At first he (Kenge) had not seemed to attach much importance to the paper, but when he (Kenge) saw it he (Kenge) appeared more interested, and when he (Kenge) had opened and read a little of it through his (Kenge) eye-glass, he (Kenge) became amazed.

``Mr. Jarndyce,'' (he)
he (Kenge) said, looking off it,
``you have perused this?'' (he)

``Not I!'' (guardian)
returned my guardian.

``But, my dear sir,'' (Mr. Kenge)
said Mr. Kenge,
``it is a will of later date than any in the suit. It appears to be all in the testator's handwriting. It is duly executed and attested. And even if intended to be cancelled, as might possibly be supposed to be denoted by these marks of fire, it is NOT cancelled. Here it is, a perfect instrument!'' (Mr. Kenge)

``Well!'' (guardian)
said my guardian.
``What is that to me?'' (unknown)

``Mr. Guppy!'' (Mr. Kenge)
cried Mr. Kenge, raising his (Kenge) voice.
``I beg your pardon, Mr. Jarndyce.'' (unknown)

``Sir.'' (unknown)

``Mr. Vholes of Symond's Inn. My compliments. Jarndyce and Jarndyce. Glad to speak with him (Jarndyce).'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Mr. Guppy disappeared.

``You ask me what is this to you, Mr. Jarndyce. If you had perused this document, you would have seen that it reduces your interest considerably, though still leaving it a very handsome one, still leaving it a very handsome one,'' (Mr. Kenge)
said Mr. Kenge, waving his (Kenge) hand persuasively and blandly.
``You would further have seen that the interests of Mr. Richard Carstone and of Miss Ada Clare, now Mrs. Richard Carstone, are very materially advanced by it.'' (unknown)

``Kenge,'' (guardian)
said my guardian,
``if all the flourishing wealth that the suit brought into this vile court of Chancery could fall to my two young cousins, I should be well contented. But do you ask ME to believe that any good is to come of Jarndyce and Jarndyce?'' (guardian)

``Oh, really, Mr. Jarndyce! Prejudice, prejudice. My dear sir, this is a very great country, a very great country. Its system of equity is a very great system, a very great system. Really, really!'' (guardian)

My guardian said no more, and Mr. Vholes arrived. He (Vholes) was modestly impressed by Mr. Kenge's professional eminence.

``How do you do, Mr. Vholes? Will you be so good as to take a chair here by me and look over this paper?'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)

Mr. Vholes did as he (Vholes) was asked and seemed to read it every word. He (Vholes) was not excited by it, but he (Vholes) was not excited by anything. When he (Vholes) had well examined it, he (Vholes) retired with Mr. Kenge into a window, and shading his (Kenge) mouth with his (Kenge) black glove, spoke to him (Kenge) at some length. I was not surprised to observe Mr. Kenge inclined to dispute what he (Kenge) said before he (Kenge) had said much, for I knew that no two people ever did agree about anything in Jarndyce and Jarndyce. But he (Jarndyce) seemed to get the better of Mr. Kenge too in a conversation that sounded as if it were almost composed of the words

``Receiver-General,'' (Mr. Kenge)
``Accountant-General,'' (Mr. Kenge)
``report,'' (Mr. Kenge)
``estate,'' (Mr. Kenge)
and
``costs.'' (Mr. Kenge)
When they had finished, they came back to Mr. Kenge's table and spoke aloud.

``Well! But this is a very remarkable document, Mr. Vholes,'' (Mr. Kenge)
said Mr. Kenge.

Mr. Vholes said,

``Very much so.'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)

``And a very important document, Mr. Vholes,'' (Mr. Kenge)
said Mr. Kenge.

Again Mr. Vholes said,

``Very much so.'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)

``And as you say, Mr. Vholes, when the cause is in the paper next term, this document will be an unexpected and interesting feature in it,'' (Mr. Kenge)
said Mr. Kenge, looking loftily at my guardian.

Mr. Vholes was gratified, as a smaller practitioner striving to keep respectable, to be confirmed in any opinion of his (Vholes) own by such an authority.

``And when,'' (guardian)
asked my guardian, rising after a pause, during which Mr. Kenge had rattled his (Kenge) money and Mr. Vholes had picked his (Vholes) pimples,
``when is next term?'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)

``Next term, Mr. Jarndyce, will be next month,'' (Mr. Kenge)
said Mr. Kenge.
``Of course we shall at once proceed to do what is necessary with this document and to collect the necessary evidence concerning it; and of course you will receive our usual notification of the cause being in the paper.'' (unknown)

``To which I shall pay, of course, my usual attention.'' (unknown)

``Still bent, my dear sir,'' (Mr. Kenge)
said Mr. Kenge, showing us through the outer office to the door,
``still bent, even with your enlarged mind, on echoing a popular prejudice? We are a prosperous community, Mr. Jarndyce, a very prosperous community. We are a great country, Mr. Jarndyce, we are a very great country. This is a great system, Mr. Jarndyce, and would you wish a great country to have a little system? Now, really, really!'' (Mr. Kenge)

He (Kenge) said this at the stair-head, gently moving his (Kenge) right hand as if it were a silver trowel with which to spread the cement of his (Kenge) words on the structure of the system and consolidate it for a thousand ages.

CHAPTER LXIII

Steel and Iron

George's Shooting Gallery is to let, and the stock is sold off, and George himself is at Chesney Wold attending on Sir Leicester in his (George) rides and riding very near his (George) bridle-rein because of the uncertain hand with which he (George) guides his (George) horse. But not to-day is George so occupied. He (George) is journeying to-day into the iron country farther north to look about him (George).

As he (George) comes into the iron country farther north, such fresh green woods as those of Chesney Wold are left behind; and coal pits and ashes, high chimneys and red bricks, blighted verdure, scorching fires, and a heavy never-lightening cloud of smoke become the features of the scenery. Among such objects rides the trooper, looking about him (trooper) and always looking for something he (trooper) has come to find.

At last, on the black canal bridge of a busy town, with a clang of iron in it, and more fires and more smoke than he (trooper) has seen yet, the trooper, swart with the dust of the coal roads, checks his (trooper) horse and asks a workman does he (trooper) know the name of Rouncewell thereabouts.

``Why, master,'' (the workman)
quoth the workman,
``do I know my own name?'' (the workman)

''`Tis so well known here, is it, comrade?'' (the workman)
asks the trooper.

``Rouncewell's? Ah! You're right.'' (unknown)

``And where might it be now?'' (the trooper)
asks the trooper with a glance before him (trooper).

``The bank, the factory, or the house?'' (the workman)
the workman wants to know.

``Hum! Rouncewell's is so great apparently,'' (mutters the trooper)
mutters the trooper, stroking his (trooper) chin,
``that I have as good as half a mind to go back again. Why, I don't know which I want. Should I find Mr. Rouncewell at the factory, do you think?'' (mutters the trooper)

``Tain't easy to say where you'd find him (Rouncewell)--at this time of the day you might find either him (Rouncewell) or his (Rouncewell) son there, if he (Rouncewell)'s in town; but his (Rouncewell) contracts take him (Rouncewell) away.'' (unknown)

And which is the factory? Why, he (trooper) sees those chimneys--the tallest ones! Yes, he (trooper) sees THEM. Well! Let him (trooper) keep his (trooper) eye on those chimneys, going on as straight as ever he (trooper) can, and presently he (trooper)'ll see 'em down a turning on the left, shut in by a great brick wall which forms one side of the street. That's Rouncewell's.

The trooper thanks his (trooper) informant and rides slowly on, looking about him (trooper). He (trooper) does not turn back, but puts up his (trooper) horse -LRB-and is much disposed to groom him (trooper) too-RRB- at a public-house where some of Rouncewell's hands are dining, as the ostler tells him (ostler). Some of Rouncewell's hands have just knocked off for dinner-time and seem to be invading the whole town. They are very sinewy and strong, are Rouncewell's hands--a little sooty too.

He (ostler) comes to a gateway in the brick wall, looks in, and sees a great perplexity of iron lying about in every stage and in a vast variety of shapes--in bars, in wedges, in sheets; in tanks, in boilers, in axles, in wheels, in cogs, in cranks, in rails; twisted and wrenched into eccentric and perverse forms as separate parts of machinery; mountains of it broken up, and rusty in its age; distant furnaces of it glowing and bubbling in its youth; bright fireworks of it showering about under the blows of the steam-hammer; red-hot iron, white-hot iron, cold-black iron; an iron taste, an iron smell, and a Babel of iron sounds.

``This is a place to make a man's head ache too!'' (the trooper)
says the trooper, looking about him (trooper) for a counting-house.
``Who comes here? This is very like me before I was set up. This ought to be my nephew, if likenesses run in families. Your servant, sir.'' (unknown)

``Yours, sir. Are you looking for any one?'' (unknown)

``Excuse me. Young Mr. Rouncewell, I believe?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``I was looking for your father, sir. I wish to have a word with him (Rouncewell).'' (The man)

The young man, telling him (man) he (man) is fortunate in his (man) choice of a time, for his (man) father is there, leads the way to the office where he (man) is to be found.

``Very like me before I was set up--devilish like me!'' (the trooper)
thinks the trooper as he (man) follows. They come to a building in the yard with an office on an upper floor. At sight of the gentleman in the office, Mr. George turns very red.

``What name shall I say to my father?'' (the man)
asks the young man.

George, full of the idea of iron, in desperation answers

``Steel,'' (Mr. George/George)
and is so presented. He (George) is left alone with the gentleman in the office, who sits at a table with account-books before him (George) and some sheets of paper blotted with hosts of figures and drawings of cunning shapes. It is a bare office, with bare windows, looking on the iron view below. Tumbled together on the table are some pieces of iron, purposely broken to be tested at various periods of their service, in various capacities. There is iron-dust on everything; and the smoke is seen through the windows rolling heavily out of the tall chimneys to mingle with the smoke from a vaporous Babylon of other chimneys.

``I am at your service, Mr. Steel,'' (the gentleman)
says the gentleman when his (gentleman) visitor has taken a rusty chair.

``Well, Mr. Rouncewell,'' (Mr. George/George)
George replies, leaning forward with his (George) left arm on his (George) knee and his (George) hat in his (George) hand, and very chary of meeting his (George) brother's eye,
``I am not without my expectations that in the present visit I may prove to be more free than welcome. I have served as a dragoon in my day, and a comrade of mine that I was once rather partial to was, if I don't deceive myself, a brother of yours. I believe you had a brother who gave his (brother) family some trouble, and ran away, and never did any good but in keeping away?'' (brother)

``Are you quite sure,'' (the ironmaster)
returns the ironmaster in an altered voice,
``that your name is Steel?'' (the ironmaster)

The trooper falters and looks at him (trooper). His (trooper) brother starts up, calls him (trooper) by his (trooper) name, and grasps him (trooper) by both hands.

``You are too quick for me!'' (the trooper)
cries the trooper with the tears springing out of his (trooper) eyes.
``How do you do, my dear old fellow? I never could have thought you would have been half so glad to see me as all this. How do you do, my dear old fellow, how do you do!'' (the trooper coupling fellow)

They shake hands and embrace each other over and over again, the trooper still coupling his (trooper)

``How do you do, my dear old fellow!'' (the trooper coupling fellow)
with his (trooper) protestation that he (trooper) never thought his (trooper) brother would have been half so glad to see him (trooper) as all this!

``So far from it,'' (he)
he (trooper) declares at the end of a full account of what has preceded his (trooper) arrival there,
``I had very little idea of making myself known. I thought if you took by any means forgivingly to my name I might gradually get myself up to the point of writing a letter. But I should not have been surprised, brother, if you had considered it anything but welcome news to hear of me.'' (he)

``We will show you at home what kind of news we think it, George,'' (brother)
returns his (trooper) brother.
``This is a great day at home, and you could not have arrived, you bronzed old soldier, on a better. I make an agreement with my son Watt to-day that on this day twelvemonth he (Watt) shall marry as pretty and as good a girl as you have seen in all your travels. She (girl) goes to Germany to-morrow with one of your nieces for a little polishing up in her (girl) education. We make a feast of the event, and you will be made the hero of it.'' (Mr. George/George)

Mr. George is so entirely overcome at first by this prospect that he (George) resists the proposed honour with great earnestness. Being overborne, however, by his (George) brother and his (George) nephew--concerning whom he (George) renews his (George) protestations that he (George) never could have thought they would have been half so glad to see him (George)--he (George) is taken home to an elegant house in all the arrangements of which there is to be observed a pleasant mixture of the originally simple habits of the father and mother with such as are suited to their altered station and the higher fortunes of their children. Here Mr. George is much dismayed by the graces and accomplishments of his (George) nieces that are and by the beauty of Rosa, his (Rosa) niece that is to be, and by the affectionate salutations of these young ladies, which he (Rosa) receives in a sort of dream. He (Rosa) is sorely taken aback, too, by the dutiful behaviour of his (Rosa) nephew and has a woeful consciousness upon him (Rosa) of being a scapegrace. However, there is great rejoicing and a very hearty company and infinite enjoyment, and Mr. George comes bluff and martial through it all, and his (George) pledge to be present at the marriage and give away the bride is received with universal favour. A whirling head has Mr. George that night when he (George) lies down in the state-bed of his (George) brother's house to think of all these things and to see the images of his (George) nieces -LRB-awful all the evening in their floating muslins-RRB- waltzing, after the German manner, over his (George) counterpane.

The brothers are closeted next morning in the ironmaster's room, where the elder is proceeding, in his (George) clear sensible way, to show how he (George) thinks he (George) may best dispose of George in his (George) business, when George squeezes his (George) hand and stops him (George).

``Brother, I thank you a million times for your more than brotherly welcome, and a million times more to that for your more than brotherly intentions. But my plans are made. Before I say a word as to them, I wish to consult you upon one family point. How,'' (the trooper arms)
says the trooper, folding his (George) arms and looking with indomitable firmness at his (George) brother,
``how is my mother to be got to scratch me?'' (brother)

``I am not sure that I understand you, George,'' (the ironmaster)
replies the ironmaster.

``I say, brother, how is my mother to be got to scratch me? She (mother) must be got to do it somehow.'' (unknown)

``Scratch you out of her (mother) will, I think you mean?'' (unknown)

``Of course I do. In short,'' (the trooper)
says the trooper, folding his (trooper) arms more resolutely yet,
``I mean--TO--scratch me!'' (the trooper)

``My dear George,'' (brother)
returns his (trooper) brother,
``is it so indispensable that you should undergo that process?'' (brother)

``Quite! Absolutely! I couldn't be guilty of the meanness of coming back without it. I should never be safe not to be off again. I have not sneaked home to rob your children, if not yourself, brother, of your rights. I, who forfeited mine long ago! If I am to remain and hold up my head, I must be scratched. Come. You are a man of celebrated penetration and intelligence, and you can tell me how it's to be brought about.'' (unknown)

``I can tell you, George,'' (the ironmaster)
replies the ironmaster deliberately,
``how it is not to be brought about, which I hope may answer the purpose as well. Look at our mother, think of her (mother), recall her (mother) emotion when she (mother) recovered you. Do you believe there is a consideration in the world that would induce her (mother) to take such a step against her (mother) favourite son? Do you believe there is any chance of her (mother) consent, to balance against the outrage it would be to her (mother) -LRB-loving dear old lady!-RRB- to propose it? If you do, you are wrong. No, George! You must make up your mind to remain UNscratched, I think.'' (the ironmaster)
There is an amused smile on the ironmaster's face as he (trooper) watches his (trooper) brother, who is pondering, deeply disappointed.
``I think you may manage almost as well as if the thing were done, though.'' (unknown)

``How, brother?'' (unknown)

``Being bent upon it, you can dispose by will of anything you have the misfortune to inherit in any way you like, you know.'' (unknown)

``That's true!'' (the trooper)
says the trooper, pondering again. Then he (trooper) wistfully asks, with his (trooper) hand on his (trooper) brother's,
``Would you mind mentioning that, brother, to your wife and family?'' (brother)

``Not at all.'' (unknown)

``Thank you. You wouldn't object to say, perhaps, that although an undoubted vagabond, I am a vagabond of the harum-scarum order, and not of the mean sort?'' (The ironmaster)

The ironmaster, repressing his (trooper) amused smile, assents.

``Thank you. Thank you. It's a weight off my mind,'' (the trooper)
says the trooper with a heave of his (trooper) chest as he (trooper) unfolds his (trooper) arms and puts a hand on each leg,
``though I had set my heart on being scratched, too!'' (he)

The brothers are very like each other, sitting face to face; but a certain massive simplicity and absence of usage in the ways of the world is all on the trooper's side.

``Well,'' (he)
he (trooper) proceeds, throwing off his (trooper) disappointment,
``next and last, those plans of mine. You have been so brotherly as to propose to me to fall in here and take my place among the products of your perseverance and sense. I thank you heartily. It's more than brotherly, as I said before, and I thank you heartily for it,'' (he)
shaking him (trooper) a long time by the hand.
``But the truth is, brother, I am a--I am a kind of a weed, and it's too late to plant me in a regular garden.'' (unknown)

``My dear George,'' (him)
returns the elder, concentrating his (trooper) strong steady brow upon him (trooper) and smiling confidently,
``leave that to me, and let me try.'' (him)

George shakes his (George) head.

``You could do it, I have not a doubt, if anybody could; but it's not to be done. Not to be done, sir! Whereas it so falls out, on the other hand, that I am able to be of some trifle of use to Sir Leicester Dedlock since his (George) illness--brought on by family sorrows--and that he (George) would rather have that help from our mother's son than from anybody else.'' (unknown)

``Well, my dear George,'' (the trooper)
returns the other with a very slight shade upon his (George) open face,
``if you prefer to serve in Sir Leicester Dedlock's household brigade--'' (the trooper)

``There it is, brother,'' (the trooper)
cries the trooper, checking him (George), with his (George) hand upon his (George) knee again;
``there it is! You don't take kindly to that idea; I don't mind it. You are not used to being officered; I am. Everything about you is in perfect order and discipline; everything about me requires to be kept so. We are not accustomed to carry things with the same hand or to look at 'em from the same point. I don't say much about my garrison manners because I found myself pretty well at my ease last night, and they wouldn't be noticed here, I dare say, once and away. But I shall get on best at Chesney Wold, where there's more room for a weed than there is here; and the dear old lady will be made happy besides. Therefore I accept of Sir Leicester Dedlock's proposals. When I come over next year to give away the bride, or whenever I come, I shall have the sense to keep the household brigade in ambuscade and not to manoeuvre it on your ground. I thank you heartily again and am proud to think of the Rouncewells as they'll be founded by you.'' (him)

``You know yourself, George,'' (the brother)
says the elder brother, returning the grip of his (brother) hand,
``and perhaps you know me better than I know myself. Take your way. So that we don't quite lose one another again, take your way.'' (the brother)

``No fear of that!'' (returns the trooper)
returns the trooper.
``Now, before I turn my horse's head homewards, brother, I will ask you--if you'll be so good--to look over a letter for me. I brought it with me to send from these parts, as Chesney Wold might be a painful name just now to the person it's written to. I am not much accustomed to correspondence myself, and I am particular respecting this present letter because I want it to be both straightforward and delicate.'' (he)

Herewith he (brother) hands a letter, closely written in somewhat pale ink but in a neat round hand, to the ironmaster, who reads as follows:

Miss Esther Summerson,

A communication having been made to me by Inspector Bucket of a letter to myself being found among the papers of a certain person, I take the liberty to make known to you that it was but a few lines of instruction from abroad, when, where, and how to deliver an enclosed letter to a young and beautiful lady, then unmarried, in England. I duly observed the same.

I further take the liberty to make known to you that it was got from me as a proof of handwriting only and that otherwise I would not have given it up, as appearing to be the most harmless in my possession, without being previously shot through the heart.

I further take the liberty to mention that if I could have supposed a certain unfortunate gentleman to have been in existence, I never could and never would have rested until I had discovered his (gentleman) retreat and shared my last farthing with him (gentleman), as my duty and my inclination would have equally been. But he (gentleman) was -LRB-officially-RRB- reported drowned, and assuredly went over the side of a transport-ship at night in an Irish harbour within a few hours of her (I) arrival from the West Indies, as I have myself heard both from officers and men on board, and know to have been -LRB-officially-RRB- confirmed.

I further take the liberty to state that in my humble quality as one of the rank and file, I am, and shall ever continue to be, your thoroughly devoted and admiring servant and that I esteem the qualities you possess above all others far beyond the limits of the present dispatch.

I have the honour to be,

GEORGE

``A little formal,'' (I)
observes the elder brother, refolding it with a puzzled face.

``But nothing that might not be sent to a pattern young lady?'' (unknown)
asks the younger.

``Nothing at all.'' (unknown)

Therefore it is sealed and deposited for posting among the iron correspondence of the day. This done, Mr. George takes a hearty farewell of the family party and prepares to saddle and mount. His (George) brother, however, unwilling to part with him (George) so soon, proposes to ride with him (George) in a light open carriage to the place where he (George) will bait for the night, and there remain with him (George) until morning, a servant riding for so much of the journey on the thoroughbred old grey from Chesney Wold. The offer, being gladly accepted, is followed by a pleasant ride, a pleasant dinner, and a pleasant breakfast, all in brotherly communion. Then they once more shake hands long and heartily and part, the ironmaster turning his (Chesney) face to the smoke and fires, and the trooper to the green country. Early in the afternoon the subdued sound of his (Chesney) heavy military trot is heard on the turf in the avenue as he (Chesney) rides on with imaginary clank and jingle of accoutrements under the old elm-trees.

CHAPTER LXIV

Esther's Narrative

Soon after I had that conversation with my guardian, he (Chesney) put a sealed paper in my hand one morning and said,

``This is for next month, my dear.'' (he)
I found in it two hundred pounds.

I now began very quietly to make such preparations as I thought were necessary. Regulating my purchases by my guardian's taste, which I knew very well of course, I arranged my wardrobe to please him (Chesney) and hoped I should be highly successful. I did it all so quietly because I was not quite free from my old apprehension that Ada would be rather sorry and because my guardian was so quiet himself. I had no doubt that under all the circumstances we should be married in the most private and simple manner. Perhaps I should only have to say to Ada,

``Would you like to come and see me married to-morrow, my pet?'' (Ada)
Perhaps our wedding might even be as unpretending as her (Ada) own, and I might not find it necessary to say anything about it until it was over. I thought that if I were to choose, I would like this best.

The only exception I made was Mrs. Woodcourt. I told her (Woodcourt) that I was going to be married to my guardian and that we had been engaged some time. She (Woodcourt) highly approved. She (Woodcourt) could never do enough for me and was remarkably softened now in comparison with what she (Woodcourt) had been when we first knew her (Woodcourt). There was no trouble she (Woodcourt) would not have taken to have been of use to me, but I need hardly say that I only allowed her (Woodcourt) to take as little as gratified her (Woodcourt) kindness without tasking it.

Of course this was not a time to neglect my guardian, and of course it was not a time for neglecting my darling. So I had plenty of occupation, which I was glad of; and as to Charley, she (Woodcourt) was absolutely not to be seen for needlework. To surround herself with great heaps of it--baskets full and tables full--and do a little, and spend a great deal of time in staring with her (Woodcourt) round eyes at what there was to do, and persuade herself that she (Woodcourt) was going to do it, were Charley's great dignities and delights.

Meanwhile, I must say, I could not agree with my guardian on the subject of the will, and I had some sanguine hopes of Jarndyce and Jarndyce. Which of us was right will soon appear, but I certainly did encourage expectations. In Richard, the discovery gave occasion for a burst of business and agitation that buoyed him (Richard) up for a little time, but he (Richard) had lost the elasticity even of hope now and seemed to me to retain only its feverish anxieties. From something my guardian said one day when we were talking about this, I understood that my marriage would not take place until after the term-time we had been told to look forward to; and I thought the more, for that, how rejoiced I should be if I could be married when Richard and Ada were a little more prosperous.

The term was very near indeed when my guardian was called out of town and went down into Yorkshire on Mr. Woodcourt's business. He (Woodcourt) had told me beforehand that his (Woodcourt) presence there would be necessary. I had just come in one night from my dear girl's and was sitting in the midst of all my new clothes, looking at them all around me and thinking, when a letter from my guardian was brought to me. It asked me to join him (Woodcourt) in the country and mentioned by what stage-coach my place was taken and at what time in the morning I should have to leave town. It added in a postscript that I would not be many hours from Ada.

I expected few things less than a journey at that time, but I was ready for it in half an hour and set off as appointed early next morning. I travelled all day, wondering all day what I could be wanted for at such a distance; now I thought it might be for this purpose, and now I thought it might be for that purpose, but I was never, never, never near the truth.

It was night when I came to my journey's end and found my guardian waiting for me. This was a great relief, for towards evening I had begun to fear -LRB-the more so as his (I) letter was a very short one-RRB- that he (I) might be ill. However, there he (I) was, as well as it was possible to be; and when I saw his (I) genial face again at its brightest and best, I said to myself, he (I) has been doing some other great kindness. Not that it required much penetration to say that, because I knew that his (I) being there at all was an act of kindness.

Supper was ready at the hotel, and when we were alone at table he (I) said,

``Full of curiosity, no doubt, little woman, to know why I have brought you here?'' (he)

``Well, guardian,'' (I)
said I,
``without thinking myself a Fatima or you a Blue Beard, I am a little curious about it.'' (I)

``Then to ensure your night's rest, my love,'' (he)
he (I) returned gaily,
``I won't wait until to-morrow to tell you. I have very much wished to express to Woodcourt, somehow, my sense of his (me) humanity to poor unfortunate Jo, his (me) inestimable services to my young cousins, and his (me) value to us all. When it was decided that he (me) should settle here, it came into my head that I might ask his (me) acceptance of some unpretending and suitable little place to lay his (me) own head in. I therefore caused such a place to be looked out for, and such a place was found on very easy terms, and I have been touching it up for him (me) and making it habitable. However, when I walked over it the day before yesterday and it was reported ready, I found that I was not housekeeper enough to know whether things were all as they ought to be. So I sent off for the best little housekeeper that could possibly be got to come and give me her (housekeeper) advice and opinion. And here she (housekeeper) is,'' (he)
said my guardian,
``laughing and crying both together!'' (guardian)

Because he (I) was so dear, so good, so admirable. I tried to tell him (I) what I thought of him (I), but I could not articulate a word.

``Tut, tut!'' (guardian)
said my guardian.
``You make too much of it, little woman. Why, how you sob, Dame Durden, how you sob!'' (unknown)

``It is with exquisite pleasure, guardian--with a heart full of thanks.'' (unknown)

``Well, well,'' (he)
said he (I).
``I am delighted that you approve. I thought you would. I meant it as a pleasant surprise for the little mistress of Bleak House.'' (I)

I kissed him (I) and dried my eyes.

``I know now!'' (I.)
said I.
``I have seen this in your face a long while.'' (I.)

``No; have you really, my dear?'' (he)
said he (I).
``What a Dame Durden it is to read a face!'' (He)

He (I) was so quaintly cheerful that I could not long be otherwise, and was almost ashamed of having been otherwise at all. When I went to bed, I cried. I am bound to confess that I cried; but I hope it was with pleasure, though I am not quite sure it was with pleasure. I repeated every word of the letter twice over.

A most beautiful summer morning succeeded, and after breakfast we went out arm in arm to see the house of which I was to give my mighty housekeeping opinion. We entered a flower-garden by a gate in a side wall, of which he (I) had the key, and the first thing I saw was that the beds and flowers were all laid out according to the manner of my beds and flowers at home.

``You see, my dear,'' (guardian)
observed my guardian, standing still with a delighted face to watch my looks,
``knowing there could be no better plan, I borrowed yours.'' (guardian)

We went on by a pretty little orchard, where the cherries were nestling among the green leaves and the shadows of the apple-trees were sporting on the grass, to the house itself--a cottage, quite a rustic cottage of doll's rooms; but such a lovely place, so tranquil and so beautiful, with such a rich and smiling country spread around it; with water sparkling away into the distance, here all overhung with summer-growth, there turning a humming mill; at its nearest point glancing through a meadow by the cheerful town, where cricket-players were assembling in bright groups and a flag was flying from a white tent that rippled in the sweet west wind. And still, as we went through the pretty rooms, out at the little rustic verandah doors, and underneath the tiny wooden colonnades garlanded with woodbine, jasmine, and honey-suckle, I saw in the papering on the walls, in the colours of the furniture, in the arrangement of all the pretty objects, MY little tastes and fancies, MY little methods and inventions which they used to laugh at while they praised them, my odd ways everywhere.

I could not say enough in admiration of what was all so beautiful, but one secret doubt arose in my mind when I saw this, I thought, oh, would he (MY) be the happier for it! Would it not have been better for his (MY) peace that I should not have been so brought before him (MY)? Because although I was not what he (MY) thought me, still he (MY) loved me very dearly, and it might remind him (MY) mournfully of what be believed he (MY) had lost. I did not wish him (MY) to forget me--perhaps he (MY) might not have done so, without these aids to his (MY) memory--but my way was easier than his (MY), and I could have reconciled myself even to that so that he (MY) had been the happier for it.

``And now, little woman,'' (guardian)
said my guardian, whom I had never seen so proud and joyful as in showing me these things and watching my appreciation of them,
``now, last of all, for the name of this house.'' (me)

``What is it called, dear guardian?'' (unknown)

``My child,'' (he)
said he (MY),
``come and see,'' (he)

He (MY) took me to the porch, which he (MY) had hitherto avoided, and said, pausing before we went out,

``My dear child, don't you guess the name?'' (he)

``No!'' (I)
said I.

We went out of the porch and he (MY) showed me written over it, Bleak House.

He (MY) led me to a seat among the leaves close by, and sitting down beside me and taking my hand in his (MY), spoke to me thus,

``My darling girl, in what there has been between us, I have, I hope, been really solicitous for your happiness. When I wrote you the letter to which you brought the answer,'' (me)
smiling as he (MY) referred to it,
``I had my own too much in view; but I had yours too. Whether, under different circumstances, I might ever have renewed the old dream I sometimes dreamed when you were very young, of making you my wife one day, I need not ask myself. I did renew it, and I wrote my letter, and you brought your answer. You are following what I say, my child?'' (he)

I was cold, and I trembled violently, but not a word he (MY) uttered was lost. As I sat looking fixedly at him (MY) and the sun's rays descended, softly shining through the leaves upon his (MY) bare head, I felt as if the brightness on him (MY) must be like the brightness of the angels.

``Hear me, my love, but do not speak. It is for me to speak now. When it was that I began to doubt whether what I had done would really make you happy is no matter. Woodcourt came home, and I soon had no doubt at all.'' (I)

I clasped him (MY) round the neck and hung my head upon his (MY) breast and wept.

``Lie lightly, confidently here, my child,'' (he)
said he (MY), pressing me gently to him (MY).
``I am your guardian and your father now. Rest confidently here.'' (unknown)

Soothingly, like the gentle rustling of the leaves; and genially, like the ripening weather; and radiantly and beneficently, like the sunshine, he (MY) went on.

``Understand me, my dear girl. I had no doubt of your being contented and happy with me, being so dutiful and so devoted; but I saw with whom you would be happier. That I penetrated his (father) secret when Dame Durden was blind to it is no wonder, for I knew the good that could never change in her (girl) better far than she (girl) did. Well! I have long been in Allan Woodcourt's confidence, although he (Woodcourt) was not, until yesterday, a few hours before you came here, in mine. But I would not have my Esther's bright example lost; I would not have a jot of my dear girl's virtues unobserved and unhonoured; I would not have her (girl) admitted on sufferance into the line of Morgan ap-Kerrig, no, not for the weight in gold of all the mountains in Wales!'' (He)

He (MY) stopped to kiss me on the forehead, and I sobbed and wept afresh. For I felt as if I could not bear the painful delight of his (MY) praise.

``Hush, little woman! Don't cry; this is to be a day of joy. I have looked forward to it,'' (he)
he (MY) said exultingly, ``for months on months! A few words more, Dame Trot, and I have said my say. Determined not to throw away one atom of my Esther's worth, I took Mrs. Woodcourt into a separate confidence. ``Now, madam,'' said I, ``I clearly perceive--and indeed I know, to boot--that your son loves my ward. I am further very sure that my ward loves your son, but will sacrifice her (madam) love to a sense of duty and affection, and will sacrifice it so completely, so entirely, so religiously, that you should never suspect it though you watched her (madam) night and day.'' Then I told her (I) all our story--ours--yours and mine. ``Now, madam,
'' said I, `come you, knowing this, and live with us. Come you, and see my child from hour to hour; set what you see against her (I) pedigree, which is this, and this'--for I scorned to mince it--`and tell me what is the true legitimacy when you shall have quite made up your mind on that subject.'' (madam)
Why, honour to her (I) old Welsh blood, my dear,'' cried my guardian with enthusiasm,
``I believe the heart it animates beats no less warmly, no less admiringly, no less lovingly, towards Dame Durden than my own!'' (Welsh)

He (Welsh) tenderly raised my head, and as I clung to him (Welsh), kissed me in his (Welsh) old fatherly way again and again. What a light, now, on the protecting manner I had thought about!

``One more last word. When Allan Woodcourt spoke to you, my dear, he (Woodcourt) spoke with my knowledge and consent--but I gave him (Woodcourt) no encouragement, not I, for these surprises were my great reward, and I was too miserly to part with a scrap of it. He (Woodcourt) was to come and tell me all that passed, and he (Woodcourt) did. I have no more to say. My dearest, Allan Woodcourt stood beside your father when he (Woodcourt) lay dead--stood beside your mother. This is Bleak House. This day I give this house its little mistress; and before God, it is the brightest day in all my life!'' (He)

He (Welsh) rose and raised me with him (Welsh). We were no longer alone. My husband--I have called him (husband) by that name full seven happy years now--stood at my side.

``Allan,'' (guardian)
said my guardian,
``take from me a willing gift, the best wife that ever man had. What more can I say for you than that I know you deserve her (wife)! Take with her (wife) the little home she (wife) brings you. You know what she (wife) will make it, Allan; you know what she (wife) has made its namesake. Let me share its felicity sometimes, and what do I sacrifice? Nothing, nothing.'' (guardian)

He (husband) kissed me once again, and now the tears were in his (husband) eyes as he (husband) said more softly,

``Esther, my dearest, after so many years, there is a kind of parting in this too. I know that my mistake has caused you some distress. Forgive your old guardian, in restoring him (Allan) to his (Allan) old place in your affections; and blot it out of your memory. Allan, take my dear.'' (he)

He (husband) moved away from under the green roof of leaves, and stopping in the sunlight outside and turning cheerfully towards us, said,

``I shall be found about here somewhere. It's a west wind, little woman, due west! Let no one thank me any more, for I am going to revert to my bachelor habits, and if anybody disregards this warning, I'll run away and never come back!'' (He)

What happiness was ours that day, what joy, what rest, what hope, what gratitude, what bliss! We were to be married before the month was out, but when we were to come and take possession of our own house was to depend on Richard and Ada.

We all three went home together next day. As soon as we arrived in town, Allan went straight to see Richard and to carry our joyful news to him (Allan) and my darling. Late as it was, I meant to go to her (Ada) for a few minutes before lying down to sleep, but I went home with my guardian first to make his (Allan) tea for him (Allan) and to occupy the old chair by his (Allan) side, for I did not like to think of its being empty so soon.

When we came home we found that a young man had called three times in the course of that one day to see me and that having been told on the occasion of his (man) third call that I was not expected to return before ten o'clock at night, he (man) had left word that he (man) would call about then. He (man) had left his (man) card three times. Mr. Guppy.

As I naturally speculated on the object of these visits, and as I always associated something ludicrous with the visitor, it fell out that in laughing about Mr. Guppy I told my guardian of his (Mr.) old proposal and his (Mr.) subsequent retraction.

``After that,'' (guardian)
said my guardian,
``we will certainly receive this hero.'' (guardian)
So instructions were given that Mr. Guppy should be shown in when he (Guppy) came again, and they were scarcely given when he (Guppy) did come again.

He (Guppy) was embarrassed when he (Guppy) found my guardian with me, but recovered himself and said,

``How de do, sir?'' (me)

``How do you do, sir?'' (guardian)
returned my guardian.

``Thank you, sir, I am tolerable,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
returned Mr. Guppy.
``Will you allow me to introduce my mother, Mrs. Guppy of the Old Street Road, and my particular friend, Mr. Weevle. That is to say, my friend has gone by the name of Weevle, but his (Weevle) name is really and truly Jobling.'' (guardian)

My guardian begged them to be seated, and they all sat down.

``Tony,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
said Mr. Guppy to his (Guppy) friend after an awkward silence.
``Will you open the case?'' (unknown)

``Do it yourself,'' (the friend)
returned the friend rather tartly.

``Well, Mr. Jarndyce, sir,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
Mr. Guppy, after a moment's consideration, began, to the great diversion of his (Guppy) mother, which she (mother) displayed by nudging Mr. Jobling with her (mother) elbow and winking at me in a most remarkable manner,
``I had an idea that I should see Miss Summerson by herself and was not quite prepared for your esteemed presence. But Miss Summerson has mentioned to you, perhaps, that something has passed between us on former occasions?'' (me)

``Miss Summerson,'' (guardian)
returned my guardian, smiling,
