``has made a communication to that effect to me.'' (guardian)

``That,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
said Mr. Guppy,
``makes matters easier. Sir, I have come out of my articles at Kenge and Carboy's, and I believe with satisfaction to all parties. I am now admitted -LRB-after undergoing an examination that's enough to badger a man blue, touching a pack of nonsense that he (man) don't want to know-RRB- on the roll of attorneys and have taken out my certificate, if it would be any satisfaction to you to see it.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``Thank you, Mr. Guppy,'' (guardian)
returned my guardian.
``I am quite willing--I believe I use a legal phrase--to admit the certificate.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Mr. Guppy therefore desisted from taking something out of his (Guppy) pocket and proceeded without it.

``I have no capital myself, but my mother has a little property which takes the form of an annuity'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
--here Mr. Guppy's mother rolled her (mother) head as if she (mother) never could sufficiently enjoy the observation, and put her (mother) handkerchief to her (mother) mouth, and again winked at me--
``and a few pounds for expenses out of pocket in conducting business will never be wanting, free of interest, which is an advantage, you know,'' (me)
said Mr. Guppy feelingly.

``Certainly an advantage,'' (guardian)
returned my guardian.

``I HAVE some connexion,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
pursued Mr. Guppy,
``and it lays in the direction of Walcot Square, Lambeth. I have therefore taken a `ouse in that locality, which, in the opinion of my friends, is a hollow bargain -LRB-taxes ridiculous, and use of fixtures included in the rent-RRB-, and intend setting up professionally for myself there forthwith.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

Here Mr. Guppy's mother fell into an extraordinary passion of rolling her (mother) head and smiling waggishly at anybody who would look at her (mother).

``It's a six-roomer, exclusive of kitchens,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
said Mr. Guppy,
``and in the opinion of my friends, a commodious tenement. When I mention my friends, I refer principally to my friend Jobling, who I believe has known me,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
Mr. Guppy looked at him (Guppy) with a sentimental air,
``from boyhood's hour.'' (him)

Mr. Jobling confirmed this with a sliding movement of his (Jobling) legs.

``My friend Jobling will render me his (Jobling) assistance in the capacity of clerk and will live in the `ouse,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
said Mr. Guppy.
``My mother will likewise live in the `ouse when her (mother) present quarter in the Old Street Road shall have ceased and expired; and consequently there will be no want of society. My friend Jobling is naturally aristocratic by taste, and besides being acquainted with the movements of the upper circles, fully backs me in the intentions I am now developing.'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)

Mr. Jobling said

``Certainly'' (Mr. Jobling/Jobling)
and withdrew a little from the elbow of Mr Guppy's mother.

``Now, I have no occasion to mention to you, sir, you being in the confidence of Miss Summerson,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
said Mr. Guppy,
''-LRB-mother, I wish you'd be so good as to keep still-RRB-, that Miss Summerson's image was formerly imprinted on my `eart and that I made her (Summerson) a proposal of marriage.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``That I have heard,'' (guardian)
returned my guardian.

``Circumstances,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
pursued Mr. Guppy,
``over which I had no control, but quite the contrary, weakened the impression of that image for a time. At which time Miss Summerson's conduct was highly genteel; I may even add, magnanimous.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

My guardian patted me on the shoulder and seemed much amused.

``Now, sir,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
said Mr. Guppy,
``I have got into that state of mind myself that I wish for a reciprocity of magnanimous behaviour. I wish to prove to Miss Summerson that I can rise to a heighth of which perhaps she (Summerson) hardly thought me capable. I find that the image which I did suppose had been eradicated from my `eart is NOT eradicated. Its influence over me is still tremenjous, and yielding to it, I am willing to overlook the circumstances over which none of us have had any control and to renew those proposals to Miss Summerson which I had the honour to make at a former period. I beg to lay the `ouse in Walcot Square, the business, and myself before Miss Summerson for her (Summerson) acceptance.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``Very magnanimous indeed, sir,'' (guardian)
observed my guardian.

``Well, sir,'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
replied Mr. Guppy with candour,
``my wish is to BE magnanimous. I do not consider that in making this offer to Miss Summerson I am by any means throwing myself away; neither is that the opinion of my friends. Still, there are circumstances which I submit may be taken into account as a set off against any little drawbacks of mine, and so a fair and equitable balance arrived at.'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)

``I take upon myself, sir,'' (guardian)
said my guardian, laughing as he (Guppy) rang the bell,
``to reply to your proposals on behalf of Miss Summerson. She (Summerson) is very sensible of your handsome intentions, and wishes you good evening, and wishes you well.'' (he)

``Oh!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
said Mr. Guppy with a blank look.
``Is that tantamount, sir, to acceptance, or rejection, or consideration?'' (unknown)

``To decided rejection, if you please,'' (guardian)
returned my guardian.

Mr. Guppy looked incredulously at his (Guppy) friend, and at his (Guppy) mother, who suddenly turned very angry, and at the floor, and at the ceiling.

``Indeed?'' (he)
said he (Guppy).
``Then, Jobling, if you was the friend you represent yourself, I should think you might hand my mother out of the gangway instead of allowing her (mother) to remain where she (mother) ain't wanted.'' (Mrs. Guppy)

But Mrs. Guppy positively refused to come out of the gangway. She (Guppy) wouldn't hear of it.

``Why, get along with you,'' (she)
said she (Guppy) to my guardian,
``what do you mean? Ain't my son good enough for you? You ought to be ashamed of yourself. Get out with you!'' (guardian)

``My good lady,'' (guardian)
returned my guardian,
``it is hardly reasonable to ask me to get out of my own room.'' (guardian)

``I don't care for that,'' (Mrs. Guppy)
said Mrs. Guppy.
``Get out with you. If we ain't good enough for you, go and procure somebody that is good enough. Go along and find 'em.'' (I)

I was quite unprepared for the rapid manner in which Mrs. Guppy's power of jocularity merged into a power of taking the profoundest offence.

``Go along and find somebody that's good enough for you,'' (Mrs. Guppy)
repeated Mrs. Guppy.
``Get out!'' (Mr. Guppy/Guppy/William Guppy)
Nothing seemed to astonish Mr. Guppy's mother so much and to make her (mother) so very indignant as our not getting out.
``Why don't you get out?'' (Mrs. Guppy)
said Mrs. Guppy.
``What are you stopping here for?'' (unknown)

``Mother,'' (son)
interposed her (Guppy) son, always getting before her (Guppy) and pushing her (Guppy) back with one shoulder as she (Guppy) sidled at my guardian,
``WILL you hold your tongue?'' (guardian)

``No, William,'' (she)
she (Guppy) returned,
``I won't! Not unless he (William) gets out, I won't!'' (she)

However, Mr. Guppy and Mr. Jobling together closed on Mr. Guppy's mother -LRB-who began to be quite abusive-RRB- and took her (mother), very much against her (mother) will, downstairs, her (mother) voice rising a stair higher every time her (mother) figure got a stair lower, and insisting that we should immediately go and find somebody who was good enough for us, and above all things that we should get out.

CHAPTER LXV

Beginning the World

The term had commenced, and my guardian found an intimation from Mr. Kenge that the cause would come on in two days. As I had sufficient hopes of the will to be in a flutter about it, Allan and I agreed to go down to the court that morning. Richard was extremely agitated and was so weak and low, though his (Richard) illness was still of the mind, that my dear girl indeed had sore occasion to be supported. But she (girl) looked forward--a very little way now--to the help that was to come to her (girl), and never drooped.

It was at Westminster that the cause was to come on. It had come on there, I dare say, a hundred times before, but I could not divest myself of an idea that it MIGHT lead to some result now. We left home directly after breakfast to be at Westminster Hall in good time and walked down there through the lively streets--so happily and strangely it seemed!--together.

As we were going along, planning what we should do for Richard and Ada, I heard somebody calling

``Esther! My dear Esther! Esther!'' (somebody)
And there was Caddy Jellyby, with her (Ada) head out of the window of a little carriage which she (Ada) hired now to go about in to her (Ada) pupils -LRB-she (Ada) had so many-RRB-, as if she (Ada) wanted to embrace me at a hundred yards' distance. I had written her (Ada) a note to tell her (Ada) of all that my guardian had done, but had not had a moment to go and see her (Ada). Of course we turned back, and the affectionate girl was in that state of rapture, and was so overjoyed to talk about the night when she (girl) brought me the flowers, and was so determined to squeeze my face -LRB-bonnet and all-RRB- between her (girl) hands, and go on in a wild manner altogether, calling me all kinds of precious names, and telling Allan I had done I don't know what for her (girl), that I was just obliged to get into the little carriage and calm her (girl) down by letting her (girl) say and do exactly what she (girl) liked. Allan, standing at the window, was as pleased as Caddy; and I was as pleased as either of them; and I wonder that I got away as I did, rather than that I came off laughing, and red, and anything but tidy, and looking after Caddy, who looked after us out of the coach-window as long as she (girl) could see us.

This made us some quarter of an hour late, and when we came to Westminster Hall we found that the day's business was begun. Worse than that, we found such an unusual crowd in the Court of Chancery that it was full to the door, and we could neither see nor hear what was passing within. It appeared to be something droll, for occasionally there was a laugh and a cry of

``Silence!'' (unknown)
It appeared to be something interesting, for every one was pushing and striving to get nearer. It appeared to be something that made the professional gentlemen very merry, for there were several young counsellors in wigs and whiskers on the outside of the crowd, and when one of them told the others about it, they put their hands in their pockets, and quite doubled themselves up with laughter, and went stamping about the pavement of the Hall.

We asked a gentleman by us if he (gentleman) knew what cause was on. He (gentleman) told us Jarndyce and Jarndyce. We asked him (Jarndyce) if he (Jarndyce) knew what was doing in it. He (Jarndyce) said really, no he (Jarndyce) did not, nobody ever did, but as well as he (Jarndyce) could make out, it was over. Over for the day? we asked him (Jarndyce). No, he (Jarndyce) said, over for good.

Over for good!

When we heard this unaccountable answer, we looked at one another quite lost in amazement. Could it be possible that the will had set things right at last and that Richard and Ada were going to be rich? It seemed too good to be true. Alas it was!

Our suspense was short, for a break-up soon took place in the crowd, and the people came streaming out looking flushed and hot and bringing a quantity of bad air with them. Still they were all exceedingly amused and were more like people coming out from a farce or a juggler than from a court of justice. We stood aside, watching for any countenance we knew, and presently great bundles of paper began to be carried out--bundles in bags, bundles too large to be got into any bags, immense masses of papers of all shapes and no shapes, which the bearers staggered under, and threw down for the time being, anyhow, on the Hall pavement, while they went back to bring out more. Even these clerks were laughing. We glanced at the papers, and seeing Jarndyce and Jarndyce everywhere, asked an official-looking person who was standing in the midst of them whether the cause was over. Yes, he (Jarndyce) said, it was all up with it at last, and burst out laughing too.

At this juncture we perceived Mr. Kenge coming out of court with an affable dignity upon him (Kenge), listening to Mr. Vholes, who was deferential and carried his (Vholes) own bag. Mr. Vholes was the first to see us.

``Here is Miss Summerson, sir,'' (he)
he (Vholes) said.
``And Mr. Woodcourt.'' (unknown)

``Oh, indeed! Yes. Truly!'' (Mr. Kenge)
said Mr. Kenge, raising his (Kenge) hat to me with polished politeness.
``How do you do? Glad to see you. Mr. Jarndyce is not here?'' (unknown)

No. He (Kenge) never came there, I reminded him (Kenge).

``Really,'' (Mr. Kenge)
returned Mr. Kenge,
``it is as well that he (Jarndyce) is NOT here to-day, for his (Jarndyce)--shall I say, in my good friend's absence, his (Jarndyce) indomitable singularity of opinion?--might have been strengthened, perhaps; not reasonably, but might have been strengthened.'' (Mr. Kenge)

``Pray what has been done to-day?'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
asked Allan.

``I beg your pardon?'' (Mr. Kenge)
said Mr. Kenge with excessive urbanity.

``What has been done to-day?'' (unknown)

``What has been done,'' (Mr. Kenge)
repeated Mr. Kenge.
``Quite so. Yes. Why, not much has been done; not much. We have been checked--brought up suddenly, I would say--upon the--shall I term it threshold?'' (unknown)

``Is this will considered a genuine document, sir?'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
said Allan.
``Will you tell us that?'' (unknown)

``Most certainly, if I could,'' (Mr. Kenge)
said Mr. Kenge;
``but we have not gone into that, we have not gone into that.'' (Mr. Kenge)

``We have not gone into that,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
repeated Mr. Vholes as if his (Kenge) low inward voice were an echo.

``You are to reflect, Mr. Woodcourt,'' (Mr. Kenge)
observed Mr. Kenge, using his (Kenge) silver trowel persuasively and smoothingly,
``that this has been a great cause, that this has been a protracted cause, that this has been a complex cause. Jarndyce and Jarndyce has been termed, not inaptly, a monument of Chancery practice.'' (Mr. Kenge)

``And patience has sat upon it a long time,'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
said Allan.

``Very well indeed, sir,'' (Mr. Kenge)
returned Mr. Kenge with a certain condescending laugh he (Kenge) had.
``Very well! You are further to reflect, Mr. Woodcourt,'' (unknown)
becoming dignified almost to severity,
``that on the numerous difficulties, contingencies, masterly fictions, and forms of procedure in this great cause, there has been expended study, ability, eloquence, knowledge, intellect, Mr. Woodcourt, high intellect. For many years, the--a--I would say the flower of the bar, and the--a--I would presume to add, the matured autumnal fruits of the woolsack--have been lavished upon Jarndyce and Jarndyce. If the public have the benefit, and if the country have the adornment, of this great grasp, it must be paid for in money or money's worth, sir.'' (unknown)

``Mr. Kenge,'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
said Allan, appearing enlightened all in a moment.
``Excuse me, our time presses. Do I understand that the whole estate is found to have been absorbed in costs?'' (unknown)

``Hem! I believe so,'' (Mr. Kenge)
returned Mr. Kenge.
``Mr. Vholes, what do YOU say?'' (unknown)

``I believe so,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
said Mr. Vholes.

``And that thus the suit lapses and melts away?'' (unknown)

``Probably,'' (Mr. Kenge)
returned Mr. Kenge.
``Mr. Vholes?'' (unknown)

``Probably,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
said Mr. Vholes.

``My dearest life,'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
whispered Allan,
``this will break Richard's heart!'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)

There was such a shock of apprehension in his (Allan) face, and he (Allan) knew Richard so perfectly, and I too had seen so much of his (Allan) gradual decay, that what my dear girl had said to me in the fullness of her (girl) foreboding love sounded like a knell in my ears.

``In case you should be wanting Mr. C., sir,'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
said Mr. Vholes, coming after us,
``you'll find him (Mr.) in court. I left him (Mr.) there resting himself a little. Good day, sir; good day, Miss Summerson.'' (Mr. Vholes/Vholes)
As he (Vholes) gave me that slowly devouring look of his (Vholes), while twisting up the strings of his (Vholes) bag before he (Vholes) hastened with it after Mr. Kenge, the benignant shadow of whose conversational presence he (Kenge) seemed afraid to leave, he (Kenge) gave one gasp as if he (Kenge) had swallowed the last morsel of his (Kenge) client, and his (Kenge) black buttoned-up unwholesome figure glided away to the low door at the end of the Hall.

``My dear love,'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
said Allan,
``leave to me, for a little while, the charge you gave me. Go home with this intelligence and come to Ada's by and by!'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)

I would not let him (Allan) take me to a coach, but entreated him (Allan) to go to Richard without a moment's delay and leave me to do as he (Richard) wished. Hurrying home, I found my guardian and told him (Richard) gradually with what news I had returned.

``Little woman,'' (he)
said he (Richard), quite unmoved for himself,
``to have done with the suit on any terms is a greater blessing than I had looked for. But my poor young cousins!'' (he)

We talked about them all the morning and discussed what it was possible to do. In the afternoon my guardian walked with me to Symond's Inn and left me at the door. I went upstairs. When my darling heard my footsteps, she (me) came out into the small passage and threw her (me) arms round my neck, but she (me) composed herself directly and said that Richard had asked for me several times. Allan had found him (Allan) sitting in the corner of the court, she (me) told me, like a stone figure. On being roused, he (Allan) had broken away and made as if he (Allan) would have spoken in a fierce voice to the judge. He (Allan) was stopped by his (Allan) mouth being full of blood, and Allan had brought him (Allan) home.

He (Allan) was lying on a sofa with his (Allan) eyes closed when I went in. There were restoratives on the table; the room was made as airy as possible, and was darkened, and was very orderly and quiet. Allan stood behind him (Allan) watching him (Allan) gravely. His (Allan) face appeared to me to be quite destitute of colour, and now that I saw him (Allan) without his (Allan) seeing me, I fully saw, for the first time, how worn away he (Allan) was. But he (Allan) looked handsomer than I had seen him (Allan) look for many a day.

I sat down by his (Allan) side in silence. Opening his (Allan) eyes by and by, he (Allan) said in a weak voice, but with his (Allan) old smile,

``Dame Durden, kiss me, my dear!'' (he)

It was a great comfort and surprise to me to find him (Allan) in his (Allan) low state cheerful and looking forward. He (Allan) was happier, he (Allan) said, in our intended marriage than he (Allan) could find words to tell me. My husband had been a guardian angel to him (husband) and Ada, and he (husband) blessed us both and wished us all the joy that life could yield us. I almost felt as if my own heart would have broken when I saw him (husband) take my husband's hand and hold it to his (husband) breast.

We spoke of the future as much as possible, and he (husband) said several times that he (husband) must be present at our marriage if he (husband) could stand upon his (husband) feet. Ada would contrive to take him (husband), somehow, he (husband) said.

``Yes, surely, dearest Richard!'' (him)
But as my darling answered him (husband) thus hopefully, so serene and beautiful, with the help that was to come to her (Ada) so near--I knew--I knew!

It was not good for him (husband) to talk too much, and when he (husband) was silent, we were silent too. Sitting beside him (husband), I made a pretence of working for my dear, as he (husband) had always been used to joke about my being busy. Ada leaned upon his (husband) pillow, holding his (husband) head upon her (Ada) arm. He (husband) dozed often, and whenever he (husband) awoke without seeing him (husband), said first of all,

``Where is Woodcourt?'' (him)

Evening had come on when I lifted up my eyes and saw my guardian standing in the little hall.

``Who is that, Dame Durden?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
Richard asked me. The door was behind him (Richard), but he (Richard) had observed in my face that some one was there.

I looked to Allan for advice, and as he (Allan) nodded

``Yes,'' (he)
bent over Richard and told him (Richard). My guardian saw what passed, came softly by me in a moment, and laid his (Richard) hand on Richard's.
``Oh, sir,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard,
``you are a good man, you are a good man!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
and burst into tears for the first time.

My guardian, the picture of a good man, sat down in my place, keeping his (man) hand on Richard's.

``My dear Rick,'' (he)
said he (Richard),
``the clouds have cleared away, and it is bright now. We can see now. We were all bewildered, Rick, more or less. What matters! And how are you, my dear boy?'' (he)

``I am very weak, sir, but I hope I shall be stronger. I have to begin the world.'' (unknown)

``Aye, truly; well said!'' (guardian)
cried my guardian.

``I will not begin it in the old way now,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard with a sad smile.
``I have learned a lesson now, sir. It was a hard one, but you shall be assured, indeed, that I have learned it.'' (unknown)

``Well, well,'' (guardian)
said my guardian, comforting him (Richard);
``well, well, well, dear boy!'' (him)

``I was thinking, sir,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
resumed Richard,
``that there is nothing on earth I should so much like to see as their house--Dame Durden's and Woodcourt's house. If I could be removed there when I begin to recover my strength, I feel as if I should get well there sooner than anywhere.'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``Why, so have I been thinking too, Rick,'' (guardian woman)
said my guardian,
``and our little woman likewise; she (woman) and I have been talking of it this very day. I dare say her (woman) husband won't object. What do you think?'' (guardian woman)

Richard smiled and lifted up his (Richard) arm to touch him (Richard) as he (Richard) stood behind the head of the couch.

``I say nothing of Ada,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard,
``but I think of her (Ada), and have thought of her (Ada) very much. Look at her (Ada)! See her (Ada) here, sir, bending over this pillow when she (Ada) has so much need to rest upon it herself, my dear love, my poor girl!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

He (Richard) clasped her (guardian) in his (Richard) arms, and none of us spoke. He (Richard) gradually released her (guardian), and she (guardian) looked upon us, and looked up to heaven, and moved her (guardian) lips.

``When I get down to Bleak House,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard,
``I shall have much to tell you, sir, and you will have much to show me. You will go, won't you?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)

``Undoubtedly, dear Rick.'' (unknown)

``Thank you; like you, like you,'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard.
``But it's all like you. They have been telling me how you planned it and how you remembered all Esther's familiar tastes and ways. It will be like coming to the old Bleak House again.'' (unknown)

``And you will come there too, I hope, Rick. I am a solitary man now, you know, and it will be a charity to come to me. A charity to come to me, my love!'' (he)
he (Richard) repeated to Ada as he (Richard) gently passed his (Richard) hand over her (Ada) golden hair and put a lock of it to his (Richard) lips. -LRB-I think he (Richard) vowed within himself to cherish her (Ada) if she (Ada) were left alone.-RRB-

``It was a troubled dream?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard, clasping both my guardian's hands eagerly.

``Nothing more, Rick; nothing more.'' (unknown)

``And you, being a good man, can pass it as such, and forgive and pity the dreamer, and be lenient and encouraging when he (dreamer) wakes?'' (unknown)

``Indeed I can. What am I but another dreamer, Rick?'' (unknown)

``I will begin the world!'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard with a light in his (Richard) eyes.

My husband drew a little nearer towards Ada, and I saw him (Richard) solemnly lift up his (Richard) hand to warn my guardian.

``When shall I go from this place to that pleasant country where the old times are, where I shall have strength to tell what Ada has been to me, where I shall be able to recall my many faults and blindnesses, where I shall prepare myself to be a guide to my unborn child?'' (Richard/Mr. Carstone/Mr. Richard)
said Richard.
``When shall I go?'' (unknown)

``Dear Rick, when you are strong enough,'' (guardian)
returned my guardian.

``Ada, my darling!'' (He)

He (Richard) sought to raise himself a little. Allan raised him (Allan) so that she (Ada) could hold him (Allan) on her (Ada) bosom, which was what he (Allan) wanted.

``I have done you many wrongs, my own. I have fallen like a poor stray shadow on your way, I have married you to poverty and trouble, I have scattered your means to the winds. You will forgive me all this, my Ada, before I begin the world?'' (she)

A smile irradiated his (Allan) face as she (Ada) bent to kiss him (Allan). He (Allan) slowly laid his (Allan) face down upon her (Ada) bosom, drew his (Allan) arms closer round her (Ada) neck, and with one parting sob began the world. Not this world, oh, not this! The world that sets this right.

When all was still, at a late hour, poor crazed Miss Flite came weeping to me and told me she (Ada) had given her (Ada) birds their liberty.

CHAPTER LXVI

Down in Lincolnshire

There is a hush upon Chesney Wold in these altered days, as there is upon a portion of the family history. The story goes that Sir Leicester paid some who could have spoken out to hold their peace; but it is a lame story, feebly whispering and creeping about, and any brighter spark of life it shows soon dies away. It is known for certain that the handsome Lady Dedlock lies in the mausoleum in the park, where the trees arch darkly overhead, and the owl is heard at night making the woods ring; but whence she (Lady) was brought home to be laid among the echoes of that solitary place, or how she (Lady) died, is all mystery. Some of her (Lady) old friends, principally to be found among the peachy-cheeked charmers with the skeleton throats, did once occasionally say, as they toyed in a ghastly manner with large fans--like charmers reduced to flirting with grim death, after losing all their other beaux--did once occasionally say, when the world assembled together, that they wondered the ashes of the Dedlocks, entombed in the mausoleum, never rose against the profanation of her (Lady) company. But the dead-and-gone Dedlocks take it very calmly and have never been known to object.

Up from among the fern in the hollow, and winding by the bridle-road among the trees, comes sometimes to this lonely spot the sound of horses' hoofs. Then may be seen Sir Leicester--invalided, bent, and almost blind, but of worthy presence yet--riding with a stalwart man beside him (man), constant to his (man) bridle-rein. When they come to a certain spot before the mausoleum-door, Sir Leicester's accustomed horse stops of his (man) own accord, and Sir Leicester, pulling off his (man) hat, is still for a few moments before they ride away.

War rages yet with the audacious Boythorn, though at uncertain intervals, and now hotly, and now coolly, flickering like an unsteady fire. The truth is said to be that when Sir Leicester came down to Lincolnshire for good, Mr. Boythorn showed a manifest desire to abandon his (Boythorn) right of way and do whatever Sir Leicester would, which Sir Leicester, conceiving to be a condescension to his (Boythorn) illness or misfortune, took in such high dudgeon, and was so magnificently aggrieved by, that Mr. Boythorn found himself under the necessity of committing a flagrant trespass to restore his (Boythorn) neighbour to himself. Similarly, Mr. Boythorn continues to post tremendous placards on the disputed thoroughfare and -LRB-with his (Boythorn) bird upon his (Boythorn) head-RRB- to hold forth vehemently against Sir Leicester in the sanctuary of his (Boythorn) own home; similarly, also, he (Boythorn) defies him (Boythorn) as of old in the little church by testifying a bland unconsciousness of his (Boythorn) existence. But it is whispered that when he (Boythorn) is most ferocious towards his (Boythorn) old foe, he (Boythorn) is really most considerate, and that Sir Leicester, in the dignity of being implacable, little supposes how much he (Boythorn) is humoured. As little does he (Boythorn) think how near together he (Boythorn) and his (Boythorn) antagonist have suffered in the fortunes of two sisters, and his (Boythorn) antagonist, who knows it now, is not the man to tell him (Boythorn). So the quarrel goes on to the satisfaction of both.

In one of the lodges of the park--that lodge within sight of the house where, once upon a time, when the waters were out down in Lincolnshire, my Lady used to see the keeper's child--the stalwart man, the trooper formerly, is housed. Some relics of his (man) old calling hang upon the walls, and these it is the chosen recreation of a little lame man about the stable-yard to keep gleaming bright. A busy little man he (man) always is, in the polishing at harness-house doors, of stirrup-irons, bits, curb-chains, harness bosses, anything in the way of a stable-yard that will take a polish, leading a life of friction. A shaggy little damaged man, withal, not unlike an old dog of some mongrel breed, who has been considerably knocked about. He (man) answers to the name of Phil.

A goodly sight it is to see the grand old housekeeper -LRB-harder of hearing now-RRB- going to church on the arm of her (housekeeper) son and to observe--which few do, for the house is scant of company in these times--the relations of both towards Sir Leicester, and his (son) towards them. They have visitors in the high summer weather, when a grey cloak and umbrella, unknown to Chesney Wold at other periods, are seen among the leaves; when two young ladies are occasionally found gambolling in sequestered saw-pits and such nooks of the park; and when the smoke of two pipes wreathes away into the fragrant evening air from the trooper's door. Then is a fife heard trolling within the lodge on the inspiring topic of the

``British Grenadiers'' (men)
; and as the evening closes in, a gruff inflexible voice is heard to say, while two men pace together up and down,
``But I never own to it before the old girl. Discipline must be maintained.'' (men)

The greater part of the house is shut up, and it is a show-house no longer; yet Sir Leicester holds his (trooper) shrunken state in the long drawing-room for all that, and reposes in his (trooper) old place before my Lady's picture. Closed in by night with broad screens, and illumined only in that part, the light of the drawing-room seems gradually contracting and dwindling until it shall be no more. A little more, in truth, and it will be all extinguished for Sir Leicester; and the damp door in the mausoleum which shuts so tight, and looks so obdurate, will have opened and received him (trooper).

Volumnia, growing with the flight of time pinker as to the red in her (Lady) face, and yellower as to the white, reads to Sir Leicester in the long evenings and is driven to various artifices to conceal her (Lady) yawns, of which the chief and most efficacious is the insertion of the pearl necklace between her (Lady) rosy lips. Long-winded treatises on the Buffy and Boodle question, showing how Buffy is immaculate and Boodle villainous, and how the country is lost by being all Boodle and no Buffy, or saved by being all Buffy and no Boodle -LRB-it must be one of the two, and cannot be anything else-RRB-, are the staple of her (Buffy) reading. Sir Leicester is not particular what it is and does not appear to follow it very closely, further than that he (chief) always comes broad awake the moment Volumnia ventures to leave off, and sonorously repeating her (Buffy) last words, begs with some displeasure to know if she (Buffy) finds herself fatigued. However, Volumnia, in the course of her (Buffy) bird-like hopping about and pecking at papers, has alighted on a memorandum concerning herself in the event of

``anything happening'' (kinsman compensation)
to her (Buffy) kinsman, which is handsome compensation for an extensive course of reading and holds even the dragon Boredom at bay.

The cousins generally are rather shy of Chesney Wold in its dullness, but take to it a little in the shooting season, when guns are heard in the plantations, and a few scattered beaters and keepers wait at the old places of appointment for low-spirited twos and threes of cousins. The debilitated cousin, more debilitated by the dreariness of the place, gets into a fearful state of depression, groaning under penitential sofa-pillows in his (cousin) gunless hours and protesting that such fernal old jail's--nough t`sew fler up--frever.

The only great occasions for Volumnia in this changed aspect of the place in Lincolnshire are those occasions, rare and widely separated, when something is to be done for the county or the country in the way of gracing a public ball. Then, indeed, does the tuckered sylph come out in fairy form and proceed with joy under cousinly escort to the exhausted old assembly-room, fourteen heavy miles off, which, during three hundred and sixty-four days and nights of every ordinary year, is a kind of antipodean lumber-room full of old chairs and tables upside down. Then, indeed, does she (fairy) captivate all hearts by her (fairy) condescension, by her (fairy) girlish vivacity, and by her (fairy) skipping about as in the days when the hideous old general with the mouth too full of teeth had not cut one of them at two guineas each. Then does she (fairy) twirl and twine, a pastoral nymph of good family, through the mazes of the dance. Then do the swains appear with tea, with lemonade, with sandwiches, with homage. Then is she (fairy) kind and cruel, stately and unassuming, various, beautifully wilful. Then is there a singular kind of parallel between her (fairy) and the little glass chandeliers of another age embellishing that assembly-room, which, with their meagre stems, their spare little drops, their disappointing knobs where no drops are, their bare little stalks from which knobs and drops have both departed, and their little feeble prismatic twinkling, all seem Volumnias.

For the rest, Lincolnshire life to Volumnia is a vast blank of overgrown house looking out upon trees, sighing, wringing their hands, bowing their heads, and casting their tears upon the window-panes in monotonous depressions. A labyrinth of grandeur, less the property of an old family of human beings and their ghostly likenesses than of an old family of echoings and thunderings which start out of their hundred graves at every sound and go resounding through the building. A waste of unused passages and staircases in which to drop a comb upon a bedroom floor at night is to send a stealthy footfall on an errand through the house. A place where few people care to go about alone, where a maid screams if an ash drops from the fire, takes to crying at all times and seasons, becomes the victim of a low disorder of the spirits, and gives warning and departs.

Thus Chesney Wold. With so much of itself abandoned to darkness and vacancy; with so little change under the summer shining or the wintry lowering; so sombre and motionless always--no flag flying now by day, no rows of lights sparkling by night; with no family to come and go, no visitors to be the souls of pale cold shapes of rooms, no stir of life about it--passion and pride, even to the stranger's eye, have died away from the place in Lincolnshire and yielded it to dull repose.

CHAPTER LXVII

The Close of Esther's Narrative

Full seven happy years I have been the mistress of Bleak House. The few words that I have to add to what I have written are soon penned; then I and the unknown friend to whom I write will part for ever. Not without much dear remembrance on my side. Not without some, I hope, on his (friend) or hers.

They gave my darling into my arms, and through many weeks I never left her (mistress). The little child who was to have done so much was born before the turf was planted on its father's grave. It was a boy; and I, my husband, and my guardian gave him (boy) his (boy) father's name.

The help that my dear counted on did come to her (mistress), though it came, in the eternal wisdom, for another purpose. Though to bless and restore his (boy) mother, not his (boy) father, was the errand of this baby, its power was mighty to do it. When I saw the strength of the weak little hand and how its touch could heal my darling's heart and raised hope within her (mother), I felt a new sense of the goodness and the tenderness of God.

They throve, and by degrees I saw my dear girl pass into my country garden and walk there with her (girl) infant in her (girl) arms. I was married then. I was the happiest of the happy.

It was at this time that my guardian joined us and asked Ada when she (Ada) would come home.

``Both houses are your home, my dear,'' (he)
said he (God),
``but the older Bleak House claims priority. When you and my boy are strong enough to do it, come and take possession of your home.'' (he)

Ada called him (God)

``her (girl) dearest cousin, John.'' (him)
But he (God) said, no, it must be guardian now. He (God) was her (Ada) guardian henceforth, and the boy's; and he (God) had an old association with the name. So she (Ada) called him (God) guardian, and has called him (God) guardian ever since. The children know him (God) by no other name. I say the children; I have two little daughters.

It is difficult to believe that Charley -LRB-round-eyed still, and not at all grammatical-RRB- is married to a miller in our neighbourhood; yet so it is; and even now, looking up from my desk as I write early in the morning at my summer window, I see the very mill beginning to go round. I hope the miller will not spoil Charley; but he (Charley) is very fond of her (our), and Charley is rather vain of such a match, for he (Charley) is well to do and was in great request. So far as my small maid is concerned, I might suppose time to have stood for seven years as still as the mill did half an hour ago, since little Emma, Charley's sister, is exactly what Charley used to be. As to Tom, Charley's brother, I am really afraid to say what he (Charley) did at school in ciphering, but I think it was decimals. He (Charley) is apprenticed to the miller, whatever it was, and is a good bashful fellow, always falling in love with somebody and being ashamed of it.

Caddy Jellyby passed her (Jellyby) very last holidays with us and was a dearer creature than ever, perpetually dancing in and out of the house with the children as if she (Jellyby) had never given a dancing-lesson in her (Jellyby) life. Caddy keeps her (Jellyby) own little carriage now instead of hiring one, and lives full two miles further westward than Newman Street. She (Jellyby) works very hard, her (Jellyby) husband -LRB-an excellent one-RRB- being lame and able to do very little. Still, she (Jellyby) is more than contented and does all she (Jellyby) has to do with all her (Jellyby) heart. Mr. Jellyby spends his (Jellyby) evenings at her (Jellyby) new house with his (Jellyby) head against the wall as he (Jellyby) used to do in her (Jellyby) old one. I have heard that Mrs. Jellyby was understood to suffer great mortification from her (Jellyby) daughter's ignoble marriage and pursuits, but I hope she (Jellyby) got over it in time. She (Jellyby) has been disappointed in Borrioboola-Gha, which turned out a failure in consequence of the king of Borrioboola wanting to sell everybody--who survived the climate--for rum, but she (Jellyby) has taken up with the rights of women to sit in Parliament, and Caddy tells me it is a mission involving more correspondence than the old one. I had almost forgotten Caddy's poor little girl. She (girl) is not such a mite now, but she (girl) is deaf and dumb. I believe there never was a better mother than Caddy, who learns, in her (mother) scanty intervals of leisure, innumerable deaf and dumb arts to soften the affliction of her (mother) child.

As if I were never to have done with Caddy, I am reminded here of Peepy and old Mr. Turveydrop. Peepy is in the Custom House, and doing extremely well. Old Mr. Turveydrop, very apoplectic, still exhibits his (Turveydrop) deportment about town, still enjoys himself in the old manner, is still believed in in the old way. He (Turveydrop) is constant in his (Turveydrop) patronage of Peepy and is understood to have bequeathed him (Turveydrop) a favourite French clock in his (Turveydrop) dressing-room--which is not his (Turveydrop) property.

With the first money we saved at home, we added to our pretty house by throwing out a little growlery expressly for my guardian, which we inaugurated with great splendour the next time he (Turveydrop) came down to see us. I try to write all this lightly, because my heart is full in drawing to an end, but when I write of him (Turveydrop), my tears will have their way.

I never look at him (Turveydrop) but I hear our poor dear Richard calling him (Richard) a good man. To Ada and her (Ada) pretty boy, he (Richard) is the fondest father; to me he (Richard) is what he (Richard) has ever been, and what name can I give to that? He (Richard) is my husband's best and dearest friend, he (Richard) is our children's darling, he (Richard) is the object of our deepest love and veneration. Yet while I feel towards him (Richard) as if he (Richard) were a superior being, I am so familiar with him (Richard) and so easy with him (Richard) that I almost wonder at myself. I have never lost my old names, nor has he (Richard) lost his (Richard); nor do I ever, when he (Richard) is with us, sit in any other place than in my old chair at his (Richard) side, Dame Trot, Dame Durden, Little Woman--all just the same as ever; and I answer,

``Yes, dear guardian!'' (I)
just the same.

I have never known the wind to be in the east for a single moment since the day when he (Durden) took me to the porch to read the name. I remarked to him (Durden) once that the wind seemed never in the east now, and he (Durden) said, no, truly; it had finally departed from that quarter on that very day.

I think my darling girl is more beautiful than ever. The sorrow that has been in her (girl) face--for it is not there now--seems to have purified even its innocent expression and to have given it a diviner quality. Sometimes when I raise my eyes and see her (girl) in the black dress that she (girl) still wears, teaching my Richard, I feel--it is difficult to express--as if it were so good to know that she (girl) remembers her (girl) dear Esther in her (girl) prayers.

I call him (Richard) my Richard! But he (Richard) says that he (Richard) has two mamas, and I am one.

We are not rich in the bank, but we have always prospered, and we have quite enough. I never walk out with my husband but I hear the people bless him (husband). I never go into a house of any degree but I hear his (husband) praises or see them in grateful eyes. I never lie down at night but I know that in the course of that day he (husband) has alleviated pain and soothed some fellow-creature in the time of need. I know that from the beds of those who were past recovery, thanks have often, often gone up, in the last hour, for his (husband) patient ministration. Is not this to be rich?

The people even praise me as the doctor's wife. The people even like me as I go about, and make so much of me that I am quite abashed. I owe it all to him (doctor), my love, my pride! They like me for his (doctor) sake, as I do everything I do in life for his (doctor) sake.

A night or two ago, after bustling about preparing for my darling and my guardian and little Richard, who are coming to-morrow, I was sitting out in the porch of all places, that dearly memorable porch, when Allan came home. So he (Allan) said,

``My precious little woman, what are you doing here?'' (he)
And I said,
``The moon is shining so brightly, Allan, and the night is so delicious, that I have been sitting here thinking.'' (I)

``What have you been thinking about, my dear?'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
said Allan then.

``How curious you are!'' (I.)
said I.
``I am almost ashamed to tell you, but I will. I have been thinking about my old looks--such as they were.'' (I.)

``And what have you been thinking about THEM, my busy bee?'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
said Allan.

``I have been thinking that I thought it was impossible that you COULD have loved me any better, even if I had retained them.'' (unknown)

''`Such as they were'?'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
said Allan, laughing.

``Such as they were, of course.'' (unknown)

``My dear Dame Durden,'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)
said Allan, drawing my arm through his (Allan),
``do you ever look in the glass?'' (Mr. Woodcourt/Allan/Allan Woodcourt)

``You know I do; you see me do it.'' (unknown)

``And don't you know that you are prettier than you ever were?'' (unknown)

``I did not know that; I am not certain that I know it now. But I know that my dearest little pets are very pretty, and that my darling is very beautiful, and that my husband is very handsome, and that my guardian has the brightest and most benevolent face that ever was seen, and that they can very well do without much beauty in me--even supposing--.'' (unknown)

***END OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK BLEAK HOUSE***
